<Chemical>The reports illustrate the need for clinicians to consider acetaminophen in patients with hypotension of unknown origin.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Adverse effects of the atypical antipsychotics. Collaborative Working Group on Clinical Trial Evaluations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Adverse effects of antipsychotics often lead to noncompliance.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Thus, clinicians should address patients' concerns about adverse effects and attempt to choose medications that will improve their patients' quality of life as well as overall health.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The side effect profiles of the atypical antipsychotics are more advantageous than those of the conventional neuroleptics.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Conventional agents are associated with unwanted central nervous system effects, including extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), tardive dyskinesia, sedation, and possible impairment of some cognitive measures, as well as cardiac effects, orthostatic hypotension, hepatic changes, anticholinergic side effects, sexual dysfunction, and weight gain.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The newer atypical agents have a lower risk of EPS, but are associated in varying degrees with sedation, cardiovascular effects, anticholinergic effects, weight gain, sexual dysfunction, hepatic effects, lowered seizure threshold (primarily clozapine), and agranulocytosis (clozapine only).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since the incidence and severity of specific adverse effects differ among the various atypicals, the clinician should carefully consider which side effects are most likely to lead to the individual's dissatisfaction and noncompliance before choosing an antipsychotic for a particular patient.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Tetrandrine (TET) and fangchinoline (FAN) are two naturally occurring analogues with a bisbenzylisoquinoline structure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was undertaken to investigate the effects of TET and FAN on the experimental thrombosis induced by collagen plus epinephrine (EP) in mice, and platelet aggregation and blood coagulation in vitro.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the in vivo study, the administration (50 mg/kg, i.p.) of TET and FAN in mice showed the inhibition of thrombosis by 55% and 35%, respectively, while acetylsalicylic acid (ASA, 50 mg/kg, i.p.), a positive control, showed only 30% inhibition.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the vitro human platelet aggregations induced by the agonists used in tests, TET and FAN showed the inhibitions dose dependently.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, neither TET nor FAN showed any anticoagulation activities in the measurement of the activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), prothrombin time (PT) and thrombin time (TT) using human-citrated plasma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that antithrombosis of TET and FAN in mice may be mainly related to the antiplatelet aggregation activities.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Gemcitabine plus vinorelbine in nonsmall cell lung carcinoma patients age 70 years or older or patients who cannot receive cisplatin. Oncopaz Cooperative Group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although the prevalence of nonsmall cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) is high among elderly patients, few data are available regarding the efficacy and toxicity of chemotherapy in this group of patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Recent reports indicate that single agent therapy with vinorelbine (VNB) or gemcitabine (GEM) may obtain a response rate of 20-30% in elderly patients, with acceptable toxicity and improvement in symptoms and quality of life.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the current study the efficacy and toxicity of the combination of GEM and VNB in elderly patients with advanced NSCLC or those with some contraindication to receiving cisplatin were assessed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Forty-nine patients with advanced NSCLC were included, 38 of whom were age >/= 70 years and 11 were age < 70 years but who had some contraindication to receiving cisplatin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All patients were evaluable for response and toxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment was comprised of VNB, 25 mg/m(2), plus GEM, 1000 mg/m(2), both on Days 1, 8, and 15 every 28 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients received a minimum of three courses unless progressive disease was detected.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: One hundred sixty-five courses were administered, with a median of 3. 6 courses per patient.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The overall response rate was 26% (95% confidence interval, 15-41%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two patients attained a complete response (4%) and 11 patients (22%) achieved a partial response.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status improved in 35% of those patients with an initial value > 0, whereas relief of at least 1 symptom without worsening of other symptoms was noted in 27 patients (55%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The median time to progression was 16 weeks and the 1-year survival rate was 33%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Toxicity was mild.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Six patients (12%) had World Health Organization Grade 3-4 neutropenia, 2 patients (4%) had Grade 3-4 thrombocytopenia, and 2 patients (4%) had Grade 3 neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Three patients with severe neutropenia (6%) died of sepsis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The median age of those patients developing Grade 3-4 neutropenia was significantly higher than that of the remaining patients (75 years vs. 72 years; P = 0.047).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The combination of GEM and VNB is moderately active and well tolerated except in patients age >/= 75 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This age group had an increased risk of myelosuppression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Therefore the prophylactic use of granulocyte-colony stimulating factor should be considered with this treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>New chemotherapy combinations with higher activity and lower toxicity are needed for elderly patients with advanced NSCLC.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Warfarin-induced artery calcification is accelerated by growth and vitamin D.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present studies demonstrate that growth and vitamin D treatment enhance the extent of artery calcification in rats given sufficient doses of Warfarin to inhibit gamma-carboxylation of matrix Gla protein, a calcification inhibitor known to be expressed by smooth muscle cells and macrophages in the artery wall.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The first series of experiments examined the influence of age and growth status on artery calcification in Warfarin-treated rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment for 2 weeks with Warfarin caused massive focal calcification of the artery media in 20-day-old rats and less extensive focal calcification in 42-day-old rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, no artery calcification could be detected in 10-month-old adult rats even after 4 weeks of Warfarin treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To directly examine the importance of growth to Warfarin-induced artery calcification in animals of the same age, 20-day-old rats were fed for 2 weeks either an ad libitum diet or a 6-g/d restricted diet that maintains weight but prevents growth.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Concurrent treatment of both dietary groups with Warfarin produced massive focal calcification of the artery media in the ad libitum-fed rats but no detectable artery calcification in the restricted-diet, growth-inhibited group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although the explanation for the association between artery calcification and growth status cannot be determined from the present study, there was a relationship between higher serum phosphate and susceptibility to artery calcification, with 30% higher levels of serum phosphate in young, ad libitum-fed rats compared with either of the groups that was resistant to Warfarin-induced artery calcification, ie, the 10-month-old rats and the restricted-diet, growth-inhibited young rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This observation suggests that increased susceptibility to Warfarin-induced artery calcification could be related to higher serum phosphate levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The second set of experiments examined the possible synergy between vitamin D and Warfarin in artery calcification.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>High doses of vitamin D are known to cause calcification of the artery media in as little as 3 to 4 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>High doses of the vitamin K antagonist Warfarin are also known to cause calcification of the artery media, but at treatment times of 2 weeks or longer yet not at 1 week.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the current study, we investigated the synergy between these 2 treatments and found that concurrent Warfarin administration dramatically increased the extent of calcification in the media of vitamin D-treated rats at 3 and 4 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was a close parallel between the effect of vitamin D dose on artery calcification and the effect of vitamin D dose on the elevation of serum calcium, which suggests that vitamin D may induce artery calcification through its effect on serum calcium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because Warfarin treatment had no effect on the elevation in serum calcium produced by vitamin D, the synergy between Warfarin and vitamin D is probably best explained by the hypothesis that Warfarin inhibits the activity of matrix Gla protein as a calcification inhibitor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>High levels of matrix Gla protein are found at sites of artery calcification in rats treated with vitamin D plus Warfarin, and chemical analysis showed that the protein that accumulated was indeed not gamma-carboxylated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These observations indicate that although the gamma-carboxyglutamate residues of matrix Gla protein are apparently required for its function as a calcification inhibitor, they are not required for its accumulation at calcification sites.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antidepressant-induced mania in bipolar patients: identification of risk factors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Concerns about possible risks of switching to mania associated with antidepressants continue to interfere with the establishment of an optimal treatment paradigm for bipolar depression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The response of 44 patients meeting DSM-IV criteria for bipolar disorder to naturalistic treatment was assessed for at least 6 weeks using the Montgomery-Asberg Depression Rating Scale and the Bech-Rafaelson Mania Rating Scale.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients who experienced a manic or hypomanic switch were compared with those who did not on several variables including age, sex, diagnosis (DSM-IV bipolar I vs. bipolar II), number of previous manic episodes, type of antidepressant therapy used (electroconvulsive therapy vs. antidepressant drugs and, more particularly, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>[SSRIs]), use and type of mood stabilizers (lithium vs. anticonvulsants), and temperament of the patient, assessed during a normothymic period using the hyperthymia component of the Semi-structured Affective Temperament Interview. RESULTS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Switches to hypomania or mania occurred in 27% of all patients (N = 12) (and in 24% of the subgroup of patients treated with SSRIs [8/33]); 16% (N = 7) experienced manic episodes, and 11% (N = 5) experienced hypomanic episodes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sex, age, diagnosis (bipolar I vs. bipolar II), and additional treatment did not affect the risk of switching.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of mood switches seemed not to differ between patients receiving an anticonvulsant and those receiving no mood stabilizer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, mood switches were less frequent in patients receiving lithium (15%, 4/26) than in patients not treated with lithium (44%, 8/18; p = .04).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The number of previous manic episodes did not affect the probability of switching, whereas a high score on the hyperthymia component of the Semistructured Affective Temperament Interview was associated with a greater risk of switching (p = .008).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION: The frequency of mood switching associated with acute antidepressant therapy may be reduced by lithium treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Particular attention should be paid to patients with a hyperthymic temperament, who have a greater risk of mood switches.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Bladder retention of urine as a result of continuous intravenous infusion of fentanyl: 2 case reports.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sedation has been commonly used in the neonate to decrease the stress and pain from the noxious stimuli and invasive procedures in the neonatal intensive care unit, as well as to facilitate synchrony between ventilator and spontaneous breaths.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fentanyl, an opioid analgesic, is frequently used in the neonatal intensive care unit setting for these very purposes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Various reported side effects of fentanyl administration include chest wall rigidity, hypotension, respiratory depression, and bradycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here, 2 cases of urinary bladder retention leading to renal pelvocalyceal dilatation mimicking hydronephrosis as a result of continuous infusion of fentanyl are reported.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Combined antiretroviral therapy causes cardiomyopathy and elevates plasma lactate in transgenic AIDS mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is implicated in cardiomyopathy (CM) and in elevated plasma lactate (LA) in AIDS through mechanisms of mitochondrial dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To determine mitochondrial events from HAART in vivo, 8-week-old hemizygous transgenic AIDS mice (NL4-3Delta gag/pol; TG) and wild-type FVB/n littermates were treated with the HAART combination of zidovudine, lamivudine, and indinavir or vehicle control for 10 days or 35 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>At termination of the experiments, mice underwent echocardiography, quantitation of abundance of molecular markers of CM (ventricular mRNA encoding atrial natriuretic factor</Chemical>
<Chemical>[ANF] and sarcoplasmic calcium ATPase [SERCA2]), and determination of plasma LA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Myocardial histologic features were analyzed semiquantitatively and results were confirmed by transmission electron microscopy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After 35 days in the TG + HAART cohort, left ventricular mass increased 160% by echocardiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Molecularly, ANF mRNA increased 250% and SERCA2 mRNA decreased 57%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Biochemically, LA was elevated (8.5 +/- 2.0 mM).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pathologically, granular cytoplasmic changes were found in cardiac myocytes, indicating enlarged, damaged mitochondria.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Findings were confirmed ultrastructurally.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No changes were found in other cohorts.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After 10 days, only ANF was elevated, and only in the TG +</Chemical>
<Chemical>HAART cohort.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Results show that cumulative HAART caused mitochondrial CM with elevated LA in AIDS transgenic mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oral contraceptives and the risk of myocardial infarction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>An association between the use of oral contraceptives and the risk of myocardial infarction has been found in some, but not all, studies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We investigated this association, according to the type of progestagen included in third-generation (i.e., desogestrel or gestodene) and second-generation (i.e., levonorgestrel) oral contraceptives, the dose of estrogen, and the presence or absence of prothrombotic mutations METHODS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a nationwide, population-based, case-control study, we identified and enrolled 248 women 18 through 49 years of age who had had a first myocardial infarction between 1990 and 1995 and 925 control women who had not had a myocardial infarction and who were matched for age, calendar year of the index event, and area of residence.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Subjects supplied information on oral-contraceptive use and major cardiovascular risk factors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An analysis for factor V Leiden and the G20210A mutation in the prothrombin gene was conducted in 217 patients and 763 controls RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The odds ratio for myocardial infarction among women who used any type of combined oral contraceptive, as compared with nonusers, was 2.0 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.5 to 2.8).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The adjusted odds ratio was 2.5 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.5 to 4.1) among women who used second-generation oral contraceptives and 1.3 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.7 to 2.5) among those who used third-generation oral contraceptives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among women who used oral contraceptives, the odds ratio was 2.1 (95 percent confidence interval, 1.5 to 3.0) for those without a prothrombotic mutation and 1.9 (95 percent confidence interval, 0.6 to 5.5) for those with a mutation CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The risk of myocardial infarction was increased among women who used second-generation oral contraceptives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results with respect to the use of third-generation oral contraceptives were inconclusive but suggested that the risk was lower than the risk associated with second-generation oral contraceptives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The risk of myocardial infarction was similar among women who used oral contraceptives whether or not they had a prothrombotic mutation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effects of 5-HT1B receptor ligands microinjected into the accumbal shell or core on the cocaine-induced locomotor hyperactivity in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was designed to examine the effect of 5-HT1B receptor ligands microinjected into the subregions of the nucleus accumbens (the shell and the core) on the locomotor hyperactivity induced by cocaine in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male Wistar rats were implanted bilaterally with cannulae into the accumbens shell or core, and then were locally injected with GR 55562 (an antagonist of 5-HT1B receptors) or CP 93129 (an agonist of 5-HT1B receptors).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Given alone to any accumbal subregion, GR 55562 (0.1-10 microg/side) or CP 93129 (0.1-10 microg/side) did not change basal locomotor activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Systemic cocaine (10 mg/kg) significantly increased the locomotor activity of rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>GR 55562 (0.1-10 microg/side), administered intra-accumbens shell prior to cocaine, dose-dependently attenuated the psychostimulant-induced locomotor hyperactivity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Such attenuation was not found in animals which had been injected with GR 55562 into the accumbens core.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When injected into the accumbens shell (but not the core) before cocaine, CP 93129 (0.1-10 microg/side) enhanced the locomotor response to cocaine; the maximum effect being observed after 10 microg/side of the agonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The later enhancement was attenuated after intra-accumbens shell treatment with GR 55562 (1 microg/side).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our findings indicate that cocaine induced hyperlocomotion is modified by 5-HT1B receptor ligands microinjected into the accumbens shell, but not core, this modification consisting in inhibitory and facilitatory effects of the 5-HT1B receptor antagonist (GR 55562) and agonist (CP 93129), respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In other words, the present results suggest that the accumbal shell 5-HT1B receptors play a permissive role in the behavioural response to the psychostimulant.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ticlopidine-induced cholestatic hepatitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report 2 cases of ticlopidine-induced cholestatic hepatitis, investigate its mechanism, and compare the observed main characteristics with those of the published cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE SUMMARIES: Two patients developed prolonged cholestatic hepatitis after receiving ticlopidine following percutaneous coronary angioplasty, with complete remission during the follow-up period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>T-cell stimulation by therapeutic concentration of ticlopidine was demonstrated in vitro in the patients, but not in healthy controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cholestatic hepatitis is a rare complication of the antiplatelet agent ticlopidine; several cases have been reported but few in the English literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our patients developed jaundice following treatment with ticlopidine and showed the clinical and laboratory characteristics of cholestatic hepatitis, which resolved after discontinuation of the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hepatitis may develop weeks after discontinuation of the drug and may run a prolonged course, but complete remission was observed in all reported cases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An objective causality assessment revealed that the adverse drug event was probably related to the use of ticlopidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanisms of this ticlopidine-induced cholestasis are unclear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immune mechanisms may be involved in the drug's hepatotoxicity, as suggested by the T-cell stimulation study reported here.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cholestatic hepatitis is a rare adverse effect of ticlopidine that may be immune mediated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients receiving the drug should be monitored with liver function tests along with complete blood cell counts.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This complication will be observed even less often in the future as ticlopidine is being replaced by the newer antiplatelet agent clopidogrel.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) subunit mRNA and protein expression in rats with puromycin aminonucleoside-induced nephrotic syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In experimental nephrotic syndrome, urinary sodium excretion is decreased during the early phase of the disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The molecular mechanism(s) leading to salt retention has not been completely elucidated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The rate-limiting constituent of collecting duct sodium transport is the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We examined the abundance of ENaC subunit mRNAs and proteins in puromycin aminonucleoside (PAN)-induced nephrotic syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The time courses of urinary sodium excretion, plasma aldosterone concentration and proteinuria were studied in male Sprague-Dawley rats treated with a single dose of either PAN or vehicle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The relative amounts of alphaENaC, betaENaC and gammaENaC mRNAs were determined in kidneys from these rats by real-time quantitative TaqMan PCR, and the amounts of proteins by Western blot.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The kinetics of urinary sodium excretion and the appearance of proteinuria were comparable with those reported previously.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sodium retention occurred on days 2, 3 and 6 after PAN injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant up-regulation of alphaENaC and betaENaC mRNA abundance on days 1 and 2 preceded sodium retention on days 2 and 3.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Conversely, down-regulation of alphaENaC, betaENaC and gammaENaC mRNA expression on day 3 occurred in the presence of high aldosterone concentrations, and was followed by a return of sodium excretion to control values.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The amounts of alphaENaC, betaENaC and gammaENaC proteins were not increased during PAN-induced sodium retention.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, ENaC mRNA expression, especially alphaENaC, is increased in the very early phase of the experimental model of PAN-induced nephrotic syndrome in rats, but appears to escape from the regulation by aldosterone after day 3.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>NO-induced migraine attack: strong increase in plasma calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) concentration and negative correlation with platelet serotonin release.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of the present study was to investigate changes in the plasma calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) concentration and platelet serotonin (5-hydroxytriptamine, 5-HT) content during the immediate headache and the delayed genuine migraine attack provoked by nitroglycerin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifteen female migraineurs (without aura) and eight controls participated in the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sublingual nitroglycerin (0.5 mg) was administered.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Blood was collected from the antecubital vein four times: 60 min before and after the nitroglycerin application, and 60 and 120 min after the beginning of the migraine attack (mean 344 and 404 min; 12 subjects).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In those subjects who had no migraine attack (11 subjects) a similar time schedule was used.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Plasma CGRP concentration increased significantly (P<0.01) during the migraine attack and returned to baseline after the cessation of the migraine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, both change and peak, showed significant positive correlations with migraine headache intensity (P<0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, plasma CGRP concentrations failed to change during immediate headache and in the subjects with no migraine attack.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Basal CGRP concentration was significantly higher and platelet 5-HT content tended to be lower in subjects who experienced a migraine attack.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Platelet serotonin content decreased significantly (P<0.01) after nitroglycerin in subjects with no migraine attack but no consistent change was observed in patients with migraine attack.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, the fact that plasma CGRP concentration correlates with the timing and severity of a migraine headache suggests a direct relationship between CGRP and migraine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, serotonin release from platelets does not provoke migraine, it may even counteract the headache and the concomitant CGRP release in this model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Coronary aneurysm after implantation of a paclitaxel-eluting stent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Formation of coronary aneurysm is a rare complication of stenting with bare metal stents, but based on experimental studies drug-eluting stents may induce toxic effects on the vessel wall with incomplete stent apposition, aneurysm formation and with the potential of stent thrombosis or vessel rupture.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We present a 43-year-old man who developed a coronary aneurysm in the right coronary artery 6 months after receiving a paclitaxel-eluting stent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient was asymptomatic and the aneurysm was detected in a routine control.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Angiography and intracoronary ultrasound demonstrated lack of contact between stent and vessel wall in a 15-mm long segment with maximal aneurysm diameter of 6.0 mm.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient was successfully treated with a graft stent.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Behavioral effects of urotensin-II centrally administered in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urotensin-II (U-II) receptors are widely distributed in the central nervous system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) injection of U-II causes hypertension and bradycardia and stimulates prolactin and thyrotropin secretion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the behavioral effects of centrally administered U-II have received little attention.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study, we tested the effects of i.c.v. injections of U-II on behavioral, metabolic, and endocrine responses in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of graded doses of U-II (1-10,000 ng/mouse) provoked: (1) a dose-dependent reduction in the number of head dips in the hole-board test; (2) a dose-dependent reduction in the number of entries in the white chamber in the black-and-white compartment test, and in the number of entries in the central platform and open arms in the plus-maze test; and (3) a dose-dependent increase in the duration of immobility in the forced-swimming test and tail suspension test.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intracerebroventricular injection of U-II also caused an increase in: food intake at doses of 100 and 1,000 ng/mouse, water intake at doses of 100-10,000 ng/mouse, and horizontal locomotion activity at a dose of 10,000 ng/mouse.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Whatever was the dose, the central administration of U-II had no effect on body temperature, nociception, apomorphine-induced penile erection and climbing behavior, and stress-induced plasma corticosterone level.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Taken together, the present study demonstrates that the central injection of U-II at doses of 1-10,000 ng/mouse induces anxiogenic- and depressant-like effects in mouse.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data suggest that U-II may be involved in some aspects of psychiatric disorders.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Recurrent dysphonia and acitretin.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We report the case of a woman complaining of dysphonia while she was treated by acitretin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Her symptoms totally regressed after drug withdrawal and reappeared when acitretin was reintroduced.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To our knowledge, this is the first case of acitretin-induced dysphonia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This effect may be related to the pharmacological effect of this drug on mucous membranes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pharmacological modulation of pain-related brain activity during normal and central sensitization states in humans.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Abnormal processing of somatosensory inputs in the central nervous system (central sensitization) is the mechanism accounting for the enhanced pain sensitivity in the skin surrounding tissue injury (secondary hyperalgesia).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Secondary hyperalgesia shares clinical characteristics with neurogenic hyperalgesia in patients with neuropathic pain.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Abnormal brain responses to somatosensory stimuli have been found in patients with hyperalgesia as well as in normal subjects during experimental central sensitization.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The aim of this study was to assess the effects of gabapentin, a drug effective in neuropathic pain patients, on brain processing of nociceptive information in normal and central sensitization states.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in normal volunteers, we studied the gabapentin-induced modulation of brain activity in response to nociceptive mechanical stimulation of normal skin and capsaicin-induced secondary hyperalgesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dose of gabapentin was 1,800 mg per os, in a single administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We found that (i) gabapentin reduced the activations in the bilateral operculoinsular cortex, independently of the presence of central sensitization; (ii) gabapentin reduced the activation in the brainstem, only during central sensitization; (iii) gabapentin suppressed stimulus-induced deactivations, only during central sensitization; this effect was more robust than the effect on brain activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The observed drug-induced effects were not due to changes in the baseline fMRI signal.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These findings indicate that gabapentin has a measurable antinociceptive effect and a stronger antihyperalgesic effect most evident in the brain areas undergoing deactivation, thus supporting the concept that gabapentin is more effective in modulating nociceptive transmission when central sensitization is present.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>MDMA polydrug users show process-specific central executive impairments coupled with impaired social and emotional judgement processes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In recent years working memory deficits have been reported in users of MDMA (3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine, ecstasy).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The current study aimed to assess the impact of MDMA use on three separate central executive processes (set shifting, inhibition and memory updating) and also on "prefrontal" mediated social and emotional judgement processes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifteen polydrug ecstasy users and 15 polydrug non-ecstasy user controls completed a general drug use questionnaire, the Brixton Spatial Anticipation task (set shifting), Backward Digit Span procedure (memory updating), Inhibition of Return (inhibition), an emotional intelligence scale, the Tromso Social Intelligence Scale and the Dysexecutive Questionnaire (DEX).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with MDMA-free polydrug controls, MDMA polydrug users showed impairments in set shifting and memory updating, and also in social and emotional judgement processes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The latter two deficits remained significant after controlling for other drug use.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These data lend further support to the proposal that cognitive processes mediated by the prefrontal cortex may be impaired by recreational ecstasy use.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Severe citrate toxicity complicating volunteer apheresis platelet donation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of severe citrate toxicity during volunteer donor apheresis platelet collection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The donor was a 40-year-old female, first-time apheresis platelet donor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Past medical history was remarkable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and depression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reported medications included bumetanide, pravastatin, and paroxetine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty minutes from the start of the procedure, the donor noted tingling around the mouth, hands, and feet.</Chemical>
<Chemical>She then very rapidly developed acute onset of severe facial and extremity tetany.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Empirical treatment with intravenous calcium gluconate was initiated, and muscle contractions slowly subsided over approximately 10 to 15 minutes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The events are consistent with a severe reaction to calcium chelation by sodium citrate anticoagulant resulting in symptomatic systemic hypocalcemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Upon additional retrospective analysis, it was noted that bumetanide is a loop diuretic that may cause significant hypocalcemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that careful screening for medications and underlying conditions predisposing to hypocalcemia is recommended to help prevent severe reactions due to citrate toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Laboratory measurement of pre-procedure serum calcium levels in selected donors may identify cases requiring heightened vigilance.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The case also illustrates the importance of maintaining preparedness for managing rare but serious reactions in volunteer apheresis blood donors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Proteinuria after conversion to sirolimus in renal transplant recipients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sirolimus (SRL) is a new, potent immunosuppressive agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>More recently, proteinuria has been reported as a consequence of sirolimus therapy, although the mechanism has remained unclear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We retrospectively examined the records of 25 renal transplant patients, who developed or displayed increased proteinuria after SRL conversion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient cohort (14 men, 11 women) was treated with SRL as conversion therapy, due to chronic allograft nephropathy (CAN) (n = 15) neoplasia (n = 8); Kaposi's sarcoma, Four skin cancers, One intestinal tumors, One renal cell carsinom) or BK virus nephropathy (n = 2).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>SRL was started at a mean of 78 +/- 42 (15 to 163) months after transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mean follow-up on SRL therapy was 20 +/- 12 (6 to 43) months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Proteinuria increased from 0.445 (0 to 1.5) g/d before conversion to 3.2 g/dL (0.2 to 12) after conversion (P = 0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Before conversion 8 (32%) patients had no proteinuria, whereas afterwards all patients had proteinuria.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 28% of patients proteinuria remained unchanged, whereas it increased in 68% of patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 40% it increased by more than 100%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twenty-eight percent of patients showed increased proteinuria to the nephrotic range.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Biopsies performed in five patients revealed new pathological changes: One membranoproliferative glomerulopathy and interstitial nephritis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These patients showed persistently good graft function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serum creatinine values did not change significantly: 1.98 +/- 0.8 mg/dL before SRL therapy and 2.53 +/- 1.9 mg/dL at last follow-up (P = .14).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five grafts were lost and the patients returned to dialysis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Five patients displayed CAN and Kaposi's sarcoma.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mean urinary protein of patients who returned to dialysis was 1.26 (0.5 to 3.5) g/d before and 4.7 (3 to 12) g/d after conversion (P = .01).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mean serum creatinine level before conversion was 2.21 mg/dL and thereafter, 4.93 mg/dL (P = .02).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Heavy proteinuria was common after the use of SRL as rescue therapy for renal transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, conversion should be considered for patients who have not developed advanced CAN and proteinuria.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The possibility of de novo glomerular pathology under SRL treatment requires further investigation by renal biopsy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In vitro characterization of parasympathetic and sympathetic responses in cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis in the rat, detrusor function is impaired and the expression and effects of muscarinic receptors altered.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Whether or not the neuronal transmission may be affected by cystitis was presently investigated.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Responses of urinary strip preparations from control and cyclophosphamide-pretreated rats to electrical field stimulation and to agonists were assessed in the absence and presence of muscarinic, adrenergic and purinergic receptor antagonists.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Generally, atropine reduced contractions, but in contrast to controls, it also reduced responses to low electrical field stimulation intensity (1-5 Hz) in inflamed preparations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In both types, purinoceptor desensitization with alpha,beta-methylene adenosine-5'-triphosphate (alpha,beta-meATP) caused further reductions at low frequencies (<10 Hz).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The muscarinic receptor antagonists atropine, 4-diphenylacetoxy-N-methylpiperidine (4-DAMP) ('M(1)/M(3)/M(5)-selective'), methoctramine ('M(2)-selective') and pirenzepine ('M(1)-selective') antagonized the tonic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contractile response more potently than the phasic component.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>4-DAMP inhibited the tonic contractions in controls more potently than methoctramine and pirenzepine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In inflamed preparations, the muscarinic receptor antagonism on the phasic component of the electrical field stimulation-evoked contraction was decreased and the pirenzepine and 4-DAMP antagonism on the tonic component was much less efficient than in controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast to controls, methoctramine increased -- instead of decreased -- the tonic responses at high frequencies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>While contractions to carbachol and ATP were the same in inflamed and in control strips when related to a reference potassium response, isoprenaline-induced relaxations were smaller in inflamed strips.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, in cystitis substantial changes of the efferent functional responses occur.</Chemical>
<Chemical>While postjunctional beta-adrenoceptor-mediated relaxations are reduced, effects by prejunctional inhibitory muscarinic receptors may be increased.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Associations between use of benzodiazepines or related drugs and health, physical abilities and cognitive function: a non-randomised clinical study in the elderly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To describe associations between the use of benzodiazepines or related drugs (BZDs/RDs) and health, functional abilities and cognitive function in the elderly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A non-randomised clinical study of patients aged > or =65 years admitted to acute hospital wards during 1 month.</Chemical>
<Chemical>164 patients (mean age +/- standard deviation [SD] 81.6 +/- 6.8 years) were admitted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of these, nearly half (n = 78) had used BZDs/RDs before admission, and the remainder (n = 86) were non-users.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cognitive ability was assessed by the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients scoring > or =20 MMSE sum points were interviewed (n = 79) and questioned regarding symptoms and functional abilities during the week prior to admission.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Data on use of BZDs/RDs before admission, current medications and discharge diagnoses were collected from medical records.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Health, physical abilities and cognitive function were compared between BZD/RD users and non-users, and adjustments were made for confounding variables.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The residual serum concentrations of oxazepam, temazepam and zopiclone were analysed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean +/- SD duration of BZD/RD use was 7 +/- 7 years (range 1-31).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two or three BZDs/RDs were concomitantly taken by 26% of users (n = 20).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Long-term use of these drugs was associated with female sex and use of a higher number of drugs with effects on the CNS, which tended to be related to diagnosed dementia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After adjustment for these variables as confounders, use of BZDs/RDs was not associated with cognitive function as measured by the MMSE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, use of BZDs/RDs was associated with dizziness, inability to sleep after awaking at night and tiredness in the mornings during the week prior to admission and with stronger depressive symptoms measured at the beginning of the hospital stay.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Use of BZDs/RDs tended to be associated with a reduced ability to walk and shorter night-time sleep during the week prior to admission.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A higher residual serum concentration of temazepam correlated with a lower MMSE sum score after adjustment for confounding variables.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Long-term use and concomitant use of more than one BZD/RD were common in elderly patients hospitalised because of acute illnesses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Long-term use was associated with daytime and night-time symptoms indicative of poorer health and potentially caused by the adverse effects of these drugs.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A 49-year-old woman was transferred to our department because of quadriparesis, lancinating pain, sensory loss, and paresthesia of the distal limbs.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>ALCOHOL STOP TAB, Shin-Poong Pharm. Co., Ansan, Korea) in a suicide attempt.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>She was not an alcoholic.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Higher optical density of an antigen assay predicts thrombosis in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES: To correlate optical density and percent inhibition of a two-step heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) antigen assay with thrombosis; the assay utilizes reaction inhibition characteristics of a high heparin concentration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients with more than 50% decrease in platelet count or thrombocytopenia (<150 x 10(9)/L) after exposure to heparin, who had a positive two-step antigen assay [optical density (OD) >0.4 and >50 inhibition with high concentration of heparin] were included in the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Forty of 94 HIT patients had thrombosis at diagnosis; 54/94 had isolated-HIT without thrombosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Eight of the isolated-HIT patients developed thrombosis within the next 30 d; thus, a total of 48 patients had thrombosis at day 30.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At diagnosis there was no significant difference in OD between HIT patients with thrombosis and those with isolated-HIT.</Chemical>

<Chemical>However, OD was significantly higher in all patients with thrombosis (n = 48, 1.34 +/- 0.89), including isolated-HIT patients who later developed thrombosis within 30 d (n = 8, 1.84 +/- 0.64) as compared to isolated-HIT patients who did not develop thrombosis (0.96 +/- 0.75; P = 0.011 and P = 0.008).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The Receiver Operative Characteristic Curve showed that OD >1.27 in the isolated-HIT group had a significantly higher chance of developing thrombosis by day 30.</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of these groups showed significant difference in percent inhibition.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Multivariate analysis showed a 2.8-fold increased risk of thrombosis in females.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Similarly, thrombotic risk increased with age and OD values.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Higher OD is associated with significant risk of subsequent thrombosis in patients with isolated-HIT; percent inhibition, however, was not predictive.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTIs) provide an alternative method of anticoagulation for patients with a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) or HIT with thrombosis (HITT) undergoing cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the following report, a 65-year-old critically ill patient with a suspected history of HITT was administered argatroban for anticoagulation on bypass during heart transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient required massive transfusion support (55 units of red blood cells, 42 units of fresh-frozen plasma, 40 units of cryoprecipitate, 40 units of platelets, and three doses of recombinant Factor VIIa) for severe intraoperative and postoperative bleeding.</Chemical>
<Chemical>STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Plasma samples from before and after CPB were analyzed postoperatively for argatroban concentration using a modified ecarin clotting time (ECT) assay.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Unexpectedly high concentrations of argatroban were measured in these samples (range, 0-32 microg/mL), and a prolonged plasma argatroban half life (t(1/2)) of 514 minutes was observed (published elimination t(1/2) is 39-51 minutes</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>[< or = 181 minutes with hepatic impairment]).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Correlation of plasma argatroban concentration versus the patient's coagulation variables and clinical course suggest that prolonged elevated levels of plasma argatroban may have contributed to the patient's extended coagulopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because DTIs do not have reversal agents, surgical teams and transfusion services should remain aware of the possibility of massive transfusion events during anticoagulation with these agents.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This is the first report to measure plasma argatroban concentration in the context of CPB and extended coagulopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antituberculosis therapy-induced acute liver failure: magnitude, profile, prognosis, and predictors of outcome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antituberculosis therapy (ATT)-associated acute liver failure (ATT-ALF) is the commonest drug-induced ALF in South Asia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prospective studies on ATT-ALF are lacking.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The current study prospectively evaluated the magnitude, clinical course, outcome, and prognostic factors in ATT-ALF.</Chemical>
<Chemical>From January 1986 to January 2009, 1223 consecutive ALF patients were evaluated: ATT alone was the cause in 70 (5.7%) patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Another 15 (1.2%) had ATT and simultaneous hepatitis virus infection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 44 (62.8%) patients, ATT was prescribed empirically without definitive evidence of tuberculosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>ATT-ALF patients were younger (32.87 [+/-15.8] years), and 49 (70%) of them were women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Most had hyperacute presentation; the median icterus encephalopathy interval was 4.5 (0-30) days.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The median duration of ATT before ALF was 30 (7-350) days.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At presentation, advanced encephalopathy and cerebral edema were present in 51 (76%) and 29 (41.4%) patients, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Gastrointestinal bleed, seizures, infection, and acute renal failure were documented in seven (10%), five (7.1%), 26 (37.1%), and seven (10%) patients, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Compared with hepatitis E virus (HEV) and non-A non-E-induced ALF, ATT-ALF patients had nearly similar presentations except for older age and less elevation of liver enzymes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mortality rate among patients with ATT-ALF was high (67.1%, n = 47), and only 23 (32.9%)</Chemical>
<Chemical>patients recovered with medical treatment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In multivariate analysis, three factors independently predicted mortality: serum bilirubin (>or=10.8 mg/dL), prothrombin time (PT) prolongation (>or=26 seconds), and grade III/IV encephalopathy at presentation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>ATT-ALF constituted 5.7% of ALF at our center and had a high mortality rate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Because the mortality rate is so high, determining which factors are predictors is less important.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A high proportion of patients had consumed ATT empirically, which could have been prevented.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Central nervous system complications during treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia in a single pediatric institution.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Central nervous system (CNS) complications during treatment of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) remain a challenging clinical problem.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Outcome improvement with more intensive chemotherapy has significantly increased the incidence and severity of adverse events.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study analyzed the incidence of neurological complications during ALL treatment in a single pediatric institution, focusing on clinical, radiological, and electrophysiological findings.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Exclusion criteria included CNS leukemic infiltration at diagnosis, therapy-related peripheral neuropathy, late-onset encephalopathy, or long-term neurocognitive defects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>During a 9-year period, we retrospectively collected 27 neurological events (11%) in as many patients, from 253 children enrolled in the ALL front-line protocol.</Chemical>

<Chemical>CNS complications included posterior reversible leukoencephalopathy syndrome (n = 10), stroke (n = 5), temporal lobe epilepsy (n = 2), high-dose methotrexate toxicity (n = 2), syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (n = 1), and other unclassified events (n = 7).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, CNS complications are frequent events during ALL therapy, and require rapid detection and prompt treatment to limit permanent damage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Safety of capecitabine: a review.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>IMPORTANCE OF THE FIELD:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Fluoropyrimidines, in particular 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), have been the mainstay of treatment for several solid tumors, including colorectal, breast and head and neck cancers, for > 40 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>AREAS COVERED IN THIS REVIEW:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This article reviews the pharmacology and efficacy of capecitabine with a special emphasis on its safety.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>WHAT THE READER WILL GAIN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The reader will gain better insight into the safety of capecitabine in special populations such as patients with advanced age, renal and kidney disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We also explore different dosing and schedules of capecitabine administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>TAKE HOME MESSAGE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Capecitabine is an oral prodrug of 5-FU and was developed to fulfill the need for a more convenient therapy and provide an improved safety/efficacy profile.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It has shown promising results alone or in combination with other chemotherapeutic agents in colorectal, breast, pancreaticobiliary, gastric, renal cell and head and neck cancers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The most commonly reported toxic effects of capecitabine are diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomatitis and hand-foot syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Capecitabine has a well-established safety profile and can be given safely to patients with advanced age, hepatic and renal dysfunctions.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Effects of pallidal neurotensin on haloperidol-induced parkinsonian catalepsy: behavioral and electrophysiological studies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The globus pallidus plays a critical role in movement regulation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Previous studies have indicated that the globus pallidus receives neurotensinergic innervation from the striatum, and systemic administration of a neurotensin analog could produce antiparkinsonian effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study aimed to investigate the effects of pallidal neurotensin on haloperidol-induced parkinsonian symptoms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Behavioral experiments and electrophysiological recordings were performed in the present study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Bilateral infusions of neurotensin into the globus pallidus reversed haloperidol-induced parkinsonian catalepsy in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Electrophysiological recordings showed that microinjection of neurotensin induced excitation of pallidal neurons in the presence of systemic haloperidol administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The neurotensin type-1 receptor antagonist SR48692 blocked both the behavioral and the electrophysiological effects induced by neurotensin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Activation of pallidal neurotensin receptors may be involved in neurotensin-induced antiparkinsonian effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antihypertensive drugs and depression: a reappraisal.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Eighty-nine new referral hypertensive out-patients and 46 new referral non-hypertensive chronically physically ill out-patients completed a mood rating scale at regular intervals for one year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results showed a high prevalence of depression in both groups of patients, with no preponderance in the hypertensive group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hypertensive patients with psychiatric histories had a higher prevalence of depression than the comparison patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was accounted for by a significant number of depressions occurring in methyl dopa treated patients with psychiatric histories.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Pulmonary shunt and cardiovascular responses to CPAP during nitroprusside-induced hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) on cardiovascular dynamics and pulmonary shunt (QS/QT) were investigated in 12 dogs before and during sodium nitroprusside infusion that decreased mean arterial blood pressure 40-50 per cent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Before nitroprusside infusion, 5 cm H2O CPAP significantly, P less than .05, decreased arterial blood pressure, but did not significantly alter heart rate, cardiac output, systemic vascular resistance, or QS/QT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ten cm H2O CPAP before nitroprusside infusion produced a further decrease in arterial blood pressure and significantly increased heart rate and decreased cardiac output and QS/QT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nitroprusside caused significant decreases in arterial blood pressure and systemic vascular resistance and increases in heart rate, but did not change cardiac output or QS/QT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five cm H2O CPAP during nitroprusside did not further alter any of the above-mentioned variables.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, 10 cm H2O CPAP decreased arterial blood pressure, cardiac output, and QS/QT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data indicate that nitroprusside infusion rates that decrease mean arterial blood pressure by 40-50 per cent do not change cardiac output or QS/QT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During nitroprusside infusion low levels of CPAP do not markedly alter cardiovascular dynamics, but high levels of CPAP (10 cm H2O), while decreasing QS/QT, produce marked decreases in arterial blood pressure and cardiac output.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mediation of enhanced reflex vagal bradycardia by L-dopa via central dopamine formation in dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>L-Dopa (5 mg/kg i.v.)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>decreased blood pressure and heart rate after extracerebral decarboxylase inhibition with MK-486 (25 mg/kg i.v.) in anesthetize MAO-inhibited dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, reflex bradycardia caused by injected norepinephrine was significantly enhanced by L-dopa, DL-Threo-dihydroxyphenylserine had no effect on blood pressure, heart rate or reflex responses to norepinephrine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>FLA-63, a dopamine-beta-oxidase inhibitor, did not have any effect on the hypotension, bradycardia or reflex-enhancing effect of L-dopa.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pimozide did not affect the actions of L-dopa on blood pressure and heart rate but completely blocked the enhancement of reflexes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Removal of the carotid sinuses caused an elevation blood pressure and heart rate and abolished the negative chronotropic effect of norepinephrine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, L-dopa restored the bradycardia caused by norepinephrine in addition to decreasing blood pressure and heart rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>5-HTP (5 mg/kg i.v.) decreased blood pressure and heart rate and decreased the reflex bradycardia to norepinephrine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is concluded that L-dopa enhances reflex bradycardia through central alpha-receptor stimulation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, the effects are mediated through dopamine rather than norepinephrine and do not require the carotid sinus baroreceptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cocaine-induced myocardial infarction: clinical observations and pathogenetic considerations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical and experimental data published to date suggest several possible mechanisms by which cocaine may result in acute myocardial infarction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In individuals with preexisting, high-grade coronary arterial narrowing, acute myocardial infarction may result from an increase in myocardial oxygen demand associated with cocaine-induced increase in rate-pressure product.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In other individuals with no underlying atherosclerotic obstruction, coronary occlusion may be due to spasm, thrombus, or both.</Chemical>
<Chemical>With regard to spasm, the clinical findings are largely circumstantial, and the locus of cocaine-induced vasoconstriction remains speculative.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although certain clinical and experimental findings support the hypothesis that spasm involves the epicardial, medium-size vessels, other data suggest intramural vasoconstriction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Diffuse intramural vasoconstriction is not consistent with reports of segmental, discrete infarction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Whereas certain in vivo data suggest that these effects are alpha-mediated, other in vitro data suggest the opposite.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The finding of cocaine-induced vasoconstriction in segments of (noninnervated) human umbilical artery suggests that the presence or absence of intact innervation is not sufficient to explain the discrepant data involving the possibility of alpha-mediated effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Finally, the contribution of a primary, thrombotic effect of cocaine has not been excluded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rabbit syndrome, antidepressant use, and cerebral perfusion SPECT scan findings.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rabbit syndrome is an extrapyramidal side effect associated with chronic neuroleptic therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Its occurrence in a patient being treated with imipramine is described, representing the first reported case of this syndrome in conjunction with antidepressants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Repeated cerebral perfusion SPECT scans revealed decreased basal ganglia perfusion while the movement disorder was present, and a return to normal perfusion when the rabbit syndrome resolved.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute bronchodilating effects of ipratropium bromide and theophylline in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The bronchodilator effects of a single dose of ipratropium bromide aerosol (36 micrograms) and short-acting theophylline tablets (dose titrated to produce serum levels of 10-20 micrograms/mL) were compared in a double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study in 21 patients with stable, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mean peak forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) increases over baseline and the proportion of patients attaining at least a 15% increase in the FEV1 (responders) were 31% and 90%, respectively, for ipratropium and 17% and 50%, respectively, for theophylline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The average FEV1 increases during the 6-hour observation period were 18% for ipratropium and 8% for theophylline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mean duration of action was 3.8 hours with ipratropium and 2.4 hours with theophylline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>While side effects were rare, those experienced after theophylline use did involve the cardiovascular and gastrointestinal systems.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results show that ipratropium is a more potent bronchodilator than oral theophylline in patients with chronic airflow obstruction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Irreversible damage to the medullary interstitium in experimental analgesic nephropathy in F344 rats.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Renal papillary necrosis (RPN) and a decreased urinary concentrating ability developed during continuous long-term treatment with aspirin and paracetamol in female Fischer 344 rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Renal structure and concentrating ability were examined after a recovery period of up to 18 weeks, when no analgesics were given, to investigate whether the analgesic-induced changes were reversible.</Chemical>

<Chemical>There was no evidence of repair to the damaged medullary interstitial matrix, or proliferation of remaining undamaged type 1 medullary interstitial cells after the recovery period following analgesic treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The recovery of urinary concentrating ability was related to the length of analgesic treatment and the extent of the resulting inner medullary structural damage.</Chemical>

<Chemical>During the early stages of analgesic treatment, the changes in urinary concentrating ability were reversible, but after prolonged analgesic treatment, maximum urinary concentrating ability failed to recover.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study shows that prolonged analgesic treatment in Fischer 344 rats causes progressive and irreversible damage to the interstitial matrix and type 1 interstitial cells leading to RPN.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The associated urinary concentrating defect is reversible only during the early stages of structural damage to the inner medulla.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Less frequent lithium administration and lower urine volume.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study was designed to determine whether patients maintained on a regimen of lithium on a once-per-day schedule have lower urine volumes than do patients receiving multiple doses per day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was a cross-sectional study of 85 patients from a lithium clinic who received different dose schedules.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients were admitted to the hospital for measurement of lithium level, creatinine clearance, urine volume, and maximum osmolality.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Multiple daily doses of lithium were associated with higher urine volumes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dosing schedule, duration of lithium treatment, and daily dose of lithium did not affect maximum osmolality or creatinine clearance.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urine volume can be reduced by giving lithium once daily and/or by lowering the total daily dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lithium-induced polyuria seems to be related to extrarenal as well as to renal effects.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Effect of adriamycin combined with whole body hyperthermia on tumor and normal tissues.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thermal enhancement of Adriamycin-mediated antitumor activity and normal tissue toxicities by whole body hyperthermia were compared using a F344 rat model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antitumor activity was studied using a tumor growth delay assay.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Acute normal tissue toxicities (i.e., leukopenia and thrombocytopenia) and late normal tissue toxicities (i.e., myocardial and kidney injury) were evaluated by functional/physiological assays and by morphological techniques.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Whole body hyperthermia (120 min at 41.5 degrees C) enhanced both Adriamycin-mediated antitumor activity and toxic side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The thermal enhancement ratio calculated for antitumor activity was 1.6.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Thermal enhancement ratios estimated for "acute" hematological changes were 1.3, whereas those estimated for "late" damage (based on morphological cardiac and renal lesions) varied between 2.4 and 4.3.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Thus, while whole body hyperthermia enhances Adriamycin-mediated antitumor effect, normal tissue toxicity is also increased, and the potential therapeutic gain of the combined modality treatment is eroded.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Prazosin-induced stress incontinence.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A case of genuine stress incontinence due to prazosin, a common antihypertensive drug, is presented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prazosin exerts its antihypertensive effects through vasodilatation caused by selective blockade of postsynaptic alpha-1 adrenergic receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>As an alpha-blocker, it also exerts a significant relaxant effect on the bladder neck and urethra.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Her incontinence resolved with the change of medication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The restoration of continence was accompanied by a substantial rise in maximum urethral pressure, maximum urethral closure pressure, and functional urethral length.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients who present with stress incontinence while taking prazosin should change their antihypertensive medication before considering surgery, because their incontinence may resolve spontaneously with a change in drug therapy.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The typical fluoxetine-induced symptoms of restlessness, constant pacing, purposeless movements of the feet and legs, and marked anxiety were indistinguishable from those of neuroleptic-induced akathisia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Stroke associated with cocaine use.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We describe eight patients in whom cocaine use was related to stroke and review 39 cases from the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among these 47 patients the mean (+/- SD) age was 32.5 +/- 12.1 years; 76% (34/45) were men.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Stroke followed cocaine use by inhalation, intranasal, intravenous, and intramuscular routes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intracranial aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations were present in 17 of 32 patients studied angiographically or at autopsy; cerebral vasculitis was present in two patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cerebral infarction occurred in 10 patients (22%), intracerebral hemorrhage in 22 (49%), and subarachnoid hemorrhage in 13 (29%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>These data indicate that (1) the apparent incidence of stroke related to cocaine use is increasing; (2) cocaine-associated stroke occurs primarily in young adults; (3) stroke may follow any route of cocaine administration; (4) stroke after cocaine use is frequently associated with intracranial aneurysms and arteriovenous malformations; and (5) in cocaine-associated stroke, the frequency of intracranial hemorrhage exceeds that of cerebral infarction.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: Four patients (1.7%) were identified with toxic hepatitis which could reasonably be attributed to the use of antithyroid agent.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Biological features of hepatitis disappeared in all cases after cessation of the incriminated drug, while biliary, viral and immunological searches were negative.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Only 2 patients of our retrospective study experienced a mild or severe neutropenia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Toxic hepatitis is a potential adverse effect of antithyroid drugs which warrants, as for haematological disturbances, a pre-therapeutic determination and a careful follow-up of relevant biological markers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Moreover, hepatotoxicity may not be restricted to one class of antithyroid agents.</Chemical>

<Chemical>During the study, vitamin B12 and folate levels were significantly higher in group II patients; however, no differences in hemoglobin, hematocrit, mean corpuscular volume, and white-cell, neutrophil and platelet counts were observed between groups at 3, 6, 9 and 12 months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Severe hematologic toxicity (neutrophil count < 1000/mm3 and/or hemoglobin < 8 g/dl) occurred in 4 patients assigned to group I and 7 assigned to group II.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Habitual use of acetaminophen as a risk factor for chronic renal failure: a comparison with phenacetin.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six epidemiologic studies in the United States and Europe indicate that habitual use of phenacetin is associated with the development of chronic renal failure and end-stage renal disease (ESRD), with a relative risk in the range of 4 to 19.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>As a result of these and other studies, phenacetin has now been withdrawn from the market in most countries.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, three case control studies, one each in North Carolina, northern Maryland, and West Berlin, Germany, showed that habitual use of acetaminophen is also associated with chronic renal failure and ESRD, with a relative risk in the range of 2 to 4.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These studies suggest that both phenacetin and acetaminophen may contribute to the burden of ESRD, with the risk of the latter being somewhat less than that of the former.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This apparent difference in risk may not be due to differences in nephrotoxic potential of the drugs themselves.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A lower relative risk would be expected for acetaminophen if the risk of both drugs in combination with other analgesics was higher than the risk of either agent alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, acetaminophen has been used both as a single agent and in combination with other analgesics, whereas phenacetin was available only in combinations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possibility that habitual use of acetaminophen alone increases the risk of ESRD has not been clearly demonstrated, but cannot be dismissed.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Treatment of previously treated metastatic breast cancer by mitoxantrone and 48-hour continuous infusion of high-dose 5-FU and leucovorin (MFL): low palliative benefit and high treatment-related toxicity.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>From October 1993 to November 1995, we treated 13 patients with previously chemotherapy-treated metastatic breast cancer by mitoxantrone, 12 mg/m2, on day 1 and continuous infusion of 5-FU, 3000 mg/m2, together with leucovorin, 300 mg/m2, for 48 h from day 1 to 2.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Each course of chemotherapy was given every 4 weeks.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Seven patients had previously received radiotherapy and seven had received hormone therapy.</Chemical>
