label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One patient had complete response, seven had stable disease, none had partial response and five had progressive disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The overall objective response rate was 7.6%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The median follow-up period was 14 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Median survival was 16 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Median progression-free survival was 5 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A complete responder had relapse-free survival up to 17 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Major toxicities were cardiotoxicity and leukopenia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Eight patients were dead in the last follow-up; two of them died of treatment-related toxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The MFL regimen achieves little palliative benefit and induces severe toxicity at a fairly high rate.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Administration of this regimen to breast cancer patients who have been treated by chemotherapy and those with impaired heart function requires careful attention.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Attempts to resuscitate the patient were not successful.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The serum level of potassium was observed to be 8.4 mequiv L-1.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Apart from the reduction in the patient's level of consciousness, there were no signs of motor neurone damage or of any of the other known predisposing conditions for hyperkalaemia following the administration of suxamethonium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is postulated that her death was caused by hypersensitivity to suxamethonium, associated with her 5-day immobilization.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>mg, for correction of Dupuytren's contracture.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The block was successful and surgery was conducted as scheduled despite persisting atrial fibrillation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Clinical and histopathologic examination of renal allografts treated with tacrolimus (FK506) for at least one year.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: We clinically and pathologically analyzed renal allografts from 1 9 renal transplant patients treated with tacrolimus (FK506) for more than 1 year.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Twenty-six renal allograft biopsy specimens from 1 9 renal transplant patients who underwent transplantations between 1991 and 1993 were evaluated.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Thirteen biopsies were performed from stable functioning renal allografts with informed consent (nonepisode biopsy) and the other 13 were from dysfunctional renal allografts with a clinical indication for biopsy (episode biopsy).</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The main pathologic diagnoses (some overlap) were acute rejection (AR; n = 4), chronic rejection (CR; n=5), AR+CR (n =4), recurrent IgA nephropathy (n =5), normal findings (n =2), minimal-type chronic FK506 nephropathy (n = 9), and mild-type FK506 nephropathy (n = 11).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the nonepisode biopsies, 7 and 4 biopsies showed minimal-type and mild-type chronic FK506 nephropathy, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronic FK506 nephropathy consisted of rough and foamy tubular vacuolization (5 biopsies), arteriolopathy (angiodegeneration of the arteriolar wall; 20 biopsies), focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (4 biopsies) and the striped form of interstitial fibrosis (11 biopsies).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The serum creatinine levels of patients in the mild-type chronic FK506 nephropathy group, which included 7 episode biopsies, were statistically higher than those in the minimum-type chronic FK506-nephropathy group (P< 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study demonstrates that chronic FK506 nephropathy consists primarily of arteriolopathy manifesting as insudative hyalinosis of the arteriolar wall, and suggests that mild-type chronic FK506 nephropathy is a condition which may lead to deterioration of renal allograft function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Memory facilitation and stimulation of endogenous nerve growth factor synthesis by the acetylcholine releaser PG-9.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of PG-9 (3alpha-tropyl 2-(p-bromophenyl)propionate), the acetylcholine releaser, on memory processes and nerve growth factor (NGF) synthesis were evaluated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the mouse passive-avoidance test, PG-9 (10-30 mg/kg, i.p.), administered 20 min before the training session, prevented amnesia induced by both the non selective antimuscarinic drug scopolamine and the M1-selective antagonist S-(-)-ET-126.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the same experimental conditions, PG-9 (5-20 microg per mouse, i.c.v.) was also able to prevent antimuscarine-induced amnesia, demonstrating a central localization of the activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At the highest effective doses, PG-9 did not produce any collateral symptoms as revealed by the Irwin test, and it did not modify spontaneous motility and inspection activity, as revealed by the hole-board test.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PG-9 was also able to increase the amount of NGF secreted in vitro by astrocytes in a dose-dependent manner.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The maximal NGF contents obtained by PG-9 were 17.6-fold of the control value.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During culture, no morphological changes were found at effective concentrations of PG-9.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The current work indicates the ability of PG-9 to induce beneficial effects on cognitive processes and stimulate activity of NGF synthesis in astroglial cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, PG-9 could represent a potential useful drug able to improve the function of impaired cognitive processes.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Recurrent use of newer oral contraceptives and the risk of venous thromboembolism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The epidemiological studies that assessed the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) associated with newer oral contraceptives (OC) did not distinguish between patterns of OC use, namely first-time users, repeaters and switchers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Data from a Transnational case-control study were used to assess the risk of VTE for the latter patterns of use, while accounting for duration of use.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Over the period 1993-1996, 551 cases of VTE were identified in Germany and the UK along with 2066 controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Totals of 128 cases and 650 controls were analysed for repeat use and 135 cases and 622 controls for switching patterns.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The adjusted rate ratio of VTE for repeat users of third generation OC was 0.6 (95% CI:0.3-1.2) relative to repeat users of second generation pills, whereas it was 1.3 (95% CI:0.7-2.4) for switchers from second to third generation pills relative to switchers from third to second generation pills.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that second and third generation agents are associated with equivalent risks of VTE when the same agent is used repeatedly after interruption periods or when users are switched between the two generations of pills.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These analyses suggest that the higher risk observed for the newer OC in other studies may be the result of inadequate comparisons of pill users with different patterns of pill use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Development of apomorphine-induced aggressive behavior: comparison of adult male and female Wistar rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The development of apomorphine-induced (1.0 mg/kg s.c. once daily) aggressive behavior of adult male and female Wistar rats obtained from the same breeder was studied in two consecutive sets.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In male animals, repeated apomorphine treatment induced a gradual development of aggressive behavior as evidenced by the increased intensity of aggressiveness and shortened latency before the first attack toward the opponent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In female rats, only a weak tendency toward aggressiveness was found.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In conclusion, the present study demonstrates gender differences in the development of the apomorphine-induced aggressive behavior and indicates that the female rats do not fill the validation criteria for use in this method.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Serotonergic antidepressants and urinary incontinence.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Many new serotonergic antidepressants have been introduced over the past decade.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although urinary incontinence is listed as one side effect of these drugs in their package inserts there is only one report in the literature.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This concerns 2 male patients who experienced incontinence while taking venlafaxine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present paper the authors describe 2 female patients who developed incontinence secondary to the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors paroxetine and sertraline, as well as a third who developed this side effect on venlafaxine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 2 of the 3 cases the patients were also taking lithium carbonate and beta-blockers, both of which could have contributed to the incontinence.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Animal studies suggest that incontinence secondary to serotonergic antidepressants could be mediated by the 5HT4 receptors found on the bladder.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further research is needed to delineate the frequency of this troubling side effect and how best to treat it.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hypotension following the initiation of tizanidine in a patient treated with an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor for chronic hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonists are one of several pharmacologic agents used in the treatment of spasticity related to disorders of the central nervous system.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition to their effects on spasticity, certain adverse cardiorespiratory effects have been reported.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Adults chronically treated with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors may have a limited ability to respond to hypotension when the sympathetic response is simultaneously blocked.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The authors present a 10-year-old boy chronically treated with lisinopril, an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor, to control hypertension who developed hypotension following the addition of tizanidine, an alpha-2 agonist, for the treatment of spasticity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possible interaction of tizanidine and other antihypertensive agents should be kept in mind when prescribing therapy to treat either hypertension or spasticity in such patients.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Peritubular capillary basement membrane reduplication in allografts and native kidney disease: a clinicopathologic study of 278 consecutive renal specimens.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>An association has been found between transplant glomerulopathy (TG) and reduplication of peritubular capillary basement membranes (PTCR).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although such an association is of practical and theoretical importance, only one prospective study has tried to confirm it.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We examined 278 consecutive renal specimens (from 135 transplants and 143 native kidneys) for ultrastructural evidence of PTCR.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In addition to renal allografts with TG, we also examined grafts with acute rejection, recurrent glomerulonephritis, chronic allograft nephropathy and stable grafts ("protocol biopsies").</Chemical>

<Chemical>Native kidney specimens included a wide range of glomerulopathies as well as cases of thrombotic microangiopathy, malignant hypertension, acute interstitial nephritis, and acute tubular necrosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We found PTCR in 14 of 15 cases of TG, in 7 transplant biopsy specimens without TG, and in 13 of 143 native kidney biopsy specimens.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These 13 included cases of malignant hypertension, thrombotic microangiopathy, lupus nephritis, Henoch-Schonlein nephritis, crescentic glomerulonephritis, and cocaine-related acute renal failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mild PTCR in allografts without TG did not predict renal failure or significant proteinuria after follow-up periods of between 3 months and 1 year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We conclude that in transplants, there is a strong association between well-developed PTCR and TG, while the significance of mild PTCR and its predictive value in the absence of TG is unclear.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PTCR also occurs in certain native kidney diseases, though the association is not as strong as that for TG.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We suggest that repeated endothelial injury, including immunologic injury, may be the cause of this lesion both in allografts and native kidneys.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Conformationally restricted analogs of BD1008 and an antisense oligodeoxynucleotide targeting sigma1 receptors produce anti-cocaine effects in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cocaine's ability to interact with sigma receptors suggests that these proteins mediate some of its behavioral effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, three novel sigma receptor ligands with antagonist activity were evaluated in Swiss Webster mice:</Chemical>

<Chemical>BD1018 (3S-1-[2-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)ethyl]-1,4-diazabicyclo[4.3.0]nonane), BD1063 (1-[2-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)ethyl]-4-methylpiperazine), and LR132 (1R,2S-(+)-cis-N-[2-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)ethyl]-2-(1-pyrrolidinyl)cyclohexylamine).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Competition binding assays demonstrated that all three compounds have high affinities for sigma1 receptors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The three compounds vary in their affinities for sigma2 receptors and exhibit negligible affinities for dopamine, opioid, GABA(A) and NMDA receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In behavioral studies, pre-treatment of mice with BD1018, BD1063, or LR132 significantly attenuated cocaine-induced convulsions and lethality.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, post-treatment with LR132 prevented cocaine-induced lethality in a significant proportion of animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast to the protection provided by the putative antagonists, the well-characterized sigma receptor agonist di-o-tolylguanidine (DTG) and the novel sigma receptor agonist BD1031 (3R-1-[2-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)ethyl]-1,4-diazabicyclo[4.3.0]nonane) each worsened the behavioral toxicity of cocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>At doses where alone, they produced no significant effects on locomotion, BD1018, BD1063 and LR132 significantly attenuated the locomotor stimulatory effects of cocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To further validate the hypothesis that the anti-cocaine effects of the novel ligands involved antagonism of sigma receptors, an antisense oligodeoxynucleotide against sigma1 receptors was also shown to significantly attenuate the convulsive and locomotor stimulatory effects of cocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Together, the data suggests that functional antagonism of sigma receptors is capable of attenuating a number of cocaine-induced behaviors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic assessment of the effects of E4031, cisapride, terfenadine and terodiline on monophasic action potential duration in dog.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>1.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Torsades de pointes (TDP) is a potentially fatal ventricular tachycardia associated with increases in QT interval and monophasic action potential duration (MAPD).</Chemical>
<Chemical>TDP is a side-effect that has led to withdrawal of several drugs from the market (e.g. terfenadine and terodiline).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The potential of compounds to cause TDP was evaluated by monitoring their effects on MAPD in dog.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Four compounds known to increase QT interval and cause TDP were investigated: terfenadine, terodiline, cisapride and E4031.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the basis that only free drug in the systemic circulation will elicit a pharmacological response target, free concentrations in plasma were selected to mimic the free drug exposures in man.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Infusion regimens were designed that rapidly achieved and maintained target-free concentrations of these drugs in plasma and data on the relationship between free concentration and changes in MAPD were obtained for these compounds.</Chemical>
<Chemical>3.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These data indicate that the free ED50 in plasma for terfenadine (1.9 nM), terodiline (76 nM), cisapride (11 nM) and E4031 (1.9 nM) closely correlate with the free concentration in man causing QT effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>For compounds that have shown TDP in the clinic (terfenadine, terodiline, cisapride) there is little differentiation between the dog ED50 and the efficacious free plasma concentrations in man (< 10-fold) reflecting their limited safety margins.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data underline the need to maximize the therapeutic ratio with respect to TDP in potential development candidates and the importance of using free drug concentrations in pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic studies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fatal myeloencephalopathy due to accidental intrathecal vincristin administration: a report of two cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report on two fatal cases of accidental intrathecal vincristine instillation in a 5-year old girl with recurrent acute lymphoblastic leucemia and a 57-year old man with lymphoblastic lymphoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The girl died seven days, the man four weeks after intrathecal injection of vincristine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinically, the onset was characterized by the signs of opistothonus, sensory and motor dysfunction and ascending paralysis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Histological and immunohistochemical investigations (HE-LFB, CD-68, Neurofilament) revealed degeneration of myelin and axons as well as pseudocystic transformation in areas exposed to vincristine, accompanied by secondary changes with numerous prominent macrophages.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The clinical course and histopathological results of the two cases are presented.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A review of all reported cases in the literature is given.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A better controlled regimen for administering vincristine and intrathecal chemotherapy is recommended.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intravenous administration of prochlorperazine by 15-minute infusion versus 2-minute bolus does not affect the incidence of akathisia: a prospective, randomized, controlled trial.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>STUDY OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We sought to compare the rate of akathisia after administration of intravenous prochlorperazine as a 2-minute bolus or 15-minute infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We conducted a prospective, randomized, double-blind study in the emergency department of a central-city teaching hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients aged 18 years or older treated with prochlorperazine for headache, nausea, or vomiting were eligible for inclusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Study participants were randomized to receive 10 mg of prochlorperazine administered intravenously by means of 2-minute push (bolus group) or 10 mg diluted in 50 mL of normal saline solution administered by means of intravenous infusion during a 15-minute period (infusion group).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The main outcome was the number of study participants experiencing akathisia within 60 minutes of administration.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Akathisia was defined as either a spontaneous report of restlessness or agitation or a change of 2 or more in the patient-reported akathisia rating scale and a change of at least 1 in the investigator-observed akathisia rating scale.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The intensity of headache and nausea was measured with a 100-mm visual analog scale.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: One hundred patients were enrolled.</Chemical>
<Chemical>One study participant was excluded after protocol violation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Seventy-three percent (73/99) of the study participants were treated for headache and 70% (70/99) for nausea.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the bolus group, 26.0% (13/50) had akathisia compared with 32.7% (16/49) in the infusion group (Delta=-6.7%; 95% confidence interval [CI] -24.6% to 11.2%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The difference between the bolus and infusion groups in the percentage of participants who saw a 50% reduction in their headache intensity within 30 minutes was 11.8% (95% CI -9.6% to 33.3%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The difference in the percentage of patients with a 50% reduction in their nausea was 12.6% (95%</Chemical>
<Chemical>CI -4.6% to 29.8%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>CONCLUSION: A 50% reduction in the incidence of akathisia when prochlorperazine was administered by means of 15-minute intravenous infusion versus a 2-minute intravenous push was not detected.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The efficacy of prochlorperazine in the treatment of headache and nausea likewise did not appear to be affected by the rate of administration, although no formal statistical comparisons were made.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antithymocyte globulin in the treatment of D-penicillamine-induced aplastic anemia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A patient who received antithymocyte globulin therapy for aplastic anemia due to D-penicillamine therapy is described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Bone marrow recovery and peripheral blood recovery were complete 1 month and 3 months, respectively, after treatment, and blood transfusion or other therapies were not necessary in a follow-up period of more than 2 years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Use of antithymocyte globulin may be the optimal treatment of D-penicillamine-induced aplastic anemia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The relationship between hippocampal acetylcholine release and cholinergic convulsant sensitivity in withdrawal seizure-prone and withdrawal seizure-resistant selected mouse lines.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The septo-hippocampal cholinergic pathway has been implicated in epileptogenesis, and genetic factors influence the response to cholinergic agents, but limited data are available on cholinergic involvement in alcohol withdrawal severity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, the relationship between cholinergic activity and responsiveness and alcohol withdrawal was investigated in a genetic animal model of ethanol withdrawal severity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cholinergic convulsant sensitivity was examined in alcohol-na  ve Withdrawal Seizure-Prone (WSP) and-Resistant (WSR) mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Animals were administered nicotine, carbachol, or neostigmine via timed tail vein infusion, and the latencies to onset of tremor and clonus were recorded and converted to threshold dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We also used microdialysis to measure basal and potassium-stimulated acetylcholine (ACh) release in the CA1 region of the hippocampus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Potassium was applied by reverse dialysis twice, separated by 75 min. Hippocampal ACh also was measured during testing for handling-induced convulsions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sensitivity to several convulsion endpoints induced by nicotine, carbachol, and neostigmine were significantly greater in WSR versus WSP mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In microdialysis experiments, the lines did not differ in basal release of ACh, and 50 mM KCl increased ACh output in both lines of mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the increase in release of ACh produced by the first application of KCl was 2-fold higher in WSP versus WSR mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>When hippocampal ACh was measured during testing for handling-induced convulsions, extracellular ACh was significantly elevated (192%) in WSP mice, but was nonsignificantly elevated (59%) in WSR mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>These results suggest that differences in cholinergic activity and postsynaptic sensitivity to cholinergic convulsants may be associated with ethanol withdrawal severity and implicate cholinergic mechanisms in alcohol withdrawal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Specifically, WSP mice may have lower sensitivity to cholinergic convulsants compared with WSR because of postsynaptic receptor desensitization brought on by higher activity of cholinergic neurons.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prenatal dexamethasone programs hypertension and renal injury in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dexamethasone is frequently administered to the developing fetus to accelerate pulmonary development.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The purpose of the present study was to determine if prenatal dexamethasone programmed a progressive increase in blood pressure and renal injury in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pregnant rats were given either vehicle or 2 daily intraperitoneal injections of dexamethasone (0.2 mg/kg body weight) on gestational days 11 and 12, 13 and 14, 15 and 16, 17 and 18, or 19 and 20.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Offspring of rats administered dexamethasone on days 15 and 16 gestation had a 20% reduction in glomerular number compared with control at 6 to 9 months of age (22 527+/-509 versus 28 050+/-561, P<0.05), which was comparable to the percent reduction in glomeruli measured at 3 weeks of age.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six- to 9-month old rats receiving prenatal dexamethasone on days 17 and 18 of gestation had a 17% reduction in glomeruli (23 380+/-587) compared with control rats (P<0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male rats that received prenatal dexamethasone on days 15 and 16, 17 and 18, and 13 and 14 of gestation had elevated blood pressures at 6 months of age; the latter group did not have a reduction in glomerular number.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adult rats given dexamethasone on days 15 and 16 of gestation had more glomeruli with glomerulosclerosis than control rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study shows that prenatal dexamethasone in rats results in a reduction in glomerular number, glomerulosclerosis, and hypertension when administered at specific points during gestation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hypertension was observed in animals that had a reduction in glomeruli as well as in a group that did not have a reduction in glomerular number, suggesting that a reduction in glomerular number is not the sole cause for the development of hypertension.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The risk of venous thromboembolism in women prescribed cyproterone acetate in combination with ethinyl estradiol: a nested cohort analysis and case-control study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Cyproterone acetate combined with ethinyl estradiol (CPA/EE) is licensed in the UK for the treatment of women with acne and hirsutism and is also a treatment option for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous studies have demonstrated an increased risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) associated with CPA/EE compared with conventional combined oral contraceptives (COCs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We believe the results of those studies may have been affected by residual confounding.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Using the General Practice Research Database we conducted a cohort analysis and case-control study nested within a population of women aged between 15 and 39 years with acne, hirsutism or PCOS to estimate the risk of VTE associated with CPA/EE. RESULTS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The age-adjusted incidence rate ratio for CPA/EE versus conventional COCs was 2.20 [95% confidence interval (CI) 1.35-3.58].</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using as the reference group women who were not using oral contraception, had no recent pregnancy or menopausal symptoms, the case-control analysis gave an adjusted odds ratio (OR(adj)) of 7.44 (95% CI 3.67-15.08) for CPA/EE use compared with an OR(adj) of 2.58 (95% CI 1.60-4.18) for use of conventional COCs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We have demonstrated an increased risk of VTE associated with the use of CPA/EE in women with acne, hirsutism or PCOS although residual confounding by indication cannot be excluded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pseudoacromegaly induced by the long-term use of minoxidil.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acromegaly is an endocrine disorder caused by chronic excessive growth hormone secretion from the anterior pituitary gland.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Significant disfiguring changes occur as a result of bone, cartilage, and soft tissue hypertrophy, including the thickening of the skin, coarsening of facial features, and cutis verticis gyrata.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pseudoacromegaly, on the other hand, is the presence of similar acromegaloid features in the absence of elevated growth hormone or insulin-like growth factor levels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We present a patient with pseudoacromegaly that resulted from the long-term use of minoxidil at an unusually high dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is the first case report of pseudoacromegaly as a side effect of minoxidil use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Combined androgen blockade-induced anemia in prostate cancer patients without bone involvement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND: To determine the onset and extent of combined androgen blockade (CAB)-induced anemia in prostate cancer patients without bone involvement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Forty-two patients with biopsy-proven prostatic adenocarcinoma [26 with stage C (T3N0M0) and 16 with stage D1 (T3N1M0)] were included in this study.</Chemical>

<Chemical>All patients received CAB [leuprolide acetate (LHRH-A) 3.75 mg, intramuscularly, every 28 days plus 250 mg flutamide, tid, per Os] and were evaluated for anemia by physical examination and laboratory tests at baseline and 4 subsequent intervals (1, 2, 3 and 6 months post-CAB).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hb, PSA and Testosterone measurements were recorded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients with stage D2-3 disease, abnormal hemoglobin level or renal and liver function tests that were higher than the upper limits were excluded from the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The duration of the study was six months.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: The mean hemoglobin (Hb) levels were significantly declined in all patients from baseline of 14.2 g/dl to 14.0 g/dl, 13.5 g/dl, 13.2 g/dl and 12.7 g/dl at 1, 2, 3 and 6 months post-CAB, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Severe and clinically evident anemia of Hb < 11 g/dl with clinical symptoms was detected in 6 patients (14.3%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>This CAB-induced anemia was normochromic and normocytic.</Chemical>

<Chemical>At six months post-CAB, patients with severe anemia had a Hb mean value of 10.2 +/- 0.1 g/dl (X +/- SE), whereas the other patients had mild anemia with Hb mean value of 13.2 +/- 0.17 (X +/- SE).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The development of severe anemia at 6 months post-CAB was predictable by the reduction of Hb baseline value of more than 2.5 g/dl after 3 months of CAB (p = 0.01).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The development of severe CAB-induced anemia in prostate cancer patients did not correlate with T baseline values (T < 3 ng/ml versus T > or = 3 ng/ml), with age (< 76 yrs versus > or = 76 yrs), and clinical stage (stage C versus stage D1).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Severe and clinically evident anemia was easily corrected by subcutaneous injections (3 times/week for 1 month) of recombinant erythropoietin (rHuEPO-beta).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Our data suggest that rHuEPO-beta correctable CAB-induced anemia occurs in 14.3% of prostate cancer patients after 6 months of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reversible dilated cardiomyopathy related to amphotericin B therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe a patient who developed dilated cardiomyopathy and clinical congestive heart failure after 2 months of therapy with amphotericin B (AmB) for disseminated coccidioidomycosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>His echocardiographic abnormalities and heart failure resolved after posaconazole was substituted for AmB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is important to recognize the rare and potentially reversible toxicity of AmB.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Risks of the consumption of beverages containing quinine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although the United States Food and Drug Administration banned its use for nocturnal leg cramps due to lack of safety and efficacy, quinine is widely available in beverages including tonic water and bitter lemon.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Numerous anecdotal reports suggest that products containing quinine may produce neurological complications, including confusion, altered mental status, seizures, and coma, particularly in older women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Psychologists need to inquire about consumption of quinine-containing beverages as part of an evaluation process.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Organophosphate-induced convulsions and prevention of neuropathological damages.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Such organophosphorus (OP) compounds as diisopropylfluorophosphate (DFP), sarin and soman are potent inhibitors of acetylcholinesterases (AChEs) and butyrylcholinesterases (BChEs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The acute toxicity of OPs is the result of their irreversible binding with AChEs in the central nervous system (CNS), which elevates acetylcholine (ACh) levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The protective action of subcutaneously (SC) administered antidotes or their combinations in DFP (2.0 mg/kg BW) intoxication was studied in 9-10-weeks-old Han-Wistar male rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rats received AChE reactivator pralidoxime-2-chloride (2PAM) (30.0 mg/kg BW), anticonvulsant diazepam (2.0 mg/kg BW),</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A(1)-adenosine receptor agonist N(6)-cyclopentyl</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>adenosine (CPA) (2.0 mg/kg BW), NMDA-receptor antagonist dizocilpine maleate (+-MK801 hydrogen maleate) (2.0 mg/kg BW) or their combinations with cholinolytic drug atropine sulfate (50.0 mg/kg BW) immediately or 30 min after the single SC injection of DFP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The control rats received atropine sulfate, but also saline and olive oil instead of other antidotes and DFP, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All rats were terminated either 24 h or 3 weeks after the DFP injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rats treated with DFP-atropine showed severe typical OP-induced toxicity signs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>When CPA, diazepam or 2PAM was given immediately after DFP-atropine, these treatments prevented, delayed or shortened the occurrence of serious signs of poisoning.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Atropine-MK801 did not offer any additional protection against DFP toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, CPA, diazepam and 2PAM in combination with atropine prevented the occurrence of serious signs of poisoning and thus reduced the toxicity of DFP in rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Differential modulation by estrogen of alpha2-adrenergic and I1-imidazoline receptor-mediated hypotension in female rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have recently shown that estrogen negatively modulates the hypotensive effect of clonidine (mixed alpha2-/I1-receptor agonist) in female rats and implicates the cardiovascular autonomic control in this interaction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study investigated whether this effect of estrogen involves interaction with alpha2- and/or I1-receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Changes evoked by a single intraperitoneal injection of rilmenidine (600 microg/kg) or alpha-methyldopa (100 mg/kg), selective I1- and alpha2-receptor agonists, respectively, in blood pressure, hemodynamic variability, and locomotor activity were assessed in radiotelemetered sham-operated and ovariectomized (Ovx) Sprague-Dawley female rats with or without 12-wk estrogen replacement.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three time domain indexes of hemodynamic variability were employed: the standard deviation of mean arterial pressure as a measure of blood pressure variability and the standard deviation of beat-to-beat intervals (SDRR) and the root mean square of successive differences in R-wave-to-R-wave intervals as measures of heart rate variability.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In sham-operated rats, rilmenidine or alpha-methyldopa elicited similar hypotension that lasted at least 5 h and was associated with reductions in standard deviation of mean arterial pressure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>SDRR was reduced only by alpha-methyldopa.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ovx significantly enhanced the hypotensive response to alpha-methyldopa, in contrast to no effect on rilmenidine hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The enhanced alpha-methyldopa hypotension in Ovx rats was paralleled with further reduction in SDRR and a reduced locomotor activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Estrogen replacement (17beta-estradiol subcutaneous pellet, 14.2 microg/day, 12 wk) of Ovx rats restored the hemodynamic and locomotor effects of alpha-methyldopa to sham-operated levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that estrogen downregulates alpha2- but not I1-receptor-mediated hypotension and highlight a role for the cardiac autonomic control in alpha-methyldopa-estrogen interaction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cardioprotective effect of tincture of Crataegus on isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tincture of Crataegus (TCR), an alcoholic extract of the berries of hawthorn (Crataegus oxycantha), is used in herbal and homeopathic medicine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was done to investigate the protective effect of TCR on experimentally induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pretreatment of TCR, at a dose of 0.5 mL/100</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>g bodyweight per day, orally for 30 days, prevented the increase in lipid peroxidation and activity of marker enzymes observed in isoproterenol-induced rats (85 mg kg(-1) s. c. for 2 days at an interval of 24 h).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>TCR prevented the isoproterenol-induced decrease in antioxidant enzymes in the heart and increased the rate of ADP-stimulated oxygen uptake and respiratory coupling ratio.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>TCR protected against pathological changes induced by isoproterenol in rat heart.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results show that pretreatment with TCR may be useful in preventing the damage induced by isoproterenol in rat heart.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Safety and adverse effects associated with raloxifene: multiple outcomes of raloxifene evaluation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To examine the effect of raloxifene on major adverse events that occur with postmenopausal estrogen therapy or tamoxifen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The Multiple Outcomes of Raloxifene Evaluation, a multicenter, randomized, double-blind trial, enrolled 7,705 postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Women were randomly assigned to raloxifene 60 mg/d or 120 mg/d or placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Outcomes included venous thromboembolism, cataracts, gallbladder disease, and endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>During a mean follow-up of 3.3 years, raloxifene was associated with an increased risk for venous thromboembolism (relative risk [RR] 2.1; 95% confidence interval</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>[CI] 1.2-3.8).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The excess event rate was 1.8 per 1,000 woman-years (95% CI -0.5-4.1), and the number needed to treat to cause 1 event was 170 (95% CI 100-582) over 3.3 years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Risk in the raloxifene group was higher than in the placebo group for the first 2 years, but decreased to about the same rate as in the placebo group thereafter.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Raloxifene did not increase risk for cataracts (RR 0.9; 95% CI 0.8-1.1), gallbladder disease (RR 1.0; 95% CI 0.7-1.3), endometrial hyperplasia (RR 1.3; 95% CI 0.4-5.1), or endometrial cancer (RR 0.9; 95% CI 0.3-2.7).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Raloxifene was associated with an increased risk for venous thromboembolism, but there was no increased risk for cataracts, gallbladder disease, endometrial hyperplasia, or endometrial cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>LEVEL OF EVIDENCE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>I</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ceftriaxone-associated biliary pseudolithiasis in paediatric surgical patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is well known that ceftriaxone leads to pseudolithiasis in some patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical and experimental studies also suggest that situations causing gallbladder dysfunction, such as fasting, may have a role for the development of pseudolithiasis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study, we prospectively evaluated the incidence and clinical importance of pseudolithiasis in paediatric surgical patients receiving ceftriaxone treatment, who often had to fast in the post-operative period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifty children who were given ceftriaxone were evaluated by serial abdominal sonograms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of those, 13 (26%) developed biliary pathology.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Comparison of the patients with or without pseudolithiasis revealed no significant difference with respect to age, sex, duration of the treatment and starvation variables.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After cessation of the treatment, pseudolithiasis resolved spontaneously within a short period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of pseudolithiasis is not affected by fasting.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Evaluation of the anticocaine monoclonal antibody GNC92H2 as an immunotherapy for cocaine overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The illicit use of cocaine continues in epidemic proportions and treatment for cocaine overdose remains elusive.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Current protein-based technology offers a new therapeutic venue by which antibodies bind the drug in the blood stream, inactivating its toxic effects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The therapeutic potential of the anticocaine antibody GNC92H2 was examined using a model of cocaine overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Swiss albino mice prepared with intrajugular catheters were tested in photocell cages after administration of 93 mg/kg (LD50) of cocaine and GNC92H2 infusions ranging from 30 to 190 mg/kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>GNC92H2 was delivered 30 min before, concomitantly or 3 min after cocaine treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Significant blockade of cocaine toxicity was observed with the higher dose of GNC92H2 (190 mg/kg), where premorbid behaviors were reduced up to 40%, seizures up to 77% and death by 72%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Importantly, GNC92H2 prevented death even post-cocaine injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results support the important potential of GNC92H2 as a therapeutic tool against cocaine overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of short-term raloxifene therapy on fibrinolysis markers: TAFI, tPA, and PAI-1.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Markers of fibrinolysis, thrombin-activatable fibrinolysis inhibitor (TAFI), tissue-type plasminogen activator (tPA), and plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1) levels were studied for the evaluation of short-term effects of raloxifene administration in postmenopausal women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Thirty-nine postmenopausal women with osteopenia or osteoporosis were included in this prospective, controlled clinical study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twenty-five women were given raloxifene hydrochloride (60 mg/day) plus calcium (500 mg/day).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Age-matched controls (n = 14) were given only calcium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma TAFI, tPA, and PAI-1 antigen levels were measured at baseline and after 3 months of treatment by commercially available ELISA kits.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Variations of individuals were assessed by Wilcoxon's test.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Relationship between those markers and demographic characteristics were investigated.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: Three months of raloxifene treatment was associated with a significant decrease in the plasma TAFI antigen concentrations (16% change, P < 0.01), and a significant increase in tPA antigen concentrations (25% change, P < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant correlation was found between baseline TAFI antigen concentrations and the duration of amenorrhea (P < 0.05; r = 0.33).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We suggest that the increased risk of venous thromboembolism due to raloxifene treatment may be related to increased tPA levels, but not TAFI levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketoconazole induced torsades de pointes without concomitant use of QT interval-prolonging drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketoconazole is not known to be proarrhythmic without concomitant use of QT interval-prolonging drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a woman with coronary artery disease who developed a markedly prolonged QT interval and torsades de pointes (TdP) after taking ketoconazole for treatment of fungal infection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Her QT interval returned to normal upon withdrawal of ketoconazole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Genetic study did not find any mutation in her genes that encode cardiac IKr channel proteins.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We postulate that by virtue of its direct blocking action on IKr, ketoconazole alone may prolong QT interval and induce TdP. This calls for attention when ketoconazole is administered to patients with risk factors for acquired long QT syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pharmacological evidence for the potential of Daucus carota in the management of cognitive dysfunctions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The present study was aimed at investigating the effects of Daucus carota seeds on cognitive functions, total serum cholesterol levels and brain cholinesterase activity in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The ethanolic extract of Daucus carota seeds (DCE) was administered orally in three doses (100, 200, 400 mg/kg) for seven successive days to different groups of young and aged mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Elevated plus maze and passive avoidance apparatus served as the exteroceptive behavioral models for testing memory.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Diazepam-, scopolamine- and ageing-induced amnesia served as the interoceptive behavioral models.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DCE (200, 400 mg/kg, p.o.) showed significant improvement in memory scores of young and aged mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The extent of memory improvement evoked by DCE was 23% at the dose of 200 mg/kg and 35% at the dose of 400 mg/kg in young mice using elevated plus maze.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Similarly, significant improvements in memory scores were observed using passive avoidance apparatus and aged mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Furthermore, DCE reversed the amnesia induced by scopolamine (0.4 mg/kg, i.p.)</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>and diazepam (1 mg/kg, i.p.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Daucus carota extract (200, 400 mg/kg, p.o.) reduced significantly the brain acetylcholinesterase activity and cholesterol levels in young and aged mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The extent of inhibition of brain cholinesterase activity evoked by DCE at the dose of 400 mg/kg was 22% in young and 19% in aged mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was a remarkable reduction in total cholesterol level as well, to the extent of 23% in young and 21% in aged animals with this dose of DCE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, DCE may prove to be a useful remedy for the management of cognitive dysfunctions on account of its multifarious beneficial effects such as, memory improving property, cholesterol lowering property and anticholinesterase activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cauda equina syndrome after epidural steroid injection: a case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: Conventional treatment methods of lumbusacral radiculopathy are physical therapy, epidural steroid injections, oral medications, and spinal manipulative therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cauda equina syndrome is a rare complication of epidural anesthesia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The following case is a report of cauda equina syndrome possibly caused by epidural injection of triamcinolone and bupivacaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CLINICAL FEATURES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 50-year-old woman with low back and right leg pain was scheduled for epidural steroid injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>INTERVENTION AND OUTCOME: An 18-gauge Touhy needle was inserted until loss of resistance occurred at the L4-5 level.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Spread of the contrast medium within the epidural space was determined by radiographic imaging.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After verifying the epidural space, bupivacaine and triamcinolone diacetate were injected.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After the injection, there was a reduction in radicular symptoms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Three hours later, she complained of perineal numbness and lower extremity weakness.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The neurologic evaluation revealed loss of sensation in the saddle area and medial aspect of her right leg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was a decrease in the perception of pinprick test.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Deep-tendon reflexes were decreased especially in the right leg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>She was unable to urinate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient's symptoms improved slightly over the next few hours.</Chemical>
<Chemical>She had a gradual return of motor function and ability of feeling Foley catheter.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All of the symptoms were completely resolved over the next 8 hours.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Complications associated with epidural steroid injections are rare.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical examination and continued vigilance for neurologic deterioration after epidural steroid injections is important.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>High-dose testosterone is associated with atherosclerosis in postmenopausal women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To study the long-term effects of androgen treatment on atherosclerosis in postmenopausal women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In a population-based study in 513 naturally postmenopausal women aged 54-67 years, we studied the association between self-reported intramuscularly administered high-dose estrogen-testosterone therapy (estradiol- and testosterone esters) and aortic atherosclerosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Aortic atherosclerosis was diagnosed by radiographic detection of calcified deposits in the abdominal aorta, which have been shown to reflect intima atherosclerosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hormone therapy users were compared with never users.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Intramuscular hormone therapy use for 1 year or longer was reported by 25 women.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In almost half of these women severe atherosclerosis of the aorta was present (n=11), while in women without hormone use severe atherosclerosis of the aorta was present in less than 20% (OR 3.1; 95% CI, 1.1-8.5, adjusted for age, years since menopause, smoking, and body mass index).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The association remained after additional adjustment for diabetes, cholesterol level, systolic blood pressure, or alcohol use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>No association was found for hormone use less than 1 year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results suggest that high-dose testosterone therapy may adversely affect atherosclerosis in postmenopausal women and indicate that androgen replacement in these women may not be harmless.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sirolimus-associated proteinuria and renal dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sirolimus is a novel immunosuppressant with potent antiproliferative actions through its ability to inhibit the raptor-containing mammalian target of rapamycin protein kinase.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sirolimus represents a major therapeutic advance in the prevention of acute renal allograft rejection and chronic allograft nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Its role in the therapy of glomerulonephritis, autoimmunity, cystic renal diseases and renal cancer is under investigation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Because sirolimus does not share the vasomotor renal adverse effects exhibited by calcineurin inhibitors, it has been designated a 'non-nephrotoxic drug'.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, clinical reports suggest that, under some circumstances, sirolimus is associated with proteinuria and acute renal dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A common risk factor appears to be presence of pre-existing chronic renal damage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mechanisms of sirolimus-associated proteinuria are multifactorial and may be due to an increase in glomerular capillary pressure following calcineurin inhibitor withdrawal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It has also been suggested that sirolimus directly causes increased glomerular permeability/injury, but evidence for this mechanism is currently inconclusive.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The acute renal dysfunction associated with sirolimus (such as in delayed graft function) may be due to suppression of compensatory renal cell proliferation and survival/repair processes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although these adverse effects occur in some patients, their occurrence could be minimised by knowledge of the molecular effects of sirolimus on the kidney, the use of sirolimus in appropriate patient populations, close monitoring of proteinuria and renal function, use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers if proteinuria occurs and withdrawal if needed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further long-term analysis of renal allograft studies using sirolimus as de novo immunosuppression along with clinical and laboratory studies will refine these issues in the future.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Progressive myopathy with up-regulation of MHC-I associated with statin therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Statins can cause a necrotizing myopathy and hyperCKaemia which is reversible on cessation of the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>What is less well known is a phenomenon whereby statins may induce a myopathy, which persists or may progress after stopping the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We investigated the muscle pathology in 8 such cases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All had myofibre necrosis but only 3 had an inflammatory infiltrate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In all cases there was diffuse or multifocal up-regulation of MHC-I expression even in non-necrotic fibres.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Progressive improvement occurred in 7 cases after commencement of prednisolone and methotrexate, and in one case spontaneously.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These observations suggest that statins may initiate an immune-mediated myopathy that persists after withdrawal of the drug and responds to immunosuppressive therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism of this myopathy is uncertain but may involve the induction by statins of an endoplasmic reticulum stress response with associated up-regulation of MHC-I expression and antigen presentation by muscle fibres.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Direct inhibition of cardiac hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated pacemaker channels by clonidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Inhibition of cardiac sympathetic tone represents an important strategy for treatment of cardiovascular disease, including arrhythmia, coronary heart disease, and chronic heart failure.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Activation of presynaptic alpha2-adrenoceptors is the most widely accepted mechanism of action of the antisympathetic drug clonidine; however, other target proteins have been postulated to contribute to the in vivo actions of clonidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS AND RESULTS: To test whether clonidine elicits pharmacological effects independent of alpha2-adrenoceptors, we have generated mice with a targeted deletion of all 3 alpha2-adrenoceptor subtypes (alpha2ABC-/-).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Alpha2ABC-/- mice were completely unresponsive to the analgesic and hypnotic effects of clonidine; however, clonidine significantly lowered heart rate in alpha2ABC-/- mice by up to 150 bpm.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clonidine-induced bradycardia in conscious alpha2ABC-/- mice was 32.3% (10 microg/kg) and 26.6% (100 microg/kg) of the effect in wild-type mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A similar bradycardic effect of clonidine was observed in isolated spontaneously beating right atria from alpha2ABC-knockout and wild-type mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clonidine inhibited the native pacemaker current (I(f)) in isolated sinoatrial node pacemaker cells and the I(f)-generating hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) 2 and HCN4 channels in transfected HEK293 cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>As a consequence of blocking I(f), clonidine reduced the slope of the diastolic depolarization and the frequency of pacemaker potentials in sinoatrial node cells from wild-type and alpha2ABC-knockout mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Direct inhibition of cardiac HCN pacemaker channels contributes to the bradycardic effects of clonidine gene-targeted mice in vivo, and thus, clonidine-like drugs represent novel structures for future HCN channel inhibitors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Influence of smoking on developing cochlea. Does smoking during pregnancy affect the amplitudes of transient evoked otoacoustic emissions in newborns?</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Maternal tobacco smoking has negative effects on fetal growth.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The influence of smoking during pregnancy on the developing cochlea has not been estimated, although smoking has been positively associated with hearing loss in adults.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The objective of this study was to determine the effects of maternal smoking on transient evoked otoacoustic emissions (TEOAEs) of healthy neonates.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study was undertaken as part of neonatal screening for hearing impairment and involved both ears of 200 newborns.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Newborns whose mothers reported smoking during pregnancy (n=200 ears) were compared to a control group of newborns (n=200 ears), whose mothers were non-smokers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Exposure to tobacco was characterized as low (<5 cigarettes per day, n=88 ears), moderate (5< or =cigarettes per day<10, n=76) or high (> or =10 cigarettes per day, n=36).</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In exposed neonates, TEOAEs mean response (across frequency) and mean amplitude at 4000Hz was significantly lower than in non-exposed neonates.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Comparisons between exposed newborns' subgroups revealed no significant differences.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, by comparing each subgroup to control group, we found statistically significant decreases of TEOAEs amplitudes at 4000Hz for all three groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mean TEOAEs responses of highly exposed newborns were also significantly lower in comparison to our control group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In utero, exposure to tobacco smoking seems to have a small impact on outer hair cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These effects seem to be equally true for all exposed newborns, regardless of the degree of exposure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Further studies are needed in order to establish a potential negative effect of maternal smoking on the neonate's hearing acuity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neuroinflammation and behavioral abnormalities after neonatal terbutaline treatment in rats: implications for autism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder presenting before 3 years of age with deficits in communication and social skills and repetitive behaviors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition to genetic influences, recent studies suggest that prenatal drug or chemical exposures are risk factors for autism.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Terbutaline, a beta2-adrenoceptor agonist used to arrest preterm labor, has been associated with increased concordance for autism in dizygotic twins.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We studied the effects of terbutaline on microglial activation in different brain regions and behavioral outcomes in developing rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Newborn rats were given terbutaline (10 mg/kg) daily on postnatal days (PN) 2 to 5 or PN 11 to 14 and examined 24 h after the last dose and at PN 30.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immunohistochemical studies showed that administration of terbutaline on PN 2 to 5 produced a robust increase in microglial activation on PN 30 in the cerebral cortex, as well as in cerebellar and cerebrocortical white matter.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>None of these effects occurred in animals given terbutaline on PN 11 to 14.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In behavioral tests, animals treated with terbutaline on PN 2 to 5 showed consistent patterns of hyper-reactivity to novelty and aversive stimuli when assessed in a novel open field, as well as in the acoustic startle response test.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our findings indicate that beta2-adrenoceptor overstimulation during an early critical period results in microglial activation associated with innate neuroinflammatory pathways and behavioral abnormalities, similar to those described in autism.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study provides a useful animal model for understanding the neuropathological processes underlying autism spectrum disorders.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute myocarditis associated with clozapine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A case of acute myocarditis associated with the commencement of clozapine is described, highlighting the onset, course and possible contributing factors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There is an urgent need to raise awareness about this potentially fatal complication of clozapine use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 20-year-old male with schizophrenia developed a sudden onset of myocarditis after commencement of clozapine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient recovered with intensive medical support.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The symptoms occurred around 2 weeks after starting clozapine in an inpatient setting.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Possible contributing factors may have been concomitant antidepressant use and unaccustomed physical activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myocarditis is an increasingly recognized complication associated with the use of clozapine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It can be fatal if not recognized and treated early.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Considering that clozapine remains the gold standard in treatment of resistant psychosis, there is an urgent need to raise awareness among medical and paramedical staff involved in the care of these patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There are also implications for recommendations and regulations regarding the use of clozapine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Encephalopathy induced by levetiracetam added to valproate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We report on the manifestation of a levetiracetam (LEV)-induced encephalopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>FINDINGS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 28-year-old man suffering from idiopathic epilepsy with generalized seizures was treated with LEV (3000 mg) added to valproate (VPA) (2000 mg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Frequency of generalized tonic-clonic seizures increased from one per 6 months to two per month.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neuropsychological testing showed impaired word fluency, psychomotor speed and working memory.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The interictal electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a generalized slowing to 5 per second theta rhythms with bilateral generalized high-amplitude discharges.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OUTCOME:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Following discontinuation of LEV, EEG and neuropsychological findings improved and seizure frequency decreased.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Norepinephrine signaling through beta-adrenergic receptors is critical for expression of cocaine-induced anxiety.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cocaine is a widely abused psychostimulant that has both rewarding and aversive properties.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>While the mechanisms underlying cocaine's rewarding effects have been studied extensively, less attention has been paid to the unpleasant behavioral states induced by cocaine, such as anxiety.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study, we evaluated the performance of dopamine beta-hydroxylase knockout (Dbh -/-) mice, which lack norepinephrine (NE), in the elevated plus maze (EPM) to examine the contribution of noradrenergic signaling to cocaine-induced anxiety.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We found that cocaine dose-dependently increased anxiety-like behavior in control (Dbh +/-) mice, as measured by a decrease in open arm exploration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The Dbh -/- mice had normal baseline performance in the EPM but were completely resistant to the anxiogenic effects of cocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cocaine-induced anxiety was also attenuated in Dbh +/- mice following administration of disulfiram, a dopamine beta-hydroxylase (DBH) inhibitor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In experiments using specific adrenergic antagonists, we found that pretreatment with the beta-adrenergic receptor antagonist propranolol blocked cocaine-induced anxiety-like behavior in Dbh +/- and wild-type C57BL6/J mice, while the alpha(1) antagonist prazosin and the alpha(2) antagonist yohimbine had no effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: These results indicate that noradrenergic signaling via beta-adrenergic receptors is required for cocaine-induced anxiety in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clonidine for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder: II. ECG changes and adverse events analysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To examine the safety and tolerability of clonidine used alone or with methylphenidate in children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In a 16-week multicenter, double-blind trial, 122 children with ADHD were randomly assigned to clonidine (n = 31), methylphenidate (n = 29), clonidine and methylphenidate (n = 32), or placebo (n = 30).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Doses were flexibly titrated up to 0.6 mg/day for clonidine and 60 mg/day for methylphenidate (both with divided dosing).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Groups were compared regarding adverse events and changes from baseline to week 16 in electrocardiograms and vital signs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>There were more incidents of bradycardia in subjects treated with clonidine compared with those not treated with clonidine (17.5% versus 3.4%; p =.02), but no other significant group differences regarding electrocardiogram and other cardiovascular outcomes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were no suggestions of interactions between clonidine and methylphenidate regarding cardiovascular outcomes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moderate or severe adverse events were more common in subjects on clonidine (79.4% versus 49.2%; p =.0006) but not associated with higher rates of early study withdrawal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Drowsiness was common on clonidine, but generally resolved by 6 to 8 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Clonidine, used alone or with methylphenidate, appears safe and well tolerated in childhood ADHD.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Physicians prescribing clonidine should monitor for bradycardia and advise patients about the high likelihood of initial drowsiness.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thalidomide has limited single-agent activity in relapsed or refractory indolent non-Hodgkin lymphomas: a phase II trial of the Cancer and Leukemia Group B.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory agent with demonstrated activity in multiple myeloma, mantle cell lymphoma and lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Its activity is believed to be due modulation of the tumour milieu, including downregulation of angiogenesis and inflammatory cytokines.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Between July 2001 and April 2004, 24 patients with relapsed/refractory indolent lymphomas received thalidomide 200 mg daily with escalation by 100 mg daily every 1-2 weeks as tolerated, up to a maximum of 800 mg daily.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients had received a median of 2 (range, 1-4) prior regimens.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of 24 evaluable patients, two achieved a complete remission and one achieved a partial remission for an overall response rate of 12.5% (95% confidence interval: 2.6-32.4%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Eleven patients progressed during therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Grade 3-4 adverse effects included myelosuppression, fatigue, somnolence/depressed mood, neuropathy and dyspnea.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of concern was the occurrence of four thromboembolic events.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results failed to demonstrate an important response rate to single agent thalidomide in indolent lymphomas and contrast with the higher activity level reported with the second generation immunomodulatory agent, lenalidomide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intracavernous epinephrine: a minimally invasive treatment for priapism in the emergency department.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Priapism is the prolonged erection of the penis in the absence of sexual arousal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 45-year-old man, an admitted frequent cocaine user, presented to the Emergency Department (ED) on two separate occasions with a history of priapism after cocaine use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The management options in the ED, as exemplified by four individual case reports, in particular the use of a minimally invasive method of intracorporal epinephrine instillation, are discussed.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Effect of green tea and vitamin E combination in isoproterenol induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was aimed to investigate the combined effects of green tea and vitamin E on heart weight, body weight, serum marker enzymes, lipid peroxidation, endogenous antioxidants and membrane bound ATPases in isoproterenol (ISO)-induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adult male albino rats, treated with ISO (200 mg/kg, s.c.) for 2 days at an interval of 24 h caused a significant (P<0.05) elevation of heart weight, serum marker enzymes, lipid peroxidation and Ca+2 ATPase level whereas there was a significant (P<0.05) decrease in body weight, endogenous antioxidants, Na+/ K+ ATPase and Mg+2 ATPase levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of green tea (100 mg/kg/day, p.o.) and vitamin E (100 mg/kg/day, p.o.) together for 30 consecutive days and challenged with ISO on the day 29th and 30th, showed a significant (P<0.05) decrease in heart weight, serum marker enzymes, lipid peroxidation, Ca+2 ATPase and a significant increase in the body weight, endogenous antioxidants, Na+/K+ ATPase and Mg+2 ATPase when compared with ISO treated group and green tea or vitamin E alone treated groups.</Chemical>

Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings indicate the synergistic protective effect of green tea and vitamin E during ISO induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Development of ocular myasthenia during pegylated interferon and ribavirin treatment for chronic hepatitis C.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A 63-year-old male experienced sudden diplopia after 9 weeks of administration of pegylated interferon (IFN) alpha-2b and ribavirin for chronic hepatitis C (CHC).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ophthalmologic examinations showed ptosis on the right upper lid and restricted right eye movement without any other neurological signs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A brain imaging study and repetitive nerve stimulation test indicated no abnormality.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The patient's ophthalmological symptoms improved rapidly 3 weeks after discontinuation of pegylated IFN alpha-2b and ribavirin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The ocular myasthenia associated with combination therapy of pegylated IFN alpha-2b and ribavirin for CHC is very rarely reported; therefore, we present this case with a review of the various eye complications of IFN therapy.</Chemical>
