text: <Chemical>The glycine transporter-1 inhibitor SSR103800 displays a selective and specific antipsychotic-like profile in normal and transgenic mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Schizophrenia has been initially associated with dysfunction in dopamine neurotransmission.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the observation that antagonists of the glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor produce schizophrenic-like symptoms in humans has led to the idea of a dysfunctioning of the glutamatergic system via its NMDA receptor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>As a result, there is a growing interest in the development of pharmacological agents with potential antipsychotic properties that enhance the activity of the glutamatergic system via a modulation of the NMDA receptor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among them are glycine transporter-1 (GlyT1) inhibitors such as SSR103800, which indirectly enhance NMDA receptor function by increasing the glycine (a co-agonist for the NMDA receptor) levels in the synapse.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study aimed at investigating the potential antipsychotic-like properties of SSR103800, with a particular focus on models of hyperactivity, involving either drug challenge (ie, amphetamine and MK-801) or transgenic mice (ie, NMDA Nr1(neo-/-) and DAT(-/-)).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Results showed that SSR103800 (10-30 mg/kg p.o.) blocked hyperactivity induced by the non-competitive NMDA receptor antagonist, MK-801 and partially reversed spontaneous hyperactivity of NMDA Nr1(neo-/-) mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, SSR103800 failed to affect hyperactivity induced by amphetamine or naturally observed in dopamine transporter (DAT(-/-)) knockout mice (10-30 mg/kg p.o.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Importantly, both classical (haloperidol) and atypical (olanzapine, clozapine and aripiprazole) antipsychotics were effective in all these models of hyperactivity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, unlike these latter, SSR103800 did not produce catalepsy (retention on the bar test) up to 30 mg/kg p.o.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Together these findings show that the GlyT1 inhibitor, SSR103800, produces antipsychotic-like effects, which differ from those observed with compounds primarily targeting the dopaminergic system, and has a reduced side-effect potential as compared with these latter drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phenylephrine but not ephedrine reduces frontal lobe oxygenation following anesthesia-induced hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Vasopressor agents are used to correct anesthesia-induced hypotension.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We describe the effect of phenylephrine and ephedrine on frontal lobe oxygenation (S(c)O(2)) following anesthesia-induced hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Following induction of anesthesia by fentanyl (0.15 mg kg(-1)) and propofol (2.0 mg kg(-1)), 13 patients received phenylephrine (0.1 mg iv) and 12 patients received ephedrine (10 mg iv) to restore mean arterial pressure (MAP).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Heart rate (HR), MAP, stroke volume (SV), cardiac output (CO), and frontal lobe oxygenation (S(c)O(2)) were registered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Induction of anesthesia was followed by a decrease in MAP, HR, SV, and CO concomitant with an elevation in S(c)O(2).</Chemical>
<Chemical>After administration of phenylephrine, MAP increased (51 +/- 12 to 81 +/- 13 mmHg; P < 0.001; mean +/- SD).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, a 14% (from 70 +/- 8% to 60 +/- 7%) reduction in S(c)O(2) (P < 0.05) followed with no change in CO (3.7 +/- 1.1 to 3.4 +/- 0.9 l min(-1)).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The administration of ephedrine led to a similar increase in MAP (53 +/- 9 to 79 +/- 8 mmHg; P < 0.001), restored CO (3.2 +/- 1.2 to 5.0 +/- 1.3 l min(-1)), and preserved S(c)O(2).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The utilization of phenylephrine to correct hypotension induced by anesthesia has a negative impact on S(c)O(2) while ephedrine maintains frontal lobe oxygenation potentially related to an increase in CO.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A novel, multiple symptom model of obsessive-compulsive-like behaviors in animals.</Chemical>

<Chemical>BACKGROUND: Current animal models of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) typically involve acute, drug-induced symptom provocation or a genetic association with stereotypies or anxiety.</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of these current models demonstrate multiple OCD-like behaviors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neonatal rats were treated with the tricyclic antidepressant clomipramine or vehicle between days 9 and 16 twice daily and behaviorally tested in adulthood.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Clomipramine exposure in immature rats produced significant behavioral and biochemical changes that include enhanced anxiety (elevated plus maze and marble burying), behavioral inflexibility (perseveration in the spontaneous alternation task and impaired reversal learning), working memory impairment (e.g., win-shift paradigm), hoarding, and corticostriatal dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dopamine D2 receptors were elevated in the striatum, whereas serotonin 2C, but not serotonin 1A, receptors were elevated in the orbital frontal cortex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This is the first demonstration of multiple symptoms consistent with an OCD-like profile in animals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Moreover, these behaviors are accompanied by biochemical changes in brain regions previously identified as relevant to OCD.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This novel model of OCD demonstrates that drug exposure during a sensitive period can program disease-like systems permanently, which could have implications for current and future therapeutic strategies for this and other psychiatric disorders.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Late recovery of renal function in a woman with the hemolytic uremic syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A case is reported of the hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in a woman taking oral contraceptives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>She was treated with heparin, dipyridamole and hemodialysis; and after more than three months, her urinary output rose above 500 ml; and six months after the onset of anuria, dialysis treatment was stopped.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This case emphasizes the possibility that HUS in adults is not invariably irreversible and that, despite prolonged oliguria, recovery of renal function can be obtained.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Therefore, in adult patients affected by HUS, dialysis should not be discontinued prematurely; moreover, bilateral nephrectomy, for treatment of severe hypertension and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, should be performed with caution.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A reproducible model for producing diffuse myocardial injury (epinephrine infusion) has been developed to study the cardioprotective effects of agents or maneuvers which might alter the evolution of acute myocardial infarction.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Infusions of epinephrine (4 mug per kilogram per minute for 6 hours) increased radiocalcium uptakes into intact myocardium and each of its subcellular components with the mitochondrial fraction showing the most consistent changes when compared to saline-infused control animals (4,957 vs. 827 counts per minute per gram of dried tissue or fraction).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>per liter failed to increase calcium influx into the myocardial cell.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Mitochondrial radiocalcium uptakes were significantly decreased in animals pretreated with acetylsalicylic acid or dipyridamole or when hydrocortisone was added to the epinephrine infusion (2,682,2,803, and 3,424 counts per minute per gram of dried fraction, respectively).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Myocardial calcium concentrations also were decreased (11.2, 8.3, and 8.9 mg.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>per 100 Gm. of fat-free dry weight, respectively) in the three treatment groups, being significantly decreased only in the last two.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Evidence of microscopic damage was graded as less severe in the three treatment groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acetylsalicylic acid, dipyridamole, and hydrocortisone all appear to have cardioprotective effects when tested in this model.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Changes in depressive status associated with topical beta-blockers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Depression and sexual dysfunction have been related to side effects of topical beta-blockers.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We performed a preliminary study in order to determine any difference between a non selective beta-blocker (timolol) and a selective beta-blocker (betaxolol) regarding CNS side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Eight glaucomatous patients chronically treated with timolol 0.5%/12h, suffering from depression diagnosed through DMS-III-R criteria, were included in the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During the six-month follow up, depression was quantified through the Beck and Zung-Conde scales every two months.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In a double blind cross-over study with control group, the patients under timolol treatment presented higher depression values measured through the Beck and the Zung-Conde scales (p < 0.001 vs control).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that betaxolol could be less of a depression-inducer than timolol in predisposed patients.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Long-term follow-up of ifosfamide renal toxicity in children treated for malignant mesenchymal tumors: an International Society of Pediatric Oncology report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The renal function of 74 children with malignant mesenchymal tumors in complete remission and who have received the same ifosfamide chemotherapy protocol (International Society of Pediatric Oncology Malignant Mesenchymal Tumor Study 84</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>[SIOP MMT 84]) were studied 1 year after the completion of treatment.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>[IVA]).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>None of them had received cisplatin chemotherapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ages ranged from 4 months to 17 years; 58 patients were males and 42 females.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifty-eight patients (78%) had normal renal tests, whereas 16 patients (22%) had renal abnormalities.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Two subsets of patients were identified from this latter group: the first included four patients (5% of the total population) who developed major toxicity resulting in Fanconi's syndrome (TDFS); and the second group included five patients with elevated beta 2 microglobulinuria and low phosphate reabsorption.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The remaining seven patients had isolated beta 2 microglobulinuria.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>This low percentage (5%) of TDFS must be evaluated with respect to the efficacy of ifosfamide in the treatment of mesenchymal tumors in children.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Evidence for an involvement of D1 and D2 dopamine receptors in mediating nicotine-induced hyperactivity in rats.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Previous studies have suggested that repeated exposure of rats to the drug or to the experimental environment is necessary to observe nicotine-induced locomotor stimulation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study the role of habituation to the experimental environment on the stimulant effect of nicotine in rats was examined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, the role of dopamine receptors in mediating nicotine-induced locomotor stimulation was investigated by examining the effects of selective D1 and D2 dopamine receptor antagonists on activity induced by nicotine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This article reports the changes in gallbladder function examined by ultrasonography in 20 Chinese patients with active acromegaly treated with sc injection of the somatostatin analog octreotide in dosages of 300-1500 micrograms/day for a mean of 24.2 +/- 13.9 months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During treatment with octreotide, 17 patients developed sludge, 10 had gallstones, and 1 developed acute cholecystitis requiring surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In all of 7 patients examined acutely, gallbladder contractility was inhibited after a single 100-micrograms injection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 8 patients followed for 24 weeks, gallbladder contractility remained depressed throughout therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After withdrawal of octreotide in 10 patients without gallstones, 8 patients assessed had return of normal gallbladder contractility within 1 month.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 8 of the remaining 10 patients who developed gallstones during treatment, gallbladder contractility normalized in 5 patients (3 of whom has disappearance of their stones within 3 weeks), and remained depressed in 3 (2 of whom had stones present at 6 months).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results suggest that the suppression of gallbladder contractility is the cause of the successive formation of bile sludge, gallstones, and cholecystitis during octreotide therapy in Chinese acromegalic patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is therefore very important to follow the changes of gallbladder function during long-term octreotide therapy of acromegalic patients.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Morphological features of encephalopathy after chronic administration of the antiepileptic drug valproate to rats. A transmission electron microscopic study of capillaries in the cerebellar cortex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Long-term intragastric application of the antiepileptic drug sodium valproate (Vupral "Polfa") at the effective dose of 200 mg/kg b. w. once daily to rats for 1, 3, 6, 9 and 12 months revealed neurological disorders indicating cerebellum damage ("valproate encephalopathy").</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The first ultrastructural changes in structural elements of the blood-brain-barrier (BBB) in the cerebellar cortex were detectable after 3 months of the experiment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>They became more severe in the later months of the experiment, and were most severe after 12 months, located mainly in the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lesions of the capillary included necrosis of endothelial cells.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Organelles of these cells, in particular the mitochondria (increased number and size, distinct degeneration of their matrix and cristae) and Golgi apparatus were altered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reduced size of capillary lumen and occlusion were caused by swollen endothelial cells which had luminal protrusions and swollen microvilli.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pressure on the vessel wall was produced by enlarged perivascular astrocytic processes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fragments of necrotic endothelial cells were in the vascular lumens and in these there was loosening and breaking of tight cellular junctions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Damage to the vascular basement lamina was also observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Damage to the capillary was accompanied by marked damage to neuroglial cells, mainly to perivascular processes of astrocytes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The proliferation of astrocytes (Bergmann's in particular) and occasionally of oligodendrocytes was found.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Alterations in the structural elements of the BBB coexisted with marked lesions of neurons of the cerebellum (Purkinje cells are earliest).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In electron micrographs both luminal and antiluminal sides of the BBB of the cerebellar cortex had similar lesions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possible influence of the hepatic damage, mainly hyperammonemia, upon the development of valproate encephalopathy is discussed.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Limited studies in animals indicate potential hepatotoxicity of some of these compounds.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We investigated an epidemic of liver disease in nine industrial workers who had had repeated accidental exposure to a mixture of 1,1-dichloro-2,2,2-trifluoroethane (HCFC 123) and 1-chloro-1,2,2,2-tetrafluoroethane (HCFC 124).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All nine exposed workers were affected to various degrees.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We aimed to test whether HCFCs 123 and 124 can result in serious liver disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The serum of six affected workers and five controls was tested for autoantibodies that react with human liver cytochrome-P450 2E1 (P450 2E1) and P58 protein disulphide isomerase isoform (P58).</Chemical>
<Chemical>FINDINGS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The liver biopsy sample showed hepatocellular necrosis which was prominent in perivenular zone three and extended focally from portal tracts to portal tracts and centrilobular areas (bridging necrosis).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Autoantibodies against P450 2E1 or P58, previously associated with halothane hepatitis, were detected in the serum of five affected workers.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Although the exact mechanism of hepatotoxicity of these agents is not known, the results suggest that trifluoroacetyl-altered liver proteins are involved.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In view of the potentially widespread use of these compounds, there is an urgent need to develop safer alternatives.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The surgery and anaesthesia were uneventful, but 3 days after surgery, the patient reported an area of hypoaesthesia over L3-L4 dermatomes of the leg which had been operated on (loss of pinprick sensation) without reduction in muscular strength.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tamoxifen (TAM), the antiestrogenic drug most widely prescribed in the chemotherapy of breast cancer, induces changes in normal discoid shape of erythrocytes and hemolytic anemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This work evaluates the effects of TAM on isolated human erythrocytes, attempting to identify the underlying mechanisms on TAM-induced hemolytic anemia and the involvement of biomembranes in its cytostatic action mechanisms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>TAM induces hemolysis of erythrocytes as a function of concentration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The extension of hemolysis is variable with erythrocyte samples, but 12.5 microM TAM induces total hemolysis of all tested suspensions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite inducing extensive erythrocyte lysis, TAM does not shift the osmotic fragility curves of erythrocytes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The hemolytic effect of TAM is prevented by low concentrations of alpha-tocopherol (alpha-T) and alpha-tocopherol acetate (alpha-TAc) (inactivated functional hydroxyl) indicating that TAM-induced hemolysis is not related to oxidative membrane damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This was further evidenced by absence of oxygen consumption and hemoglobin oxidation both determined in parallel with TAM-induced hemolysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, it was observed that TAM inhibits the peroxidation of human erythrocytes induced by AAPH, thus ruling out TAM-induced cell oxidative stress.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hemolysis caused by TAM was not preceded by the leakage of K(+) from the cells, also excluding a colloid-osmotic type mechanism of hemolysis, according to the effects on osmotic fragility curves.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, TAM induces release of peripheral proteins of membrane-cytoskeleton and cytosol proteins essentially bound to band 3.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Either alpha-T or alpha-TAc increases membrane packing and prevents TAM partition into model membranes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These effects suggest that the protection from hemolysis by tocopherols is related to a decreased TAM incorporation in condensed membranes and the structural damage of the erythrocyte membrane is consequently avoided.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, TAM-induced hemolysis results from a structural perturbation of red cell membrane, leading to changes in the framework of the erythrocyte membrane and its cytoskeleton caused by its high partition in the membrane.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These defects explain the abnormal erythrocyte shape and decreased mechanical stability promoted by TAM, resulting in hemolytic anemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Additionally, since membrane leakage is a final stage of cytotoxicity, the disruption of the structural characteristics of biomembranes by TAM may contribute to the multiple mechanisms of its anticancer action.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>They suggest that, in normal conscious rats, the central tachycardia of bromocriptine appears to predominate and to mask the bradycardia of this agonist at peripheral dopamine D2 receptors.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>A developmental analysis of clonidine's effects on cardiac rate and ultrasound production in infant rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Under controlled conditions, infant rats emit ultrasonic vocalizations during extreme cold exposure and after administration of the alpha(2) adrenoceptor agonist, clonidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous investigations have determined that, in response to clonidine, ultrasound production increases through the 2nd-week postpartum and decreases thereafter.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Given that sympathetic neural dominance exhibits a similar developmental pattern, and given that clonidine induces sympathetic withdrawal and bradycardia, we hypothesized that clonidine's developmental effects on cardiac rate and ultrasound production would mirror each other.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, in the present experiment, the effects of clonidine administration (0.5 mg/kg) on cardiac rate and ultrasound production were examined in 2-, 8-, 15-, and 20-day-old rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Age-related changes in ultrasound production corresponded with changes in cardiovascular variables, including baseline cardiac rate and clonidine-induced bradycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This experiment is discussed with regard to the hypothesis that ultrasound production is the acoustic by-product of a physiological maneuver that compensates for clonidine's detrimental effects on cardiovascular function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Differential effects of systemically administered ketamine and lidocaine on dynamic and static hyperalgesia induced by intradermal capsaicin in humans.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have examined the effect of systemic administration of ketamine and lidocaine on brush-evoked (dynamic) pain and punctate-evoked (static) hyperalgesia induced by capsaicin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study, we studied 12 volunteers in three experiments.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Capsaicin 100 micrograms was injected intradermally on the volar forearm followed by an i.v. infusion of ketamine (bolus 0.1 mg kg-1 over 10 min followed by infusion of 7 micrograms kg-1 min-1), lidocaine 5 mg kg-1 or saline for 50 min. Infusion started 15 min after injection of capsaicin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The following were measured: spontaneous pain, pain evoked by punctate and brush stimuli (VAS), and areas of brush-evoked and punctate-evoked hyperalgesia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ketamine reduced both the area of brush-evoked and punctate-evoked hyperalgesia significantly and it tended to reduce brush-evoked pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lidocaine reduced the area of punctate-evoked hyperalgesia significantly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It tended to reduce VAS scores of spontaneous pain but had no effect on evoked pain.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The differential effects of ketamine and lidocaine on static and dynamic hyperalgesia suggest that the two types of hyperalgesia are mediated by separate mechanisms and have a distinct pharmacology.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cyclosporine and tacrolimus-associated thrombotic microangiopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The development of thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) associated with the use of cyclosporine has been well documented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatments have included discontinuation or reduction of cyclosporine dose with or without concurrent plasma exchange, plasma infusion, anticoagulation, and intravenous immunoglobulin G infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, for recipients of organ transplantation, removing the inciting agent is not without the attendant risk of precipitating acute rejection and graft loss.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The last decade has seen the emergence of tacrolimus as a potent immunosuppressive agent with mechanisms of action virtually identical to those of cyclosporine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>As a result, switching to tacrolimus has been reported to be a viable therapeutic option in the setting of cyclosporine-induced TMA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>With the more widespread application of tacrolimus in organ transplantation, tacrolimus-associated TMA has also been recognized.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, literature regarding the incidence of the recurrence of TMA in patients exposed sequentially to cyclosporine and tacrolimus is limited.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of a living donor renal transplant recipient who developed cyclosporine-induced TMA that responded to the withdrawal of cyclosporine in conjunction with plasmapheresis and fresh frozen plasma replacement therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Introduction of tacrolimus as an alternative immunosuppressive agent resulted in the recurrence of TMA and the subsequent loss of the renal allograft.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients who are switched from cyclosporine to tacrolimus or vice versa should be closely monitored for the signs and symptoms of recurrent TMA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Repeated transient anuria following losartan administration in a patient with a solitary kidney.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report the case of a 70-year-old hypertensive man with a solitary kidney and chronic renal insufficiency who developed two episodes of transient anuria after losartan administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>He was hospitalized for a myocardial infarction with pulmonary edema, treated with high-dose diuretics.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Due to severe systolic dysfunction losartan was prescribed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Surprisingly, the first dose of 50 mg of losartan resulted in a sudden anuria, which lasted eight hours despite high-dose furosemide and amine infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One week later, by mistake, losartan was prescribed again and after the second dose of 50 mg, the patient developed a second episode of transient anuria lasting 10 hours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During these two episodes, his blood pressure diminished but no severe hypotension was noted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ultimately, an arteriography showed a 70-80% renal artery stenosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this patient, renal artery stenosis combined with heart failure and diuretic therapy certainly resulted in a strong activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Under such conditions, angiotensin II receptor blockade by losartan probably induced a critical fall in glomerular filtration pressure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This case report highlights the fact that the angiotensin II receptor antagonist losartan can cause serious unexpected complications in patients with renovascular disease and should be used with extreme caution in this setting.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In vivo protection of dna damage associated apoptotic and necrotic cell deaths during acetaminophen-induced nephrotoxicity, amiodarone-induced lung toxicity and doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by a novel IH636 grape seed proanthocyanidin extract.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Grape seed extract, primarily a mixture of proanthocyanidins, has been shown to modulate a wide-range of biological, pharmacological and toxicological effects which are mainly cytoprotective.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study assessed the ability of IH636 grape seed proanthocyanidin extract (GSPE) to prevent acetaminophen (AAP)-induced nephrotoxicity, amiodarone (AMI)-induced lung toxicity, and doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiotoxicity in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Experimental design consisted of four groups: control (vehicle alone), GSPE alone, drug alone and GSPE+drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>For the cytoprotection study, animals were orally gavaged 100 mg/Kg GSPE for 7-10 days followed by i.p. injections of organ specific three drugs (AAP: 500 mg/Kg for 24 h; AMI: 50 mg/Kg/day for four days; DOX: 20 mg/Kg for 48 h).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Parameters of study included analysis of serum chemistry (ALT, BUN and CPK), and orderly fragmentation of genomic DNA (both endonuclease-dependent and independent) in addition to microscopic evaluation of damage and/or protection in corresponding PAS stained tissues.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Results indicate that GSPE preexposure prior to AAP, AMI and DOX, provided near complete protection in terms of serum chemistry changes (ALT, BUN and CPK), and significantly reduced DNA fragmentation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Histopathological examination of kidney, heart and lung sections revealed moderate to massive tissue damage with a variety of morphological aberrations by all the three drugs in the absence of GSPE preexposure than in its presence.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>GSPE+drug exposed tissues exhibited minor residual damage or near total recovery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Additionally, histopathological alterations mirrored both serum chemistry changes and the pattern of DNA fragmentation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Interestingly, all the drugs, such as, AAP, AMI and DOX induced apoptotic death in addition to necrosis in the respective organs which was very effectively blocked by GSPE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since AAP, AMI and DOX undergo biotransformation and are known to produce damaging radicals in vivo, the protection by GSPE may be linked to both inhibition of metabolism and/or detoxification of cytotoxic radicals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, its' presumed contribution to DNA repair may be another important attribute, which played a role in the chemoprevention process.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Additionally, this may have been the first report on AMI-induced apoptotic death in the lung tissue.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Taken together, these events undoubtedly establish GSPE's abundant bioavailability, and the power to defend multiple target organs from toxic assaults induced by structurally diverse and functionally different entities in vivo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Palpebral twitching in a depressed adolescent on citalopram.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Current estimates suggest that between 0.4% and 8.3% of children and adolescents are affected by major depression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We report a favorable response to treatment with citalopram by a 15-year-old boy with major depression who exhibited palpebral twitching during his first 2 weeks of treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This may have been a side effect of citalopram as it remitted with redistribution of doses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Metamizol potentiates morphine antinociception but not constipation after chronic treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This work evaluates the antinociceptive and constipating effects of the combination of 3.2 mg/kg s.c. morphine with 177.8 mg/kg s.c. metamizol in acutely and chronically treated (once a day for 12 days) rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the 13th day, antinociceptive effects were assessed using a model of inflammatory nociception, pain-induced functional impairment model, and the charcoal meal test was used to evaluate the intestinal transit.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Simultaneous administration of morphine with metamizol resulted in a markedly antinociceptive potentiation and an increasing of the duration of action after a single (298+/-7 vs. 139+/-36 units area (ua); P<0.001) and repeated administration (280+/-17 vs. 131+/-22 ua; P<0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antinociceptive effect of morphine was reduced in chronically treated rats (39+/-10 vs. 18+/-5 au) while the combination-induced antinociception was remained similar as an acute treatment (298+/-7 vs. 280+/-17 au).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acute antinociceptive effects of the combination were partially prevented by 3.2 mg/kg naloxone s.c. (P<0.05), suggesting the partial involvement of the opioidergic system in the synergism observed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In independent groups, morphine inhibited the intestinal transit in 48+/-4% and 38+/-4% after acute and chronic treatment, respectively, suggesting that tolerance did not develop to the constipating effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The combination inhibited intestinal transit similar to that produced by morphine regardless of the time of treatment, suggesting that metamizol did not potentiate morphine-induced constipation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings show a significant interaction between morphine and metamizol in chronically treated rats, suggesting that this combination could be useful for the treatment of chronic pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ifosfamide encephalopathy presenting with asterixis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CNS toxic effects of the antineoplastic agent ifosfamide (IFX) are frequent and include a variety of neurological symptoms that can limit drug use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of a 51-year-old man who developed severe, disabling negative myoclonus of the upper and lower extremities after the infusion of ifosfamide for plasmacytoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>He was awake, revealed no changes of mental status and at rest there were no further motor symptoms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cranial magnetic resonance imaging and extensive laboratory studies failed to reveal structural lesions of the brain and metabolic abnormalities.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An electroencephalogram showed continuous, generalized irregular slowing with admixed periodic triphasic waves indicating symptomatic encephalopathy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The administration of ifosfamide was discontinued and within 12 h the asterixis resolved completely.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the patient described, the presence of asterixis during infusion of ifosfamide, normal laboratory findings and imaging studies and the resolution of symptoms following the discontinuation of the drug suggest that negative myoclonus is associated with the use of IFX.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sub-chronic low dose gamma-vinyl GABA (vigabatrin) inhibits cocaine-induced increases in nucleus accumbens dopamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RATIONALE: gamma-Vinyl GABA (GVG) irreversibly inhibits GABA-transaminase.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This non-receptor mediated inhibition requires de novo synthesis for restoration of functional GABA catabolism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Given its preclinical success for treating substance abuse and the increased risk of visual field defects (VFD) associated with cumulative lifetime exposure, we explored the effects of sub-chronic low dose GVG on cocaine-induced increases in nucleus accumbens (NAcc) dopamine (DA).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Using in vivo microdialysis, we compared acute exposure (450 mg/kg) to an identical sub-chronic exposure (150 mg/kg per day for 3 days), followed by 1- or 3-day washout.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Finally, we examined the low dose of 150 mg/kg (50 mg/kg per day) using a similar washout period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Sub-chronic GVG exposure inhibited the effect of cocaine for 3 days, which exceeded in magnitude and duration the identical acute dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Sub-chronic low dose GVG potentiates and extends the inhibition of cocaine-induced increases in dopamine, effectively reducing cumulative exposures and the risk for VFDS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amount of bleeding and hematoma size in the collagenase-induced intracerebral hemorrhage rat model.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aggravated risk on intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) with drugs used for stroke patients should be estimated carefully.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We therefore established sensitive quantification methods and provided a rat ICH model for detection of ICH deterioration.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In ICH intrastriatally induced by 0.014-unit, 0.070-unit, and 0.350-unit collagenase, the amount of bleeding was measured using a hemoglobin assay developed in the present study and was compared with the morphologically determined hematoma volume.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The blood amounts and hematoma volumes were significantly correlated, and the hematoma induced by 0.014-unit collagenase was adequate to detect ICH deterioration.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In ICH induction using 0.014-unit collagenase, heparin enhanced the hematoma volume 3.4-fold over that seen in control ICH animals and the bleeding 7.6-fold.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Data suggest that this sensitive hemoglobin assay is useful for ICH detection, and that a model with a small ICH induced with a low-dose collagenase should be used for evaluation of drugs that may affect ICH.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Estradiol reduces seizure-induced hippocampal injury in ovariectomized female but not in male rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Estrogens protect ovariectomized rats from hippocampal injury induced by kainic acid-induced status epilepticus (SE).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We compared the effects of 17beta-estradiol in adult male and ovariectomized female rats subjected to lithium-pilocarpine-induced SE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats received subcutaneous injections of 17beta-estradiol (2 microg/rat) or oil once daily for four consecutive days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>SE was induced 20 h following the second injection and terminated 3 h later.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The extent of silver-stained CA3 and CA1 hippocampal neurons was evaluated 2 days after SE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>17beta-Estradiol did not alter the onset of first clonus in ovariectomized rats but accelerated it in males.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>17beta-Estradiol reduced the argyrophilic neurons in the CA1 and CA3-C sectors of ovariectomized rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In males, estradiol increased the total damage score.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that the effects of estradiol on seizure threshold and damage may be altered by sex-related differences in the hormonal environment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Delirium during clozapine treatment: incidence and associated risk factors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Incidence and risk factors for delirium during clozapine treatment require further clarification.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We used computerized pharmacy records to identify all adult psychiatric inpatients treated with clozapine (1995-96), reviewed their medical records to score incidence and severity of delirium, and tested associations with potential risk factors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Subjects (n = 139) were 72 women and 67 men, aged 40.8 +/- 12.1 years, hospitalized for 24.9 +/- 23.3 days, and given clozapine, gradually increased to an average daily dose of 282 +/- 203 mg (3.45 +/- 2.45 mg/kg) for 18.9 +/- 16.4 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Delirium was diagnosed in 14 (10.1 % incidence, or 1.48 cases/person-years of exposure); 71.4 % of cases were moderate or severe.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Associated factors were co-treatment with other centrally antimuscarinic agents, poor clinical outcome, older age, and longer hospitalization (by 17.5 days, increasing cost); sex, diagnosis or medical co-morbidity, and daily clozapine dose, which fell with age, were unrelated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Delirium was found in 10 % of clozapine-treated inpatients, particularly in older patients exposed to other central anticholinergics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Delirium was inconsistently recognized clinically in milder cases and was associated with increased length-of-stay and higher costs, and inferior clinical outcome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ketoconazole-induced neurologic sequelae.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 77-y-old patient developed weakness of extremities, legs paralysis, dysarthria and tremor 1 h after ingestion of 200 mg ketoconazole for the first time in his life.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All complaints faded away within 24 h. Few days later, the patient used another 200 mg ketoconazole tablet, and within an hour experienced a similar clinical picture, which resolved again spontaneously within hours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Laboratory evaluations, including head CT scan, were normal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This case illustrates the need for close vigilance in adverse drug reactions, particularly in the elderly.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Noxious chemical stimulation of rat facial mucosa increases intracranial blood flow through a trigemino-parasympathetic reflex--an experimental model for vascular dysfunctions in cluster headache.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cluster headache is characterized by typical autonomic dysfunctions including facial and intracranial vascular disturbances.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Both the trigeminal and the cranial parasympathetic systems may be involved in mediating these dysfunctions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An experimental model was developed in the rat to measure changes in lacrimation and intracranial blood flow following noxious chemical stimulation of facial mucosa.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Blood flow was monitored in arteries of the exposed cranial dura mater and the parietal cortex using laser Doppler flowmetry.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Capsaicin (0.01-1 mm) applied to oral or nasal mucosa induced increases in dural and cortical blood flow and provoked lacrimation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These responses were blocked by systemic pre-administration of hexamethonium chloride (20 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The evoked increases in dural blood flow were also abolished by topical pre-administration of atropine (1 mm) and</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>[Lys1, Pro2,5, Arg3,4, Tyr6]-VIP (0.1 mm), a vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) antagonist, onto the exposed dura mater.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We conclude that noxious stimulation of facial mucosa increases intracranial blood flow and lacrimation via a trigemino-parasympathetic reflex.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The blood flow responses seem to be mediated by the release of acetylcholine and VIP within the meninges.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Similar mechanisms may be involved in the pathogenesis of cluster headache.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recurrent excitation in the dentate gyrus of a murine model of temporal lobe epilepsy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Similar to rats, systemic pilocarpine injection causes status epilepticus (SE) and the eventual development of spontaneous seizures and mossy fiber sprouting in C57BL/6</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>and CD1 mice, but the physiological correlates of these events have not been identified in mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Population responses in granule cells of the dentate gyrus were examined in transverse slices of the ventral hippocampus from pilocarpine-treated and untreated mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In Mg(2+)-free bathing medium containing bicuculline, conditions designed to increase excitability in the slices, electrical stimulation of the hilus resulted in a single population spike in granule cells from control mice and pilocarpine-treated mice that did not experience SE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In SE survivors, similar stimulation resulted in a population spike followed, at a variable latency, by negative DC shifts and repetitive afterdischarges of 3-60 s duration, which were blocked by ionotropic glutamate receptor antagonists.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Focal glutamate photostimulation of the granule cell layer at sites distant from the recording pipette resulted in population responses of 1-30 s duration in slices from SE survivors but not other groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data support the hypothesis that SE-induced mossy fiber sprouting and synaptic reorganization are relevant characteristics of seizure development in these murine strains, resembling rat models of human temporal lobe epilepsy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The alpha3 and beta4 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subunits are necessary for nicotine-induced seizures and hypolocomotion in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Binding of nicotine to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) elicits a series of dose-dependent behaviors that go from altered exploration, sedation, and tremors, to seizures and death.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>nAChRs are pentameric ion channels usually composed of alpha and beta subunits.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A gene cluster comprises the alpha3, alpha5 and beta4 subunits, which coassemble to form functional receptors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We examined the role of the beta4 subunits in nicotine-induced seizures and hypolocomotion in beta4 homozygous null (beta4 -/-) and alpha3 heterozygous (+/-) mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>beta4</Chemical>

<Chemical>-/- mice were less sensitive to the effects of nicotine both at low doses, measured as decreased exploration in an open field, and at high doses, measured as sensitivity to nicotine-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using in situ hybridization probes for the alpha3 and alpha5 subunits, we showed that alpha5 mRNA levels are unchanged, whereas alpha3 mRNA levels are selectively decreased in the mitral cell layer of the olfactory bulb, and the inferior and the superior colliculus of beta4 -/- brains.</Chemical>
<Chemical>alpha3 +/- mice were partially resistant to nicotine-induced seizures when compared to wild-type littermates.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>mRNA levels for the alpha5 and the beta4 subunits were unchanged in alpha3 +/- brains.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Together, these results suggest that the beta4 and the alpha3 subunits are mediators of nicotine-induced seizures and hypolocomotion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recurrent acute interstitial nephritis induced by azithromycin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 14-year-old girl is reported with recurrent, azithromycin-induced, acute interstitial nephritis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The second episode was more severe than the first; and although both were treated with intensive corticosteroid therapy, renal function remained impaired.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although most cases of antibiotic induced acute interstitial nephritis are benign and self-limited, some patients are at risk for permanent renal injury.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Valproate-induced encephalopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Valproate-induced encephalopathy is a rare syndrome that may manifest in otherwise normal epileptic individuals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It may even present in patients who have tolerated this medicine well in the past.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is usually but not necessarily associated with hyperammonemia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The EEG shows characteristic triphasic waves in most patients with this complication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A case of valproate-induced encephalopathy is presented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The problems in diagnosing this condition are subsequently discussed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nitro-L-arginine methyl ester: a potential protector against gentamicin ototoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The nitric oxide (NO) inhibitor nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME) may act as an otoprotectant against high-frequency hearing loss caused by gentamicin, but further studies are needed to confirm this.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Aminoglycoside antibiotics are still widely used by virtue of their efficacy and low cost.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Their ototoxicity is a serious health problem and, as their ototoxic mechanism involves the production of NO, we need to assess the use of NO inhibitors for the prevention of aminoglycoside-induced sensorineural hearing loss.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this experimental study we used 30 Sprague-Dawley rats, 27 of which had gentamicin instilled into the middle ear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The otoprotectant L-NAME was administered topically to 12/27 animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Its effect was determined in terms of attenuation of hearing loss, measured by shifts in the auditory brainstem response threshold.</Chemical>
<Chemical>L-NAME reduced gentamicin-induced hearing loss in the high-frequency range, but gave no protection in the middle or low frequencies.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cerebral vasculitis following oral methylphenidate intake in an adult: a case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methylphenidate is structurally and functionally similar to amphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cerebral vasculitis associated with amphetamine abuse is well documented, and in rare cases ischaemic stroke has been reported after methylphenidate intake in children.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report the case of a 63-year-old female who was treated with methylphenidate due to hyperactivity and suffered from multiple ischaemic strokes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We consider drug-induced cerebral vasculitis as the most likely cause of recurrent ischaemic strokes in the absence of any pathological findings during the diagnostic work-up.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We conclude that methylphenidate mediated vasculitis should be considered in patients with neurological symptoms and a history of methylphenidate therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This potential side-effect, though very rare, represents one more reason to be very restrictive in the use of methylphenidate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cerebral haemorrhage induced by warfarin - the influence of drug-drug interactions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>To evaluate the frequency, severity and preventability of warfarin-induced cerebral haemorrhages due to warfarin and warfarin-drug interactions in patients living in the county of Osterg  tland, Sweden.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients with a diagnosed cerebral haemorrhage at three hospitals during the period 2000-2002 were identified.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Medical records were studied retrospectively to evaluate whether warfarin and warfarin-drug interactions could have caused the cerebral haemorrhage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The proportion of possibly avoidable cases due to drug interactions was estimated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Among 593 patients with cerebral haemorrhage, 59 (10%) were assessed as related to warfarin treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This imply an incidence of 1.7/100,000 treatment years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of the 59 cases, 26 (44%) had a fatal outcome, compared to 136 (25%) among the non-warfarin patients (p < 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A warfarin-drug interaction could have contributed to the haemorrhage in 24 (41%) of the warfarin patients and in 7 of these (12%) the bleeding complication was considered being possible to avoid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Warfarin-induced cerebral haemorrhages are a major clinical problem with a high fatality rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Almost half of the cases was related to a warfarin-drug interaction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant proportion of warfarin-related cerebral haemorrhages might have been prevented if greater caution had been taken when prescribing drugs known to interact with warfarin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Side effects of postoperative administration of methylprednisolone and gentamicin into the posterior sub-Tenon's space.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>To assess the incidence of postoperative emetic side effects after the administration of methylprednisolone and gentamicin into the posterior sub-Tenon's space at the end of routine cataract surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>SETTING:</Chemical>
<Chemical>St. Luke's Hospital, Gwardamangia, Malta.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A double-blind double-armed prospective study comprised 40 patients who had uneventful sutureless phacoemulsification under sub-Tenon's local infiltration of 3 mL of plain lignocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At the end of the procedure, Group A (n = 20) had 20 mg/0.5 mL of methylprednisolone and 10 mg/0.5 mL of gentamicin injected into the posterior sub-Tenon's space and Group B (n = 20) had the same combination injected into the anterior sub-Tenon's space.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Postoperatively, all patients were assessed for symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and headache.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A chi-square test was used to assess the statistical significance of results.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Sixty percent in Group A developed postoperative emetic symptoms, headache, or both; 1 patient in Group B developed symptoms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The administration of methylprednisolone and gentamicin in the posterior sub-Tenon's space was related to a high incidence of side effects including nausea, vomiting, and headache.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All adverse effects were self-limiting.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cardiac Angiography in Renally Impaired Patients (CARE) study: a randomized double-blind trial of contrast-induced nephropathy in patients with chronic kidney disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>No direct comparisons exist of the renal tolerability of the low-osmolality contrast medium iopamidol with that of the iso-osmolality contrast medium iodixanol in high-risk patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The present study is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind comparison of iopamidol and iodixanol in patients with chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate, 20 to 59 mL/min) who underwent cardiac angiography or percutaneous coronary interventions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum creatinine (SCr) levels and estimated glomerular filtration rate were assessed at baseline and 2 to 5 days after receiving medications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The primary outcome was a postdose SCr increase > or = 0.5 mg/dL (44.2 micromol/L) over baseline.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Secondary outcomes were a postdose SCr increase > or = 25%, a postdose estimated glomerular filtration rate decrease of > or = 25%, and the mean peak change in SCr.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In 414 patients, contrast volume, presence of diabetes mellitus, use of N-acetylcysteine, mean baseline SCr, and estimated glomerular filtration rate were comparable in the 2 groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>SCr increases > or = 0.5 mg/dL occurred in 4.4% (9 of 204 patients) after iopamidol and 6.7% (14 of 210 patients) after iodixanol (P=0.39), whereas rates of SCr increases > or = 25% were 9.8% and 12.4%, respectively (P=0.44).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients with diabetes, SCr increases > or = 0.5 mg/dL were 5.1% (4 of 78 patients) with iopamidol and 13.0% (12 of 92 patients) with iodixanol (P=0.11), whereas SCr increases > or = 25% were 10.3% and 15.2%, respectively (P=0.37).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mean post-SCr increases were significantly less with iopamidol (all patients: 0.07 versus 0.12 mg/dL, 6.2 versus 10.6 micromol/L, P=0.03; patients with diabetes: 0.07 versus 0.16 mg/dL, 6.2 versus 14.1 micromol/L, P=0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The rate of contrast-induced nephropathy, defined by multiple end points, is not statistically different after the intraarterial administration of iopamidol or iodixanol to high-risk patients, with or without diabetes mellitus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Any true difference between the agents is small and not likely to be clinically significant.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A novel compound, maltolyl p-coumarate, attenuates cognitive deficits and shows neuroprotective effects in vitro and in vivo dementia models.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To develop a novel and effective drug that could enhance cognitive function and neuroprotection, we newly synthesized maltolyl p-coumarate by the esterification of maltol and p-coumaric acid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study, we investigated whether maltolyl p-coumarate could improve cognitive decline in scopolamine-injected rats and in amyloid beta peptide(1-42)-infused rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Maltolyl p-coumarate was found to attenuate cognitive deficits in both rat models using passive avoidance test and to reduce apoptotic cell death observed in the hippocampus of the amyloid beta peptide(1-42)-infused rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We also examined the neuroprotective effects of maltolyl p-coumarate in vitro using SH-SY5Y cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cells were pretreated with maltolyl p-coumarate, before exposed to amyloid beta peptide(1-42), glutamate or H2O2.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We found that maltolyl p-coumarate significantly decreased apoptotic cell death and reduced reactive oxygen species, cytochrome c release, and caspase 3 activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Taking these in vitro and in vivo results together, our study suggests that maltolyl p-coumarate is a potentially effective candidate against Alzheimer's disease that is characterized by wide spread neuronal death and progressive decline of cognitive function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Interaction between warfarin and levofloxacin: case series.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Warfarin is the most widely used oral anticoagulant and is indicated for many clinical conditions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Levofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, is one of the most commonly prescribed antibiotics in clinical practice and is effective against Gram-positive, Gram-negative, and atypical bacteria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>While small prospective studies have not revealed any significant drug-drug interaction between warfarin and levofloxacin, several case reports have indicated that levofloxacin may significantly potentiate the anticoagulation effect of warfarin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report 3 cases of serious bleeding complications that appear to be the result of the interaction between warfarin and levofloxacin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Physicians should be aware of this potential interaction and use caution when prescribing levofloxacin to patients taking warfarin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mutations associated with lamivudine-resistance in therapy-na  ve hepatitis B virus (HBV) infected patients with and without HIV co-infection: implications for antiretroviral therapy in HBV and HIV co-infected South African patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This was an exploratory study to investigate lamivudine-resistant hepatitis B virus (HBV) strains in selected lamivudine-na  ve HBV carriers with and without human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) co-infection in South African patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty-five lamivudine-na  ve HBV infected patients with or without HIV co-infection were studied: 15 chronic HBV mono-infected patients and 20 HBV-HIV co-infected patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The latter group was further sub-divided into 13 occult HBV (HBsAg-negative) and 7 overt HBV (HBsAg- positive) patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>HBsAg, anti-HBs, anti-HBc, and anti-HIV 1/2 were determined as part of routine diagnosis using Axsym assays (Abbott Laboratories, North Chicago, IL).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum samples were PCR amplified with HBV reverse transcriptase (RT) primers, followed by direct sequencing across the tyrosine-methionine-aspartate-aspartate (YMDD) motif of the major catalytic region in the C domain of the HBV RT enzyme.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>HBV viral load was performed with Amplicor HBV Monitor test v2.0</Chemical>
<Chemical>(Roche Diagnostics, Penzberg, Germany).</Chemical>
<Chemical>HBV lamivudine-resistant strains were detected in 3 of 15 mono-infected chronic hepatitis B patients and 10 of 20 HBV-HIV co-infected patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To the best of our knowledge, this constitutes the first report of HBV lamivudine-resistant strains in therapy-na  ve HBV-HIV co-infected patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The HBV viral loads for mono-infected and co-infected patients ranged from 3.32 x 10(2) to 3.82 x 10(7) and <200 to 4.40 x 10(3) copies/ml, respectively.</Chemical>

<Chemical>It remains to be seen whether such pre-existing antiviral mutations could result in widespread emergence of HBV resistant strains when lamivudine-containing highly active antiretroviral (ARV) treatment (HAART) regimens become widely applied in South Africa, as this is likely to have potential implications in the management of HBV-HIV co-infected patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sex differences in NMDA antagonist enhancement of morphine antihyperalgesia in a capsaicin model of persistent pain: comparisons to two models of acute pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In acute pain models, N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) antagonists enhance the antinociceptive effects of morphine to a greater extent in males than females.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of this investigation was to extend these findings to a persistent pain model which could be distinguished from acute pain models on the basis of the nociceptive fibers activated, neurochemical substrates, and duration of the nociceptive stimulus.</Chemical>

<Chemical>To this end, persistent hyperalgesia was induced by administration of capsaicin in the tail of gonadally intact F344 rats, following which the tail was immersed in a mildly noxious thermal stimulus, and tail-withdrawal latencies measured.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>For comparison, tests were conducted in two acute pain models, the hotplate and warm water tail-withdrawal procedures.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In males, the non-competitive NMDA antagonist dextromethorphan enhanced the antihyperalgesic effect of low to moderate doses of morphine in a dose-and time-dependent manner.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Across the doses and pretreatment times examined, enhancement was not observed in females.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Enhancement of morphine antinociception by dextromethorphan was seen in both males and females in the acute pain models, with the magnitude of this effect being greater in males.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings demonstrate a sexually-dimorphic interaction between NMDA antagonists and morphine in a persistent pain model that can be distinguished from those observed in acute pain models.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Development of proteinuria after switch to sirolimus-based immunosuppression in long-term cardiac transplant patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Calcineurin-inhibitor therapy can lead to renal dysfunction in heart transplantation patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The novel immunosuppressive (IS) drug sirolmus (Srl) lacks nephrotoxic effects; however, proteinuria associated with Srl has been reported following renal transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In cardiac transplantation, the incidence of proteinuria associated with Srl is unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this study, long-term cardiac transplant patients were switched from cyclosporine to Srl-based IS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Concomitant IS consisted of mycophenolate mofetil +/- steroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Proteinuria increased significantly from a median of 0.13 g/day (range 0-5.7) preswitch to 0.23 g/day (0-9.88) at 24 months postswitch (p = 0.0024).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Before the switch, 11.5% of patients had high-grade proteinuria (>1.0 g/day); this increased to 22.9% postswitch (p = 0.006).</Chemical>
<Chemical>ACE inhibitor and angiotensin-releasing blocker (ARB) therapy reduced proteinuria development.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients without proteinuria had increased renal function (median 42.5 vs. 64.1, p = 0.25), whereas patients who developed high-grade proteinuria showed decreased renal function at the end of follow-up (median 39.6 vs. 29.2, p = 0.125).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thus, proteinuria may develop in cardiac transplant patients after switch to Srl, which may have an adverse effect on renal function in these patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Srl should be used with ACEi/ARB therapy and patients monitored for proteinuria and increased renal dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Synthesis of N-pyrimidinyl-2-phenoxyacetamides as adenosine A2A receptor antagonists.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A series of N-pyrimidinyl-2-phenoxyacetamide adenosine A(2A) antagonists is described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>SAR studies led to compound 14 with excellent potency (K(i) = 0.4 nM), selectivity (A(1)/A(2A) > 100), and efficacy (MED 10 mg/kg p.o.) in the rat haloperidol-induced catalepsy model for Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methamphetamine-induced neurotoxicity and microglial activation are not mediated by fractalkine receptor signaling.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methamphetamine (METH) damages dopamine (DA) nerve endings by a process that has been linked to microglial activation but the signaling pathways that mediate this response have not yet been delineated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cardona et al.</Chemical>
<Chemical>[Nat. Neurosci.</Chemical>
<Chemical>9 (2006), 917] recently identified the microglial-specific fractalkine receptor (CX3CR1) as an important mediator of MPTP-induced neurodegeneration of DA neurons.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because the CNS damage caused by METH and MPTP is highly selective for the DA neuronal system in mouse models of neurotoxicity, we hypothesized that the CX3CR1 plays a role in METH-induced neurotoxicity and microglial activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mice in which the CX3CR1 gene has been deleted and replaced with a cDNA encoding enhanced green fluorescent protein (eGFP) were treated with METH and examined for striatal neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METH depleted DA, caused microglial activation, and increased body temperature in CX3CR1 knockout mice to the same extent and over the same time course seen in wild-type controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of METH in CX3CR1 knockout mice were not gender-dependent and did not extend beyond the striatum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Striatal microglia expressing eGFP constitutively show morphological changes after METH that are characteristic of activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This response was restricted to the striatum and contrasted sharply with unresponsive eGFP-microglia in surrounding brain areas that are not damaged by METH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude from these studies that CX3CR1 signaling does not modulate METH neurotoxicity or microglial activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, it appears that striatal-resident microglia respond to METH with an activation cascade and then return to a surveying state without undergoing apoptosis or migration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recovery of tacrolimus-associated brachial neuritis after conversion to everolimus in a pediatric renal transplant recipient--case report and review of the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>TAC has been shown to be a potent immunosuppressive agent for solid organ transplantation in pediatrics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neurotoxicity is a potentially serious toxic effect.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is characterized by encephalopathy, headaches, seizures, or neurological deficits.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Here, we describe an eight-and-a-half-yr-old male renal transplant recipient with right BN.</Chemical>
<Chemical>MRI demonstrated hyperintense T2 signals in the cervical cord and right brachial plexus roots indicative of both myelitis and right brachial plexitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Symptoms persisted for three months despite TAC dose reduction, administration of IVIG and four doses of methylprednisolone pulse therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Improvement and eventually full recovery only occurred after TAC was completely discontinued and successfully replaced by everolimus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
