text: <Chemical>Valvular heart disease in patients with Parkinson's disease treated with pergolide. Course following treatment modifications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Valvular heart abnormalities have been reported in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) treated with pergolide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the incidence and severity of these abnormalities vary from study to study and their course after drug withdrawal has not been systematically assessed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To estimate the frequency and severity of valvular heart abnormality and its possible reversibility after drug withdrawal in a case-control study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>All PD patients in the Amiens area treated with pergolide were invited to attend a cardiologic assessment including transthoracic echocardiography.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty PD patients participated in the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A second echocardiography was performed (median interval: 13 months) after pergolide withdrawal (n=10 patients).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Controls were age- and sex-matched non-PD patients referred to the cardiology department.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Compared to controls, aortic regurgitation (OR: 3.1; 95% IC: 1.1-8.8) and mitral regurgitation (OR: 10.7; 95% IC: 2.1-53) were more frequent in PD patients (tricuspid: NS).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The number of affected valves (n=2.4+/-0.7) and the sum of regurgitation grades (n=2.8+/-1.09) were higher (p=0.008 and p=0.006, respectively) in the pergolide group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Severity of regurgitation was not correlated with pergolide cumulative dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A restrictive pattern of valvular regurgitation, suggestive of the role of pergolide, was observed in 12/30 (40%) patients including two with heart failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pergolide was discontinued in 10 patients with valvular heart disease, resulting in a lower regurgitation grade (p=0.01) at the second transthoracic echocardiography and the two patients with heart failure returned to nearly normal clinical examination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study supports the high frequency of restrictive valve regurgitation in PD patients treated with pergolide and reveals that a significant improvement is usual when the treatment is converted to non-ergot dopamine agonists.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adverse effects of topical papaverine on auditory nerve function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Papaverine hydrochloride is a direct-acting vasodilator used to manage vasospasm during various neurosurgical operations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Transient cranial nerve dysfunction has been described in a few cases with topical papaverine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study supports previous reports and provides neurophysiological evidence of an adverse effect on the auditory nerve.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We conducted a retrospective review of 70 consecutive microvascular decompression operations and studied those patients who received topical papaverine for vasospasm.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Topical papaverine was used as a direct therapeutic action to manage vasospasm in a total of 11 patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The timing of papaverine application and ongoing operative events was reviewed relative to changes in neurophysiological recordings.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Brainstem auditory evoked potentials (BAEPs) were routinely used to monitor cochlear nerve function during these operations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>FINDINGS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A temporal relationship was found between topical papaverine and BAEP changes leading to complete waveform loss.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The average temporal delay between papaverine and the onset of an adverse BAEP change was 5 min.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 10 of 11 patients, BAEP waves II/III-V completely disappeared within 2 to 25 min after papaverine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Eight of these 10 patients had complete loss of BAEP waveforms within 10 min.</Chemical>
<Chemical>One patient showed no recovery of later waves and a delayed profound sensorineural hearing loss.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The average recovery time of BAEP waveforms to pre-papaverine baseline values was 39 min. CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Topical papaverine for the treatment of vasospasm was associated with the onset of a transient disturbance in neurophysiological function of the ascending auditory brainstem pathway.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The complete disappearance of BAEP waveforms with a consistent temporal delay suggests a possible adverse effect on the proximal eighth nerve.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recommendations to avoid potential cranial nerve deficits from papaverine are provided.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Massive proteinuria and acute renal failure after oral bisphosphonate (alendronate) administration in a patient with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 61-year-old Japanese man with nephrotic syndrome due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis was initially responding well to steroid therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The amount of daily urinary protein decreased from 15.6 to 2.8 g. Within 14 days of the oral bisphosphonate (alendronate sodium) administration, the amount of daily urinary protein increased rapidly up to 12.8 g with acute renal failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After discontinuing the oral alendronate, the patient underwent six cycles of hemodialysis and four cycles of LDL apheresis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urinary volume and serum creatinine levels recovered to the normal range, with urinary protein disappearing completely within 40 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This report demonstrates that not only intravenous, but also oral bisphosphonates can aggravate proteinuria and acute renal failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum- and glucocorticoid-inducible kinase 1 in doxorubicin-induced nephrotic syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Doxorubicin-induced nephropathy leads to epithelial sodium channel (ENaC)-dependent volume retention and renal fibrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aldosterone-sensitive serum- and glucocorticoid-inducible kinase SGK1 has been shown to participate in the stimulation of ENaC and to mediate renal fibrosis following mineralocorticoid and salt excess.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was performed to elucidate the role of SGK1 in the volume retention and fibrosis during nephrotic syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>To this end, doxorubicin (15 mug/g body wt) was injected intravenously into gene-targeted mice lacking SGK1 (sgk1(-/-)) and their wild-type littermates (sgk1(+/+)).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Doxorubicin treatment resulted in heavy proteinuria (>100 mg protein/mg crea) in 15/44 of sgk1(+/+) and 15/44 of sgk1(-/-) mice leading to severe nephrotic syndrome with ascites, lipidemia, and hypoalbuminemia in both genotypes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma aldosterone levels increased in nephrotic mice of both genotypes and was followed by increased SGK1 protein expression in sgk1(+/+) mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urinary sodium excretion reached signficantly lower values in sgk1(+/+) mice (15 +/- 5 mumol/mg crea) than in sgk1(-/-) mice (35 +/- 5 mumol/mg crea) and was associated with a significantly higher body weight gain in sgk1(+/+) compared with sgk1(-/-) mice (+6.6 +/- 0.7 vs. +4.1 +/- 0.8 g).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During the course of nephrotic syndrome, serum urea concentrations increased significantly faster in sgk1(-/-) mice than in sgk1(+/+)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>mice leading to uremia and a reduced median survival in sgk1(-/-) mice (29 vs. 40 days in sgk1(+/+) mice)</Chemical>
<Chemical>.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In conclusion, gene-targeted mice lacking SGK1 showed blunted volume retention, yet were not protected against renal fibrosis during experimental nephrotic syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Severe and long lasting cholestasis after high-dose co-trimoxazole treatment for Pneumocystis pneumonia in HIV-infected patients--a report of two cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), a common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals, is generally treated with high doses of co-trimoxazole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, treatment is often limited by adverse effects.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Here, we report two cases of severely immunocompromised HIV-infected patients who developed severe intrahepatic cholestasis, and in one patient lesions mimicking liver abscess formation on radiologic exams, during co-trimoxazole treatment for PCP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Whereas patient 1 showed lesions of up to 1 cm readily detectable on magnetic resonance imaging under prolonged co-trimoxazole treatment, therapy of patient 2 was switched early.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinically significant proteinuria following the administration of sirolimus to renal transplant recipients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sirolimus is the latest immunosuppressive agent used to prevent rejection, and may have less nephrotoxicity than calcineurin inhibitor (CNI)-based regimens.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To date there has been little documentation of clinically significant proteinuria linked with the use of sirolimus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have encountered several patients who developed substantial proteinuria associated with sirolimus use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In each patient, the close temporal association between the commencement of sirolimus therapy and proteinuria implicated sirolimus as the most likely etiology of the proteinuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We analyzed the clinical and laboratory information available for all 119 patients transplanted at the Washington Hospital Center between 1999-2003 for whom sirolimus was a component of their immunosuppressant regimen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In these patients, the magnitude of proteinuria was assessed on morning urine samples by turbidometric measurement or random urine protein:creatinine ratios, an estimate of grams of proteinuria/day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Laboratory results were compared between prior, during and following sirolimus use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Twenty-eight patients (24%) developed increased proteinuria from baseline during their post-transplantation course.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 21 patients an alternative cause of proteinuria was either obvious or insufficient data was available to be conclusive.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 7 of the 28 patients there was a striking temporal association between the initiation of sirolimus and the development of nephrotic-range proteinuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Proteinuria correlated most strongly with sirolimus therapy when compared to other demographic and clinical variables.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In most patients, discontinuation of sirolimus resulted in a decrease, but not resolution, of proteinuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sirolimus induces or aggravates pre-existing proteinuria in an unpredictable subset of renal allograft recipients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Proteinuria may improve, but does not resolve, when sirolimus is withdrawn.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Comparative cognitive and subjective side effects of immediate-release oxycodone in healthy middle-aged and older adults.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study measured the objective and subjective neurocognitive effects of a single 10-mg dose of immediate-release oxycodone in healthy, older (> 65 years), and middle-aged (35 to 55 years) adults who were not suffering from chronic or significant daily pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Seventy-one participants completed 2 separate study days and were blind to medication condition (placebo, 10-mg oxycodone).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma oxycodone concentration peaked between 60 and 90 minutes postdose (P < .01) and pupil size, an indication of physiological effects of the medication, peaked at approximately 90 to 120 minutes postdose (P < .01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Significant declines in simple and sustained attention, working memory, and verbal memory were observed at 1 hour postdose compared to baseline for both age groups with a trend toward return to baseline by 5 hours postdose.</Chemical>

<Chemical>For almost all cognitive measures, there were no medication by age-interaction effects, which indicates that the 2 age groups exhibited similar responses to the medication challenge.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study suggests that for healthy older adults who are not suffering from chronic pain, neurocognitive and pharmacodynamic changes in response to a 10-mg dose of immediate-release oxycodone are similar to those observed for middle-aged adults.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PERSPECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Study findings indicate that the metabolism, neurocognitive effects, and physical side effects of oral oxycodone are similar for healthy middle-aged and older adults.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, clinicians should not avoid prescribing oral opioids to older adults based on the belief that older adults are at higher risk for side effects than younger adults.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Normalizing effects of modafinil on sleep in chronic cocaine users.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The purpose of the present study was to determine the effect of morning-dosed modafinil on sleep and daytime sleepiness in chronic cocaine users.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD: Twenty cocaine-dependent participants were randomly assigned to receive modafinil, 400 mg (N=10), or placebo (N=10) every morning at 7:30 a.m. for 16 days in an inpatient, double-blind randomized trial.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Participants underwent polysomnographic sleep recordings on days 1 to 3, 7 to 9, and 14 to 16 (first, second, and third weeks of abstinence).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The Multiple Sleep Latency Test was performed at 11:30 a.m., 2:00 p.m., and 4:30 p.m. on days 2, 8, and 15.</Chemical>

<Chemical>For comparison of sleep architecture variables, 12 healthy comparison participants underwent a single night of experimental polysomnography that followed 1 night of accommodation polysomnography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Progressive abstinence from cocaine was associated with worsening of all measured polysomnographic sleep outcomes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with placebo, modafinil decreased nighttime sleep latency and increased slow-wave sleep time in cocaine-dependent participants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of modafinil interacted with the abstinence week and was associated with longer total sleep time and shorter REM sleep latency in the third week of abstinence.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Comparison of slow-wave sleep time, total sleep time, and sleep latency in cocaine-dependent and healthy participants revealed a normalizing effect of modafinil in cocaine-dependent participants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Modafinil was associated with increased daytime sleep latency, as measured by the Multiple Sleep Latency Test, and a nearly significant decrease in subjective daytime sleepiness.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Morning-dosed modafinil promotes nocturnal sleep, normalizes sleep architecture, and decreases daytime sleepiness in abstinent cocaine users.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These effects may be relevant in the treatment of cocaine dependence.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Efficacy and safety of asenapine in a placebo- and haloperidol-controlled trial in patients with acute exacerbation of schizophrenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Asenapine is approved by the Food and Drugs Administration in adults for acute treatment of schizophrenia or of manic or mixed episodes associated with bipolar I disorder with or without psychotic features.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a double-blind 6-week trial, 458 patients with acute schizophrenia were randomly assigned to fixed-dose treatment with asenapine at 5 mg twice daily (BID), asenapine at 10 mg BID, placebo, or haloperidol at 4 mg BID (to verify assay sensitivity).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>With last observations carried forward (LOCF), mean Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale total score reductions from baseline to endpoint were significantly greater with asenapine at 5 mg BID (-16.2) and haloperidol (-15.4) than placebo (-10.7; both P < 0.05); using mixed model for repeated measures (MMRM), changes at day 42 were significantly greater with asenapine at 5 and 10 mg BID (-21.3 and -19.4, respectively) and haloperidol (-20.0) than placebo (-14.6; all P < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale positive subscale, all treatments were superior to placebo with LOCF and MMRM; asenapine at 5 mg BID was superior to placebo on the negative subscale with MMRM and on the general psychopathology subscale with LOCF and MMRM.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment-related adverse events (AEs) occurred in 44% and 52%, 57%, and 41% of the asenapine at 5 and 10 mg BID, haloperidol, and placebo groups, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Extrapyramidal symptoms reported as AEs occurred in 15% and 18%, 34%, and 10% of the asenapine at 5 and 10 mg BID, haloperidol, and placebo groups, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Across all groups, no more than 5% of patients had clinically significant weight change.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Post hoc analyses indicated that efficacy was similar with asenapine and haloperidol; greater contrasts were seen in AEs, especially extrapyramidal symptoms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Permeability, ultrastructural changes, and distribution of novel proteins in the glomerular barrier in early puromycin aminonucleoside nephrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is still unclear what happens in the glomerulus when proteinuria starts.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Using puromycin aminonucleoside nephrosis (PAN) rats, we studied early ultrastructural and permeability changes in relation to the expression of the podocyte-associated molecules nephrin, a-actinin, dendrin, and plekhh2, the last two of which were only recently discovered in podocytes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Using immune stainings, semiquantitative measurement was performed under the electron microscope.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Permeability was assessed using isolated kidney perfusion with tracers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Possible effects of ACE inhibition were tested.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>By day 2, some patchy foot process effacement, but no proteinuria, appeared.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The amount of nephrin was reduced in both diseased and normal areas.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The other proteins showed few changes, which were limited to diseased areas.</Chemical>
<Chemical>By day 4, foot process effacement was complete and proteinuria appeared in parallel with signs of size barrier damage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nephrin decreased further, while dendrin and plekhh2 also decreased but a-actinin remained unchanged.</Chemical>
<Chemical>ACE inhibition had no significant protective effect.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>PAN glomeruli already showed significant pathology by day 4, despite relatively mild proteinuria.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was preceded by altered nephrin expression, supporting its pivotal role in podocyte morphology.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The novel proteins dendrin and plekhh2 were both reduced, suggesting roles in PAN, whereas a-actinin was unchanged.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twin preterm neonates with cardiac toxicity related to lopinavir/ritonavir therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report twin neonates who were born prematurely at 32 weeks of gestation to a mother with human immunodeficiency virus infection.</Chemical>

<Chemical>One of the twins developed complete heart block and dilated cardiomyopathy related to lopinavir/ritonavir therapy, a boosted protease-inhibitor agent, while the other twin developed mild bradycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We recommend caution in the use of lopinavir/ritonavir in the immediate neonatal period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Learning of rats under amnesia caused by pentobarbital.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dissociated learning of rats in the normal state and the state of amnesia produced by pentobarbital (15 mg/kg, ip) was carried out.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats were trained to approach a shelf where they received food reinforcement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In Group 1 the rats were trained under the influence of pentobarbital to run to the same shelf as in the normal state.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In Group 2 the rats were trained to approach different shelves in different drug states.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It was shown that memory dissociation occurred in both groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Differences in the parameters of training under the influence of pentobarbital between Groups 1 and 2 were revealed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings show that the brain-dissociated state induced by pentobarbital is formed with the participation of the mechanisms of information perception.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Angiosarcoma of the liver associated with diethylstilbestrol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Angiosarcoma of the liver occurred in a 76-year-old man who had been treated for a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma of the liver with diethylstilbestrol for 13 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Angiosarcoma was also present within pulmonary and renal arteries.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The possibility that the intraarterial lesions might represent independent primary tumors is considered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Role of xanthine oxidase in dexamethasone-induced hypertension in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>1.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Glucocorticoid-induced hypertension (GC-HT) in the rat is associated with nitric oxide-redox imbalance.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We studied the role of xanthine oxidase (XO), which is implicated in the production of reactive oxygen species, in dexamethasone-induced hypertension (dex-HT).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>3.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thirty male Sprague-Dawley rats were divided randomly into four treatment groups: saline, dexamethasone (dex), allopurinol plus saline, and allopurinol plus dex. 4.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Systolic blood pressures (SBP) and bodyweights were recorded each alternate day.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thymus weight was used as a marker of glucocorticoid activity, and serum urate to assess XO inhibition.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>5.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dex increased SBP (110 +/- 2-126 +/- 3 mmHg; P < 0.001) and decreased thymus (P < 0.001) and bodyweights (P" < 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Allopurinol decreased serum urate from 76 +/- 5 to 30 +/- 3 micromol/L (P < 0.001) in saline and from 84 +/- 13 to 28 +/- 2 micromol/L in dex-treated (P < 0.01) groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>6.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Allopurinol did not prevent dex-HT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This, together with our previous findings that allopurinol failed to prevent adrenocorticotrophic hormone induced hypertension, suggests that XO activity is not a major determinant of GC-HT in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Extrapyramidal side effects with risperidone and haloperidol at comparable D2 receptor occupancy levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Risperidone is an antipsychotic drug with high affinity at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2 receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous clinical studies have proposed that risperidone's pharmacologic profile may produce improved efficacy for negative psychotic symptoms and decreased propensity for extrapyramidal side effects; features shared by so-called 'atypical' neuroleptics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To determine if routine risperidone treatment is associated with a unique degree of D2 receptor occupancy and pattern of clinical effects, we used [123I]IBZM SPECT to determine D2 occupancy in subjects treated with routine clinical doses of risperidone (n = 12) or haloperidol (n = 7).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both risperidone and haloperidol produced D2 occupancy levels between approximately 60 and 90% at standard clinical doses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was no significant difference between occupancy levels obtained with haloperidol or risperidone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Drug-induced parkinsonism was observed in subjects treated with risperidone (42%) and haloperidol (29%) and was observed at occupancy levels above 60%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Based on these observations, it is concluded that 5-HT2 blockade obtained with risperidone at D2 occupancy rates of 60% and above does not appear to protect against the risk for extrapyramidal side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Simvastatin-ezetimibe-induced hepatic failure necessitating liver transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Abstract Serum aminotransferase elevations are a commonly known adverse effect of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A reductase inhibitor (statin) therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, hepatotoxic events have not been widely published with ezetimibe or the combination agent simvastatin-ezetimibe.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe a 70-year-old Hispanic woman who developed fulminant hepatic failure necessitating liver transplantation 10 weeks after conversion from simvastatin 40 mg/day to simvastatin 10 mg-ezetimibe 40 mg/day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient's lipid panel had been maintained with simvastatin for 18 months before the conversion without evidence of hepatotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A routine laboratory work-up 10 weeks after conversion revealed elevated serum aminotransferase levels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Simvastatinezetimibe and escitalopram (which she was taking for depression) were discontinued, and other potential causes of hepatotoxicity were excluded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A repeat work-up revealed further elevations in aminotransferase levels, and liver biopsy revealed evidence of moderate-to-severe drug toxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>She underwent liver transplantation with an uneventful postoperative course.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Her aminotransferase levels returned to normal by postoperative day 23, and her 2-year follow-up showed no adverse events.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ezetimibe undergoes extensive glucuronidation by uridine diphosphate glucoronosyltransferases (UGT) in the intestine and liver and may have inhibited the glucuronidation of simvastatin hydroxy acid, resulting in increased simvastatin exposure and subsequent hepatotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To our knowledge, this is the first case report of simvastatin-ezetimibe-induced liver failure that resulted in liver transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We postulate that the mechanism of the simvastatinezetimibe-induced hepatotoxicity is the increased simvastatin exposure by ezetimibe inhibition of UGT enzymes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinicians should be aware of potential hepatotoxicity with simvastatin-ezetimibe especially in elderly patients and should carefully monitor serum aminotransferase levels when starting therapy and titrating the dosage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oral manifestations of "meth mouth": a case report.</Chemical>
<Chemical>AIM:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim of the documentation of this clinical case is to make clinicians aware of "meth mouth" and the medical risks associated with this serious condition.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Methamphetamine is a very addictive, powerful stimulant that increases wakefulness and physical activity and can produce other effects such as cardiac dysrhythmias, hypertension, hallucinations, and violent behavior.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dental patients abusing methamphetamine can present with poor oral hygiene, xerostomia, rampant caries ("meth mouth"), and excessive tooth wear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oral rehabilitation of patients using methamphetamine can be challenging.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE DESCRIPTION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 30-year-old Caucasian woman presented with dental pain, bad breath, and self-reported poor esthetics.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A comprehensive examination including her medical history, panoramic radiograph, and intraoral examination revealed 19 carious lesions, which is not very common for a healthy adult.</Chemical>
<Chemical>She reported her use of methamphetamine for five years and had not experienced any major carious episodes before she started using the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>SUMMARY:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient's medical and dental histories along with radiographic and clinical findings lead to a diagnosis of "meth mouth."</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although three different dental treatment modalities (either conventional or implant-supported) have been offered to the patient since August 2007, the patient has yet to initiate any treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This clinical case showing oral manifestations of meth mouth was presented to help dental practitioners recognize and manage patients who may be abusing methamphetamines.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dental practitioners also may be skeptical about the reliability of appointment keeping by these patients, as they frequently miss their appointments without reasonable justification.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thyroxine abuse: an unusual case of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Eating disorders and the associated behavioural problems and drug abuse are uncommon in pregnancy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>When they do occur they are often unrecognized because of denial but when significant may pose a risk to both the mother and her fetus.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This case illustrates a number of problems that may be encountered in women with eating disorders in pregnancy, including prolonged and recurrent metabolic disturbances and diuretic abuse.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In particular it illustrates the derangements of thyroid function seen in pregnant women with eating disorders and reminds us that when a cause for thyrotoxicosis remains obscure, thyroxine abuse should be considered and explored.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Attenuation of methamphetamine-induced nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurotoxicity in mice by lipopolysaccharide pretreatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immunological activation has been proposed to play a role in methamphetamine-induced dopaminergic terminal damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this study, we examined the roles of lipopolysaccharide, a pro-inflammatory and inflammatory factor, treatment in modulating the methamphetamine-induced nigrostriatal dopamine neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lipopolysaccharide pretreatment did not affect the basal body temperature or methamphetamine-elicited hyperthermia three days later.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Such systemic lipopolysaccharide treatment mitigated methamphetamine-induced striatal dopamine and 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid depletions in a dose-dependent manner.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>As the most potent dose (1 mg/kg) of lipopolysaccharide was administered two weeks, one day before or after the methamphetamine dosing regimen, methamphetamine-induced striatal dopamine and 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid depletions remained unaltered.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, systemic lipopolysaccharide pretreatment (1 mg/kg) attenuated local methamphetamine infusion-produced dopamine and 3,4-dihydroxyphenylacetic acid depletions in the striatum, indicating that the protective effect of lipopolysaccharide is less likely due to interrupted peripheral distribution or metabolism of methamphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We concluded a critical time window for systemic lipopolysaccharide pretreatment in exerting effective protection against methamphetamine-induced nigrostriatal dopamine neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of converting enzyme inhibition on the course of adriamycin-induced nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of the converting enzyme inhibitor (CEI) enalapril was assessed in Munich-Wistar rats with established adriamycin nephrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats were given a single dose of adriamycin and one month later divided into four groups matched for albuminuria, blood pressure, and plasma albumin concentration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Groups 1 and 3 remained untreated while groups 2 and 4 received enalapril.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Groups 1 and 2 underwent micropuncture studies after 10 days.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These short-term studies showed that enalapril reduced arterial blood pressure (101 +/- 2 vs. 124 +/- 3 mm Hg, group 2 vs. 1, P less than 0.05) and glomerular capillary pressure (54 +/- 1 vs. 61 +/- 2 mm Hg, P less than 0.05) without reducing albuminuria (617 +/- 50 vs. 570 +/- 47 mg/day) or GFR (1.03 +/- 0.04 vs. 1.04 +/- 0.11 ml/min).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Groups 3 and 4 were studied at four and at six months to assess the effect of enalapril on progression of renal injury in adriamycin nephrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronic enalapril treatment reduced blood pressure without reducing albuminuria in group 4.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Untreated group 3 rats exhibited a progressive reduction in GFR (0.35 +/- 0.08 ml/min at 4 months, 0.27 +/- 0.07 ml/min at 6 months).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Enalapril treatment blunted but did not prevent reduction in GFR in group 4 (0.86 +/- 0.15 ml/min at 4 months, 0.69 +/- 0.13 ml/min at 6 months, both P less than 0.05 vs. group 3).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reduction in GFR was associated with the development of glomerular sclerosis in both treated and untreated rats.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Chemical>
<Chemical>Butyrylcholinesterase gene mutations in patients with prolonged apnea after succinylcholine for electroconvulsive therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: patients undergoing electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) often receive succinylcholine as part of the anesthetic procedure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The duration of action may be prolonged in patients with genetic variants of the butyrylcholinesterase enzyme (BChE), the most common being the K- and the A-variants.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The aim of the study was to assess the clinical significance of genetic variants in butyrylcholinesterase gene (BCHE) in patients with a suspected prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine after ECT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: a total of 13 patients were referred to the Danish Cholinesterase Research Unit after ECT during 38 months.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We determined the BChE activity and the BCHE genotype using molecular genetic methods, the duration of apnea, time to sufficient spontaneous ventilation and whether neuromuscular monitoring was used.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The duration of apnea was compared with published data on normal subjects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: in 11 patients, mutations were found in the BCHE gene, the K-variant being the most frequent.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The duration of apnea was 5-15 min compared with 3-5.3 min from the literature.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Severe distress was noted in the recovery phase in two patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neuromuscular monitoring was used in two patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>CONCLUSION: eleven of 13 patients with a prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine had mutations in BCHE, indicating that this is the possible reason for a prolonged period of apnea.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We recommend objective neuromuscular monitoring during the first ECT.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ketamine sedation for the reduction of children's fractures in the emergency department.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: There recently has been a resurgence in the utilization of ketamine, a unique anesthetic, for emergency-department procedures requiring sedation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of the present study was to examine the safety and efficacy of ketamine for sedation in the treatment of children's fractures in the emergency department.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: One hundred and fourteen children (average age, 5.3 years; range, twelve months to ten years and ten months) who underwent closed reduction of an isolated fracture or dislocation in the emergency department at a level-I trauma center were prospectively evaluated.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ketamine hydrochloride was administered intravenously (at a dose of two milligrams per kilogram of body weight) in ninety-nine of the patients and intramuscularly (at a dose of four milligrams per kilogram of body weight) in the other fifteen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A board-certified emergency physician skilled in airway management supervised administration of the anesthetic, and the patients were monitored by a registered nurse.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Any pain during the reduction was rated by the orthopaedic surgeon treating the patient according to the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale (CHEOPS).</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The average time from intravenous administration of ketamine to manipulation of the fracture or dislocation was one minute and thirty-six seconds (range, twenty seconds to five minutes), and the average time from intramuscular administration to manipulation was four minutes and forty-two seconds (range, sixty seconds to fifteen minutes).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The average score according to the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario Pain Scale was 6.4 points (range, 5 to 10 points), reflecting minimal or no pain during fracture reduction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Adequate fracture reduction was obtained in 111 of the children.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ninety-nine percent (sixty-eight) of the sixty-nine parents present during the reduction were pleased with the sedation and would allow it to be used again in a similar situation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patency of the airway and independent respiration were maintained in all of the patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Blood pressure and heart rate remained stable.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Minor side effects included nausea (thirteen patients), emesis (eight of the thirteen patients with nausea), clumsiness (evident as ataxic movements in ten patients), and dysphoric reaction (one patient).</Chemical>
<Chemical>No long-term sequelae were noted, and no patients had hallucinations or nightmares.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ketamine reliably, safely, and quickly provided adequate sedation to effectively facilitate the reduction of children's fractures in the emergency department at our institution.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketamine should only be used in an environment such as the emergency department, where proper one-on-one monitoring is used and board-certified physicians skilled in airway management are directly involved in the care of the patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prophylactic use of lamivudine with chronic immunosuppressive therapy for rheumatologic disorders.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The objective of this study was to report our experience concerning the effectiveness of the prophylactic administration of lamivudine in hepatitis B virus surface antigen (HBs Ag) positive patients with rheumatologic disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>From June 2004 to October 2006, 11 HBs Ag positive patients with rheumatologic diseases, who were on both immunosuppressive and prophylactic lamivudine therapies, were retrospectively assessed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Liver function tests, hepatitis B virus (HBV) serologic markers, and HBV DNA levels of the patients during follow-up were obtained from hospital file records.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Eleven patients (six male) with median age 47 years (range 27-73), median disease duration 50 months (range 9-178) and median follow-up period of patients 13.8 months (range 5-27) were enrolled in this study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lamivudine therapy was started 3-7 days prior to immunosuppressive therapy in all patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Baseline, liver function tests were elevated in two patients (fourth patient: ALT:122 IU/l, AST:111 IU/l, tenth patient:ALT:294 IU/l, AST:274 IU/l, with minimal changes in the liver biopsy in both).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Shortly after treatment their tests normalized and during follow-up period none of the patients had abnormal liver function tests.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In four patients HBV DNA levels were higher than normal at baseline.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two of these normalized and the others increased later.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In three additional patients, HBV DNA levels were increased during follow-up.</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of the patients had significant clinical sings of HBV activation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lamivudine was well tolerated and was continued in all patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prophylactic administration of lamivudine in patients who required immunosuppressive therapy seems to be safe, well tolerated and effective in preventing HBV reactivation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Safety of transesophageal echocardiography in adults: study in a multidisciplinary hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND: TEE is a semi-invasive tool broadly used and its utilization associated to sedatives drugs might to affect the procedure safety.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE: to analyze aspects of TEE safety associated to the use of Midazolan (MZ) and Flumazenil (FL) and the influence of the clinical variables on the event rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD: prospective study with 137 patients that underwent TEE with MZ associated to moderate sedation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We analyzed the following events: complications related with the topical anesthesia, with MZ use and with the procedure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Uni- and multivariate analyses were used to test the influence of the clinical variables: age, sex, stroke, myocardiopathy (MP), duration of the test, mitral regurgitation (MR) and the MZ dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: All patients (65+/-16 yrs; 58% males) finished the examination.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean doses of MZ and FL were 4.3+/-1.9 mg and 0.28+/-0.2 mg, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The duration of the examination and the mean ejection fraction (EF) were 16.4+/-6.1 minutes and 60+/-9%, respectively.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Mild hypoxia (SO2<90%) was the most common event (11 patients); 3 patients (2%) presented transient hypoxia due to upper airway obstruction by probe introduction and 8 (5.8%) due to hypoxia caused by MZ use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Transient hypotension (SAP<90mmHg) occurred in 1 patient (0.7%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The multivariate analysis showed that severe MR, MP (EF<45%) and high doses of MZ (>5mg) were associated with events (p<0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The EF was 40%, in the group with MP and 44% in the group with severe MR and it can be a factor associated with clinical events in the last group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION: TEE with sedation presents a low rate of events.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were no severe events and there was no need to interrupt the examinations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effects of calcium channel blockers on bupivacaine-induced toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of this study was to investigate the influence of calcium channel blockers on bupivacaine-induced acute toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>For each of the three tested calcium channel blockers (diltiazem, verapamil and bepridil) 6 groups of mice were treated by two different doses, i.e. 2 and 10 mg/kg/i.p., or an equal volume of saline for the control group (n = 20); 15 minutes later, all the animals were injected with a single 50 mg/kg/i.p. dose of bupivacaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The convulsant activity, the time of latency to convulse and the mortality rate were assessed in each group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The local anesthetic-induced mortality was significantly increased by the three different calcium channel blockers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The convulsant activity of bupivacaine was not significantly modified but calcium channel blockers decreased the time of latency to obtain bupivacaine-induced convulsions; this effect was less pronounced with bepridil.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Selegiline-induced postural hypotension in Parkinson's disease: a longitudinal study on the effects of drug withdrawal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The United Kingdom Parkinson's Disease Research Group (UKPDRG) trial found an increased mortality in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD) randomized to receive 10 mg selegiline per day and L-dopa compared with those taking L-dopa alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recently, we found that therapy with selegiline and L-dopa was associated with selective systolic orthostatic hypotension which was abolished by withdrawal of selegiline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This unwanted effect on postural blood pressure was not the result of underlying autonomic failure.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The aims of this study were to confirm our previous findings in a separate cohort of patients and to determine the time course of the cardiovascular consequences of stopping selegiline in the expectation that this might shed light on the mechanisms by which the drug causes orthostatic hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The cardiovascular responses to standing and head-up tilt were studied repeatedly in PD patients receiving selegiline and as the drug was withdrawn.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Head-up tilt caused systolic orthostatic hypotension which was marked in six of 20 PD patients on selegiline, one of whom lost consciousness with unrecordable blood pressures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A lesser degree of orthostatic hypotension occurred with standing.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Orthostatic hypotension was ameliorated 4 days after withdrawal of selegiline and totally abolished 7 days after discontinuation of the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Stopping selegiline also significantly reduced the supine systolic and diastolic blood pressures consistent with a previously undescribed supine pressor action.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study confirms our previous finding that selegiline in combination with L-dopa is associated with selective orthostatic hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possibilities that these cardiovascular findings might be the result of non-selective inhibition of monoamine oxidase or of amphetamine and metamphetamine are discussed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Explicit episodic memory for sensory-discriminative components of capsaicin-induced pain: immediate and delayed ratings.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain memory is thought to affect future pain sensitivity and thus contribute to clinical pain conditions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Systematic investigations of the human capacity to remember sensory features of experimental pain are sparse.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In order to address long-term pain memory, nine healthy male volunteers received intradermal injections of three doses of capsaicin (0.05, 1 and 20 microg, separated by 15 min breaks), each given three times in a balanced design across three sessions at one week intervals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain rating was performed using a computerized visual analogue scale (0-100) digitized at 1/s, either immediately online or one hour or one day after injection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Subjects also recalled their pains one week later.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Capsaicin injection reliably induced a dose-dependent flare (p<0.001) without any difference within or across sessions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The strong burning pain decayed exponentially within a few minutes.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Subjects were able to reliably discriminate pain magnitude and duration across capsaicin doses (both p<0.001), regardless of whether first-time ratings were requested immediately, after one hour or after one day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain recall after one week was similarly precise (magnitude: p<0.01, duration: p<0.05).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Correlation with rating recall after one week was best when first-time ratings were requested as late as one day after injection (R(2)=0.79) indicating that both rating retrievals utilized similar memory traces.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results indicate a reliable memory for magnitude and duration of experimentally induced pain.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The data further suggest that the consolidation of this memory is an important interim stage, and may take up to one day.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reversibility of captopril-induced renal insufficiency after prolonged use in an unusual case of renovascular hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of severe hypertension with an occluded renal artery to a solitary kidney, who developed sudden deterioration of renal function following treatment with captopril.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>His renal function remained impaired but stable during 2 years' treatment with captopril but returned to pre-treatment levels soon after cessation of the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This indicates reversibility in captopril-induced renal failure even after its prolonged use and suggests that no organic damage occurs to glomerular arterioles following chronic ACE inhibition.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>This is an addition to the list of drugs that must be considered in the evaluation of chronic liver disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Capsaicin-induced muscle pain alters the excitability of the human jaw-stretch reflex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The pathophysiology of painful temporomandibular disorders is not fully understood, but evidence suggests that muscle pain modulates motor function in characteristic ways.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study tested the hypothesis that activation of nociceptive muscle afferent fibers would be linked to an increased excitability of the human jaw-stretch reflex and whether this process would be sensitive to length and velocity of the stretch.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Capsaicin (10 micro g) was injected into the masseter muscle to induce pain in 11 healthy volunteers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Short-latency reflex responses were evoked in the masseter and temporalis muscles by a stretch device with different velocities and displacements before, during, and after the pain.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The normalized reflex amplitude increased with an increase in velocity at a given displacement, but remained constant with different displacements at a given velocity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The normalized reflex amplitude was significantly higher during pain, but only at faster stretches in the painful muscle.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Increased sensitivity of the fusimotor system during acute muscle pain could be one likely mechanism to explain the findings.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation for levodopa-induced dyskinesias in Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a placebo-controlled, single-blinded, crossover study, we assessed the effect of "real" repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) versus "sham" rTMS (placebo) on peak dose dyskinesias in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ten patients with PD and prominent dyskinesias had rTMS (1,800 pulses; 1 Hz rate) delivered over the motor cortex for 4 consecutive days twice, once real stimuli and once sham stimulation were used; evaluations were done at the baseline and 1 day after the end of each of the treatment series.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Direct comparison between sham and real rTMS effects showed no significant difference in clinician-assessed dyskinesia severity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, comparison with the baseline showed small but significant reduction in dyskinesia severity following real rTMS but not placebo.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The major effect was on dystonia subscore.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Similarly, in patient diaries, although both treatments caused reduction in subjective dyskinesia scores during the days of intervention, the effect was sustained for 3 days after the intervention for the real rTMS only.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Following rTMS, no side effects and no adverse effects on motor function and PD symptoms were noted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results suggest the existence of residual beneficial clinical aftereffects of consecutive daily applications of low-frequency rTMS on dyskinesias in PD.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The effects may be further exploited for potential therapeutic uses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Disulfiram-like syndrome after hydrogen cyanamide professional skin exposure: two case reports in France.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hydrogen cyanamide is a plant growth regulator used in agriculture to induce bud break in fruit trees.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Contact with the skin can result in percutaneous absorption of the substance that inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase and can induce acetaldehyde syndrome in case of alcohol use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of this report is to describe two cases of a disulfiram-like syndrome following occupational exposure to hydrogen cyanamide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The first case involved a 59-year-old man who used Dormex, which contains hydrogen cyanamide, without protection after consuming a large amount of alcohol during a meal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In less than 1 hour after the ingestion of alcohol, he developed malaise with flushing of the face, tachycardia, and dyspnea.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Manifestations regressed spontaneously under surveillance in the hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The second case occurred in a 55-year-old farmer following cutaneous contact with Dormex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five hours after exposure, he developed disulfiram-like syndrome with flushing, tachycardia, and arterial hypotension after consuming three glasses of wine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient recovered spontaneously in 3 hours under surveillance in the hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These cases confirm the necessity of avoiding alcohol consumption as recommended in the instructions for use of Dormex and of preventing cutaneous contact during use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Repeated trimipramine induces dopamine D2/D3 and alpha1-adrenergic up-regulation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Trimipramine (TRI), which shows a clinical antidepressant activity, is chemically related to imipramine but does not inhibit the reuptake of noradrenaline and 5-hydroxytryptamine, nor does it induce beta-adrenergic down-regulation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism of its antidepressant activity is still unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of the present study was to find out whether TRI given repeatedly was able to induce adaptive changes in the dopaminergic and alpha1-adrenergic systems, demonstrated by us previously for various antidepressants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>TRI was given to male Wistar rats and male Albino Swiss mice perorally twice daily for 14 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the acute experiment TRI (given i.p.) does not antagonize the reserpine hypothermia in mice and does not potentiate the 5-hydroxytryptophan head twitches in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>TRI given repeatedly to rats increases the locomotor hyperactivity induced by d-amphetamine, quinpirole and (+)-7-hydroxy-dipropyloaminotetralin (dopamine D2 and D3 effects).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The stereotypies induced by d-amphetamine or apomorphine are not potentiated by TRI.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It increases the behaviour stimulation evoked by phenylephrine (given intraventricularly) in rats, evaluated in the open field test as well as the aggressiveness evoked by clonidine in mice, both these effects being mediated by an alpha1-adrenergic receptor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It may be concluded that, like other tricyclic antidepressants studied previously, TRI given repeatedly increases the responsiveness of brain dopamine D2 and D3 (locomotor activity but not stereotypy) as well as alpha1-adrenergic receptors to their agonists.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A question arises whether the reuptake inhibition is of any importance to the adaptive changes induced by repeated antidepressants, suggested to be responsible for the antidepressant activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This drug occasionally has been associated with acute interstitial nephritis in native kidneys.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There are no similar reports with renal transplantation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We report a case of ranitidine-induced acute interstitial nephritis in a recipient of a cadaveric renal allograft presenting with acute allograft dysfunction within 48 hours of exposure to the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The biopsy specimen showed pathognomonic features, including eosinophilic infiltration of the interstitial compartment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can cause nephrolithiasis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We studied 20 patients receiving long-term carbonic anhydrase inhibitor treatment for periodic paralysis and myotonia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Three patients on acetazolamide (15%) developed renal calculi.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Extracorporeal lithotripsy successfully removed a renal calculus in one patient and surgery removed a staghorn calculus in another, permitting continued treatment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Is the treatment of scabies hazardous?</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment for scabies is usually initiated by general practitioners; most consider lindane (gamma benzene hexachloride) the treatment of choice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lindane is also widely used as an agricultural and industrial pesticide, and as a result the toxic profile of this insecticide is well understood.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Evidence is accumulating that lindane can be toxic to the central nervous system and may be associated with aplastic anaemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Preparations containing lindane continue to be sold over the counter and may represent a hazard to poorly informed patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This literature review suggests that general practitioners should prescribe scabicides with increased caution for certain at-risk groups, and give adequate warnings regarding potential toxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Anaesthetists' nightmare: masseter spasm after induction in an undiagnosed case of myotonia congenita.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Neither the patient nor the anaesthetist was aware of the diagnosis before this potentially lethal complication occurred.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Toxicity in rhesus monkeys following administration of the 8-aminoquinoline 8-[(4-amino-l-methylbutyl)amino]- 5-(l-hexyloxy)-6-methoxy-4-methylquinoline (WR242511).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>INTRODUCTION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Many substances that form methemoglobin (MHb) effectively counter cyanide (CN) toxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although MHb formers are generally applied as treatments for CN poisoning, it has been proposed that a stable, long-acting MHb former could serve as a CN pretreatment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Using this rationale, the 8-aminoquinoline WR242511, a potent long-lasting MHb former in rodents and beagle dogs, was studied in the rhesus monkey for advanced development as a potential CN pretreatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study, WR242511 was administered intravenously (IV) in 2 female and 4 male rhesus monkeys in doses of 3.5 and/or 7.0 mg/kg; a single male also received WR242511 orally (PO) at 7.0 mg/kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Health status and MHb levels were monitored following exposure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The selected doses of WR242511, which produced significant methemoglobinemia in beagle dogs in earlier studies conducted elsewhere, produced very little MHb (mean < 2.0%) in the rhesus monkey.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, transient hemoglobinuria was noted approximately 60 minutes postinjection of WR242511 (3.5 or 7.0 mg/kg), and 2 lethalities occurred (one IV and one PO) following the 7.0 mg/kg dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Myoglobinuria was also observed following the 7.0 mg/kg dose.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Histopathology analyses in the 2 animals that died revealed liver and kidney toxicity, with greater severity in the orally-treated animal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: These data demonstrate direct and/or indirect drug-induced toxicity.</Chemical>

<Chemical>It is concluded that WR242511 should not be pursued as a pretreatment for CN poisoning unless the anti-CN characteristics of this compound can be successfully dissociated from those producing undesirable toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neuroplasticity of the adult primate auditory cortex following cochlear hearing loss.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tonotopic organization is an essential feature of the primary auditory area (A1) of primate cortex.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In A1 of macaque monkeys, low frequencies are represented rostrolaterally and high frequencies are represented caudomedially.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The purpose of this study was to determine if changes occur in this tonotopic organization following cochlear hearing loss.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Under anesthesia, the superior temporal gyrus of adult macaque monkeys was exposed, and the tonotopic organization of A1 was mapped using conventional microelectrode recording techniques.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Following recovery, the monkeys were selectively deafened for high frequencies using kanamycin and furosemide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The actual frequencies deafened were determined by the loss of tone-burst elicited auditory brainstem responses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Three months after deafening, A1 was remapped.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Postmortem cytoarchitectural features identifying A1 were correlated with the electrophysiologic data.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results indicate that the deprived area of A1 undergoes extensive reorganization and becomes responsive to intact cochlear frequencies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The region of cortex that represents the low frequencies was not obviously affected by the cochlear hearing loss.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Atypical sensations following the use of subcutaneous sumatriptan are common, but of uncertain origin.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>They are almost always benign, but can be mistaken for a serious adverse event by the patient.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two patients are presented with tingling or burning sensations limited to areas of heat exposure or sunburn.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In these individuals, side effects are most likely generated superficially in the skin.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tremor side effects of salbutamol, quantified by a laser pointer technique.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To study tremor side effects of salbutamol an easily applicable, quick and low-priced method is needed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A new method using a commercially available, pen-shaped laser pointer was developed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Aim of the study was to determine sensitivity, reproducibility, reference values and the agreement with a questionnaire.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tremor was measured using a laser pointer technique.</Chemical>
<Chemical>To determine sensitivity we assessed tremor in 44 patients with obstructive lung disease after administration of cumulative doses of salbutamol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subjects were asked to aim at the centre of a target, subdivided in concentric circles, from 5 m distance.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The circle in which the participant succeeded to aim was recorded in millimetres radius.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In another series of measurements, reproducibility and reference values of the tremor was assessed in 65 healthy subjects in three sessions, at 9 a.m., 4 p.m. and 9 a.m., respectively, 1 week later.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Postural tremor was measured with the arm horizontally outstretched rest tremor with the arm supported by an armrest and finally tremor was measured after holding a 2-kg weight until exhaustion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Inter-observer variability was measured in a series of 10 healthy subjects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tremor was measured simultaneously by two independent observers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Salbutamol significantly increased tremor severity in patients in a dose-dependent way.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Within healthy adults no age-dependency could be found (b = 0.262 mm/year; P = 0.72).</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was no agreement between the questionnaire and tremor severity (r = 0.093; P = 0.53).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Postural tremor showed no significant difference between the first and third session (P = 0.07).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Support of the arm decreased tremor severity, exhaustion increased tremor severity significantly.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A good agreement was found between two independent observers (interclass correlation coefficient 0.72).</Chemical>
<Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Quantifying tremor by using an inexpensive laser pointer is, with the exception of children (<12 years) a sensitive and reproducible method.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Increased frequency of venous thromboembolism with the combination of docetaxel and thalidomide in patients with metastatic androgen-independent prostate cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>STUDY OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the frequency of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in patients with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer who were treated with docetaxel alone or in combination with thalidomide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Retrospective analysis of a randomized phase II trial.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING: National Institutes of Health clinical research center.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS: Seventy men, aged 50-80 years, with advanced androgen-independent prostate cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>INTERVENTION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Each patient received either intravenous docetaxel 30 mg/m2/week for 3 consecutive weeks, followed by 1 week off, or the combination of continuous oral thalidomide 200 mg every evening plus the same docetaxel regimen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This 4-week cycle was repeated until there was evidence of excessive toxicity or disease progression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of 23 patients who received docetaxel alone developed VTE, whereas 9 of 47 patients (19%) who received docetaxel plus thalidomide developed VTE (p=0.025).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The addition of thalidomide to docetaxel in the treatment of prostate cancer significantly increases the frequency of VTE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinicians should be aware of this potential complication when adding thalidomide to chemotherapeutic regimens.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Severe thrombocytopenia and haemolytic anaemia associated with ciprofloxacin: a case report with fatal outcome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Haematological adverse reactions associated with fatal outcome are rare during treatment with ciprofloxacin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 30-year old Caucasian man reported with abdominal pain and jaundice after 3-day administration of oral ciprofloxacin for a suspect of urinary tract infection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical evaluations suggested an initial diagnosis of severe thrombocytopenia and haemolysis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient progressively developed petechiae and purpura on thorax and lower limbs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Despite pharmacological and supportive interventions, laboratory parameters worsened and the patient died 17 hours after admission.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An accurate autopsy revealed most organs with diffuse petechial haemorrhages.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No signs of bone marrow depression were found.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No thrombi or signs of microangiopathies were observed in arterial vessels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Blood and urine cultures did not show any bacterial growth.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This case report shows that ciprofloxacin may precipitate life-threatening thrombocytopenia and haemolytic anaemia, even in the early phases of treatment and without apparent previous exposures.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>It is likely that this complication will be seen more often with the increased worldwide use of this drug and its approval for all arteriopathic patients.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Intracranial aneurysms and cocaine abuse: analysis of prognostic indicators.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The outcome of subarachnoid hemorrhage associated with cocaine abuse is reportedly poor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, no study in the literature has reported the use of a statistical model to analyze the variables that influence outcome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A review of admissions during a 6-year period revealed 14 patients with cocaine-related aneurysms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This group was compared with a control group of 135 patients with ruptured aneurysms and no history of cocaine abuse.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Age at presentation, time of ictus after intoxication, Hunt and Hess grade of subarachnoid hemorrhage, size of the aneurysm, location of the aneurysm, and the Glasgow Outcome Scale score were assessed and compared.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patients in the study group were significantly younger than the patients in the control group (P < 0.002).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In patients in the study group, all aneurysms were located in the anterior circulation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The majority of these aneurysms were smaller than those of the control group (8 +/- 6.08 mm versus 11 +/- 5.4 mm; P = 0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The differences in mortality and morbidity between the two groups were not significant.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hunt and Hess grade (P < 0.005) and age (P < 0.007) were significant predictors of outcome for the patients with cocaine-related aneurysms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cocaine use predisposed aneurysmal rupture at a significantly earlier age and in much smaller aneurysms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Contrary to the published literature, this group did reasonably well with aggressive management.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Anti-epileptic drugs-induced de novo absence seizures.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The authors present three patients with de novo absence epilepsy after administration of carbamazepine and vigabatrin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite the underlying diseases, the prognosis for drug-induced de novo absence seizure is good because it subsides rapidly after discontinuing the use of the offending drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The gamma-aminobutyric acid-transmitted thalamocortical circuitry accounts for a major part of the underlying neurophysiology of the absence epilepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because drug-induced de novo absence seizure is rare, pro-absence drugs can only be considered a promoting factor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The underlying epileptogenecity of the patients or the synergistic effects of the accompanying drugs is required to trigger the de novo absence seizure.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The possibility of drug-induced aggravation should be considered whenever an unexpected increase in seizure frequency and/or new seizure types appear following a change in drug treatment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>By understanding the underlying mechanism of absence epilepsy, we can avoid the inappropriate use of anticonvulsants in children with epilepsy and prevent drug-induced absence seizures.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the remaining three patients, procainamide was administered orally for treatment of chronic premature ventricular contractions or atrial flutter.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In two patients, the arrhythmia degenerated into irreversible ventricular fibrillation and both patients died.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cellular mechanisms which account for disruption the blood-brain barrier during acute hypertension are not clear.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Permeability of the blood-brain barrier was quantitated by clearance of fluorescent-labeled dextran before and during phenylephrine-induced acute hypertension in rats treated with vehicle and Hoe-140 (0.1 microM).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phenylephrine infusion increased arterial pressure, arteriolar diameter and clearance of fluorescent dextran by a similar magnitude in both groups.</Chemical>
