text: <Chemical>5-azacytidine potentiates initiation induced by carcinogens in rat liver.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To test the validity of the hypothesis that hypomethylation of DNA plays an important role in the initiation of carcinogenic process, 5-azacytidine (5-AzC) (10 mg/kg), an inhibitor of DNA methylation, was given to rats during the phase of repair synthesis induced by the three carcinogens, benzo[a]-pyrene (200 mg/kg), N-methyl-N-nitrosourea (60 mg/kg) and 1,2-dimethylhydrazine (1,2-DMH) (100 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The initiated hepatocytes in the liver were assayed as the gamma-glutamyltransferase (gamma-GT) positive foci formed following a 2-week selection regimen consisting of dietary 0.02% 2-acetylaminofluorene coupled with a necrogenic dose of CCl4.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results obtained indicate that with all three carcinogens, administration of 5-AzC during repair synthesis increased the incidence of initiated hepatocytes, for example 10-20 foci/cm2 in 5-AzC and carcinogen-treated rats compared with 3-5 foci/cm2 in rats treated with carcinogen only.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of [3H]-5-azadeoxycytidine during the repair synthesis induced by 1,2-DMH further showed that 0.019 mol % of cytosine residues in DNA were substituted by the analogue, indicating that incorporation of 5-AzC occurs during repair synthesis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the absence of the carcinogen, 5-AzC given after a two thirds partial hepatectomy, when its incorporation should be maximum, failed to induce any gamma-GT positive foci.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results suggest that hypomethylation of DNA per se may not be sufficient for initiation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Perhaps two events might be necessary for initiation, the first caused by the carcinogen and a second involving hypomethylation of DNA.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Twenty children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia who developed meningeal disease were treated with a high-dose intravenous methotrexate regimen that was designed to achieve and maintain CSF methotrexate concentrations of 10(-5) mol/L without the need for concomitant intrathecal dosing.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The methotrexate was administered as a loading dose of 6,000 mg/m2 for a period of one hour followed by an infusion of 1,200 mg/m2/h for 23 hours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Leucovorin rescue was initiated 12 hours after the end of the infusion with a loading dose of 200 mg/m2 followed by 12 mg/m2 every three hours for six doses and then every six hours until the plasma methotrexate level decreased to less than 1 X 10(-7) mol/L.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mean steady-state plasma and CSF methotrexate concentrations achieved were 1.1 X 10(-3) mol/L and 3.6 X 10(-5) mol/L, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All 20 patients responded to this regimen, 16/20 (80%) achieved a complete remission, and 20% obtained a partial remission.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Assessment of a new non-invasive index of cardiac performance for detection of dobutamine-induced myocardial ischemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Electrocardiography has a very low sensitivity in detecting dobutamine-induced myocardial ischemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>

<Chemical>To assess the added diagnostic value of a new cardiac performance index (dP/dtejc) measurement, based on brachial artery flow changes, as compared to standard 12-lead ECG, for detecting dobutamine-induced myocardial ischemia, using Tc99m-Sestamibi single-photon emission computed tomography as the gold standard of comparison to assess the presence or absence of ischemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The study group comprised 40 patients undergoing Sestamibi-SPECT/dobutamine stress test.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Simultaneous measurements of ECG and brachial artery dP/dtejc were performed at each dobutamine level.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 19 of the 40 patients perfusion defects compatible with ischemia were detected on SPECT.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The increase in dP/dtejc during infusion of dobutamine in this group was severely impaired as compared to the non-ischemic group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>dP/dtejc outcome was combined with the ECG results, giving an ECG-enhanced value, and compared to ECG alone.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The sensitivity improved dramatically from 16% to 79%, positive predictive value increased from 60% to 68% and negative predictive value from 54% to 78%, and specificity decreased from 90% to 67%.</Chemical>

<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: If ECG alone is used for specificity, the combination with dP/dtejc improved the sensitivity of the test and could be a cost-savings alternative to cardiac imaging or perfusion studies to detect myocardial ischemia, especially in patients unable to exercise.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE REPORT:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We describe 2 patients who were regular consumers of alcohol and who developed liver failure within 3-5 days after hospitalization and stopping alcohol consumption while being treated with 4 g paracetamol/day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A paracetamol serum level obtained in one of these patients was not in the toxic range.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Possible risk factors for the development of hepatotoxicity in patients treated with therapeutic doses of paracetamol are discussed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In patients with risk factors, e.g. regular consumption of alcohol, liver failure is possible when therapeutic doses are ingested.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We propose that the paracetamol dose should not exceed 2 g/day in such patients and that their liver function should be monitored closely while being treated with paracetamol.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Severe rhabdomyolysis and acute renal failure secondary to concomitant use of simvastatin, amiodarone, and atazanavir.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of a severe interaction between simvastatin, amiodarone, and atazanavir resulting in rhabdomyolysis and acute renal failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: A 72-year-old white man with underlying human immunodeficiency virus, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, and hyperlipidemia presented with generalized pain, fatigue, and dark orange urine for 3 days.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The patient was taking 80 mg simvastatin at bedtime (initiated 27 days earlier); amiodarone at a dose of 400 mg daily for 7 days, then 200 mg daily (initiated 19 days earlier); and 400 mg atazanavir daily (initiated at least 2 years previously).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Laboratory evaluation revealed 66,680 U/L creatine kinase, 93 mg/dL blood urea nitrogen, 4.6 mg/dL creatinine, 1579 U/L aspartate aminotransferase, and 738 U/L alanine aminotransferase.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Simvastatin, amiodarone, and the patient's human immunodeficiency virus medications were all temporarily discontinued and the patient was given forced alkaline diuresis and started on dialysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nine days later the patient's creatine kinase had dropped to 1695 U/L and creatinine was 3.3 mg/dL.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient was discharged and continued outpatient dialysis for 1 month until his renal function recovered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The risk of rhabdomyolysis is increased in the presence of concomitant drugs that inhibit simvastatin metabolism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Simvastatin is metabolized by CYP3A4.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amiodarone and atazanavir are recognized CYP3A4 inhibitors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pharmacokinetic differences in statins are an important consideration for assessing the risk of potential drug interactions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients requiring the concurrent use of statins and CYP3A4 inhibitors, pravastatin, fluvastatin, and rosuvastatin carry the lowest risk of drug interactions; atorvastatin carries moderate risk, whereas simvastatin and lovastatin have the highest risk and should be avoided in patients taking concomitant CYP3A4 inhibitors.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Phase II trial of vinorelbine in metastatic squamous cell esophageal carcinoma. European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Gastrointestinal Treat Cancer Cooperative Group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To evaluate the response rate and toxic effects of vinorelbine (VNB) administered as a single agent in metastatic squamous cell esophageal carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Forty-six eligible patients with measurable lesions were included and were stratified according to previous chemotherapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thirty patients without prior chemotherapy and 16 pretreated with cisplatin-based chemotherapy were assessable for toxicity and response.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>VNB was administered weekly as a 25-mg/m2 short intravenous (i.v.) infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Six of 30 patients (20%) without prior chemotherapy achieved a partial response (PR) (95% confidence interval</Chemical>
<Chemical>[CI], 8% to 39%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The median duration of response was 21 weeks (range, 17 to 28).</Chemical>
<Chemical>One of 16 patients (6%) with prior chemotherapy had a complete response (CR) of 31 weeks' duration (95% CI, 0% to 30%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The overall response rate (World Health Organization [WHO] criteria) was 15% (CR, 2%; PR 13%; 95% CI, 6% to 29%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The median dose-intensity (DI) was 20 mg/m2/wk. VNB was well tolerated and zero instances of WHO grade 4 nonhematologic toxicity occurred.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At least one episode of grade 3 or 4 granulocytopenia was seen in 59% of patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A grade 2 or 3 infection occurred in 16% of patients, but no toxic deaths occurred.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Other side effects were rare, and peripheral neurotoxicity has been minor (26% grade 1).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION: These data indicate that VNB is an active agent in metastatic esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Given its excellent tolerance profile and low toxicity, further evaluation of VNB in combination therapy is warranted.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine combination chemotherapy within a multidisciplinary therapeutic approach in metastatic nonsmall cell lung carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Cisplatin-based chemotherapy combinations improve quality of life and survival in advanced nonsmall cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The emergence of new active drugs might translate into more effective regimens for the treatment of this disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The objective of this study was to determine the feasibility, response rate, and toxicity of a paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine combination to treat metastatic NSCLC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty-five consecutive chemotherapy-naive patients with Stage IV NSCLC and an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status of 0-2 were treated with a combination of paclitaxel (135 mg/m(2) given intravenously in 3 hours) on Day 1, cisplatin (120 mg/m(2) given intravenously in 6 hours) on Day 1, and gemcitabine (800 mg/m(2) given intravenously in 30 minutes) on Days 1 and 8, every 4 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although responding patients were scheduled to receive consolidation radiotherapy and 24 patients received preplanned second-line chemotherapy after disease progression, the response and toxicity rates reported refer only to the chemotherapy regimen given.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: All the patients were examined for toxicity; 34 were examinable for response.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An objective response was observed in 73.5% of the patients (95% confidence interval</Chemical>
<Chemical>[CI], 55.6-87.1%), including 4 complete responses (11.7%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>According to intention-to-treat, the overall response rate was 71.4% (95% CI, 53. 7-85.4%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>After 154 courses of therapy, the median dose intensity was 131 mg/m(2) for paclitaxel (97.3%), 117 mg/m(2) for cisplatin (97.3%), and 1378 mg/m(2) for gemcitabine (86.2%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>World Health Organization Grade 3-4 neutropenia and thrombocytopenia occurred in 39.9% and 11.4% of patients, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was one treatment-related death.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nonhematologic toxicities were mild.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After a median follow-up of 22 months, the median progression free survival rate was 7 months, and the median survival time was 16 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The combination of paclitaxel, cisplatin, and gemcitabine is well tolerated and shows high activity in metastatic NSCLC.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>This treatment merits further comparison with other cisplatin-based regimens.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We prospectively evaluated the adverse reactions of apraclonidine in 20 normal volunteers by instilling a single drop of 1% apraclonidine in their right eyes.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Examinations, including blood pressure, pulse rate, conjunctiva and cornea, intraocular pressure (IOP), pupil diameter, basal tear secretion and margin reflex distance of both upper and lower eyelids, were performed prior to entry and at 1, 3, 5 and 7 hours after instillation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The primary response variable was based on central reading of 24 hour ambulatory electrocardiographic recordings and was defined as the occurrence of 30 or more single premature ventricular complexes in any two consecutive 30 minute blocks or one or more runs of two or more premature ventricular complexes in the entire 24 hour electrocardiographic recording.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Fatal intracranial bleeding associated with prehospital use of epinephrine.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Subsequently, acute cardiac arrest and fatal subarachnoid hemorrhage occurred.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Differential impact of immune escape mutations G145R and P120T on the replication of lamivudine-resistant hepatitis B virus e antigen-positive and -negative strains.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immune escape variants of the hepatitis B virus (HBV) represent an emerging clinical challenge, because they can be associated with vaccine escape, HBV reactivation, and failure of diagnostic tests.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recent data suggest a preferential selection of immune escape mutants in distinct peripheral blood leukocyte compartments of infected individuals.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We therefore systematically analyzed the functional impact of the most prevalent immune escape variants, the sG145R and sP120T mutants, on the viral replication efficacy and antiviral drug susceptibility of common treatment-associated mutants with resistance to lamivudine (LAM) and/or HBeAg negativity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Replication-competent HBV strains with sG145R or sP120T and LAM resistance (rtM204I or rtL180M/rtM204V) were generated on an HBeAg-positive and an HBeAg-negative background with precore (PC) and basal core promoter (BCP) mutants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The sG145R mutation strongly reduced HBsAg levels and was able to fully restore the impaired replication of LAM-resistant HBV mutants to the levels of wild-type HBV, and PC or BCP mutations further enhanced viral replication.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although the sP120T substitution also impaired HBsAg secretion, it did not enhance the replication of LAM-resistant clones.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the concomitant occurrence of HBeAg negativity (PC/BCP), sP120T, and LAM resistance resulted in the restoration of replication to levels of wild-type HBV.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In all clones with combined immune escape and LAM resistance mutations, the nucleotide analogues adefovir and tenofovir remained effective in suppressing viral replication in vitro.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings reveal the differential impact of immune escape variants on the replication and drug susceptibility of complex HBV mutants, supporting the need of close surveillance and treatment adjustment in response to the selection of distinct mutational patterns.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>1.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Atorvastatin (Ato) possesses pleiotropic properties that have been reported to improve endothelial function through increased availability of NO and reduced O2- production in various forms of hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study, we investigated whether 50 mg/kg per day, p.o., Ato could prevent endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) downregulation and the increase in O2- in Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats, thereby reducing blood pressure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Infarct-avid radiopharmaceuticals are necessary for rapid and timely diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A new infarct-avid radiopharmaceutical based on glucaric acid was prepared in the hospital radiopharmacy of the INCMNSZ.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The rat biodistribution studies showed a rapid blood clearance via the kidneys.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thirty minutes after 99mTc-glucarate administration the standardised heart uptake value S(h)UV was 4.7 in infarcted rat heart which is six times more than in normal rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>ROIs drawn over the gamma camera images showed a ratio of 4.4.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The high image quality suggests that high contrast images can be obtained in humans and the 96 h stability makes it an ideal agent to detect, in patients, early cardiac infarction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A randomized, placebo-controlled dose-comparison trial of haloperidol for psychosis and disruptive behaviors in Alzheimer's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The goal of this study was to compare the efficacy and side effects of two doses of haloperidol and placebo in the treatment of psychosis and disruptive behaviors in patients with Alzheimer's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In a 6-week random-assignment, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial (phase A), haloperidol, 2-3 mg/day (standard dose), and haloperidol, 0.50-0.75 mg/day (low dose), were compared in 71 outpatients with Alzheimer's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>For the subsequent 6-week double-blind crossover phase (phase B), patients taking standard- or low-dose haloperidol were switched to placebo, and patients taking placebo were randomly assigned to standard- or low-dose haloperidol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>For the 60 patients who completed phase A, standard-dose haloperidol was efficacious and superior to both low-dose haloperidol and placebo for scores on the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale psychosis factor and on psychomotor agitation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Response rates according to three sets of criteria were greater with the standard dose (55%-60%) than the low dose (25%-35%) and placebo (25%-30%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The advantage of standard dose over low dose was replicated in phase B.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In phase A, extrapyramidal signs tended to be greater with the standard dose than in the other two conditions, primarily because of a subgroup (20%) who developed moderate to severe signs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Low-dose haloperidol did not differ from placebo on any measure of efficacy or side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results indicated a favorable therapeutic profile for haloperidol in doses of 2-3 mg/day, although a subgroup developed moderate to severe extrapyramidal signs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A starting dose of 1 mg/day with gradual, upward dose titration is recommended.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The narrow therapeutic window observed with haloperidol may also apply to other neuroleptics used in Alzheimer's disease patients with psychosis and disruptive behaviors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Individual differences in renal ACE activity in healthy rats predict susceptibility to adriamycin-induced renal damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In man, differences in angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels, related to ACE (I/D) genotype, are associated with renal prognosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This raises the hypothesis that individual differences in renal ACE activity are involved in renal susceptibility to inflicted damage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Therefore, we studied the predictive effect of renal ACE activity for the severity of renal damage induced by a single injection of adriamycin in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Renal ACE activity (Hip-His-Leu cleavage by cortical homogenates) was determined by renal biopsy in 27 adult male Wistar rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 1 week of recovery, proteinuria was induced by adriamycin [1.5 mg/kg intravenously (i.v.) n = 18; controls, saline i.v. n = 9].</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Proteinuria was measured every 2 weeks.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After 12 weeks, rats were sacrificed and their kidneys harvested.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: As anticipated, adriamycin elicited nephrotic range proteinuria, renal interstitial damage and mild focal glomerulosclerosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Baseline renal ACE positively correlated with the relative rise in proteinuria after adriamycin (r = 0.62, P<0.01), renal interstitial alpha-smooth muscle actin (r = 0.49, P<0.05), interstitial macrophage influx (r = 0.56, P<0.05), interstitial collagen III (r = 0.53, P<0.05), glomerular alpha-smooth muscle actin (r = 0.74, P<0.01) and glomerular desmin (r = 0.48, P<0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Baseline renal ACE did not correlate with focal glomerulosclerosis (r = 0.22, NS).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In controls, no predictive values for renal parameters were observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION: Individual differences in renal ACE activity predict the severity of adriamycin-induced renal damage in this outbred rat strain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This supports the assumption that differences in renal ACE activity predispose to a less favourable course of renal damage.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this study, 62 patients with confirmed initial normal renal function and treated with 2 to 5 mg/kg/day of gentamicin sulfate or tobramycin sulfate for a minimum of seven days were followed up prospectively for the development of aminoglycoside-related renal failure, defined as at least a one-third reduction in renal function.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In these 62 patients, no other causes for renal failure could be identified.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Thus, gentamicin was associated with renal failure more than three times as often as was tobramycin.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Neuroprotective action of MPEP, a selective mGluR5 antagonist, in methamphetamine-induced dopaminergic neurotoxicity is associated with a decrease in dopamine outflow and inhibition of hyperthermia in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of this study was to examine the role of metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5) in the toxic action of methamphetamine on dopaminergic neurones in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methamphetamine (10 mg/kg sc), administered five times, reduced the levels of dopamine and its metabolites in striatal tissue when measured 72 h after the last injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A selective antagonist of mGluR5, 2-methyl-6-(phenylethynyl)pyridine (MPEP; 5 mg/kg ip), when administered five times immediately before each methamphetamine injection reversed the above-mentioned methamphetamine effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A single MPEP (5 mg/kg ip) injection reduced the basal extracellular dopamine level in the striatum, as well as dopamine release stimulated either by methamphetamine (10 mg/kg sc) or by intrastriatally administered veratridine (100 microM).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, it transiently diminished the methamphetamine (10 mg/kg sc)-induced hyperthermia and reduced basal body temperature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MPEP administered into the striatum at high concentrations (500 microM) increased extracellular dopamine levels, while lower concentrations (50-100 microM) were devoid of any effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results of this study suggest that the blockade of mGluR5 by MPEP may protect dopaminergic neurones against methamphetamine-induced toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neuroprotection rendered by MPEP may be associated with the reduction of the methamphetamine-induced dopamine efflux in the striatum due to the blockade of extrastriatal mGluR5, and with a decrease in hyperthermia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Pharmacokinetics of desipramine HCl when administered with cinacalcet HCl.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In vitro work has demonstrated that cinacalcet is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome P450 isoenzyme (CYP) 2D6.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effect of cinacalcet on CYP2D6 activity, using desipramine as a probe substrate, in healthy subjects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Seventeen subjects who were genotyped as CYP2D6 extensive metabolizers were enrolled in this randomized, open-label, crossover study to receive a single oral dose of desipramine (50 mg) on two separate occasions, once alone and once after multiple doses of cinacalcet (90 mg for 7 days).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Blood samples were obtained predose and up to 72 h postdose.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Fourteen subjects completed both treatment arms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Relative to desipramine alone, mean AUC and C(max) of desipramine increased 3.6- and 1.8-fold when coadministered with cinacalcet.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The t (1/2,z) of desipramine was longer when desipramine was coadministered with cinacalcet (21.0 versus 43.3 hs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The t (max) was similar between the regimens.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Fewer subjects reported adverse events following treatment with desipramine alone than when receiving desipramine with cinacalcet (33 versus 86%), the most frequent of which (nausea and headache) have been reported for patients treated with either desipramine or cinacalcet.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study demonstrates that cinacalcet is a strong inhibitor of CYP2D6.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data suggest that during concomitant treatment with cinacalcet, dose adjustment may be necessary for drugs that demonstrate a narrow therapeutic index and are metabolized by CYP2D6.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Proteomic analysis of striatal proteins in the rat model of L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia (LID) is among the motor complications that arise in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients after a prolonged treatment with L-DOPA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To this day, transcriptome analysis has been performed in a rat model of LID</Chemical>
<Chemical>[Neurobiol.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dis., 17 (2004), 219] but information regarding the proteome is still lacking.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In the present study, we investigated the changes occurring at the protein level in striatal samples obtained from the unilaterally 6-hydroxydopamine-lesion rat model of PD treated with saline, L-DOPA or bromocriptine using two-dimensional difference gel electrophoresis and mass spectrometry (MS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats treated with L-DOPA were allocated to two groups based on the presence or absence of LID.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among the 2000 spots compared for statistical difference, 67 spots were significantly changed in abundance and identified using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight MS, atmospheric pressure matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization and HPLC coupled tandem MS (LC/MS/MS).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Out of these 67 proteins, LID significantly changed the expression level of five proteins: alphabeta-crystalin, gamma-enolase, guanidoacetate methyltransferase, vinculin, and proteasome alpha-2 subunit.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Complementary techniques such as western immunoblotting and immunohistochemistry were performed to investigate the validity of the data obtained using the proteomic approach.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In conclusion, this study provides new insights into the protein changes occurring in LID.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Two patients treated with parenteral paramethasone (Triniol) and dexamethasone (Sedionbel) are described.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>A few minutes after administration of the drugs, they presented urticaria (patients 1 and 2) and conjunctivitis (patient 1).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that paramethasone caused pseudoallergic reactions in our patients.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The basic mechanisms of those reactions are not yet fully understood.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Valproic acid induced encephalopathy--19 new cases in Germany from 1994 to 2003--a side effect associated to VPA-therapy not only in young children.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Valproic acid (VPA) is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic drug and is usually well-tolerated.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Rare serious complications may occur in some patients, including haemorrhagic pancreatitis, bone marrow suppression, VPA-induced hepatotoxicity and VPA-induced encephalopathy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Risk factors of sensorineural hearing loss in preterm infants.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Different lobular distributions of altered hepatocyte tight junctions in rat models of intrahepatic and extrahepatic cholestasis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although hepatocyte TJs are impaired in cholestasis, attempts to localize the precise site of hepatocyte TJ damage by freeze-fracture electron microscopy have produced limited information.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recently, several TJ-associated proteins like ZO-1 and 7H6 have been identified and characterized.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Immunolocalization of 7H6 appears to closely correlate with paracellular permeability.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We used rat models of intrahepatic cholestasis by ethinyl estradiol (EE) treatment and extrahepatic cholestasis by bile duct ligation (BDL) to precisely determine the site of TJ damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Alterations in hepatocyte TJs were assessed by double-immunolabeling for 7H6 and ZO-1 using a confocal laser scanning microscope.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In control rats, immunostaining for 7H6 and ZO-1 colocalized to outline bile canaliculi in a continuous fashion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, 7H6 and ZO-1 immunostaining was more discontinuous, outlining the bile canaliculi after BDL.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Immunostaining for 7H6, not ZO-1, decreased and predominantly appeared as discrete signals in the submembranous cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes after BDL.</Chemical>

<Chemical>After EE treatment, changes in immunostaining for 7H6 and ZO-1 were similar to those seen in periportal hepatocytes after BDL, but distributed more diffusely throughout the lobule.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study is the first to demonstrate that impairment of hepatocyte TJs occurs heterogenously in the liver lobule after BDL and suggests that BDL and EE treatments produce different lobular distributions of increased paracellular permeability.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Long term audiological evaluation of beta-thalassemic patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The objective of this study was to identify the incidence and to monitor the progression of hearing loss in children and young adults with beta-thalassemia major.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS: One hundred and four (104) patients aged 6-35 years (mean 17,2 years) participated in the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients were on a regular transfusion-chelation program maintaining a mean hemoglobin level of 9.5 gr/dl.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Subjects were receiving desferrioxamine (DFO) chelation treatment with a mean daily dose of 50-60 mg/kg, 5-6 days a week during the first six years of the study, which was then reduced to 40-50 mg/kg for the following eight years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients were followed for 8-14 years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Overall, 21 out of 104 patients (20.2%) presented with high frequency sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), either unilateral or bilateral.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No ototoxic factor, other than DFO, was present in any of the patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients with SNHL presented with relatively lower serum ferritin levels than those with normal hearing, however, no statistically significant difference was observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Subjects with SNHL were submitted to DFO reduction or temporary withdrawal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Following intervention, 7 out of 21 affected patients recovered, 10 remained stable and 4 demonstrated aggravation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The findings are indicative of DFO's contributing role in the development of hearing impairment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Regular audiologic evaluation is imperative in all thalassemic patients so that early changes may be recognized and treatment may be judiciously adjusted in order to prevent or reverse hearing impairment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Design and analysis of the HYPREN-trial: safety of enalapril and prazosin in the initial treatment phase of patients with congestive heart failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since the introduction of angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors into the adjunctive treatment of patients with congestive heart failure, cases of severe hypotension, especially on the first day of treatment, have occasionally been reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To assess the safety of the ACE inhibitor enalapril a multicenter, randomized, prazosin-controlled trial was designed that compared the incidence and severity of symptomatic hypotension on the first day of treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Trial medication was 2.5 mg enalapril or 0.5 prazosin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subjects were 1210 inpatients with New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class II and III.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients who received enalapril experienced clinically and statistically significantly less symptomatic hypotension (5.2%) than the patients who received prazosin (12.9%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All patients recovered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It was concluded that treatment with enalapril was well tolerated and it is, therefore, unreasonable to restrict the initiation of treatment with enalapril to inpatients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antagonism between interleukin 3 and erythropoietin in mice with azidothymidine-induced anemia and in bone marrow endothelial cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Azidothymidine (AZT)-induced anemia in mice can be reversed by the administration of IGF-IL-3 (fusion protein of insulin-like growth factor II (IGF II) and interleukin 3).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although interleukin 3 (IL-3) and erythropoietin (EPO) are known to act synergistically on hematopoietic cell proliferation in vitro, injection of IGF-IL-3 and EPO in AZT-treated mice resulted in a reduction of red cells and an increase of plasma EPO levels as compared to animals treated with IGF-IL-3 or EPO alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We tested the hypothesis that the antagonistic effect of IL-3 and EPO on erythroid cells may be mediated by endothelial cells.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bovine liver erythroid cells were cultured on monolayers of human bone marrow endothelial cells previously treated with EPO and IGF-IL-3.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was a significant reduction of thymidine incorporation into both erythroid and endothelial cells in cultures pre-treated with IGF-IL-3 and EPO.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Endothelial cell culture supernatants separated by ultrafiltration and ultracentrifugation from cells treated with EPO and IL-3 significantly reduced thymidine incorporation into erythroid cells as compared to identical fractions obtained from the media of cells cultured with EPO alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that endothelial cells treated simultaneously with EPO and IL-3 have a negative effect on erythroid cell production.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Independent but not additive effects of Na and Ca are shown by decreases in the values of [verapamil]o needed to reduce BF by 30% (IC30) with the following order of inhibitory potency: LNa > LCa > HCa > N, resulting LNa+HCa similar to LNa.</Chemical>

<Chemical>HCa = N.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results indicate that rat atrial spontaneous beating is more dependent on [Na]o than on [Ca]o in a range of +/- 50% of their normal concentration.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Sodium status influences chronic amphotericin B nephrotoxicity in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The nephrotoxic potential of amphotericin B (5 mg/kg per day intraperitoneally for 3 weeks) has been investigated in salt-depleted, normal-salt, and salt-loaded rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In salt-depleted rats, amphotericin B decreased creatinine clearance linearly with time, with an 85% reduction by week 3.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, in normal-salt rats creatinine clearance was decreased but to a lesser extent at week 2 and 3, and in salt-loaded rats creatinine clearance did not change for 2 weeks and was decreased by 43% at week 3.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All rats in the sodium-depleted group had histopathological evidence of patchy tubular cytoplasmic degeneration in tubules that was not observed in any normal-salt or salt-loaded rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Concentrations of amphotericin B in plasma were not significantly different among the three groups at any time during the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, at the end of 3 weeks, amphotericin B levels in the kidneys and liver were significantly higher in salt-depleted and normal-salt rats than those in salt-loaded rats, with plasma/kidney ratios of 21, 14, and 8 in salt-depleted, normal-salt, and salt-loaded rats, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, reductions in creatinine clearance and renal amphotericin B accumulation after chronic amphotericin B administration were enhanced by salt depletion and attenuated by sodium loading in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reversible inferior colliculus lesion in metronidazole-induced encephalopathy: magnetic resonance findings on diffusion-weighted and fluid attenuated inversion recovery imaging.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This is to present reversible inferior colliculus lesions in metronidazole-induced encephalopathy, to focus on the diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) and fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) imaging.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>From November 2005 to September 2007, 8 patients (5 men and 3 women) were diagnosed as having metronidazole-induced encephalopathy (age range; 43-78 years).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>They had been taking metronidazole (total dosage, 45-120 g; duration, 30 days to 2 months) to treat the infection in various organs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Initial brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) were obtained after the hospitalization, including DWI (8/8), apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) map (4/8), FLAIR (7/8), and T2-weighted image (8/8).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Follow-up MRIs were performed on 5 patients from third to 14th days after discontinuation of metronidazole administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Findings of initial and follow-up MRIs were retrospectively evaluated by 2 neuroradiologists by consensus, to analyze the presence of abnormal signal intensities, their locations, and signal changes on follow-up images.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: Initial MRIs showed abnormal high signal intensities on DWI and FLAIR (or T2-weighted image) at the dentate nucleus (8/8), inferior colliculus (6/8), corpus callosum (2/8), pons (2/8), medulla (1/8), and bilateral cerebral white matter (1/8).</Chemical>

<Chemical>High-signal intensity lesions on DWI tended to show low signal intensity on ADC map (3/4), but in one patient, high signal intensity was shown at bilateral dentate nuclei on not only DWI but also ADC map.</Chemical>

<Chemical>All the lesions in dentate, inferior colliculus, pons, and medullas had been resolved completely on follow-up MRIs in 5 patients, but in 1 patient of them, corpus callosal lesion persisted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reversible inferior colliculus lesions could be considered as the characteristic for metronidazole-induced encephalopathy, next to the dentate nucleus involvement.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Comparison of the respiratory effects of i.v. infusions of morphine and regional analgesia by extradural block.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of postoperative respiratory apnoea was compared between five patients receiving a continuous i.v. infusion of morphine (mean 73.6 mg) and five patients receiving a continuous extradural infusion of 0.25% bupivacaine (mean 192 mg) in the 24-h period following upper abdominal surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Monitoring consisted of airflow detection by a carbon dioxide analyser, chest wall movement detected by pneumatic capsules, and continuous electrocardiograph recorded with a Holter ambulatory monitor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both obstructive (P less than 0.05) and central apnoea (P less than 0.05) occurred more frequently in patients who had a morphine infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was also a higher incidence of tachyarrhythmias (P less than 0.05) and ventricular ectopic beats (P less than 0.05) in the morphine infusion group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Magnetic resonance volumetry of the cerebellum in epileptic patients after phenytoin overdosages.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of this study was to evaluate the relationship between phenytoin medication and cerebellar atrophy in patients who had experienced clinical intoxication.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five females and 6 males, 21-59 years of age, were examined with a 1.5-T whole-body system using a circular polarized head coil.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Conventional spin echo images were acquired in the sagittal and transverse orientation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition, we performed a high-resolution 3D gradient echo, T1-weighted sequences at a 1-mm slice thickness.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The images were subsequently processed to obtain volumetric data for the cerebellum.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cerebellar volume for the patient group ranged between 67.66 and 131.08 ml (mean 108.9 ml).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition 3D gradient echo data sets from 10 healthy male and 10 healthy female age-matched volunteers were used to compare cerebellar volumes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Using linear regression we found that no correlation exists between seizure duration, elevation of phenytoin serum levels and cerebellar volume.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, multiple regression for the daily dosage, duration of phenytoin treatment and cerebellar volume revealed a correlation of these parameters.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that phenytoin overdosage does not necessarily result in cerebellar atrophy and it is unlikely that phenytoin medication was the only cause of cerebellar atrophy in the remaining patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Quantitative morphometric studies of the cerebellum provide valuable insights into the pathogenesis of cerebellar disorders.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Evaluation of cardiac troponin I and T levels as markers of myocardial damage in doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy rats, and their relationship with echocardiographic and histological findings.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Cardiac troponins I (cTnI) and T (cTnT) have been shown to be highly sensitive and specific markers of myocardial cell injury.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We investigated the diagnostic value of cTnI and cTnT for the diagnosis of myocardial damage in a rat model of doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiomyopathy, and we examined the relationship between serial cTnI and cTnT with the development of cardiac disorders monitored by echocardiography and histological examinations in this model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Thirty-five Wistar rats were given 1.5 mg/kg DOX, i.v., weekly for up to 8 weeks for a total cumulative dose of 12 mg/kg BW.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ten rats received saline as a control group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>cTnI was measured with Access(R) (ng/ml) and a research immunoassay (pg/ml), and compared with cTnT, CK-MB mass and CK.</Chemical>

<Chemical>By using transthoracic echocardiography, anterior and posterior wall thickness, LV diameters and LV fractional shortening (FS) were measured in all rats before DOX or saline, and at weeks 6 and 9 after treatment in all surviving rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Histology was performed in DOX-rats at 6 and 9 weeks after the last DOX dose and in all controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Eighteen of the DOX rats died prematurely of general toxicity during the 9-week period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>End-diastolic (ED) and end-systolic (ES) LV diameters/BW significantly increased, whereas LV FS was decreased after 9 weeks in the DOX group (p<0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These parameters remained unchanged in controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Histological evaluation of hearts from all rats given DOX revealed significant slight degrees of perivascular and interstitial fibrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 7 of the 18 rats, degeneration and myocyte vacuolisation were found.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Only five of the controls exhibited evidence of very slight perivascular fibrosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A significant rise in cTnT was found in DOX rats after cumulative doses of 7.5 and 12 mg/kg in comparison with baseline (p<0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>cTnT found in rats after 12 mg/kg were significantly greater than that found after 7.5 mg/kg DOX.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Maximal cTnI (pg/ml) and cTnT levels were significantly increased in DOX rats compared with controls (p=0.006, 0.007).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>cTnI (ng/ml), CK-MB mass and CK remained unchanged in DOX rats compared with controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All markers remained stable in controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Analysis of data revealed a significant correlation between maximal cTnT and ED and ES LV diameters/BW (r=0.81 and 0.65; p<0.0001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>A significant relationship was observed between maximal cTnT and the extent of myocardial morphological changes, and between LV diameters/BW and histological findings.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Among markers of ischemic injury after DOX in rats, cTnT showed the greatest ability to detect myocardial damage assessed by echocardiographic detection and histological changes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although there was a discrepancy between the amount of cTnI and cTnT after DOX, probably due to heterogeneity in cross-reactivities of mAbs to various cTnI and cTnT forms, it is likely that cTnT in rats after DOX indicates cell damage determined by the magnitude of injury induced and that cTnT should be a useful marker for the prediction of experimentally induced cardiotoxicity and possibly for cardioprotective experiments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Calcineurin-inhibitor induced pain syndrome (CIPS): a severe disabling complication after organ transplantation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bone pain after transplantation is a frequent complication that can be caused by several diseases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment strategies depend on the correct diagnosis of the pain.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nine patients with severe pain in their feet, which was registered after transplantation, were investigated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bone scans showed an increased tracer uptake of the foot bones.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Magnetic resonance imaging demonstrated bone marrow oedema in the painful bones.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Pain was not explained by other diseases causing foot pain, like reflex sympathetic dystrophy, polyneuropathy, Morton's neuralgia, gout, osteoporosis, avascular necrosis, intermittent claudication, orthopaedic foot deformities, stress fractures, and hyperparathyroidism.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The reduction of cyclosporine- or tacrolimus trough levels and the administration of calcium channel blockers led to relief of pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The Calcineurin-inhibitor Induced Pain Syndrome (CIPS) is a rare but severe side effect of cyclosporine or tacrolimus and is accurately diagnosed by its typical presentation, magnetic resonance imaging and bone scans.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Incorrect diagnosis of the syndrome will lead to a significant reduction of life quality in patients suffering from CIPS.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The haemodynamic effects of propofol in combination with ephedrine in elderly patients (ASA groups 3 and 4).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The marked vasodilator and negative inotropic effects of propofol are disadvantages in frail elderly patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We investigated the safety and efficacy of adding different doses of ephedrine to propofol in order to obtund the hypotensive response.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The haemodynamic effects of adding 15, 20 or 25 mg of ephedrine to 200 mg of propofol were compared to control in 40 ASA 3/4 patients over 60 years presenting for genito-urinary surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The addition of ephedrine to propofol appears to be an effective method of obtunding the hypotensive response to propofol at all doses used in this study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, marked tachycardia associated with the use of ephedrine in combination with propofol occurred in the majority of patients, occasionally reaching high levels in individual patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Due to the risk of this tachycardia inducing myocardial ischemia, we would not recommend the use in elderly patients of any of the ephedrine/propofol/mixtures studied.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neurotoxicity of halogenated hydroxyquinolines: clinical analysis of cases reported outside Japan.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An analysis is presented of 220 cases of possible neurotoxic reactions to halogenated hydroxyquinolines reported from outside Japan.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 80 cases insufficient information was available for adequate comment and in 29 a relationship to the administration of clioquinol could be excluded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the remainder, a relationship to clioquinol was considered probable in 42 and possible in 69 cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In six of the probable cases the neurological disturbance consisted of an acute reversible encephalopathy usually related to the ingestion of a high dose of clioquinol over a short period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The most common manifestation, observed in 15 further cases, was isolated optic atrophy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was most frequently found in children, many of whom had received clioquinol as treatment for acrodermatitis enteropathica.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the remaining cases, a combination of myelopathy, visual disturbance, and peripheral neuropathy was the most common manifestation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Isolated myelopathy or peripheral neuropathy, or these manifestations occurring together, were infrequent.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The onset of all manifestations (except toxic encephalopathy) was usually subacute, with subsequent partial recovery.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Older subjects tended to display more side effects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The full syndrome of subacute myelo-optic neuropathy was more frequent in women, but they tended to have taken greater quantities of the drug.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Epileptic seizures following cortical application of fibrin sealants containing tranexamic acid in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Fibrin sealants (FS) derived from human plasma are frequently used in neurosurgery.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In order to increase clot stability, FS typically contain aprotinin, a natural fibrinolysis inhibitor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recently, synthetic fibrinolysis inhibitors such as tranexamic acid (tAMCA) have been considered as substitutes for aprotinin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, tAMCA has been shown to cause epileptic seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We wanted to study whether tAMCA retains its convulsive action if incorporated into a FS. METHOD:</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>FS containing aprotinin or different concentrations of tAMCA (0.5-47.5 mg/ml) were applied to the pial surface of the cortex of anaesthetized rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The response of the animals was evaluated using electroencephalography and by monitoring the clinical behaviour during and after recovery from anaesthesia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>FINDINGS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>FS containing tAMCA caused paroxysmal brain activity which was associated with distinct convulsive behaviours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The degree of these seizures increased with increasing concentration of tAMCA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, FS containing 47.5 mg/ml tAMCA evoked generalized seizures in all tested rats (n=6) while the lowest concentration of tAMCA (0.5 mg/ml) only evoked brief episodes of jerk-correlated convulsive potentials in 1 of 6 rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, FS containing aprotinin did not evoke any paroxysmal activity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>INTERPRETATION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tranexamic acid retains its convulsive action within FS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, use of FS containing tAMCA for surgery within or close to the CNS may pose a substantial risk to the patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A diet promoting sugar dependency causes behavioral cross-sensitization to a low dose of amphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous research in this laboratory has shown that a diet of intermittent excessive sugar consumption produces a state with neurochemical and behavioral similarities to drug dependency.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The present study examined whether female rats on various regimens of sugar access would show behavioral cross-sensitization to a low dose of amphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After a 30-min baseline measure of locomotor activity (day 0), animals were maintained on a cyclic diet of 12-h deprivation followed by 12-h access to 10% sucrose solution and chow pellets (12 h access starting 4 h after onset of the dark period) for 21 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Locomotor activity was measured again for 30 min at the beginning of days 1 and 21 of sugar access.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Beginning on day 22, all rats were maintained on ad libitum chow.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nine days later locomotor activity was measured in response to a single low dose of amphetamine (0.5 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The animals that had experienced cyclic sucrose and chow were hyperactive in response to amphetamine compared with four control groups (ad libitum 10% sucrose and chow followed by amphetamine injection, cyclic chow followed by amphetamine injection, ad libitum chow with amphetamine, or cyclic 10% sucrose and chow with a saline injection).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that a diet comprised of alternating deprivation and access to a sugar solution and chow produces bingeing on sugar that leads to a long lasting state of increased sensitivity to amphetamine, possibly due to a lasting alteration in the dopamine system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>D-penicillamine-induced angiopathy in rats. The effect of high dose D-penicillamine treatment on aortic permeability to albumin and on the ultrastructure of the vessel.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male Sprague-Dawley rats were treated with D-penicillamine (D-pen) 500 mg/kg/day for 10 or 42 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pair fed rats served as controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Changes in aortic morphology were examined by light- and transmission-electron microscopy (TEM).</Chemical>

<Chemical>In addition, the endothelial permeability and the penetration through the aortic wall of albumin were studied 10 minutes, 24 and 48 hours after i. v. injection of human serum 131I-albumin (131I-HSA).</Chemical>
<Chemical>TEM revealed extensive elastolysis in the arterial wall of D-pen-treated rats, consistent with an inhibitory effect on crosslink formation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In experimental animals excess deposition of collagen and glycoaminoglycans was observed in the subendothelial and medial layer of the aortic wall, together with prominent basal membrane substance around aortic smooth muscle cells.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The aorta/serum-ratio and the radioactive build-up 24 and 48 hours after injection of 131I-HSA was reduced in animals treated with D-pen for 42 days, indicating an impeded transmural transport of tracer which may be caused by a steric exclusion effect of abundant hyaluronate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The endothelial ultrastructure was unaffected by D-pen, and no differences in aortic 131I-HSA radioactivity or aorta/serum-ratio were recorded between experimental and control groups 10 minutes after tracer injection, indicating that the permeability of the endothelial barrier to albumin remained unaffected by D-pen treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These observations support the hypothesis that treatment with high doses of D-pen may induce a fibroproliferative response in rat aorta, possibly by an inhibitory effect on the cross-linking of collagen and elastin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Brain natriuretic peptide is a predictor of anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anthracyclines are effective antineoplastic drugs, but they frequently cause dose-related cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The cardiotoxicity of conventional anthracycline therapy highlights a need to search for methods that are highly sensitive and capable of predicting cardiac dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We measured the plasma level of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) to determine whether BNP might serve as a simple diagnostic indicator of anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity in patients with acute leukemia treated with a daunorubicin (DNR)-containing regimen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirteen patients with acute leukemia were treated with a DNR-containing regimen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cardiac functions were evaluated with radionuclide angiography before chemotherapies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The plasma levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and BNP were measured at the time of radionuclide angiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Three patients developed congestive heart failure after the completion of chemotherapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Five patients were diagnosed as having subclinical heart failure after the completion of chemotherapy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The plasma levels of BNP in all the patients with clinical and subclinical heart failure increased above the normal limit (40 pg/ml) before the detection of clinical or subclinical heart failure by radionuclide angiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>On the other hand, BNP did not increase in the patients without heart failure given DNR, even at more than 700 mg/m(2).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The plasma level of ANP did not always increase in all the patients with clinical and subclinical heart failure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These preliminary results suggest that BNP may be useful as an early and sensitive indicator of anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antibacterial medication use during pregnancy and risk of birth defects: National Birth Defects Prevention Study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To estimate the association between antibacterial medications and selected birth defects.</Chemical>

<Chemical>DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS: Population-based, multisite, case-control study of women who had pregnancies affected by 1 of more than 30 eligible major birth defects identified via birth defect surveillance programs in 10 states (n = 13 155) and control women randomly selected from the same geographical regions (n = 4941).</Chemical>
<Chemical>MAIN EXPOSURE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reported maternal use of antibacterials (1 month before pregnancy through the end of the first trimester).</Chemical>
<Chemical>MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Odds ratios (ORs) measuring the association between antibacterial use and selected birth defects adjusted for potential confounders.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The reported use of antibacterials increased during pregnancy, peaking during the third month.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sulfonamides were associated with anencephaly (adjusted OR [AOR] = 3.4; 95% confidence interval</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>[CI], 1.3-8.8), hypoplastic left heart syndrome (AOR = 3.2; 95% CI, 1.3-7.6), coarctation of the aorta (AOR = 2.7; 95% CI, 1.3-5.6), choanal atresia (AOR = 8.0; 95% CI, 2.7-23.5), transverse limb deficiency (AOR = 2.5; 95% CI, 1.0-5.9), and diaphragmatic hernia (AOR = 2.4; 95% CI, 1.1-5.4).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Nitrofurantoins were associated with anophthalmia or microphthalmos (AOR = 3.7; 95% CI, 1.1-12.2), hypoplastic left heart syndrome (AOR = 4.2; 95% CI, 1.9-9.1), atrial septal defects (AOR = 1.9; 95% CI, 1.1-3.4), and cleft lip with cleft palate (AOR = 2.1; 95% CI, 1.2-3.9).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Other antibacterial agents that showed associations included erythromycins (2 defects), penicillins (1 defect), cephalosporins (1 defect), and quinolones (1 defect).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Reassuringly, penicillins, erythromycins, and cephalosporins, although used commonly by pregnant women, were not associated with many birth defects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sulfonamides and nitrofurantoins were associated with several birth defects, indicating a need for additional scrutiny.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Incidence of neoplasms in patients with rheumatoid arthritis exposed to different treatment regimens.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Immunosuppressive drugs have been used during the last 30 years in treatment of patients with severe rheumatoid arthritis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The drugs commonly used are cyclophosphamide and chlorambucil (alkylating agents), azathioprine (purine analogue), and methotrexate (folic acid analogue).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There is evidence that all four immunosuppressive drugs can reduce synovitis, but disease activity almost always recurs after therapy is stopped.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Since adverse reactions are frequent, less than 50 percent of patients are able to continue a particular drug for more than one year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Since it takes three to 12 months to achieve maximal effects, those patients who are unable to continue the drug receive little benefit from it.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients treated with alkylating agents have an increased risk of development of acute nonlymphocytic leukemia, and both alkylating agents and azathioprine are associated with the development of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cyclophosphamide therapy increases the risk of carcinoma of the bladder.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There have been several long-term studies of patients with rheumatoid arthritis treated with azathioprine and cyclophosphamide and the incidence of most of the common cancers is not increased.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Data on the possible increased risk of malignancy in rheumatoid arthritis are still being collected, and until further information is available, the use of immunosuppressive drugs, particularly alkylating agents, in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis should be reserved for patients with severe progressive disease or life-threatening complications.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Patterns of hepatic injury induced by methyldopa.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Twelve patients with liver disease related to methyldopa were seen between 1967 and 1977.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Illness occurred within 1--9 weeks of commencement of therapy in 9 patients, the remaining 3 patients having received the drug for 13 months, 15 months and 7 years before experiencing symptoms.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Jaundice with tender hepatomegaly, usually preceded by symptoms of malaise, anorexia, nausea and vomiting, and associated with upper abdominal pain, was an invariable finding in all patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Biochemical liver function tests indicated hepatocellular necrosis and correlated with histopathological evidence of hepatic injury, the spectrum of which ranged from fatty change and focal hepatocellular necrosis to massive hepatic necrosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Most patients showed moderate to severe acute hepatitis or chronic active hepatitis with associated cholestasis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The drug was withdrawn on presentation to hospital in 11 patients, with rapid clinical improvement in 9.</Chemical>

<Chemical>One patient died, having presented in hepatic failure, and another, who had been taking methyldopa for 7 years, showed slower clinical and biochemical resolution over a period of several months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The remaining patient in the series developed fulminant hepatitis when the drug was accidentally recommenced 1 year after a prior episode of methyldopa-induced hepatitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this latter patient, and in 2 others, the causal relationship between methyldopa and hepatic dysfunction was proved with the recurrence of hepatitis within 2 weeks of re-exposure to the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A phase I/II study of paclitaxel plus cisplatin as first-line therapy for head and neck cancers: preliminary results.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Improved outcomes among patients with head and neck carcinomas require investigations of new drugs for induction therapy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Preliminary results of an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group study of single-agent paclitaxel (Taxol; Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Princeton, NJ) reported a 37% response rate in patients with head and neck cancer, and the paclitaxel/cisplatin combination has been used successfully and has significantly improved median response duration in ovarian cancer patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We initiated a phase I/II trial to determine the response and toxicity of escalating paclitaxel doses combined with fixed-dose cisplatin with granulocyte colony-stimulating factor support in patients with untreated locally advanced inoperable head and neck carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To date, 23 men with a median age of 50 years and good performance status have entered the trial.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Primary tumor sites were oropharynx, 10 patients; hypopharynx, four; larynx, two; oral cavity, three; unknown primary, two; and nasal cavity and parotid gland, one each.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of 20 patients evaluable for toxicity, four had stage III and 16 had stage IV disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment, given every 21 days for a maximum of three cycles, consisted of paclitaxel by 3-hour infusion followed the next day by a fixed dose of cisplatin (75 mg/m2).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dose levels incorporate escalating paclitaxel doses, and intrapatient escalations within a given dose level are permitted if toxicity permits.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At the time of this writing, dose level 4 (260, 270, and 280 mg/m2) is being evaluated; three patients from this level are evaluable.</Chemical>
<Chemical>With paclitaxel doses of 200 mg/m2 and higher, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor 5 micrograms/kg/d is given (days 4 through 12).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of 18 patients evaluable for response, seven (39%) achieved a complete response and six (33%) achieved a partial response.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Three patients had no change and disease progressed in two.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The overall response rate is 72%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Eleven responding patients had subsequent surgery/radiotherapy or radical radiotherapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two pathologic complete responses were observed in patients who had achieved clinical complete responses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Alopecia, paresthesias, and arthralgias/myalgias have occurred frequently, but with one exception (a grade 3 myalgia) they have been grade 1 or 2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No dose-limiting hematologic toxicity has been seen.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Paclitaxel/cisplatin is an effective first-line regimen for locoregionally advanced head and neck cancer and continued study is warranted.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Results thus far suggest no dose-response effect for paclitaxel doses above 200 mg/m2.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A phase I study of 4'-0-tetrahydropyranyladriamycin. Clinical pharmacology and pharmacokinetics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A Phase I study of intravenous (IV) bolus 4'-0-tetrahydropyranyladriamycin (Pirarubicin) was done in 55 patients in good performance status with refractory tumors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Twenty-six had minimal prior therapy (good risk), 23 had extensive prior therapy (poor risk), and six had renal and/or hepatic dysfunction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A total of 167 courses at doses of 15 to 70 mg/m2 were evaluable.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Maximum tolerated dose in good-risk patients was 70 mg/m2, and in poor-risk patients, 60 mg/m2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The dose-limiting toxic effect was transient noncumulative granulocytopenia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Granulocyte nadir was on day 14 (range, 4-22).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Less frequent toxic effects included thrombocytopenia, anemia, nausea, mild alopecia, phlebitis, and mucositis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myelosuppression was more in patients with hepatic dysfunction.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Pharmacokinetic analyses in 21 patients revealed Pirarubicin plasma T 1/2 alpha (+/- SE) of 2.5 +/- 0.85 minutes, T beta 1/2 of 25.6 +/- 6.5 minutes, and T 1/2 gamma of 23.6 +/- 7.6 hours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The area under the curve was 537 +/- 149 ng/ml x hours, volume of distribution (Vd) 3504 +/- 644 l/m2, and total clearance (ClT) was 204 + 39.3 l/hour/m2.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Adriamycinol, doxorubicin, adriamycinone, and tetrahydropyranyladriamycinol were the metabolites detected in plasma and the amount of doxorubicin was less than or equal to 10% of the total metabolites.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urinary excretion of Pirarubicin in the first 24 hours was less than or equal to 10%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Activity was noted in mesothelioma, leiomyosarcoma, and basal cell carcinoma.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The recommended starting dose for Phase II trials is 60 mg/m2 IV bolus every 3 weeks.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Differential effects of gamma-hexachlorocyclohexane (lindane) on pharmacologically-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Gamma-hexachlorocyclohexane (gamma-HCH), the active ingredient of the insecticide lindane, has been shown to decrease seizure threshold to pentylenetrazol (PTZ) 3 h after exposure to gamma-HCH and conversely increase threshold to PTZ-induced seizures 24 h after exposure to gamma-HCH (Vohland et al. 1981).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this study, the severity of response to other seizure-inducing agents was tested in mice 1 and 24 h after intraperitoneal administration of 80 mg/kg gamma-HCH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>One hour after the administration of gamma-HCH, the activity of seizure-inducing agents was increased, regardless of their mechanism, while 24 h after gamma-HCH a differential response was observed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Seizure activity due to PTZ and picrotoxin (PTX) was significantly decreased; however, seizure activity due to 3-mercaptopropionic acid (MPA), bicuculline (BCC), methyl 6,7-dimethoxy-4-ethyl-B-carboline-3-carboxylate (DMCM), or strychnine (STR) was not different from control.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The pharmacological challenge data suggest that tolerance may occur to seizure activity induced by PTZ and PTX 24 h after gamma-HCH, since the response to only these two seizure-inducing agents is decreased.</Chemical>
