text: <Chemical>Severe ocular and orbital toxicity after intracarotid injection of carboplatin for recurrent glioblastomas.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Glioblastoma is a malignant tumor that occurs in the cerebrum during adulthood.</Chemical>
<Chemical>With current treatment regimens including combined surgery, radiation and chemotherapy, the average life expectancy of the patients is limited to approximately 1 year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Therefore, patients with glioblastoma sometimes have intracarotid injection of carcinostatics added to the treatment regimen.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Generally, carboplatin is said to have milder side effects than cisplatin, whose ocular and orbital toxicity are well known.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, we experienced a case of severe ocular and orbital toxicity after intracarotid injection of carboplatin, which is infrequently reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 58-year-old man received an intracarotid injection of carboplatin for recurrent glioblastomas in his left temporal lobe.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>He complained of pain and visual disturbance in the ipsilateral eye 30 h after the injection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Various ocular symptoms and findings caused by carboplatin toxicity were seen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>He was treated with intravenous administration of corticosteroids and glycerin for 6 days after the injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although the intraocular pressure elevation caused by secondary acute angle-closure glaucoma decreased and ocular pain diminished, inexorable papilledema and exudative retinal detachment continued for 3 weeks.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Finally, 6 weeks later, diffuse chorioretinal atrophy with optic atrophy occurred and the vision in his left eye was lost.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>When performing intracarotid injection of carboplatin, we must be aware of its potentially blinding ocular toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is recommended that further studies and investigations are undertaken in the effort to minimize such severe side effects.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>CI-921 (NSC 343499; 9-[[2-methoxy-4-[(methylsulphonyl)amino]phenyl]amino] -N,5-dimethyl- 4-acridinecarboxamide) is a topoisomerase II poison with high experimental antitumour activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It was administered by 15 min infusion to 16 evaluable patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) (7 with no prior treatment, 9 patients in relapse following surgery/radiotherapy) at a dose (648 mg/m2 divided over 3 days, repeated every 3 weeks) determined by phase I trial.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients had a median performance status of 1 (WHO), and median age of 61 years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The histology comprised squamous carcinoma (11), adenocarcinoma (1), mixed histology (2), bronchio-alveolar carcinoma (1) and large cell undifferentiated carcinoma (1).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neutropenia grade greater than or equal to 3 was seen in 15 patients, infections with recovery in 3, and grand mal seizures in 1 patient.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Grade less than or equal to 2 nausea and vomiting occurred in 66% courses and phlebitis in the infusion arm in 37%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>1 patient with squamous cell carcinoma achieved a partial response lasting 5 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Further testing in this and other tumour types using multiple daily schedules is warranted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Alpha-lipoic acid prevents mitochondrial damage and neurotoxicity in experimental chemotherapy neuropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The study investigates if alpha-lipoic acid is neuroprotective against chemotherapy induced neurotoxicity, if mitochondrial damage plays a critical role in toxic neurodegenerative cascade, and if neuroprotective effects of alpha-lipoic acid depend on mitochondria protection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We used an in vitro model of chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy that closely mimic the in vivo condition by exposing primary cultures of dorsal root ganglion (DRG) sensory neurons to paclitaxel and cisplatin, two widely used and highly effective chemotherapeutic drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This approach allowed investigating the efficacy of alpha-lipoic acid in preventing axonal damage and apoptosis and the function and ultrastructural morphology of mitochondria after exposure to toxic agents and alpha-lipoic acid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our results demonstrate that both cisplatin and paclitaxel cause early mitochondrial impairment with loss of membrane potential and induction of autophagic vacuoles in neurons.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Alpha-lipoic acid exerts neuroprotective effects against chemotherapy induced neurotoxicity in sensory neurons: it rescues the mitochondrial toxicity and induces the expression of frataxin, an essential mitochondrial protein with anti-oxidant and chaperone properties.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion mitochondrial toxicity is an early common event both in paclitaxel and cisplatin induced neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Alpha-lipoic acid protects sensory neurons through its anti-oxidant and mitochondrial regulatory functions, possibly inducing the expression of frataxin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that alpha-lipoic acid might reduce the risk of developing peripheral nerve toxicity in patients undergoing chemotherapy and encourage further confirmatory clinical trials.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Optimising stroke prevention in non-valvular atrial fibrillation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Atrial fibrillation is associated with substantial morbidity and mortality.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Pooled data from trials comparing antithrombotic treatment with placebo have shown that warfarin reduces the risk of stroke by 62%, and that aspirin alone reduces the risk by 22%.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Overall, in high-risk patients, warfarin is superior to aspirin in preventing strokes, with a relative risk reduction of 36%.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The concomitant administration of etoposide and cyclosporin A resulted in eradication of hitherto refractory leukemic infiltration of bone marrow.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The hematologic effects of cefonicid and cefazedone in the dog: a potential model of cephalosporin hematotoxicity in man.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cephalosporin antibiotics cause a variety of hematologic disturbances in man, the pathogeneses and hematopathology of which remain poorly characterized.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There is a need for a well-defined animal model in which these blood dyscrasias can be studied.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In four subacute toxicity studies, the intravenous administration of cefonicid or cefazedone to beagle dogs caused a dose-dependent incidence of anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia after 1-3 months of treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A nonregenerative anemia was the most compromising of the cytopenias and occurred in approximately 50% of dogs receiving 400-500 mg/kg cefonicid or 540-840 mg/kg cefazedone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All three cytopenias were completely reversible following cessation of treatment; the time required for recovery of the erythron (approximately 1 month) was considerably longer than that of the granulocytes and platelets (hours to a few days).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Upon rechallenge with either cephalosporin, the hematologic syndrome was reproduced in most dogs tested; cefonicid (but not cefazedone)-treated dogs showed a substantially reduced induction period (15 +/- 5 days) compared to that of the first exposure to the drug (61 +/- 24 days).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This observation, along with the rapid rate of decline in red cell mass parameters of affected dogs, suggests that a hemolytic component complicated the red cell production problem and that multiple toxicologic mechanisms contributed to the cytopenia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We conclude that the administration of high doses of cefonicid or cefazedone to dogs can induce hematotoxicity similar to the cephalosporin-induced blood dyscrasias described in man and thus provides a useful model for studying the mechanisms of these disorders.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Prolonged cholestasis after troleandomycin-induced acute hepatitis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We report the case of a patient in whom troleandomycin-induced hepatitis was followed by prolonged anicteric cholestasis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Jaundice occurred after administration of troleandomycin for 7 days and was associated with hypereosinophilia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Jaundice disappeared within 3 months but was followed by prolonged anicteric cholestasis marked by pruritus and high levels of alkaline phosphatase and gammaglutamyltransferase activities.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Finally, pruritus disappeared within 19 months, and liver tests returned to normal 27 months after the onset of hepatitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This observation demonstrates that prolonged cholestasis can follow troleandomycin-induced acute hepatitis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Lovastatin and simvastatin are the 2 best-known members of the class of hypolipidaemic agents known as HMG CoA reductase inhibitors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical experience with lovastatin includes over 5000 patients, 700 of whom have been treated for 2 years or more, and experience with simvastatin includes over 3500 patients, of whom 350 have been treated for 18 months or more.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lovastatin has been marketed in the United States for over 6 months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both agents show substantial clinical efficacy, with reductions in total cholesterol of over 30% and in LDL-cholesterol of 40% in clinical studies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Modest increases in HDL-cholesterol levels of about 10% are also reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical tolerability of both agents has been good, with fewer than 3% of patients withdrawn from treatment because of clinical adverse experiences.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ophthalmological examinations in over 1100 patients treated with one or the other agent have revealed no evidence of significant short term (up to 2 years) cataractogenic potential.</Chemical>
<Chemical>One to 2% of patients have elevations of serum transaminases to greater than 3 times the upper limit of normal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These episodes are asymptomatic and reversible when therapy is discontinued.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Minor elevations of creatine kinase levels are reported in about 5% of patients.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Myopathy, associated in some cases with myoglobinuria, and in 2 cases with transient renal failure, has been rarely reported with lovastatin, especially in patients concomitantly treated with cyclosporin, gemfibrozil or niacin.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Alpha and beta coma in drug intoxication uncomplicated by cerebral hypoxia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Four patients who were rendered comatose or stuporous by drug intoxication, but who were not hypoxic, are described.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient with nitrazepam overdose and two of those with chlormethiazole intoxication conformed to the criteria of 'alpha coma', showing non-reactive generalized or frontally predominant alpha activity in the EEG.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The fourth patient who was unconscious after chlormethiazole administration exhibite generalized non-reactive activity in the slow beta range.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All four recovered completely without neurological sequelae following the withdrawal of the offending agents.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The similarities between the effects of structural lesions and pharmacological depression of the brain stem reticular formation are discussed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is suggested that in both situations disturbed reticulo-thalamic interactions are important in the pathogenesis of alpha coma.</Chemical>

<Chemical>It is concluded that when this electroencephalographic and behavioural picture is seen in drug intoxication, in the absence of significant hypoxaemia, a favourable outcome may be anticipated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Omitting fentanyl reduces nausea and vomiting, without increasing pain, after sevoflurane for day surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Despite advantages of induction and maintenance of anaesthesia with sevoflurane, postoperative nausea and vomiting occurs frequently.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fentanyl is a commonly used supplement that may contribute to this, although it may also improve analgesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This double-blind study examined the incidence and severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting and pain in the first 24 h after sevoflurane anaesthesia in 216 adult day surgery patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients were randomly allocated to either receive or not receive 1 1 fentanyl, while a third group received dexamethasone in addition to fentanyl.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Omission of fentanyl did not reduce the overall incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting, but did reduce the incidence of vomiting and/or moderate to severe nausea prior to discharge from 20% and 17% with fentanyl and fentanyl-dexamethasone, respectively, to 5% (P = 0.013).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antiemetic requirements were reduced from 24% and 31% to 7% (P = 0.0012).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dexamethasone had no significant effect on the incidence or severity of postoperative nausea and vomiting.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Combining the two fentanyl groups revealed further significant benefits from the avoidance of opioids, reducing postoperative nausea and vomiting and nausea prior to discharge from 35% and 33% to 22% and 19% (P = 0.049 and P = 0.035), respectively, while nausea in the first 24 h was decreased from 42% to 27% (P = 0.034).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain severity and analgesic requirements were unaffected by the omission of fentanyl.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fentanyl did reduce minor intraoperative movement but had no sevoflurane-sparing effect and increased respiratory depression, hypotension and bradycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>As fentanyl exacerbated postoperative nausea and vomiting without an improvement in postoperative pain and also had adverse cardiorespiratory effects, it appears to be an unnecessary and possibly detrimental supplement to sevoflurane in day surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

<Chemical>Transient platypnea-orthodeoxia-like syndrome induced by propafenone overdose in a young woman with Ebstein's anomaly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this report we describe the case of a 37-year-old white woman with Ebstein's anomaly, who developed a rare syndrome called platypnea-orthodeoxia, characterized by massive right-to-left interatrial shunting with transient profound hypoxia and cyanosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This shunt of blood via a patent foramen ovale occurred in the presence of a normal pulmonary artery pressure, and was probably precipitated by a propafenone overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This drug caused biventricular dysfunction, due to its negative inotropic effect, and hypotension, due to its peripheral vasodilatory effect.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These effects gave rise to an increase in the right atrial pressure and a decrease in the left one with a consequent stretching of the foramen ovale and the creation of massive right-to-left shunting.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In our case this interatrial shunt was very accurately detected at bubble contrast echocardiography.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cisplatin has minimal antitumor activity when used as second- or third-line treatment of metastatic breast carcinoma.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Older reports suggest an objective response rate of 8% when 60-120 mg/m2 of cisplatin is administered every 3-4 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although a dose-response effect has been observed with cisplatin, the dose-limiting toxicities associated with cisplatin (e.g., nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, and neurotoxicity) have limited its use as a treatment for breast carcinoma.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>WR-2721 or amifostine initially was developed to protect military personnel in the event of nuclear war.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amifostine subsequently was shown to protect normal tissues from the toxic effects of alkylating agents and cisplatin without decreasing the antitumor effect of the chemotherapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A Phase II study of the combination of cisplatin plus amifostine was conducted in patients with progressive metastatic breast carcinoma who had received one, but not more than one, chemotherapy regimen for metastatic disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients received amifostine, 910 mg/m2 intravenously over 15 minutes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After completion of the amifostine infusion, cisplatin 120 mg/m2 was administered over 30 minutes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intravenous hydration and mannitol was administered before and after cisplatin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment was administered every 3 weeks until disease progression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Forty-four patients were enrolled in the study of which 7 (16%) were ineligible.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A median of 2 cycles of therapy was administered to the 37 eligible patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Six partial responses were observed for an overall response rate of 16%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Most patients (57%) stopped treatment because of disease progression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neurologic toxicity was reported in 52% of patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Seven different life-threatening toxicities were observed in patients while receiving treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The combination of cisplatin and amifostine in this study resulted in an overall response rate of 16%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neither a tumor-protective effect nor reduced toxicity to normal tissues was observed with the addition of amifostine to cisplatin in this trial.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The present study sought to characterize the cognitive-enhancing effects of the 5-HT(6) antagonist Ro4368554 (3-benzenesulfonyl-7-(4-methyl-piperazin-1-yl)1H-indole) in a rat object recognition task employing a cholinergic (scopolamine pretreatment) and a serotonergic- (tryptophan (TRP) depletion) deficient model, and compared its pattern of action with that of the acetylcholinesterase inhibitor metrifonate.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, although Ro4368554 did not improve a time-related retention deficit, it reversed a cholinergic and a serotonergic memory deficit, suggesting that both mechanisms may be involved in the facilitation of object memory by Ro4368554 and, possibly, other 5-HT(6) receptor antagonists.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Atrial fibrillation in young patients without structural heart disease is rare.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Therefore, when the arrhythmia is present in this population, reversible causes must be identified and resolved.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thyroid disorders, illicit drug or stimulant use, and acute alcohol intoxication are among these causes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We report the case of a 30-year-old Caucasian man who came to the emergency department in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.</Chemical>
<Chemical>His medical history was unremarkable, except for minor fractures of the fingers and foot.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Comparison of developmental toxicity of selective and non-selective cyclooxygenase-2 inhibitors in CRL:(WI)WUBR Wistar rats--DFU and piroxicam study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors are one of the most often ingested drugs during pregnancy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Unlike general toxicity data, their prenatal toxic effects were not extensively studied before.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The aim of the experiment was to evaluate the developmental toxicity of the non-selective (piroxicam) and selective (DFU; 5,5-dimethyl-3-(3-fluorophenyl)-4-(4-methylsulphonyl) phenyl-2(5H)-furanon) COX-2 inhibitors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Drugs were separately, orally once daily dosed to pregnant rats from day 8 to 21 (GD1=plug day).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Doses were set at 0.3, 3.0 and 30.0mg/kg for piroxicam and 0.2, 2.0 and 20.0mg/kg for DFU.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fetuses were delivered on GD 21 and routinely examined.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Comprehensive clinical and developmental measurements were done.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The pooled statistical analysis for ventricular septal (VSD) and midline (MD) defects was performed for rat fetuses exposed to piroxicam, selective and non-selective COX-2 inhibitor based on present and historic data.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Maternal toxicity, intrauterine growth retardation, and increase of external and skeletal variations were found in rats treated with the highest dose of piroxicam.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Decrease of fetal length was the only signs of the DFU developmental toxicity observed in pups exposed to the highest compound dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lack of teratogenicity was found in piroxicam and DFU-exposed groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prenatal exposure to non-selective COX inhibitors increases the risk of VSD and MD when compared to historic control but not with selective COX-2 inhibitors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION: Both selective and non-selective COX-2 inhibitors were toxic for rats fetuses when administered in the highest dose.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Unlike DFU, piroxicam was also highly toxic to the dams.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prenatal exposure to selective COX-2 inhibitors does not increase the risk of ventricular septal and midline defects in rat when compared to non-selective drugs and historic control.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Protective efficacy of neuroactive steroids against cocaine kindled-seizures in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neuroactive steroids demonstrate pharmacological actions that have relevance for a host of neurological and psychiatric disorders.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>They offer protection against seizures in a range of models and seem to inhibit certain stages of drug dependence in preclinical assessments.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The present study was designed to evaluate two endogenous and one synthetic neuroactive steroid that positively modulate the gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA(A)) receptor against the increase in sensitivity to the convulsant effects of cocaine engendered by repeated cocaine administration (seizure kindling).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Allopregnanolone (3alpha-hydroxy-5alpha-pregnan-20-one), pregnanolone (3alpha-hydroxy-5beta-pregnan-20-one) and ganaxolone (a synthetic derivative of allopregnanolone 3alpha-hydroxy-3beta-methyl-5alpha-pregnan-20-one) were tested for their ability to suppress the expression (anticonvulsant effect) and development (antiepileptogenic effect) of cocaine-kindled seizures in male, Swiss-Webster mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Kindled seizures were induced by daily administration of 60 mg/kg cocaine for 5 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All of these positive GABA(A) modulators suppressed the expression of kindled seizures, whereas only allopregnanolone and ganaxolone inhibited the development of kindling.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Allopregnanolone and pregnanolone, but not ganaxolone, also reduced cumulative lethality associated with kindling.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings demonstrate that some neuroactive steroids attenuate convulsant and sensitizing properties of cocaine and add to a growing literature on their potential use in the modulation of effects of drugs of abuse.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Kidney function and morphology after short-term combination therapy with cyclosporine A, tacrolimus and sirolimus in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Sirolimus (SRL) may supplement calcineurin inhibitors in clinical organ transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These are nephrotoxic, but SRL seems to act differently displaying only minor nephrotoxic effects, although this question is still open.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a number of treatment protocols where SRL was combined with a calcineurin inhibitor indications of a synergistic nephrotoxic effect were described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of this study was to examine further the renal function, including morphological analysis of the kidneys of male Sprague-Dawley rats treated with either cyclosporine A (CsA), tacrolimus (FK506) or SRL as monotherapies or in different combinations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>For a period of 2 weeks, CsA 15 mg/kg/day (given orally), FK506 3.0 mg/kg/day (given orally) or SRL 0.4 mg/kg/day (given intraperitoneally) was administered once a day as these doses have earlier been found to achieve a significant immunosuppressive effect in Sprague-Dawley rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the 'conscious catheterized rat' model, the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) was measured as the clearance of Cr(EDTA).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The morphological analysis of the kidneys included a semi-quantitative scoring system analysing the degree of striped fibrosis, subcapsular fibrosis and the number of basophilic tubules, plus an additional stereological analysis of the total grade of fibrosis in the cortex stained with Sirius Red.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>CsA, FK506 and SRL all significantly decreased the GFR.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A further deterioration was seen when CsA was combined with either FK506 or SRL, whereas the GFR remained unchanged in the group treated with FK506 plus SRL when compared with treatment with any of the single substances.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The morphological changes presented a similar pattern.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The semi-quantitative scoring was significantly worst in the group treated with CsA plus SRL (P<0.001 compared with controls) and the analysis of the total grade of fibrosis also showed the highest proportion in the same group and was significantly different from controls (P<0.02).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The FK506 plus SRL combination showed only a marginally higher degree of fibrosis as compared with controls (P=0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This rat study demonstrated a synergistic nephrotoxic effect of CsA plus SRL, whereas FK506 plus SRL was better tolerated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of fucoidan treatment on collagenase-induced intracerebral hemorrhage in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Inflammatory cells are postulated to mediate some of the brain damage following ischemic stroke.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Intracerebral hemorrhage is associated with more inflammation than ischemic stroke.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We tested the sulfated polysaccharide fucoidan, which has been reported to reduce inflammatory brain damage, in a rat model of intracerebral hemorrhage induced by injection of bacterial collagenase into the caudate nucleus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats were treated with seven day intravenous infusion of fucoidan (30 micrograms h-1) or vehicle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The hematoma was assessed in vivo by magnetic resonance imaging.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Motor behavior, passive avoidance, and skilled forelimb function were tested repeatedly for six weeks.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Fucoidan-treated rats exhibited evidence of impaired blood clotting and hemodilution, had larger hematomas, and tended to have less inflammation in the vicinity of the hematoma after three days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>They showed significantly more rapid improvement of motor function in the first week following hemorrhage and better memory retention in the passive avoidance test.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute white matter edema and eventual neuronal loss in the striatum adjacent to the hematoma did not differ between the two groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Investigation of more specific anti-inflammatory agents and hemodiluting agents are warranted in intracerebral hemorrhage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Paracetamol-associated coma, metabolic acidosis, renal and hepatic failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A case of metabolic acidosis, acute renal failure and hepatic failure following paracetamol ingestion is presented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The diagnostic difficulty at presentation is highlighted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Continuous arteriovenous haemofiltration proved a valuable means of maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient recovered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hepatic reactions associated with ketoconazole in the United Kingdom.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketoconazole was introduced in the United Kingdom in 1981.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>By November 1984 the Committee on Safety of Medicines had received 82 reports of possible hepatotoxicity associated with the drug, including five deaths.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An analysis of the 75 cases that had been adequately followed up suggested that 16, including three deaths, were probably related to treatment with the drug.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of the remainder, 48 were possibly related to treatment, five were unlikely to be so, and six were unclassifiable.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean age of patients in the 16 probable cases was 57.9, with hepatotoxicity being more common in women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The average duration of treatment before the onset of jaundice was 61 days.</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of these well validated cases occurred within the first 10 days after treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results of serum liver function tests suggested hepatocellular injury in 10 (63%); the rest showed a mixed pattern.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, the results of histological examination of the liver often showed evidence of cholestasis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The characteristics of the 48 patients in the possible cases were similar.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Allergic manifestations such as rash and eosinophilia were rare.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hepatitis was usually reversible when treatment was stopped, with the results of liver function tests returning to normal after an average of 3.1 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In two of the three deaths probably associated with ketoconazole treatment the drug had been continued after the onset of jaundice and other symptoms of hepatitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical and biochemical monitoring at regular intervals for evidence of hepatitis is advised during long term treatment with ketoconazole to prevent possible serious hepatic injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Combined effects of prolonged prostaglandin E1-induced hypotension and haemodilution on human hepatic function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Combined effects of prolonged prostaglandin E1 (PGE1)-induced hypotension and haemodilution on hepatic function were studied in 30 patients undergoing hip surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patients were randomly allocated to one of three groups; those in group A (n = 10) were subjected to controlled hypotension alone, those in group B (n = 10) to haemodilution alone and those in group C (n = 10) to both controlled hypotension and haemodilution.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Haemodilution in groups B and C was produced by withdrawing approximately 1000 mL of blood and replacing it with the same amount of dextran solution, and final haematocrit values were 21 or 22%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Controlled hypotension in groups A and C was induced with PGE1 to maintain mean arterial blood pressure at 55 mmHg for 180 min.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Measurements included arterial ketone body ratio (AKBR, aceto-acetate/3-hydroxybutyrate) and clinical hepatic function parameters.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>AKBR and biological hepatic function tests showed no change throughout the time course in groups A and B. In group C, AKBR showed a significant decrease at 120 min (-40%) and at 180 min (-49%) after the start of hypotension and at 60 min (-32%) after recovery of normotension, and SGOT, SGPT, LDH and total bilirubin showed significant increases after operation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results suggest that a prolonged combination of more than 120 min of PGE1-induced hypotension and moderate haemodilution would cause impairment of hepatic function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Levodopa-induced dyskinesias in patients with Parkinson's disease: filling the bench-to-bedside gap.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Levodopa is the most effective drug for the treatment of Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the long-term use of this dopamine precursor is complicated by highly disabling fluctuations and dyskinesias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although preclinical and clinical findings suggest pulsatile stimulation of striatal postsynaptic receptors as a key mechanism underlying levodopa-induced dyskinesias, their pathogenesis is still unclear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In recent years, evidence from animal models of Parkinson's disease has provided important information to understand the effect of specific receptor and post-receptor molecular mechanisms underlying the development of dyskinetic movements.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Recent preclinical and clinical data from promising lines of research focus on the differential role of presynaptic versus postsynaptic mechanisms, dopamine receptor subtypes, ionotropic and metabotropic glutamate receptors, and non-dopaminergic neurotransmitter systems in the pathophysiology of levodopa-induced dyskinesias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prevention of seizures and reorganization of hippocampal functions by transplantation of bone marrow cells in the acute phase of experimental epilepsy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this study, we investigated the therapeutic potential of bone marrow mononuclear cells (BMCs) in a model of epilepsy induced by pilocarpine in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BMCs obtained from green fluorescent protein (GFP) transgenic mice or rats were transplanted intravenously after induction of status epilepticus (SE).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Spontaneous recurrent seizures (SRS) were monitored using Racine's seizure severity scale.</Chemical>

<Chemical>All of the rats in the saline-treated epileptic control group developed SRS, whereas none of the BMC-treated epileptic animals had seizures in the short term (15 days after transplantation), regardless of the BMC source.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Over the long-term chronic phase (120 days after transplantation), only 25% of BMC-treated epileptic animals had seizures, but with a lower frequency and duration compared to the epileptic control group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The density of hippocampal neurons in the brains of animals treated with BMCs was markedly preserved.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At hippocampal Schaeffer collateral-CA1 synapses, long-term potentiation was preserved in BMC-transplanted rats compared to epileptic controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The donor-derived GFP(+) cells were rarely found in the brains of transplanted epileptic rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In conclusion, treatment with BMCs can prevent the development of chronic seizures, reduce neuronal loss, and influence the reorganization of the hippocampal neuronal network.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cardioprotective effect of salvianolic acid A on isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was designed to evaluate the cardioprotective potential of salvianolic acid A on isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hemodynamic parameters and lead II electrocardiograph were monitored and recorded continuously.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cardiac marker enzymes and antioxidative parameters in serum and heart tissues were measured.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Assay for mitochondrial respiratory function and histopathological examination of heart tissues were performed.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Isoproterenol-treated rats showed significant increases in the levels of lactate dehydrogenase, aspartate transaminase, creatine kinase and malondialdehyde and significant decreases in the activities of superoxide dismutase, catalase and glutathione peroxidase in serum and heart.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These rats also showed declines in left ventricular systolic pressure, maximum and minimum rate of developed left ventricular pressure, and elevation of left ventricular end-diastolic pressure and ST-segment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition, mitochondrial respiratory dysfunction characterized by decreased respiratory control ratio and ADP/O was observed in isoproterenol-treated rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of salvianolic acid A for a period of 8 days significantly attenuated isoproterenol-induced cardiac dysfunction and myocardial injury and improved mitochondrial respiratory function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The protective role of salvianolic acid A against isoproterenol-induced myocardial damage was further confirmed by histopathological examination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results of our study suggest that salvianolic acid A possessing antioxidant activity has a significant protective effect against isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acute effects of N-(2-propylpentanoyl)urea on hippocampal amino acid neurotransmitters in pilocarpine-induced seizure in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study aimed to investigate the anticonvulsant activity as well as the effects on the level of hippocampal amino acid neurotransmitters (glutamate, aspartate, glycine and GABA) of N-(2-propylpentanoyl)urea (VPU) in comparison to its parent compound, valproic acid (VPA).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>VPU was more potent than VPA, exhibiting the median effective dose (ED(50)) of 49 mg/kg in protecting rats against pilocarpine-induced seizure whereas the corresponding value for VPA was 322 mg/kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In vivo microdialysis demonstrated that an intraperitoneal administration of pilocarpine induced a pronounced increment of hippocampal glutamate and aspartate whereas no significant change was observed on the level of glycine and GABA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pretreatment with either VPU (50 and 100 mg/kg) or VPA (300 and 600 mg/kg) completely abolished pilocarpine-evoked increases in extracellular glutamate and aspartate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, a statistically significant reduction was also observed on the level of GABA and glycine but less than a drastic reduction of glutamate and aspartate level.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Based on the finding that VPU and VPA could protect the animals against pilocarpine-induced seizure it is suggested that the reduction of inhibitory amino acid neurotransmitters was comparatively minor and offset by a pronounced reduction of glutamate and aspartate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, like VPA, the finding that VPU could drastically reduce pilocarpine-induced increases in glutamate and aspartate should account, at least partly, for its anticonvulsant activity observed in pilocarpine-induced seizure in experimental animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Some other mechanism than those being reported herein should be further investigated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute hepatitis attack after exposure to telithromycin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>INTRODUCTION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Antibiotic-associated hepatotoxicity is rare.</Chemical>
<Chemical>With widespread use of antimicrobial agents, however, hepatic injury occurs frequently, and among adverse drug reactions, idiosyncratic reactions are the most serious.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CASE SUMMARY:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A 25-year-old male patient, with a height of 175 cm and weight of 72 kg presented to Marmara University Hospital Emergency Department, Istanbul, Turkey, with 5 days' history of jaundice, malaise, nausea, and vomiting.</Chemical>
<Chemical>He had been prescribed telithromycin 400 mg/d PO to treat an upper respiratory tract infection 7 days prior.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Admission laboratory tests were as follows: alanine aminotransferase, 67 U/L (reference range, 10-37 U/L); aspartate aminotransferase, 98 U/L (10-40 U/L); alkaline phosphatase, 513 U/L (0-270 U/L); gamma-glutamyltransferase, 32 U/L (7-49 U/L); amylase, 46 U/L (0-220 U/L); total bilirubin, 20.1 mg/dL (0.2-1.0 mg/dL); direct bilirubin, 14.8 mg/dL (0-0.3 mg/dL); and albumin, 4.7 mg/dL (3.5-5.4 mg/dL).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>No toxin, alcohol, or other drugs were reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient had suffered a previous episode of "acute hepatitis of unknown origin," that occurred after telithromycin usage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both incidents occurred within a year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Telithromycin is the first of the ketolide antibacterials to receive US Food and Drug Administration approval for clinical use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It has been associated with infrequent and usually reversible severe hepatic dysfunction.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Based on a score of 8 on the Naranjo adverse drug reaction probability scale, telithromycin was the probable cause of acute hepatitis in this patient, and pathological findings suggested drug-induced toxic hepatitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recurrence of hepatitis attack might have been avoided if the initial incident had been communicated to the attending physician who prescribed telithromycin the second time.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Here we report a case of acute hepatitis probably associated with the administration of telithromycin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Spironolactone-induced renal insufficiency and hyperkalemia in patients with heart failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A previous randomized controlled trial evaluating the use of spironolactone in heart failure patients reported a low risk of hyperkalemia (2%) and renal insufficiency (0%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because treatments for heart failure have changed since the benefits of spironolactone were reported, the prevalence of these complications may differ in current clinical practice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We therefore sought to determine the prevalence and clinical associations of hyperkalemia and renal insufficiency in heart failure patients treated with spironolactone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We performed a case control study of heart failure patients treated with spironolactone in our clinical practice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cases were patients who developed hyperkalemia (K(+) ></Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>5.0 mEq/L) or renal insufficiency (Cr >or=2.5 mg/dL), and they were compared to 2 randomly selected controls per case.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical characteristics, medications, and serum chemistries at baseline and follow-up time periods were compared.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Sixty-seven of 926 patients (7.2%) required discontinuation of spironolactone due to hyperkalemia (n = 33) or renal failure (n = 34).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients who developed hyperkalemia were older and more likely to have diabetes, had higher baseline serum potassium levels and lower baseline potassium supplement doses, and were more likely to be treated with beta-blockers than controls (n = 134).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients who developed renal insufficiency had lower baseline body weight and higher baseline serum creatinine, required higher doses of loop diuretics, and were more likely to be treated with thiazide diuretics than controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Spironolactone-induced hyperkalemia and renal insufficiency are more common in our clinical experience than reported previously.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This difference is explained by patient comorbidities and more frequent use of beta-blockers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>End-stage renal disease (ESRD) after orthotopic liver transplantation (OLTX) using calcineurin-based immunotherapy: risk of development and treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The calcineurin inhibitors cyclosporine and tacrolimus are both known to be nephrotoxic.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Their use in orthotopic liver transplantation (OLTX) has dramatically improved success rates.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recently, however, we have had an increase of patients who are presenting after OLTX with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).</Chemical>
<Chemical>This retrospective study examines the incidence and treatment of ESRD and chronic renal failure (CRF) in OLTX patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients receiving an OLTX only from June 1985 through December of 1994 who survived 6 months postoperatively were studied (n=834).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Our prospectively collected database was the source of information.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients were divided into three groups: Controls, no CRF or ESRD, n=748; CRF, sustained serum creatinine >2.5 mg/dl, n=41; and ESRD, n=45.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Groups were compared for preoperative laboratory variables, diagnosis, postoperative variables, survival, type of ESRD therapy, and survival from onset of ESRD.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>At 13 years after OLTX, the incidence of severe renal dysfunction was 18.1% (CRF 8.6% and ESRD 9.5%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Compared with control patients, CRF and ESRD patients had higher preoperative serum creatinine levels, a greater percentage of patients with hepatorenal syndrome, higher percentage requirement for dialysis in the first 3 months postoperatively, and a higher 1-year serum creatinine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Multivariate stepwise logistic regression analysis using preoperative and postoperative variables identified that an increase of serum creatinine compared with average at 1 year, 3 months, and 4 weeks postoperatively were independent risk factors for the development of CRF or ESRD with odds ratios of 2.6, 2.2, and 1.6, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Overall survival from the time of OLTX was not significantly different among groups, but by year 13, the survival of the patients who had ESRD was only 28.2% compared with 54.6% in the control group.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients developing ESRD had a 6-year survival after onset of ESRD of 27% for the patients receiving hemodialysis versus 71.4% for the patients developing ESRD who subsequently received kidney transplants.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients who are more than 10 years post-OLTX have CRF and ESRD at a high rate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The development of ESRD decreases survival, particularly in those patients treated with dialysis only.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients who develop ESRD have a higher preoperative and 1-year serum creatinine and are more likely to have hepatorenal syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, an increase of serum creatinine at various times postoperatively is more predictive of the development of CRF or ESRD.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>New strategies for long-term immunosuppression may be needed to decrease this complication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effect of intravenous nimodipine on blood pressure and outcome after acute stroke.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The Intravenous Nimodipine West European Stroke Trial (INWEST) found a correlation between nimodipine-induced reduction in blood pressure (BP) and an unfavorable outcome in acute stroke.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We sought to confirm this correlation with and without adjustment for prognostic variables and to investigate outcome in subgroups with increasing levels of BP reduction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients with a clinical diagnosis of ischemic stroke (within 24 hours) were consecutively allocated to receive placebo (n=100), 1 mg/h (low-dose) nimodipine (n=101), or 2 mg/h (high-dose) nimodipine (n=94).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The correlation between average BP change during the first 2 days and the outcome at day 21 was analyzed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Two hundred sixty-five patients were included in this analysis (n=92, 93, and 80 for placebo, low dose, and high dose, respectively).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nimodipine treatment resulted in a statistically significant reduction in systolic BP (SBP) and diastolic BP (DBP) from baseline compared with placebo during the first few days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In multivariate analysis, a significant correlation between DBP reduction and worsening of the neurological score was found for the high-dose group (beta=0.49, P=0. 048).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients with a DBP reduction of > or =20% in the high-dose group had a significantly increased adjusted OR for the compound outcome variable death or dependency (Barthel Index <60) (n/N=25/26, OR 10. 16, 95% CI 1.02 to 101.74) and death alone (n/N=9/26, OR 4.336, 95% CI 1.131 16.619) compared with all placebo patients (n/N=62/92 and 14/92, respectively).</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was no correlation between SBP change and outcome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: DBP, but not SBP, reduction was associated with neurological worsening after the intravenous administration of high-dose nimodipine after acute stroke.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>For low-dose nimodipine, the results were not conclusive.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results do not confirm or exclude a neuroprotective property of nimodipine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Transient neurologic symptoms after spinal anesthesia: a lower incidence with prilocaine and bupivacaine than with lidocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recent evidence suggests that transient neurologic symptoms (TNSs) frequently follow lidocaine spinal anesthesia but are infrequent with bupivacaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, identification of a short-acting local anesthetic to substitute for lidocaine for brief surgical procedures remains an important goal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prilocaine is an amide local anesthetic with a duration of action similar to that of lidocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Accordingly, the present, prospective double-blind study compares prilocaine with lidocaine and bupivacaine with respect to duration of action and relative risk of TNSs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Ninety patients classified as American Society of Anesthesiologists physical status I or II who were scheduled for short gynecologic procedures under spinal anesthesia were randomly allocated to receive 2.5 ml 2% lidocaine in 7.5% glucose, 2% prilocaine in 7.5% glucose, or 0.5% bupivacaine in 7.5% glucose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All solutions were provided in blinded vials by the hospital pharmacy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Details of spinal puncture, extension and regression of spinal block, and the times to reach discharge criteria were noted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the evening of postoperative day 1, patients were evaluated for TNSs by a physician unaware of the drug administered and the details of the anesthetic procedure.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: Nine of 30 patients receiving lidocaine experienced TNSs, 1 of 30 patients receiving prilocaine (P = 0.03) had them, and none of 30 patients receiving bupivacaine had TNSs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Times to ambulate and to void were similar after lidocaine and prilocaine (150 vs. 165 min and 238 vs. 253 min, respectively) but prolonged after bupivacaine (200 and 299 min, respectively; P < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prilocaine may be preferable to lidocaine for short surgical procedures because it has a similar duration of action but a lower incidence of TNSs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The role of nicotine in smoking-related cardiovascular disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nicotine activates the sympathetic nervous system and in this way could contribute to cardiovascular disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Animal studies and mechanistic studies indicate that nicotine could play a role in accelerating atherosclerosis, but evidence among humans is too inadequate to be definitive about such an effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Almost certainly, nicotine via its hemodynamic effects contributes to acute cardiovascular events, although current evidence suggests that the effects of nicotine are much less important than are the prothrombotic effects of cigarette smoking or the effects of carbon monoxide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nicotine does not appear to enhance thrombosis among humans.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical studies of pipe smokers and people using transdermal nicotine support the idea that toxins other than nicotine are the most important causes of acute cardiovascular events.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Finally, the dose response for cardiovascular events of nicotine appears to be flat, suggesting that if nicotine is involved, adverse effects might be seen with relatively low-level cigarette exposures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Seizure resulting from a venlafaxine overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of venlafaxine overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE SUMMARY:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 40-year-old woman with major depression took an overdose of venlafaxine in an apparent suicide attempt.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After the ingestion of 26 venlafaxine 50-mg tablets, the patient experienced a witnessed generalized seizure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>She was admitted to the medical intensive care unit, venlafaxine was discontinued, and no further sequelae were seen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of venlafaxine overdose that resulted in a generalized seizure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Based on nonoverdose pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of venlafaxine and the potential risks of available interventions, no emergent therapy was instituted.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The venlafaxine overdose in our patient resulted in a single episode of generalized seizure but elicited no further sequelae.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of nifedipine on renal function in liver transplant recipients receiving tacrolimus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of nifedipine on renal function in liver transplant recipients who were receiving tacrolimus was evaluated between January 1992 and January 1996.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two groups of patients receiving tacrolimus were compared over a period of 1 year, one group comprising hypertensive patients who were receiving nifedipine, and the other comprising nonhypertensive patients not receiving nifedipine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The time from transplant to baseline was similar in all patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nifedipine significantly improved kidney function as indicated by a significant lowering of serum creatinine levels at 6 and 12 months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The observed positive impact of nifedipine on reducing the nephrotoxicity associated with tacrolimus in liver transplant recipients should be an important factor in selecting an agent to treat hypertension in this population.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sinus arrest associated with continuous-infusion cimetidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The administration of intermittent intravenous infusions of cimetidine is infrequently associated with the development of bradyarrhythmias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 40-year-old man with leukemia and no history of cardiac disease developed recurrent, brief episodes of apparent sinus arrest while receiving continuous-infusion cimetidine 50 mg/hour.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The arrhythmias were temporally related to cimetidine administration, disappeared after dechallenge, and did not recur during ranitidine treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is the first reported case of sinus arrest associated with continuous-infusion cimetidine.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Composition of gall bladder stones associated with octreotide: response to oral ursodeoxycholic acid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Octreotide, an effective treatment for acromegaly, induces gall bladder stones in 13-60% of patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because knowledge of stone composition is essential for studies of their pathogenesis, treatment, and prevention, this was investigated by direct and indirect methods in 14 octreotide treated acromegalic patients with gall stones.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chemical analysis of gall stones retrieved at cholecystectomy from two patients, showed that they contained 71% and 87% cholesterol by weight.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the remaining 12 patients, localised computed tomography of the gall bladder showed that eight had stones with maximum attenuation scores of < 100 Hounsfield units (values of < 100 HU predict cholesterol rich, dissolvable stones).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Gall bladder bile was obtained by ultrasound guided, fine needle puncture from six patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All six patients had supersaturated bile (mean (SEM) cholesterol saturation index of 1.19 (0.08)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>(range 1.01-1.53)) and all had abnormally rapid cholesterol microcrystal nucleation times (< 4 days (range 1-4)), whilst in four, the bile contained cholesterol microcrystals immediately after sampling.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the 12 patients considered for oral ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) treatment, two had a blocked cystic duct and were not started on UDCA while one was lost to follow up.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After one year of treatment, five of the remaining nine patients showed either partial (n = 3) or complete (n = 2) gall stone dissolution, suggesting that their stones were cholesterol rich.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This corresponds, by actuarial (life table) analysis, to a combined gall stone dissolution rate of 58.3 (15.9%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>In conclusion, octreotide induced gall stones are generally small, multiple, and cholesterol rich although, in common with spontaneous gall stone disease, at presentation some patients will have a blocked cystic duct and some gall stones containing calcium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of this study was to evaluate the neurologic consequences of deliberate subarachnoid injection of large volumes of 2-chloroprocaine-CE in experimental animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possible role of low pH as well as total volume as potential factors in causing neurotoxicity was evaluated.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The 65 dogs in the study received injections in the subarachnoid space as follows: 6 to 8 ml of bupivacaine (N = 15), 2-chloroprocaine-CE (N = 20), low pH normal saline (pH 3.0) (N = 20), or normal saline (N = 10).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the 20 animals that received subarachnoid injection of 2-chloroprocaine-CE seven (35%) developed hind-limb paralysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>None of the animals that received bupivacaine, normal saline, or normal saline titrated to a pH 3.0 developed hind-limb paralysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the 15 spinal cords of the animals that received 2-chloroprocaine-CE, 13 showed subpial necrosis; the nerve roots and subarachnoid vessels were normal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The spinal cords of the animals that received bupivacaine, low pH normal saline (pH 3.0), or normal saline did not show abnormal findings.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Early adjuvant adriamycin in superficial bladder carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A multicenter study was performed in 110 patients with superficial transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Adriamycin (50 mg/50 ml) was administered intravesically within 24 h after transurethral resection of TA-T1 (O-A) bladder tumors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Instillation was repeated twice during the first week, then weekly during the first month and afterwards monthly for 1 year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The tolerance was evaluated in these 110 patients, and 29 patients presented with local side-effects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 24 of these patients chemical cystitis was severe enough for them to drop out of the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No systemic side-effects were observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recurrence was studied in 82 evaluable patients after 1 year of follow-up and in 72 patients followed for 2-3 years (mean 32 months).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of the 82 patients studied after 1 year, 23 had primary and 59 recurrent disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of the 82 evaluable patients, 50 did not show any recurrence after 1 year (61%), while 32 presented with one or more recurrences (39%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of these recurrences, 27 were T1 tumors while five progressed to more highly invasive lesions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In patients that were free of recurrence during the first year, 80% remained tumor-free during the 2- to 3-year follow-up period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of the patients developing one or more recurrences during the first year, only 50% presented with further recurrence once the instillations were stopped.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The beneficial effect of Adriamycin appears obvious and might be related to the drug itself, the early and repeated instillations after TUR, or both.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hyperkalemia associated with sulindac therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hyperkalemia has recently been recognized as a complication of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents (NSAID) such as indomethacin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Several recent studies have stressed the renal sparing features of sulindac, owing to its lack of interference with renal prostacyclin synthesis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe 4 patients in whom hyperkalemia ranging from 6.1 to 6.9 mEq/l developed within 3 to 8 days of sulindac administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In all of them normal serum potassium levels reached within 2 to 4 days of stopping sulindac.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>As no other medications known to effect serum potassium had been given concomitantly, this course of events is suggestive of a cause-and-effect relationship between sulindac and hyperkalemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These observations indicate that initial hopes that sulindac may not be associated with the adverse renal effects of other NSAID are probably not justified.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Immunohistochemical, electron microscopic and morphometric studies of estrogen-induced rat prolactinomas after bromocriptine treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To clarify the effects of bromocriptine on prolactinoma cells in vivo, immunohistochemical, ultrastructural and morphometrical analyses were applied to estrogen-induced rat prolactinoma cells 1 h and 6 h after injection of bromocriptine (3 mg/kg of body weight).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One h after treatment, serum prolactin levels decreased markedly.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Electron microscopy disclosed many secretory granules, slightly distorted rough endoplasmic reticulum, and partially dilated Golgi cisternae in the prolactinoma cells.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Morphometric analysis revealed that the volume density of secretory granules increased, while the volume density of cytoplasmic microtubules decreased.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These findings suggest that lowered serum prolactin levels in the early phase of bromocriptine treatment may result from an impaired secretion of prolactin due to decreasing numbers of cytoplasmic microtubules.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At 6 h after injection, serum prolactin levels were still considerably lower than in controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The prolactinoma cells at this time were well granulated, with vesiculated rough endoplasmic reticulum and markedly dilated Golgi cisternae.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Electron microscopical immunohistochemistry revealed positive reaction products noted on the secretory granules, Golgi cisternae, and endoplasmic reticulum of the untreated rat prolactinoma cells.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, only secretory granules showed the positive reaction products for prolactin 6 h after bromocriptine treatment of the adenoma cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An increase in the volume density of secretory granules and a decrease in the volume densities of rough endoplasmic reticulum and microtubules was determined by morphometric analysis, suggesting that bromocriptine inhibits protein synthesis as well as bringing about a disturbance of the prolactin secretion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>On two paradoxical side-effects of prednisolone in rats, ribosomal RNA biosyntheses, and a mechanism of action.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Liver enlargement and muscle wastage occurred in Wistar rats following the subcutaneous administration of prednisolone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the liver both the content of RNA and the biosynthesis of ribosomal RNA increased while both the RNA content and ribosomal RNA biosynthesis were reduced in the gastrocnemius muscle.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is suggested that the drug acted in a selective and tissue-specific manner to enhance ribosomal RNA synthesis in the liver and depress such synthesis in the muscle.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This view supports the contention that the liver and muscle are independent sites of prednisolone action.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was carried out to test the effects of L-alpha-glycerylphosphorylcholine (L-alpha-GFC) on memory impairment induced by scopolamine in man.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty-two healthy young volunteers were randomly allocated to four different groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>They were given a ten day pretreatment with either L-alpha-GFC or placebo, p.o., and on the eleventh day either scopolamine or placebo, i.m. Before and 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 6 h after injection the subjects were given attention and mnemonic tests.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Seizures induced by the cocaine metabolite benzoylecgonine in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The half-life (t1/2) of cocaine is relatively short, but some of the consequences of its use, such as seizures and strokes, can occur hours after exposure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This led us to hypothesize that a metabolite of cocaine may be responsible for some of those delayed sequelae.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We evaluated the potential of the major metabolite of cocaine, benzoylecgonine (BE), to cause seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two separate equimolar doses (0.2 and 0.4 mumol) of either cocaine or BE were injected ventricularly in unanesthetized juvenile rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treated rats were then evaluated for incidence, latency, and seizure pattern or for locomotor activity in animals without seizures.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BE-Induced seizures occurred more frequently and had significantly longer latencies than those induced by equimolar amounts of cocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Whereas cocaine-induced seizures were best characterized as brief, generalized, and tonic and resulted in death, those induced by BE were prolonged, often multiple and mixed in type, and rarely resulted in death.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Electrical recordings from the hippocampus showed a rhythmic progression in EEG frequency and voltage with clinical seizure expression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BE-Injected rats that did not have seizures had significantly more locomotor activity than cocaine-injected animals without seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The finding that cocaine- and BE-induced seizures differ in several respects suggests more than one mechanism for cocaine-induced seizures and emphasizes the importance of a cocaine metabolite, BE.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Protection against amphetamine-induced neurotoxicity toward striatal dopamine neurons in rodents by LY274614, an excitatory amino acid antagonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>LY274614, 3SR,4aRS,6SR,8aRS-6-[phosphonomethyl]decahydr oisoquinoline-3- carboxylic acid, has been described as a potent antagonist of the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) subtype of glutamate receptor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here its ability to antagonize the prolonged depletion of dopamine in the striatum by amphetamine in iprindole-treated rats is reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A single 18.4 mg/kg (i.p.) dose of (+/-)-amphetamine hemisulfate, given to rats pretreated with iprindole, resulted in persistent depletion of dopamine in the striatum 1 week later.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This prolonged depletion of dopamine in the striatum was antagonized by dizocilpine (MK-801, a non-competitive antagonist of NMDA receptors) or by LY274614 (a competitive antagonist of NMDA receptors).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The protective effect of LY274614 was dose-dependent, being maximum at 10-40 mgkg (i.p.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 10 mg/kg dose of LY274614 was effective in antagonizing the depletion of dopamine in the striatum, when given as long as 8 hr prior to amphetamine but not when given 24 hr prior to amphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Depletion of dopamine in the striatum was also antagonized when LY274614 was given after the injection of amphetamine; LY274614 protected when given up to 4 hr after but not when given 8 or 24 hr after amphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The prolonged depletion of dopamine in the striatum in mice, given multiple injections of methamphetamine, was also antagonized dose-dependently and completely by LY274614.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The data strengthen the evidence that the neurotoxic effect of amphetamine and related compounds toward nigrostriatal dopamine neurons involves NMDA receptors and that LY274614 is an NMDA receptor antagonist with long-lasting in vivo effects in rats.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Hg (P less than 0.001), for 60 minutes.</Chemical>

<Chemical>mm</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Elevation of ADAM10, ADAM17, MMP-2 and MMP-9 expression with media degeneration features CaCl2-induced thoracic aortic aneurysm in a rat model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study was designed to establish a rat model of thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) by calcium chloride (CaCl(2))-induced arterial injury and to explore the potential role of a disintegrin and metalloproteinase (ADAM), matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and their endogenous inhibitors (TIMPs) in TAA formation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thoracic aorta of male Sprague-Dawley rats was exposed to 0.5M CaCl(2) or normal saline (NaCl).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 12weeks, animals were euthanized, and CaCl(2)-treated, CaCl(2)-untreated (n=12) and NaCl-treated aortic segments (n=12) were collected for histological and molecular assessments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>MMP-TIMP and ADAM mRNAs were semi-quantitatively analyzed and protein expressions were determined by immunohistochemistry.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Despite similar external diameters among CaCl(2)-treated, non-CaCl(2)-treated and NaCl-treated segments, aneurymal alteration (n=6, 50%), media degeneration with regional disruption, fragmentation of elastic fiber, and increased collagen deposition (n=12, 100%) were demonstrated in CaCl(2)-treated segments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>MMP-2, MMP-9, ADAM-10 and ADAM-17 mRNA levels were increased in CaCl(2)-treated segments (all p<0.01), with trends of elevation in CaCl(2)-untreated segments, as compared with NaCl-treated segments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immunohistochemistry displayed significantly increased expressions of MMP-2, MMP-9, ADAM-10 and ADAM-17 (all p<0.01) in intima and media for CaCl(2)-treated segments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>TIMP mRNA and tissue levels did not differ obviously among the three aortic segments.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study establishes a TAA model by periarterial CaCl(2) exposure in rats, and demonstrates a significant elevation of expression of MMP-2, MMP-9, ADAM10 and ADAM17 in the pathogenesis of vascular remodeling.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When drugs disappear from the patient: elimination of intravenous medication by hemodiafiltration.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Increasing doses of catecholamines, sedatives, and muscle relaxants administered through a central venous catheter were ineffective.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>However, a bolus of epinephrine injected through an alternative catheter provoked a hypertensive crisis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, interference with the central venous infusion by the dialysis catheter was suspected.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The catheters were changed, and hemodynamics stabilized at lower catecholamine doses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When the effects of IV drugs are inadequate in patients receiving CVVHDF, interference with adjacent catheters resulting in elimination of the drug by CVVHDF should be suspected.</Chemical>
