label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Toxic peripheral neuropathy is still a significant limiting factor for chemotherapy with paclitaxel (PAC), although glutamate and its closely related amino acid glutamine were claimed to ameliorate PAC neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This pilot trial aimed to evaluate the role of glutamate supplementation for preventing PAC-induced peripheral neuropathy in a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blinded clinical and electro-diagnostic study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Forty-three ovarian cancer patients were available for analysis following six cycles of the same PAC-containing regimen: 23 had been supplemented by glutamate all along the treatment period, at a daily dose of three times 500 mg (group G), and 20 had received a placebo (group P).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients were evaluated by neurological examinations, questionnaires and sensory-motor nerve conduction studies.</Chemical>

<Chemical>There was no significant difference in the frequency of signs or symptoms between the two groups although neurotoxicity symptoms presented mostly with lower scores of severity in group G. However, this difference reached statistical significance only with regard to reported pain sensation (P = 0.011).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Also the frequency of abnormal electro-diagnostic findings showed similarity between the two groups (G: 7/23 = 30.4%; P: 6/20 = 30%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>This pilot study leads to the conclusion that glutamate supplementation at the chosen regimen fails to protect against peripheral neurotoxicity of PAC.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Attentional modulation of perceived pain intensity in capsaicin-induced secondary hyperalgesia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Perceived pain intensity is modulated by attention.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, it is not known that how pain intensity ratings are affected by attention in capsaicin-induced secondary hyperalgesia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Here we show that perceived pain intensity in secondary hyperalgesia is decreased when attention is distracted away from the painful pinprick stimulus with a visual task.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Testosterone-dependent hypertension and upregulation of intrarenal angiotensinogen in Dahl salt-sensitive rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Blood pressure (BP) is more salt sensitive in men than in premenopausal women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In Dahl salt-sensitive rats (DS), high-salt (HS) diet increases BP more in males than females.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast to the systemic renin-angiotensin system, which is suppressed in response to HS in male DS, intrarenal angiotensinogen expression is increased, and intrarenal levels of ANG II are not suppressed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this study, the hypothesis was tested that there is a sexual dimorphism in HS-induced upregulation of intrarenal angiotensinogen mediated by testosterone that also causes increases in BP and renal injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>On a low-salt (LS) diet, male DS had higher levels of intrarenal angiotensinogen mRNA than females.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>HS diet for 4 wk increased renal cortical angiotensinogen mRNA and protein only in male DS, which was prevented by castration.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ovariectomy of female DS had no effect on intrarenal angiotensinogen expression on either diet.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Radiotelemetric BP was similar between males and castrated rats on LS diet.</Chemical>
<Chemical>HS diet for 4 wk caused a progressive increase in BP, protein and albumin excretion, and glomerular sclerosis in male DS rats, which were attenuated by castration.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Testosterone replacement in castrated DS rats increased BP, renal injury, and upregulation of renal angiotensinogen associated with HS diet.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Testosterone contributes to the development of hypertension and renal injury in male DS rats on HS diet possibly through upregulation of the intrarenal renin-angiotensin system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prenatal protein deprivation alters dopamine-mediated behaviors and dopaminergic and glutamatergic receptor binding.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Epidemiological evidence indicates that prenatal nutritional deprivation may increase the risk of schizophrenia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The goal of these studies was to use an animal model to examine the effects of prenatal protein deprivation on behaviors and receptor binding with relevance to schizophrenia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We report that prenatally protein deprived (PD) female rats showed an increased stereotypic response to apomorphine and an increased locomotor response to amphetamine in adulthood.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These differences were not observed during puberty.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No changes in haloperidol-induced catalepsy or MK-801-induced locomotion were seen following PD.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, PD female rats showed increased (3)H-MK-801 binding in the striatum and hippocampus, but not in the cortex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PD female rats also showed increased (3)H-haloperidol binding and decreased dopamine transporter binding in striatum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>No statistically significant changes in behavior or receptor binding were found in PD males with the exception of increased (3)H-MK-801 binding in cortex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This animal model may be useful to explore the mechanisms by which prenatal nutritional deficiency enhances risk for schizophrenia in humans and may also have implications for developmental processes leading to differential sensitivity to drugs of abuse.</Chemical>
<Chemical>mToR inhibitors-induced proteinuria: mechanisms, significance, and management.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Massive urinary protein excretion has been observed after conversion from calcineurin inhibitors to mammalian target of rapamycin (mToR) inhibitors, especially sirolimus, in renal transplant recipients with chronic allograft nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hyperprolactinemia can reduce fertility and libido.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>To test the hypothesis that estrogen increases PRL-R expression and sensitivity to prolactin, we next demonstrated that estradiol greatly augments prolactin-induced STAT5 activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sulpiride induced only SOCS-1 in the medial preoptic area, where GnRH neurons are regulated, but in the arcuate nucleus and choroid plexus, PRL-R, SOCS-3, and CIS mRNA levels were also induced.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Estradiol enhanced these effects on SOCS-3 and CIS.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Upregulation of brain expression of P-glycoprotein in MRP2-deficient TR(-) rats resembles seizure-induced up-regulation of this drug efflux transporter in normal rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP2) is a drug efflux transporter that is expressed predominantly at the apical domain of hepatocytes but seems also to be expressed at the apical membrane of brain capillary endothelial cells that form the blood-brain barrier (BBB).</Chemical>
<Chemical>MRP2 is absent in the transport-deficient (TR(-))</Chemical>

<Chemical>Wistar rat mutant, so that this rat strain was very helpful in defining substrates of MRP2 by comparing tissue concentrations or functional activities of compounds in MRP2-deficient rats with those in transport-competent Wistar rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>By using this strategy to study the involvement of MRP2 in brain access of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs), we recently reported that phenytoin is a substrate for MRP2 in the BBB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, one drawback of such studies in genetically deficient rats is the fact that compensatory changes with upregulation of other transporters can occur.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This prompted us to study the brain expression of P-glycoprotein (Pgp), a major drug efflux transporter in many tissues, including the BBB, in TR(-) rats compared with nonmutant (wild-type) Wistar rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The expression of MRP2 and Pgp in brain and liver sections of TR(-) rats and normal Wistar rats was determined with immunohistochemistry, by using a novel, highly selective monoclonal MRP2 antibody and the monoclonal Pgp antibody C219, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Immunofluorescence staining with the MRP2 antibody was found to label a high number of microvessels throughout the brain in normal Wistar rats, whereas such labeling was absent in TR(-) rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>TR(-)</Chemical>
<Chemical>rats exhibited a significant up-regulation of Pgp in brain capillary endothelial cells compared with wild-type controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No such obvious upregulation of Pgp was observed in liver sections.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A comparable overexpression of Pgp in the BBB was obtained after pilocarpine-induced seizures in wild-type Wistar rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Experiments with systemic administration of the Pgp substrate phenobarbital and the selective Pgp inhibitor tariquidar in TR(-) rats substantiated that Pgp is functional and compensates for the lack of MRP2 in the BBB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The data on TR(-) rats indicate that Pgp plays an important role in the compensation of MRP2 deficiency in the BBB.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Because such a compensatory mechanism most likely occurs to reduce injury to the brain from cytotoxic compounds, the present data substantiate the concept that MRP2 performs a protective role in the BBB.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Furthermore, our data suggest that TR(-) rats are an interesting tool to study consequences of overexpression of Pgp in the BBB on access of drugs in the brain, without the need of inducing seizures or other Pgp-enhancing events for this purpose.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Use of chromosome substitution strains to identify seizure susceptibility loci in mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Seizure susceptibility varies among inbred mouse strains.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Chromosome substitution strains (CSS), in which a single chromosome from one inbred strain (donor) has been transferred onto a second strain (host) by repeated backcrossing, may be used to identify quantitative trait loci (QTLs) that contribute to seizure susceptibility.</Chemical>

<Chemical>QTLs for susceptibility to pilocarpine-induced seizures, a model of temporal lobe epilepsy, have not been reported, and CSS have not previously been used to localize seizure susceptibility genes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report QTLs identified using a B6 (host) x A/J (donor) CSS panel to localize genes involved in susceptibility to pilocarpine-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three hundred fifty-five adult male CSS mice, 58 B6, and 39 A/J were tested for susceptibility to pilocarpine-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Highest stage reached and latency to each stage were recorded for all mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>B6 mice were resistant to seizures and slower to reach stages compared to A/J mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The CSS for Chromosomes 10 and 18 progressed to the most severe stages, diverging dramatically from the B6 phenotype.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Latencies to stages were also significantly shorter for CSS10 and CSS18 mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CSS mapping suggests seizure susceptibility loci on mouse Chromosomes 10 and 18.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This approach provides a framework for identifying potentially novel homologous candidate genes for human temporal lobe epilepsy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Investigation of mitochondrial involvement in the experimental model of epilepsy induced by pilocarpine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mitochondrial abnormalities have been associated with several aspects of epileptogenesis, such as energy generation, control of cell death, neurotransmitter synthesis, and free radical (FR) production.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Increased production of FRs may cause mtDNA damage leading to decreased activities of oxidative phosphorylation complexes containing mtDNA-encoded subunits.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study, we investigated whether increased generation of FR during status epilepticus would be sufficient to provoke abnormalities in mtDNA and in the expression and activity of cytochrome c oxidase (CCO), complex IV of the respiratory chain, in the chronic phase of the pilocarpine model of temporal lobe epilepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DNA analysis revealed low amounts of a 4.8 kb mtDNA deletion but with no differences in frequency or quantity in the control and experimental groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We did not find abnormalities in the expression and distribution of an mtDNA-encoded subunit of CCO (CCO-I) or a relative decrease in CCO-I when compared with nuclear-encoded subunits (CCO-IV and SDH-fp).</Chemical>
<Chemical>No abnormality in CCO activity was observed through histochemistry.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although evidences of mitochondrial abnormalities were found in previously published studies, our results do not suggest that the FRs, generated during the acute phase, determined important abnormalities in mtDNA, in expression of CCO-I, and in CCO activity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Causes of acute thrombotic microangiopathy in patients receiving kidney transplantation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thrombotic microangiopathy is a well-known problem in patients following renal transplantation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In postrenal transplantation, thrombotic microangiopathy is often a reflection of hemolytic uremic syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We aimed to determine the causes of thrombotic microangiopathy in a population of renal transplantation recipients and discuss the literature.</Chemical>
<Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We investigated the causes of thrombotic microangiopathy during a 1-year period, from June 2003 to June 2004, at the King Fahad National Guard Hospital in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, by reviewing the slides of all transplant biopsies (n=25) performed during this interval.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pre- and posttransplant crossmatching was done when possible.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Five cases of thrombotic microangiopathy were found.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Three of these cases were from the 25 transplantations performed at King Fahad National Guard Hospital, while the other 2 transplantations had been performed abroad and were referred to us for follow-up.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Three cases were related to cyclosporine, and 1 case was secondary to both cyclosporine and tacrolimus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The fifth case had features of thrombotic microangiopathy related to an antiphospholipid syndrome in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the literature, the most-frequent cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in patients following renal transplantation is recurrence of the hemolytic uremic syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Other causes include drug-related (cyclosporine, tacrolimus) toxicity, procoagulant status, and antibody-mediated rejection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We found that the most-frequent cause of thrombotic microangiopathy was drug related, secondary mainly to cyclosporine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the current study, the frequency of thrombotic microangiopathy was similar to the percentage reported in the literature (20%).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In contrast, reports of myocardial dysfunction due to acute iatrogenic overdose are rare.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A 35-year-old woman whose cervix uteri was inadvertently injected with 8 mg of epinephrine developed myocardial stunning that was characterized by severe hemodynamic compromise, profound, albeit transient, left ventricular systolic and diastolic dysfunction, and only modestly elevated biochemical markers of myocardial necrosis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Our case illustrates the serious consequences of medical errors that can be avoided through improved medication labeling and staff supervision.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urinary bladder cancer in Wegener's granulomatosis: risks and relation to cyclophosphamide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To assess and characterise the risk of bladder cancer, and its relation to cyclophosphamide, in patients with Wegener's granulomatosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the population based, nationwide Swedish Inpatient Register a cohort of 1065 patients with Wegener's granulomatosis, 1969-95, was identified.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Through linkage with the Swedish Cancer Register, all subjects in this cohort diagnosed with bladder cancer were identified.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Nested within the cohort, a matched case-control study was performed to estimate the association between cyclophosphamide and bladder cancer using odds ratios (ORs) as relative risk.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the cohort the cumulative risk of bladder cancer after Wegener's granulomatosis, and the relative prevalence of a history of bladder cancer at the time of diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis, were also estimated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The median cumulative doses of cyclophosphamide among cases (n = 11) and controls (n = 25) were 113 g and 25 g, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The risk of bladder cancer doubled for every 10 g increment in cyclophosphamide (OR = 2.0, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.8 to 4.9).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment duration longer than 1 year was associated with an eightfold increased risk (OR = 7.7, 95% CI 0.9 to 69).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The absolute risk for bladder cancer in the cohort reached 10% 16 years after diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis, and a history of bladder cancer was (non-significantly) twice as common as expected at the time of diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The results indicate a dose-response relationship between cyclophosphamide and the risk of bladder cancer, high cumulative risks in the entire cohort, and also the possibility of risk factors operating even before Wegener's granulomatosis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In each patient who had abnormalities on the initial MR study, a follow-up MR study was performed 1 month later.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Of the 14 patients, 5 (35.7%) had white matter abnormalities, 1 (7.1%) had putaminal hemorrhage, and 8 (57.1%) had normal findings on initial MR images.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Among the 5 patients with white matter abnormalities, 4 patients (80.0%) showed higher than normal ADC values on initial MR images, and all showed complete resolution on follow-up images.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The remaining 1 patient (20.0%) showed lower than normal ADC value and showed incomplete resolution with cortical laminar necrosis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Sequential observations of exencephaly and subsequent morphological changes by mouse exo utero development system: analysis of the mechanism of transformation from exencephaly to anencephaly.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Anencephaly has been suggested to develop from exencephaly; however, there is little direct experimental evidence to support this, and the mechanism of transformation remains unclear.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We examined this theory using the exo utero development system that allows direct and sequential observations of mid- to late-gestation mouse embryos.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We observed the exencephaly induced by 5-azacytidine at embryonic day 13.5 (E13.5), let the embryos develop exo utero until E18.5, and re-observed the same embryos at E18.5.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We confirmed several cases of transformation from exencephaly to anencephaly.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, in many cases, the exencephalic brain tissue was preserved with more or less reduction during this period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>To analyze the transformation patterns, we classified the exencephaly by size and shape of the exencephalic tissue into several types at E13.5 and E18.5.</Chemical>

<Chemical>It was found that the transformation of exencephalic tissue was not simply size-dependent, and all cases of anencephaly at E18.5 resulted from embryos with a large amount of exencephalic tissue at E13.5.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Microscopic observation showed the configuration of exencephaly at E13.5, frequent hemorrhaging and detachment of the neural plate from surface ectoderm in the exencephalic head at E15.5, and multiple modes of reduction in the exencephalic tissue at E18.5.</Chemical>
<Chemical>From observations of the vasculature, altered distribution patterns of vessels were identified in the exencephalic head.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These findings suggest that overgrowth of the exencephalic neural tissue causes the altered distribution patterns of vessels, subsequent peripheral circulatory failure and/or hemorrhaging in various parts of the exencephalic head, leading to the multiple modes of tissue reduction during transformation from exencephaly to anencephaly.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>INTRODUCTION: Intoxications with carbachol, a muscarinic cholinergic receptor agonist are rare.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report an interesting case investigating a (near) fatal poisoning.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The son of an 84-year-old male discovered a newspaper report stating clinical success with plant extracts in Alzheimer's disease.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>He bought 25 g of carbachol as pure substance in a pharmacy, and the father was administered 400 to 500 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Carbachol concentrations in serum and urine on day 1 and 2 of hospital admission were analysed by HPLC-mass spectrometry.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Minutes after oral administration, the patient developed nausea, sweating and hypotension, and finally collapsed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bradycardia, cholinergic symptoms and asystole occurred.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Initial cardiopulmonary resuscitation and immediate treatment with adrenaline (epinephrine), atropine and furosemide was successful.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On hospital admission, blood pressure of the intubated, bradyarrhythmic patient was 100/65 mmHg.</Chemical>

<Chemical>High doses of atropine (up to 50 mg per 24 hours), adrenaline and dopamine were necessary.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient was extubated 1 week later.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, increased dyspnoea and bronchospasm necessitated reintubation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Respiratory insufficiency was further worsened by Proteus mirabilis infection and severe bronchoconstriction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>One week later, the patient was again extubated and 3 days later was transferred to a peripheral ward.</Chemical>
<Chemical>On the next day he died, probably as a result of heart failure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serum samples from the first and second days contained 3.6 and 1.9 mg/l carbachol, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The corresponding urine concentrations amounted to 374 and 554 mg/l. CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This case started with a media report in a popular newspaper, initiated by published, peer-reviewed research on herbals, and involved human failure in a case history, medical examination and clinical treatment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The analysed carbachol concentration exceeded the supposed serum level resulting from a therapeutic dose by a factor of 130 to 260.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cervical and inguinal lymph node biopsies showed the features of severe necrotising lymphadenitis, associated with erythrophagocytosis and prominent eosinophilic infiltrates, without viral inclusion bodies, suggestive of an adverse drug reaction.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Post-mortem examination showed evidence of massive hepatocellular necrosis, acute hypersensitivity myocarditis, focal acute tubulo-interstitial nephritis and extensive bone marrow necrosis, with no evidence of malignancy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Analysis was performed on 61 women with chemotherapy-responsive metastatic breast cancer receiving 96-h infusional cyclophosphamide as part of a triple sequential high-dose regimen to assess association between presence of peritransplant congestive heart failure (CHF) and the following pretreatment characteristics: presence of electrocardiogram (EKG) abnormalities, age, hypertension, prior cardiac history, smoking, diabetes mellitus, prior use of anthracyclines, and left-sided chest irradiation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Can angiogenesis be a target of treatment for ribavirin associated hemolytic anemia?</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND/AIMS:</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We aimed to investigate whether there is a relation between hemoglobin, haptoglobin and angiogenesis soluble markers which are modifiable and can help in developing strategies against anemia.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum hemoglobin, haptoglobin and angiogenesis markers of vascular endothelial growth factor and angiopoetin-2 were investigated before and after therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We observed a significant decrease in haptoglobin levels at the end of the treatment period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hemoglobin levels also decreased but insignificantly by treatment.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We found no correlation of angiogenesis soluble markers with either hemoglobin or haptoglobin.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This is the first study in the literature investigating a link between angiogenesis soluble markers and ribavirin induced anemia in patients with hepatitis C and we could not find any relation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Future research with larger number of patients is needed to find out modifiable factors that will improve the safety of ribavirin therapy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We report a case of intractable hemorrhagic cystitis due to cyclophosphamide therapy for Wegener's granulomatosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Conservative treatment, including bladder irrigation with physiological saline and instillation of prostaglandin F2 alpha, failed to totally control hemorrhage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We then used hyperbaric oxygen at an absolute pressure of 2 atm, 5 days a week for 8 consecutive weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The bleeding ceased completely by the end of treatment and the patient remained free of hematuria thereafter.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No side effect was noted during the course of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In future, this form of therapy can offer a safe alternative in the treatment of cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Further studies on effects of irrigation solutions on rat bladders.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Further studies on the effects of certain irrigating fluids on the rat bladder for 18 hours are reported.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results have shown that the degradation product p-choloroaniline is not a significant factor in chlorhexidine-digluconate associated erosive cystitis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A high percentage of kanamycin-colistin and povidone-iodine irrigations were associated with erosive cystitis and suggested a possible complication with human usage.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Clinical experiences in an open and a double-blind trial.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A total of sixty patients were trated with bromperidol first in open conditions (20 patients), then on a double blind basis (40 patients) with haloperidol as the reference substance.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The open study lasted for four weeks; the drug was administrated in the form of 1 mg tablets.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The daily dose (initial dose: 1 mg; mean dose at the end of the trial: 4.47 mg) was always administered in one single dose.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nineteen patients finished the trial, and in 18 cases the therapeutic result was considered very good to good.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results were confirmed by statistical analysis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nine patients exhibited mild to moderate extrapyramidal concomitant symptoms; no other side effects were observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results of detailed laboratory tests and evaluations of various quantitative and qualitative tolerability parameters were not indicative of toxic effects.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In the double blind study with haloperidol, both substances were found to be highly effective in the treatment of psychotic syndromes belonging predominantly to the schizophrenia group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Certain clues, including the onset of action, seem to be indicative of the superiority of bromperidol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>No differences were observed with respect to side effects and general tolerability.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Curcumin ameliorates cognitive dysfunction and oxidative damage in phenobarbitone and carbamazepine administered rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The antiepileptic drugs, phenobarbitone and carbamazepine are well known to cause cognitive impairment on chronic use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The increase in free radical generation has been implicated as one of the important mechanisms of cognitive impairment by antiepileptic drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Curcumin has shown antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and neuro-protective properties.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, the present study was carried out to investigate the effect of chronic curcumin administration on phenobarbitone- and carbamazepine-induced cognitive impairment and oxidative stress in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pharmacokinetic interactions of curcumin with phenobarbitone and carbamazepine were also studied.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vehicle/drugs were administered daily for 21days to male Wistar rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Passive avoidance paradigm and elevated plus maze test were used to assess cognitive function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At the end of study period, serum phenobarbitone and carbamazepine, whole brain malondialdehyde and reduced glutathione levels were estimated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The administration of phenobarbitone and carbamazepine for 21days caused a significant impairment of learning and memory as well as an increased oxidative stress.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Concomitant curcumin administration prevented the cognitive impairment and decreased the increased oxidative stress induced by these antiepileptic drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Curcumin co-administration did not cause any significant alteration in the serum concentrations of both phenobarbitone as well as carbamazepine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results show that curcumin has beneficial effect in mitigating the deterioration of cognitive functions and oxidative damage in rats treated with phenobarbitone and carbamazepine without significantly altering their serum concentrations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The findings suggest that curcumin can be considered as a potential safe and effective adjuvant to phenobarbitone and carbamazepine therapy in preventing cognitive impairment associated with these drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate protects the piriform cortex in the pilocarpine status epilepticus model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate (PDTC) has a dual mechanism of action as an antioxidant and an inhibitor of the transcription factor kappa-beta.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both, production of reactive oxygen species as well as activation of NF-kappaB have been implicated in severe neuronal damage in different sub-regions of the hippocampus as well as in the surrounding cortices.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of PDTC on status epilepticus-associated cell loss in the hippocampus and piriform cortex was evaluated in the rat fractionated pilocarpine model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment with 150 mg/kg PDTC before and following status epilepticus significantly increased the mortality rate to 100%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of 50 mg/kg PDTC (low-dose) did not exert major effects on the development of a status epilepticus or the mortality rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In vehicle-treated rats, status epilepticus caused pronounced neuronal damage in the piriform cortex comprising both pyramidal cells and interneurons.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Low-dose PDTC treatment almost completely protected from lesions in the piriform cortex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant decrease in neuronal density of the hippocampal hilar formation was identified in vehicle- and PDTC-treated rats following status epilepticus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, the NF-kappaB inhibitor and antioxidant PDTC protected the piriform cortex, whereas it did not affect hilar neuronal loss.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data might indicate that the generation of reactive oxygen species and activation of NF-kappaB plays a more central role in seizure-associated neuronal damage in the temporal cortex as compared to the hippocampal hilus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, future investigations are necessary to exactly analyze the biochemical mechanisms by which PDTC exerted its beneficial effects in the piriform cortex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Safety profile of a nicotine lozenge compared with that of nicotine gum in adult smokers with underlying medical conditions: a 12-week, randomized, open-label study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nicotine polacrilex lozenges deliver 25% to 27% more nicotine compared with equivalent doses of nicotine polacrilex gum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The increased nicotine exposure from the lozenge has raised questions about the relative safety of the lozenge and gum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The objective of this study was to compare the safety profiles of the 4-mg nicotine lozenge and 4-mg nicotine gum in smokers with selected label-restricted diseases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was a multicenter, randomized, open-label study in adult smokers with heart disease, hypertension not controlled by medication, and/or diabetes mellitus.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients were randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive the 4-mg nicotine lozenge or 4-mg nicotine gum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Safety assessments were made at baseline and at 2, 4, 6, and 12 weeks after the start of product use.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Nine hundred one patients were randomized to treatment, 447 who received the lozenge and 454 who received the gum (safety population).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The majority were women (52.7%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients' mean age was 53.9 years, their mean weight was 193.9 pounds, and they smoked a mean of 25.2 cigarettes per day at baseline.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Five hundred fifty-three patients, 264 taking the lozenge and 289 taking the gum, used the study product for > or =4 days per week during the first 2 weeks (evaluable population).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The nicotine lozenge and nicotine gum were equally well tolerated, despite increased nicotine exposure from the lozenge.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of adverse events in the 2 groups was similar during the first 2 weeks of product use (evaluation population: 55.3% lozenge, 54.7% gum), as well as during the entire study (safety population: 63.8% and 58.6%, respectively).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Stratification of patients by sex, age, extent of concurrent smoking, extent of product use, and severity of adverse events revealed no clinically significant differences between the lozenge and gum.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The most common adverse events were nausea (17.2% and 16.1%; 95% CI, -3.7 to 6.0), hiccups (10.7% and 6.6%; 95% CI, 0.5 to 7.8), and headache (8.7% and 9.9%; 95% Cl, -5.0 to 2.6).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serious adverse events were reported in 11 and 13 patients in the respective groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fewer than 6% of patients in either group were considered by the investigator to have a worsening of their overall disease condition during the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The majority of patients (>60%) experienced no change in their disease status from baseline.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The 4-mg nicotine lozenge and 4-mg nicotine gum had comparable safety profiles in these patients with label-restricted medical conditions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Development of levodopa-induced dyskinesias in parkinsonian monkeys may depend upon rate of symptom onset and/or duration of symptoms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Levodopa-induced dyskinesias (LIDs) present a major problem for the long-term management of Parkinson's disease (PD) patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Due to the interdependence of risk factors in clinical populations, it is difficult to independently examine factors that may influence the development of LIDs.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Using macaque monkeys with different types of MPTP-induced parkinsonism, the current study evaluated the degree to which rate of symptom progression, symptom severity, and response to and duration of levodopa therapy may be involved in the development of LIDs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Monkeys with acute (short-term) MPTP exposure, rapid symptom onset and short symptom duration prior to initiation of levodopa therapy developed dyskinesia between 11 and 24 days of daily levodopa administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, monkeys with long-term MPTP exposure, slow symptom progression and/or long symptom duration prior to initiation of levodopa therapy were more resistant to developing LIDs (e.g., dyskinesia developed no sooner than 146 days of chronic levodopa administration).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All animals were similarly symptomatic at the start of levodopa treatment and had similar therapeutic responses to the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data suggest distinct differences in the propensity to develop LIDs in monkeys with different rates of symptom progression or symptom durations prior to levodopa and demonstrate the value of these models for further studying the pathophysiology of LIDs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Propylthiouracil-induced perinuclear-staining antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody-positive vasculitis in conjunction with pericarditis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To describe a case of propylthiouracil-induced vasculitis manifesting with pericarditis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We present the first case report of a woman with hyperthyroidism treated with propylthiouracil in whom a syndrome of pericarditis, fever, and glomerulonephritis developed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serologic testing and immunologic studies were done, and a pericardial biopsy was performed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 25-year-old woman with Graves' disease had a febrile illness and evidence of pericarditis, which was confirmed by biopsy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serologic evaluation revealed the presence of perinuclear-staining antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibodies (pANCA) against myeloperoxidase (MPO).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Propylthiouracil therapy was withdrawn, and she was treated with a 1-month course of prednisone, which alleviated her symptoms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A literature review revealed no prior reports of pericarditis in anti-MPO pANCA-positive vasculitis associated with propylthio- uracil therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pericarditis may be the initial manifestation of drug-induced vasculitis attributable to propylthio- uracil therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two mouse lines selected for differential sensitivities to beta-carboline-induced seizures are also differentially sensitive to various pharmacological effects of other GABA(A) receptor ligands.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Two mouse lines were selectively bred according to their sensitivity (BS line) or resistance (BR line) to seizures induced by a single i.p. injection of methyl beta-carboline-3-carboxylate (beta-CCM), an inverse agonist of the GABA(A) receptor benzodiazepine site.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our aim was to characterize both lines' sensitivities to various physiological effects of other ligands of the GABA(A) receptor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We measured diazepam-induced anxiolysis with the elevated plus-maze test, diazepam-induced sedation by recording the vigilance states, and picrotoxin- and pentylenetetrazol-induced seizures after i.p. injections.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Results presented here show that the differential sensitivities of BS and BR lines to beta-CCM can be extended to diazepam, picrotoxin, and pentylenetetrazol, suggesting a genetic selection of a general sensitivity and resistance to several ligands of the GABA(A) receptor.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Analgesic effect of intravenous ketamine in cancer patients on morphine therapy: a randomized, controlled, double-blind, crossover, double-dose study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain not responsive to morphine is often problematic.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Animal and clinical studies have suggested that N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) antagonists, such as ketamine, may be effective in improving opioid analgesia in difficult pain syndromes, such as neuropathic pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A slow bolus of subhypnotic doses of ketamine (0.25 mg/kg or 0.50 mg/kg) was given to 10 cancer patients whose pain was unrelieved by morphine in a randomized, double-blind, crossover, double-dose study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain intensity on a 0 to 10 numerical scale; nausea and vomiting, drowsiness, confusion, and dry mouth, using a scale from 0 to 3 (not at all, slight, a lot, awful); Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) (0-30); and arterial pressure were recorded before administration of drugs (T0) and after 30 minutes (T30), 60 minutes (T60), 120 minutes (T120), and 180 minutes (T180).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ketamine, but not saline solution, significantly reduced the pain intensity in almost all the patients at both doses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This effect was more relevant in patients treated with higher doses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hallucinations occurred in 4 patients, and an unpleasant sensation ("empty head") was also reported by 2 patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These episodes reversed after the administration of diazepam 1 mg intravenously.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Significant increases in drowsiness were reported in patients treated with ketamine in both groups and were more marked with ketamine 0.50 mg/kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant difference in MMSE was observed at T30 in patients who received 0.50 mg/kg of ketamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketamine can improve morphine analgesia in difficult pain syndromes, such as neuropathic pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the occurrence of central adverse effects should be taken into account, especially when using higher doses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This observation should be tested in studies of prolonged ketamine administration.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Endocrine screening in 1,022 men with erectile dysfunction: clinical significance and cost-effective strategy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We reviewed the results of serum testosterone and prolactin determination in 1,022 patients referred because of erectile dysfunction and compared the data with history, results of physical examination, other etiological investigations and effects of endocrine therapy to refine the rules of cost-effective endocrine screening and to pinpoint actual responsibility for hormonal abnormalities.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Testosterone and prolactin were determined by radioimmunoassay.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Every patient was screened for testosterone and 451 were screened for prolactin on the basis of low sexual desire, gynecomastia or testosterone less than 4 ng./ml.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Determination was repeated in case of abnormal first results.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prolactin results were compared with those of a previous personal cohort of 1,340 patients with erectile dysfunction and systematic prolactin determination.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Main clinical criteria tested regarding efficiency in hormone determination were low sexual desire, small testes and gynecomastia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Endocrine therapy consisted of testosterone heptylate or human chorionic gonadotropin for hypogonadism and bromocriptine for hyperprolactinemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Testosterone was less than 3 ng./ml.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>in 107 patients but normal in 40% at repeat determination.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The prevalence of repeatedly low testosterone increased with age (4% before age 50 years and 9% 50 years or older).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two pituitary tumors were discovered after testosterone determination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Most of the other low testosterone levels seemed to result from nonorganic hypothalamic dysfunction because of normal serum luteinizing hormone and prolactin and to have only a small role in erectile dysfunction (definite improvement in only 16 of 44</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>[36%] after androgen therapy, normal morning or nocturnal erections in 30% and definite vasculogenic contributions in 42%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Determining testosterone only in cases of low sexual desire or abnormal physical examination would have missed 40% of the cases with low testosterone, including 37% of those subsequently improved by androgen therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prolactin exceeded 20 ng./ml.</Chemical>
<Chemical>in 5 men and was normal in 2 at repeat determination.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Only 1 prolactinoma was discovered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These data are lower than those we found during the last 2 decades (overall prolactin greater than 20 ng./ml.</Chemical>
<Chemical>in 1.86% of 1,821 patients, prolactinomas in 7, 0.38%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bromocriptine was definitely effective in cases with prolactin greater than 35 ng./ml.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>(8 of 12 compared to only 9 of 22 cases with prolactin between 20 and 35 ng./ml.).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Testosterone was low in less than 50% of cases with prolactin greater than 35 ng./ml.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Low prevalences and effects of low testosterone and high prolactin in erectile dysfunction cannot justify their routine determination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, cost-effective screening strategies recommended so far missed 40 to 50% of cases improved with endocrine therapy and the pituitary tumors.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We now advocate that before age 50 years testosterone be determined only in cases of low sexual desire and abnormal physical examination but that it be measured in all men older than 50 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prolactin should be determined only in cases of low sexual desire, gynecomastia and/or testosterone less than 4 ng./ml.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thiopentone pretreatment for propofol injection pain in ambulatory patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study investigated propofol injection pain in patients undergoing ambulatory anaesthesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a randomized, double-blind trial, 90 women were allocated to receive one of three treatments prior to induction of anaesthesia with propofol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients in Group C received 2 ml normal saline, Group L, 2 ml, lidocaine 2% (40 mg) and Group T, 2 ml thiopentone 2.5% (50 mg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Venous discomfort was assessed with a visual analogue scale (VAS) 5-15 sec after commencing propofol administration using an infusion pump (rate 1000 micrograms.kg-1.min-1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Loss of consciousness occurred in 60-90 sec.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Visual analogue scores (mean +/- SD) during induction were lower in Groups L (3.3 +/- 2.5) and T (4.1 +/- 2.7) than in Group C (5.6 +/- 2.3); P = 0.0031.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of venous discomfort was lower in Group L (76.6%; P < 0.05) than in Group C (100%) but not different from Group T (90%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The VAS scores for recall of pain in the recovery room were correlated with the VAS scores during induction (r = 0.7045; P < 0.0001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recovery room discharge times were similar: C (75.9 +/- 19.4 min);</Chemical>
<Chemical>L 73.6 +/- 21.6 min); T (77.1 +/- 18.9 min).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Assessing their overall satisfaction, 89.7% would choose propofol anaesthesia again.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that lidocaine reduces the incidence and severity of propofol injection pain in ambulatory patients whereas thiopentone only reduces its severity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Comparison of i.v. glycopyrrolate and atropine in the prevention of bradycardia and arrhythmias following repeated doses of suxamethonium in children.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effectiveness of administration of glycopyrrolate 5 and 10 micrograms kg-1 and atropine 10 and 20 micrograms kg-1 i.v. immediately before the induction of anaesthesia, to prevent arrhythmia and bradycardia following repeated doses of suxamethonium in children, was studied.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A control group was included for comparison with the lower dose range of glycopyrrolate and atropine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A frequency of bradycardia of 50% was noted in the control group, but this was not significantly different from the frequency with the active drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bradycardia (defined as a decrease in heart rate to less than 50 beat min-1) was prevented when the larger dose of either active drug was used.</Chemical>

<Chemical>It is recommended that either glycopyrrolate 10 micrograms kg-1 or atropine 20 micrograms kg-1 i.v. should immediately precede induction of anaesthesia, in children, if the repeated administration of suxamethonium is anticipated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reduction in caffeine toxicity by acetaminophen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A patient who allegedly consumed 100 tablets of an over-the-counter analgesic containing sodium acetylsalicylate, caffeine, and acetaminophen displayed no significant CNS stimulation despite the presence of 175 micrograms of caffeine per mL of serum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because salicylates have been reported to augment the stimulatory effects of caffeine on the CNS, attention was focused on the possibility that the presence of acetaminophen (52 micrograms/mL) reduced the CNS toxicity of caffeine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Studies in DBA/2J mice showed that: 1) pretreatment with acetaminophen (100 mg/kg) increased the interval between the administration of caffeine (300 to 450 mg/kg IP) and the onset of fatal convulsions by a factor of about two; and 2) pretreatment with acetaminophen (75 mg/kg) reduced the incidence of audiogenic seizures produced in the presence of caffeine (12.5 to 75 mg/kg IP).</Chemical>
