Chemical

text: <Chemical>The frequency of sound-induced seizures after 12.5 or 25 mg/kg caffeine was reduced from 50 to 5% by acetaminophen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the absence of caffeine, acetaminophen (up to 300 mg/kg) did not modify the seizures induced by maximal electroshock and did not alter the convulsant dose of pentylenetetrezol in mice (tests performed by the Anticonvulsant Screening Project of NINCDS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acetaminophen (up to 150 micrograms/mL) did not retard the incorporation of radioactive adenosine into ATP in slices of rat cerebral cortex.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus the mechanism by which acetaminophen antagonizes the actions of caffeine in the CNS remains unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flestolol: an ultra-short-acting beta-adrenergic blocking agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flestolol (ACC-9089) is a nonselective, competitive, ultra-short-acting beta-adrenergic blocking agent, without any intrinsic sympathomimetic activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flestolol is metabolized by plasma esterases and has an elimination half-life of approximately 6.5 minutes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This agent was well tolerated in healthy volunteers at doses up to 100 micrograms/kg/min.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In long-term infusion studies, flestolol was well tolerated at the effective beta-blocking dose (5 micrograms/kg/min) for up to seven days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flestolol blood concentrations increased linearly with increasing dose and good correlation exists between blood concentrations of flestolol and beta-adrenergic blockade.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flestolol produced a dose-dependent attenuation of isoproterenol-induced tachycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Electrophysiologic and hemodynamic effects of flestolol are similar to those of other beta blockers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast with other beta blockers, flestolol-induced effects reverse rapidly (within 30 minutes) following discontinuation because of its short half-life.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flestolol effectively reduced heart rate in patients with supraventricular tachyarrhythmia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients with unstable angina, flestolol infusion was found to be safe and effective in controlling chest pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is concluded that flestolol is a potent, well-tolerated, ultra-short-acting beta-adrenergic blocking agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Use of flestolol in the critical care setting is currently undergoing investigation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adverse effect of the calcium channel blocker nitrendipine on nephrosclerosis in rats with renovascular hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of a 6-week treatment with the calcium channel blocker nitrendipine or the angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor enalapril on blood pressure, albuminuria, renal hemodynamics, and morphology of the nonclipped kidney was studied in rats with two-kidney, one clip renovascular hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six weeks after clipping of one renal artery, hypertensive rats (178 +/- 4 mm Hg) were randomly assigned to three groups: untreated hypertensive controls (n = 8), enalapril-treated (n = 8), or nitrendipine-treated (n = 10).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sham-operated rats served as normotensive controls (128 +/- 3 mm Hg, n = 8).</Chemical>
<Chemical>After 6 weeks of treatment, renal hemodynamics (glomerular filtration rate and renal plasma flow) were measured in the anesthetized rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Renal tissue was obtained for determination of glomerular size and sclerosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Enalapril but not nitrendipine reduced blood pressure significantly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 6 weeks of therapy, glomerular filtration rate was not different among the studied groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Renal plasma flow increased, but albumin excretion and glomerulosclerosis did not change after enalapril treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, in the nitrendipine-treated group albuminuria increased from 12.8 +/- 2 progressively to 163 +/- 55 compared with 19.2 +/- 9 mg/24 hr in the hypertensive controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, glomerulosclerosis index was significantly increased in the nitrendipine-treated group compared with the hypertensive controls (0.38 +/- 0.1 versus 0.13 +/- 0.04).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, glomerular size was higher in the nitrendipine-treated group (14.9 +/- 0.17 10(-3) mm2) but lower in the enalapril-treated group (11.5 +/- 0.15 10(-3) mm2) compared with the hypertensive controls (12.1 +/- 0.17 10(-3)</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>mm2).(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment of tinnitus by intratympanic instillation of lignocaine (lidocaine) 2 per cent through ventilation tubes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Idiopathic subjective tinnitus (IST) is one of the most obscure otological pathologies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This paper presents the results of treating IST by intratympanic instillation of lignocaine (lidocaine) 2 per cent through a grommet, for five weekly courses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifty-two patients suffering from intractable tinnitus entered this therapeutic trial, but only nine finished all five courses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In one patient, the tinnitus was almost completely abolished, but in all the nine patients the decompensated tinnitus changed to a compensated one.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We suggest this mode of treatment for patients that were previously treated by drugs, acupuncture and biofeedback, with disappointing results.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients should be warned about the side effects of vertigo and vomiting, which subsides gradually with every new instillation, and that the tinnitus may not disappear but will be alleviated, enabling them to cope more easily with the disease and lead a more normal life.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Perhexiline maleate and peripheral neuropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Peripheral neuropathy has been noted as a complication of therapy with perhexiline maleate, a drug widely used in France (and in clinical trials in the United States) for the prophylactic treatment of angina pectoris.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 24 patients with this complication, the marked slowing of motor nerve conduction velocity and the electromyographic changes imply mainly a demyelinating disorder.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Improvement was noted with cessation of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In a few cases the presence of active denervation signified a poor prognosis, with only slight improvement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The underlying mechanism causing the neuropathy is not yet fully known, although some evidence indicates that it may be a lipid storage process.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effect of humoral modulators of morphine-induced increase in locomotor activity of mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of humoral modulators on the morphine-induced increase in locomotor activity of mice was studied.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The subcutaneous administration of 10 mg/kg of morphine-HC1 produced a marked increase in locomotor activity in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The morphine-induced hyperactivity was potentiated by scopolamine and attenuated by physostigmine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, both methscopolamine and neostigmine, which do not penetrate the blood-brain barrier, had no effect on the hyperactivity produced by morphine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pretreatment of mice with alpha-methyltyrosine (20 mg/kg i.p., one hour), an inhibitor of tyrosine hydroxylase, significantly decreased the activity-increasing effects of morphine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the other hand, pretreatment with p-chlorophenylalamine (3 X 320 mg/kg i.p., 24 hr), a serotonin depletor, caused no significant change in the hyperactivity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The study suggests that the activity-increasing effects of morphine are mediated by the release of catecholamines from adrenergic neurons in the brain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>And the results are consistent with the hypothesis that morphine acts by retarding the release of acetylcholine at some central cholinergic synapses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is also suggested from collected evidence that the activity-increasing effects of morphine in mice are mediated by mechanisms different from those which mediate the activity-increasing effects of morphine in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mechanisms of FK 506-induced hypertension in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>-Tacrolimus (FK 506) is a powerful, widely used immunosuppressant.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The clinical utility of FK 506 is complicated by substantial hypertension and nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To clarify the mechanisms of FK 506-induced hypertension, we studied the chronic effects of FK 506 on the synthesis of endothelin-1 (ET-1), the expression of mRNA of ET-1 and endothelin-converting enzyme-1 (ECE-1), the endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) activity, and the expression of mRNA of eNOS and C-type natriuretic peptide (CNP) in rat blood vessels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, the effect of the specific endothelin type A receptor antagonist FR 139317 on FK 506-induced hypertension in rats was studied.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>FK 506, 5 mg. kg-1. d-1 given for 4 weeks, elevated blood pressure from 102+/-13 to 152+/-15 mm</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hg and increased the synthesis of ET-1 and the levels of ET-1 mRNA in the mesenteric artery (240% and 230%, respectively).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Little change was observed in the expression of ECE-1 mRNA and CNP mRNA.</Chemical>
<Chemical>FK 506 decreased eNOS activity and the levels of eNOS mRNA in the aorta (48% and 55%, respectively).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The administration of FR 139317 (10 mg. kg-1. d-1) prevented FK 506-induced hypertension in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results indicate that FK 506 may increase blood pressure not only by increasing ET-1 production but also by decreasing NO synthesis in the vasculature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Suxamethonium induced prolonged apnea in a patient receiving electroconvulsive therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Suxamethonium causes prolonged apnea in patients in whom pseudocholinesterase enzyme gets deactivated by organophosphorus (OP) poisons.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here, we present a similar incident in a severely depressed patient who received electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prolonged apnea in our case ensued because the information about suicidal attempt by OP compound was concealed from the treating team.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of the adjunctive bupropion on male sexual dysfunction induced by a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor: a double-blind placebo-controlled and randomized study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To determine the safety and efficacy of adjunctive bupropion sustained-release (SR) on male sexual dysfunction (SD) induced by a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), as SD is a common side-effect of SSRIs and the most effective treatments have yet to be determined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The randomized sample consisted of 234 euthymic men who were receiving some type of SSRI.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The men were randomly assigned to bupropion SR (150 mg twice daily, 117) or placebo (twice daily, 117) for 12 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Efficacy was evaluated using the Clinical Global Impression-Sexual Function (CGI-SF; the primary outcome measure), the International Index of Erectile Function (IIEF), Arizona Sexual Experience Scale (ASEX), and Erectile Dysfunction Inventory of Treatment Satisfaction (EDITS) (secondary outcome measures).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Participants were followed biweekly during study period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>After 12 weeks of treatment, the mean (sd) scores for CGI-SF were significantly lower, i.e. better, in patients on bupropion SR, at 2.4 (1.2), than in the placebo group, at 3.9 (1.1) (P= 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Men who received bupropion had a significant increase in the total IIEF score (54.4% vs 1.2%; P= 0.003), and in the five different domains of the IIEF.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Total ASEX scores were significantly lower, i.e. better, among men who received bupropion than placebo, at 15.5 (4.3) vs 21.5 (4.7) (P= 0.002).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The EDITS scores were 67.4 (10.2) for the bupropion and 36.3 (11.7) for the placebo group (P= 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The ASEX score and CGI-SF score were correlated (P= 0.003).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In linear regression analyses the CGI-SF score was not affected significantly by the duration of SD, type of SSRI used and age.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bupropion is an effective treatment for male SD induced by SSRIs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results provide empirical support for conducting a further study of bupropion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lamivudine for the prevention of hepatitis B virus reactivation in hepatitis-B surface antigen (HBSAG) seropositive cancer patients undergoing cytotoxic chemotherapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is one of the major causes of chronic liver disease worldwide.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Cancer patients who are chronic carriers of HBV have a higher hepatic complication rate while receiving cytotoxic chemotherapy (CT) and this has mainly been attributed to HBV reactivation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study, cancer patients who have solid and hematological malignancies with chronic HBV infection received the antiviral agent lamivudine prior and during CT compared with historical control group who did not receive lamivudine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The objectives were to assess the efficacy of lamivudine in reducing the incidence of HBV reactivation, and diminishing morbidity and mortality during CT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two groups were compared in this study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The prophylactic lamivudin group consisted of 37 patients who received prophylactic lamivudine treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The historical controls consisted of 50 consecutive patients who underwent CT without prophylactic lamivudine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>They were followed up during and for 8 weeks after CT.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The outcomes were compared for both groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of our control group (n= 50), 21 patients (42%) were established hepatitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twelve (24%) of them were evaluated as severe hepatitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the prophylactic lamivudine group severe hepatitis were observed only in 1 patient (2.7%) of 37 patients (p < 0.006).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Comparison of the mean ALT values revealed significantly higher mean alanine aminotransferase (ALT) values in the control group than the prophylactic lamivudine group;</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>154:64 (p < 0.32).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our study suggests that prophylactic lamivudine significantly decreases the incidence of HBV reactivation and overall morbidity in cancer patients during and after immunosuppressive therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further studies are needed to determine the most appropriate nucleoside or nucleotide analogue for antiviral prophylaxis during CT and the optimal duration of administration after completion of CT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ginsenoside Rg1 restores the impairment of learning induced by chronic morphine administration in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rg1, as a ginsenoside extracted from Panax ginseng, could ameliorate spatial learning impairment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous studies have demonstrated that Rg1 might be a useful agent for the prevention and treatment of the adverse effects of morphine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of Rg1 on learning impairment by chronic morphine administration and the mechanism responsible for this effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male rats were subcutaneously injected with morphine (10 mg/kg) twice a day at 12 hour intervals for 10 days, and Rg1 (30 mg/kg) was intraperitoneally injected 2 hours after the second injection of morphine once a day for 10 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Spatial learning capacity was assessed in the Morris water maze.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results showed that rats treated with Morphine/Rg1 decreased escape latency and increased the time spent in platform quadrant and entering frequency.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>By implantation of electrodes and electrophysiological recording in vivo, the results showed that Rg1 restored the long-term potentiation (LTP) impaired by morphine in both freely moving and anaesthetised rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The electrophysiological recording in vitro showed that Rg1 restored the LTP in slices from the rats treated with morphine, but not changed LTP in the slices from normal saline- or morphine/Rg1-treated rats; this restoration could be inhibited by N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist MK801.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that Rg1 may significantly improve the spatial learning capacity impaired by chonic morphine administration and restore the morphine-inhibited LTP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This effect is NMDA receptor dependent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A study on the effect of the duration of subcutaneous heparin injection on bruising and pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIM:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study was carried out to determine the effect of injection duration on bruising and pain following the administration of the subcutaneous injection of heparin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although different methods to prevent bruising and pain following the subcutaneous injection of heparin have been widely studied and described, the effect of injection duration on the occurrence of bruising and pain is little documented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study was designed as within-subject, quasi-experimental research.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The sample for the study consisted of 50 patients to whom subcutaneous heparin was administered.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Heparin was injected over 10 seconds on the right abdominal site and 30 seconds on the left abdominal site.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Injections areas were assessed for the presence of bruising at 48 and 72 hours after each injection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dimensions of the bruising on the heparin applied areas were measured using transparent millimetric measuring paper.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The visual analog scale (VAS) was used to measure pain intensity and a stop-watch was used to time the pain period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Data were analysed using chi-square test, Mann-Whitney U, Wilcoxon signed ranks tests and correlation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The percentage of bruising occurrence was 64% with the injection of 10 seconds duration and 42% in the 30-second injection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It was determined that the size of the bruising was smaller in the 30-second injection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pain intensity and pain period were statistically significantly lower for the 30-second injection than for the 10-second injection.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>It was determined that injection duration had an effect on bruising and pain following the subcutaneous administration of heparin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study should be repeated on a larger sample.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RELEVANCE TO CLINICAL PRACTICE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>When administering subcutaneous heparin injections, it is important to extend the duration of the injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acute reserpine and subchronic haloperidol treatments change synaptosomal brain glutamate uptake and elicit orofacial dyskinesia in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reserpine- and haloperidol-induced orofacial dyskinesia are putative animal models of tardive dyskinesia (TD) whose pathophysiology has been related to free radical generation and oxidative stress.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study, the authors induced orofacial dyskinesia by acute reserpine and subchronic haloperidol administration to rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reserpine injection (one dose of 1 mg/kg s.c.)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>every other day for 3 days caused a significant increase in vacuous chewing, tongue protrusion and duration of facial twitching, compared to the control.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Haloperidol administration (one dose of 12 mg/kg once a week s.c.) for 4 weeks caused an increase in vacuous chewing, tongue protrusion and duration of facial twitching observed in four weekly evaluations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After the treatments and behavioral observation, glutamate uptake by segments of the brain was analyzed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A decreased glutamate uptake was observed in the subcortical parts of animals treated with reserpine and haloperidol, compared to the control.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Importantly, a decrease in glutamate uptake correlates negatively with an increase in the incidence of orofacial diskinesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results indicate that early changes in glutamate transport may be related to the development of vacuous chewing movements in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acute psychosis due to treatment with phenytoin in a nonepileptic patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The development of psychosis related to antiepileptic drug treatment is usually attributed to the interaction between the epileptic brain substratum and the antiepileptic drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The case of a nonepileptic patient who developed psychosis following phenytoin treatment for trigeminal neuralgia is described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This case suggests that the psychotic symptoms that occur following phenytoin treatment in some epileptic patients may be the direct result of medication, unrelated to seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of treatment with gum Arabic on gentamicin nephrotoxicity in rats: a preliminary study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present work we assessed the effect of treatment of rats with gum Arabic on acute renal failure induced by gentamicin (GM) nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats were treated with the vehicle (2 mL/kg of distilled water and 5% w/v cellulose, 10 days), gum Arabic (2 mL/kg of a 10% w/v aqueous suspension of gum Arabic powder, orally for 10 days), or gum Arabic concomitantly with GM (80mg/kg/day intramuscularly, during the last six days of the treatment period).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nephrotoxicity was assessed by measuring the concentrations of creatinine and urea in the plasma and reduced glutathione (GSH) in the kidney cortex, and by light microscopic examination of kidney sections.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results indicated that concomitant treatment with gum Arabic and GM significantly increased creatinine and urea by about 183 and 239%, respectively (compared to 432 and 346%, respectively, in rats treated with cellulose and GM), and decreased that of cortical GSH by 21% (compared to 27% in the cellulose plus GM group)</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The GM-induced proximal tubular necrosis appeared to be slightly less severe in rats given GM together with gum Arabic than in those given GM and cellulose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It could be inferred that gum Arabic treatment has induced a modest amelioration of some of the histological and biochemical indices of GM nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further work is warranted on the effect of the treatments on renal functional aspects in models of chronic renal failure, and on the mechanism(s) involved.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Visual hallucinations associated with zonisamide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Zonisamide is a broad-spectrum antiepileptic drug used to treat various types of seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although visual hallucinations have not been reported as an adverse effect of this agent, we describe three patients who experienced complex visual hallucinations and altered mental status after zonisamide treatment was begun or its dosage increased.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All three had been diagnosed earlier with epilepsy, and their electroencephalogram (EEG) findings were abnormal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>During monitoring, visual hallucinations did not correlate with EEG readings, nor did video recording capture any of the described events.</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of the patients had experienced visual hallucinations before this event.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The only recent change in their treatment was the introduction or increased dosage of zonisamide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>With either discontinuation or decreased dosage of the drug the symptoms disappeared and did not recur.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Further observations and reports will help clarify this adverse effect.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Until then, clinicians need to be aware of this possible complication associated with zonisamide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>GLEPP1 receptor tyrosine phosphatase (Ptpro) in rat PAN nephrosis. A marker of acute podocyte injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Glomerular epithelial protein 1 (GLEPP1) is a podocyte receptor membrane protein tyrosine phosphatase located on the apical cell membrane of visceral glomerular epithelial cell and foot processes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This receptor plays a role in regulating the structure and function of podocyte foot process.</Chemical>

<Chemical>To better understand the utility of GLEPP1 as a marker of glomerular injury, the amount and distribution of GLEPP1 protein and mRNA were examined by immunohistochemistry, Western blot and RNase protection assay in a model of podocyte injury in the rat.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Puromycin aminonucleoside nephrosis was induced by single intraperitoneal injection of puromycin aminonucleoside (PAN, 20 mg/100g BW).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tissues were analyzed at 0, 5, 7, 11, 21, 45, 80 and 126 days after PAN injection so as to include both the acute phase of proteinuria associated with foot process effacement (days 5-11) and the chronic phase of proteinuria associated with glomerulosclerosis (days 45-126).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At day 5, GLEPP1 protein and mRNA were reduced from the normal range (265.2 +/- 79.6 x 10(6) moles/glomerulus and 100%) to 15% of normal (41.8 +/- 4.8 x 10(6) moles/glomerulus, p < 0.005).</Chemical>
<Chemical>This occurred in association with an increase in urinary protein content from 1.8 +/- 1 to 99.0 +/- 61 mg/day (p < 0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, podocalyxin did not change significantly at this time.</Chemical>
<Chemical>By day 11, GLEPP1 protein and mRNA had begun to return towards baseline.</Chemical>

<Chemical>By day 45-126, at a time when glomerular scarring was present, GLEPP1 was absent from glomerulosclerotic areas although the total glomerular content of GLEPP1 was not different from normal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We conclude that GLEPP1 expression, unlike podocalyxin, reflects podocyte injury induced by PAN.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>GLEPP1 expression may be a useful marker of podocyte injury.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ticlopidine-induced aplastic anemia: report of three Chinese patients and review of the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this study, three Chinese patients with ticlopidine-induced aplastic anemia were reported and another 13 patients in the English literature were reviewed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We attempted to find underlying similarities, evaluate the risk factors, and identify appropriate treatment for this complication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All but one of the patients were over 60 years old, and the 6 who died were all older than 65.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Therefore, old age may be a risk factor for developing this complication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Agranulocytosis occurred 3-20 weeks after initiation of ticlopidine, so frequent examination of white cell count during treatment is recommended.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There seemed to be no direct correlation between the dose or duration used and the severity of bone marrow suppression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment for ticlopidine-induced aplastic anemia with colony-stimulating factors seemed to have little effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The fact that 5 of the 6 patients who received concurrent calcium channel blockers died, should alert clinicians to be more cautious when using these two drugs simultaneously.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Facilitation of memory retrieval by pre-test morphine and its state dependency in the step-through type passive avoidance learning test in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amnesia produced by scopolamine and cycloheximide were reversed by morphine given 30 min before the test trial (pre-test), and pre-test morphine also facilitated the memory retrieval in the animals administered naloxone during the training trial.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Similarly, pre-test scopolamine partially reversed the scopolamine-induced amnesia, but not significantly; and pre-test cycloheximide failed to reverse the cycloheximide-induced amnesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that the facilitation of memory retrieval by pre-test morphine might be the direct action of morphine rather than a state dependent effect.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Test conditions influence the response to a drug challenge in rodents.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These studies were conducted to examine the differential response to a drug challenge under varied experimental test conditions routinely employed to study drug-induced behavioral and neurophysiological responses in rodents.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Apomorphine, a nonselective dopamine agonist, was selected due to its biphasic behavioral effects, its ability to induce hypothermia, and to produce distinct changes to dopamine turnover in the rodent brain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>From such experiments there is evidence that characterization and detection of apomorphine-induced activity in rodents critically depends upon the test conditions employed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In rats, detection of apomorphine-induced hyperactivity was facilitated by a period of acclimatization to the test conditions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, test conditions can impact upon other physiological responses to apomorphine such as drug-induced hypothermia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In mice, apomorphine produced qualitatively different responses under novel conditions when compared to those behaviors elicited in the home test cage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Drug-induced gross activity counts were increased in the novel exploratory box only, while measures of stereotypic behavior were similar in both.</Chemical>
<Chemical>By contrast, apomorphine-induced locomotion was more prominent in the novel exploratory box.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dopamine turnover ratios (DOPAC:DA and HVA:DA) were found to be lower in those animals exposed to the exploratory box when compared to their home cage counterparts.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, apomorphine-induced reductions in striatal dopamine turnover were detected in both novel and home cage environments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The implications of these findings are discussed with particular emphasis upon conducting psychopharmacological challenge tests in rodents.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tricuspid valve regurgitation and lithium carbonate toxicity in a newborn infant.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A newborn with massive tricuspid regurgitation, atrial flutter, congestive heart failure, and a high serum lithium level is described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is the first patient to initially manifest tricuspid regurgitation and atrial flutter, and the 11th described patient with cardiac disease among infants exposed to lithium compounds in the first trimester of pregnancy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sixty-three percent of these infants had tricuspid valve involvement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lithium carbonate may be a factor in the increasing incidence of congenital heart disease when taken during early pregnancy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It also causes neurologic depression, cyanosis, and cardiac arrhythmia when consumed prior to delivery.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A 2-year-old child with known neurologic impairment developed a dyskinesia soon after starting phenobarbital therapy for seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Known causes of movement disorders were eliminated after evaluation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>On repeat challenge with phenobarbital, the dyskinesia recurred.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phenobarbital should be added to the list of anticonvulsant drugs that can cause movement disorders.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Acute changes of blood ammonia may predict short-term adverse effects of valproic acid.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Valproic acid (VPA) was given to 24 epileptic patients who were already being treated with other antiepileptic drugs.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>A standardized loading dose of VPA was administered, and venous blood was sampled at 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 hours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ammonia (NH3) was higher in patients who, during continuous therapy, complained of drowsiness (7 patients) than in those who were symptom-free (17 patients), although VPA plasma levels were similar in both groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>By measuring VPA-induced changes of blood NH3 content, it may be possible to identify patients at higher risk of obtundation when VPA is given chronically.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Effects of calcitonin on rat extrapyramidal motor system: behavioral and biochemical data.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The effects of i.v.c. injection of human and salmon calcitonin on biochemical and behavioral parameters related to the extrapyramidal motor system, were investigated in male rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Calcitonin injection resulted in a potentiation of haloperidol-induced catalepsy and a partial prevention of apomorphine-induced hyperactivity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover calcitonin induced a significant decrease in nigral GAD activity but no change in striatal DA and DOPAC concentration or GAD activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results are discussed in view of a primary action of calcitonin on the striatonigral GABAergic pathway mediating the DA-related behavioral messages of striatal origin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Development of isoproterenol-induced cardiac hypertrophy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The development of cardiac hypertrophy was studied in adult female Wistar rats following daily subcutaneous injections of isoproterenol (ISO) (0.3 mg/kg body weight).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A time course was established for the change in tissue mass, RNA and DNA content, as well as hydroxyproline content.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Heart weight increased 44% after 8 days of treatment with a half time of 3.4 days.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ventricular RNA content was elevated 26% after 24 h of a single injection and reached a maximal level following 8 days of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The half time for RNA accumulation was 2.0 days.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The total content of hydroxyproline remained stable during the first 2 days of treatment but increased 46% after 4 days of therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ventricular DNA content was unchanged during the early stage (1-4 days) of hypertrophic growth but increased to a new steady-state level 19% above the controls after 8 days of treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Intraventricular pressures and coronary flow measures were similar for control and experimental animals following 4 days of developed hypertrophy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, dP/dt in the ISO-treated hearts was slightly but significantly (P less than 0.05) elevated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data indicate that the adaptive response to ISO shows an early hypertrophic phase (1-4 days) characterized by a substantial increase in RNA content and cardiac mass in the absence of changes in DNA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, prolonged stimulation (8-12 days) appears to represent a complex integration of both cellular hypertrophy and hyperplasia within the heart.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Co-carcinogenic effect of retinyl acetate on forestomach carcinogenesis of male F344 rats induced with butylated hydroxyanisole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The potential modifying effect of retinyl acetate (RA) on butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA)-induced rat forestomach tumorigenesis was examined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male F344 rats, 5 weeks of age, were maintained on diet containing 1% or 2% BHA by weight and simultaneously on drinking water supplemented with RA at various concentrations (w/v) for 52 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In groups given 2% BHA, although marked hyperplastic changes of the forestomach epithelium were observed in all animals, co-administration of 0.25% RA significantly (P less than 0.05) increased the incidence of forestomach tumors (squamous cell papilloma and carcinoma) to 60% (9/15, 2 rats with carcinoma) from 15% (3/20, one rat with carcinoma) in the group given RA-free water.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In rats given 1% BHA, RA co-administered at a dose of 0.05, 0.1, 0.2 or 0.25% showed a dose-dependent enhancing effect on the development of the BHA-induced epithelial hyperplasia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tumors, all papillomas, were induced in 3 rats (17%) with 0.25% RA and in one rat (10%) with 0.05% RA co-administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RA alone did not induce hyperplastic changes in the forestomach.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings indicate that RA acted as a co-carcinogen in the BHA forestomach carcinogenesis of the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketanserin pretreatment reverses alfentanil-induced muscle rigidity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Systemic pretreatment with ketanserin, a relatively specific type-2 serotonin receptor antagonist, significantly attenuated the muscle rigidity produced in rats by the potent short-acting opiate agonist alfentanil.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Following placement of subcutaneous electrodes in each animal's left gastrocnemius muscle, rigidity was assessed by analyzing root-mean-square electromyographic activity.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Intraperitoneal ketanserin administration at doses of 0.63 and 2.5 mg/kg prevented the alfentanil-induced increase in electromyographic activity compared with animals pretreated with saline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chlordiazepoxide at doses up to 10 mg/kg failed to significantly influence the rigidity produced by alfentanil.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite the absence of rigidity, animals that received ketanserin (greater than 0.31 mg/kg i.p.) followed by alfentanil were motionless, flaccid, and less responsive to external stimuli than were animals receiving alfentanil alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats that received ketanserin and alfentanil exhibited less rearing and exploratory behavior at the end of the 60-min recording period than did animals that received ketanserin alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results, in combination with previous work, suggest that muscle rigidity, a clinically relevant side-effect of parenteral narcotic administration, may be partly mediated via serotonergic pathways.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Pretreatment with type-2 serotonin antagonists may be clinically useful in attenuating opiate-induced rigidity, although further studies will be necessary to assess the interaction of possibly enhanced CNS, cardiovascular, and respiratory depression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Glycopyrronium requirements for antagonism of the muscarinic side effects of edrophonium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have compared, in 60 adult patients, the cardiovascular effects of glycopyrronium 5 micrograms kg-1 and 10 micrograms kg-1 given either simultaneously or 1 min before edrophonium 1 mg kg-1.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Significant differences between the four groups were detected (P less than 0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Both groups receiving 10 micrograms kg-1 showed increases in heart rate of up to 30 beat min-1 (95% confidence limits 28-32 beat min-1).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Use of glycopyrronium 5 micrograms kg-1 provided greater cardiovascular stability and, given 1 min before the edrophonium, was sufficient to minimize early, edrophonium-induced bradycardias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This low dose of glycopyrronium provided good control of oropharyngeal secretions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Involvement of locus coeruleus and noradrenergic neurotransmission in fentanyl-induced muscular rigidity in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Whereas muscular rigidity is a well-known side effect that is associated with high-dose fentanyl anesthesia, a paucity of information exists with regard to its underlying mechanism(s).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We investigated in this study the possible engagement of locus coeruleus of the pons in this phenomenon, using male Sprague-Dawley rats anesthetized with ketamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Under proper control of respiration, body temperature and end-tidal CO2, intravenous administration of fentanyl (50 or 100 micrograms/kg) consistently promoted an increase in electromyographic activity recorded from the gastrocnemius and abdominal rectus muscles.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Such an induced muscular rigidity by the narcotic agent was significantly antagonized or even reduced by prior electrolytic lesions of the locus coeruleus or pretreatment with the alpha-adrenoceptor blocker, prazosin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Microinjection of fentanyl (2.5 micrograms/50 nl) directly into this pontine nucleus, on the other hand, elicited discernible electromyographic excitation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is speculated that the induction of muscular rigidity by fentanyl may involve the coerulospinal noradrenergic fibers to the spinal motoneurons.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cerebral sinus thrombosis as a potential hazard of antifibrinolytic treatment in menorrhagia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We describe a 42-year-old woman who developed superior sagittal and left transverse sinus thrombosis associated with prolonged epsilon-aminocaproic acid therapy for menorrhagia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This antifibrinolytic agent has been used in women with menorrhagia to promote clotting and reduce blood loss.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although increased risk of thromboembolic disease has been reported during treatment with epsilon-aminocaproic acid, cerebral sinus thrombosis has not been previously described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Careful use of epsilon-aminocaproic acid therapy is recommended.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hemorrhagic cystitis complicating bone marrow transplantation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hemorrhagic cystitis is a potentially serious complication of high-dose cyclophosphamide therapy administered before bone marrow transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>As standard practice at our institution, patients who are scheduled to receive a bone marrow transplant are treated prophylactically with forced hydration and bladder irrigation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In an attempt to obviate the inconvenience of bladder irrigation, we conducted a feasibility trial of uroprophylaxis with mesna, which neutralizes the hepatic metabolite of cyclophosphamide that causes hemorrhagic cystitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of 97 patients who received standard prophylaxis, 4 had symptomatic hemorrhagic cystitis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In contrast, two of four consecutive patients who received mesna uroprophylaxis before allogeneic bone marrow transplantation had severe hemorrhagic cystitis for at least 2 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because of this suboptimal result, we resumed the use of bladder irrigation and forced hydration to minimize the risk of hemorrhagic cystitis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Reversal of central benzodiazepine effects by flumazenil after intravenous conscious sedation with diazepam and opioids: report of a double-blind multicenter study. The Flumazenil in Intravenous Conscious Sedation with Diazepam Multicenter Study Group II.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The efficacy and safety of a new benzodiazepine antagonist, flumazenil, were assessed in a double-blind multicenter study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flumazenil (mean dose, 0.76 mg) or placebo (mean dose, 8.9 ml) was administered intravenously to 130 and 67 patients, respectively, who had been given diazepam in conjunction with an opioid (fentanyl, meperidine, or morphine) for the induction and maintenance of intravenous conscious sedation for diagnostic or therapeutic surgical procedures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The group assessable for efficacy comprised 122 patients treated with flumazenil and 64 patients given placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 5 minutes, 80/115 (70%) flumazenil-treated patients, compared with 21/63 (33%) placebo-treated patients, were completely awake and alert, as indicated by a score of 5 on the Observer's Assessment of Alertness/Sedation Scale.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ninety-five percent of patients in each group who attained a score of 5 at the 5-minute assessment showed no loss of alertness throughout the 180-minute assessment period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Flumazenil-treated patients also performed significantly better on the Finger-to-Nose Test and the recall of pictures shown at the 5-minute assessment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flumazenil was well tolerated, with no serious adverse effects reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty-nine (30%) of flumazenil-treated patients, compared with 17 (25%) of placebo-treated patients had one or more drug-related adverse experiences.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The most common adverse effects were nausea and vomiting in the flumazenil group and nausea and injection-site pain in the placebo group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Flumazenil was found to promptly reverse sedation induced by diazepam in the presence of opioids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hepatic adenomas and focal nodular hyperplasia of the liver in young women on oral contraceptives: case reports.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two cases of hepatic adenoma and one of focal nodular hyperplasia presumably associated with the use of oral contraceptives, are reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Special reference is made to their clinical presentation, which may be totally asymptomatic.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Liver-function tests are of little diagnostic value, but valuable information may be obtained from both liver scanning and hepatic angiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Histologic differences and clinical similarities between hepatic adenoma and focal nodular hyperplasia of the liver are discussed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Arterial thromboembolism in patients receiving systemic heparin therapy: a complication associated with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Arterial thromboembolism is a recognized complication of systemic heparin therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Characteristic of the entity is arterial occlusion by platelet-fibrin thrombi with distal ischemia occurring four to twenty days after the initiation of heparin therapy, preceded by profound thrombocytopenia with platelet counts in the range of 30,000 to 40,000 per cubic millimeter.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The clinically apparent occlusion may be preceded by gastrointestinal and musculoskeletal symptoms that appear to be ischemic in origin, and might serve to warn the clinician of these complications.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Previous reports of these phenomena as well as recent studies of the effect of heparin are reviewed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The common factor relating thromboembolism and thrombocytopenia is heparin-induced platelet aggregation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Appropriate treatment consists of discontinuation of heparin, and anticoagulation with sodium warfarin if necessary.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vascular procedures are performed as indicated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Long-term prognosis for transplant-free survivors of paracetamol-induced acute liver failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The prognosis for transplant-free survivors of paracetamol-induced acute liver failure remains unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIM: To examine whether paracetamol-induced acute liver failure increases long-term mortality.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We followed up all transplant-free survivors of paracetamol-induced acute liver injury, hospitalized in a Danish national referral centre during 1984-2004.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We compared age-specific mortality rates from 1 year post-discharge through 2008 between those in whom the liver injury led to an acute liver failure and those in whom it did not.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We included 641 patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>On average, age-specific mortality rates were slightly higher for the 101 patients whose paracetamol-induced liver injury had caused an acute liver failure (adjusted mortality rate ratio = 1.70, 95% CI 1.02-2.85), but the association was age-dependent, and no survivors of acute liver failure died of liver disease, whereas suicides were frequent in both groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These observations speak against long-term effects of acute liver failure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>More likely, the elevated mortality rate ratio resulted from incomplete adjustment for the greater prevalence of substance abuse among survivors of acute liver failure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Paracetamol-induced acute liver failure did not affect long-term mortality.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical follow-up may be justified by the cause of the liver failure, but not by the liver failure itself.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serotonin 6 receptor gene is associated with methamphetamine-induced psychosis in a Japanese population.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Altered serotonergic neural transmission is hypothesized to be a susceptibility factor for psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The serotonin 6 (5-HT6) receptor is therapeutically targeted by several second generation antipsychotics, such as clozapine and olanzapine, and d-amphetamine-induced hyperactivity in rats is corrected with the use of a selective 5-HT6 receptor antagonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, the disrupted prepulse inhibition induced by d-amphetamine or phencyclidine was restored by 5-HT6 receptor antagonist in an animal study using rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These animal models were considered to reflect the positive symptoms of schizophrenia, and the above evidence suggests that altered 5-HT6 receptors are involved in the pathophysiology of psychotic disorders.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The symptoms of methamphetamine (METH)-induced psychosis are similar to those of paranoid type schizophrenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore, we conducted an analysis of the association of the 5-HT6 gene (HTR6) with METH-induced psychosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Using five tagging SNPs (rs6693503, rs1805054, rs4912138, rs3790757 and rs9659997), we conducted a genetic association analysis of case-control samples (197 METH-induced psychosis patients and 337 controls) in the Japanese population.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The age and sex of the control subjects did not differ from those of the methamphetamine dependence patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: rs6693503 was associated with METH-induced psychosis patients in the allele/genotype-wise analysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, this association remained significant after Bonferroni correction.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In the haplotype-wise analysis, we detected an association between two markers (rs6693503 and rs1805054) and three markers (rs6693503, rs1805054 and rs4912138) in HTR6 and METH-induced psychosis patients, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>HTR6 may play an important role in the pathophysiology of METH-induced psychosis in the Japanese population.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of increasing intraperitoneal infusion rates on bupropion hydrochloride-induced seizures in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is not known if there is a relationship between input rate and incidence of bupropion-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is important, since different controlled release formulations of bupropion release the active drug at different rates.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We investigated the effect of varying the intraperitoneal infusion rates of bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg, a known convulsive dose 50 (CD50), on the incidence and severity of bupropion-induced convulsions in the Swiss albino mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A total of 69 mice, approximately 7 weeks of age, and weighing 21.0 to 29.1 g were randomly assigned to bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg treatment by intraperitoneal (IP) administration in 7 groups (9 to 10 animals per group).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Bupropion HCl was infused through a surgically implanted IP dosing catheter with infusions in each group of 0 min, 15 min, 30 min, 60 min, 90 min, 120 min, and 240 min.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The number, time of onset, duration and the intensity of the convulsions or absence of convulsions were recorded.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results showed that IP administration of bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg by bolus injection induced convulsions in 6 out of 10 mice (60% of convulsing mice) in group 1.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Logistic regression analysis revealed that infusion time was significant (p = 0.0004; odds ratio = 0.974) and increasing the IP infusion time of bupropion HCl 120 mg/kg was associated with a 91% reduced odds of convulsions at infusion times of 15 to 90 min compared to bolus injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further increase in infusion time resulted in further reduction in the odds of convulsions to 99.8% reduction at 240 min. CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In conclusion, the demonstration of an inverse relationship between infusion time of a fixed and convulsive dose of bupropion and the risk of convulsions in a prospective study is novel.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Detailed spectral profile analysis of penicillin-induced epileptiform activity in anesthetized rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Penicillin model is a widely used experimental model for epilepsy research.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study we aimed to portray a detailed spectral analysis of penicillin-induced epileptiform activity in comparison with basal brain activity in anesthetized Wistar rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male Wistar rats were anesthetized with i.p. urethane and connected to an electrocorticogram setup.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After a short period of basal activity recording, epileptic focus was induced by injecting 400IU/2 microl penicillin-G potassium into the left lateral ventricle while the cortical activity was continuously recorded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Basal activity, latent period and the penicillin-induced epileptiform activity periods were then analyzed using both conventional methods and spectral analysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Spectral analyses were conducted by dividing the whole spectrum into different frequency bands including delta, theta (slow and fast), alpha-sigma, beta (1 and 2) and gamma (1 and 2) bands.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results show that the most affected frequency bands were delta, theta, beta-2 and gamma-2 bands during the epileptiform activity and there were marked differences in terms of spectral densities between three investigated episodes (basal activity, latent period and epileptiform activity).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results may help to analyze novel data obtained using similar experimental models and the simple analysis method described here can be used in similar studies to investigate the basic neuronal mechanism of this or other types of experimental epilepsies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>High dose dexmedetomidine as the sole sedative for pediatric MRI.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This large-scale retrospective review evaluates the sedation profile of dexmedetomidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIM: To determine the hemodynamic responses, efficacy and adverse events associated with the use of high dose dexmedetomidine as the sole sedative for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) studies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dexmedetomidine has been used at our institution since 2005 to provide sedation for pediatric radiological imaging studies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Over time, an effective protocol utilizing high dose dexmedetomidine as the sole sedative agent has evolved.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS/MATERIALS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>As part of the ongoing Quality Assurance process, data on all sedations are reviewed monthly and protocols modified as needed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Data were analyzed from all 747 consecutive patients who received dexmedetomidine for MRI sedation from April 2005 to April 2007.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Since 2005, the 10-min loading dose of our dexmedetomidine protocol increased from 2 to 3 microg.kg(-1), and the infusion rate increased from 1 to 1.5 to 2 microg.kg(-1).h(-1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The current sedation protocol progressively increased the rate of successful sedation (able to complete the imaging study) when using dexmedetomidine alone from 91.8% to 97.6% (P = 0.009), reducing the requirement for adjuvant pentobarbital in the event of sedation failure with dexmedetomidine alone and decreased the mean recovery time by 10 min (P < 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although dexmedetomidine sedation was associated with a 16% incidence of bradycardia, all concomitant mean arterial blood pressures were within 20% of age-adjusted normal range and oxygen saturations were 95% or higher.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION: Dexmedetomidine in high doses provides adequate sedation for pediatric MRI studies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>While use of high dose dexmedetomidine is associated with decreases in heart rate and blood pressure outside the established 'awake' norms, this deviation is generally within 20% of norms, and is not associated with adverse sequelae.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dexmedetomidine is useful as the sole sedative for pediatric MRI.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methamphetamine causes alterations in the MAP kinase-related pathways in the brains of mice that display increased aggressiveness.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Aggressive behaviors have been reported in patients who suffer from some psychiatric disorders, and are common in methamphetamine (METH) abusers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Herein, we report that multiple (but not single) injections of METH significantly increased aggressiveness in male CD-1 mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This increase in aggressiveness was not secondary to METH-induced hyperactivity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Analysis of protein expression using antibody microarrays and Western blotting revealed differential changes in MAP kinase-related pathways after multiple and single METH injections.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were statistically significant (p<0.05) decreases in MEK1, Erk2p, GSK3alpha, 14-3-3e, and MEK7 in the striata of mice after multiple injections of METH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MEK1 was significantly decreased also after a single injection of METH, but to a much lesser degree than after multiple injections of METH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the frontal cortex, there was a statistically significant decrease in GSK3alpha after multiple (but not single) injections of METH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that alterations in MAP kinase-related pathways in the prefronto-striatal circuitries might be involved in the manifestation of aggressive behaviors in mice.</Chemical>
