<Chemical>Assessment of the onset and persistence of amnesia during procedural sedation with propofol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>

<Chemical>To assess patients' ability to repeat and recall words presented to them while undergoing procedural sedation with propofol, and correlate their recall with their level of awareness as measured by bispectral index (BIS) monitoring.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was a prospective, single-intervention study of consenting adult patients undergoing procedural sedation with propofol between December 28, 2002, and October 31, 2003.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BIS monitoring was initiated starting 3 minutes before the procedure and continuing until the patient had regained baseline mental status.</Chemical>

<Chemical>At 1-minute intervals during the procedural sedation, until the patient regained baseline mental status at the end of the procedure, a word from a standardized list was read aloud, and the patient was asked to immediately repeat the word to the investigator.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The BIS score at the time the word was read and the patient's ability to repeat the word were recorded.</Chemical>

<Chemical>After the procedure, the patient was asked to state all of the words from the list that he or she could recall, and to identify the last word recalled from prior to the start of the procedure and the first word recalled from after the procedure was completed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Seventy-five consenting patients were enrolled; one patient was excluded from data analysis for a protocol violation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No serious adverse events were noted during the procedural sedations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean (+/-standard deviation) time of data collection was 16.4 minutes (+/-7.1; range 5 to 34 minutes).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean initial (preprocedure)</Chemical>
<Chemical>BIS score was 97.1 (+/-2.3; range 92 to 99).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean lowest BIS score occurring during these procedural sedations was 66.9 (+/-14.4; range 33 to 91).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean lowest BIS score corresponding to the ability of the patient to immediately repeat words read from the list was 77.1 (95% CI = 74.3 to 80.0).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean highest BIS score corresponding to the inability to repeat words was 81.5 (95% CI = 78.1 to 84.8).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean BIS score corresponding to the last word recalled from prior to the initiation of the sedation was 96.7 (+/-2.4; range 84 to 98).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean BIS score corresponding to the first word recalled after the procedure was completed was 91.2 (95% CI = 88.1 to 94.3).</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients recalled at least one word that had been read to them during the protocol.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean lowest BIS score for any recalled word was 91.5 (+/-11.1; range 79 to 98), and no words were recalled when the corresponding BIS score was less than 90.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>There is a range of BIS scores during which sedated patients are able to repeat words read to them but are not able to subsequently recall these words.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Furthermore, patients had no recall of words repeated prior to procedural sedation in BIS ranges associated with recall after procedural sedation, suggestive of retrograde amnesia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Assessment of perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention in New Hampshire delivery hospitals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate current performance on recommended perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention practices in New Hampshire.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Data were extracted from 2021 paired mother-infant records for the year 2000 birth cohort in New Hampshire's 25 delivery hospitals.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Assessment was done on the following: prenatal screening for hepatitis B and rubella, administration of the hepatitis B vaccine birth dose to all infants, administration of hepatitis B immune globulin to infants who were born to hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers, rubella immunity, and administration of in-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine to rubella nonimmune women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prenatal screening rates for hepatitis B (98.8%) and rubella (99.4%) were high.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hepatitis B vaccine birth dose was administered to 76.2% of all infants.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All infants who were born to hepatitis B surface antigen-positive mothers also received hepatitis B immune globulin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Multivariate logistic regression showed that the month of delivery and infant birth weight were independent predictors of hepatitis B vaccination.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The proportion of infants who were vaccinated in January and February 2000 (48.5% and 67.5%, respectively) was less than any other months, whereas the proportion who were vaccinated in December 2000 (88.2%) was the highest.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Women who were born between 1971 and 1975 had the highest rate of rubella nonimmunity (9.5%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In-hospital postpartum rubella vaccine administration was documented for 75.6% of nonimmune women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study documents good compliance in New Hampshire's birthing hospitals with national guidelines for perinatal hepatitis B and rubella prevention and highlights potential areas for improvement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Expression of p300 protects cardiac myocytes from apoptosis in vivo.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Doxorubicin is an anti-tumor agent that represses cardiac-specific gene expression and induces myocardial cell apoptosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Doxorubicin depletes cardiac p300, a transcriptional coactivator that is required for the maintenance of the differentiated phenotype of cardiac myocytes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the role of p300 in protection against doxorubicin-induced apoptosis is unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Transgenic mice overexpressing p300 in the heart and wild-type mice were subjected to doxorubicin treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with wild-type mice, transgenic mice exhibited higher survival rate as well as more preserved left ventricular function and cardiac expression of alpha-sarcomeric actin.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Doxorubicin induced myocardial cell apoptosis in wild-type mice but not in transgenic mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Expression of p300 increased the cardiac level of bcl-2 and mdm-2, but not that of p53 or other members of the bcl-2 family.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These findings demonstrate that overexpression of p300 protects cardiac myocytes from doxorubicin-induced apoptosis and reduces the extent of acute heart failure in adult mice in vivo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mitochondrial DNA and its respiratory chain products are defective in doxorubicin nephrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Doxorubicin induces a self-perpetuating nephropathy characterized by early glomerular and late-onset tubular lesions in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We investigated the potential role of mitochondrial injury in the onset of these lesions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Rats were treated with intravenous doxorubicin (1 mg kg(-1) week(-1)) for 7 weeks and were sacrificed either 1 week ('short-term') or 30 weeks ('long-term') following the last dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Additional rats received a single dose either 6 days or 2 h prior to euthanasia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All rats were killed at 48 weeks of age.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Glomerular and tubular injury was monitored and correlated to the activity or expression of respiratory chain components.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Finally, we quantified both nuclear and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) as well as superoxide production and the 4834 base pair 'common' mtDNA deletion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The 'long-term' group had significant glomerular and tubular lesions, depressed activities of mtDNA-encoded NADH dehydrogenase and cytochrome-c oxidase (COX) and increased citrate synthase activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, expression of the mtDNA-encoded COX subunit I was reduced and mtDNA levels were decreased.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 'short-term' rats, there were fewer tubular lesions, but similar numbers of glomerular lesions activity.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Among all animals, glomerular and tubular injury were inversely correlated with mtDNA levels, mtDNA-encoded respiratory chain activities and with the expression of the mtDNA-encoded respiratory chain subunit COX-I. Injury was positively correlated with superoxide production and the activities of nucleus-encoded mitochondrial or cytoplasmic enzymes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Kidneys from the 'long-term' group showed more mtDNA deletions than in 'short-term' animals and these were not observed in the other groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>These results suggest an important role for quantitative and qualitative mtDNA alterations through the reduction of mtDNA-encoded respiratory chain function and induction of superoxide in doxorubicin-induced renal lesions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amphotericin B-induced seizures in a patient with AIDS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of multiple episodes of seizure activity in an AIDS patent following amphotericin B infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE SUMMARY:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A 46-year-old African-American man experienced recurrent grand mal seizures during intravenous infusion of amphotericin B, then petit mal seizures as the infusion was stopped and the drug concentrations decreased with time.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patients concurrent medications included didanosine, hydroxyzine, promethazine, hydrocortisone, and prochlorperazine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite administration of phenytoin and lorazepam, the seizures persisted and occurred only during amphotercin B administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>AIDS and cryptococcal meningitis, both of which the patient had, can potentially cause seizures.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient had a history of alcohol abuse; alcohol intake as well as withdrawal can also cause seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Didanosine also has a potential for inducing seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, these other potential causes of seizure were ruled out.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The time course of events suggested that amphotericin B was the cause of the seizures in this AIDS patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Amphotericin B seems to be the probable cause of the seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To date, only three cases of seizures associated with amphotericin B have been reported in the literature, but healthcare providers should be aware of the potential for this rare adverse effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therapeutic drug monitoring of tobramycin: once-daily versus twice-daily dosage schedules.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the effect of dosage regimen (once-daily vs. twice-daily) of tobramicyn on steady-state serum concentrations and toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients undergoing treatment with i.v. tobramycin (4 mg/kg/day) were randomised to two groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Group OD (n = 22) received a once-daily dose of tobramycin and group TD (n = 21) received the same dose divided into two doses daily.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tobramycin serum concentrations (peak and trough) were measured by enzyme multiplied immunoassay.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The renal and auditory functions of the patients were monitored before, during and immediately after treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The two groups were comparable with respect to sex, age, body weight and renal function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No statistically significant differences were found in mean daily dose, duration of treatment, or cumulative dose.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Trough concentrations were < 2 g/ml in the two groups (100%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Peak concentrations were > 6 microg/ml in 100% of the OD group and in 67% of the TD group (P< 0.01).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mean peak concentrations were markedly different: 11.00+/-2.89 microg/ml in OD vs. 6.53+/-1.45 microg/ml in TD (P< 0.01).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The pharmacokinetics parameters were: Ke, (0.15+/-0.03/h in OD vs. 0.24+/-0.06/h in TD), t1/2, (4.95+/-1.41 h in OD vs. 3.07+/-0.71 h in TD),</Chemical>
<Chemical>Vd (0.35+/-0.11 l/kg in OD vs. 0.33+/-0.09 l/kg in TD), Cl (0.86+/-0.29 ml/min/kg in OD vs. 1.28+/-0.33 ml/min/kg in TD).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Increased serum creatinine was observed in 73% of patients in OD versus 57% of patients in TD, without evidence of nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In TD group, three patients developed decreased auditory function, of which one presented with an auditory loss of -30 dB, whereas in the OD group only one patient presented decreased auditory function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This small study suggests that a once-daily dosing regimen of tobramycin is at least as effective as and is no more and possibly less toxic than the twice-daily regimen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using a single-dose therapy, peak concentration determination is not necessary, only trough samples should be monitored to ensure levels below 2 microg/ml.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Chronic effects of a novel synthetic anthracycline derivative (SM-5887) on normal heart and doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy in beagle dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study was designed to investigate the chronic cardiotoxic potential of SM-5887 and a possible deteriorating effect of SM-5887 on low-grade cardiotoxicity pre-induced by doxorubicin in beagle dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the chronic treatment, beagle dogs of each sex were given intravenously once every 3 weeks, either a sublethal dose of doxorubicin (1.5 mg/kg) or SM-5887 (2.5 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The experiment was terminated 3 weeks after the ninth dosing.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Animals which received over six courses of doxorubicin demonstrated the electrocardiogram (ECG) changes, decrease of blood pressure and high-grade histopathological cardiomyopathy, while animals which were terminally sacrificed after the SM-5887 administration did not show any changes in ECG, blood pressure and histopathological examinations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To examine a possibly deteriorating cardiotoxic effect of SM-5887, low-grade cardiomyopathy was induced in dogs by four courses of doxorubicin (1.5 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nine weeks after pre-treatment, dogs were given four courses of either doxorubicin (1.5 mg/kg) or SM-5887 (2.5 mg/kg) once every 3 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The low-grade cardiotoxic changes were enhanced by the additional doxorubicin treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the contrary, the SM-5887 treatment did not progress the grade of cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, SM-5887 does not have any potential of chronic cardiotoxicity and deteriorating effect on doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity in dogs.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Posteroventral medial pallidotomy in advanced Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Posteroventral medial pallidotomy sometimes produces striking improvement in patients with advanced Parkinson's disease, but the studies to date have involved small numbers of patients and short-term follow-up.</Chemical>

<Chemical>METHODS: Forty patients with Parkinson's disease underwent serial, detailed assessments both after drug withdrawal ("off" period) and while taking their optimal medical regimens ("on" period).</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients were examined preoperatively and 39 were examined at six months; 27 of the patients were also examined at one year, and 11 at two years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The percent improvements at six months were as follows: off-period score for overall motor function, 28 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 19 to 38 percent), with most of the improvement in the contralateral limbs; off-period score for activities of daily living, 29 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 19 to 39 percent); on-period score for contralateral dyskinesias, 82 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 72 to 91 percent); and on-period score for ipsilateral dyskinesias, 44 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 29 to 59 percent).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The improvements in dyskinesias and the total scores for off-period parkinsonism, contralateral bradykinesia, and rigidity were sustained in the 11 patients examined at two years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The improvement in ipsilateral dyskinesias was lost after one year, and the improvements in postural stability and gait lasted only three to six months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Approximately half the patients who had been dependent on assistance in activities of daily living in the off period before surgery became independent after surgery.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The complications of surgery were generally well tolerated, and there were no significant changes in the use of medication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In late-stage Parkinson's disease, pallidotomy significantly reduces levodopa-induced dyskinesias and off-period disability.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Much of the benefit is sustained at two years, although some improvements, such as those on the ipsilateral side and in axial symptoms, wane within the first year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The on-period symptoms that are resistant to dopaminergic therapy do not respond to pallidotomy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neuropeptide-Y immunoreactivity in the pilocarpine model of temporal lobe epilepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neuropeptide-Y (NPY) is expressed by granule cells and mossy fibres of the hippocampal dentate gyrus during experimental temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE).</Chemical>
<Chemical>This expression may represent an endogenous damping mechanism since NPY has been shown to block seizure-like events following high-frequency stimulation in hippocampal slices.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The pilocarpine (PILO) model of epilepsy is characterized by an acute period of status epilepticus followed by spontaneous recurrent seizures and related brain damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report peroxidase-antiperoxidase immunostaining for NPY in several brain regions in this model.</Chemical>

<Chemical>PILO-injected animals exhibited NPY immunoreactivity in the region of the mossy fibre terminals, in the dentate gyrus inner molecular layer and, in a few cases, within presumed granule cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>NPY immunoreactivity was also dramatically changed in the entorhinal cortex, amygdala and sensorimotor areas.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition, PILO injected animals exhibited a reduction in the number of NPY-immunoreactive interneurons compared with controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results demonstrate that changes in NPY expression, including expression in the granule cells and mossy fibres and the loss of vulnerable NPY neurons, are present in the PILO model of TLE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the significance of this changed synthesis of NPY remains to be determined.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effect of myopic excimer laser photorefractive keratectomy on the electrophysiologic function of the retina and optic nerve.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To assess by electrophysiologic testing the effect of photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) on the retina and optic nerve.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Eye Clinic, S. Salvatore Hospital, L'Aquila University, Italy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Standard pattern electroretinograms (P-ERGs) and standard pattern visual evoked potentials (P-VEPs) were done in 25 eyes of 25 patients who had myopic PRK for an attempted correction between 5.00 and 15.00 diopters (D) (mean 8.00 D).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Testing was done preoperatively and 3, 6, 12, and 18 months postoperatively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The contralateral eyes served as controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>During the follow-up, 3 patients (12%) developed steroid-induced elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) that resolved after corticosteroid therapy was discontinued.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>No statistically significant differences were seen between treated and control eyes nor between treated eyes preoperatively and postoperatively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myopic excimer laser PRK did not seem to affect the posterior segment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The transient steroid-induced IOP rise did not seem to cause functional impairment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Relation of perfusion defects observed with myocardial contrast echocardiography to the severity of coronary stenosis: correlation with thallium-201 single-photon emission tomography.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>It has been previously shown that myocardial contrast echocardiography is a valuable technique for delineating regions of myocardial underperfusion secondary to coronary occlusion and to critical coronary stenoses in the presence of hyperemic stimulation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The aim of this study was to determine whether myocardial contrast echocardiography performed with a stable solution of sonicated albumin could detect regions of myocardial underperfusion resulting from various degrees of coronary stenosis.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During a transient (20-s) coronary occlusion, a perfusion defect was observed with contrast echocardiography in 14 of the 15 dogs in which the occlusion was produced.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The perfusion defect correlated significantly with the anatomic area at risk (r = 0.74; p less than 0.002).</Chemical>
<Chemical>During dipyridamole-induced hyperemia, 12 of the 16 dogs with a partial coronary stenosis had a visible area of hypoperfusion by contrast echocardiography.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The four dogs without a perfusion defect had a stenosis that resulted in a mild (0% to 50%) reduction in dipyridamole-induced hyperemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The size of the perfusion defect during stenosis correlated significantly with the anatomic area at risk (r = 0.61; p = 0.02).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Thallium-201 SPECT demonstrated a perfusion defect in all 14 dogs analyzed during dipyridamole-induced hyperemia; the size of the perfusion defect correlated with the anatomic area at risk (r = 0.58; p less than 0.03) and with the perfusion defect by contrast echocardiography (r = 0.58; p less than 0.03).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, myocardial contrast echocardiography can be used to visualize and quantitate the amount of jeopardized myocardium during moderate to severe degrees of coronary stenosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results obtained show a correlation with the anatomic area at risk similar to that obtained with thallium-201 SPECT.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Potential deleterious effect of furosemide in radiocontrast nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of the study was to determine the efficacy of furosemide in addition to intravenous fluids in the prevention of radiocontrast nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>18 patients, referred to a radiocontrast study, considered at risk because of preexisting renal insufficiency, were enrolled in a prospective, randomized, controlled trial, performed at the secondary care center of a 1,100-bed private university hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition to fluids, the treatment group received furosemide (mean dose 110 mg) intravenously 30 min prior to the injection of contrast material.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The control group received fluids (mean 3 liters).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Radiological studies were mostly angiographies performed with both ionic and non-ionic contrast material, at an average dose of 245 ml.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Renal function significantly deteriorated in the group pretreated with furosemide (p < 0.005 by ANOVA), with a rise in serum creatinine from 145 +/- 13 to 182 +/- 16 mumol/l at 24 h, while no change occurred in the control group (from 141 +/- 6 to 142 +/- 7 mumol/l).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Renal failure was associated with weight loss in the furosemide-treated group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furosemide may be deleterious in the prevention of radiocontrast nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A case of lithium-induced diabetes insipidus is reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At necropsy microscopy shoed unique and extensive damage to cells lining the distal nephron.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is suggested that these changes represent a specific toxic effect of lithium, reported here for the first time in man.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Etiologic factors in the pathogenesis of liver tumors associated with oral contraceptives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Within the last several years, previously rare liver tumors have been seen in young women using oral contraceptive steroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The Registry for Liver Tumors Associated with Oral Contraceptives at the University of California, Irvine, has clearly identified 27 cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The recent literature contains 44 case reports.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Common to these 71 cases has been a histopathologic diagnosis of focal nodular hyperplasia, adenoma, hamartoma, and hepatoma.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Significant statistical etiologic factors include prolonged uninterrupted usage of oral contraceptive steroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Eight deaths and liver rupture in 18 patients attest to the seriousness of this new potentially lethal adverse phenomenon.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Graft-versus-host disease prophylaxis with everolimus and tacrolimus is associated with a high incidence of sinusoidal obstruction syndrome and microangiopathy: results of the EVTAC trial.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A calcineurin inhibitor combined with methotrexate is the standard prophylaxis for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Everolimus, a derivative of sirolimus, seems to mediate antileukemia effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report on a combination of everolimus and tacrolimus in 24 patients (median age, 62 years) with either myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS; n = 17) or acute myeloid leukemia (AML; n = 7) undergoing intensive conditioning followed by HSCT from related (n = 4) or unrelated (n = 20) donors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All patients engrafted, and only 1 patient experienced grade IV mucositis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nine patients (37%) developed acute grade II-IV GVHD, and 11 of 17 evaluable patients (64%) developed chronic extensive GVHD.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Transplantation-associated microangiopathy (TMA) occurred in 7 patients (29%), with 2 cases of acute renal failure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The study was terminated prematurely because an additional 6 patients (25%) developed sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (SOS), which was fatal in 2 cases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>With a median follow-up of 26 months, the 2-year overall survival rate was 47%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although this new combination appears to be effective as a prophylactic regimen for acute GVHD, the incidence of TMA and SOS is considerably higher than seen with other regimens.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effect of some convulsants on the protective activity of loreclezole and its combinations with valproate or clonazepam in amygdala-kindled rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Loreclezole (5 mg/kg) exerted a significant protective action in amygdala-kindled rats, reducing both seizure and afterdischarge durations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The combinations of loreclezole (2.5 mg/kg) with valproate, clonazepam, or carbamazepine (applied at their subprotective doses) also exhibited antiseizure effect in this test.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, only two first combinations occurred to be of pharmacodynamic nature.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Among several chemoconvulsants, bicuculline, N-methyl-D-aspartic acid and BAY k-8644 (the opener of L-type calcium channels) reversed the protective activity of loreclezole alone and its combination with valproate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the other hand, bicuculline, aminophylline and BAY k-8644 inhibited the anticonvulsive action of loreclezole combined with clonazepam.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results support the hypothesis that the protective activity of loreclezole and its combinations with other antiepileptics may involve potentiation of GABAergic neurotransmission and blockade of L-type of calcium channels.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Acute liver failure with concurrent bupropion and carbimazole therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of fatal liver failure possibly associated with concurrent use of bupropion and carbimazole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE SUMMARY:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 41-year-old Chinese man with a history of hyperthyroidism had been treated with carbimazole and propranolol for the past 5 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>He received a 10-day course of bupropion as an aid for smoking cessation 10 weeks prior to presentation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>He developed acute liver failure with rapid deterioration of renal function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Liver biopsy showed evidence of nonspecific drug-induced acute liver injury.</Chemical>
<Chemical>His condition was further complicated by sepsis and coagulopathy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Death resulted 19 days after the onset of symptoms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The likelihood that bupropion induced hepatotoxicity in our patient was possible, based on the Naranjo probability scale.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although there is increasing evidence of hepatotoxicity induced by bupropion, this is the first case of fatality that could have resulted from acute liver failure in a patient receiving bupropion while on concomitant treatment with carbimazole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Clinicians should be aware of the possibility of acute liver insult induced by bupropion given concurrently with other hepatotoxic drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Long term hormone therapy for perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Hormone therapy (HT) is widely used for controlling menopausal symptoms and has also been used for the management and prevention of cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis and dementia in older women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This is an updated version of the original Cochrane review first published in 2005.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To assess the effect of long-term HT on mortality, cardiovascular outcomes, cancer, gallbladder disease, cognition, fractures and quality of life.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SEARCH STRATEGY:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We searched the following databases to November 2007: Trials Register of the Cochrane Menstrual Disorders and Subfertility Group, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, MEDLINE, EMBASE, Biological Abstracts.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Also relevant non-indexed journals and conference abstracts.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SELECTION CRITERIA:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Randomised double-blind trials of HT versus placebo, taken for at least one year by perimenopausal or postmenopausal women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>HT included oestrogens, with or without progestogens, via oral, transdermal, subcutaneous or transnasal routes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS: Two authors independently assessed trial quality and extracted data.</Chemical>
<Chemical>MAIN RESULTS: Nineteen trials involving 41,904 women were included.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In relatively healthy women, combined continuous HT significantly increased the risk of venous thrombo-embolism or coronary event (after one year's use), stroke (after three years), breast cancer and gallbladder disease.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Long-term oestrogen-only HT significantly increased the risk of venous thrombo-embolism, stroke and gallbladder disease (after one to two years, three years and seven years' use respectively), but did not significantly increase the risk of breast cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The only statistically significant benefits of HT were a decreased incidence of fractures and (for combined HT) colon cancer, with long-term use.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Among women aged over 65 who were relatively healthy (i.e. generally fit, without overt disease) and taking continuous combined HT, there was a statistically significant increase in the incidence of dementia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Among women with cardiovascular disease, long-term use of combined continuous HT significantly increased the risk of venous thrombo-embolism.</Chemical>

<Chemical>One trial analysed subgroups of 2839 relatively healthy 50 to 59 year old women taking combined continuous HT and 1637 taking oestrogen-only HT, versus similar-sized placebo groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The only significantly increased risk reported was for venous thrombo-embolism in women taking combined continuous HT: their absolute risk remained low, at less than 1/500.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, this study was not powered to detect differences between groups of younger women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>AUTHORS' CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>HT is not indicated for the routine management of chronic disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We need more evidence on the safety of HT for menopausal symptom control, though short-term use appears to be relatively safe for healthy younger women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Passage of mannitol into the brain around gliomas: a potential cause of rebound phenomenon. A study on 21 patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIM:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Widespread use of mannitol to reduce brain edema and lower elevated ICP in brain tumor patients continues to be afflicted by the so-called rebound phenomenon.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Leakage of mannitol into the brain parenchyma through an altered BBB and secondary reversal of osmotic gradient is considered the major cause of rebound .</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This has only been demonstrated experimentally in animals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>As a contribution to this issue we decided to research the possible passage of mannitol into the brain after administration to 21 brain tumor patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mannitol (18% solution; 1 g/kg) was administered as a bolus to patients (ten had malignant glioma, seven brain metastases and four meningioma) about 30 minutes before craniotomy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During resection, a sample of the surrounding edematous white matter was taken at the same time as a 10 ml venous blood sample.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mannitol concentrations were measured in plasma and white matter by a modified version of the enzyme assay of Blonquist et al. RESULTS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In most glioma patients, mannitol concentrations in white matter were 2 to 6 times higher than in plasma (mean 3.5 times).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In meningioma and metastases patients plasma concentrations of mannitol were higher than white matter concentrations except in three cases with infiltration by neoplastic cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The results of our study show that even after a single bolus, mannitol may leak through the altered BBB near gliomas, reversing the initial plasma-to-blood osmotic gradient, aggravating peritumoral edema and promoting rebound of ICP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Can lidocaine reduce succinylcholine induced postoperative myalgia?</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study was undertaken to determine the effect of lidocaine pretreatment on reduction of succinylcholine-induced myalgia in patients undergoing general anesthesia for gynecological surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One hundred and thirty-five patients were assigned to one of three groups in a prospective, double blind, randomized manner.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Group PS, the control group, received normal saline and succinylcholine 1.5 mg x kg(-1); Group LS, lidocaine 1.5 mg x kg(-1) and succinylcholine 1.5 mg x kg(-1); Group PR, normal saline and rocuronium 0.6 mg x kg(-1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Morphine 0.1 mg x kg(-1) iv was given for premedication and all patients were monitored with a noninvasive blood pressure monitor, ECG and pulse oximetry.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anesthesia was induced with 5 mg.kg(-1) thiopental iv. followed by succinylcholine (Group PS, LS) or rocuronium (Group PR) for tracheal intubation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Following administration of these agents, the presence, and degree of fasciculation were assessed visually on a four point scale by one investigator who was blinded to the drug administered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The blood pressure and heart rate of each patient were monitored on nine occasions.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Twenty-four hours later, any myalgia experienced was assessed according to a structured questionaire and graded by a four point scale by one investigator blinded to the intraoperative management.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The results indicate that muscle fasciculation was not found in Group PR while the patients in Group LS had a lower incidence of muscle fasciculation than those in Group PS (p < 0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>At 24 h, the incidence of myalgia was higher in Group PS than in Group LS and PR (p < 0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>A correlation was not found between the incidence of myalgia and the occurrence of muscle fasciculation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The changes in systolic and diastolic blood pressure and heart rate were not significant among the three groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In conclusion, where succinylcholine is used, lidocaine is proven to be the useful pretreatment agent for the reduction of postoperative myalgia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Open-label assessment of levofloxacin for the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis in adults.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To evaluate the efficacy and safety of levofloxacin (500 mg orally once daily for 10 to 14 days) in treating adult outpatients with acute bacterial sinusitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A total of 329 patients enrolled in the study at 24 centers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients had a pre-therapy Gram's stain and culture of sinus exudate obtained by antral puncture or nasal endoscopy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Clinical response was assessed on the basis of signs and symptoms and sinus radiograph or computed tomography results.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Microbiologic cure rates were determined on the basis of presumed plus documented eradication of the pre-therapy pathogen(s).</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The most common pathogens were Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Moraxella catarrhalis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of 300 clinically evaluable patients, 175 (58%) were cured and 90 (30%) were improved at the post-therapy evaluation, resulting in a clinical success rate of 88%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thirty-five patients (12%) clinically failed treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The microbiologic eradication rate (presumed plus documented) among 138 microbiologically evaluable patients was 92%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Microbiologic eradication rates (presumed plus documented) of the most common pathogens ranged from 93% (M. catarrhalis) to 100% (S. pneumoniae) at the post-therapy visit.</Chemical>

<Chemical>All but one of the 265 patients who were cured or improved at post-therapy returned for a long-term follow-up visit; 243 (92%) remained well 4 to 6 weeks after therapy; and 21 (8%) had a relapse of symptoms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Adverse events considered to be related to levofloxacin administration were reported by 29 patients (9%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The most common drug-related adverse events were diarrhea, flatulence, and nausea; most adverse events were mild to moderate in severity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results of this study indicate that levofloxacin 500 mg once daily is an effective and safe treatment for acute bacterial sinusitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical evaluation on combined administration of oral prostacyclin analogue beraprost and phosphodiesterase inhibitor cilostazol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among various oral antiplatelets, a combination of a novel prostacyclin analogue beraprost (BPT) and a potent phosphodiesterase inhibitor cilostazol (CLZ) may result in untoward clinical effects due to possible synergistic elevation of intracellular cAMP (cyclic adenosine 3',5'-monophosphate).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thereby, a clinical study of the combined administration of the two agents was attempted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twelve healthy volunteers were assigned to take BPT/CLZ in the following schedule; BPT: 40 micrograms at day 1 and 120 micrograms t.i.d.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>from day 7 to 14, CLZ: 200 mg t.i.d.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>from day 3 to 14.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At various time intervals, physical examination and blood collection for ex vivo platelet aggregation and determination of intraplatelet cAMP were performed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Throughout the observation period, no significant alteration in vital signs was observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Seven out of 12 subjects experienced headache of a short duration accompanying facial flush in one and nausea in one, especially after ingestion of CLZ.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All of these symptoms, probably caused by the vasodilating effect of the two agents, were of mild degree and no special treatment was required.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Intraplatelet cAMP content was gradually but significantly increased to 9.84 +/- 4.59 pmol per 10(9) platelets at day 14 in comparison with the initial value (6.87 +/- 2.25 pmol).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The platelet aggregability was significantly suppressed at various time intervals but no additive or synergistic inhibitory effect by the combined administration was noted.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In conclusion, the combined administration of BPT/CLZ is safe at doses used in the study, though the beneficial clinical effect of the combined administration has yet to be elucidated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Gastrointestinal tolerability of etoricoxib in rheumatoid arthritis patients: results of the etoricoxib vs diclofenac sodium gastrointestinal tolerability and effectiveness trial (EDGE-II).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A randomised, double-blind study to compare the gastrointestinal (GI) tolerability, safety and efficacy of etoricoxib and diclofenac in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A total of 4086 patients (mean age 60.8 years) diagnosed with RA were enrolled and received etoricoxib 90 mg daily (n = 2032) or diclofenac 75 mg twice daily (n = 2054).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Use of gastroprotective agents and low-dose aspirin was allowed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The prespecified primary end point consisted of the cumulative rate of patient discontinuations due to clinical and laboratory GI adverse experiences (AEs).</Chemical>
<Chemical>General safety was also assessed, including adjudicated thrombotic cardiovascular event data.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Efficacy was evaluated using the Patient Global Assessment of Disease Status (PGADS; 0-4 point scale).</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mean (SD; maximum) duration of treatment was 19.3 (10.3; 32.9) and 19.1 (10.4; 33.1) months in the etoricoxib and diclofenac groups, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The cumulative discontinuation rate due to GI AEs was significantly lower with etoricoxib than diclofenac (5.2 vs 8.5 events per 100 patient-years, respectively; hazard ratio 0.62 (95% CI: 0.47, 0.81; p<or=0.001)).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of discontinuations for hypertension-related and oedema-related AEs were significantly higher with etoricoxib (2.5% and 1.1% respectively) compared with diclofenac (1.5% and 0.4% respectively; p<0.001 for hypertension and p<0.01 for oedema).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Etoricoxib and diclofenac treatment resulted in similar efficacy (PGADS mean changes from baseline -0.62 vs -0.58, respectively).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Etoricoxib 90 mg demonstrated a significantly lower risk for discontinuing treatment due to GI AEs compared with diclofenac 150 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Discontinuations from renovascular AEs, although less common than discontinuations from GI AEs, were significantly higher with etoricoxib.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Placebo-level incidence of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) with quetiapine in controlled studies of patients with bipolar mania.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES: To evaluate extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), including akathisia, with quetiapine in patients with bipolar mania.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Data were analyzed from four similarly designed, randomized, double-blind, 3- to 12-week studies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two studies evaluated quetiapine monotherapy (up to 800 mg/day) (n = 209) versus placebo (n = 198), with lithium or haloperidol monotherapy as respective active controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two studies evaluated quetiapine (up to 800 mg/day) in combination with a mood stabilizer (lithium or divalproex, QTP + Li/DVP) (n = 196) compared to placebo and mood stabilizer (PBO + Li/DVP) (n = 203).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Extrapyramidal symptoms were evaluated using the Simpson-Angus Scale (SAS), the Barnes Akathisia Rating Scale (BARS), adverse event reports and anticholinergic drug usage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of EPS-related adverse events, including akathisia, was no different with quetiapine monotherapy (12.9%) than with placebo (13.1%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Similarly, EPS-related adverse events with QTP + Li/DVP (21.4%) were no different than with PBO + Li/DVP (19.2%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adverse events related to EPS occurred in 59.6% of patients treated with haloperidol (n = 99) monotherapy, whereas 26.5% of patients treated with lithium (n = 98) monotherapy experienced adverse events related to EPS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of akathisia was low and similar with quetiapine monotherapy (3.3%) and placebo (6.1%), and with QTP + Li/DVP (3.6%) and PBO + Li/DVP (4.9%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lithium was associated with a significantly higher incidence (p < 0.05) of tremor (18.4%) than quetiapine (5.6%); cerebellar tremor, which is a known adverse effect of lithium, may have contributed to the elevated rate of tremor in patients receiving lithium therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Haloperidol induced a significantly higher incidence (p < 0.001) of akathisia (33.3% versus 5.9%), tremor (30.3% versus 7.8%), and extrapyramidal syndrome (35.4% versus 5.9%) than quetiapine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>No significant differences were observed between quetiapine and placebo on SAS and BARS scores.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anticholinergic use was low and similar with quetiapine or placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In bipolar mania, the incidence of EPS, including akathisia, with quetiapine therapy is similar to that with placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Contribution of the sympathetic nervous system to salt-sensitivity in lifetime captopril-treated spontaneously hypertensive rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To test the hypothesis that, in lifetime captopril-treated spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR), the sympathetic nervous system contributes importantly to the hypertensive effect of dietary sodium chloride supplementation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Male SHR (aged 6 weeks) that had been treated from conception onward with either captopril or vehicle remained on a basal sodium chloride diet or were fed a high sodium chloride diet.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 2 weeks, the rats were subjected to ganglionic blockade and 2 days later, an infusion of clonidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lifetime captopril treatment significantly lowered mean arterial pressure in both groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intravenous infusion of the ganglionic blocker hexamethonium resulted in a rapid decline in MAP that eliminated the dietary sodium chloride-induced increase in MAP in both groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Infusion of the central nervous system alpha2-adrenergic receptor agonist clonidine also resulted in a greater reduction in MAP in both groups of SHR that were fed the high (compared with the basal) sodium chloride diet.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In both lifetime captopril-treated and control SHR, the sympathetic nervous system contributes to the pressor effects of a high sodium chloride diet.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dose-related beneficial and adverse effects of dietary corticosterone on organophosphorus-induced delayed neuropathy in chickens.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Tri-ortho-tolyl phosphate (TOTP), 360 mg/kg, po, and 0,0'-diisopropyl phosphorofluoridate (DFP), 1 mg/kg sc, were administered to adult White Leghorn chickens 24 hr after they were placed on diets containing 0 to 300 ppm corticosterone.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 74-year-old man with depressive symptoms was admitted to a psychiatric hospital due to insomnia, loss of appetite, exhaustion, and agitation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Medical treatment was initiated at a daily dose of 20 mg paroxetine and 1.2 mg alprazolam.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the 10th day of paroxetine and alprazolam treatment, the patient exhibited marked psychomotor retardation, disorientation, and severe muscle rigidity with tremors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient had a fever (38.2 degrees C), fluctuating blood pressure (between 165/90 and 130/70</Chemical>
<Chemical>mg mm Hg), and severe extrapyramidal symptoms.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Laboratory tests showed an elevation of creatine phosphokinase (2218 IU/L), aspartate aminotransferase (134 IU/L), alanine aminotransferase (78 IU/L), and BUN (27.9 mg/ml) levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient received bromocriptine and diazepam to treat his symptoms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>7 days later, the fever disappeared and the patient's serum CPK levels were normalized (175 IU/L).</Chemical>

<Chemical>This patient presented with symptoms of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), thus demonstrating that NMS-like symptoms can occur after combined paroxetine and alprazolam treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The adverse drug reaction score obtained by the Naranjo algorithm was 6 in our case, indicating a probable relationship between the patient's NMS-like adverse symptoms and the combined treatment used in this case.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The involvement of physiologic and environmental aspects specific to this patient was suspected.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Several risk factors for NMS should be noted in elderly depressive patients whose symptoms often include dehydration, agitation, malnutrition, and exhaustion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Careful therapeutic intervention is necessary in cases involving elderly patients who suffer from depression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pilocarpine seizures cause age-dependent impairment in auditory location discrimination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Children who have status epilepticus have continuous or rapidly repeating seizures that may be life-threatening and may cause life-long changes in brain and behavior.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The extent to which status epilepticus causes deficits in auditory discrimination is unknown.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A naturalistic auditory location discrimination method was used to evaluate this question using an animal model of status epilepticus.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Male Sprague-Dawley rats were injected with saline on postnatal day (P) 20, or a convulsant dose of pilocarpine on P20 or P45.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pilocarpine on either day induced status epilepticus; status epilepticus at P45 resulted in CA3 cell loss and spontaneous seizures, whereas P20 rats had no cell loss or spontaneous seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mature rats were trained with sound-source location and sound-silence discriminations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Control (saline P20)</Chemical>
<Chemical>rats acquired both discriminations immediately.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In status epilepticus (P20) rats, acquisition of the sound-source location discrimination was moderately impaired.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Status epilepticus (P45) rats failed to acquire either sound-source location or sound-silence discriminations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Status epilepticus in rat causes an age-dependent, long-term impairment in auditory discrimination.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This impairment may explain one cause of impaired auditory location discrimination in humans.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cardiovascular risk with cyclooxygenase inhibitors: general problem with substance specific differences?</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Randomised clinical trials and observational studies have shown an increased risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, hypertension and heart failure during treatment with cyclooxygenase inhibitors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adverse cardiovascular effects occurred mainly, but not exclusively, in patients with concomitant risk factors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cyclooxygenase inhibitors cause complex changes in renal, vascular and cardiac prostanoid profiles thereby increasing vascular resistance and fluid retention.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of cardiovascular adverse events tends to increase with the daily dose and total exposure time.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A comparison of individual selective and unselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors suggests substance-specific differences, which may depend on differences in pharmacokinetic parameters or inhibitory potency and may be contributed by prostaglandin-independent effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diagnostic markers such as N-terminal pro brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) or high-sensitive C-reactive protein might help in the early identification of patients at risk, thus avoiding the occurrence of serious cardiovascular toxicity.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Predictors of decreased renal function in patients with heart failure during angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy: results from the studies of left ventricular dysfunction (SOLVD)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy reduces mortality rates in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF), it may also cause decreased renal function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Little information is available to predict which patients are at highest risk for this complication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To quantify specific clinical predictors of reduction in renal function in patients with CHF who are prescribed angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We analyzed data from the Studies of Left Ventricular Dysfunction (SOLVD), a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of enalapril for the treatment of CHF.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were 3379 patients randomly assigned to enalapril with a median follow-up of 974 days and 3379 patients randomly assigned to placebo with a mean follow-up of 967 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Decreased renal function was defined as a rise in serum creatinine >/=0.5</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>mg/dL (44 micromol/L) from baseline.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We used time-to-event analysis to identify potential predictors of decrease in renal function including age, baseline ejection fraction, baseline creatinine, low systolic blood pressure (<100 mm Hg), history of hypertension, diabetes, and use of antiplatelet, diuretic, and beta-blocker therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients randomly assigned to enalapril had a 33% greater likelihood of decreased renal function than controls (P =.003).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>By multivariate analysis, in both the placebo and enalapril groups older age, diuretic therapy, and diabetes were associated with decreased renal function, whereas beta-blocker therapy and higher ejection fraction were renoprotective.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Older age was associated with a greater risk of developing decreased renal function in both groups, but significantly more so in the enalapril group (enalapril: risk ratio [RR] 1.42 per 10 years, 95% confidence interval</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>[CI] 1.32-1.52 with enalapril; placebo: RR 1.18, 95% CI 1.12-1.25).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diuretic therapy was likewise associated with a greater risk of decreased renal function in the enalapril group (RR 1.89, 95% CI 1.70-2.08) than in the placebo group (RR 1.35, 95% CI 1.09-1.66).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Conversely, enalapril had a relative renoprotective effect (RR 1.33, 95% CI 1.13-1.53) compared with placebo (RR 1.96, 95% CI 1.57-2.44) in patients with diabetes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A lower risk of renal impairment was seen in both groups with beta-blocker therapy (RR 0.70, 95% CI 0.57-0.85) and higher baseline ejection fraction (RR 0.93 per 5% increment, 95% CI 0.91-0. 96).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Enalapril use caused a 33% increase in the risk of decreased renal function in patients with CHF.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diuretic use and advanced age increased this risk.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diabetes was associated with an increased risk of renal impairment in all patients with CHF, but this risk was reduced in the enalapril group compared with the placebo group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>beta-Blocker therapy and higher ejection fraction were renoprotective in all patients regardless of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pemoline induced acute choreoathetosis: case report and review of the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pemoline is an oxazolidine derivative that is structurally different from amphetamines and used in the treatment of attention deficit disorder.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pemoline has not been commonly associated in the literature as a cause of acute movement disorders.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The following case describes two children acutely poisoned with pemoline who experienced profound choreoathetosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE REPORT: Two, 3-year-old male, identical twin siblings presented to the emergency department after found playing with a an empty bottle of pemoline originally containing 59 tablets.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The children had a medical history significant for attention deficit disorder previously treated with methylphenidate without success.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This was their first day of pemoline therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The choreoathetoid movements began 45 min to 1 h after ingestion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The children gave no history of prior movement disorders and there was no family history of movement disorders.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The children received gastrointestinal decontamination and high doses of intravenous benzodiazepines in an attempt to control the choreoathetoid movements.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite treatment, the children continued to have choreoathetosis for approximately 24 hours.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Forty-eight hours after admission, the children appeared to be at their baseline and were discharged home.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pemoline associated movement disorder has been rarely reported in the acute toxicology literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possibility of choreoathetoid movements should be considered in patients presenting after pemoline overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Continuous subcutaneous administration of mesna to prevent ifosfamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hemorrhagic cystitis is a major potential toxicity of ifosfamide that can be prevented by administering mesna along with the cytotoxic agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mesna is generally administered by the intravenous route, although experience with oral delivery of the drug has increased.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The continuous subcutaneous administration of mesna has the advantage of not requiring intravenous access.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, subcutaneous delivery of the neutralizing agent will not be associated with the risk of inadequate urinary mesna concentrations, such as in a patient taking oral mesna who experiences severe ifosfamide-induced emesis and is unable to absorb the drug.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Limited clinical experience with continuous subcutaneous mesna administration suggests it is a safe, practical, and economic method of drug delivery that permits ifosfamide to be administered successfully in the outpatient setting.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Modification of drug action by hyperammonemia.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, hyperammonemia is capable of altering drug action and must be considered along with impaired drug metabolism in enhanced drug responses associated with liver disease.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Experiments in vitro showed that acetylcholine-induced catecholamine release from bovine adrenal medulla is depressed as much as 50% by 0.3 mM NH4Ac and KCl-induced contractions of guinea-pig ileum were inhibited 20% by 5 mM NH4Ac.</Chemical>

Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggested that ammonia blocks calcium channels.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Parallels in the actions of NH4Ac and the calcium channel blocker verapamil support this concept.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both verapamil (10 mg/kg i.p.) and NH4Ac pretreatment enhanced morphine analgesia- and diazepam-induced muscular incoordination and antagonized amphetamine-induced motor activity, and neither verapamil nor NH4Ac affected the convulsant action of metrazol.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Risk of nephropathy after consumption of nonionic contrast media by children undergoing cardiac angiography: a prospective study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite increasing reports on nonionic contrast media-induced nephropathy (CIN) in hospitalized adult patients during cardiac procedures, the studies in pediatrics are limited, with even less focus on possible predisposing factors and preventive measures for patients undergoing cardiac angiography.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This prospective study determined the incidence of CIN for two nonionic contrast media (CM), iopromide and iohexol, among 80 patients younger than 18 years and compared the rates for this complication in relation to the type and dosage of CM and the presence of cyanosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The 80 patients in the study consecutively received either iopromide (group A, n = 40) or iohexol (group B, n = 40).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum sodium (Na), potassium (K), and creatinine (Cr) were measured 24 h before angiography as baseline values, then measured again at 12-, 24-, and 48-h intervals after CM use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urine samples for Na and Cr also were checked at the same intervals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Risk of renal failure, Injury to the kidney, Failure of kidney function, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage renal damage (RIFLE criteria) were used to define CIN and its incidence in the study population.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Accordingly, among the 15 CIN patients (18.75%), 7.5% of the patients in group A had increased risk and 3.75% had renal injury, whereas 5% of group B had increased risk and 2.5% had renal injury.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Whereas 33.3% of the patients with CIN were among those who received the proper dosage of CM, the percentage increased to 66.6% among those who received larger doses, with a significant difference in the incidence of CIN related to the different dosages of CM (p = 0.014).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among the 15 patients with CIN, 6 had cyanotic congenital heart diseases, but the incidence did not differ significantly from that for the noncyanotic patients (p = 0.243).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although clinically silent, CIN is not rare in pediatrics.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The incidence depends on dosage but not on the type of consumed nonionic CM, nor on the presence of cyanosis, and although CIN usually is reversible, more concern is needed for the prevention of such a complication in children.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Suboptimal seizure duration is commonly encountered in electroconvulsive therapy practice, especially in older patients with higher seizure thresholds.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Intravenous caffeine is commonly used to improve seizure duration and quality in such patients and is generally well tolerated aside from occasional reports of relatively benign ventricular ectopy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We describe a patient with no previous history of cardiac disease or arrhythmia who developed sustained bigeminy and 2 brief runs of ventricular tachycardia after caffeine administration.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Although intravenous caffeine is generally well tolerated, the clinician should be aware of the potential for unpredictable and serious ventricular arrhythmias.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Optical coherence tomography can measure axonal loss in patients with ethambutol-induced optic neuropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To map and identify the pattern, in vivo, of axonal degeneration in ethambutol-induced optic neuropathy using optical coherence tomography (OCT).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ethambutol is an antimycobacterial agent often used to treat tuberculosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A serious complication of ethambutol is an optic neuropathy that impairs visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, and color vision.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, early on, when the toxic optic neuropathy is mild and partly reversible, the funduscopic findings are often subtle and easy to miss.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Three subjects with a history of ethambutol (EMB)-induced optic neuropathy of short-, intermediate-, and long-term visual deficits were administered a full neuro-ophthalmologic examination including visual acuity, color vision, contrast sensitivity, and fundus examination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, OCT (OCT 3000, Humphrey-Zeiss, Dublin, CA) was performed on both eyes of each subject using the retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL) analysis protocol.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OCT interpolates data from 100 points around the optic nerve to effectively map out the RNFL.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results were compared to the calculated average RNFL of normal eyes accumulated from four prior studies using OCT, n=661.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In all subjects with history of EMB-induced optic neuropathy, there was a mean loss of 72% nerve fiber layer thickness in the temporal quadrant (patient A, with eventual recovery of visual acuity and fields, 58% loss; patient B, with intermediate visual deficits, 68% loss; patient C, with chronic visual deficits, 90% loss), with an average mean optic nerve thickness of 26+/-16 microm.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was a combined mean loss of 46% of fibers from the superior, inferior, and nasal quadrants in the (six) eyes of all three subjects (mean average thickness of 55+/-29 microm).</Chemical>

<Chemical>In both sets (four) of eyes of the subjects with persistent visual deficits (patients B and C), there was an average loss of 79% of nerve fiber thickness in the temporal quadrant.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The OCT results in these patients with EMB-induced optic neuropathy show considerable loss especially of the temporal fibers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is consistent with prior histopathological studies that show predominant loss of parvo-cellular axons (or small-caliber axons) within the papillo-macular bundle in toxic or hereditary optic neuropathies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OCT can be a valuable tool in the quantitative analysis of optic neuropathies.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Additionally, in terms of management of EMB-induced optic neuropathy, it is important to properly manage ethambutol dosing in patients with renal impairment and to achieve proper transition to a maintenance dose once an appropriate loading dose has been reached.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effects of the cyclooxygenase-2 specific inhibitor valdecoxib versus nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents and placebo on cardiovascular thrombotic events in patients with arthritis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There have been concerns that the risk of cardiovascular thrombotic events may be higher with cyclooxygenase (COX)-2-specific inhibitors than nonselective nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).</Chemical>

<Chemical>We evaluated cardiovascular event data for valdecoxib, a new COX-2-specific inhibitor in approximately 8000 patients with osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis treated with this agent in randomized clinical trials.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of cardiovascular thrombotic events (cardiac, cerebrovascular and peripheral vascular, or arterial thrombotic) was determined by analyzing pooled valdecoxib (10-80 mg daily), nonselective NSAID (diclofenac 75 mg bid, ibuprofen 800 mg tid, or naproxen 500 mg bid) and placebo data from 10 randomized osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis trials that were 6-52 weeks in duration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence rates of events were determined in all patients (n = 7934) and in users of low-dose (< or =325 mg daily) aspirin (n = 1051) and nonusers of aspirin (n = 6883).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Crude and exposure-adjusted incidences of thrombotic events were similar for valdecoxib, NSAIDs, and placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The risk of serious thrombotic events was also similar for each valdecoxib dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thrombotic risk was consistently higher for users of aspirin users than nonusers of aspirin (placebo, 1.4% vs. 0%; valdecoxib, 1.7% vs. 0.2%; NSAIDs, 1.9% vs. 0.5%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rates of events in users of aspirin were similar for all 3 treatment groups and across valdecoxib doses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Short- and intermediate-term treatment with therapeutic (10 or 20 mg daily) and supratherapeutic (40 or 80 mg daily) valdecoxib doses was not associated with an increased incidence of thrombotic events relative to nonselective NSAIDs or placebo in osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis patients in controlled clinical trials.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A randomized, placebo-controlled, crossover study of ephedrine for SSRI-induced female sexual dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The objective of this study was to determine whether ephedrine, an alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonist previously shown to enhance genital blood flow in women, has beneficial effects in reversing antidepressant-induced sexual dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nineteen sexually dysfunctional women receiving either fluoxetine, sertraline, or paroxetine participated in an eight-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled, cross-over study of the effects of ephedrine (50 mg) on self-report measures of sexual desire, arousal, orgasm, and sexual satisfaction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although there were significant improvements relative to baseline in sexual desire and orgasm intensity/pleasure on 50 mg ephedrine 1-hr prior to sexual activity, significant improvements in these measures, as well as in sexual arousal and orgasmic ability also were noted with placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings highlight the importance of conducting placebo-controlled trials for this condition.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Erectile dysfunction occurs following substantia nigra lesions in the rat.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Erectile function was assessed 6 weeks following uni- and bilateral injections of 6-hydroxydopamine in the substantia nigra nucleus of the brain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Behavioral apomorphine-induced penile erections were reduced (5/8) and increased (3/8) in uni- and bilateral lesioned animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intracavernous pressures, following electrical stimulation of the cavernous nerve, decreased in lesioned animals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lesions of the substantia nigra were confirmed by histology.</Chemical>
