label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lesions of the substantia nigra are therefore associated with erectile dysfunction in rats and may serve as a model to study erectile dysfunction in Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Potential therapeutic use of the selective dopamine D1 receptor agonist, A-86929: an acute study in parkinsonian levodopa-primed monkeys.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The clinical utility of dopamine (DA) D1 receptor agonists in the treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD) is still unclear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The therapeutic use of selective DA D1 receptor agonists such as SKF-82958 (6-chloro-7,8-dihydroxy-3-allyl-1-phenyl-2,3,4,5-tetrahydro-1H-3-benzaze pine hydrobromide) and A-77636 ([1R, 3S]</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>3-[1'-admantyl]-1-aminomethyl-3,4-dihydro-5,6-dihydroxy-1H-2-benzo pyran hydrochloride) seems limited because of their duration of action, which is too short for SKF-82958 (< 1 hr) and too long for A-77636 (> 20 hr, leading to behavioral tolerance).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We therefore conducted the present acute dose-response study in four 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP)-exposed cynomolgus monkeys primed to exhibit levodopa-induced dyskinesias to evaluate the locomotor and dyskinetic effects on challenge with four doses (from 0.03 to 1.0 mg/kg) of A-86929 ([-]-[5aR,11bS]-4,5,5a,6,7,11b-hexahydro-2-propyl-3-thia-5-+ ++azacyclopent-1- ena[c]phenathrene-9-10-diol), a selective and full DA D1-like receptor agonist with an intermediate duration of action.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Levodopa and the DA D2-like receptor agonist, LY-171555 ([4aR-trans]-4,4a,5,6,7,8,8a,9-o-dihydro-5n-propyl-2H-pyrazo lo-3-4-quinoline hydrochloride) were also used for comparison.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acute administration of A-86929 was as efficacious in alleviating MPTP-induced parkinsonism as levodopa and LY-171555, but was less likely to reproduce the levodopa-induced dyskinesias in these animals than with either LY-171555 or subsequent challenge of levodopa.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Selective stimulation of the DA D1 receptor may provide better integration of neural inputs transmitted to the internal segment of the globus pallidus (referred to as the basal ganglia output) compared with levodopa and selective DA D2 receptor agonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Potent DA D1 receptor agents with an intermediate duration of efficacy such as A-86929 (approximately 4 hr at higher doses tested) are potential therapeutic tools in PD and merit further attention.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Deaths from local anesthetic-induced convulsions in mice.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Median convulsant (CD50) and median lethal (LD50) doses of three representative local anesthetics were determined in adult mice to evaluate the threat to life of local anesthetic-induced convulsions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The CD50 and LD50, respectively, were 57.7 and 58.7 mg/kg for bupivacaine, 111.0 and 133.1 mg/kg for lidocaine, and 243.4 and 266.5 mg/kg for chloroprocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>When given intraperitoneally, bupivacaine thus was only about twice as toxic as lidocaine and four times as toxic as chloroprocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Convulsions always preceded death, except after precipitous cardiopulmonary arrest from extreme doses.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A CD50 dose of local anesthetic (causing convulsions in 50% of mice) was fatal in 90% of bupivacaine-induced seizures, in 57% of the chloroprocaine group, and in 6% of the lidocaine group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The narrow gap between convulsant and lethal doses of local anesthetics indicates that untreated convulsions present much more of a threat to life than heretofore appreciated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myoclonic, atonic, and absence seizures following institution of carbamazepine therapy in children.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five children, aged 3 to 11 years, treated with carbamazepine for epilepsy, had an acute aberrant reaction characterized by the onset of myoclonic, atypical absence and/or atonic (minor motor) seizures within a few days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When the carbamazepine was discontinued, two of the children returned to their former state very quickly, two had the minor motor seizures resolve in 3 and 6 months, and one had the seizures persist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The child in whom the seizures persisted was later found to have ceroid lipofuscinosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The other children are doing well on other anticonvulsants.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Naloxone reversal of hypotension due to captopril overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The hemodynamic effects of captopril and other angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors may be mediated by the endogenous opioid system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The opioid antagonist naloxone has been shown to block or reverse the hypotensive actions of captopril.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of an intentional captopril overdose, manifested by marked hypotension, that resolved promptly with the administration of naloxone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To our knowledge, this is the first reported case of captopril-induced hypotension treated with naloxone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our experience demonstrates a possible role of naloxone in the reversal of hypotension resulting from captopril.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Carbamazepine-induced cardiac dysfunction. Characterization of two distinct clinical syndromes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A patient with sinus bradycardia and atrioventricular block, induced by carbamazepine, prompted an extensive literature review of all previously reported cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>From the analysis of these cases, two distinct forms of carbamazepine-associated cardiac dysfunction emerged.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>One patient group developed sinus tachycardias in the setting of a massive carbamazepine overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The second group consisted almost exclusively of elderly women who developed potentially life-threatening bradyarrhythmias or atrioventricular conduction delay, associated with either therapeutic or modestly elevated carbamazepine serum levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because carbamazepine is widely used in the treatment of many neurologic and psychiatric conditions, the recognition of the latter syndrome has important implications for the use of this drug in elderly patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Glutamatergic neurotransmission mediated by NMDA receptors in the inferior colliculus can modulate haloperidol-induced catalepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The inferior colliculus (IC) is primarily involved in the processing of auditory information, but it is distinguished from other auditory nuclei in the brainstem by its connections with structures of the motor system.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Functional evidence relating the IC to motor behavior derives from experiments showing that activation of the IC by electrical stimulation or excitatory amino acid microinjection causes freezing, escape-like behavior, and immobility.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the nature of this immobility is still unclear.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The present study examined the influence of excitatory amino acid-mediated mechanisms in the IC on the catalepsy induced by the dopamine receptor blocker haloperidol administered systemically (1 or 0.5 mg/kg) in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Haloperidol-induced catalepsy was challenged with prior intracollicular microinjections of glutamate NMDA receptor antagonists, MK-801 (15 or 30 mmol/0.5 microl) and AP7 (10 or 20 nmol/0.5 microl), or of the NMDA receptor agonist N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA, 20 or 30 nmol/0.5 microl).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results showed that intracollicular microinjection of MK-801 and AP7 previous to systemic injections of haloperidol significantly attenuated the catalepsy, as indicated by a reduced latency to step down from a horizontal bar.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Accordingly, intracollicular microinjection of NMDA increased the latency to step down the bar.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that glutamate-mediated mechanisms in the neural circuits at the IC level influence haloperidol-induced catalepsy and participate in the regulation of motor activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Metabotropic glutamate 7 receptor subtype modulates motor symptoms in rodent models of Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Metabotropic glutamate (mGlu) receptors modulate synaptic transmission in the central nervous system and represent promising therapeutic targets for symptomatic treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among the eight mGlu receptor subtypes, mGlu7 receptor is prominently expressed in the basal ganglia, but its role in restoring motor function in animal models of PD is not known.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The effects of N,N'-dibenzhydrylethane-1,2-diamine dihydrochloride (AMN082), the first selective allosteric activator of mGlu7 receptors, were thus tested in different rodent models of PD.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here, we show that oral (5 mg/kg) or intrastriatal administration (0.1 and 0.5 nmol) of AMN082 reverses haloperidol-induced catalepsy in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>AMN082 (2.5 and 5 mg/kg) reduces apomorphine-induced rotations in unilateral 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA)-lesioned rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a more complex task commonly used to evaluate major akinetic symptoms of PD patients, 5 mg/kg AMN082 reverses the increased reaction time to respond to a cue of bilateral 6-OHDA-lesioned rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, AMN082 reduces the duration of haloperidol-induced catalepsy in a mGlu7 receptor-dependent manner in wild-type but not mGlu7 receptor knockout mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Higher doses of AMN082 (10 and 20 mg/kg p.o.) have no effect on the same models of PD.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Overall these findings suggest that mGlu7 receptor activation can reverse motor dysfunction associated with reduced dopamine activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Selective ligands of mGlu7 receptor subtypes may thus be considered as promising compounds for the development of antiparkinsonian therapeutic strategies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nimodipine prevents memory impairment caused by nitroglycerin-induced hypotension in adult mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Hypotension and a resultant decrease in cerebral blood flow have been implicated in the development of cognitive dysfunction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We tested the hypothesis that nimodipine (NIMO) administered at the onset of nitroglycerin (NTG)-induced hypotension would preserve long-term associative memory.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The passive avoidance (PA) paradigm was used to assess memory retention.</Chemical>
<Chemical>For PA training, latencies (seconds) were recorded for entry from a suspended platform into a Plexiglas tube where a shock was automatically delivered.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Latencies were recorded 48 h later for a testing trial.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ninety-six Swiss-Webster mice (30-35 g, 6-8 wk), were randomized into 6 groups 1) saline (control), 2) NTG immediately after learning, 3) NTG 3 h after learning, 4) NTG and NIMO, 5) vehicle, and 6) NIMO alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The extent of hypotension and changes in brain tissue oxygenation (PbtO(2)) and in cerebral blood flow were studied in a separate group of animals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: All groups exhibited similar training latencies (17.0 +/- 4.6 s).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Mice subjected to hypotensive episodes showed a significant decrease in latency time (178 +/- 156 s) compared with those injected with saline, NTG + NIMO, or delayed NTG (580 +/- 81 s, 557 +/- 67 s, and 493 +/- 146 s, respectively).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A Kruskal-Wallis 1-way analysis of variance indicated a significant difference among the 4 treatment groups (H = 15.34; P < 0.001).</Chemical>

<Chemical>In a separate group of mice not subjected to behavioral studies, the same dose of NTG (n = 3) and NTG + NIMO (n = 3) caused mean arterial blood pressure to decrease from 85.9 +/- 3.8 mm Hg sem to 31.6 +/- 0.8 mm</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hg sem and from 86.2 +/-</Chemical>
<Chemical>3.7 mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg sem to 32.6 +/- 0.2</Chemical>
<Chemical>mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg sem, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mean arterial blood pressure in mice treated with NIMO alone decreased from 88.1 +/- 3.8 mm</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hg to 80.0 +/- 2.9 mm Hg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The intergroup difference was statistically significant (P < 0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>PbtO(2) decreased from 51.7 +/- 4.5 mm Hg sem to 33.8 +/- 5.2 mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg sem in the NTG group and from 38.6 +/- 6.1 mm Hg sem to 25.4 +/- 2.0 mm Hg sem in the NTG + NIMO groups, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were no significant differences among groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In a PA retention paradigm, the injection of NTG immediately after learning produced a significant impairment of long-term associative memory in mice, whereas delayed induced hypotension had no effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>NIMO attenuated the disruption in consolidation of long-term memory caused by NTG but did not improve latency in the absence of hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The observed effect of NIMO may have been attributable to the preservation of calcium homeostasis during hypotension, because there were no differences in the PbtO(2) indices among groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fatal haemopericardium and gastrointestinal haemorrhage due to possible interaction of cranberry juice with warfarin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of fatal internal haemorrhage in an elderly man who consumed only cranberry juice for two weeks while maintaining his usual dosage of warfarin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We propose that naturally occurring compounds such as flavonoids, which are present in fruit juices, may increase the potency of warfarin by competing for the enzymes that normally inactivate warfarin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>While traditionally regarded as foodstuffs, consumption of fruit juices should be considered when patients develop adverse drug reactions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Isoproterenol induces primary loss of dystrophin in rat hearts: correlation with myocardial injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism of isoproterenol-induced myocardial damage is unknown, but a mismatch of oxygen supply vs. demand following coronary hypotension and myocardial hyperactivity is the best explanation for the complex morphological alterations observed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Severe alterations in the structural integrity of the sarcolemma of cardiomyocytes have been demonstrated to be caused by isoproterenol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Taking into account that the sarcolemmal integrity is stabilized by the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex (DGC) that connects actin and laminin in contractile machinery and extracellular matrix and by integrins, this study tests the hypothesis that isoproterenol affects sarcolemmal stability through changes in the DGC and integrins.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We found different sensitivity of the DGC and integrin to isoproterenol subcutaneous administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immunofluorescent staining revealed that dystrophin is the most sensitive among the structures connecting the actin in the cardiomyocyte cytoskeleton and the extracellular matrix.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The sarcomeric actin dissolution occurred after the reduction or loss of dystrophin.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Subsequently, after lysis of myofilaments, gamma-sarcoglycan, beta-dystroglycan, beta1-integrin, and laminin alpha-2 expressions were reduced followed by their breakdown, as epiphenomena of the myocytolytic process.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In conclusion, administration of isoproterenol to rats results in primary loss of dystrophin, the most sensitive among the structural proteins that form the DGC that connects the extracellular matrix and the cytoskeleton in cardiomyocyte.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These changes, related to ischaemic injury, explain the severe alterations in the structural integrity of the sarcolemma of cardiomyocytes and hence severe and irreversible injury induced by isoproterenol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>High fat diet-fed obese rats are highly sensitive to doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Often, chemotherapy by doxorubicin (Adriamycin) is limited due to life threatening cardiotoxicity in patients during and posttherapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recently, we have shown that moderate diet restriction remarkably protects against doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This cardioprotection is accompanied by decreased cardiac oxidative stress and triglycerides and increased cardiac fatty-acid oxidation, ATP synthesis, and upregulated JAK/STAT3 pathway.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the current study, we investigated whether a physiological intervention by feeding 40% high fat diet (HFD), which induces obesity in male Sprague-Dawley rats (250-275 g), sensitizes to doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A LD(10) dose (8 mg doxorubicin/kg, ip) administered on day 43 of the HFD feeding regimen led to higher cardiotoxicity, cardiac dysfunction, lipid peroxidation, and 80% mortality in the obese (OB) rats in the absence of any significant renal or hepatic toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Doxorubicin toxicokinetics studies revealed no change in accumulation of doxorubicin and doxorubicinol (toxic metabolite) in the normal diet-fed (ND) and OB hearts.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mechanistic studies revealed that OB rats are sensitized due to: (1) higher oxyradical stress leading to upregulation of uncoupling proteins 2 and 3, (2) downregulation of cardiac peroxisome proliferators activated receptor-alpha, (3) decreased plasma adiponectin levels, (4) decreased cardiac fatty-acid oxidation (666.9+/-14.0 nmol/min/g heart in ND versus 400.2+/-11.8 nmol/min/g heart in OB), (5) decreased mitochondrial AMP-alpha2 protein kinase, and (6) 86% drop in cardiac ATP levels accompanied by decreased ATP/ADP ratio after doxorubicin administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Decreased cardiac erythropoietin and increased SOCS3 further downregulated the cardioprotective JAK/</Chemical>
<Chemical>STAT3 pathway.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In conclusion, HFD-induced obese rats are highly sensitized to doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity by substantially downregulating cardiac mitochondrial ATP generation, increasing oxidative stress and downregulating the JAK/STAT3 pathway.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Complete atrioventricular block secondary to lithium therapy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Sinus node dysfunction has been reported most frequently among the adverse cardiovascular effects of lithium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present case, complete atrioventricular (AV) block with syncopal attacks developed secondary to lithium therapy, necessitating permanent pacemaker implantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum lithium levels remained under or within the therapeutic range during the syncopal attacks.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Lithium should be used with extreme caution, especially in patients with mild disturbance of AV conduction.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Neuroleptic malignant syndrome induced by ziprasidone on the second day of treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is the rarest and most serious of the neuroleptic-induced movement disorders.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We describe a case of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) associated with the use of ziprasidone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although conventional neuroleptics are more frequently associated with NMS, atypical antipsychotic drugs like ziprasidone may also be a cause.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient is a 24-year-old male with a history of schizophrenia who developed signs and symptoms of NMS after 2 days of treatment with an 80-mg/day dose of orally administrated ziprasidone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This case is the earliest (second day of treatment)</Chemical>
<Chemical>NMS due to ziprasidone reported in the literature.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Role of mangiferin on biochemical alterations and antioxidant status in isoproterenol-induced myocardial infarction in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The current study dealt with the protective role of mangiferin, a polyphenol from Mangifera indica Linn.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>(Anacardiaceae), on isoproterenol (ISPH)-induced myocardial infarction (MI) in rats through its antioxidative mechanism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subcutaneous injection of ISPH (200 mg/kg body weight in 1 ml saline) to rats for 2 consecutive days caused myocardial damage in rat heart, which was determined by the increased activity of serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and creatine phosphokinase isoenzymes (CK-MB), increased uric acid level and reduced plasma iron binding capacity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The protective role of mangiferin was analyzed by triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) test used for macroscopic enzyme mapping assay of the ischemic myocardium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The heart tissue antioxidant enzymes such as superoxide dismutase, catalase, glutathione peroxidase, glutathione transferase and glutathione reductase activities, non-enzymic antioxidants such as cerruloplasmin, Vitamin C, Vitamin E and glutathione levels were altered in MI rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Upon pretreatment with mangiferin (100 mg/kg body weight suspended in 2 ml of dimethyl sulphoxide) given intraperitoneally for 28 days to MI rats protected the above-mentioned parameters to fall from the normal levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Activities of heart tissue enzymic antioxidants and serum non-enzymic antioxidants levels rose significantly upon mangiferin administration as compared to ISPH-induced MI rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>From the present study it is concluded that mangiferin exerts a beneficial effect against ISPH-induced MI due to its antioxidant potential, which regulated the tissues defense system against cardiac damage.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Remifentanil pretreatment reduces myoclonus after etomidate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>STUDY OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The aim of the study was to compare the effect of pretreatment with remifentanil 1 microg/kg and the effect of gender on the incidence of myoclonus after anesthesia induction with etomidate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was a randomized, double-blind study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The study was conducted at a university hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS: Sixty patients were pretreated in a randomized double-blinded fashion with remifentanil 1 microg/kg or placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two minutes after remifentanil or placebo injection, etomidate 0.3 mg/kg was given.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>MEASUREMENTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myoclonus was recorded with a scale of 0 to 3.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The grade of sedation (none, mild, moderate, severe), nausea, pruritus, and apnea were recorded after injection of both drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>MAIN RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of myoclonus was significantly lower in the remifentanil group (6.7%) than in the placebo group (70%) (P < 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>None of the patients experienced sedation, apnea, nausea, or pruritus after injection of both drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the placebo group, male patients were associated with significantly increased incidence of myoclonus after etomidate administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION: Pretreatment with remifentanil 1 microg/kg reduced myoclonus after etomidate induction without side effects such as sedation, apnea, nausea, or pruritus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Men experience increased incidence of myoclonus than women after etomidate administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Daidzein activates choline acetyltransferase from MC-IXC cells and improves drug-induced amnesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) activator, which enhances cholinergic transmission via an augmentation of the enzymatic production of acetylcholine (ACh), is an important factor in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease (AD).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methanolic extracts from Pueraria thunbergiana exhibited an activation effect (46%) on ChAT in vitro.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Via the sequential isolation of Pueraria thunbergiana, the active component was ultimately identified as daidzein (4',7-dihydroxy-isoflavone).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In order to investigate the effects of daidzein from Pueraria thunbergiana on scopolamine-induced impairments of learning and memory, we conducted a series of in vivo tests.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of daidzein (4.5 mg/kg body weight) to mice was shown significantly to reverse scopolamine-induced amnesia, according to the results of a Y-maze test.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Injections of scopolamine into mice resulted in impaired performance on Y-maze tests (a 37% decreases in alternation behavior).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>By way of contrast, mice treated with daidzein prior to the scopolamine injections were noticeably protected from this performance impairment (an approximately 12%-21% decrease in alternation behavior).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results indicate that daidzein might play a role in acetylcholine biosynthesis as a ChAT activator, and that it also ameliorates scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Possible azithromycin-associated hiccups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of persistent hiccups associated by azithromycin therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE SUMMARY:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 76-year-old man presented with persistent hiccups after beginning azithromycin for the treatment of pharyngitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hiccups were persistent and exhausting.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Discontinuation of azithromycin and therapy with baclofen finally resolved hiccups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>No organic cause of hiccups was identified despite extensive investigation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pharmacotherapeutic agents have been uncommonly associated with hiccups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Corticosteroids (dexamethasone and methylprednisolone), benzodiazepines (midazolam) and general anaesthesia have been the specific agents mentioned most frequently in the literature as being associated with the development of hiccups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Few cases of drug-induced hiccups have been reported related to macrolide antimicrobials.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using the Naranjo adverse effect reaction probability scale this event could be classified as possible (score 5 points), mostly because of the close temporal sequence, previous reports on this reaction with other macrolides and the absence of any alternative explanation for hiccups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our hypothesis is that a vagal mechanism mediated by azithromycin could be the pathogenesis of hiccups in our patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Diagnosis of drug-induced hiccups is difficult and often achieved only by a process of elimination.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, macrolide antimicrobials have been reported to be associated with hiccups and vagal mechanism could explain the development of this side-effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Time trends in warfarin-associated hemorrhage.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The annual incidence of warfarin-related bleeding at Brigham and Women's Hospital increased from 0.97/1,000 patient admissions in the first time period (January 1995 to October 1998) to 1.19/1,000 patient admissions in the second time period (November 1998 to August 2002) of this study.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The proportion of patients with major and intracranial bleeding increased from 20.2% and 1.9%, respectively, in the first time period, to 33.3% and 7.8%, respectively, in the second.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Glyceryl trinitrate induces attacks of migraine without aura in sufferers of migraine with aura.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Migraine with aura and migraine without aura have the same pain phase, thus indicating that migraine with aura and migraine without aura share a common pathway of nociception.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In recent years, increasing evidence has suggested that the messenger molecule nitric oxide (NO) is involved in pain mechanisms of migraine without aura.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In order to clarify whether the same is true for migraine with aura, in the present study we examined the headache response to intravenous infusion of glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) (0.5 microg/kg/min for 20 min) in 12 sufferers of migraine with aura.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The specific aim was to elucidate whether an aura and/or an attack of migraine without aura could be induced.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fourteen healthy subjects served as controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Aura symptoms were not elicited in any subject.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Headache was more severe in migraineurs than in the controls during and immediately after GTN infusion (p=0.037) as well as during the following 11 h (p = 0.008).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the controls, the GTN-induced headache gradually disappeared, whereas in migraineurs peak headache intensity occurred at a mean time of 240 min post-infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At this time the induced headache in 6 of 12 migraineurs fulfilled the diagnostic criteria for migraine without aura of the International Headache Society.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results therefore suggest that NO is involved in the pain mechanisms of migraine with aura.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since cortical spreading depression has been shown to liberate NO in animals, this finding may help our understanding of the coupling between cortical spreading depression and headache in migraine with aura.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>This case-control study was conducted in the defined population comprising members of Kaiser Permanente of Northern and Southern California.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We attempted to identify all incident strokes in women ages 15-44 years during a 3-year period using hospital admission and discharge records, emergency department logs, and payment requests for out-of-plan hospitalizations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We selected controls, matched on age and facility of usual care, at random from healthy members of the health plan.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We obtained information in face-to-face interviews.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were 347 confirmed stroke cases and 1,021 controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The univariate matched odds ratio for stroke in women who admitted to using cocaine and/or amphetamine was 8.5 (95% confidence interval = 3.6-20.0).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After further adjustment for potential confounders, the odds ratio in women who reported using cocaine and/or amphetamine was 7.0 (95% confidence interval = 2.8-17.9).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The use of cocaine and/or amphetamine is a strong risk factor for stroke in this socioeconomically heterogeneous, insured urban population.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Prevention of breast cancer with tamoxifen: preliminary findings from the Italian randomised trial among hysterectomised women. Italian Tamoxifen Prevention Study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tamoxifen is a candidate chemopreventive agent in breast cancer, although the drug may be associated with the development of endometrial cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Therefore we did a trial in hysterectomised women of tamoxifen as a chemopreventive.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In October, 1992, we started a double-blind placebo-controlled, randomised trial of tamoxifen in women (mainly in Italy) who did not have breast cancer and who had had a hysterectomy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Women were randomised to receive tamoxifen 20 mg per day or placebo, both orally for 5 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The original plan was to follow the intervention phase by 5 years' follow-up.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In June, 1997, the trialists and the data-monitoring committee decided to end recruitment primarily because of the number of women dropping out of the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recruitment ended on July 11, 1997, and the study will continue as planned.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The primary endpoints are the occurrence of and deaths from breast cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This preliminary interim analysis is based on intention-to-treat.</Chemical>
<Chemical>FINDINGS: 5408 women were randomised; participating women have a median follow-up of 46 months for major endpoints.</Chemical>
<Chemical>41 cases of breast cancer occurred so far; there have been no deaths from breast cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There is no difference in breast-cancer frequency between the placebo (22 cases) and tamoxifen (19) arms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There is a statistically significant reduction of breast cancer among women receiving tamoxifen who also used hormone-replacement therapy during the trial: among 390 women on such therapy and allocated to placebo, we found eight cases of breast cancer compared with one case among 362 women allocated to tamoxifen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with the placebo group, there was a significantly increased risk of vascular events and hypertriglyceridaemia among women on tamoxifen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>INTERPRETATION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although this preliminary analysis has low power, in this cohort of women at low-to-normal risk of breast cancer, the postulated protective effects of tamoxifen are not yet apparent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Women using hormone-replacement therapy appear to have benefited from use of tamoxifen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were no deaths from breast cancer recorded in women in the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is essential to continue follow-up to quantify the long-term risks and benefits of tamoxifen therapy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Comparison of the effectiveness of ranitidine and cimetidine in inhibiting acid secretion in patients with gastric hypersecretory states.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The H2-histamine receptor antagonists ranitidine and cimetidine were compared for their abilities to control gastric acid hypersecretion on a short- and long-term basis in 22 patients with gastric acid hypersecretory states.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nineteen patients had Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, one patient had systemic mastocytosis, and two patients had idiopathic hypersecretion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The rates of onset of the action of cimetidine and ranitidine were the same.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The actions of both drugs were increased by anticholinergic agents, and there was a close correlation between the daily maintenance dose of each drug needed to control acid secretion.</Chemical>

<Chemical>However, ranitidine was threefold more potent than cimetidine both in acute inhibition studies and in the median maintenance dose needed (1.2 g per day for ranitidine and 3.6 g per day for cimetidine).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sixty percent of the males developed breast changes or impotence while taking cimetidine and in all cases these changes disappeared when cimetidine was replaced by ranitidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment with high doses of cimetidine (one to 60 months; median, 11 months) or ranitidine (two to 31 months; median, 14 months) was not associated with hepatic or hematologic toxicity or alterations of serum gastrin concentrations, but ranitidine therapy was associated with a significantly lower serum creatinine level than seen with cimetidine therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results show that both drugs can adequately inhibit acid secretion in patients with gastric hypersecretory states.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Both are safe at high doses, but ranitidine is threefold more potent and does not cause the antiandrogen side effects frequently seen with high doses of cimetidine.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A catch in the Reye.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twenty-six cases of Reye syndrome from The Children's Hospital, Camperdown, Australia, occurring between 1973 and 1982 were reviewed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of these, 20 cases met the US Public Health Service Centers for Disease Control criteria for the diagnosis of Reye syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Aspirin or salicylate ingestion had occurred in only one of the 20 cases (5%), and paracetamol (acetaminophen) had been administered in only six of the cases (30%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pathologic confirmation of the diagnosis of Reye syndrome was accomplished in 90% of the cases.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The incidence of Reye syndrome in New South Wales, Australia, is estimated from this study to be approximately nine cases per 1 million children compared with recent US data of ten to 20 cases per 1 million children and three to seven cases per 1 million children in Great Britain.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mortality for these Reye syndrome cases in Australia was 45% as compared with a 32% case-fatality rate in the United States.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In Australia, the pediatric usage of aspirin has been extremely low for the past 25 years (less than 1% of total dosage units sold), with paracetamol (acetaminophen) dominating the pediatric analgesic and antipyretic market.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reye syndrome may be disappearing from Australia despite a total lack of association with salicylates or aspirin ingestion, since there were no cases found at The Children's Hospital in 1983, 1984, or 1985.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Midline B3 serotonin nerves in rat medulla are involved in hypotensive effect of methyldopa.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous experiments in this laboratory have shown that microinjection of methyldopa onto the ventrolateral cells of the B3 serotonin neurons in the medulla elicits a hypotensive response mediated by a projection descending into the spinal cord.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present experiments were designed to investigate the role of the midline cells of the B3 serotonin neurons in the medulla, coinciding with the raphe magnus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In spontaneously hypertensive, stroke-prone rats, microinjection of methyldopa into the area of the midline B3 serotonin cell group in the ventral medulla caused a potent hypotension of 30-40 mm Hg, which was maximal 2-3 h after administration and was abolished by the serotonin neurotoxin 5,7-dihydroxytryptamine (5,7-DHT) injected intracerebroventricularly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, intraspinal injection of 5,7-DHT to produce a more selective lesion of only descending serotonin projections in the spinal cord did not affect this hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further, 5,7-DHT lesion of serotonin nerves travelling in the median forebrain bundle, one of the main ascending pathways from the B3 serotonin cells, did not affect the fall in blood pressure associated with a midline B3 serotonin methyldopa injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is concluded therefore that, unlike the ventrolateral B3 cells which mediate a methyldopa-induced hypotension via descending projections, the midline serotonin B3 cells in the medulla contribute to the hypotensive action of methyldopa, either by way of an ascending projection which does not pass through the median forebrain bundle, or through a projection restricted to the caudal brainstem.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Preclinical and clinical studies suggest that yohimbine facilitates sexual behavior and may be helpful in the treatment of male impotence.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>This study evaluated yohimbine as a treatment for the sexual side effects caused by serotonin reuptake blockers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD: Six patients with either obsessive compulsive disorder, trichotillomania, anxiety, or affective disorders who suffered sexual side effects after treatment with serotonin reuptake blockers were given yohimbine on a p.r.n.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>basis in an open clinical trial.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Various doses of yohimbine were used to determine the ideal dose for each patient.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Five of the six patients experienced improved sexual functioning after taking yohimbine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>One patient who failed to comply with yohimbine treatment had no therapeutic effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Side effects of yohimbine included excessive sweating, increased anxiety, and a wound-up feeling in some patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Future controlled studies are needed to further investigate the effectiveness and safety of yohimbine for this indication.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Hypersensitivity immune reaction as a mechanism for dilevalol-associated hepatitis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To assess lymphocyte reactivity to dilevalol and to serum containing putative ex vivo dilevalol antigens or metabolites in a case of dilevalol-induced liver injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENT:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 58-year-old woman with a clinical diagnosis of dilevalol-induced liver injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Peripheral blood mononuclear cells collected from the patient were cultured in the presence of a solution of dilevalol and also with sera collected from a volunteer before and after dilevalol intake.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A similar protocol was performed with lymphocytes from a healthy subject.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>No lymphocyte proliferation was observed either in the patient or in the healthy volunteer in the presence of dilevalol solutions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant proliferative response to serum collected after dilevalol intake was observed in the case of the patient compared with the proliferative response to the serum collected before the drug intake.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>No reactivity was found when lymphocytes from the healthy subject were tested under similar conditions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The methodology used allowed the detection of lymphocyte sensitization to sera containing ex vivo-prepared dilevalol antigens, suggesting the involvement of an immunologic mechanism in dilevalol-induced liver injury.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Reversible myocardial hypertrophy induced by tacrolimus in a pediatric heart transplant recipient: case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tacrolimus is a potent immunosuppressant that is frequently used in organ transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, adverse effects include cardiac toxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Herein we describe transient myocardial hypertrophy induced by tacrolimus after heart transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The hypertrophy caused no clinical symptoms but was noted because of elevation of plasma brain natriuretic peptide concentration and confirmed at echocardiography.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Initially, allograft rejection was feared; however, myocardial biopsy samples revealed only interstitial edema and mild myocardial hypertrophy; neither cellular nor humoral rejection was detected.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The blood tacrolimus concentration was higher than usual at that time; thus, tacrolimus dosage was reduced.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Myocardial hypertrophy completely resolved upon reducing the target concentration of tacrolimus and did not recur, as confirmed at echocardiography and myocardial biopsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, we conclude that tacrolimus induces reversible myocardial hypertrophy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients receiving tacrolimus therapy, blood concentration should be carefully controlled and extreme attention paid to cardiac involvement.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Comparison of unilateral pallidotomy and subthalamotomy findings in advanced idiopathic Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ten consecutive patients (mean age, 58.4 +/- 6.8 years; 7 men, 3 women) with similar characteristics at the duration of disease (mean disease time, 8.4 +/- 3.5 years), disabling motor fluctuations (Hoehn _</Chemical>
<Chemical>Yahr stage 3-5 in off-drug phases) and levodopa-induced dyskinesias were selected.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>All patients had bilateral symptoms and their levodopa equivalent dosing were analysed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six patients were operated on in the globus pallidus interna (GPi) and four in the subthalamic nucleus (STN).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Clinical evaluation included the use of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS), Hoehn_Yahr score and Schwab England activities of daily living (ADL) score in 'on'- and 'off'-drug conditions before surgery and 6 months after surgery.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was statistically significant improvement in all contralateral major parkinsonian motor signs in all patients followed for 6 months.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Changes in UPDRS, Hoehn _</Chemical>
<Chemical>Yahr and Schwab England ADL scores were similar in both groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cognitive functions were unchanged in both groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Complications were observed in two patients: one had a left homonymous hemianopsia after pallidotomy and another one developed left hemiballistic movements 3 days after subthalamotomy which partly improved within 1 month with Valproate 1000 mg/day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The findings of this study suggest that lesions of the unilateral STN and GPi are equally effective treatment for patients with advanced PD refractory to medical treatment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Our observations show that beta2-subunits play an important role in the regulation of sodium channel density and function in neurons in vivo and are required for normal action potential generation and control of excitability.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Screening for stimulant use in adult emergency department seizure patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The objective of this study was to determine the prevalence of positive plasma drug screening for cocaine or amphetamine in adult emergency department seizure patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This prospective study evaluated consecutive eligible seizure patients who had a plasma sample collected as part of their clinical evaluation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Plasma was tested for amphetamine and the cocaine metabolite benzoylecgonine using enzyme-mediated immunoassay methodology.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma samples with benzoylecgonine greater than 150 ng/mL or an amphetamine greater than 500 ng/mL were defined as positive.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patient demographics, history of underlying drug or alcohol-related seizure disorder, estimated time from seizure to sample collection, history or suspicion of cocaine or amphetamine abuse, results of clinical urine testing for drugs of abuse, and assay results were recorded without patient identifiers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Fourteen of 248 (5.6%, 95% CI 2.7%-8.5%) plasma samples were positive by immunoassay testing for benzoylecgonine and no samples (0%, 95% CI 0-1.2%) were positive for amphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Positive test results were more common in patient visits where there was a history or suspicion of cocaine or amphetamine abuse (p < 0.0005).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>During this study period, routine plasma screening for cocaine and amphetamines in adult seizure patients had a low yield.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>As a result, routine plasma screening would yield few cases of stimulant drug in which there was neither a history nor suspicion of drug abuse in this population.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Evidence of functional somatotopy in GPi from results of pallidotomy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The objective of this study was to explore the functional anatomy of the globus pallidus internus (GPi) by studying the effects of unilateral pallidotomy on parkinsonian 'off' signs and levodopa-induced dyskinesias (LID).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We found significant positive correlations between the preoperative levodopa responsiveness of motor signs and the levodopa responsiveness of scores in timed tests (Core Assessment Program for Intracerebral Transplantations) in the contralateral limbs and the improvement in these scores after surgery, whereas there was no correlation with the improvement in LID.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We also found a highly significant correlation (P: < 0.0001, r = 0.8) between the volume of the ventral lesion in the GPi and the improvement in LID in the contralateral limbs, whereas there was no correlation between the ventral volume and the improvement in parkinsonian 'off' signs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The volumes of the total lesion cylinder and the dorsal lesion did not correlate with the outcome of either dyskinesias or parkinsonian 'off' signs.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The differential predictive value of levodopa responsiveness for the outcome of parkinsonian 'off' signs and LID and the different correlations of ventral lesion volume with dyskinesias and parkinsonian 'off' signs indicate that different anatomical or pathophysiological substrates may be responsible for the generation of parkinsonian 'off' signs and dyskinesias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Whereas cells in a wider area of the GPi may be implicated in parkinsonism, the ventral GPi seems to be crucial for the manifestation of LID.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We suggest that our observations are additional proof of the functional somatotopy of the systems within the GPi that mediate parkinsonism and dyskinesias, especially along the dorsoventral trajectory used in pallidotomy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The outcome of pallidotomy in which the lesion involves the ventral and dorsal GPi could be the net effect of alteration in the activity of pathways which mediate different symptoms, and hence could be variable.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pain responses in methadone-maintained opioid abusers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Providing pain management for known opioid abusers is a challenging clinical task, in part because little is known about their pain experience and analgesic requirements.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This study was designed to describe pain tolerance and analgesic response in a sample of opioid addicts stabilized in methadone-maintenance (MM) treatment (n = 60) in comparison to matched nondependent control subjects (n = 60).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>By using a placebo-controlled, two-way factorial design, tolerance to cold-pressor (CP) pain was examined, both before and after oral administration of therapeutic doses of common opioid (hydromorphone 2 mg) and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory (ketorolac 10 mg) analgesic agents.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Results showed that MM individuals were significantly less tolerant of CP pain than control subjects, replicating previous work.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Analgesic effects were significant neither for medication nor group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These data indicate that MM opioid abusers represent a pain-intolerant subset of clinical patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Their complaints of pain should be evaluated seriously and managed aggressively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urine N-acetyl-beta-D-glucosaminidase--a marker of tubular damage?</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although an indicator of renal tubular dysfunction, an increased urinary N-acetyl-beta-D-glucosaminidase (NAG) activity might reflect increased lysosomal activity in renal tubular cells.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Puromycin aminonucleoside (PAN) was administered to Sprague Dawley rats to induce proteinuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Total protein, albumin, NAG activity and protein electrophoretic pattern were assessed in daily urine samples for 33 days.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The morphological appearance of the kidneys was examined on days three, four, six, eight and thirty three and the NAG isoenzyme patterns on days zero, four, eight and thirty three.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Following intravenous PAN urine volume and urine NAG activity increased significantly by day two, but returned to normal by day four.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After day four all treated animals exhibited a marked rise in urine albumin, total protein excretion and NAG activity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Electrophoresis showed a generalised increase in middle and high molecular weight urine proteins from day four onwards.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Protein droplets first appeared prominent in tubular cells on day four.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Peak urine NAG activity and a change in NAG isoenzyme pattern coincided with both the peak proteinuria and the reduction in intracellular protein and NAG droplets (day six onwards).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This animal model demonstrates that an increase in lysosomal turnover and hence urine NAG activity, occurs when increased protein is presented to the tubular cells.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urine NAG activity is thus a measure of altered function in the renal tubules and not simply an indicator of damage.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Over expression of vascular endothelial growth factor and its receptor during the development of estrogen-induced rat pituitary tumors may mediate estrogen-initiated tumor angiogenesis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Estrogens, which have been associated with several types of human and animal cancers, can induce tumor angiogenesis in the pituitary of Fischer 344 rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanistic details of tumor angiogenesis induction, during estrogen carcinogenesis, are still unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To elucidate the role of estrogen in the regulation of tumor angiogenesis in the pituitary of female rats, the density of blood vessels was analysed using factor VIII related antigen (FVIIIRAg) immunohistochemistry and the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor/vascular permeability factor (VEGF/VPF) was examined by Western blot and immunohistochemical analysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The expression of VEGF receptor (VEGFR-2/Flk-1/KDR) was also examined by immunohistochemistry.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results demonstrated that 17beta-estradiol (E2) induces neovascularization, as well as the growth and enlargement of blood vessels after 7 days of exposure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The high tumor angiogenic potential was associated with an elevated VEGF/VPF protein expression in the E2 exposed pituitary of ovariectomized (OVEX) rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>VEGF/VPF and FVIIIRAg immunohistochemistry and endothelial specific lectin (UEA1) binding studies, indicate that the elevation of VEGF protein expression initially occurred in both blood vessels and non-endothelial cells.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After 15 days of E2 exposure, VEGF/VPF protein expression, in the non-endothelial cell population, sharply declined and was restricted to the blood vessels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The function of non-endothelial-derived VEGF is not clear.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Furthermore, immunohistochemical studies demonstrated that VEGFR-2 (flk-1/KDR), expression was elevated significantly in the endothelial cells of microblood vessels after 7 days of E2 exposure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that over expression of VEGF and its receptor (VEGFR-2) may play an important role in the initial step of the regulation of estrogen induced tumor angiogenesis in the rat pituitary.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The patient, a 69-year-old man was affected by non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and hypertension.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>He was admitted with acute myopathy of the lower limbs which resolved in a few days after pravastatin discontinuation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A previously unknown hypothyroidism, probably due to chronic autoimmune thyroiditis, was evidenced.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Muscle biopsy (left gastrocnemius) revealed a perimysial and endomysial inflammatory infiltrate with a prevalence of CD4+ lymphocytes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>While lovastatin and simvastatin have been associated with toxic myopathy, pravastatin-associated myopathy could represent a distinct, inflammatory entity.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Dose-effect and structure-function relationships in doxorubicin cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The cardiomyopathy (CM) produced by the anticancer drug doxorubicin (DXR) (Adriamycin) provides a unique opportunity to analyze dose-effect and structure-function relationships during development of myocardial disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We measured the degree of morphologic damage by ultrastructural examination of endomyocardial biopsy and the degree of performance abnormally by right heart catheterization in patients receiving DXR.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Morphologic damage was variable but was proportional to the total cumulative DXR dose between 100 and 600 mg/m2.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Performance abnormalities correlated weakly with dose, exhibited a curvilinear relationship, and had a "threshold" for expression.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Catheterization abnormalities correlated well with morphologic damage (r = 0.57 to 0.78) in a subgroup of patients in whom exercise hemodynamics were measured, and this relationship also exhibited a curvilinear, threshold configuration.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In DXR-CM myocardial damage is proportional to the degree of cytotoxic insult (DXR dose) while myocardial function is preserved until a critical dose or degree of damage is reached, after which myocardial performance deteriorates rapidly.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The combined administration of CSA and various chemotherapeutic drugs with a nephrotoxic potential, such as gentamicin (at therapeutic doses), amphothericin B and ketoconazole, which are frequently used in immunosuppressed patients, did not aggravate the CSA induced toxicity in the rat model.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>At the end of each pretreatment period, animals were used for (i) determining their locomotor response to acutely injected nicotine (0.2 mg/kg, s.c.) and (ii) measuring the density of L-[3H]nicotine and [3H]spiperone binding sites in the striatum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In rats which were pretreated with nicotine for 5 days, there was a significant increase in the nicotine-stimulated locomotor response which was associated with an increase in the number of L-[3H]nicotine binding sites and also with an elevated dopamine (DA) level in the striatum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that chronic nicotine-treated rats develop locomotor hyperactivity in response to nicotine initially due to increases of both the density of nicotinic receptors and DA concentration, followed by inducing DA receptor supersensitivity in the striatum.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Although diastolic blood pressure remained unchanged, systolic blood pressure increased from 119 to 135</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Although suprofen has been associated with the development of acute renal failure in greater than 100 subjects, the mechanism of damage remains unclear.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The direct nephrotoxic effects of a single dose of 15 mg of suprofen were compared in the recirculating isolated rat kidney perfused with cell-free buffer with or without the addition of 5 mg/dL of uric acid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were no significant differences in renal sodium excretion, oxygen consumption, or urinary flow rates in kidneys perfused with suprofen compared with the drug-free control groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, a significant decline in glomerular filtration rate was found after the introduction of suprofen to the kidney perfused with uric acid; no changes were found with suprofen in the absence of uric acid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant decrease in the baseline excretion rate of uric acid was found in rats given suprofen, compared with drug-free controls.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In summary, suprofen causes acute declines in renal function, most likely by directly altering the intrarenal distribution of uric acid.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cocaine-induced brainstem seizures and behavior.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A variety of abnormal sensory/motor behaviors associated with electrical discharges recorded from the bilateral brainstem were induced in adult WKY rats by mechanical (electrode implants) and DC electrical current stimulations and by acute and chronic administration of cocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The electrode implant implicated one side or the other of the reticular system of the brainstem but subjects were not incapacitated by the stimulations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cocaine (40 mg/kg) was injected subcutaneously for an acute experiment and subsequent 20 mg/kg doses twice daily for 3 days in a chronic study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cocaine generated more abnormal behaviors in the brainstem perturbation group, especially the electrically perturbated subjects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The abnormal behaviors were yawning, retrocollis, hyperactivity, hypersensitivity, "beating drum" behavior, squealing, head bobbing, circling, sniffing, abnormal posturing, and facial twitching.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Shifts in the power frequency spectra of the discharge patterns were noted between quiet and pacing behavioral states.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Hypersensitivity to various auditory, tactile, and visual stimulation was present and shifts in the brainstem ambient power spectral frequency occurred in response to tactile stimulation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These findings suggest that the brainstem generates and propagates pathological discharges that can be elicited by mechanical and DC electrical perturbation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Cocaine was found to activate the discharge system and thus induce abnormal behaviors that are generated at the discharge site and at distant sites to which the discharge propagates.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cognitive functions may also be involved since dopaminergic and serotonergic cellular elements at the brainstem level are also implicated.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Ethinyl estradiol treatment did not impair conjugation of deoxycholic acid, but did result in an increase in sulfation of taurodeoxycholic acid from 1.5% in controls to nearly 4.0% (P less than 0.01).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Effects of ouabain on myocardial oxygen supply and demand in patients with chronic coronary artery disease. A hemodynamic, volumetric, and metabolic study in patients without heart failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of digitalis glycosides on myocardial oxygen supply and demand are of particular interest in the presence of obstructive coronary artery disease, but have not been measured previously in man.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We assessed the effects of ouabain (0.015 mg/kg body weight) on hemodynamic, volumetric, and metabolic parameters in 11 patients with severe chronic coronary artery disease without clinical congestive heart failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because the protocol was long and involved interventions which might affect the determinations, we also studied in nine patients using an identical protocol except that ouabain administration was omitted.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure and left ventricular end-diastolic volume fell in each patient given ouabain, even though they were initially elevated in only two patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure fell from 11.5+/-1.4 (mean+/-SE) to 5.6+/-0.9 mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg (P less than 0.001) and left ventricular end-diastolic volume fell from 100+/-17 to 82+/-12 ml/m2 (P less than 0.01) 1 h after ouabain infusion was completed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The maximum velocity of contractile element shortening increased from 1.68+/-0.11 ml/s to 2.18+/-0.21 muscle-lengths/s (P less than 0.05) and is consistent with an increase in contractility.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No significant change in these parameters occurred in the control patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>No significant change in myocardial oxygen consumption occurred after ouabain administration but this may be related to a greater decrease in mean arterial pressure in the ouabain patients than in the control patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that in patients with chronic coronary artery disease who are not in clinical congestive heart failure left ventricular end-diastolic volume falls after ouabain administration even when it is initially normal.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Though this fall would be associated with a decrease in wall tension, and, therefore, of myocardial oxygen consumption, it may not be of sufficient magnitude to prevent a net increase in myocardial oxygen consumption.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nevertheless, compensatory mechanisms prevent a deterioration of resting myocardial metabolism.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cisapride, a cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4) substrate, is widely prescribed for the treatment of gastrointestinal motility disorders.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Prolongation of QT interval, torsades de pointes, and sudden cardiac death have been reported after concomitant administration with erythromycin or azole antifungal agents, but not with other CYP3A4 inhibitors.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A possible drug interaction occurred in a 45-year-old woman who was taking cisapride for gastroesophageal reflux disorder and diltiazem, an agent that has inhibitory effect on CYP3A4, for hypertension.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Paclitaxel combined with carboplatin in the first-line treatment of advanced ovarian cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a phase I study to determine the maximum tolerated dose of paclitaxel (Taxol; Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, Princeton, NJ) given as a 3-hour infusion in combination with carboplatin administered every 21 days to women with advanced ovarian cancer, paclitaxel doses were escalated as follows: level 1, 135 mg/m2; level 2, 160 mg/m2; level 3, 185 mg/m2; and level 4,210 mg/m2.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The fixed dose of carboplatin at levels 1 through 4 was given to achieve an area under the concentration-time curve (AUC) of 5 using the Calvert formula.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In levels 5 and 6 the carboplatin dose was targeted at AUCs of 6 and 7.5, respectively, combined with a fixed paclitaxel dose of 185 mg/m2.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To date, 30 previously untreated patients, all with a good performance status (Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group 0 to 2) have been entered into this ongoing study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The dose-limiting toxicity of the combination was myelosuppression (leukopenia, granulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neurotoxicity was largely moderate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>So far, 14 patients are evaluable for response; of these, eight (57%) showed objective (complete or partial) response and disease stabilized in six patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No patient had disease progression.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We conclude that the combination of paclitaxel 185 mg/m2 administered as a 3-hour infusion followed immediately by a 1-hour infusion of carboplatin at an AUC of 6 can be administered safely in a 21-day schedule in the outpatient setting.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The recommended dose for phase III studies is paclitaxel 185 mg/m2 and carboplatin AUC 6.</Chemical>

We recorded indication for conversion, whether conversion was early or late after transplantation, tacrolimus dose and trough blood level at conversion, and incidence of rejection after conversion.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Conversion was early in 29 patients (41.4%) and late in 41 (58.6%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Indications for early conversion were neurotoxicity (20), (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus (IDDM) (5), nephrotoxicity (3), gastrointestinal (GI) toxicity (6), and cardiomyopathy (1), and for late conversion were neurotoxicity (15), IDDM (12), nephrotoxicity (3), GI toxicity (5), hepatotoxicity (6), post-transplant lmphoproliferate disease (PTLD) (2), cardiomyopathy (1), hemolytic anemia (1), and pruritus (1).</Chemical>
<Chemical>All early-conversion patients showed improvement/resolution of symptoms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Among late-conversion patients, 37 (90.2%) had improvement/resolution; in 4 (9.8%), adverse effects persisted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The overall rejection rate was 30%.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sixty-two patients (88.6%) are alive with functioning grafts 686 +/- 362 days (range, 154-1433 days) after conversion.</Chemical>

<Chemical>When tacrolimus side effects are unresponsive to dose reduction, conversion to CyA can be accomplished safely, with no increased risk of rejection and excellent long-term outcome.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Of those evaluated with posttherapy audiograms, three of four netilmicin and piperacillin-treated patients had auditory thresholds return to baseline compared with one of nine tobramycin and piperacillin-treated patients.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The number of greater than or equal to 15-dB increases in auditory threshold as a proportion of total greater than or equal to 15-dB changes (increases and decreases) was significantly lower in netilmicin and piperacillin- vs tobramycin and piperacillin-treated patients (18 of 78 vs 67 of 115).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We conclude that aminoglycoside-associated ototoxicity was less severe and more often reversible with netilmicin than with tobramycin.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor-associated angioedema of the stomach and small intestine: a case report.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This is a case report on a 45-year old African-American female with newly diagnosed hypertension, who was started on a combination pill of amlodipine/benazapril 10/5 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The very next day, she presented at the emergency room (ER) with abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Physical exam, complete metabolic panel, and hemogram were in the normal range.</Chemical>
<Chemical>She was discharged from the ER after a few hours of treatment with fluid and analgesics.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, she returned to the ER the next day with the same complaints.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This time the physical exam was significant for a distended abdomen with dullness to percussion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CT scan of the abdomen revealed markedly thickened antrum of the stomach, duodenum and jejunum, along with fluid in the abdominal and pelvic cavity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI)-induced angioedema was suspected, and anti-hypertensive medications were discontinued.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Her symptoms improved within the next 24 hours, and repeat CT after 72 hours revealed marked improvement in stomach and small bowel thickening and resolution of ascites.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The recognition of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) and angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) intestinal angioedema constitutes a challenge to primary care physicians, internists, emergency room personal and surgeons.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Valproic acid I: time course of lipid peroxidation biomarkers, liver toxicity, and valproic acid metabolite levels in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A single dose of valproic acid (VPA), which is a widely used antiepileptic drug, is associated with oxidative stress in rats, as recently demonstrated by elevated levels of 15-F(2t)-isoprostane (15-F(2t)-IsoP).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To determine whether there was a temporal relationship between VPA-associated oxidative stress and hepatotoxicity, adult male Sprague-Dawley rats were treated ip with VPA (500 mg/kg) or 0.9% saline (vehicle) once daily for 2, 4, 7, 10, or 14 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oxidative stress was assessed by determining plasma and liver levels of 15-F(2t)-IsoP, lipid hydroperoxides (LPO), and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma and liver 15-F(2t)-IsoP were elevated and reached a plateau after day 2 of VPA treatment compared to control.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Liver LPO levels were not elevated until day 7 of treatment (1.8-fold versus control, p < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Liver and plasma TBARs were not increased until 14 days (2-fold vs. control, p < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Liver toxicity was evaluated based on serum levels of alpha-glutathione S-transferase (alpha-GST) and by histology.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum alpha-GST levels were significantly elevated by day 4, which corresponded to hepatotoxicity as shown by the increasing incidence of inflammation of the liver capsule, necrosis, and steatosis throughout the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The liver levels of beta-oxidation metabolites of VPA were decreased by day 14, while the levels of 4-ene-VPA and (E)-2,4-diene-VPA were not elevated throughout the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Overall, these findings indicate that VPA treatment results in oxidative stress, as measured by levels of 15-F(2t)-IsoP, which precedes the onset of necrosis, steatosis, and elevated levels of serum alpha-GST.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
