text: <Chemical>In our case, use of the Naranjo probability scale indicated a possible relationship between the hypertensive crisis and amisulpride and tiapride therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Dexmedetomidine and cardiac protection for non-cardiac surgery: a meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We conducted a systematic review of the effects of dexmedetomidine on cardiac outcomes following non-cardiac surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We included prospective, randomised peri-operative studies of dexmedetomidine that reported mortality, cardiac morbidity or adverse drug events.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A PubMed Central and EMBASE search was conducted up to July 2007.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The reference lists of identified papers were examined for further trials.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of 425 studies identified, 20 were included in the meta-analysis (840 patients).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Dexmedetomidine was associated with a trend towards improved cardiac outcomes; all-cause mortality (OR 0.27, 95% CI 0.01-7.13, p = 0.44), non-fatal myocardial infarction (OR 0.26, 95% CI 0.04-1.60, p = 0.14), and myocardial ischaemia (OR 0.65, 95% CI 0.26-1.63, p = 0.36).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Peri-operative hypotension (26%, OR 3.80, 95% CI 1.91-7.54, p = 0.0001) and bradycardia (17%, OR 5.45, 95% CI 2.98-9.95, p < 0.00001) were significantly increased.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An anticholinergic did not reduce the incidence of bradycardia (p = 0.43).</Chemical>
<Chemical>A randomised placebo-controlled trial of dexmedetomidine is warranted.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The neurological and electrophysiological findings were not typical of myositis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Intravenous ribavirin treatment for severe adenovirus disease in immunocompromised children.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Adenovirus is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in the immunocompromised host.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The incidence of severe adenovirus disease in pediatrics is increasing in association with growing numbers of immunocompromised children, where case fatality rates as high as 50% to 80% have been reported.</Chemical>

<Chemical>There are no approved antiviral agents with proven efficacy for the treatment of severe adenovirus disease, nor are there any prospective randomized, controlled trials of potentially useful anti-adenovirus therapies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Apparent clinical success in the treatment of severe adenovirus disease is limited to a few case reports and small series.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Experience is greatest with intravenous ribavirin and cidofovir.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ribavirin, a guanosine analogue, has broad antiviral activity against both RNA and DNA viruses, including documented activity against adenovirus in vitro.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ribavirin is licensed in aerosol form for the treatment of respiratory syncytial virus infection, and orally in combination with interferon to treat hepatitis C. Intravenous ribavirin is the treatment of choice for infection with hemorrhagic fever viruses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The most common adverse effect of intravenous ribavirin is reversible mild anemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The use of cidofovir in severe adenovirus infection has been limited by adverse effects, the most significant of which is nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We report our experience with intravenous ribavirin therapy for severe adenovirus disease in a series of immunocompromised children and review the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN/METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We retrospectively reviewed the medical records of 5 children treated with intravenous ribavirin for documented severe adenovirus disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two patients developed adenovirus hemorrhagic cystitis after cardiac and bone marrow transplants, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The bone marrow transplant patient also received intravenous cidofovir for progressive disseminated disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An additional 3 children developed adenovirus pneumonia; 2 were neonates, 1 of whom had partial DiGeorge syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The remaining infant had recently undergone a cardiac transplant.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Intravenous ribavirin was administered on a compassionate-use protocol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Complete clinical recovery followed later by viral clearance was observed in 2 children: the cardiac transplant recipient with adenovirus hemorrhagic cystitis and the immunocompetent neonate with adenovirus pneumonia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The remaining 3 children died of adenovirus disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Intravenous ribavirin therapy was well tolerated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Use of cidofovir in 1 child was associated with progressive renal failure and neutropenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our series of patients is representative of the spectrum of immunocompromised children at greatest risk for severe adenovirus disease, namely solid-organ and bone marrow transplant recipients, neonates, and children with immunodeficiency.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although intravenous ribavirin was not effective for all children with severe adenovirus disease in this series or in the literature, therapy is unlikely to be of benefit if begun late in the course of the infection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Early identification, eg by polymerase chain reaction of those patients at risk of disseminated adenovirus disease may permit earlier antiviral treatment and better evaluation of therapeutic response.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Two of 5 children with severe adenovirus disease treated with intravenous ribavirin recovered.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The availability of newer rapid diagnostic techniques, such as polymerase chain reaction, may make earlier, more effective treatment of adenovirus infection possible.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Given the seriousness and increasing prevalence of adenovirus disease in certain hosts, especially children, a large, multicenter clinical trial of potentially useful anti-adenoviral therapies, such as intravenous ribavirin, is clearly required to demonstrate the most effective and least toxic therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hepatotoxicity of amiodarone.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Amiodarone has proved very effective in the treatment of otherwise resistant cardiac tachyarrhythmias.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The use of amiodarone has, however, been limited due to its serious side-effects.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A patient with cholestatic hepatitis due to amiodarone treatment is presented below and a review of the hepatotoxicity of amiodarone is given.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>It is concluded that solid evidence exists of hepatic injury due to amiodarone treatment, including steatosis, alterations resembling alcoholic hepatitis, cholestatic hepatitis and micronodular cirrhosis of the liver.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Catalepsy induced by combinations of ketamine and morphine: potentiation, antagonism, tolerance and cross-tolerance in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous studies demonstrated that both ketamine and morphine induced analgesia and catalepsy in the rat.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Pre-treatment with ketamine produced cross-tolerance to morphine, whereas pretreatment with morphine did not induce cross-tolerance to ketamine but rather augmented the cataleptic response; this augmentation was attributed to residual morphine in the brain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present studies explored the duration of the loss of righting reflex induced by sub-effective doses of ketamine and morphine, administered simultaneously.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was mutual potentiation between sub-effective doses of ketamine and morphine, but sub-effective doses of ketamine partly antagonized fully-effective doses of morphine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Latency to the loss of righting reflex, rigidity and behavior on recovery, reflected the relative predominance of ketamine or morphine in each combination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Naloxone inhibited the induced cataleptic effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The degree and time course of development of tolerance to daily administration of sub-effective dose combinations of ketamine and morphine were similar.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats, tolerant to ketamine-dominant combinations, were cross-tolerant to both drugs, while those tolerant to morphine-dominant combinations were cross-tolerant to morphine but showed either no cross-tolerance or an augmented response to ketamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>While the mutual potentiation, antagonism and tolerance suggest common mechanisms for the induced catalepsy, differences in latency, rigidity and behavior, asymmetry of cross-tolerance and a widely-different ID50 for naloxone would argue against an action at a single opioid site.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Delayed leukoencephalopathy with stroke-like presentation in chemotherapy recipients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A transient leukoencephalopathy mimicking cerebrovascular accident has been described as a complication of chemotherapy, most commonly in recipients of intrathecal methotrexate for childhood leukaemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recently published neuroimaging data suggest a common pathophysiology associated with a variety of chemotherapy agents and modes of administration.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We reviewed the medical literature for single reports and case series of patients presenting with stroke-like episodes while receiving systemic or intrathecal chemotherapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We only included studies providing detailed neuroimaging data.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients with cerebrovascular accidents were excluded.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We identified 27 reports of toxic leukoencephalopathy in patients treated with methotrexate (intrathecal, systemic), 5-fluorouracil and its derivative carmofur, and capecitabine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diffusion weighted imaging (DWI) of all patients revealed well demarcated hyperintense lesions within the subcortical white matter of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus callosum, corresponding to areas of decreased proton diffusion on apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) maps (available in 21/27 patients).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lesions exceeded the confines of adjacent vascular territories.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Complete resolution of symptoms within 1-4 days was accompanied by normalisation of ADC abnormalities.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) sequences frequently revealed persistent white matter abnormalities.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Several pathophysiological models of delayed leukoencephalopathy after exposure to intrathecal or systemic chemotherapy have been proposed.</Chemical>

<Chemical>DWI findings in this cohort are indicative of cytotoxic oedema within cerebral white matter and lend support to an at least partially reversible metabolic derangement as the basis for this syndrome.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Daily administration of desipramine increased the incidence of appearance of lidocaine-induced convulsions and decreased that of cocaine-induced convulsions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Co-administration of lidocaine with desipramine reversed the changes of convulsive activity of lidocaine and cocaine induced by repeated administration of desipramine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that down-regulation of hippocampal NET induced by chronic administration of desipramine may be relevant to desipramine-induced sensitization of lidocaine convulsions.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Definition and management of anemia in patients infected with hepatitis C virus.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Chronic infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV) can progress to cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and end-stage liver disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The current best treatment for HCV infection is combination therapy with pegylated interferon and ribavirin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although this regimen produces sustained virologic responses (SVRs) in approximately 50% of patients, it can be associated with a potentially dose-limiting hemolytic anemia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Hemoglobin concentrations decrease mainly as a result of ribavirin-induced hemolysis, and this anemia can be problematic in patients with HCV infection, especially those who have comorbid renal or cardiovascular disorders.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In general, anemia can increase the risk of morbidity and mortality, and may have negative effects on cerebral function and quality of life.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although ribavirin-associated anemia can be reversed by dose reduction or discontinuation, this approach compromises outcomes by significantly decreasing SVR rates.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recombinant human erythropoietin has been used to manage ribavirin-associated anemia but has other potential disadvantages.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Viramidine, a liver-targeting prodrug of ribavirin, has the potential to maintain the virologic efficacy of ribavirin while decreasing the risk of hemolytic anemia in patients with chronic hepatitis C.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Calcium carbonate toxicity: the updated milk-alkali syndrome; report of 3 cases and review of the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To describe 3 patients with calcium carbonate-induced hypercalcemia and gain insights into the cause and management of the milk-alkali syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We report the clinical and laboratory data in 3 patients who presented with severe hypercalcemia (corrected serum calcium > or = 14 mg/dL) and review the pertinent literature on milk-alkali syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The 3 patients had acute renal insufficiency, relative metabolic alkalosis, and low parathyroid hormone (PTH), PTH-related peptide, and 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D concentrations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>No malignant lesion was found.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment included aggressive hydration and varied amounts of furosemide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The 2 patients with the higher serum calcium concentrations received pamidronate intravenously (60 and 30 mg, respectively), which caused severe hypocalcemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the 3 patients, 2 were ingesting acceptable doses of elemental calcium (1 g and 2 g daily, respectively) in the form of calcium carbonate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition to our highlighted cases, we review the history, classification, pathophysiologic features, and treatment of milk-alkali syndrome and summarize the cases reported from early 1995 to November 2003.</Chemical>

<Chemical>CONCLUSION: Milk-alkali syndrome may be a common cause of unexplained hypercalcemia and can be precipitated by small amounts of orally ingested calcium carbonate in susceptible persons.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment with hydration, furosemide, and discontinuation of the calcium and vitamin D source is adequate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pamidronate treatment is associated with considerable risk for hypocalcemia, even in cases of initially severe hypercalcemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Management strategies for ribavirin-induced hemolytic anemia in the treatment of hepatitis C: clinical and economic implications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Recently published studies have demonstrated increased efficacy and cost-effectiveness of combination therapy with interferon and alpha-2b/ribavirin compared with interferon-alpha monotherapy in the treatment of chronic hepatitis C (CHC).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Combination therapy is associated with a clinically important adverse effect: ribavirin-induced hemolytic anemia (RIHA).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The objective of this study was to evaluate the direct health-care costs and management of RIHA during treatment of CHC in a clinical trial setting.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A systematic literature review was conducted to synthesize information on the incidence and management of RIHA.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Decision-analytic techniques were used to estimate the cost of treating RIHA.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Uncertainty was evaluated using sensitivity analyses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: RIHA, defined as a reduction in hemoglobin to less than 100 g/L, occurs in approximately 7% to 9% of patients treated with combination therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The standard of care for management of RIHA is reduction or discontinuation of the ribavirin dosage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We estimated the direct cost of treating clinically significant RIHA to be  170 per patient receiving combination therapy per 48-week treatment course (range  68- 692).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results of the one-way sensitivity analyses ranged from  57 to  317.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In comparison, the cost of 48 weeks of combination therapy is  16,459.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The direct cost of treating clinically significant RIHA is 1% ( 170/ 16,459) of drug treatment costs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Questions remain about the optimal dose of ribavirin and the incidence of RIHA in a real-world population.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite these uncertainties, this initial evaluation of the direct cost of treating RIHA provides an estimate of the cost and management implications of this clinically important adverse effect.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effects of amine pretreatment on ketamine catatonia in pinealectomized or hypophysectomized animals.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The present studies were designed to clarify the role of catecholamines and pineal idolamines on ketamine-induced catatonia in the intact, pinealectomized or hypophysectomized chick and rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the pinealectomized chick, pretreatment with dopamine increased the duration of catatonia (DOC) after ketamine, but pretreatment with norepinephrine did not.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The pineal indolamines exhibited mixed actions.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Serotonin and N-acetyl serotonin which augmented ketamine DOC, did not do so in the absence of the pineal gland, whereas melatonin potentiated the ketamine DOC in both the intact and pinealectomized chick.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study did not demonstrate a species difference regarding the role of the amines on the pineal in spite of the immature blood-brain barrier in the young chick and the intact barrier in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, these data indicate a direct role of the pituitary in the augmentation of ketamine DOC induced by melatonin.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Multicenter, double-blind, multiple-dose, parallel-groups efficacy and safety trial of azelastine, chlorpheniramine, and placebo in the treatment of spring allergic rhinitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Azelastine, a novel antiallergic medication, was compared with chlorpheniramine maleate and placebo for efficacy and safety in the treatment of spring allergic rhinitis in a multicenter, double-blind, multiple-dose, parallel-groups study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One hundred fifty-five subjects participated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Subjects ranged in age from 18 to 60 years of age and had at least a 2-year history of spring allergic rhinitis, confirmed by positive skin test to spring aeroallergens.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Medications were given four times daily; the azelastine groups received 0.5, 1.0, or 2.0 mg in the morning and evening with placebo in the early and late afternoon; the chlorpheniramine group received 4.0 mg four times daily.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Daily subject symptom cards were completed during a screening period to assess pretreatment symptoms and during a 4-week treatment period while subjects received study medications.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Individual symptoms, total symptoms, and major symptoms were compared to determine efficacy of medication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Elicited, volunteered, and observed adverse experiences were recorded for each subject and compared among groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Vital signs, body weights, serum chemistry values, complete blood cell counts, urine studies, and electrocardiograms were obtained for each subject and compared among groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Symptoms relief in the group receiving the highest concentration of azelastine (2.0 mg twice daily) was statistically greater than in the placebo group during all weeks of the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lower doses of azelastine were statistically more effective than placebo only during portions of the first 3 weeks of the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, although the chlorpheniramine group did have fewer symptoms than the placebo group during the study, the difference never reached statistical significance during any week of the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were no serious side effects in any of the treatment groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Drowsiness and altered taste perception were increased significantly over placebo only in the high-dose azelastine group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Azelastine appears to be a safe, efficacious medication for seasonal allergic rhinitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The powders had been obtained from pharmacists unknown to the patients' medical practitioners.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Prolonged paralysis due to nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents and corticosteroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The long-term use of nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (ND-NMBA) has recently been implicated as a cause of prolonged muscle weakness, although the site of the lesion and the predisposing factors have been unclear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report 3 patients (age 37-52 years) with acute respiratory insufficiency who developed prolonged weakness following the discontinuation of ND-NMBAs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two patients also received intravenous corticosteroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Renal function was normal but hepatic function was impaired in all patients, and all had acidosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Electrophysiologic studies revealed low amplitude compound motor action potentials, normal sensory studies, and fibrillations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Repetitive stimulation at 2 Hz showed a decremental response in 2 patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The serum vecuronium level measured in 1 patient 14 days after the drug had been discontinued was 172 ng/mL. A muscle biopsy in this patient showed loss of thick, myosin filaments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The weakness in these patients is due to pathology at both the neuromuscular junction (most likely due to ND-NMBA) and muscle (most likely due to corticosteroids).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hepatic dysfunction and acidosis are contributing risk factors.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prostaglandin E2-induced bladder hyperactivity in normal, conscious rats: involvement of tachykinins?</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In normal conscious rats investigated by continuous cystometry, intravesically instilled prostaglandin (PG) E2 facilitated micturition and increased basal intravesical pressure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect was attenuated by both the NK1 receptor selective antagonist RP 67,580 and the NK2 receptor selective antagonist SR 48,968, given intra-arterially, suggesting that it was mediated by stimulation of both NK1 and NK2 receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intra-arterially given PGE2 produced a distinct increase in bladder pressure before initiating a micturition reflex, indicating that the PG had a direct contractant effect on the detrusor smooth muscle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of intra-arterial PGE2 could not be blocked by intra-arterial RP 67,580 or SR 48,968, which opens the possibility that the micturition reflex elicited by intra-arterial PGE2 was mediated by pathways other than the reflex initiated when the PG was given intravesically.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present results thus suggest that intra-arterial PGE2, given near the bladder, may initiate micturition in the normal rat chiefly by directly contracting the smooth muscle of the detrusor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, when given intravesically, PGE2 may stimulate micturition by releasing tachykinins from nerves in and/or immediately below the urothelium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These tachykinins, in turn, initiate a micturition reflex by stimulating NK1 and NK2 receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prostanoids may, via release of tachykinins, contribute to both urge and bladder hyperactivity seen in inflammatory conditions of the lower urinary tract.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thiazide diuretics, hypokalemia and cardiac arrhythmias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thiazide diuretics are widely accepted as the cornerstone of antihypertensive treatment programs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hypokalemia is a commonly encountered metabolic consequence of chronic thiazide therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We treated 38 patients (22 low renin, 16 normal renin) with moderate diastolic hypertension with hydrochlorothiazide (HCTC) administered on a twice daily schedule.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Initial dose was 50 mg and the dose was increased at monthly intervals to 100 mg, 150 mg and 200 mg daily until blood pressure normalized.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The serum K during the control period was 4.5 +/- 0.2 mEq/l an on 50, 100, 150 and 200 mg HCTZ daily 3.9 +/- 0.3, 3.4 +/- 0.2, 2.9 +/- 0.2, and 2.4 +/- 0.3 mEq/l, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Corresponding figures for whole body K were 4107 +/- 208, 3722 +/- 319, 3628 +/- 257, 3551 +/- 336, and 3269 +/- 380 mEq, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 13 patients we observed the effects of HCTZ therapy (100 mg daily) on the occurrence of PVC's during rest as well as during static and dynamic exercise.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During rest we observed 0.6 +/- 0.08 PVC beats/min +/- SEM and during static and dynamic exercise 0.6 +/- 0.06 and 0.8 +/- 0.15, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Corresponding figures during HCTZ therapy 100 mg daily were 1.4 +/- 0.1, 3.6 +/- 0.7 and 5.7 4/- 0.8, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The occurrence of PVC's correlated significantly with the fall in serum K+ observed r = 0.72, p less than 0.001.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion we found that thiazide diuretics cause hypokalemia and depletion of body potassium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The more profound hypokalemia, the greater the propensity for the occurrence of PVC's.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Diuretics, potassium and arrhythmias in hypertensive coronary disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It has been proposed that modest changes in plasma potassium can alter the tendency towards cardiac arrhythmias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>If this were so, patients with coronary artery disease might be especially susceptible.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Thus, myocardial electrical excitability was measured in patients with mild essential hypertension and known coronary artery disease after 8 weeks of treatment with a potassium-conserving diuretic (amiloride) and a similar period on a potassium-losing diuretic (chlorthalidone) in a randomised study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma potassium concentrations were on average 1 mmol/L lower during the chlorthalidone phase compared to amiloride therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Blood pressure and volume states as assessed by bodyweight, plasma renin and noradrenaline (norepinephrine) concentrations were similar on the 2 regimens.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared to amiloride treatment, the chlorthalidone phase was associated with an increased frequency of ventricular ectopic beats (24-hour Holter monitoring) and a higher Lown grading, increased upslope and duration of the monophasic action potential, prolonged ventricular effective refractory period, and increased electrical instability during programmed ventricular stimulation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The above results indicate that because potassium-losing diuretic therapy can increase myocardial electrical excitability in patients with ischaemic heart disease, even minor falls in plasma potassium concentrations are probably best avoided in such patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>GABA involvement in naloxone induced reversal of respiratory paralysis produced by thiopental.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>No agent is yet available to reverse respiratory paralysis produced by CNS depressants, such as general anesthetics.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this study naloxone reversed respiratory paralysis induced by thiopental in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>25 mg/kg, i.v. thiopental produced anesthesia without altering respiratory rate, increased GABA, decreased glutamate, and had no effect on aspartate or glycine levels compared to controls in rat cortex and brain stem.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pretreatment of rats with thiosemicarbazide for 30 minutes abolished the anesthetic action as well as the respiratory depressant action of thiopental.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>50 mg/kg, i.v. thiopental produced respiratory arrest with further increase in GABA and decrease in glutamate again in cortex and brain stem without affecting any of the amino acids studied in four regions of rat brain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Naloxone (2.5 mg/kg, i.v.) reversed respiratory paralysis, glutamate and GABA levels to control values in brain stem and cortex with no changes in caudate or cerebellum.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data suggest naloxone reverses respiratory paralysis produced by thiopental and involves GABA in its action.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Similar results were obtained by acetic acid writhing tests.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Swallowing-induced atrial tachyarrhythmia triggered by salbutamol: case report and review of the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 49-year-old patient experienced chest discomfort while swallowing.</Chemical>
<Chemical>On electrocardiogram, episodes of atrial tachyarrhythmia were recorded immediately after swallowing; 24-hour Holter monitoring recorded several events.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The arrhythmia resolved after therapy with atenolol, but recurred a year later.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient noticed that before these episodes he had been using an inhalator of salbutamol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After stopping the beta-agonist, and after a week with the atenolol, the arrhythmia disappeared.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Swallowing-induced atrial tachyarrhythmia (SIAT) is a rare phenomenon.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fewer than 50 cases of SIAT have been described in the literature.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This article summarizes all the cases published, creating a comprehensive review of the current knowledge and approach to SIAT.</Chemical>

<Chemical>It discusses demographics, clinical characteristics and types of arrhythmia, postulated mechanisms of SIAT, and different treatment possibilities such as medications, surgery, and radiofrequency catheter ablation (RFCA).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Salbutamol is presented here as a possible trigger for SIAT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although it is difficult to define causality in a case report, it is logical to think that a beta-agonist like salbutamol (known to induce tachycardia) may be the trigger of adrenergic reflexes originating in the esophagus while swallowing and that a beta-blocker such as atenolol (that blocks the adrenergic activity) may relieve it.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Coenzyme Q10 treatment ameliorates acute cisplatin nephrotoxicity in mice.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The nephroprotective effect of coenzyme Q10 was investigated in mice with acute renal injury induced by a single i.p. injection of cisplatin (5 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Coenzyme Q10 treatment (10 mg/kg/day, i.p.) was applied for 6 consecutive days, starting 1 day before cisplatin administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Coenzyme Q10 significantly reduced blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine levels which were increased by cisplatin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Coenzyme Q10 significantly compensated deficits in the antioxidant defense mechanisms (reduced glutathione level and superoxide dismutase activity), suppressed lipid peroxidation, decreased the elevations of tumor necrosis factor-alpha, nitric oxide and platinum ion concentration, and attenuated the reductions of selenium and zinc ions in renal tissue resulted from cisplatin administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Also, histopathological renal tissue damage mediated by cisplatin was ameliorated by coenzyme Q10 treatment.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that coenzyme Q10 significantly decreased the cisplatin-induced overexpression of inducible nitric oxide synthase, nuclear factor-kappaB, caspase-3 and p53 in renal tissue.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It was concluded that coenzyme Q10 represents a potential therapeutic option to protect against acute cisplatin nephrotoxicity commonly encountered in clinical practice.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Metformin prevents experimental gentamicin-induced nephropathy by a mitochondria-dependent pathway.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The antidiabetic drug metformin can diminish apoptosis induced by oxidative stress in endothelial cells and prevent vascular dysfunction even in nondiabetic patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here we tested whether it has a beneficial effect in a rat model of gentamicin toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mitochondrial analysis, respiration intensity, levels of reactive oxygen species, permeability transition, and cytochrome c release were assessed 3 and 6 days after gentamicin administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Metformin treatment fully blocked gentamicin-mediated acute renal failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This was accompanied by a lower activity of N-acetyl-beta-D-glucosaminidase, together with a decrease of lipid peroxidation and increase of antioxidant systems.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Metformin also protected the kidney from histological damage 6 days after gentamicin administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These in vivo markers of kidney dysfunction and their correction by metformin were complemented by in vitro studies of mitochondrial function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We found that gentamicin treatment depleted respiratory components (cytochrome c, NADH), probably due to the opening of mitochondrial transition pores.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These injuries, partly mediated by a rise in reactive oxygen species from the electron transfer chain, were significantly decreased by metformin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, our study suggests that pleiotropic effects of metformin can lessen gentamicin nephrotoxicity and improve mitochondrial homeostasis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Sedation depth during spinal anesthesia and the development of postoperative delirium in elderly patients undergoing hip fracture repair.</Chemical>

<Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To determine whether limiting intraoperative sedation depth during spinal anesthesia for hip fracture repair in elderly patients can decrease the prevalence of postoperative delirium.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We performed a double-blind, randomized controlled trial at an academic medical center of elderly patients (>or=65 years) without preoperative delirium or severe dementia who underwent hip fracture repair under spinal anesthesia with propofol sedation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sedation depth was titrated using processed electroencephalography with the bispectral index (BIS), and patients were randomized to receive either deep (BIS, approximately 50) or light (BIS, >or=80) sedation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Postoperative delirium was assessed as defined by Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Third Edition Revised) criteria using the Confusion Assessment Method beginning at any time from the second day after surgery.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>From April 2, 2005, through October 30, 2008, a total of 114 patients were randomized.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The prevalence of postoperative delirium was significantly lower in the light sedation group (11/57 [19%] vs 23/57 [40%] in the deep sedation group; P=.02), indicating that 1 incident of delirium will be prevented for every 4.7 patients treated with light sedation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean +/- SD number of days of delirium during hospitalization was lower in the light sedation group than in the deep sedation group (0.5+/-1.5 days vs 1.4+/-4.0 days; P=.01).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The use of light propofol sedation decreased the prevalence of postoperative delirium by 50% compared with deep sedation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Limiting depth of sedation during spinal anesthesia is a simple, safe, and cost-effective intervention for preventing postoperative delirium in elderly patients that could be widely and readily adopted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sorafenib-induced acute myocardial infarction due to coronary artery spasm.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A 65-year-old man with advanced renal cell carcinoma was admitted due to continuing chest pain at rest.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two weeks before his admission, sorafenib had been started.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>He was diagnosed with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction by laboratory data and electrocardiogram.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Enhanced heart magnetic resonance imaging also showed subendocardial infarction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, there was no stenosis in coronary arteries on angiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Coronary artery spasm was induced by a provocative test.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cessation of sorafenib and administration of Ca-channel blocker and nitrates ameliorated his symptoms, but relapse occurred after resumption of sorafenib.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Addition of oral nicorandil reduced his symptoms and maintained stable angina status.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We report the first case of sorafenib-induced coronary artery spasm.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sorafenib is a multikinase inhibitor that targets signaling pathways necessary for cellular proliferation and survival.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>On the other hand, the Rho/ROCK pathway has an important role in the pathogenesis of coronary artery spasm.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Anxiogenic potential of ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>INTRODUCTION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The possible anxiogenic effects of fluoroquinolones, namely ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin, were investigated in adult Charles Foster albino rats of either sex, weighing 150-200 g. METHODS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The drugs were given orally, in doses of 50 mg/kg for five consecutive days and the experiments were performed on the fifth day.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The tests included open-field exploratory behaviour, elevated plus maze and elevated zero maze, social interaction and novelty-suppressed feeding latency behaviour.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results indicate that ciprofloxacin- and norfloxacin-treated rats showed anxious behaviour in comparison to control rats in all the parameters studied.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, ciprofloxacin- and norfloxacin-treated rats did not differ significantly from each other in various behavioural parameters.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The present experimental findings substantiate the clinically observed anxiogenic potential of ciprofloxacin and norfloxacin.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Myocardial Fas ligand expression increases susceptibility to AZT-induced cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and myocarditis occur in many HIV-infected individuals, resulting in symptomatic heart failure in up to 5% of patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) has significantly reduced morbidity and mortality of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), but has resulted in an increase in cardiac and skeletal myopathies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In order to investigate whether the HAART component zidovudine (3'-azido-2',3'-deoxythymidine; AZT) triggers the Fas-dependent cell-death pathway and cause cytoskeletal disruption in a murine model of DCM, 8-week-old transgenic (expressing Fas ligand in the myocardium: FasL Tg) and non-transgenic (NTg)</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>mice received water ad libitum containing different concentrations of AZT (0, 0.07, 0.2, and 0.7 mg/ml).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 6 weeks, cardiac function was assessed by echocardiography and morphology was assessed by histopathologic and immunohistochemical methods.</Chemical>
<Chemical>NTg and untreated FasL</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tg mice showed little or no change in cardiac structure or function.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In contrast, AZT-treated FasL Tg mice developed cardiac dilation and depressed cardiac function in a dose-dependent manner, with concomitant inflammatory infiltration of both ventricles.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These changes were associated with an increased sarcolemmal expression of Fas and FasL, as well as increased activation of caspase 3, translocation of calpain 1 to the sarcolemma and sarcomere, and increased numbers of cells undergoing apoptosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These were associated with changes in dystrophin and cardiac troponin I localization, as well as loss of sarcolemmal integrity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The expression of Fas ligand in the myocardium, as identified in HIV-positive patients, might increase the susceptibility to HAART-induced cardiomyopathy due to activation of apoptotic pathways, resulting in cardiac dilation and dysfunction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Valproate-induced chorea and encephalopathy in atypical nonketotic hyperglycinemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nonketotic hyperglycinemia is a disorder of amino acid metabolism in which a defect in the glycine cleavage system leads to an accumulation of glycine in the brain and other body compartments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the classical form it presents as neonatal apnea, intractable seizures, and hypotonia, followed by significant psychomotor retardation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An important subset of children with nonketotic hyperglycinemia are atypical variants who present in a heterogeneous manner.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This report describes a patient with mild language delay and mental retardation, who was found to have nonketotic hyperglycinemia following her presentation with acute encephalopathy and chorea shortly after initiation of valproate therapy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Microinjection of ritanserin into the CA1 region of hippocampus improves scopolamine-induced amnesia in adult male rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of ritanserin (5-HT2 antagonist) on scopolamine (muscarinic cholinergic antagonist)-induced amnesia in Morris water maze (MWM) was investigated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats were divided into eight groups and bilaterally cannulated into CA1 region of the hippocampus.</Chemical>

<Chemical>One week later, they received repeatedly vehicles (saline, DMSO, saline+DMSO), scopolamine (2 microg/0.5 microl saline/side; 30 min before training), ritanserin (2, 4 and 8 microg/0.5 microl DMSO/side; 20 min before training) and scopolamine (2 microg/0.5 microl; 30 min before ritanserin injection)+ritanserin (4 microg/0.5 microl DMSO) through cannulae each day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Animals were tested for four consecutive days (4 trial/day) in MWM during which the position of hidden platform was unchanged.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the fifth day, the platform was elevated above the water surface in another position to evaluate the function of motor, motivational and visual systems.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results showed a significant increase in escape latencies and traveled distances to find platform in scopolamine-treated group as compared to saline group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ritanserin-treated rats (4 microg/0.5 microl/side) showed a significant decrease in the mentioned parameters as compared to DMSO-treated group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, scopolamine and ritanserin co-administration resulted in a significant decrease in escape latencies and traveled distances as compared to the scopolamine-treated rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our findings show that microinjection of ritanserin into the CA1 region of the hippocampus improves the scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Hypoxia in renal disease with proteinuria and/or glomerular hypertension.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Despite the increasing need to identify and quantify tissue oxygenation at the cellular level, relatively few methods have been available.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study, we developed a new hypoxia-responsive reporter vector using a hypoxia-responsive element of the 5' vascular endothelial growth factor untranslated region and generated a novel hypoxia-sensing transgenic rat.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We then applied this animal model to the detection of tubulointerstitial hypoxia in the diseased kidney.</Chemical>

<Chemical>With this model, we were able to identify diffuse cortical hypoxia in the puromycin aminonucleoside-induced nephrotic syndrome and focal and segmental hypoxia in the remnant kidney model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Expression of the hypoxia-responsive transgene increased throughout the observation period, reaching 2.2-fold at 2 weeks in the puromycin aminonucleoside model and 2.6-fold at 4 weeks in the remnant kidney model, whereas that of vascular endothelial growth factor showed a mild decrease, reflecting distinct behaviors of the two genes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The degree of hypoxia showed a positive correlation with microscopic tubulointerstitial injury in both models.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Finally, we identified the localization of proliferating cell nuclear antigen-positive, ED-1-positive, and terminal dUTP nick-end labeled-positive cells in the hypoxic cortical area in the remnant kidney model.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We propose here a possible pathological tie between chronic tubulointerstitial hypoxia and progressive glomerular diseases.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Consensus statement concerning cardiotoxicity occurring during haematopoietic stem cell transplantation in the treatment of autoimmune diseases, with special reference to systemic sclerosis and multiple sclerosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Autologous haematopoietic stem cell transplantation is now a feasible and effective treatment for selected patients with severe autoimmune diseases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Worldwide, over 650 patients have been transplanted in the context of phase I and II clinical trials.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results are encouraging enough to begin randomised phase III trials.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, as predicted, significant transplant-related morbidity and mortality have been observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This is primarily due to complications related to either the stage of the disease at transplant or due to infections.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The number of deaths related to cardiac toxicity is low.</Chemical>

<Chemical>However, caution is required when cyclophosphamide or anthracyclines such as mitoxantrone are used in patients with a possible underlying heart damage, for example, systemic sclerosis patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In November 2002, a meeting was held in Florence, bringing together a number of experts in various fields, including rheumatology, cardiology, neurology, pharmacology and transplantation medicine.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The object of the meeting was to analyse existing data, both published or available, in the European Group for Blood and Marrow Transplantation autoimmune disease database, and to propose a safe approach to such patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A full cardiological assessment before and during the transplant emerged as the major recommendation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Immunohistochemical study on inducible type of nitric oxide (iNOS), basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and tumor growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1) in arteritis induced in rats by fenoldopam and theophylline, vasodilators.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Arteritis induced in rats by vasodilators, fenoldopam and theophylline, was examined immunohistochemically for expressions of inducible type of nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF) and tumor growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats were administered fenoldopam for 24 hours by intravenous infusion with or without following repeated daily oral administrations of theophylline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Irrespective of theophylline administration, iNOS antigens were remarkably abundant in ED-1-positive cells on day 5 and 8 post-fenoldopam-infusion (DPI); bFGF antigens were remarkably abundant in ED-1-positive cells on 1 and 3 DPI; TGF-beta1 antigens were observed in ED-1-positive cells on and after 5 DPI.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that the peak expression of iNOS antigen was followed by that of bFGF antigen, and bFGF may have a suppressive effect on iNOS expression in these rat arteritis models.</Chemical>
<Chemical>On the other hand, TGF-beta1 was not considered to have a suppressive effect on iNOS expression in these models.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Low-molecular-weight heparin for the treatment of patients with mechanical heart valves.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The interruption of oral anticoagulant (OAC) administration is sometimes indicated in patients with mechanical heart valves, mainly before noncardiac surgery, non-surgical interventions, and pregnancy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Unfractionated heparin (UH) is currently the substitute for selected patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) offers theoretical advantages over UH, but is not currently considered in clinical guidelines as an alternative to UH in patients with prosthetic valves.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>HYPOTHESIS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim of the present study was to review the data accumulated so far on the use of LMWH in this patient population and to discuss its applicability in common practice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>For this paper, the current medical literature on LMWH in patients with mechanical heart valves was extensively reviewed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were eight series and six case reports.</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of the studies was randomized, and only one was prospective.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Data to establish the thromboembolic risk were incomplete.</Chemical>

<Chemical>After excluding case reports, the following groups were constructed: (a) short-term administration, after valve insertion (n = 212); (b) short-term, perioperative (noncardiac)/periprocedural (n = 114); (c) long-term, due to intolerance to OAC (n = 16); (d) long-term, in pregnancy (n = 10).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The incidence rate of thromboembolism was 0.9% for all the studies and 0.5, 0, 20, and 0% in groups a, b, c, and d, respectively; for hemorrhage, the overall rate was 3.4% (3.8, 2.6, 10, and 0% for the respective groups).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In patients with mechanical heart valves, short-term LMWH therapy compares favorably with UH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Data on mid- and long-term LMWH administration in these patients are sparse.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further randomized studies are needed to confirm the safety and precise indications for the use of LMWH in patients with mechanical heart valves.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Topiramate-induced nephrolithiasis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Topiramate is a recently developed antiepileptic medication that is becoming more widely prescribed because of its efficacy in treating refractory seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urologists should be aware that this medication can cause metabolic acidosis in patients secondary to inhibition of carbonic anhydrase.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition, a distal tubular acidification defect may result, thus impairing the normal compensatory drop in urine pH.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These factors can lead to the development of calcium phosphate nephrolithiasis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report the first two cases of topiramate-induced nephrolithiasis in the urologic literature.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Spironolactone: is it a novel drug for the prevention of amphotericin B-related hypokalemia in cancer patients?</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nephrotoxicity is the major adverse effect of amphotericin B (AmB), often limiting administration of full dosage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Selective distal tubular epithelial toxicity seems to be responsible for the profound potassium wasting that is a major clinical side effect of treatment with AmB. Potassium depletion also potentiates the tubular toxicity of AmB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study was designed to assess the ability of spironolactone to reduce potassium requirements and to prevent hypokalemia in neutropenic patients on AmB treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study 26 patients with various hematological disorders were randomized to receive either intravenous AmB alone or AmB and oral spironolactone 100 mg twice daily when developing a proven or suspected fungal infection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients receiving concomitant AmB and spironolactone had significantly higher plasma potassium levels than those receiving AmB alone (P = 0.0027).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Those patients receiving AmB and spironolactone required significantly less potassium supplementation to maintain their plasma potassium within the normal range (P = 0.022).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, urinary potassium losses were significantly less in patients receiving AmB and spironolactone than those receiving AmB alone (P = 0.040).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study showed that spironolactone can reduce potassium requirements and prevent hypokalemia by reducing urinary potassium loss in neutropenic patients on AmB treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dopamine D2 receptor signaling controls neuronal cell death induced by muscarinic and glutamatergic drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dopamine (DA), through D1/D2 receptor-mediated signaling, plays a major role in the control of epileptic seizures arising in the limbic system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Excitotoxicity leading to neuronal cell death in the affected areas is a major consequence of seizures at the cellular level.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this respect, little is known about the role of DA receptors in the occurrence of epilepsy-induced neuronal cell death.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here we analyze the occurrence of seizures and neurotoxicity in D2R -/- mice treated with the cholinergic agonist pilocarpine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We compared these results with those previously obtained with kainic acid (KA), a potent glutamate agonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Importantly, D2R -/- mice develop seizures at doses of both drugs that are not epileptogenic for WT littermates and show greater neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, pilocarpine-induced seizures result in a more widespread neuronal death in both WT and D2R -/- brains in comparison to KA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, the absence of D2R lowers the threshold for seizures induced by both glutamate and acetylcholine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, the dopaminergic control of epilepsy-induced neurodegeneration seems to be mediated by distinct interactions of D2R signaling with these two neurotransmitters.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia with a dopamine agonist in children.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Risperidone, a potent antagonist of both serotonergic (5HT2A) and dopaminergic D2 receptors is associated with hyperprolactinemia in adults and children.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronically elevated prolactin levels in children with prolactinomas may be associated with arrested growth and development resulting in either delayed puberty or short stature.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These possibilities stress the importance of developing a safe and effective approach to drug-induced hyperprolactinemia in youth.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We report the successful treatment of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia with cabergoline in youth.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We undertook a retrospective case review of four children with risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia treated with cabergoline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Four males (age 6-11 years) with Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (fourth edition) bipolar disorder or psychoses, with risperidone-induced elevations in serum prolactin levels (57.5-129 ng/mL, normal 5-15 ng/mL), were treated with cabergoline (mean dose 2.13 +/- 0.09 mg/week).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>When serum prolactin levels normalized in all four subjects (mean 11.2 +/- 10.9 ng/mL), the cabergoline dose was reduced to 1 mg/week in three of four subjects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mean duration of therapy with cabergoline was 523.5 +/- 129.7 days, and the mean duration of therapy with risperidone was 788.5 +/- 162.5 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cabergoline was well tolerated without adverse effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cabergoline may be useful for the treatment of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia in youth; however, further research is needed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cholestatic jaundice associated with the use of metformin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a patient who developed cholestatic jaundice shortly after initiation of treatment with metformin hydrochloride.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ultrasound of the liver and abdominal CT were normal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An ERCP showed normal biliary anatomy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A percutaneous liver biopsy was obtained showing marked cholestasis, with portal edema, ductular proliferation, and acute inflammation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Metformin hydrochloride was discontinued, and the patient's jaundice resolved slowly over a period of several months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Given the onset of his jaundice 2 wk after the initiation of metformin, we believe that this case represents an example of metformin-associated hepatotoxicity, the first such case reported.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Electro-oculography, electroretinography, visual evoked potentials, and multifocal electroretinography in patients with vigabatrin-attributed visual field constriction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Symptomatic visual field constriction thought to be associated with vigabatrin has been reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The current study investigated the visual fields and visual electrophysiology of eight patients with known vigabatrin-attributed visual field loss, three of whom were reported previously.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six of the patients were no longer receiving vigabatrin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The central and peripheral fields were examined with the Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Full visual electrophysiology, including flash electroretinography (ERG), pattern electroretinography, multifocal ERG using the VERIS system, electro-oculography, and flash and pattern visual evoked potentials, was undertaken.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Seven patients showed marked visual field constriction with some sparing of the temporal visual field.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The eighth exhibited concentric constriction.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Most electrophysiological responses were usually just within normal limits; two patients had subnormal Arden electro-oculography indices; and one patient showed an abnormally delayed photopic b wave.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, five patients showed delayed 30-Hz flicker b waves, and seven patients showed delayed oscillatory potentials.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Multifocal ERG showed abnormalities that sometimes correlated with the visual field appearance and confirmed that the deficit occurs at the retinal level.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Marked visual field constriction appears to be associated with vigabatrin therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The field defects and some electrophysiological abnormalities persist when vigabatrin therapy is withdrawn.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Conversion to rapamycin immunosuppression in renal transplant recipients: report of an initial experience.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of RAPA conversion in patients undergoing cyclosporine (CsA) or tacrolimus (Tac) toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twenty renal transplant recipients were switched to fixed dose rapamycin (RAPA) (5 mg/day) 0</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>to 204 months posttransplant.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Drug monitoring was not initially used to adjust doses.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The indications for switch were chronic CsA or Tac nephrotoxicity (12), acute CsA or Tac toxicity (3), severe facial dysmorphism (2), posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) in remission (2), and hepatotoxicity in 1.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Follow-up is 7 to 24 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the 12 patients switched because of chronic nephrotoxicity there was a significant decrease in serum creatinine [233+/-34 to 210+/-56 micromol/liter (P<0.05) at 6 months].</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Facial dysmorphism improved in two patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No relapse of PTLD was observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Five patients developed pneumonia (two Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia, one infectious mononucleosis with polyclonal PTLD lung infiltrate) and two had bronchiolitis obliterans.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were no deaths.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RAPA was discontinued in four patients, because of pneumonia in two, PTLD in one, and oral aphtous ulcers in one.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RAPA levels were high (>15 ng/ml) in 7 of 13 (54%) patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>RAPA conversion provides adequate immunosuppression to enable CsA withdrawal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, when converting patients to RAPA drug levels should be monitored to avoid over-immunosuppression and adequate antiviral and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia prophylaxis should be given.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Worsening of levodopa-induced dyskinesias by motor and mental tasks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ten patients who had Parkinson's disease with disabling dyskinesia were included in this study to evaluate the role of mental (mental calculation) and motor (flexion/extension of right fingers, flexion/extension of left fingers, flexion/extension of the neck, speaking aloud) tasks on the worsening of peak-dose dyskinesia following administration of an effective single dose of apomorphine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with the score at rest (1.3+/-0.3), a significant aggravation of the dyskinesia score was observed during speaking aloud (5.2+/-1.1, p<0.05), movements of right (4.5+/-1.0, p<0.05) and left (3.7+/-0.8, p<0.05) fingers, movements of the neck (5.1+/-1.0, p<0.05), and mental calculation (3.1+/-1.0, p<0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results suggest that activation tasks such as "speaking aloud" could be used for objective assessment of dyskinesia severity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Structural and functional impairment of mitochondria in adriamycin-induced cardiomyopathy in mice: suppression of cytochrome c oxidase II gene expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The use of adriamycin (ADR) in cancer chemotherapy has been limited due to its cumulative cardiovascular toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Earlier observations that ADR interacts with mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase (COX) and suppresses its enzyme activity led us to investigate ADR's action on the cardiovascular functions and heart mitochondrial morphology in Balb-c mice i.p. treated with ADR for several weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>At various times during treatment, the animals were assessed for cardiovascular functions by electrocardiography and for heart tissue damage by electron microscopy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In parallel, total RNA was extracted from samples of dissected heart and analyzed by Northern blot hybridization to determine the steady-state level of three RNA transcripts encoded by the COXII, COXIII, and COXIV genes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Similarly, samples obtained from the liver of the same animals were analyzed for comparative studies.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results indicated that 1) treatment of mice with ADR caused cardiovascular arrhythmias characterized by bradycardia, extension of ventricular depolarization time (tQRS), and failure of QRS at high concentrations (10-14 mg/kg body weight cumulative dose); 2) the heart mitochondria underwent swelling, fusion, dissolution, and/or disruption of mitochondrial cristae after several weeks of treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Such abnormalities were not observed in the mitochondria of liver tissue; and 3) among the three genes of COX enzyme examined, only COXII gene expression was suppressed by ADR treatment, mainly after 8 weeks in both heart and liver.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Knowing that heart mitochondria represent almost 40% of heart muscle by weight, we conclude that the deteriorating effects of ADR on cardiovascular function involve mitochondrial structural and functional impairment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Enhanced bradycardia induced by beta-adrenoceptor antagonists in rats pretreated with isoniazid.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>High doses of isoniazid increase hypotension induced by vasodilators and change the accompanying reflex tachycardia to bradycardia, an interaction attributed to decreased synthesis of brain gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In the present study, the possible enhancement by isoniazid of bradycardia induced by beta-adrenoceptor antagonists was determined in rats anaesthetised with chloralose-urethane.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Isoniazid significantly increased bradycardia after propranolol, pindolol, labetalol and atenolol, as well as after clonidine, but not after hexamethonium or carbachol.</Chemical>
