text: <Chemical>Enhancement was not observed in rats pretreated with methylatropine or previously vagotomised.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results are compatible with interference by isoniazid with GABAergic inhibition of cardiac parasympathetic tone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Such interference could be exerted centrally, possibly at the nucleus ambiguus, or peripherally at the sinus node.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Epileptogenic activity of folic acid after drug induces SLE (folic acid and epilepsy)</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To study the effect of folic acid-containing multivitamin supplementation in epileptic women before and during pregnancy in order to determine the rate of structural birth defects and epilepsy-related side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>STUDY DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>First a randomised trial, later periconception care including in total 12225 females.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Of 60 epileptic women with periconceptional folic acid (0.8 mg)-containing multivitamin supplementation, no one developed epilepsy-related side effects during the periconception period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>One epileptic woman delivered a newborn with cleft lip and palate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Another patient exhibited with a cluster of seizures after the periconception period using another multivitamin.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This 22-year-old epileptic woman was treated continuously by carbamazepine and a folic acid (1 mg)-containing multivitamin from the 20th week of gestation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>She developed status epilepticus and later symptoms of systemic lupus erythematodes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Her pregnancy ended with stillbirth.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The epileptic pregnant patient's autoimmune disease (probably drug-induced lupus) could damage the blood-brain barrier, therefore the therapeutic dose (> or =1 mg) of folic acid triggered a cluster of seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Physiological dose (<1 mg) of folic acid both in healthy and 60 epileptic women, all without any autoimmune disease, did not increase the risk for epileptic seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effects of cisapride on symptoms and postcibal small-bowel motor function in patients with irritable bowel syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Irritable bowel syndrome is a common cause of abdominal pain and discomfort and may be related to disordered gastrointestinal motility.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Our aim was to assess the effects of long-term treatment with a prokinetic agent, cisapride, on postprandial jejunal motility and symptoms in the irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Thirty-eight patients with IBS (constipation-predominant, n = 17; diarrhoea-predominant, n = 21) underwent 24-h ambulatory jejunal manometry before and after 12 week's treatment [cisapride, 5 mg three times daily (n = 19) or placebo (n = 19)].</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In diarrhoea-predominant patients significant differences in contraction characteristics were observed between the cisapride and placebo groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In cisapride-treated diarrhoea-predominant patients the mean contraction amplitude was higher (29.3 +/- 3.2 versus 24.9 +/- 2.6 mm Hg, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.001); pretreatment, 25.7 +/- 6.0 mm Hg), the mean contraction duration longer (3.4 +/- 0.2 versus 3.0 +/- 0.2 sec, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.001); pretreatment, 3.1 +/- 0.5 sec), and the mean contraction frequency lower (2.0 +/- 0.2 versus 2.5 +/- 0.4 cont./min, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.001); pretreatment, 2.5 +/- 1.1 cont./min] than patients treated with placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>No significant differences in jejunal motility were found in the constipation-predominant IBS group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Symptoms were assessed by using a visual analogue scale before and after treatment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Symptom scores relating to the severity of constipation were lower in cisapride-treated constipation-predominant IBS patients [score, 54 +/- 5 versus 67 +/- 14 mm, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.05); pretreatment, 62 +/- 19 mm].</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diarrhoea-predominant IBS patients had a higher pain score after cisapride therapy</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>[score, 55 +/- 15 versus 34 +/- 12 mm, cisapride versus placebo (P < 0.05); pretreatment, 67 +/- 19 mm].</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cisapride affects jejunal contraction characteristics and some symptoms in IBS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clarithromycin-induced ventricular tachycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clarithromycin is a relatively new macrolide antibiotic that offers twice-daily dosing.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It differs from erythromycin only in the methylation of the hydroxyl group at position 6.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although the side-effect profile of erythromycin is established, including gastroenteritis and interactions with other drugs subject to hepatic mixed-function oxidase metabolism, experience with the newer macrolides is still being recorded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cardiotoxicity has been demonstrated after both intravenous and oral administration of erythromycin but has never been reported with the newer macrolides.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of ventricular dysrhythmias that occurred after six therapeutic doses of clarithromycin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dysrhythmias resolved after discontinuation of the drug.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Persistent nephrogenic diabetes insipidus following lithium therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report the case of a patient who developed severe hypernatraemic dehydration following a head injury.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ten years previously he had been diagnosed to have lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and lithium therapy had been discontinued.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>He remained thirsty and polyuric despite cessation of lithium and investigations on admission showed him to have normal osmoregulated thirst and vasopressin secretion, with clear evidence of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is considered to be reversible on cessation of therapy but polyuria persisted in this patient for ten years after lithium was stopped.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We discuss the possible renal mechanisms and the implications for management of patients with lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Late cardiotoxicity after treatment for a malignant bone tumor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cardiac function was assessed in long-term survivors of malignant bone tumors who were treated according to Rosen's T5 or T10 protocol, both including doxorubicin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty-one patients, age 10-45 years (median age 17.8 years) were evaluated 2.3-14.1 years (median 8.9 years) following completion of treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cumulative doses of doxorubicin were 225-550 mg/m2 (median dose 360).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The evaluation consisted of a history, physical examination, electrocardiogram (ECG), signal averaged ECG, 24-hour ambulatory ECG, echocardiography and radionuclide angiography.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Eighteen of 31 (58%) patients showed cardiac toxicity, defined as having one or more of the following abnormalities: late potentials, complex ventricular arrhythmias, left ventricular dilation, decreased shortening fraction, or decreased ejection fraction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of cardiac abnormalities increased with length of follow-up (P< or = .05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>No correlation could be demonstrated between cumulative dose of doxorubicin and cardiac status, except for heart rate variability.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When adjusted to body surface area, the left ventricular posterior wall thickness (LVPW index) was decreased in all patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity is high and increases with follow-up, irrespective of cumulative dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Life-long cardiac follow-up in these patients is warranted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results of our study suggest that heart rate variability and LVPW index could be sensitive indicators for cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Venous complications of midazolam versus diazepam.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although some studies have suggested fewer venous complications are associated with midazolam than with diazepam for endoscopic procedures, this variable has not been well documented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We prospectively evaluated the incidence of venous complications after intravenous injection of diazepam or midazolam in 122 consecutive patients undergoing colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Overall, venous complications were more frequent with diazepam (22 of 62 patients) than with midazolam (4 of 60 patients) (p < 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A palpable venous cord was present in 23% (14 of 62) of patients in the diazepam group, compared with 2% (1 of 60 patients) in the midazolam group (p < 0.002).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain at the injection site occurred in 35% (22 of 62) of patients in the diazepam group compared with 7% (4 of 60 patients) in the midazolam group (p < 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Swelling and warmth at the injection site were not significantly different between the two groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Smoking, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use, intravenous catheter site, dwell time of the needle, alcohol use, and pain during the injection had no effect on the incidence of venous complications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tetany and rhabdomyolysis due to surreptitious furosemide--importance of magnesium supplementation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diuretics may induce hypokalemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>While severe hypokalemia may cause muscle weakness, severe hypomagnesemia is associated with muscle spasms and tetany which cannot be corrected by potassium and calcium supplementation alone (1,2).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Surreptitious diuretic ingestion has been described, mainly in women who are concerned that they are obese or edematous.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Symptomatic hypokalemia has been reported in such patients (3-7) and in one case hypocalcemia was observed (8), but the effects of magnesium depletion were not noted in these patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Loss of glutamate decarboxylase mRNA-containing neurons in the rat dentate gyrus following pilocarpine-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In situ hybridization methods were used to determine if glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) mRNA-containing neurons within the hilus of the dentate gyrus are vulnerable to seizure-induced damage in a model of chronic seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sprague-Dawley rats were injected intraperitoneally with pilocarpine, and the hippocampal formation was studied histologically at 1, 2, 4, and 8 week intervals after pilocarpine-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In situ hybridization histochemistry, using a digoxigenin-labeled GAD cRNA probe, demonstrated a substantial decrease in the number of GAD mRNA-containing neurons in the hilus of the dentate gyrus in the pilocarpine-treated rats as compared to controls at all time intervals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Additional neuronanatomical studies, including cresyl violet staining, neuronal degeneration methods, and histochemical localization of glial fibrillary acidic protein, suggested that the decrease in the number of GAD mRNA-containing neurons was related to neuronal loss rather than to a decrease in GAD mRNA levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The loss of GAD mRNA-containing neurons in the hilus contrasted with the relative preservation of labeled putative basket cells along the inner margin of the granule cell layer.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Quantitative analyses of labeled neurons in three regions of the dentate gyrus in the 1 and 2 week groups showed statistically significant decreases in the mean number of GAD mRNA-containing neurons in the hilus of both groups of experimental animals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No significant differences were found in the molecular layer or the granule cell layer, which included labeled neurons along the lower margin of the granule cell layer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results indicate that, in this model, a subpopulation of GAD mRNA-containing neurons within the dentate gyrus is selectively vulnerable to seizure-induced damage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Such differential vulnerability appears to be another indication of the heterogeneity of GABA neurons.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Protective effect of misoprostol on indomethacin induced renal dysfunction in elderly patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the possible protective effects of misoprostol on renal function in hospitalized elderly patients treated with indomethacin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Forty-five hospitalized elderly patients (> 65 years old) who required therapy with nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAID) were randomly assigned to receive either indomethacin, 150 mg/day (Group A), or indomethacin 150 mg/day plus misoprostol at 0.6 mg/day (Group B).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Laboratory variables of renal function [serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and electrolytes] were evaluated before initiation of therapy and every 2 days, until termination of the study (a period of at least 6 days).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Response to treatment was estimated by the visual analog scale for severity of pain.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: Forty-two patients completed the study, 22 in Group A and 20 in Group B. BUN and creatinine increased by > 50% of baseline levels in 54 and 45% of Group A patients, respectively, compared to only 20 and 10% of Group B patients (p < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Potassium (K) increment of 0.6 mEq/l or more was observed in 50% of Group A, but in only 15% of Group B patients (p < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mean increments in BUN, creatinine, and K were reduced by 63, 80, and 42%, respectively, in Group B patients compared to Group A. Response to treatment did not differ significantly between the 2 groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hospitalized elderly patients are at risk for developing indomethacin related renal dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Addition of misoprostol can minimize this renal impairment without affecting pain control.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nephrotoxic effects of aminoglycoside treatment on renal protein reabsorption and accumulation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To quantify the effects of gentamicin, kanamycin and netilmicin on renal protein reabsorption and accumulation, these drugs were administered to rats intraperitoneally (30 mg/kg/day) for 7, 14 or 21 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Scanning electron microscopy of the glomerular endothelia, urinary measurements of sodium, potassium, endogenous lysozyme, N-acetyl-beta-D-glucosaminidase (NAG) as well as clearance and accumulation experiments after i.v. administration of egg-white lysozyme and measurements of inulin clearance (GFR) were done in each treatment group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Gentamicin administration decreased diameter, density and shape of endothelial fenestrae.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Kanamycin and netilmicin appeared to have no effect at the dose used.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All three aminoglycosides decreased GFR and increased urinary excretion of sodium and potassium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>While gentamicin and kanamycin decreased the percentage reabsorption and accumulation of lysozyme after i.v. administration of egg-white lysozyme netilmicin had no effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Daily excretion of total protein, endogenous lysozyme and NAG increased only after treatment with kanamycin and gentamicin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, aminoglycosides may act as nephrotoxicants at glomerular and/or tubular level inducing impairment of renal reabsorption and accumulation of proteins.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pharmacology of GYKI-41 099 (chlorpropanol, Tobanum) a new potent beta-adrenergic antagonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The compound GYKI-41 099, as a beta-adrenergic antagonist, is 3-8 times more potent than propranolol in vitro and in vivo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Its antiarrhythmic effectiveness surpasses that of propranolol and pindolol inhibiting the ouabain arrhythmia in dogs and cats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>GYKI-41 900 has a negligible cardiodepressant activity; it is not cardioselective.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The compound shows a rapid and long lasting effect.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was a prolonged elimination of the radioactivity after the injection of 14C-41 099 to rats and dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The half life of the unlabeled substance in humans was more than 10 hours.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Chorea associated with oral contraception.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three patients developed chorea while receiving oral contraceptives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two were young patients whose chorea developed long after treatment had been started and disappeared soon after it had been discontinued.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The third patient had acute amphetamine-induced chorea after prolonged oral contraception.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prolonged administration of female sex hormones is a possible cause of chorea in women who have not previously had chorea or rheumatic fever.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reversal of ammonia coma in rats by L-dopa: a peripheral effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ammonia coma was produced in rats within 10 to 15 minutes of an intraperitonealinjection of 1.7 mmol NH4CL.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This coma was prevented with 1.68 mmol L-dopa given by gastric intubation 15 minutes before the ammonium salt injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of L-dopa was correlated with a decrease in blood and brain ammonia, an increase in brain dopamine, and an increase in renal excretion of ammonia and urea.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intraventricular infusion of dopamine sufficient to raise the brain dopamine to the same extent did not prevent the ammonia coma nor affect the blood and brain ammonia concentrations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Bilateral nephrectomy eliminated the beneficial effect of L-dopa on blood and brain ammonia and the ammonia coma was not prevented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, the reduction in blood and brain ammonia and the prevention of ammonia coma after L-dopa, can be accounted for by the peripheral effect of dopamine on renal function rather than its central action.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results provide a reasonable explanation for the beneficial effects observed in some encephalopathic patients receiving L-dopa.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia after liver transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Unfractionated heparin sodium (UFH) or low-molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is used in anticoagulant protocols at several institutions to prevent thrombosis after liver transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is an adverse immune-mediated reaction to heparin, resulting in platelet count decreases of more than 50%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The frequencies of HIT after liver transplantation and platelet factor 4/heparin-reactive antibody (HIT antibody) positivity in liver transplantation patients, however, are unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The 32 men and 20 women underwent living donor liver transplantation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We started LMWH (25 IU/kg/h) on postoperative day (POD) 1, switching to UFH (5000 U/d) on POD 2 or 3.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dose of UFH was changed according to the activated clotting time level.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>HIT antibody levels were measured the day before surgery and on POD 7 and 14.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Platelet count was measured daily for 3 weeks.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The average platelet counts preoperatively, and on POD 7, 14, and 21 were 65, 88, 149, and 169 x 10(9)/L, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two patients developed hepatic artery thrombosis on POD 11 and 19, respectively, although they were HIT antibody-negative and their platelet counts were stable.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In 2 other patients, the platelet count decreased suddenly from 107 x 10(9)/L on POD 4 to 65 x 10(9)/L on POD 6 and from 76 x 10(9)/L on POD 7 to 33 x 10(9)/L on POD 9, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The heparin-induced platelet aggregation test was negative in these patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The percentage of HIT antibody-positive patients was 0.5% preoperatively, 5.6% on POD 7, and 5.6% on POD 14.</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of the subjects/patients developed UFH-related HIT.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In our series, the occurrence of HIT after liver transplantation was uncommon.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PTU-associated vasculitis in a girl with Turner Syndrome and Graves' disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Palpable purpura is a concerning clinical finding in pediatric patients and can have many causes, including infectious and autoimmune processes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A rare cause, drug-induced vasculitis, may result from the production of antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) in response to a medication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We report a girl with Turner syndrome and Graves' disease who presented with palpable purpuric lesions.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The diagnosis of propylthiouracil (PTU)-associated vasculitis was made by observation of consistent clinical features, the detection of elevated ANA and ANCA in the blood, and the observed clinical resolution of symptoms following withdrawal of PTU.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subsequent treatment of persistent hyperthyroidism with radioablation did not result in an exacerbation of the vasculitis, a complication described in prior case reports.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Succinylcholine-induced masseter muscle rigidity during bronchoscopic removal of a tracheal foreign body.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Masseter muscle rigidity during general anesthesia is considered an early warning sign of a possible episode of malignant hyperthermia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The decision whether to continue or discontinue the procedure depends on the urgency of the surgery and severity of masseter muscle rigidity.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Here, we describe a case of severe masseter muscle rigidity (jaw of steel) after succinylcholine (Sch) administration during general anesthetic management for rigid bronchoscopic removal of a tracheal foreign body.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anesthesia was continued uneventfully with propofol infusion while all facilities were available to detect and treat malignant hyperthermia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Minor neurological dysfunction, cognitive development, and somatic development at the age of 3 to 7 years after dexamethasone treatment in very-low birth-weight infants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The objective of this study was to assess minor neurological dysfunction, cognitive development, and somatic development after dexamethasone therapy in very-low-birthweight infants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty-three children after dexamethasone treatment were matched to 33 children without dexamethasone treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Data were assessed at the age of 3-7 years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dexamethasone was started between the 7th and the 28th day of life over 7 days with a total dose of 2.35 mg/kg/day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Exclusion criteria were asphyxia, malformations, major surgical interventions, small for gestational age, intraventricular haemorrhage grades III and IV, periventricular leukomalacia, and severe psychomotor retardation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Each child was examined by a neuropediatrician for minor neurological dysfunctions and tested by a psychologist for cognitive development with a Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children and a Draw-a-Man Test.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were no differences in demographic data, growth, and socio-economic status between the two groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fine motor skills and gross motor function were significantly better in the control group (p<0.01).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the Draw-a-Man Test, the control group showed better results (p<0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were no differences in development of speech, social development, and the Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After dexamethasone treatment, children showed a higher rate of minor neurological dysfunctions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neurological development was affected even without neurological diagnosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Further long-term follow-up studies will be necessary to fully evaluate the impact of dexamethasone on neurological and cognitive development.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Force overflow and levodopa-induced dyskinesias in Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We assessed force coordination of the hand in Parkinson's disease and its relationship to motor complications of levodopa therapy, particularly to levodopa-induced dyskinesias (LID).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We studied two groups of Parkinson's disease patients with (Parkinson's disease + LID, n = 23) and without levodopa-induced dyskinesias (Parkinson's disease - LID, n = 10), and age-matched healthy controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The motor score of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale, a dyskinesia score and force in a grip-lift paradigm were assessed ON and OFF levodopa.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A pathological increase of forces was seen in ON-state in Parkinson's disease + LID only.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In Parkinson's disease + LID, the force involved in pressing down the object before lifting was significantly increased by levodopa (by 61%, P < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An overshooting of peak grip force by 51% (P < 0.05) and of static grip force by 45% (P < 0.01) was observed in the ON- compared with the OFF-drug condition.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, no excessive force was found in Parkinson's disease - LID.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Peak grip force in ON-state was 140% (P < 0.05) higher in Parkinson's disease + LID than in Parkinson's disease - LID, while static grip force was increased by 138% (P < 0.01) between groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Severity of peak-dose dyskinesias was strongly correlated with grip force in ON-state (r = 0.79 with peak force, P < 0.01).</Chemical>
<Chemical>No correlation was observed between forces and the motor score as well as with the daily dose of dopaminergic medication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Force excess was only observed in patients with LID and motor fluctuations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A close relationship was seen between the overshooting of forces and dyskinesias in the ON-drug condition.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We postulate that both LID and grip force excess share common pathophysiological mechanisms related to motor fluctuations.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two cases of postinfarction ventricular septal rupture in patients on long-term steroid therapy are presented and the favourable outcome in both cases described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A possible association between steroid therapy and subsequent postinfarction septal rupture is discussed.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Angioedema associated with droperidol administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Angioedema, also known as angioneurotic edema or Quincke's disease, is a well-demarcated, localized edema involving the subcutaneous tissues that may cause upper-airway obstruction.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We report the case of a previously healthy 19-year-old man with no known drug allergies in whom angioedema with significant tongue swelling and protrusion developed within 10 minutes of the administration of a single IV dose of droperidol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clarithromycin-associated visual hallucinations in a patient with chronic renal failure on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Visual hallucinations are a rare event in chronic renal failure and not related to uremia per se.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Unreported in the literature is visual hallucinations occurring in association with the new macrolide antibiotic, clarithromycin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe such a case in a patient with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) maintained on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The combination of a relatively high dose of clarithromycin in face of chronic renal failure in a functionally anephric patient, with underlying aluminum intoxication, may have facilitated the appearance of this neurotoxic side effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is important to understand the pharmacokinetics of medications in face of chronic renal failure, the possibility of drug interactions, and how these factors should help guide medication therapy in the ESRD patient.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acute doxorubicin-loaded nanoparticle (DXNP) renal toxicity was explored in both normal rats and rats with experimental glomerulonephritis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In normal rats, 2/6 rats given free doxorubicin (DX) (5 mg/kg) died within one week, whereas all control animals and all rats having received free NP or DXNP survived.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 3 times higher proteinuria appeared in animals treated with DXNP than in those treated with DX.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Free NP did not provoke any proteinuria.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In rats with immune experimental glomerulonephritis, 5/6 rats given DX died within 7 days, in contrast to animals treated by DXNP, NP, or untreated, which all survived.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Proteinuria appeared in all series, but was 2-5 times more intense (p > 0.001) and prolonged after doxorubicin treatment (400-700 mg/day), without significant difference between DXNP and DX.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats treated by unloaded NP behaved as controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results demonstrate that, in these experimental conditions, DXNP killed less animals than free DX, despite of an enhanced renal toxicity of the former.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both effects (better survival and nephrosis) are most probably related to an enhanced capture of DXNP by cells of the mononuclear phagocyte system, including mesangial cells.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A subjective assessment of sexual behavior in the study and control groups was carried out, using parameters such as sexual desire, sexual excitement, and frequency of sexual relations.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The differences in the means were significant.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Plasma and urinary lipids and lipoproteins during the development of nephrotic syndrome induced in the rat by puromycin aminonucleoside.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study was undertaken to ascertain whether the alterations of plasma lipoproteins found in nephrotic syndrome induced by puromycin aminonucleoside were due to nephrotic syndrome per se, or, at least in part, to the aminonucleoside.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of the present study was to investigate the changes in plasma and urinary lipoproteins during the administration of puromycin aminonucleoside (20 mg/kg for 7 days) and the subsequent development of nephrotic syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since massive albuminuria occurred after 6 days of treatment, the time-course study was divided into two stages: pre-nephrotic stage (day 1-5) and nephrotic stage (day 6-11).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In pre-nephrotic stage the plasma level of fatty acids, triacylglycerol and VLDL decreased while that of phospholipid, cholesteryl esters and HDL remained constant.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma apolipoprotein A-I tended to increase (40% increase at day 5).</Chemical>

<Chemical>At the beginning of nephrotic stage (day 6) the concentration of plasma albumin dropped to a very low level, while that of apolipoprotein A-I increased abruptly (4-fold increase) and continued to rise, although less steeply, in the following days.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The plasma concentration of HDL followed the same pattern.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Plasma VLDL and LDL increased at a later stage (day 9).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Plasma apolipoprotein A-I was found not only in HDL (1.063-1.210 g/ml) but also in the LDL density class (1.025-1.050 g/ml).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the pre-nephrotic stage lipoproteinuria was negligible, while in the early nephrotic stage the urinary loss of plasma lipoproteins consisted mainly of HDL.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These observations indicate that puromycin aminonucleoside alters plasma lipoproteins by lowering VLDL and increasing HDL.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is likely that the early and striking increase of plasma HDL found in nephrotic rats is related to a direct effect of the drug on HDL metabolism.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Circulating lysosomal enzymes and acute hepatic necrosis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The activities of the lysosomal enzymes acid and neutral protease, N-acetylglucosaminidase, and acid phosphatase were measured in the serum of patients with fulminant hepatic failure.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Acid protease (cathepsin D) activity was increased about tenfold in patients who died and nearly fourfold in those who survived fulminant hepatic failure after paracetamol overdose, whereas activities were increased equally in patients with fulminant hepatic failure due to viral hepatitis whether or not they survived.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A correlation was found between serum acid protease activity and prothrombin time, and the increase in cathepsin D activity was sustained over several days compared with aspartate aminotransferase, which showed a sharp early peak and then a fall.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Circulating lysosomal proteases can damage other organs, and measurement of their activity may therefore be of added value in assessing prognosis in this condition.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We studied a thiamine-dependent enzyme, transketolase, from fibroblasts of a diabetic patient who developed Wernicke's encephalopathy when treated with tolazamide, in order to delineate if this patient also had transketolase abnormality [high Km for thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)], as previously reported in postalcoholic Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition to this patient, we also studied this enzyme from three diabetic kindreds without any history of Wernicke's encephalopathy and from four normal controls.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>These data suggest a similarity between postalcoholic Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and the patient with tolazamide-induced Wernicke's encephalopathy from the standpoint of transketolase abnormality.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Mechanisms of myocardial ischemia induced by epinephrine: comparison with exercise-induced ischemia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The role of epinephrine in eliciting myocardial ischemia was examined in patients with coronary artery disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Objective signs of ischemia and factors increasing myocardial oxygen consumption were compared during epinephrine infusion and supine bicycle exercise.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both epinephrine and exercise produced myocardial ischemia as evidenced by ST segment depression and angina.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the mechanisms of myocardial ischemia induced by epinephrine were significantly different from those of exercise.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Exercise-induced myocardial ischemia was marked predominantly by increased heart rate and rate-pressure product with a minor contribution of end-diastolic volume, while epinephrine-induced ischemia was characterized by a marked increase in contractility and a less pronounced increase in heart rate and rate-pressure product.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings indicate that ischemia produced by epinephrine, as may occur during states of emotional distress, has a mechanism distinct from that due to physical exertion.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Transient contralateral rotation following unilateral substantia nigra lesion reflects susceptibility of the nigrostriatal system to exhaustion by amphetamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Following unilateral 6-OHDA induced SN lesion, a transient period of contralateral rotation has been reported to precede the predominant ipsilateral circling.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In order to clarify the nature of this initial contralateral rotation we examined the effect of the duration of recovery period after the lesion, on amphetamine-induced rotational behavior.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three days post lesion, most rats circled predominantly contralaterally to the lesion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Such contralateral rotation may result from either degeneration-induced breakdown of the DA pool, or lesion-induced increase of DA turnover in the spared neurons.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A substantial degree of contralateral preference was still evident when amphetamine was administered for the first time 24 days after lesioning, indicating involvement of spared cells in the contralateral rotation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, regardless of the duration of recovery (and irrespective of either lesion volume, amphetamine dose, or post-lesion motor exercise), amphetamine-induced rotation tended to become gradually more ipsilateral as the observation session progressed, and all rats circled ipsilaterally to the lesion in response to further amphetamine injections.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that amphetamine has an irreversible effect on the post-lesion DA pool contributing to contralateral rotation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Sensitivity of erythroid progenitor colonies to erythropoietin in azidothymidine treated immunodeficient mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The anaemia induced by 3'-azido-3'dideoxythymidine (AZT) is poorly understood.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have used a murine model of AIDS, infection of female C57BL/6 mice with LP-BM5 murine leukaemia (MuLV) virus, to determine if AZT-induced anaemia is due, in part, to decreased responsiveness of erythropoietic precursors (BFU-e) to erythropoietin (EPO).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mice in the early stage of LP-BM5 MuLV disease were given AZT in their drinking water at 1.0 and 2.5 mg/ml.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AZT produced anaemia in both groups, in a dose-dependent fashion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite the anaemia, the number of splenic and bone marrow BFU-e in AZT treated mice increased up to five-fold over levels observed in infected untreated animals after 15 d of treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Colony formation by splenic and bone marrow BFUe was stimulated at lower concentrations of EPO in mice receiving AZT for 15 d than for infected, untreated mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>By day 30, sensitivity of both splenic and bone marrow BFU-e of treated animals returned to that observed from cells of infected untreated animals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean plasma levels of EPO observed in AZT treated mice were appropriate for the degree of anaemia observed when compared with phenylhydrazine (PHZ) treated mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The numbers of BFU-e and the percentage of bone marrow erythroblasts observed were comparable in AZT and PHZ treated mice with similar degrees of anaemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, reticulocytosis was inappropriate for the degree of anaemia observed in AZT treated infected mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AZT-induced peripheral anaemia in the face of increased numbers of BFU-e and increased levels of plasma EPO suggest a lesion in terminal differentiation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Detection of abnormal cardiac adrenergic neuron activity in adriamycin-induced cardiomyopathy with iodine-125-metaiodobenzylguanidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Radiolabeled metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG), an analog of norepinephrine (NE), serves as an index of adrenergic neuron integrity and function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using a rat model of adriamycin-induced cardiomyopathy, we tested the hypothesis that abnormal cardiac adrenergic neuron activity may appear and be exacerbated dose-dependently in adriamycin cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The degree of vacuolar degeneration of myocardial cells was analyzed in relation to the duration of adriamycin treatment (2 mg/kg, once a week).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were no abnormalities or only isolated degeneration in the 1- or 2-wk treatment groups, isolated or scattered degeneration in half of the 3-wk group, frequent scattered degeneration in the 4-wk group, scattered or focal degeneration in the 5-wk group, and extensive degeneration in the 8-wk group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myocardial accumulation of [125I]MIBG 4 hr after intravenous injection did not differ between the controls and the groups treated 3 wk or less.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the 4-wk group had a slightly lower accumulation in the right ventricular wall (82% of the control) and significantly lower accumulation in the left ventricular wall (about 66% of the control: p less than 0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the 5-wk group, MIBG accumulation in the right and left ventricular wall was 35% and 27% of that in controls, respectively (p less than 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the 8-wk group, MIBG accumulation in the right and left ventricular wall was 18% and 14% of that in controls, respectively (p less than 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, MIBG accumulation in the myocardium decreased in an adriamycin dose-dependent manner.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The appearance of impaired cardiac adrenergic neuron activity in the presence of slight myocardial impairment (scattered or focal vacuolar degeneration) indicates that MIBG scintigraphy may be a useful method for detection of adriamycin-induced cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Conscious SHR (male 300-350 g) were subjected to 90 degrees head-up tilts for 60 s following acute administration of prazosin (0.1 mg kg-1 i.p.) or rauwolscine (3 mg kg-1 i.v.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Orthostatic hypotension was determined by the average decrease (%) in mean arterial pressure (MAP femoral) over the 60-s tilt period.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the head-up tilt induced orthostatic hypotension in the SHR treated with prazosin (-16% MAP, n = 6), but not in the SHR treated with rauwolscine (less than +2% MAP, n = 6).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>3.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>for chronic alpha 1-adrenoceptor blockade.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Conversely, administration of rauwolscine (3 mg kg-1 i.v.) in chronic prazosin treated SHR decreased the basal MAP by 12-31% (n = 4), and subsequent tilts induced further drops of MAP by 19-23% in these rats.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>4.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, the bradycardia that accompanied the noradrenaline-induced pressor effect in SHR was similar with and without chronic prazosin treatment despite a 47-71% reduction of the pressor effect in chronic alpha 1-receptor blocked SHR.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 400 WORDS)</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>min(-1) while electrocardiogram, electroencephalogram, and arterial pressure were continuously monitored.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Resuscitation was considered successful when a systolic arterial pressure > or =100 mm</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>22-oxacalcitriol suppresses secondary hyperparathyroidism without inducing low bone turnover in dogs with renal failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Calcitriol therapy suppresses serum levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in patients with renal failure but has several drawbacks, including hypercalcemia and/or marked suppression of bone turnover, which may lead to adynamic bone disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A new vitamin D analogue, 22-oxacalcitriol (OCT), has been shown to have promising characteristics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study was undertaken to determine the effects of OCT on serum PTH levels and bone turnover in states of normal or impaired renal function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Sixty dogs were either nephrectomized (Nx, N = 38) or sham-operated (Sham, N = 22).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The animals received supplemental phosphate to enhance PTH secretion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fourteen weeks after the start of phosphate supplementation, half of the Nx and Sham dogs received doses of OCT (three times per week); the other half were given vehicle for 60 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thereafter, the treatment modalities for a subset of animals were crossed over for an additional eight months.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Biochemical and hormonal indices of calcium and bone metabolism were measured throughout the study, and bone biopsies were done at baseline, 60 weeks after OCT or vehicle treatment, and at the end of the crossover period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In Nx dogs, OCT significantly decreased serum PTH levels soon after the induction of renal insufficiency.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In long-standing secondary hyperparathyroidism, OCT (0.03 microg/kg) stabilized serum PTH levels during the first months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum PTH levels rose thereafter, but the rise was less pronounced compared with baseline than the rise seen in Nx control.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These effects were accompanied by episodes of hypercalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In animals with normal renal function, OCT induced a transient decrease in serum PTH levels at a dose of 0.1 microg/kg, which was not sustained with lowering of the doses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In Nx dogs, OCT reversed abnormal bone formation, such as woven osteoid and fibrosis, but did not significantly alter the level of bone turnover.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, OCT improved mineralization lag time, (that is, the rate at which osteoid mineralizes) in both Nx and Sham dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: These results indicate that even though OCT does not completely prevent the occurrence of hypercalcemia in experimental dogs with renal insufficiency, it may be of use in the management of secondary hyperparathyroidism because it does not induce low bone turnover and, therefore, does not increase the risk of adynamic bone disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two phase II trials of 24-hour paclitaxel infusions in chemotherapy-naive patients with stage IIIB or IV non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) reported response rates of 21% and 24%.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Leukopenia was dose limiting: as many as 62.5% of patients experienced grade 4 leukopenia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We investigated the efficacy and toxicity of a 3-hour paclitaxel infusion in a phase II trial in patients with inoperable stage IIIB or IV NSCLC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The 58 patients treated (41 men and 17 women) had a median age of 59 years (age range, 25 to 75) and a performance status of 0 through 2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Most patients (72.4%) had stage IV NSCLC.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Paclitaxel 225 mg/m2 was infused over 3 hours every 3 weeks with standard prophylactic premedication.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of 50 patients evaluable for response, 12 (24%) had partial remission, 26 (52%) had no change, and 12 had disease progression (24%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hematologic toxicities were mild: only one patient (2%) developed grade 3 or 4 neutropenia, while 29% had grade 1 or 2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Grade 1 or 2 polyneuropathy affected 56% of patients while only one (2%) experienced severe polyneuropathy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Similarly, grade 1 or 2 myalgia/arthralgia was observed in 63.2% of patients, but only 14.3% experienced grade 3 or 4.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nausea and vomiting were infrequent, with 14% of patients experiencing grade 1 or 2 and only 2% experiencing grade 3 or 4.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Paclitaxel is thus an active single agent in this patient population, with a 3-hour infusion proving comparably effective to a 24-hour infusion and superior in terms of the incidence of hematologic and nonhematologic toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further phase II studies with paclitaxel combined with other drugs active against NSCLC are indicated, and phase III studies comparing paclitaxel with standard chemotherapy remain to be completed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cerebral hemorrhage associated with phenylpropanolamine in combination with caffeine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phenylpropanolamine (PPA) is a drug that has been associated with serious side effects including stroke.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is often combined with caffeine in diet preparations and "look-alike" pills.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In order to determine if PPA/caffeine can lead to stroke in normotensive and/or hypertensive rats, we administered the combination in six times the allowed human dose calculated on a per weight basis for the rats two times per day for five days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subarachnoid and cerebral hemorrhage was noted in 18% of the hypertensive rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A single PPA/caffeine administration (same dose) lead to acute hypertension in both the normotensive and hypertensive animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results suggest that PPA/caffeine can lead to cerebral hemorrhage in previously hypertensive animals when administered in greater than the allowed dosage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>An acute elevation in blood pressure may be a contributing factor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Long-term efficacy and toxicity of high-dose amiodarone therapy for ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amiodarone was administered to 154 patients who had sustained, symptomatic ventricular tachycardia (VT) (n = 118) or a cardiac arrest (n = 36) and who were refractory to conventional antiarrhythmic drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The loading dose was 800 mg/day for 6 weeks and the maintenance dose was 600 mg/day.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Sixty-nine percent of patients continued treatment with amiodarone and had no recurrence of symptomatic VT or ventricular fibrillation (VF) over a follow-up of 6 to 52 months (mean +/- standard deviation 14.2 +/- 8.2).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six percent of the patients had a nonfatal recurrence of VT and were successfully managed by continuing amiodarone at a higher dose or by the addition of a conventional antiarrhythmic drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>One or more adverse drug reactions occurred in 51% of patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Adverse effects forced a reduction in the dose of amiodarone in 41% and discontinuation of amiodarone in 10% of patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The most common symptomatic adverse reactions were tremor or ataxia (35%), nausea and anorexia (8%), visual halos or blurring (6%), thyroid function abnormalities (6%) and pulmonary interstitial infiltrates (5%).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although large-dose amiodarone is highly effective in the long-term treatment of VT or VF refractory to conventional antiarrhythmic drugs, it causes significant toxicity in approximately 50% of patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, when the dose is adjusted based on clinical response or the development of adverse effects, 75% of patients with VT or VF can be successfully managed with amiodarone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of calcium chloride and 4-aminopyridine therapy on desipramine toxicity in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hypotension is a major contributor to mortality in tricyclic antidepressant overdose.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recent data suggest that tricyclic antidepressants inhibit calcium influx in some tissues.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study addressed the potential role of calcium channel blockade in tricyclic antidepressant-induced hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Two interventions were studied that have been shown previously to improve blood pressure with calcium channel blocker overdose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CaCl2 and 4-aminopyridine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anesthetized rats received the tricyclic antidepressant desipramine IP to produce hypotension, QRS prolongation, and bradycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifteen min later, animals received CaCl2, NaHCO3, or saline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a second experiment, rats received tricyclic antidepressant desipramine IP followed in 15 min by 4-aminopyridine or saline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>NaHCO3 briefly (5 min) reversed hypotension and QRS prolongation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CaCl2 and 4-aminopyridine failed to improve blood pressure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of ventricular arrhythmias (p = 0.004) and seizures (p = 0.03) in the CaCl2 group was higher than the other groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The administration of CaCl2 or 4-aminopyridine did not reverse tricyclic antidepressant-induced hypotension in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CaCl2 therapy may possibly worsen both cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings do not support a role for calcium channel inhibition in the pathogenesis of tricyclic antidepressant-induced hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phase I trial of 13-cis-retinoic acid in children with neuroblastoma following bone marrow transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment of neuroblastoma cell lines with 13-cis-retinoic acid (cis-RA) can cause sustained inhibition of proliferation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since cis-RA has demonstrated clinical responses in neuroblastoma patients, it may be effective in preventing relapse after cytotoxic therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This phase I trial was designed to determine the maximal-tolerated dosage (MTD), toxicities, and pharmacokinetics of cis-RA administered on an intermittent schedule in children with neuroblastoma following bone marrow transplantation (BMT).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Fifty-one assessable patients, 2 to 12 years of age, were treated with oral cis-RA administered in two equally divided doses daily for 2 weeks, followed by a 2-week rest period, for up to 12 courses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dose was escalated from 100 to 200 mg/m2/d until dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) was observed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A single intrapatient dose escalation was permitted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The MTD of cis-RA was 160 mg/m2/d. Dose-limiting toxicities in six of nine patients at 200 mg/m2/d included hypercalcemia (n = 3), rash (n = 2), and anemia/thrombocytopenia/emesis/rash (n = 1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All toxicities resolved after cis-RA was discontinued.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three complete responses were observed in marrow metastases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serum levels of 7.4 +/- 3.0 mumol/L (peak) and 4.0 +/- 2.8 mumol/L (trough) at the MTD were maintained during 14 days of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The DLT correlated with serum levels > or = 10 mumol/L. CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The MTD of cis-RA given on this intermittent schedule was 160 mg/m2/d. Serum levels known to be effective against neuroblastoma in vitro were achieved at this dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The DLT included hypercalcemia, and may be predicted by serum cis-RA levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Monitoring of serum calcium and cis-RA levels is indicated in future trials.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of calcium chloride on gross behavioural changes produced by carbachol and eserine in cats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of calcium chloride injected into the cerebral ventricles of group-housed unanaesthetized cats upon vocalization (rage, hissing and snarling), fighting (attack with paws and claws, defense with paws and claws and biting), mydriasis, tremor and clonic-tonic convulsions produced by carbachol and eserine injected similarly was investigated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Calcium chloride depressed or almost completely abolished the vocalization and fighting due to carbachol and eserine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the other hand, mydriasis, tremor and clonic-tonic convulsions evoked by carbachol and eserine were not significantly changed by calcium chloride.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is apparent that calcium chloride can "dissociate" vocalization and fighting from autonomic and motor phenomena such as mydriasis, tremor and clonic-tonic convulsions caused by carbachol and eserine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Calcium chloride inhibited the vocalization and fighting produced by carbachol and eserine most probably by a nonspecific stabilizing action on central muscarinic cholinoceptive sites.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results further support the view that calcium ions in excess have an atropine-like action also in the central nervous system.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Multiple side effects of penicillamine therapy in one patient with rheumatoid arthritis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Skin rashes, proteinuria, systemic lupus erythematosus, polymyositis and myasthenia gravis have all been recorded as complications of penicillamine therapy in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A patient who had developed all 5 is now described.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The skin lesion resembled elastosis perforans serpiginosa, which has been reported as a rare side effect in patients with Wilson's disease but not in patients with rheumatoid arthritis treated with penicillamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Electrocardiographic changes and cardiac arrhythmias in patients receiving psychotropic drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Eight patients had cardiac manifestations that were life-threatening in five while taking psychotropic drugs, either phenothiazines or tricyclic antidepressants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although most patients were receiving several drugs, Mellaril (thioridazine) appeared to be responsible for five cases of ventricular tachycardia, one of which was fatal in a 35 year old woman.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Supraventricular tachycardia developed in one patient receiving Thorazine (chlorpromazine).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Aventyl (nortriptyline) and Elavil (amitriptyline) each produced left bundle branch block in a 73 year old woman.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Electrocardiographic T and U wave abnormalities were present in most patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The ventricular arrhythmias responded to intravenous administration of lidocaine and to direct current electric shock; ventricular pacing was required in some instances and intravenous administration of propranolol combined with ventricular pacing in one.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The tachyarrhythmias generally subsided within 48 hours after administration of the drugs was stopped.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Five of the eight patients were 50 years of age or younger; only one clearly had antecedent heart disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Major cardiac arrhythmias are a potential hazard in patients without heart disease who are receiving customary therapeutic doses of psychotropic drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A prospective clinical trial is suggested to quantify the risk of cardiac complications to patients receiving phenothiazines or tricyclic antidepressant drugs.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Serotonergic drugs, benzodiazepines and baclofen block muscimol-induced myoclonic jerks in a strain of mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In male Swiss mice, muscimol produced myoclonic jerks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 3 mg/kg (i.p.) dose induced this response in all of the mice tested and the peak response of 73 jerks per min was observed between 27 and 45 min.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Increasing the brain serotonin levels by the administration of 5-hydroxytryptophan (80-160 mg/kg) in combination with a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor resulted in an inhibition of the muscimol effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, in a similar experiment l-dopa (80-160 mg/kg) was without effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In doses of 3-10 mg/kg, the serotonin receptor agonist MK-212 caused a dose-dependent blockade of the response of muscimol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the benzodiazepines, clonazepam (0.1-0.3 mg/kg) was found to be several fold more potent than diazepam (0.3-3 mg/kg) in blocking the myoclonic jerks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>While (-)-baclofen (1-3 mg/kg) proved to be an effective antagonist of muscimol, its (+)-isomer (5-20 mg/kg) lacked this property.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Considering the fact that 5-HTP and the benzodiazepines have been found to be beneficial in the management of clinical myoclonus, the muscimol-induced myoclonus seems to be a satisfactory animal model that may prove useful for the development of new drug treatments for this condition.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our present study indicated the possible value of MK-212 and (-)-baclofen in the management of clinical myoclonus.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Hyperglycemic acidotic coma and death in Kearns-Sayre syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This paper presents the clinical and metabolic findings in two young boys with long-standing Kearns-Sayre syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Following short exposure to oral prednisone, both boys developed lethargy, increasing somnolence, polydipsia, polyphagia, and polyuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both presented in the emergency room with profound coma, hypotension, severe hyperglycemia, and acidosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nonketotic lactic acidosis was present in one and ketosis without a known serum lactate level was present in the other.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Respiratory failure rapidly ensued and both patients expired in spite of efforts at resuscitation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We believe these two cases represent a newly described and catastrophic metabolic-endocrine failure in the Kearns-Sayre syndrome.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effects of active constituents of Crocus sativus L., crocin on streptozocin-induced model of sporadic Alzheimer's disease in male rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The involvement of water-soluble carotenoids, crocins, as the main and active components of Crocus sativus L. extract in learning and memory processes has been proposed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study, the effect of crocins on sporadic Alzheimer's disease induced by intracerebroventricular (icv) streptozocin (STZ) in male rats was investigated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Male adult Wistar rats (n = 90 and 260-290 g) were divided into 1, control; 2 and 3, crocins (15 and 30 mg/kg); 4, STZ; 5 and 6, STZ + crocins (15 and 30 mg/kg) groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In Alzheimer's disease groups, rats were injected with STZ-icv bilaterally (3 mg/kg) in first day and 3 days later, a similar STZ-icv application was repeated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In STZ + crocin animal groups, crocin was applied in doses of 15 and 30 mg/kg, i.p., one day pre-surgery and continued for three weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prescription of crocin in each dose was repeated once for two days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the learning and memory performance was assessed using passive avoidance paradigm, and for spatial cognition evaluation, Y-maze task was used.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>It was found out that crocin (30 mg/kg)-treated STZ-injected rats show higher correct choices and lower errors in Y-maze than vehicle-treated STZ-injected rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, crocin in the mentioned dose could significantly attenuated learning and memory impairment in treated STZ-injected group in passive avoidance test.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Therefore, these results demonstrate the effectiveness of crocin (30 mg/kg) in antagonizing the cognitive deficits caused by STZ-icv in rats and its potential in the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rosaceiform dermatitis associated with topical tacrolimus treatment.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Skin biopsy specimens showed telangiectasia and noncaseating epithelioid granulomatous tissue formation in the papillary to mid dermis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Continuous topical use of immunomodulators such as tacrolimus or pimecrolimus should be regarded as a potential cause of rosaceiform dermatitis, although many cases have not been reported.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A novel animal model to evaluate the ability of a drug delivery system to promote the passage through the BBB.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The purpose of this investigation was to explore the potentiality of a novel animal model to be used for the in vivo evaluation of the ability of a drug delivery system to promote the passage through the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and/or to improve the brain localization of a bioactive compound.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A Tween 80-coated poly-L-lactid acid nanoparticles was used as a model of colloidal drug delivery system, able to trespass the BBB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tacrine, administered in LiCl pre-treated rats, induces electrocorticographic seizures and delayed hippocampal damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The toxic effects of tacrine-loaded poly-L-lactid acid nanoparticles (5mg/kg), a saline solution of tacrine (5mg/kg) and an empty colloidal nanoparticle suspension were compared following i.p. administration in LiCl-pre-treated Wistar rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All the animals treated with tacrine-loaded nanoparticles showed an earlier outcome of CNS adverse symptoms, i.e. epileptic onset, with respect to those animals treated with the free compound (10 min vs. 22 min respectively).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, tacrine-loaded nanoparticles administration induced damage of neuronal cells in CA1 field of the hippocampus in all treated animals, while the saline solution of tacrine only in 60% of animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Empty nanoparticles provided similar results to control (saline-treated) group of animals.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In conclusion, the evaluation of time-to-onset of symptoms and the severity of neurodegenerative processes induced by the tacrine-lithium model of epilepsy in the rat, could be used to evaluate preliminarily the capability of a drug delivery system to trespass (or not) the BBB in vivo.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The antiarrhythmic effect and possible ionic mechanisms of pilocarpine on animal models.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>This study was designed to evaluate the effects of pilocarpine and explore the underlying ionic mechanism, using both aconitine-induced rat and ouabain-induced guinea pig arrhythmia models.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Confocal microscopy was used to measure intracellular free-calcium concentrations ([Ca(2+)](i)) in isolated myocytes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The current data showed that pilocarpine significantly delayed onset of arrhythmias, decreased the time course of ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation, reduced arrhythmia score, and increased the survival time of arrhythmic rats and guinea pigs.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>[Ca(2+)](i) overload induced by aconitine or ouabain was reduced in isolated myocytes pretreated with pilocarpine.</Chemical>

Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, M(3)-muscarinic acetylcholine receptor (mAChR) antagonist 4-DAMP (4-diphenylacetoxy-N-methylpiperidine-methiodide) partially abolished the beneficial effects of pilocarpine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data suggest that pilocarpine produced antiarrhythmic actions on arrhythmic rat and guinea pig models induced by aconitine or ouabain via stimulating the cardiac M(3)-mAChR. The mechanism may be related to the improvement of Ca(2+) handling.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Disulfiram-induced transient optic and peripheral neuropathy: a case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIM: To report a case of optic and peripheral neuropathy after chronic use of disulfiram for alcohol dependence management.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A case report.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 57-year-old male presented with gradual loss of vision in both eyes with intermittent headaches for 2 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>He also complained of paraesthesia with numbness in both feet.</Chemical>
<Chemical>His vision was 6/15 and 2/60 in the right and left eyes, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fundoscopy revealed bilaterally swollen optic nerve heads.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Visual field testing confirmed bilateral central-caecal scotomata.</Chemical>
<Chemical>He had been taking disulfiram for alcohol dependence for the preceding 3 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Disulfiram discontinuation lead to an immediate symptomatic improvement.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Physicians initiating long-term disulfiram therapy should be aware of these adverse effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>They should recommend annual ophthalmic reviews with visual field testing.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients should be reassured with respect to the reversibility of these adverse effects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Sustained clinical improvement of a patient with decompensated hepatitis B virus-related cirrhosis after treatment with lamivudine monotherapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, which causes liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, remains a major health problem in Asian countries.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Recent development of vaccine for prevention is reported to be successful in reducing the size of chronically infected carriers, although the standard medical therapies have not been established up to now.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this report, we encountered a patient with decompensated HBV-related cirrhosis who exhibited the dramatic improvements after antiviral therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient was a 50-year-old woman.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Previous conventional medical treatments were not effective for this patient, thus this patient had been referred to our hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, the administration of lamivudine, a reverse transcriptase inhibitor, for 23 months dramatically improved her liver severity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During this period, no drug resistant mutant HBV emerged, and the serum HBV-DNA level was continuously suppressed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These virological responses were also maintained even after the antiviral therapy was discontinued.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Moreover, both hepatitis B surface antigen and e antigen were observed to have disappeared in this patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The administration of lamivudine to patients with HBV-related cirrhosis, like our present case, should be considered as an initial medical therapeutic option, especially in countries where liver transplantation is not reliably available.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dual effects of melatonin on barbiturate-induced narcosis in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Melatonin affects the circadian sleep/wake cycle, but it is not clear whether it may influence drug-induced narcosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sodium thiopenthal was administered intraperitoneally into male rats pre-treated with melatonin (0.05, 0.5, 5 and 50 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Melatonin pre-treatment affected in a dual manner barbiturate narcosis, however, no dose-effect correlation was found.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In particular, low doses reduced the latency to and prolonged the duration of barbiturate narcosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, the highest dose of melatonin (50 mg/kg) caused a paradoxical increase in the latency and produced a sustained reduction of the duration of narcosis, and a reduction in mortality rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Melatonin 0.5 and 5 mg/kg influenced the duration but not the latency of ketamine- or diazepam-induced narcosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, the dual action of melatonin on pharmacological narcosis seems to be specific for the barbiturate mechanism of action.</Chemical>
