text: <Chemical>Effects of NIK-247 on cholinesterase and scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of NIK-247 on cholinesterase, scopolamine-induced amnesia and spontaneous movement were examined and compared with those of the well-known cholinesterase inhibitors tacrine and E-2020.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>NIK-247, tacrine and E-2020 all strongly inhibited acetylcholinesterase (AChE) in human red blood cells (IC50s = 1.0 x 10(-6), 2.9 x 10(-7) and 3.7 x 10(-8) M, respectively).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, NIK-247 and tacrine, but not E-2020, strongly inhibited butyrylcholinestrase (BuChE) in human serum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All three drugs produced mixed inhibition of AChE activity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Moreover, the inhibitory effect of NIK-247 on AChE was reversible.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All compounds at 0.1-1 mg/kg p.o. significantly improved the amnesia induced by scopolamine (0.5 mg/kg s.c.) in rats performing a passive avoidance task.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The three compounds at 1 and 3 mg/kg p.o. did not significantly decrease spontaneous movement by rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These findings suggest that NIK-247 at a low dose (0.1-1 mg/kg p.o.) improves scopolamine-induced amnesia but does not affect spontaneous movement.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The findings suggest that NIK-247 may be a useful drug for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Fifty-six days after initiation of the treatment the patient presented hallucinations that only stopped after the withdrawal of psycho-active drugs and tramadol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The case report questions the long term use of pain killers combined with psycho-active drugs in chronic non malignant pain, especially if pain is under control.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Apparent cure of rheumatoid arthritis by bone marrow transplantation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We describe the induction of sustained remissions and possible cure of severe erosive rheumatoid arthritis (RA) by bone marrow transplantation (BMT) in 2 patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BMT was used to treat severe aplastic anemia which was caused by gold in one case and D-penicillamine in the other.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the 8 and 6 years since the transplants (representing 8 and 4 years since cessation of all immunosuppressive therapy, respectively), the RA in each case has been completely quiescent.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although short term remission of severe RA following BMT has been reported, these are the first cases for which prolonged followup has been available.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This experience raises the question of the role of BMT itself as a therapeutic option for patients with uncontrolled destructive synovitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urinary enzymes and protein patterns as indicators of injury to different regions of the kidney.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Acute experimental models of renal damage to the proximal tubular, glomerular, and papillary regions of the rat were produced by administration of hexachloro-1:3-butadiene (HCBD), puromycin aminonucleoside (PAN), and 2-bromoethylamine (BEA), respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Several routine indicators of nephrotoxicity, the enzymes alkaline phosphatase and N-acetyl-beta-glucosaminidase, and the molecular weight of protein excretion were determined on urine samples.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tubular damage produced by HCBD or BEA was discriminated both quantitatively and qualitatively from glomerular damage produced by PAN.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The latter was characterized by a pronounced increase in protein excretion, especially proteins with molecular weight greater than 40,000 Da.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, protein excretion in tubular damage was raised only slightly and characterized by excretion of proteins of a wide range of molecular weights.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Proximal tubular damage caused by HCBD and papillary damage caused by BEA were distinguished both by conventional urinalysis (volume and specific gravity) and by measurement of the two urinary enzymes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Alkaline phosphatase and glucose were markedly and transiently elevated in proximal tubular damage and N-acetyl-beta-glucosaminidase showed a sustained elevation in papillary damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is concluded that both selective urinary enzymes and the molecular weight pattern of urinary proteins can be used to provide diagnostic information about the possible site of renal damage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neuromuscular blockade with magnesium sulfate and nifedipine.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>A patient who received tocolysis with nifedipine developed neuromuscular blockade after 500 mg of magnesium sulfate was administered.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This reaction demonstrates that nifedipine can seriously potentiate the toxicity of magnesium.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Ifosfamide continuous infusion without mesna. A phase I trial of a 14-day cycle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Twenty patients received 27 courses of ifosfamide administered as a 24-hour continuous infusion for 14 days without Mesna.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The goal of the study was to deliver a dose rate and total cumulative dose of ifosfamide that would be comparable to standard bolus or short-term infusions administered with Mesna.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dose escalations proceeded from 200 to 300, 400, 450, 500, and 550 mg/m2/d. Four patients developed transient microscopic hematuria at 400, 450, and 500 mg/m2/d.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were no instances of macroscopic hematuria.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At 550 mg/m2/d, three patients experienced nonurologic toxicity; confusion (1), nausea (1), and Grade 2 leukopenia (1).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The recommended dose of 500 mg/m2/d delivers a total dose of 7 g/m2 per cycle, which is comparable to that delivered in clinical practice for bolus or short-term infusion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Because few patients received multiple courses over time, the cumulative effects are indeterminate in the present trial.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The frequency and predictability of hematuria are not precise, and at least daily monitoring by urine Hematest is essential, adding Mesna to the infusate in patients with persistent hematuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The protracted infusion schedule for ifosfamide permits convenient outpatient administration without Mesna and reduces the drug cost of clinical usage of this agent by up to  890 per cycle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical activity was demonstrated in a single patient, but a comparative trial of standard bolus schedules with the protracted infusion schedule will be necessary to determine if the clinical effectiveness of the drug is maintained.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myocardial infarction in pregnancy associated with clomiphene citrate for ovulation induction: a case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Clomiphene citrate (CC) is commonly prescribed for ovulation induction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is considered safe, with minimal side effects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thromboembolism is a rare but life-threatening complication that has been reported after ovulation induction with CC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Spontaneous coronary thrombosis or thromboembolism with subsequent clot lysis has been suggested as one of the most common causes of myocardial infarction (MI) during pregnancy, with a subsequently normal coronary angiogram.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CASE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 33-year-old woman with a 5-week gestation had recently received CC for ovulation induction and presented with chest pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An electrocardiogram showed a lateral and anterior wall myocardial infarction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cardiac enzymes showed a peak rise in troponin I to 9.10 ng/mL. An initial exercise stress test was normal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At the time of admission, the patient was at high risk of radiation injury to the fetus, so a coronary angiogram was postponed until the second trimester.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It showed normal coronary vessels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This appears to be the first reported case documenting a possible association between CC and myocardial infarction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thrombosis might be a rare but hazardous complication of CC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Given this life-threatening complication, appropriate prophylactic measures should be used in high-risk woman undergoing ovarian stimulation.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phenobarbital (PB) has a reputation for safety, and it is commonly believed that PB-related increases in serum aminotransferase levels do not indicate or predict the development of significant chronic liver disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here we report of two adult patients with a long history of epilepsy treated with PB who died suddenly: one as consequence of cardiac arrest, the other of acute bronchopneumonia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At autopsy, analysis of liver parenchyma revealed rich portal inflammatory infiltrate, which consisted of mixed eosinophil and monocyte cells, associated with several foci of necrosis surrounded by a hard ring of non-specific granulomatous tissue.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Inflammatory reactions of internal and external hepatic biliary ducts were also seen.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Our findings illustrate that PB may be associated with chronic liver damage, which may lead to more serious and deleterious consequences.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>For this reason, each clinician should recognize this entity in the differential diagnosis of PB-related asymptomatic chronic hepatic enzyme dysfunction.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Ethambutol-associated optic neuropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>INTRODUCTION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ethambutol is used in the treatment of tuberculosis, which is still prevalent in Southeast Asia, and can be associated with permanent visual loss.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report 3 cases which presented with bitemporal hemianopia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CLINICAL PICTURE: Three patients with ethambutol-associated toxic optic neuropathy are described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All 3 patients had loss of central visual acuity, colour vision (Ishihara) and visual field.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The visual field loss had a bitemporal flavour, suggesting involvement of the optic chiasm.</Chemical>
<Chemical>TREATMENT:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Despite stopping ethambutol on diagnosis, visual function continued to deteriorate for a few months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subsequent improvement was mild in 2 cases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the third case, visual acuity and colour vision normalised but the optic discs were pale.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OUTCOME: All 3 patients had some permanent loss of visual function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ethambutol usage is associated with permanent visual loss and should be avoided if possible or used with caution and proper ophthalmological follow-up.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The author postulates that in cases of ethambutol associated chiasmopathy, ethambutol may initially affect the optic nerves and subsequently progress to involve the optic chiasm.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Tolerability of nimesulide and paracetamol in patients with NSAID-induced urticaria/angioedema.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous studies evaluated the tolerance of nimesulide and paracetamol in subjects with cutaneous, respiratory and anaphylactoid reactions induced by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this study we investigated tolerability and reliability of nimesulide and paracetamol in a very large number of patients with an exclusive well-documented history of NSAID-induced urticaria/angioedema.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, we evaluated whether some factors have the potential to increase the risk of reaction to paracetamol and nimesulide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A single-placebo-controlled oral challenge procedure with nimesulide or paracetamol was applied to 829 patients with a history of NSAID-induced urticaria/angioedema.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A total of 75/829 (9.4%) patients experienced reactions to nimesulide or paracetamol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the 715 patients tested with nimesulide 62 (8.6%) showed a positive test, while of 114 subjects submitted to the challenge with paracetamol, 13 (9.6%) did not tolerate this drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, 18.28% of patients with a history of chronic urticaria and 11.8% of subjects with an history of NSAID-induced urticaria/angioedema or angioedema alone (with or without chronic urticaria) resulted to be intolerant to alternative drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Taken together, our results confirm the good tolerability of nimesulide and paracetamol in patients who experienced urticaria/angioedema caused by NSAIDs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the risk of reaction to these alternative study drugs is statistically increased by a history of chronic urticaria and, above all, by a history of NSAID-induced angioedema.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effects of verapamil on atrial fibrillation and its electrophysiological determinants in dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Atrial tachycardia-induced remodeling promotes the occurrence and maintenance of atrial fibrillation (AF) and decreases L-type Ca(2+) current.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There is also a clinical suggestion that acute L-type Ca(2) channel blockade can promote AF, consistent with an AF promoting effect of Ca(2+) channel inhibition.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: To evaluate the potential mechanisms of AF promotion by Ca(2+) channel blockers, we administered verapamil to morphine-chloralose anesthetized dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diltiazem was used as a comparison drug and autonomic blockade with atropine and nadolol was applied in some experiments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Epicardial mapping with 240 epicardial electrodes was used to evaluate activation during AF. RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Verapamil caused AF promotion in six dogs, increasing mean duration of AF induced by burst pacing, from 8+/-4 s (mean+/-S.E.) to 95+/-39 s (P<0.01 vs. control) at a loading dose of 0.1 mg/kg and 228+/-101 s</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>(P<0.0005 vs. control) at a dose of 0.2 mg/kg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Underlying electrophysiological mechanisms were studied in detail in five additional dogs under control conditions and in the presence of the higher dose of verapamil.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In these experiments, verapamil shortened mean effective refractory period (ERP) from 122+/-5 to 114+/-4 ms (P<0.02) at a cycle length of 300 ms, decreased ERP heterogeneity (from 15+/-1 to 10+/-1%, P<0.05), heterogeneously accelerated atrial conduction and decreased the cycle length of AF (94+/-4 to 84+/-3 ms, P<0.005).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diltiazem did not affect ERP, AF cycle length or AF duration, but produced conduction acceleration similar to that caused by verapamil (n=5).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the presence of autonomic blockade, verapamil failed to promote AF and increased, rather than decreasing, refractoriness.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neither verapamil nor diltiazem affected atrial conduction in the presence of autonomic blockade.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Epicardial mapping suggested that verapamil promoted AF by increasing the number of simultaneous wavefronts reflected by separate zones of reactivation in each cycle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Verapamil promotes AF in normal dogs by promoting multiple circuit reentry, an effect dependent on intact autonomic tone and not shared by diltiazem.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hypotension, bradycardia, and asystole after high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone in a monitored patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of hypotension, bradycardia, and asystole after intravenous administration of high-dose methylprednisolone in a 73-year-old patient who underwent electrocardiographic (ECG) monitoring throughout the episode.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was a history of ischemic cardiac disease 9 years earlier.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The patient was admitted with a pulmonary-renal syndrome with hemoptysis, rapidly progressive renal failure, and hypoxemia that required mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After receiving advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation, the patient recovered cardiac rhythm.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The ECG showed a junctional rhythm without ventricular arrhythmia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study reviews the current proposed mechanisms of sudden death after a high dose of intravenous methylprednisolone (IVMP).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These mechanisms are not well understood because, in most cases, the patients were not monitored at the moment of the event.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Rapid infusion and underlying cardiac disease were important risk factors in the case reported here, and the authors discount ventricular arrhythmia as the main mechanism.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lifetime treatment of mice with azidothymidine (AZT) produces myelodysplasia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>AZT has induced a macrocytic anemia in AIDS patients on long term AZT therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is generally assumed that DNA elongation is stopped by the insertion of AZT into the chain in place of thymidine thus preventing the phosphate hydroxyl linkages and therefore suppresses hemopoietic progenitor cell proliferation in an early stage of differentiation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CBA/Ca male mice started on AZT 0.75 mg/ml H2O at 84 days of age and kept on it for 687 days when dosage reduced to 0.5 mg/ml H2O for a group, another group removed from AZT to see recovery, and third group remained on 0.75 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>At 687 days mice that had been on 0.75 mg had average platelet counts of 2.5 x 10(6).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Histological examination on 9 of 10 mice with such thrombocytopenia showed changes compatible with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).</Chemical>
<Chemical>A variety of histological patterns was observed.</Chemical>

<Chemical>There were two cases of hypocellular myelodysplasia, two cases of hypersegmented myelodysplastic granulocytosis, two cases of hypercellular marrow with abnormal megakaryocytes with bizarre nuclei, one case of megakaryocytic myelosis associated with a hyperplastic marrow, dysmyelopoiesis and a hypocellular marrow and two cases of myelodysplasia with dyserythropoiesis, hemosiderosis and a hypocellular marrow.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Above mentioned AZT incorporation may have induced an ineffective hemopoiesis in the primitive hemopoietic progenitor cells, which is known to be seen commonly in the myelodysplastic syndrome.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Influence of diet free of NAD-precursors on acetaminophen hepatotoxicity in mice.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recently, we demonstrated the hepatoprotective effects of nicotinic acid amide, a selective inhibitor of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP; EC 2.4.2.30) on mice suffering from acetaminophen (AAP)-hepatitis, suggesting that the AAP-induced liver injury involves a step which depends on adenoribosylation.</Chemical>

Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study investigates the effects of a diet free of precursors of NAD, the substrate on which PARP acts, in female NMRI mice with AAP hepatitis and evaluates the influence of simultaneous ethanol consumption in these animals.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Liver injuries were quantified as serum activities of glutamate-oxaloacetate transaminase (GOT) and glutamate-pyruvate transaminase (GPT).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>While AAP caused a 117-fold elevation of serum transaminase activities in mice kept on a standard laboratory diet, which was significantly exacerbated by ethanol and inhibited by nicotinic acid amide (NAA), adverse effects were noted in animals fed a diet free of precursors of NAD.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In these animals, only minor increases of serum transaminase activities were measured in the presence of AAP, and unlike the exacerbation caused by ethanol in mice on a standard diet, the liver damage was inhibited by 50% by ethanol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A further 64% reduction of hepatitis was observed, when NAA was given to ethanol/AAP-mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our results provide evidence that the AAP-induced hepatitis and its exacerbation by ethanol can either be reduced by end-product inhibition of PARP by NAA or by dietary depletion of the enzyme's substrate NAD.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We see the main application of NAA as for the combinational use in pharmaceutical preparations of acetaminophen in order to avoid hepatic damage in patients treated with this widely used analgesic.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cibenzoline suppressed all the arrhythmias, and the minimum effective plasma concentrations for arrhythmias induced by 24-h coronary ligation, 48-h coronary ligation, digitalis, and adrenaline were 1.9 +/- 0.9 (by 8 mg/kg i.v.), 1.6 +/- 0.5 (by 8 mg/kg i.v.), 0.6 +/- 0.2 (by 2 mg/kg i.v.), and 3.5 +/- 1.3 (by 5 mg/kg i.v.)</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Because cibenzoline had only weak hypotensive and sinus node depressive effects and was found to be orally active when given to coronary ligation arrhythmia dogs, its clinical usefulness is expected.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Rapid reversal of anticoagulation reduces hemorrhage volume in a mouse model of warfarin-associated intracerebral hemorrhage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Warfarin-associated intracerebral hemorrhage (W-ICH) is a severe type of stroke.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There is no consensus on the optimal treatment for W-ICH.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Using a mouse model, we tested whether the rapid reversal of anticoagulation using human prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) can reduce hemorrhagic blood volume.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male CD-1 mice were treated with warfarin (2 mg/kg over 24 h), resulting in a mean (+/-s.d.)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>International Normalized Ratio of 3.5+/-0.9.</Chemical>
<Chemical>First, we showed that an intravenous administration of human PCC rapidly reversed anticoagulation in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Second, a stereotactic injection of collagenase was administered to induce hemorrhage in the right striatum.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Forty-five minutes later, the animals were randomly treated with PCC (100 U/kg) or saline i.v.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>(n=12 per group).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twenty-four hours after hemorrhage induction, hemorrhagic blood volume was quantified using a photometric hemoglobin assay.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean hemorrhagic blood volume was reduced in PCC-treated animals (6.5+/-3.1 microL) compared with saline controls (15.3+/-11.2 microL, P=0.015).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the saline group, 45% of the mice developed large hematomas (i.e., >15 microL).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, such extensive lesions were never found in the PCC group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We provide experimental data suggesting PCC to be an effective acute treatment for W-ICH in terms of reducing hemorrhagic blood volume.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Future studies are needed to assess the therapeutic potential emerging from our finding for human W-ICH.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Impact of alcohol exposure after pregnancy recognition on ultrasonographic fetal growth measures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: More than 3 decades after Jones and Smith (1973) reported on the devastation caused by alcohol exposure on fetal development, the rates of heavy drinking during pregnancy remain relatively unchanged.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Early identification of fetal alcohol exposure and maternal abstinence led to better infant outcomes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study examined the utility of biometry for detecting alcohol-related fetal growth impairment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We obtained fetal ultrasound measures from routine ultrasound examinations for 167 pregnant hazardous drinkers who were enrolled in a brief alcohol intervention study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The fetal measures for women who quit after learning of their pregnancies were compared with measures for women who continued some drinking throughout the course of their pregnancies.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Because intensity of alcohol consumption is associated with poorer fetal outcomes, separate analyses were conducted for the heavy (average of >or=5 drinks per drinking day) alcohol consumers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fetal measures from the heavy-exposed fetuses were also compared with measures from a nondrinking group that was representative of normal, uncomplicated pregnancies from our clinics.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Analyses of covariance were used to determine whether there were differences between groups after controlling for influences of gestational age and drug abuse.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Nearly half of the pregnant drinkers abstained after learning of their pregnancies.</Chemical>

<Chemical>When women reportedly quit drinking early in their pregnancies, fetal growth measures were not significantly different from a non-alcohol-exposed group, regardless of prior drinking patterns.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Any alcohol consumption postpregnancy recognition among the heavy drinkers resulted in reduced cerebellar growth as well as decreased cranial to body growth in comparison with women who either quit drinking or who were nondrinkers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amphetamine abuse was predictive of larger cranial to body growth ratios.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Alterations in fetal biometric measurements were observed among the heavy drinkers only when they continued drinking after becoming aware of their pregnancies.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although the reliance on self-reported drinking is a limitation in this study, these findings support the benefits of early abstinence and the potential for ultrasound examinations in the detection of fetal alcohol effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urinary symptoms and quality of life changes in Thai women with overactive bladder after tolterodine treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To study the urinary symptoms and quality of life changes in Thai women with overactive bladder (OAB) after tolterodine treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIAL AND METHOD:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Thirty women (aged 30-77 years) diagnosed as having OAB at the Gynecology Clinic, King Chulalongkorn Memorial Hospital from January to April 2004 were included in the present study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tolterodine 2 mg, twice daily was given.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 8 weeks treatment, changes in micturition diary variables and tolerability were determined.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Short form 36 (SF36) questionaires (Thai version) were given before and after 8 weeks of treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>At 8 weeks, all micturition per day decreased from 16.</Chemical>
<Chemical>7 +/- 5. 3 to 6.</Chemical>
<Chemical>7 +/- 2.4 times per day.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The number of nocturia episodes decreased from 5.4 +/- 4.2 to 1.1 +/- 1.0 times per night.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The most common side effect was dry month in 5 cases (16.7%) with 2 cases reporting a moderate degree and 1 case with severe degree.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Only one case (3.3%) withdrew from the present study due to a severe dry mouth.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The SF-36 scores changed significantly in the domains of physical functioning, role function emotional, social function and mental heath.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tolterodine was well tolerated and its effects improved the quality of life in Thai women with OAB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, there are few studies of angiographic effects of cocaine on human cerebral arteries.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Information on these effects could be obtained from angiograms of patients with cocaine-associated subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) who underwent angiography shortly after cocaine use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We screened patients with SAH retrospectively and identified those with positive urine toxicology for cocaine or its metabolites.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Quantitative arterial diameter measurements from angiograms of these patients were compared to measurements from control patients with SAH who were matched for factors known to influence arterial diameter.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Qualitative comparisons of small artery changes also were made.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Thirteen patients with positive cocaine toxicology were compared to 26 controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There were no significant differences between groups in the mean diameters of the intradural internal carotid, sphenoidal segment of the middle cerebral, precommunicating segment of the anterior cerebral, or basilar arteries (p greater than 0.05 for all comparisons, unpaired t-tests).</Chemical>

<Chemical>There also were no significant differences between groups when expressing diameters as the sum of the precommunicating segment of the anterior cerebral + sphenoidal segment of the middle cerebral + supraclinoid internal carotid artery + basilar artery divided by the diameter of the petrous internal carotid artery (p greater than 0.05, unpaired t-tests).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Qualitative assessments showed two arterial irregularities in the distal vasculature in each group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>No quantitative evidence for narrowing of large cerebral arteries or qualitative angiographic evidence for distal narrowing or vasculitis could be found in patients who underwent angiography after aneurysmal SAH associated with cocaine use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Atrial fibrillation following chemotherapy for stage IIIE diffuse large B-cell gastric lymphoma in a patient with myotonic dystrophy (Steinert's disease).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The authors describe the unusual association between diffuse B-cell gastric lymphoma and myotonic dystrophy, the most common form of adult muscular dystrophy, and sudden atrial fibrillation following one cycle of doxorubicin-based chemotherapy in the same patient.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Atrial fibrillation or other cardiac arrhythmias are unusual complications in patients treated with chemotherapy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The cardiac toxicity intrinsically associated with the aggressive chemotherapy employed could function as a triggering factor for the arrhythmia in the predisposed myocardium of this patient.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A phase II study of thalidomide in advanced metastatic renal cell carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES: To evaluate the toxicity and activity of thalidomide in patients with advanced metastatic renal cell cancer and to measure changes of one angiogenic factor, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)165, with therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS: 29 patients were enrolled on a study of thalidomide using an intra-patient dose escalation schedule.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients began thalidomide at 400 mg/d and escalated as tolerated to 1200 mg/d by day 54.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifty-nine per cent of patients had had previous therapy with IL-2 and 52% were performance status 2 or 3.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Systemic plasma VEGF165 levels were measured by dual monoclonal ELISA in 8 patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: 24 patients were evaluable for response with one partial response of 11 months duration of a patient with hepatic and pulmonary metastases (4%), one minor response, and 2 patients stable for over 6 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Somnolence and constipation were prominent toxicities and most patients could not tolerate the 1200 mg/day dose level.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Systemic plasma VEGF165 levels did not change with therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results are consistent with a low level of activity of thalidomide in renal cell carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of doses over 800 mg/day was difficult to achieve in this patient population, however lower doses were practical.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The dose-response relationship, if any, of thalidomide for renal cell carcinoma is unclear.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The striatum as a target for anti-rigor effects of an antagonist of mGluR1, but not an agonist of group II metabotropic glutamate receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of the present study was to find out whether the metabotropic receptor 1 (mGluR1) and group II mGluRs, localized in the striatum, are involved in antiparkinsonian-like effects in rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Haloperidol (1 mg/kg ip) induced parkinsonian-like muscle rigidity, measured as an increased resistance of a rat's hind foot to passive flexion and extension at the ankle joint.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>(RS)-1-aminoindan-1,5-dicarboxylic acid (AIDA; 0.5-15 microg/0.5 microl), a potent and selective mGluR1 antagonist, or (2R,4R)-4-aminopyrrolidine-2,4-dicarboxylate (2R,4R-APDC; 7.5-15 microg/0.5 microl), a selective group II agonist, was injected bilaterally into the striatum of haloperidol-treated animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIDA in doses of 7.5-15 microg/0.5 microl diminished the haloperidol-induced muscle rigidity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, 2R,4R-APDC injections were ineffective.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present results may suggest that the blockade of striatal mGluR1, but not the stimulation of group II mGluRs, may ameliorate parkinsonian muscle rigidity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute cholestatic hepatitis after exposure to isoflurane.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report a case of acute cholestatic hepatitis following exposure to the inhalational anesthetic isoflurane.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE SUMMARY:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 70-year-old healthy woman from Iraq developed acute cholestatic hepatitis 3 weeks following repair of the right rotator cuff under general anesthesia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was no evidence for viral, autoimmune, or metabolic causes of hepatitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No other medications were involved except for dipyrone for analgesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The alanine aminotransferase was elevated to a peak concentration of 1533 U/L and the serum bilirubin reached a peak of 17.0 mg/dL.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was slow improvement over 4 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Accidental reexposure by the patient to dipyrone was uneventful.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The clinical and histologic picture of this case resembles halothane hepatitis, which has a significant mortality rate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Isoflurane, a common anesthetic agent, can cause severe cholestatic hepatitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Calcitonin gene-related peptide levels during nitric oxide-induced headache in patients with chronic tension-type headache.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It has been proposed that nitric oxide (NO) induced headache in primary headaches may be associated with release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study we aimed to investigate plasma levels of CGRP during headache induced by the NO donor glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) in 16 patients with chronic tension-type headache and 16 healthy controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The subjects were randomly allocated to receive 0.5 microg/kg/min GTN or placebo over 20 min on two headache-free days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Blood samples were collected at baseline, 10, 20 and 60 min after start of infusion.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Both patients and controls developed significantly stronger immediate headache on the GTN day than on the placebo day and the headache was significantly more pronounced in patients than in controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was no difference between the area under the CGRP curve (AUCCGRP) on GTN vs. placebo day in either patients (P=0.65) or controls (P=0.48).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The AUCCGRP recorded on the GTN day did not differ between patients and controls (P=0.36).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both in patients and controls, CGRP levels changed significantly over time, on both the GTN and placebo days (P < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study indicates that NO-induced immediate headache is not associated with release of CGRP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Myocardial ischemia due to coronary artery spasm during dobutamine stress echocardiography.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dobutamine stress echocardiography (DSE) is a useful and safe provocation test for myocardial ischemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Until now, the test has been focused only on the organic lesion in the coronary artery, and positive DSE has indicated the presence of significant fixed coronary artery stenosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim of the present study is to examine whether myocardial ischemia due to coronary spasm is induced by dobutamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We performed DSE on 51 patients with coronary spastic angina but without significant fixed coronary artery stenosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients had anginal attacks at rest with ST elevation on the electrocardiogram (variant angina).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Coronary spasm was induced by intracoronary injection of acetylcholine, and no fixed coronary artery stenosis was documented on angiograms in all patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DSE was performed with intravenous dobutamine infusion with an incremental doses of 5, 10, 20, 30, and 40 microg/kg/min every 5 minutes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the 51 patients, 7 patients showed asynergy with ST elevation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All 7 patients (13.7%) had chest pain during asynergy, and both chest pain and electrocardiographic changes were preceded by asynergy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These findings indicate that dobutamine can provoke coronary spasm in some patients with coronary spastic angina.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When DSE is performed to evaluate coronary artery disease, not only fixed coronary stenosis, but also coronary spasm should be considered as a genesis of asynergy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Nitric oxide synthase expression in the course of lead-induced hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We recently showed elevated reactive oxygen species (ROS), reduced urinary excretion of NO metabolites (NOx), and increased NO sequestration as nitrotyrosine in various tissues in rats with lead-induced hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study was designed to discern whether the reduction in urinary NOx in lead-induced hypertension is, in part, due to depressed NO synthase (NOS) expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male Sprague-Dawley rats were randomly assigned to a lead-treated group (given lead acetate, 100 ppm, in drinking water and regular rat chow), a group given lead and vitamin E-fortified chow, or a normal control group given either regular food and water or vitamin E-fortified food for 12 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tail blood pressure, urinary NOx excretion, plasma malondialdehyde (MDA), and endothelial and inducible NOS (eNOS and iNOS) isotypes in the aorta and kidney were measured.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The lead-treated group exhibited a rise in blood pressure and plasma MDA concentration, a fall in urinary NOx excretion, and a paradoxical rise in vascular and renal tissue eNOS and iNOS expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vitamin E supplementation ameliorated hypertension, lowered plasma MDA concentration, and raised urinary NOx excretion while significantly lowering vascular, but not renal, tissue eNOS and iNOS expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vitamin E supplementation had no effect on either blood pressure, plasma MDA, or NOS expression in the control group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The study also revealed significant inhibition of NOS enzymatic activity by lead in cell-free preparations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, lead-induced hypertension in this model was associated with a compensatory upregulation of renal and vascular eNOS and iNOS expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is, in part, due to ROS-mediated NO inactivation, lead-associated inhibition of NOS activity, and perhaps stimulatory actions of increased shear stress associated with hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Risk for valvular heart disease among users of fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine who underwent echocardiography before use of medication.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Because uncontrolled echocardiographic surveys suggested that up to 30% to 38% of users of fenfluramine and dexfenfluramine had valvular disease, these drugs were withdrawn from the market.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>To determine the risk for new or worsening valvular abnormalities among users of fenfluramine or dexfenfluramine who underwent echocardiography before they began to take these medications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cohort study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Academic primary care practices.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS: 46 patients who used fenfluramine or dexfenfluramine for 14 days or more and had echocardiograms obtained before therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>MEASUREMENTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Follow-up echocardiography.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The primary outcome was new or worsening valvulopathy, defined as progression of either aortic or mitral regurgitation by at least one degree of severity and disease that met U.S. Food and Drug Administration criteria (at least mild aortic regurgitation or moderate mitral regurgitation).</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Two patients (4.3% [95% CI, 0.6% to 14.8%]) receiving fenfluramine-phentermine developed valvular heart disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One had baseline bicuspid aortic valve and mild aortic regurgitation that progressed to moderate regurgitation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The second patient developed new moderate aortic insufficiency.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Users of diet medications are at risk for valvular heart disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, the incidence may be lower than that reported previously.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Carboplatin toxic effects on the peripheral nervous system of the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The most striking of carboplatin's advantages (CBDCA) over cisplatin (CDDP) is its markedly reduced rate of neurotoxic effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the use of CBDCA higher-intensity schedules and the association with other neurotoxic drugs in polychemotherapy may cause some concern about its safety with respect to peripheral nervous system damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS: Two different schedules of CBDCA administration (10 mg/kg and 15 mg/kg i.p.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>twice a week for nine times) were evaluated in Wistar rats.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Neurotoxicity was assessed for behavioral (tail-flick test), neurophysiological (nerve conduction velocity in the tail nerve), morphological, morphometrical and analytical effects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>CBDCA administration induced dose-dependent peripheral neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pain perception and nerve conduction velocity in the tail were significantly impaired, particularly after the high-dose treatment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The dorsal root ganglia sensory neurons and, to a lesser extent, satellite cells showed the same changes as those induced by CDDP, mainly affecting the nucleus and nucleolus of ganglionic sensory neurons.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, significant amounts of platinum were detected in the dorsal root ganglia and kidney after CBDCA treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>CBDCA is neurotoxic in our model, and the type of pathological changes it induces are so closely similar to those caused by CDDP that it is probable that neurotoxicity is induced in the two drugs by the same mechanism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This model can be used alone or in combination with other drugs to explore the effect of CBDCA on the peripheral nervous system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Iatrogenic risks of endometrial carcinoma after treatment for breast cancer in a large French case-control study. F  d  ration Nationale des Centres de Lutte Contre le Cancer (FNCLCC).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Since tamoxifen is widely used in breast cancer treatment and has been proposed for the prevention of breast cancer, its endometrial iatrogenic effects must be carefully examined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have investigated the association between endometrial cancer and tamoxifen use or other treatments in women treated for breast cancer in a case-control study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cases of endometrial cancer diagnosed after breast cancer (n = 135) and 467 controls matched for age, year of diagnosis of breast cancer and hospital and survival time with an intact uterus were included.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Women who had received tamoxifen were significantly more likely to have endometrial cancer diagnosed than those who had not (crude relative risk = 4.9, p = 0.0001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Univariate and adjusted analyses showed that the risk increased with the length of treatment (p = 0.0001) or the cumulative dose of tamoxifen received (p = 0.0001), irrespective of the daily dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Women who had undergone pelvic radiotherapy also had a higher risk (crude relative risk = 7.8, p = 0.0001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>After adjusting for confounding factors, the risk was higher for tamoxifen users (p = 0.0012), treatment for more than 3 years (all p < 0.03) and pelvic radiotherapy (p = 0.012).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Women who had endometrial cancer and had received tamoxifen had more advanced disease and poorer prognosis than those with endometrial cancer who had not received this treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our results suggest a causal role of tamoxifen in endometrial cancer, particularly when used as currently proposed for breast cancer prevention.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pelvic radiotherapy may be an additional iatrogenic factor for women with breast cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Endometrial cancers diagnosed in women treated with tamoxifen have poorer prognosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Women who receive tamoxifen for breast cancer should be offered gynaecological surveillance during and after treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A long-term evaluation of the risk-benefit ratio of tamoxifen as a preventive treatment for breast cancer is clearly warranted.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary associated with antecedent tamoxifen use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Increased attention has been focused recently on the estrogenic effects of tamoxifen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Review of the literature reveals an association between tamoxifen use and gynecologic tumors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman was treated with tamoxifen for stage II estrogen receptor-positive breast carcinoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Her aspartate transaminase and alanine transaminase levels increase markedly after 6 months of tamoxifen use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After an additional 17 months of elevated serum transaminases, the patient was found to have a stage Ic granulosa cell tumor of the ovary.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients with tamoxifen-induced liver dysfunction may be at increased risk for granulosa cell tumors because of alterations in tamoxifen metabolism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A murine model of adenomyosis: the effects of hyperprolactinemia induced by fluoxetine hydrochloride, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, on adenomyosis induction in Wistar albino rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim of this study was to investigate whether fluoxetine given to castrated and noncastrated rats caused hyperprolactinemia and its effects with respect to adenomyosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fluoxetine, a serotonin reuptake inhibitor, was given to Wistar Albino rats for 98 days to produce hyperprolactinemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The drug was given to two groups consisting of castrated and noncastrated rats and compared to two groups of castrated and noncastrated controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prolactin levels were measured and the uteri of the rats were removed for histopathological analysis at the end of 98 days.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Marmara University School of Medicine, Department of Histology and Embryology, Zeynep Kamil Women and Children's Hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Serum prolactin levels, uterine histopathology.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The prolactin levels of castrated and noncastrated groups treated with fluoxetine were statistically significantly higher when compared to their respective control groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Histological studies revealed 11 cases of adenomyosis, all within the noncastrated group receiving fluoxetine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>It was suggested that high serum prolactin levels cause degeneration of myometrial cells in the presence of ovarian steroids that results in a myometrial invasion by endometrial stroma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This invasion eventually progresses to adenomyosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effects of deliberate hypotension induced by labetalol with isoflurane on neuropsychological function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of deliberate hypotension on brain function measured by neuropsychological tests was studied in 41 adult patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Twenty-four patients were anaesthetized for middle-ear surgery with deliberate hypotension induced by labetalol with isoflurane (hypotensive group).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Seventeen patients without hypotension served as a control group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mean arterial pressure was 77 +/- 2 mmHg (10.3 +/- 0.3 kPa) before hypotension and 50 +/- 0</Chemical>
<Chemical>mmHg (6.7 +/- 0.0 kPa) during hypotension in the hypotensive group, and 86 +/- 2 mmHg (11.5 +/- 0.3 kPa) during anaesthesia in the control group.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The following psychological tests were performed: four subtests of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (similarities, digit span, vocabulary and digit symbol), Trail-Making tests A and B, Zung tests (self-rating anxiety scale and self-rating depression scale) and two-part memory test battery with immediate and delayed recall.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The tests were performed preoperatively and 2 days postoperatively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were no statistically significant differences between the groups in any of the tests in the changes from preoperative value to postoperative value.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results indicate that hypotension induced by labetalol with isoflurane has no significant harmful effects on mental functions compared to normotensive anaesthesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Auditory disturbance associated with interscalene brachial plexus block.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We performed an audiometric study in 20 patients who underwent surgery of the shoulder region under an interscalene brachial plexus block (IBPB).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bupivacaine 0.75% with adrenaline was given followed by a 24-hr continuous infusion of 0.25% bupivacaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three audiometric threshold measurements (0.25-18 kHz) were made: the first before IBPB, the second 2-6 h after surgery and the third on the first day after operation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In four patients hearing impairment on the side of the block was demonstrated after operation, in three measurements on the day of surgery and in one on the following day.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The frequencies at which the impairment occurred varied between patients; in one only low frequencies (0.25-0.5 kHz) were involved.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The maximum change in threshold was 35 dB at 6 kHz measured at the end of the continuous infusion of bupivacaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This patient had hearing threshold changes (15-20 dB) at 6-10 kHz on the opposite side also.</Chemical>
<Chemical>IBPB may cause transient auditory dysfunction in the ipsilateral ear, possibly via an effect on sympathetic innervation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Midazolam compared with thiopentone as an induction agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients premedicated with scopolamine + morphine (+5 mg nitrazepam the evening before surgery),</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>the sleep-inducing effect of midazolam 0.15 mg/kg i.v. was clearly slower in onset than that of thiopentone 4.67 mg/kg i.v.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Somewhat fewer cardiovascular and local sequelae were found in the midazolam group, but, although apnoea occurred less often in the midazolam group it lasted longer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the whole, the differences between midazolam and thiopentone had no apparent clinical consequences.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Midazolam is a new alternative agent for induction in combination anaesthesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cardiotoxic and possible leukemogenic effects of adriamycin in nonhuman primates.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>10 monkeys (macaques) received adriamycin by monthly intravenous injections at 12 mg/m2 (1 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>8 of the 10 monkeys developed congestive heart failure at an average cumulative adriamycin dose (310 mg/m2) well below that considered the safe upper limit (550 mg/m2) in man.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Histologically, the myocardial lesions resembled those found in human anthracycline-induced cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>1 of the 10 monkeys developed acute myeloblastic leukemia after receiving 324 mg/m2 of adriamycin; the 10th monkey is alive and well 26 months after the last dose of drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our results suggest that adriamycin is a more potent cardiotoxin in monkeys than in man, and that leukemia may be a consequence of prolonged treatment with this drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Doxorubicin cardiomyopathy in children with left-sided Wilms tumor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two children with Wilms tumor of the left kidney experienced severe anthracycline cardiomyopathy after irradiation to the tumor bed and conventional dosage of doxorubicin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The cardiomyopathy is attributed 1) to the fact that radiation fields for left Wilms tumor include the lower portion of the heart and 2) to the interaction of doxorubicin and irradiation on cardiac muscle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is recommended that doxorubicin dosage be sharply restricted in children with Wilms tumor of the left kidney who receive postoperative irradiation.</Chemical>
