text: <Chemical>Promotional effects of testosterone and dietary fat on prostate carcinogenesis in genetically susceptible rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Germfree (GF)</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lobund strain Wistar (LW) rats, fed vegetable diet L-485, have developed prostate adenocarcinomas spontaneously (10% incidence) at average age 34 months.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Conventional LW rats, implanted with testosterone at age 4 months, developed a higher incidence of prostate cancer after an average interval of 14 months: 24% had developed gross tumors, and 40% when it included microscopic tumors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Preliminary results indicate that testosterone-treated LW rats that were fed the same diet, which was supplemented with corn oil up to 20% fat, developed prostate cancer after intervals of 6-12 months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Aged GF Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats have not developed prostate cancer spontaneously.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Conventional SD rats fed diet L-485 and treated with testosterone developed only prostatitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Experimental designs should consider genetic susceptibility as a basic prerequisite for studies on experimental prostate cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Mitomycin C associated hemolytic uremic syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mitomycin C associated Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a potentially fatal but uncommon condition that is not yet widely recognised.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It consists of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and progressive renal failure associated with mitomycin C treatment and affects about 10% of patients treated with this agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The renal failure usually develops about 8-10 mth after start of mitomycin C treatment and the mortality is approximately 60% from renal failure or pulmonary edema.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Renal lesions are similar to those seen in idiopathic HUS and include arteriolar fibrin thrombi, expanded subendothelial zones in glomerular capillary walls, ischemic wrinkling of glomerular basement membranes and mesangiolysis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mechanism of action is postulated as mitomycin C-induced endothelial cell damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe the clinical course and pathological findings in a 65 yr-old man with gastric adenocarcinoma who developed renal failure and thrombocytopenia while on treatment with mitomycin C and died in pulmonary edema.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring during fluorouracil therapy: a prospective study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although there have been anecdotal reports of cardiac toxicity associated with fluorouracil (5-FU) therapy, this phenomenon has not been studied in a systematic fashion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We prospectively performed continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring on 25 patients undergoing 5-FU infusion for treatment of solid tumors in order to assess the incidence of ischemic ST changes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients were monitored for 23 +/- 4 hours before 5-FU infusion, and 98 +/- 9 hours during 5-FU infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anginal episodes were rare: only one patient had angina (during 5-FU infusion).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, asymptomatic ST changes (greater than or equal to 1 mm ST deviation) were common: six of 25 patients (24%) had ST changes before 5-FU infusion v 17 (68%) during 5-FU infusion (P less than .002).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The incidence of ischemic episodes per patient per hour was 0.05 +/- 0.02 prior to 5-FU infusion v 0.13 +/- 0.03 during 5-FU infusion (P less than .001); the duration of ECG changes was 0.6 +/- 0.3 minutes per patient per hour before 5-FU v 1.9 +/- 0.5 minutes per patient per hour during 5-FU (P less than .01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>ECG changes were more common among patients with known coronary artery disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There were two cases of sudden death, both of which occurred at the end of the chemotherapy course.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We conclude that 5-FU infusion is associated with a significant increase in silent ST segment deviation suggestive of ischemia, particularly among patients with coronary artery disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism and clinical significance of these ECG changes remain to be determined.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lethal anuria complicating high dose ifosfamide chemotherapy in a breast cancer patient with an impaired renal function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A sixty-year-old woman with advanced breast cancer, previously treated with cisplatin, developed an irreversible lethal renal failure with anuria, the day after 5 g/m2 bolus ifosfamide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Postrenal failure was excluded by echography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A prerenal component could have contributed to renal failure because of a transient hypotension, due to an increasing ascitis, occurring just before anuria.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, correction of the hemodynamic parameters did not improve renal function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ifosfamide is a known nephrotoxic drug with demonstrated tubulopathies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We strongly suspect that this lethal anuria was mainly due to ifosfamide, occurring in a patient having received previous cisplatin chemotherapy and with poor kidney perfusion due to transient hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We recommend careful use of ifosfamide in patients pretreated with nephrotoxic chemotherapy and inadequate renal perfusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Central vein thrombosis and topical dipivalyl epinephrine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A report is given on an 83-year-old female who acquired central vein thrombosis in her seeing eye one day after having started topical medication with dipivalyl epinephrine for advanced glaucoma discovered in the other eye.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>From present knowledge about the effects of adrenergic eye drops on ocular blood circulation, it is difficult to suggest an association between the two events, which may be coincidental only.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Amelioration of bendrofluazide-induced hypokalemia by timolol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The beta adrenergic blocking drug, timolol, tended to correct the hypokalemia of short-term bendrofluazide treatment in 6 healthy male subjects and although the effect was small it was significant.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Timolol also reduced the rise in plasma aldosterone and urine potassium excretion following bendrofluazide and increased the urine sodium/potassium ratio.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was no evidence of a shift of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A cross-sectional evaluation of the effect of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors on bone mineral density in boys.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim of the present study was to investigate the effect of risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia on trabecular bone mineral density (BMD) in children and adolescents.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD: Medically healthy 7- to 17-year-old males chronically treated, in a naturalistic setting, with risperidone were recruited for this cross-sectional study through child psychiatry outpatient clinics between November 2005 and June 2007.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anthropometric measurements and laboratory testing were conducted.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The clinical diagnoses were based on chart review, and developmental and treatment history was obtained from the medical record.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Volumetric BMD of the ultradistal radius was measured using peripheral quantitative computed tomography, and areal BMD of the lumbar spine was estimated using dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hyperprolactinemia was present in 49% of 83 boys (n = 41) treated with risperidone for a mean of 2.9 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum testosterone concentration increased with pubertal status but was not affected by hyperprolactinemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>As expected, bone mineral content and BMD increased with sexual maturity.</Chemical>

<Chemical>After adjusting for the stage of sexual development and height and BMI z scores, serum prolactin was negatively associated with trabecular volumetric BMD at the ultradistal radius (P < .03).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Controlling for relevant covariates, we also found treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) to be associated with lower trabecular BMD at the radius (P = .03) and BMD z score at the lumbar spine (P < .05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings became more marked when the analysis was restricted to non-Hispanic white patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Of 13 documented fractures, 3 occurred after risperidone and SSRIs were started, and none occurred in patients with hyperprolactinemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This is the first study to link risperidone-induced hyperprolactinemia and SSRI treatment to lower BMD in children and adolescents.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Future research should evaluate the longitudinal course of this adverse event to determine its temporal stability and whether a higher fracture rate ensues.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Seizures associated with levofloxacin: case presentation and literature review.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We present a case of a patient who developed seizures shortly after initiating treatment with levofloxacin and to discuss the potential drug-drug interactions related to the inhibition of cytochrome P450 (CYP) 1A2 in this case, as well as in other cases, of levofloxacin-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Several biomedical databases were searched including MEDLINE, Cochrane and Ovid.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The main search terms utilized were case report and levofloxacin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The search was limited to studies published in English.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Six cases of levofloxacin-induced seizures have been reported in the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Drug-drug interactions related to the inhibition of CYP1A2 by levofloxacin are likely involved in the clinical outcome of these cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Clinicians are exhorted to pay close attention when initiating levofloxacin therapy in patients taking medications with epileptogenic properties that are CYP1A2 substrates.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mice lacking mPGES-1 are resistant to lithium-induced polyuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cyclooxygenase-2 activity is required for the development of lithium-induced polyuria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the involvement of a specific, terminal prostaglandin (PG) isomerase has not been evaluated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study was undertaken to assess lithium-induced polyuria in mice deficient in microsomal prostaglandin E synthase-1 (mPGES-1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 2-wk administration of LiCl (4 mmol.kg(-1).day(-1) ip) in mPGES-1 +/+ mice led to a marked polyuria with hyposmotic urine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This was associated with elevated renal mPGES-1 protein expression and increased urine PGE(2) excretion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, mPGES-1</Chemical>
<Chemical>-/- mice were largely resistant to lithium-induced polyuria and a urine concentrating defect, accompanied by nearly complete blockade of high urine PGE(2) and cAMP output.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Immunoblotting, immunohistochemistry, and quantitative (q) RT-PCR consistently detected a significant decrease in aquaporin-2 (AQP2) protein expression in both the renal cortex and medulla of lithium-treated +/+ mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This decrease was significantly attenuated in the -/- mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>qRT-PCR detected similar patterns of changes in AQP2 mRNA in the medulla but not in the cortex.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Similarly, the total protein abundance of the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter (NKCC2) in the medulla but not in the cortex of the +/+ mice was significantly reduced by lithium treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, the dowregulation of renal medullary NKCC2 expression was significantly attenuated in the -/- mice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We conclude that mPGES-1-derived PGE(2) mediates lithium-induced polyuria likely via inhibition of AQP2 and NKCC2 expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Identification of a simple and sensitive microplate method for the detection of oversulfated chondroitin sulfate in heparin products.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Heparin is a commonly implemented anticoagulant used to treat critically ill patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recently, a number of commercial lots of heparin products were found to be contaminated with an oversulfated chondroitin sulfate (OSCS) derivative that could elicit a hypotensive response in pigs following a single high-dose infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using both contaminated heparin products and the synthetically produced derivative, we showed that the OSCS produces dose-dependent hypotension in pigs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The no observed effect level (NOEL) for this contaminant appears to be approximately 1mg/kg, corresponding to a contamination level of approximately 3%.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We also demonstrated that OSCS can be identified in heparin products using a simple, inexpensive, commercially available heparin enzyme immunoassay (EIA) kit that has a limit of detection of approximately 0.1%, well below the NOEL.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This kit may provide a useful method to test heparin products for contamination with oversulfated GAG derivatives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Doxorubicin cardiomyopathy-induced inflammation and apoptosis are attenuated by gene deletion of the kinin B1 receptor.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical use of the anthracycline doxorubicin (DOX) is limited by its cardiotoxic effects, which are attributed to the induction of apoptosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To elucidate the possible role of the kinin B1 receptor (B1R) during the development of DOX cardiomyopathy, we studied B1R</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>knockout mice (B1R(-/-)) by investigating cardiac inflammation and apoptosis after induction of DOX-induced cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DOX control mice showed cardiac dysfunction measured by pressure-volume loops in vivo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This was associated with a reduced activation state of AKT, as well as an increased bax/bcl2 ratio in Western blots, indicating cardiac apoptosis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Furthermore, mRNA levels of the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin 6 were increased in the cardiac tissue.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In DOX B1R(-/-) mice, cardiac dysfunction was improved compared to DOX control mice, which was associated with normalization of the bax/bcl-2 ratio and interleukin 6, as well as AKT activation state.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings suggest that B1R is detrimental in DOX cardiomyopathy in that it mediates the inflammatory response and apoptosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These insights might have useful implications for future studies utilizing B1R</Chemical>
<Chemical>antagonists for treatment of human DOX cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hepatotoxicity associated with sulfasalazine in inflammatory arthritis: A case series from a local surveillance of serious adverse events.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Spontaneous reporting systems for adverse drug reactions (ADRs) are handicapped by under-reporting and limited detail on individual cases.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We report an investigation from a local surveillance for serious adverse drug reactions associated with disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs that was triggered by the occurrence of liver failure in two of our patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serious ADR reports have been solicited from local clinicians by regular postcards over the past seven years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients', who had hepatotoxicity on sulfasalazine and met a definition of a serious ADR, were identified.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two clinicians reviewed structured case reports and assessed causality by consensus and by using a causality assessment instrument.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The likely frequency of hepatotoxicity with sulfasalazine was estimated by making a series of conservative assumptions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Ten cases were identified: eight occurred during surveillance.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Eight patients were hospitalised, two in hepatic failure - one died after a liver transplant.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All but one event occurred within 6 weeks of treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Seven patients had a skin rash, three eosinophilia and one interstitial nephritis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Five patients were of Black British of African or Caribbean descent.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Liver enzymes showed a hepatocellular pattern in four cases and a mixed pattern in six.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Drug-related hepatotoxicity was judged probable or highly probable in 8 patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The likely frequency of serious hepatotoxicity with sulfasalazine was estimated at 0.4% of treated patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Serious hepatotoxicity associated with sulfasalazine appears to be under-appreciated and intensive monitoring and vigilance in the first 6 weeks of treatment is especially important.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An evaluation of amikacin nephrotoxicity in the hematology/oncology population.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amikacin is an aminoglycoside commonly used to provide empirical double gram-negative treatment for febrile neutropenia and other suspected infections.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Strategies of extended-interval and conventional dosing have been utilized extensively in the general medical population; however, data are lacking to support a dosing strategy in the hematology/oncology population.</Chemical>

<Chemical>To evaluate amikacin-associated nephrotoxicity in an adult hematology/oncology population, a prospective, randomized, open-label trial was conducted at a university-affiliated medical center.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Forty patients with a diagnosis consistent with a hematologic/oncologic disorder that required treatment with an aminoglycoside were randomized to either conventional or extended-interval amikacin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The occurrence of nephrotoxicity by means of an increase in serum creatinine and evaluation of efficacy via amikacin serum concentrations with respective pathogens were assessed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The occurrence of nephrotoxicity was similar between the conventional and extended-interval groups, at 10% and 5%, respectively (P = 1.00).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Six patients in the conventional group had a positive culture, compared with none in the extended-interval group (P = 0.002).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The occurrence of nephrotoxicity was similar between the two dosing regimens, but the distribution of risk factors was variable between the two groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Efficacy could not be assessed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Memory function and serotonin transporter promoter gene polymorphism in ecstasy (MDMA) users.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA or ecstasy) has been shown to damage brain serotonin (5-HT) neurons in animals and possibly humans, little is known about the long-term consequences of MDMA-induced 5-HT neurotoxic lesions on functions in which 5-HT is involved, such as cognitive function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because 5-HT transporters play a key element in the regulation of synaptic 5-HT transmission it may be important to control for the potential covariance effect of a polymorphism in the 5-HT transporter promoter gene region (5-HTTLPR) when studying the effects of MDMA as well as cognitive functioning.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of the study was to investigate the effects of moderate and heavy MDMA use on cognitive function, as well as the effects of long-term abstention from MDMA, in subjects genotyped for 5-HTTLPR.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A second aim of the study was to determine whether these effects differ for females and males.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Fifteen moderate MDMA users (<55 lifetime tablets), 22 heavy MDMA+ users (>55 lifetime tablets), 16 ex-MDMA+ users (last tablet > 1 year ago) and 13 controls were compared on a battery of neuropsychological tests.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DNA from peripheral nuclear blood cells was genotyped for 5-HTTLPR using standard polymerase chain reaction methods.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A significant group effect was observed only on memory function tasks (p = 0.04) but not on reaction times (p = 0.61) or attention/executive functioning (p = 0.59).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Heavy and ex-MDMA+ users performed significantly poorer on memory tasks than controls.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, no evidence of memory impairment was observed in moderate MDMA users.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>No significant effect of 5-HTTLPR or gender was observed.</Chemical>

<Chemical>While the use of MDMA in quantities that may be considered "moderate" is not associated with impaired memory functioning, heavy use of MDMA use may lead to long lasting memory impairments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>No effect of 5-HTTLPR or gender on memory function or MDMA use was observed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Aging process of epithelial cells of the rat prostate lateral lobe in experimental hyperprolactinemia induced by haloperidol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of the study was to examine the influence of hyperprolactinemia, induced by haloperidol (HAL) on age related morphology and function changes of epithelial cells in rat prostate lateral lobe.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The study was performed on sexually mature male rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Serum concentrations of prolactin (PRL) and testosterone (T) were measured.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tissue sections were evaluated with light and electron microscopy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Immunohistochemical reactions for Anti-Proliferating Cell Nuclear Antigen (PCNA) were performed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In rats of the experimental group, the mean concentration of: PRL was more than twice higher, whereas T concentration was almost twice lower than that in the control group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Light microscopy visualized the following: hypertrophy and epithelium hyperplasia of the glandular ducts, associated with increased PCNA expression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Electron microscopy revealed changes in columnar epithelial cells, concerning organelles, engaged in protein synthesis and secretion.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Does supplemental vitamin C increase cardiovascular disease risk in women with diabetes?</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Vitamin C acts as a potent antioxidant; however, it can also be a prooxidant and glycate protein under certain circumstances in vitro.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These observations led us to hypothesize that a high intake of vitamin C in diabetic persons might promote atherosclerosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The objective was to examine the relation between vitamin C intake and mortality from cardiovascular disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We studied the relation between vitamin C intake and mortality from total cardiovascular disease (n = 281), coronary artery disease (n = 175), and stroke (n = 57) in 1923 postmenopausal women who reported being diabetic at baseline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diet was assessed with a food-frequency questionnaire at baseline, and subjects initially free of coronary artery disease were prospectively followed for 15 y. RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>After adjustment for cardiovascular disease risk factors, type of diabetes medication used, duration of diabetes, and intakes of folate, vitamin E, and beta-carotene, the adjusted relative risks of total cardiovascular disease mortality were 1.0, 0.97, 1.11, 1.47, and 1.84 (P for trend < 0.01) across quintiles of total vitamin C intake from food and supplements.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adjusted relative risks of coronary artery disease were 1.0, 0.81, 0.99, 1.26, and 1.91 (P for trend = 0.01) and of stroke were 1.0, 0.52, 1.23, 2.22, and 2.57 (P for trend < 0.01).</Chemical>
<Chemical>When dietary and supplemental vitamin C were analyzed separately, only supplemental vitamin C showed a positive association with mortality endpoints.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vitamin C intake was unrelated to mortality from cardiovascular disease in the nondiabetic subjects at baseline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION: A high vitamin C intake from supplements is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease mortality in postmenopausal women with diabetes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Absolute and attributable risk of venous thromboembolism in women on combined cyproterone acetate and ethinylestradiol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To achieve absolute risk estimates of venous thromboembolism (VTE) among women on cyproterone acetate plus ethinylestradiol (CPA/EE), and among women on combined oral contraceptives (COCs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>From the Danish National Register of Patients (NRP), 1996 to 1998, the records of 1.1 million Danish women, ages 15 to 44 years, were searched for evidence of VTE.</Chemical>
<Chemical>COC use was ascertained through mailed questionnaires.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sales statistics of COCs and CPA/EE were provided through Danish Drug Statistics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>During the time frame of the study, 330 women were found to have had VTE while on COCs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of these women, 67 were on levonorgestrel-containing COCs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Eleven were on CPA/EE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The corresponding absolute risk of VTE was 3.4 (range, 3.1-3.8) per 10 000 women years among the women on COCs, 4.2 (range, 3.2-5.2) per 10 000 women years among women on levonorgestrel-containing COCs, and 3.1 (range, 1.3-4.9) per 10 000 women years among the women on CPA/EE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Our results suggest the absolute risk of VTE among Danish women on COCs is similar to that among women taking CPA/EE.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of lindane on hepatic and brain cytochrome P450s and influence of P450 modulation in lindane induced neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oral administration of lindane (2.5, 5, 10 and 15 mg/kg, body weight) for 5 days was found to produce a dose-dependent increase in the activity of P450 dependent 7-ethoxyresorufin-O-deethylase (EROD), 7-pentoxyresorufin-O-dealkylase (PROD) and N-nitrosodimethylamine demethylase (NDMA-d) in rat brain and liver.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A significant increase in the hepatic and brain P450 monooxygenases was also observed when the duration of exposure of low dose (2.5 mg/kg) of lindane was increased from 5 days to 15 or 21 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>As observed with different doses, the magnitude of induction in the activity of P450 monooxygenases was several fold higher in liver microsomes when compared with the brain.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Western blotting studies have indicated that the increase in the P450 enzymes could be due to the increase in the expression of P450 1A1/1A2, 2B1/2B2 and 2E1 isoenzymes.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In vitro studies using organic inhibitors specific for individual P450 isoenzymes and antibody inhibition experiments have further demonstrated that the increase in the activity of PROD, EROD and NDMA-d are due to the increase in the levels of P450 2B1/2B2, 1A1/1A2 and 2E1 isoenzymes, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Induction studies have further shown that while pretreatment of 3-methylcholanthrene (MC), an inducer of P4501A1/1A2, did not produce any significant effect in the incidence of lindane induced convulsions, pretreatment with phenobarbital (PB), an inducer of P450 2B1/2B2 or ethanol, an inducer of P450 2E1 catalysed reactions, significantly increased the incidence of lindane induced convulsions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Similarly, when the P450-mediated metabolism of lindane was blocked by cobalt chloride incidence of convulsions was increased in animals treated with lindane indicating that lindane per se or its metabolites formed by PB or ethanol inducible P450 isoenzymes are involved in its neurobehavioral toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Seizure associated with sleep deprivation and sustained-release bupropion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This case report describes a generalized seizure associated with sustained-release bupropion use and sleep deprivation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The subject, a 31-year-old female smoker, was participating in a clinical trial evaluating an investigational medication for smoking cessation that used sustained-release bupropion as an active control.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 5 weeks of bupropion use, the subject experienced a generalized tonic clonic seizure after staying up nearly all night packing and moving to a new residence.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient had no other risk factors for seizures.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We suggest that sleep deprivation may add to the risk of bupropion-associated seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nephrotoxic effects in high-risk patients undergoing angiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The use of iodinated contrast medium can result in nephropathy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Whether iso-osmolar contrast medium is less nephrotoxic than low-osmolar contrast medium in high-risk patients is uncertain.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We conducted a randomized, double-blind, prospective, multicenter study comparing the nephrotoxic effects of an iso-osmolar, dimeric, nonionic contrast medium, iodixanol, with those of a low-osmolar, nonionic, monomeric contrast medium, iohexol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The study involved 129 patients with diabetes with serum creatinine concentrations of 1.5 to 3.5 mg per deciliter who underwent coronary or aortofemoral angiography.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The primary end point was the peak increase from base line in the creatinine concentration during the three days after angiography.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Other end points were an increase in the creatinine concentration of 0.5 mg per deciliter or more, an increase of 1.0 mg per deciliter or more, and a change in the creatinine concentration from day 0 to day 7.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The creatinine concentration increased significantly less in patients who received iodixanol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>From day 0 to day 3, the mean peak increase in creatinine was 0.13 mg per deciliter in the iodixanol group and 0.55 mg per deciliter in the iohexol group (P=0.001; the increase with iodixanol minus the increase with iohexol, -0.42 mg per deciliter [95 percent confidence interval, -0.73 to -0.22]).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two of the 64 patients in the iodixanol group (3 percent) had an increase in the creatinine concentration of 0.5 mg per deciliter or more, as compared with 17 of the 65 patients in the iohexol group (26 percent)</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>(P=0.002; odds ratio for such an increase in the iodixanol group, 0.09 [95 percent confidence interval, 0.02 to 0.41]).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Experimental cranial pain elicited by capsaicin: a PET study.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Using a positron emission tomography (PET) study it was shown recently that in migraine without aura certain areas in the brain stem were activated during the headache state, but not in the headache free interval.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It was suggested that this brain stem activation is inherent to the migraine attack itself and represents the so called 'migraine generator'.</Chemical>
<Chemical>To test this hypothesis we performed an experimental pain study in seven healthy volunteers, using the same positioning in the PET scanner as in the migraine patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A small amount of capsaicin was administered subcutaneously in the right forehead to evoke a burning painful sensation in the first division of the trigeminal nerve.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Increases of regional cerebral blood flow (rCBF) were found bilaterally in the insula, in the anterior cingulate cortex, the cavernous sinus and the cerebellum.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Using the same stereotactic space limits as in the above mentioned migraine study no brain stem activation was found in the acute pain state compared to the pain free state.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The increase of activation in the region of the cavernous sinus however, suggests that this structure is more likely to be involved in trigeminal transmitted pain as such, rather than in a specific type of headache as was suggested for cluster headache.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>However, long-term survival is possible when radical cystectomy is performed for bladder tumors with any sign of invasion and for recurrent high grade disease, even when noninvasive.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Acute blood pressure elevations with caffeine in men with borderline systemic hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Whether the vasoconstrictive actions of caffeine are enhanced in hypertensive persons has not been demonstrated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, caffeine (3.3 mg/kg) versus placebo was tested in 48 healthy men (aged 20 to 35 years) selected after screening on 2 separate occasions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Borderline hypertensive men (n = 24) were selected with screening systolic blood pressure (BP) of 140 to 160 mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg and/or diastolic BP 90 to 99 mm Hg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Low-risk controls (n = 24) reported no parental history of hypertension and had screening BP <</Chemical>
<Chemical>130/85</Chemical>
<Chemical>mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Participants were then tested on 2 occasions after 12-hour abstinence from caffeine in each of 2 protocols; this required a total of 4 laboratory visits.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Caffeine-induced changes in diastolic BP were 2 to 3 times larger in borderline subjects than in controls (+8.4 vs +3.8 mm</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hg, p < 0.0001), and were attributable to larger changes in impedance-derived measures of systemic vascular resistance (+135 vs +45 dynes.s.cm-5, p < 0.004).</Chemical>
<Chemical>These findings were consistent and reached significance in both protocols.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The percentage of borderline subjects in whom diastolic BP changes exceeded the median control response was 96%.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Consequently, whereas all participants exhibited normotensive levels during the resting predrug baseline, 33% of borderline subjects achieved hypertensive BP levels after caffeine ingestion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, in borderline hypertensive men, exaggerated responses to caffeine were: selective for diastolic BP, consistent with greater vasoconstriction, replicated in 2 protocols, and representative of nearly all borderline hypertensives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We suspect that the potential for caffeine to stabilize high resistance states in susceptible persons suggests that its use may facilitate their disease progression, as well as hinder accurate diagnosis and treatment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Hallucinations and ifosfamide-induced neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Most cases of ifosfamide-induced hallucinations have been reported with other mental status changes.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All patients were receiving high-dose ifosfamide as part of their bone marrow transplant procedure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hallucinations occurred only when the patient's eyes were closed and, in all but one case, were reported as disturbing or frightening.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Underreporting of these hallucinations by patients is likely.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hallucinations may be the sole or first manifestation of neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence may be dose and infusion-time related.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The clinician should be alerted for possible ifosfamide-induced hallucinations, which may occur without other signs of neurotoxicity.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>"Eyes-closed" hallucinatory experiences appear to be an unusual feature of this presentation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In 42 of these patients, data were examined for factors associated with clinical outcome.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Variables evaluated included patient weight, age, sex, serum creatinine level, creatinine clearance, duration of therapy, total dose, mean daily dose, organism minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC), mean peak levels, mean trough levels, mean area under the serum concentration-time curve (AUC), total AUC, mean AUC greater than MIC, total AUC greater than MIC, mean Schumacher's intensity factor (IF), total IF, In (mean maximum concentration [Cmax]/MIC).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Model-dependent pharmacokinetic parameters were calculated by computer based on a one-compartment model.</Chemical>
<Chemical>When the parameters were examined individually, duration of therapy and total AUC correlated significantly (P less than .05) with nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, a stepwise discriminant function analysis identified only duration of therapy (P less than .001) as an important factor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Based on this model and on Bayes' theorem, the predictive accuracy of identifying "nephrotoxic" patients increased from 0.17 to 0.39.</Chemical>
<Chemical>When examined individually, mean IF, MIC, total dose, mean daily dose, and ln (mean Cmax/MIC) correlated significantly (P less than .05) with cure.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In contrast, a simultaneous multivariable analysis identified IF, MIC, and total dose according to one model and ln (mean Cmax/MIC) according to a second statistical model of parameters selected to have the greatest prospective value.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Based on Bayes' theorem and the first model, the predictive accuracy of identifying patients not cured increased from 0.19 to 0.83.</Chemical>
<Chemical>For the second model, the predictive accuracy increased from 0.19 to 0.50.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To describe the incidence of haematological, renal, hepatic and gastrointestinal toxicities in tumour-bearing dogs receiving 1-(2-chloroethyl)-3-cyclohexyl-1-nitrosourea (CCNU).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Of the 206 dogs treated with CCNU, 185 met the inclusion criteria for at least one class of toxicity.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>CCNU was used most commonly in the treatment of lymphoma, mast cell tumour, brain tumour, histiocytic tumours and epitheliotropic lymphoma.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The corresponding epimers with the 3-hydroxy group in the beta-position were also effective but less potent (ED50 values, 33.8-63.5, i.p.).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although the neuroactive steroids were considerably less potent than the benzodiazepine clonazepam in protecting against pilocarpine seizures, steroids with the 5 alpha,3 alpha-configuration had comparable or higher protective index values (TD50 for motor impairment divided by ED50 for seizure protection) than clonazepam, indicating that some neuroactive steroids may have lower relative toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Steroids with the 5 alpha,3 alpha- or 5 beta,3 alpha-configurations also produced a dose-dependent delay in the onset of limbic seizures induced by kainic acid (32 mg/kg, s.c.), but did not completely protect against the seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, when a second dose of the steroid was administered 1 hr after the first dose, complete protection from the kainic acid-induced limbic seizures and status epilepticus was obtained.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The steroids also caused a dose-dependent delay in NMDA (257 mg/kg, s.c.)-induced lethality, but did not completely protect against NMDA seizures or lethality.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that neuroactive steroids are highly effective in protecting against pilocarpine- and kainic acid-induced seizures and status epilepticus in mice, and may be of utility in the treatment of some forms of status epilepticus in humans.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The safety and efficacy of combination N-butyl-deoxynojirimycin (SC-48334) and zidovudine in patients with HIV-1 infection and 200-500 CD4 cells/mm3.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conducted a double-blind, randomized phase II study to evaluate the safety and activity of combination therapy with N-butyl-deoxynojirimycin (SC-48334) (an alpha-glucosidase I inhibitor) and zidovudine versus zidovudine alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients with 200 to 500 CD4 cells/mm3 who tolerated < or = 12 weeks of prior zidovudine therapy received SC-48334 (1000 mg every 8 h) and zidovudine (100 mg every 8 h) or zidovudine and placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sixty patients received combination therapy and 58, zidovudine and placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Twenty-three patients (38%) and 15 (26%), in the combination and zidovudine groups, respectively, discontinued therapy (p = 0.15).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mean SC-48334 steady-state trough level (4.04 +/- 0.99 micrograms/ml) was below the in vitro inhibitory concentration for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mean increase in CD4 cells at week 4 was 73.8 cells/mm3 and 52.4 cells/mm3 for the combination and zidovudine groups, respectively (p > 0.36).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>For patients with prior zidovudine therapy, the mean change in CD4 cells in the combination and zidovudine groups was 63.7 cells/mm3 and 4.9 cells/mm3 at week 8 and 6.8 cells/mm3 and -45.1 cells/mm3 at week 16, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The number of patients with suppression of HIV p24 antigenemia in the combination and zidovudine groups was six (40%) and two (11%) at week 4 (p = 0.10) and five (45%) and two (14%) at week 24 (p = 0.08), respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diarrhea, flatulence, abdominal pain, and weight loss were common for combination recipients.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Chemical>
<Chemical>Recent preclinical and clinical studies with the thymidylate synthase inhibitor N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid (CB 3717).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CB 3717, N10-propargyl-5,8-dideazafolic acid, is a tight-binding inhibitor of thymidylate synthase (TS) whose cytotoxicity is mediated solely through the inhibition of this enzyme.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Recent preclinical studies have focused on the intracellular formation of CB 3717 polyglutamates.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Following a 12-hour exposure of L1210 cells to 50 microM [3H]CB 3717, 30% of the extractable radioactivity could be accounted for as CB 3717 tetra- and pentaglutamate, as determined by high-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) analyses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>As inhibitors of isolated L1210 TS, CB 3717 di-, tri-, tetra- and pentaglutamate are 26-, 87-, 119- and 114-fold more potent than CB 3717, respectively, and their formation may, therefore, be an important determinant of CB 3717 cytotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In early clinical studies with CB 3717, activity has been seen in breast cancer, ovarian cancer, hepatoma, and mesothelioma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Toxicities included hepatotoxicity, malaise, and dose-limiting nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This latter effect is thought to be due to drug precipitation within the renal tubule as a result of the poor solubility of CB 3717 under acidic conditions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In an attempt to overcome this problem, a clinical trial of CB 3717 administered with alkaline diuresis is under way.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Preliminary results at 400 and 500 mg/m2 suggest that a reduction in nephrotoxicity may have been achieved with only 1 instance of renal toxicity in 10 patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hepatotoxicity and malaise are again the most frequent side effects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Evidence of antitumor activity has been seen in 3 patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Pharmacokinetic investigations have shown that alkaline diuresis does not alter CB 3717 plasma levels or urinary excretion and that satisfactory urinary alkalinization can be readily achieved.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Ethopropazine and benztropine in neuroleptic-induced parkinsonism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a 12-week controlled study ethopropazine was compared to benztropine in the treatment of parkinsonism induced by fluphenazine enanthate in 60 schizophrenic outpatients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ethopropazine and benztropine were found to be equally effective in controlling parkinsonian symptoms and were as efficacious as procyclidine, their previous antiparkinsonian drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, benztropine treated patients had a significant increase in tardive dyskinesia compared to their condition during procyclindine treatment, and significantly more anxiety and depression than ethopropazine treated patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This suggests that benztropine is not the anticholinergic drug of choice in the treatment of neuroleptic-induced parkinsonian symptoms, because of its more toxic central and peripheral atropinic effect.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Effect of alpha-tocopherol and deferoxamine on methamphetamine-induced neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methamphetamine (MA)-induced dopaminergic neurotoxicity is believed to be associated with the increased formation of free radicals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study examined the effect of alpha-tocopherol (alpha-TC), a scavenger of reactive oxygen species, and deferoxamine (DFO), an iron chelator, on the MA-induced neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male rats were treated with MA (10 mg/kg, every 2 h for four injections).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rat received either alpha-TC (20 mg/kg) intraperitoneally for 3 days and 30 min prior to MA administration or DFO (50 mg/kg) subcutaneously 30 min before MA administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The concentrations of dopamine (DA), serotonin and their metabolites decreased significantly after MA administration, which was inhibited by the alpha-TC and DFO pretreatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>alpha-TC and DFO attenuated the MA-induced hyperthermia as well as the alterations in the locomotor activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The level of lipid peroxidation was higher and the reduced glutathione concentration was lower in the MA-treated rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These changes were significantly attenuated by alpha-TC and DFO.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This suggests that alpha-TC and DFO ameliorate the MA-induced neuronal damage by decreasing the level of oxidative stress.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Use of dexamethasone with mesna for the prevention of ifosfamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIM: Hemorrhagic cystitis (HC) is a limiting side-effect of chemotherapy with ifosfamide (IFS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the study presented here, we investigated the use of dexamethasone in combination with mesna for the prevention of IFS-induced HC. METHODS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Male Wistar rats (150-200 g; 6 rats per group) were treated with saline or mesna 5 min (i.p.) before and 2 and 6 h after (v.o.) administration of IFS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One, two or three doses of mesna were replaced with dexamethasone alone or with dexamethasone plus mesna.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cystitis was evaluated 24 h after its induction by the changes in bladder wet weight and by macroscopic and microscopic analysis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The replacement of the last dose or the last two doses of mesna with dexamethasone reduced the increase in bladder wet weight induced by IFS by 84.79% and 89.13%, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, it almost abolished the macroscopic and microscopic alterations induced by IFS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, the addition of dexamethasone to the last two doses of mesna was more efficient than three doses of mesna alone when evaluated microscopically.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION: Dexamethasone in combination with mesna was efficient in blocking IFS-induced HC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the replacement of last two doses of mesna with saline or all of the mesna doses with dexamethasone did not prevent HC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Behavioral effects of MK-801 on reserpine-treated mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of dizocilpine (MK-801), a noncompetitive N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist, were studied on dopamine-related behaviors induced by reserpine treatments.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study focuses on behavioral syndromes that may used as models for Parkinson's disease, or tardive dyskinesia, and its response after glutamatergic blockage.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Reserpine (1 mg/kg), administered once every other day for 4 days, produced increases in orofacial dyskinesia, tongue protrusion and vacuous chewing in mice, which are signs indicative of tardive dyskinesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reserpine also produced tremor and catalepsy, which are signs suggestive of Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MK-801 (0.1 mg/kg), administered 30 min before the observation test, prevented the vacuous chewing movements, tongue protrusions and catalepsy induced by reserpine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, MK-801 injection produced a significant increase of tremor in reserpine-treated mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reserpine (1 mg/kg), administered 90 min before the test and followed by apomophine injection (0.1 mg/kg) 5 min before the test, did not produce oral dyskinesia in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the other hand, reserpine induced increases in tremor and catalepsy compared to control mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MK-801 (0.1 mg/kg) administration attenuated the catalepsy and tremor induced by reserpine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pretreatment with reserpine (1 mg/kg) 24 h before the observation test produced increases in vacuous chewing movements and tongue protrusion, as well as increases in tremor and catalepsy, whereas MK-801 (0.1 mg/kg) injection 90 min before the test reversed the effects of reserpine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results show that reserpine produces different and abnormal movements, which are related to dose and schedule employed and can be considered as parkinsonian-like and tardive dsykinesia signs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The glutamatergic blockage produced by NMDA can restore these signs, such as vacuous chewing movements, tongue protrusions, catalepsy and tremor according to the employed model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of glyceryl trinitrate on the sphincter of Oddi spasm evoked by prostigmine-morphine administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In this study the effect of glyceryl trinitrate on the prostigmine-morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm was evaluated in nine female patients with sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Sphincter of Oddi spasm was induced by prostigmine-morphine administration (0.5 mg prostigmine intramuscularly and 10 mg morphine subcutaneously) and visualized by quantitative hepatobiliary scintigraphy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The entire procedure was repeated during glyceryl trinitrate infusion (Nitrolingual 1 microg/kg/min for 120 min).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Prostigmine-morphine provocation caused significant increases in the time to peak activity (Tmax) over the hepatic hilum (HH: 34.33 +/- 5.05 vs. 22.77 +/- 3.26) and the common bile duct (CBD: 60.44 +/- 5.99 vs. 40.0 +/- 2.88) and in the half-time of excretion (T1/2) over the liver parenchyma (LP: 120.04 +/- 16.01 vs. 27.37 +/- 2.19), HH (117.61 +/- 14.71 vs. 31.85 +/- 3.99) and CBD (158.11 +/- 9.18 vs. 40.1 +/- 6.24), indicating a complete spasm at the level of the sphincter of Oddi.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Glyceryl trinitrate infusion completely normalized the prostigmine-morphine-induced alterations in these quantitative parameters (TmaX over the LP: 11.33 +/- 1.13; over the HH: 18.88 +/- 1.48; and over the CBD: 36.22 +/- 1.92; and T1/2 over the LP: 28.21 +/- 1.83; over the HH: 33.42 +/- 3.10; and over the CBD: 41.66 +/- 6.33), suggesting an effective sphincter-relaxing effect of glyceryl trinitrate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results provide the first evidence of the effectiveness of glyceryl trinitrate on the morphine-induced sphincter of Oddi spasm in humans.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since glyceryl trinitrate is able to overcome even the drastic effect of morphine, it might be of relevance in the treatment of sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effects of acute steroid administration on ventilatory and peripheral muscles in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Occasional case reports have shown that acute myopathy may occur in patients treated with massive doses of corticosteroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism of this myopathy is poorly understood.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Therefore, 60 male rats were randomly assigned to receive daily injection of saline (C), methylprednisolone (M), or triamcinolone (T) 80 mg/kg/d for 5 d. Nutritional intake, measured daily in 15 animals, showed a significant reduction of food intake in the steroid-treated groups (-50 and -79% in M and T, respectively).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This was associated with a similar loss in body weight.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the 45 remaining animals, diaphragm contractility and histopathologic features of several muscles were studied.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Weights of respiratory and peripheral muscles were similarly decreased after steroid treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Maximal twitches of the diaphragm were lower in the C group (653 +/- 174 g/cm(2)) than in the M group (837 +/- 171 g/cm(2); p < 0.05) and the T group (765 +/- 145 g/cm(2), NS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Half-relaxation time was prolonged in both steroid groups, and time to peak tension was longer with M, whereas tetanic tensions were similar.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Steroid treatment also induced a leftward shift of the force-frequency curve at 25 and 50 Hz when compared with saline treatment (p < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>ATPase staining of the diaphragm, scalenus medius, and gastrocnemius showed type IIb fiber atrophy in the steroid groups and also diaphragmatic type IIa atrophy with T, whereas histologic examinations revealed a normal muscular pattern with absence of necrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Finally, a pair-fed (PF) study, performed in 18 rats (C, T, and PF), showed that muscle atrophy was considerably less pronounced in PF animals than in T-treated animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that (1) short-term treatment with massive doses of steroids induced severe respiratory and limb muscle wasting; (2) both types of steroids induced predominantly type IIb atrophy, resulting in the expected alterations in diaphragm contractile properties; (3) neither steroid caused muscle necrosis; (4) type IIb atrophy was not caused by acute nutritional deprivation alone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Refractory cardiogenic shock and complete heart block after verapamil SR and metoprolol treatment. A case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A seventy-eight-year-old woman presented with complete heart block and refractory hypotension two days after a therapeutic dose of sustained-release verapamil with concomitant use of metoprolol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient continued to remain hypotensive with complete heart block, even with multiple uses of intravenous atropine as well as high doses of pressor agents such as dopamine and dobutamine.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>However, shortly after the use of intravenous calcium chloride, the refractory hypotension and complete heart block resolved.</Chemical>
