text: <Chemical>A phase I clinical study of the antipurine antifolate lometrexol (DDATHF) given with oral folic acid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Lometrexol is an antifolate which inhibits glycinamide ribonucleotide formyltransferase (GARFT), an enzyme essential for de novo purine synthesis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Extensive experimental and limited clinical data have shown that lometrexol has activity against tumours which are refractory to other drugs, notably methotrexate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the initial clinical development of lometrexol was curtailed because of severe and cumulative antiproliferative toxicities.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Preclinical murine studies demonstrated that the toxicity of lometrexol can be prevented by low dose folic acid administration, i.e. for 7 days prior to and 7 days following a single bolus dose.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This observation prompted a Phase I clinical study of lometrexol given with folic acid supplementation which has confirmed that the toxicity of lometrexol can be markedly reduced by folic acid supplementation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thrombocytopenia and mucositis were the major toxicities.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was no clear relationship between clinical toxicity and the extent of plasma folate elevation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Associated studies demonstrated that lometrexol plasma pharmacokinetics were not altered by folic acid administration indicating that supplementation is unlikely to reduce toxicity by enhancing lometrexol plasma clearance.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The work described in this report has identified for the first time a clinically acceptable schedule for the administration of a GARFT inhibitor.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This information will facilitate the future evaluation of this class of compounds in cancer therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Involvement of the mu-opiate receptor in peripheral analgesia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The intradermal injection of mu (morphine, Tyr-D-Ala-Gly-NMe-Phe-Gly-ol and morphiceptin), kappa (trans-3,4-dichloro-N-methyl-N[2-(1-pyrrolidinyl) cyclohexyl]benzeneactemide) and delta ([D-Pen2.5]-enkephalin and [D-Ser2]-[Leu]enkephalin-Thr) selective opioid-agonists, by themselves, did not significantly affect the mechanical nociceptive threshold in the hindpaw of the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intradermal injection of mu, but not delta or kappa opioid-agonists, however, produced dose-dependent inhibition of prostaglandin E2-induced hyperalgesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The analgesic effect of the mu-agonist morphine was dose-dependently antagonized by naloxone and prevented by co-injection of pertussis toxin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Morphine did not, however, alter the hyperalgesia induced by 8-bromo cyclic adenosine monophosphate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that the analgesic action of opioids on the peripheral terminals of primary afferents is via a binding site with characteristics of the mu-opioid receptor and that this action is mediated by inhibition of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate second messenger system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adequate timing of ribavirin reduction in patients with hemolysis during combination therapy of interferon and ribavirin for chronic hepatitis C.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hemolytic anemia is one of the major adverse events of the combination therapy of interferon and ribavirin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because of ribavirin-related hemolytic anemia, dose reduction is a common event in this therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this clinical retrospective cohort study we have examined the suitable timing of ribavirin reduction in patients with hemolysis during combination therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Thirty-seven of 160 patients who had HCV-genotype 1b, had high virus load, and received 24-week combination therapy developed anemia with hemoglobin level <10 g/dl or anemia-related signs during therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After that, these 37 patients were reduced one tablet of ribavirin (200 mg) per day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After reduction of ribavirin, 27 of 37 patients could continue combination therapy for a total of 24 weeks (group A).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, 10 of 37 patients with reduction of ribavirin could not continue combination therapy because their <8.5 g/dl hemoglobin values decreased to or anemia-related severe side effects occurred (group B).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We assessed the final efficacy and safety after reduction of ribavirin in groups A and B. RESULTS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A sustained virological response (SVR) was 29.6% (8/27) in group A and 10% (1/10) in group B, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 34.4% (12/27) of SVR + biological response in group A was higher than 10% (1/10) in group B ( P = 0.051), with slight significance.</Chemical>

<Chemical>With respect to hemoglobin level at the time of ribavirin reduction, a rate of continuation of therapy in patients with > or =10 g/dl hemoglobin was higher than that in patients with <10 g/dl ( P = 0.036).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reduction of ribavirin at hemoglobin level > or =10 g/dl is suitable in terms of efficacy and side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Increased expression and apical targeting of renal ENaC subunits in puromycin aminonucleoside-induced nephrotic syndrome in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nephrotic syndrome is often accompanied by sodium retention and generalized edema.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the molecular basis for the decreased renal sodium excretion remains undefined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We hypothesized that epithelial Na channel (ENaC) subunit dysregulation may be responsible for the increased sodium retention.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>An experimental group of rats was treated with puromycin aminonucleoside (PAN; 180 mg/kg iv), whereas the control group received only vehicle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 7 days, PAN treatment induced significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, decreased urinary sodium excretion, and extensive ascites.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The protein abundance of alpha-ENaC and beta-ENaC was increased in the inner stripe of the outer medulla (ISOM) and in the inner medulla (IM) but was not altered in the cortex.</Chemical>
<Chemical>gamma-ENaC abundance was increased in the cortex, ISOM, and IM.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Immunoperoxidase brightfield-</Chemical>

<Chemical>and laser-scanning confocal fluorescence microscopy demonstrated increased targeting of alpha-ENaC, beta-ENaC, and gamma-ENaC subunits to the apical plasma membrane in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT2), connecting tubule, and cortical and medullary collecting duct segments.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Immunoelectron microscopy further revealed an increased labeling of alpha-ENaC in the apical plasma membrane of cortical collecting duct principal cells of PAN-treated rats, indicating enhanced apical targeting of alpha-ENaC subunits.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, the protein abundances of Na(+)/H(+) exchanger type 3 (NHE3), Na(+)-K(+)-2Cl(-) cotransporter (BSC-1), and thiazide-sensitive Na(+)-Cl(-) cotransporter (TSC) were decreased.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, the abundance of the alpha(1)-subunit of the Na-K-ATPase was decreased in the cortex and ISOM, but it remained unchanged in the IM.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, the increased or sustained expression of ENaC subunits combined with increased apical targeting in the DCT2, connecting tubule, and collecting duct are likely to play a role in the sodium retention associated with PAN-induced nephrotic syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The decreased abundance of NHE3, BSC-1, TSC, and Na-K-ATPase may play a compensatory role to promote sodium excretion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Does hormone therapy for the treatment of breast cancer have a detrimental effect on memory and cognition? A pilot study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This pilot study examines whether hormone therapy for breast cancer affects cognition.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients participating in a randomised trial of anastrozole, tamoxifen alone or combined (ATAC) (n=94) and a group of women without breast cancer (n=35) completed a battery of neuropsychological measures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with the control group, the patients were impaired on a processing speed task (p=0.032) and on a measure of immediate verbal memory (p=0.026) after controlling for the use of hormone replacement therapy in both groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patient group performance was not significantly related to length of treatment or measures of psychological morbidity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results showed specific impairments in processing speed and verbal memory in women receiving hormonal therapy for the treatment of breast cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Verbal memory may be especially sensitive to changes in oestrogen levels, a finding commonly reported in studies of hormone replacement therapy in healthy women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In view of the increased use of hormone therapies in an adjuvant and preventative setting their impact on cognitive functioning should be investigated more thoroughly.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Association of nitric oxide production and apoptosis in a model of experimental nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In recent studies increased amounts of nitric oxide (NO) and apoptosis have been implicated in various pathological conditions in the kidney.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have studied the role of NO and its association with apoptosis in an experimental model of nephrotic syndrome induced by a single injection of adriamycin (ADR).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The alteration in the NO pathway was assessed by measuring nitrite levels in serum/urine and by evaluating the changes in vascular reactivity of the isolated perfused rat kidney (IPRK) system.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rats were stratified into control groups and ADR-induced nephropathy groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These two groups were then divided into: group 1, animals receiving saline; and group 2, animals receiving aminoguanidine (AG) which is a specific inhibitor of inducible-NO synthase.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On day 21, rats were sacrificed after obtaining material for biochemical analysis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Histopathological examination of the kidneys of rats treated with ADR revealed focal areas of mesangial proliferation and mild tubulointerstitial inflammation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>They also had significantly higher levels of proteinuria compared with control and treatment groups (P < 0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urine nitrite levels were significantly increased in the ADR-nephropathy group (P < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the IPRK phenylephrine and acetylcholine related responses were significantly impaired in the ADR-nephropathy group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Apoptosis was not detected in controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, in the ADR-nephropathy group, numerous apoptotic cells were identified in the tubulointerstitial areas.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Double staining revealed numerous interstitial apoptotic cells to stain for ED1, a marker for monocytes/macrophages.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Treatment with AG prevented the impairment of renal vascular bed responses and reduced both urine nitrite levels and apoptosis to control levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>We suggest that interactions between NO and apoptosis are important in the pathogenesis of the ADR-induced nephrosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The attenuating effect of carteolol hydrochloride, a beta-adrenoceptor antagonist, on neuroleptic-induced catalepsy in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is known that beta-adrenoceptor antagonists are effective in the treatment of akathisia, one of the extrapyramidal side effects that occur during neuroleptic treatment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Neuroleptic-induced catalepsy, a model of neuroleptic-induced extrapyramidal side effects, was considered suitable as a model for predicting neuroleptic-induced akathisia in humans, although neuroleptic-induced catalepsy was not considered a specific test for neuroleptic-induced akathisia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Therefore, the effects of carteolol, a beta-adrenoceptor antagonist, on haloperidol-induced catalepsy in rats were behaviorally studied and compared with those of propranolol and biperiden, a muscarinic receptor antagonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Carteolol, as well as propranolol and biperiden, inhibited the haloperidol-induced catalepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The inhibitory effect of carteolol was almost comparable to that of propranolol, but was weaker than that of biperiden.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Carteolol did not evoke postsynaptic dopamine receptor-stimulating behavioral signs such as stereotypy and hyperlocomotion in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Carteolol did not antagonize the inhibitory effects of haloperidol on apomorphine-induced stereotypy and locomotor activity in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, carteolol did not evoke 5-HT1A receptor-stimulating behavioral signs such as flat body posture and forepaw treading and did not inhibit 5-hydroxytryptophan-induced head twitch in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Finally, carteolol did not inhibit physostigmine-induced lethality in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results strongly suggest that carteolol improves haloperidol-induced catalepsy via its beta-adrenoceptor antagonistic activity and is expected to be effective in the treatment of akathisia without attenuating neuroleptic-induced antipsychotic effects due to its postsynaptic dopamine receptor antagonistic activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Penicillamine-induced rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 67-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis presented rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) after 5 months of D-penicillamine (250 mg/day) treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Light microscopy study showed severe glomerulonephritis with crescent formation in 60% of the glomeruli and infiltration of inflammatory cells in the wall of an arteriole.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Immunofluorescence revealed scanty granular IgG, IgA and C3 deposits along the capillary walls and mesangium.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient was treated with steroid pulse, plasmapheresis, cyclophosphamide and antiplatelet agents.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A complete recovery of renal function was achieved in a few weeks.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This new case of RPGN in the course of D-penicillamine treatment emphasizes the need for frequent monitoring of renal function and evaluation of urinary sediment and proteinuria in these patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The prompt discontinuation of D-penicillamine and vigorous treatment measures could allow for a good prognosis as in this case.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nature, time course and dose dependence of zidovudine-related side effects: results from the Multicenter Canadian Azidothymidine Trial.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To characterize the nature, time course and dose dependency of zidovudine-related side effects, we undertook a multicenter, prospective, dose-range finding study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our study group consisted of 74 HIV-positive homosexual men belonging to groups II B, III and IV C2 from the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) classification of HIV disease.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Following a 3-week observation period, volunteers were treated with zidovudine 600 mg/day for 18 weeks, 900 mg/day for 9 weeks and 1200 mg/day for 9 weeks, followed by a washout period of 6 weeks after which they were re-started on 1200 mg/day or the highest tolerated dose at 8-hourly intervals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subjects were randomly assigned to 4-hourly or 8-hourly regimens within CDC groups while taking 600 and 1200 mg/day.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Clinical and laboratory evaluations were performed at 3-week intervals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Symptomatic adverse effects were present in 96% of subjects, most commonly nausea (64%), fatigue (55%) and headache (49%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>These were generally self-limited, reappearing briefly at each dose increment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A decrease in hemoglobin occurred shortly after initiation of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was not dose dependent and reversed rapidly upon discontinuation of treatment.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A red blood cell count decrease, a mean cell volume increase and a granulocyte count decrease developed early in a dose-independent fashion, reverting at least partially during the washout phase.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The decrease in reticulocyte count was dose related between 600 and 900 mg/day with no further change when the dose was escalated to 1200 mg/day.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bone marrow changes occurred rapidly as demonstrated by megaloblastosis in 95% of 65 specimens at week 18.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Chemical>
<Chemical>Bilateral optic neuropathy due to combined ethambutol and isoniazid treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The case of a 40-year-old patient who underwent an unsuccessful cadaver kidney transplantation and was treated with ethambutol and isoniazid is reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A bilateral retrobulbar neuropathy with an unusual central bitemporal hemianopic scotoma was found.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ethambutol was stopped and only small improvement of the visual acuity followed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Isoniazid was discontinued later, followed by a dramatic improvement in the visual acuity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The hazards of optic nerve toxicity due to ethambutol are known.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We emphasize the potential danger in the use of ethambutol and isoniazid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Progestational agents and blood coagulation. VII. Thromboembolic and other complications of oral contraceptive therapy in relationship to pretreatment levels of blood coagulation factors: summary report of a ten-year study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During a ten-year period, 348 women were studied for a total of 5,877 patient months in four separate studies relating oral contraceptives to changes in hematologic parameters.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Significant increases in certain factors of the blood coagulation and fibrinolysin systems (factors I,II,VII,VIII,IX, and X and plasminogen) were observed in the treated groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Severe complications developed in four patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All four had an abnormal blood coagulation profile, suggesting "hypercoagulability" before initiation of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Some of these findings represented the most extreme abnormalities seen in the entire group of patients; some increased further during therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>One of these patients developed a myocardial infarction before receiving any medication, shortly after the base-line values were obtained.</Chemical>
<Chemical>One patient developed retinopathy 19 months after she began therapy, and another developed thrombophlebitis after 27 months of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The fourth patient developed thrombophlebitis 14 days after initiation of contraceptive therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All four patients were of the A or AB blood group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Previous studies suggested the possiblility of increased propensity for thromboembolic episodes in patients possessing the A antigen.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It appears from these data that hematologic work-ups may be useful in women who are about to start long-term oral contraceptive therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cardiac arrest in a child with cerebral palsy undergoing sevoflurane induction of anesthesia after preoperative clonidine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clonidine is a frequently administered alpha2-adrenergic agonist which can decrease heart rate and blood pressure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We present a case of a 5-year-old child with cerebral palsy and seizure disorder, receiving clonidine for restlessness, who presented for placement of a baclofen pump.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Without the knowledge of the medical personnel, the patient's mother administered three doses of clonidine during the evening before and morning of surgery to reduce anxiety.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During induction of anesthesia, the patient developed bradycardia and hypotension requiring cardiac resuscitation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There are no previous reports of clonidine-associated cardiac arrest in a child undergoing induction of anesthesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effects of UMB24 and (+/-)-SM 21, putative sigma2-preferring antagonists, on behavioral toxic and stimulant effects of cocaine in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Earlier studies have demonstrated that antagonism of sigma1 receptors attenuates the convulsive, lethal, locomotor stimulatory and rewarding actions of cocaine in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, the contribution of sigma2 receptors is unclear because experimental tools to selectively target this subtype are unavailable.</Chemical>
<Chemical>To begin addressing this need, we characterized UMB24</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>(1-(2-phenethyl)-4-(2-pyridyl)-piperazine) and (+/-)-SM 21 (3alpha-tropanyl-2-(4-chorophenoxy)butyrate) in receptor binding and behavioral studies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Receptor binding studies confirmed that UMB24 and (+/-)-SM 21 display preferential affinity for sigma2 over sigma1 receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In behavioral studies, pretreatment of Swiss Webster mice with UMB24 or (+/-)-SM 21 significantly attenuated cocaine-induced convulsions and locomotor activity, but not lethality.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>When administered alone, (+/-)-SM 21 produced no significant effects compared to control injections of saline, but UMB24 had locomotor depressant actions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Together, the data suggest that sigma2 receptor antagonists have the potential to attenuate some of the behavioral effects of cocaine, and further development of more selective, high affinity ligands are warranted.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methimazole-induced cholestatic jaundice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Methimazole is a widely used and generally well-tolerated antithyroid agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 43-year-old woman had severe jaundice and itching 1 month after receiving methimazole (10 mg tid) and propranolol (20 mg tid) for treatment of hyperthyroidism.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient continued treatment for another 4 days after the appearance of jaundice until she finished both medications.</Chemical>
<Chemical>When seen at the emergency department 2 weeks later, she still had severe icterus, pruritus, and hyperbilirubinemia, formed mainly of the conjugated fraction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Methimazole-induced cholestasis was diagnosed, and propranolol therapy was resumed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Over the following 9 days, the symptoms improved and plasma bilirubin levels were normal after 12 weeks without methimazole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In rare cases within the first few weeks of therapy, this drug can cause severe and reversible cholestatic jaundice.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Physicians and patients should be aware of this adverse effect so that, upon occurrence, they can discontinue methimazole therapy and avoid unnecessary invasive procedures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ciprofloxacin-induced acute interstitial nephritis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ciprofloxacin has been associated with several side effects including interstitial nephritis and hemolytic anemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The combination of both side effects is extremely rare.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this report, we describe a case of ciprofloxacin-induced interstitial nephritis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hemolytic anemia improved after stopping the drug and initiation of steroid therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Unfortunately, acute interstitial nephritis was irreversible and the patient developed end-stage renal disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Contribution of sodium valproate to the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report the case of a 62-year-old man who was administered sodium valproate (VPA) and who subsequently developed the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>He had been taking VPA for treatment of idiopathic generalized tonic-clonic convulsions since he was 56 years old.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After substituting VPA with zonisamide, the serum sodium level returned to normal.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We consider this episode of SIADH to be the result of a combination of factors including a weakness of the central nervous system and the long-term administration of VPA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vasopressin in the treatment of milrinone-induced hypotension in severe heart failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The use of phosphodiesterase inhibitors such as milrinone in the treatment of severe heart failure is frequently restricted because they cause vasodilation and hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients with decompensated heart failure with hypotension after treatment with milrinone, low doses of vasopressin restored blood pressure without inhibiting the inotropic effect of milrinone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Halogenated anesthetics form liver adducts and antigens that cross-react with halothane-induced antibodies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two halogenated anesthetics, enflurane and isoflurane, have been associated with an allergic-type hepatic injury both alone and following previous exposure to halothane.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Halothane hepatitis appears to involve an aberrant immune response.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An antibody response to a protein-bound biotransformation product (trifluoroacetyl adduct) has been detected on halothane hepatitis patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This study was performed to determine cross-reactivity between enflurane and isoflurane with the hypersensitivity induced by halothane.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The subcellular and lobular production of hepatic neoantigens recognized by halothane-induced antibodies following enflurane and isoflurane, and the biochemical nature of these neoantigens was investigated in two animal models.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Enflurane administration resulted in neoantigens detected in both the microsomal and cytosolic fraction of liver homogenates and in the centrilobular region of the liver.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the same liver, biochemical analysis detected fluorinated liver adducts that were up to 20-fold greater in guinea pigs than in rats.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This supports and extends previous evidence for a mechanism by which enflurane and/or isoflurane could produce a hypersensitivity condition similar to that of halothane hepatitis either alone or subsequent to halothane administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The guinea pig would appear to be a useful model for further investigations of the immunological response to these antigens.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Induction by paracetamol of bladder and liver tumours in the rat. Effects on hepatocyte fine structure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Groups of male and female inbred Leeds strain rats were fed diets containing either 0.5% or 1.0% paracetamol by weight for up to 18 months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At the 1.0% dosage level, 20% of rats of both sexes developed neoplastic nodules of the liver, a statistically significant incidence.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These rats also showed gross enlargement of their livers and an increase in foci of cellular alteration, the latter also being observed in the low dosage male rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Papillomas of the transitional epithelium of the bladder developed in all paracetamol-treated groups, and three rats bore bladder carcinomas.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, significant yields of bladder tumours were only obtained from low dosage females and high dosage males.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Additionally, 20 to 25% of paracetamol-treated rats developed hyperplasia of the bladder epithelium, which was not coincident with the presence of bladder calculi.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A low yield of tumours at various other sites also arose following paracetamol feeding.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>An electron microscope study of the livers of paracetamol-treated rats revealed ultrastructural changes in the hepatocytes that resemble those that result from exposure to a variety of known hepatocarcinogens.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rat extraocular muscle regeneration. Repair of local anesthetic-induced damage.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Local anesthetics that are commonly used in ophthalmic surgery (0.75% bupivacaine hydrochloride, 2.0% mepivacaine hydrochloride, and 2.0% lidocaine hydrochloride plus 1:100,000 epinephrine) were injected into the retrobulbar area of rat eyes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Controls were injected with physiological saline.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All three anesthetics produced massive degeneration of the extraocular muscles.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Muscle degeneration is followed by regeneration of the damaged muscle fibers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition to muscle damage, severe damage was also seen in harderian glands, especially after exposure to mepivacaine and lidocaine plus epinephrine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>With these findings in rats, it is hypothesized that the temporary diplopia sometimes seen in patients after ophthalmic surgery might be due to anesthetic-induced damage to the extraocular muscles.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Reversal of neuroleptic-induced catalepsy by novel aryl-piperazine anxiolytic drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The novel anxiolytic drug, buspirone, reverses catalepsy induced by haloperidol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A series of aryl-piperazine analogues of buspirone and other 5-hydroxytryptaminergic agonists were tested for their ability to reverse haloperidol induced catalepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Those drugs with strong affinity for 5-hydroxytryptamine1a receptors were able to reverse catalepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Drugs with affinity for other 5-HT receptors or weak affinity were ineffective.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, inhibition of postsynaptic 5-HT receptors neither inhibited nor potentiated reversal of catalepsy and leaves open the question as to the site or mechanism for this effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Diazepam facilitates reflex bradycardia in conscious rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of diazepam on cardiovascular function were assessed in conscious rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intravenous administration of diazepam (1-30 mg kg-1) produced a dose-dependent decrease in both the mean arterial pressure and the heart rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Also, reflex bradycardia was produced in rats by intravenous infusion of adrenaline (1.25-2.5 micrograms kg-1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intravenous pretreatment of the rats with diazepam, although causing no change in the adrenaline-induced pressor effect, did enhance the adrenaline-induced reflex bradycardia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, the diazepam enhancement of adrenaline-induced reflex bradycardia was antagonized by pretreatment of rats with an intravenous dose of picrotoxin (an agent blocks chloride channels by binding to sites associated with the benzodiazepine-GABA-chloride channel macromolecular complex).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The data indicate that diazepam acts through the benzodiazepine-GABA-chloride channel macromolecular complex within the central nervous system to facilitate reflex bradycardia mediated through baroreceptor reflexes in response to an acute increase in arterial pressure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronic carbamazepine inhibits the development of local anesthetic seizures kindled by cocaine and lidocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of carbamazepine (CBZ) treatment on local anesthetic-kindled seizures and lethality were evaluated in different stages of the kindling process and under different methods of CBZ administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronic oral CBZ inhibited the development of both lidocaine- and cocaine-induced seizures, but had little effect on the fully developed local anesthetic seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronic CBZ also decreased the incidence of seizure-related mortality in the cocaine-injected rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Acute CBZ over a range of doses (15-50 mg/kg) had no effect on completed lidocaine-kindled or acute cocaine-induced seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Repeated i.p. injection of CBZ (15 mg/kg) also was without effect on the development of lidocaine- or cocaine-kindled seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The differential effects of CBZ depending upon stage of seizure development suggest that distinct mechanisms underlie the development versus maintenance of local anesthetic-kindled seizures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effectiveness of chronic but not repeated, intermittent injections of CBZ suggests that different biochemical consequences result from the different treatment regimens.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possible utility of chronic CBZ in preventing the development of toxic side effects in human cocaine users is suggested by these data, but remains to be directly evaluated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>D-penicillamine in the treatment of localized scleroderma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Localized scleroderma has no recognized internal organ involvement but may be disfiguring and disabling when the cutaneous lesions are extensive or affect children.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There is no accepted or proven treatment for localized scleroderma.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Case reports of 11 patients with severe, extensive localized scleroderma who were treated with D-penicillamine are summarized in this article.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This drug was judged to have a favorable effect on the disease course in 7 (64%) of 11 patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Improvement began within 3 to 6 months and consisted of cessation of active cutaneous lesions in all 7 patients, skin softening in 5, and more normal growth of the affected limb in 2 of 3 children.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Joint stiffness and contractures also improved.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The dose of D-penicillamine associated with a favorable response was as low as 2 to 5 mg/kg per day given over a period ranging from 15 to 53 months.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>D-Penicillamine caused nephrotic syndrome in 1 patient and milder reversible proteinuria in 3 other patients; none developed renal insufficiency.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data suggest that D-penicillamine may be effective in severe cases of localized scleroderma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Preservation of renal blood flow during hypotension induced with fenoldopam in dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The introduction of drugs that could induce hypotension with different pharmacological actions would be advantageous because side effects unique to a specific drug could be minimized by selecting appropriate therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Specific dopamine-1, (DA1) and dopamine-2 (DA2) receptor agonists are now under clinical investigation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fenoldopam mesylate is a specific DA1 receptor agonist that lowers blood pressure by vasodilatation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The hypothesis that fenoldopam could be used to induce hypotension and preserve blood flow to the kidney was tested.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Systemic aortic blood pressure and renal blood flow were measured continuously with a carotid arterial catheter and an electromagnetic flow probe respectively, in order to compare the cardiovascular and renal vascular effects of fenoldopam and sodium nitroprusside in ten dogs under halothane general anaesthesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Mean arterial pressure was decreased 30 +/- 8 per cent from control with infusion of fenoldopam (3.4 +/- 2.0 micrograms.kg-1.min-1) and 34 +/- 4 per cent with infusion of sodium nitroprusside (5.9 micrograms.kg-1.min-1) (NS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Renal blood flow (RBF) increased during fenoldopam-induced hypotension 11 +/- 7 per cent and decreased 21 +/- 8 per cent during sodium nitroprusside-induced hypotension (P less than 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sodium nitroprusside is a non-selective arteriolar and venous vasodilator that can produce redistribution of blood flow away from the kidney during induced hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fenoldopam is a selective dopamine-1 (DA1) receptor agonist that causes vasodilatation to the kidney and other organs with DA1 receptors and preserves blood flow to the kidney during induced hypotension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antiarrhythmic effects of optical isomers of cibenzoline on canine ventricular arrhythmias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antiarrhythmic effects of (+)-cibenzoline and (-)-cibenzoline were examined using two canine ventricular arrhythmia models.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Digitalis arrhythmia, which is suppressed by Na channel blockers, was induced by intermittent intravenous (i.v.) injection of ouabain in pentobarbital-anesthetized dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Adrenaline arrhythmia, which is suppressed by Ca channel blockers, was induced by adrenaline infusion in halothane-anesthetized dogs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ten and 5 mg/kg i.v. (+)-cibenzoline suppressed digitalis- and adrenaline-induced arrhythmias, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The minimum effective plasma concentrations of (+)-cibenzoline for digitalis- and adrenaline-induced arrhythmias were 1.4 +/- 0.4 and 2.0 +/- 0.6 micrograms/ml, respectively (mean +/- SD, n = 6).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A lower dose of 1 mg/kg i.v. of (-)-cibenzoline suppressed the digitalis-induced arrhythmia, whereas 5 mg/kg i.v. was needed to suppress adrenaline-induced arrhythmias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The minimum effective plasma concentrations of (-)-cibenzoline for digitalis- and adrenaline-induced arrhythmia were 0.06 +/- 0.04 and 0.7 +/- 0.1 micrograms/ml, respectively (mean +/- SD, n = 6).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The stronger antiarrhythmic effect of (-)-cibenzoline indicates that (-)-isomer may have an effect nearly 5-20 times stronger in suppressing Na channels, but effects of both drugs on Ca channels may be almost equipotent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of Hibiscus rosa sinensis on reserpine-induced neurobehavioral and biochemical alterations in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of methanolic extract of Hibiscus rosa sinensis (100-300 mg/kg) was studied on reserpine-induced orofacial dyskinesia and neurochemical alterations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rats were treated with intraperitoneal reserpine (1 mg/kg, ip) for 3 days every other day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>On day 5, vacuous chewing movements and tongue protrusions were counted for 5 min. Reserpine treated rats significantly developed vacuous chewing movements and tongue protrusions however, coadministration of Hibiscus rosa sinensis roots extract (100, 200 and 300 mg/kg, per orally) attenuated the effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Biochemical analysis of brain revealed that the reserpine treatment significantly increased lipid peroxidation and decreased levels of superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT) and glutathione reductase (GSH), an index of oxidative stress process.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Coadministration of extract significantly reduced the lipid peroxidation and reversed the decrease in brain SOD, CAT and GSH levels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The results of the present study suggested that Hibiscus rosa sinensis had a protective role against reserpine-induced orofacial dyskinesia and oxidative stress.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Comparison of aqueous and gellan ophthalmic timolol with placebo on the 24-hour heart rate response in patients on treatment for glaucoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Topical beta-blocker treatment is routine therapy in the management of patients with glaucoma.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Therapy results in systemic absorption, however, the degree of reduction of resting and peak heart rate has not been quantified.</Chemical>
<Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This trial evaluated the effect of placebo, 0.5% aqueous timolol (timolol solution) and a 0.5% timolol suspension that forms a gel on application to the conjunctiva (timolol gellan) on the 24-hour heart rate in patients currently being treated for glaucoma to quantify the reduction in mean heart rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS: Forty-three Caucasian patients with primary open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension with a mean (+/-SD) age of 63 (+/-8) years were randomized and crossed over in a double-masked manner to 14 days of treatment with placebo (morning and evening in both eyes), timolol solution (morning and evening in both eyes), or timolol gellan (morning in both eyes with placebo in the evening).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the 13th day of each period, heart rate was recorded continuously during a typical, ambulant 24-hour period.</Chemical>

<Chemical>RESULTS: Both timolol solution and timolol gellan reduced the mean 24-hour heart rate compared with placebo (P < or = .001), and this reduction was most pronounced during the daytime (-7.5% change in mean heart rate, -5.7 beats/min).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Timolol gellan showed a numerically but not significantly smaller reduction in 24-hour heart rate, compared with timolol solution.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>During the night, the mean 12-hour heart rate on placebo and timolol gellan were both significantly less than on timolol solution; the difference between solution and gellan treatments was statistically significant (P = .01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Both timolol solution and timolol gellan decrease the mean 24-hour heart rate compared with placebo.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This response was most pronounced during the active daytime period.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These data quantify the modest bradycardia associated with ophthalmic beta-blocker therapy in a typical patient population on therapy for glaucoma.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although exercise performance was not assessed in this trial, reductions of this magnitude should not have substantial clinical consequences.</Chemical>
<Chemical>5 flourouracil-induced apical ballooning syndrome: a case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The apical ballooning syndrome (ABS) is a recently described stress-mediated acute cardiac syndrome characterized by transient wall-motion abnormalities involving the apex and midventricle with hyperkinesis of the basal left ventricular (LV) segments without obstructive epicardial coronary disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cardiotoxicity is not an uncommon adverse effect of chemotherapeutic agents.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, there are no reports of ABS secondary to chemotherapeutic agents.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We describe the case of a woman who developed the syndrome after chemotherapy for metastatic cancer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 79-year-old woman presented with typical ischemic chest pain, elevated cardiac enzymes with significant ST-segment abnormalities on her electrocardiogram.</Chemical>
<Chemical>She underwent recent chemotherapy with fluorouracil for metastatic colorectal cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Echocardiography revealed a wall-motion abnormality involving the apical and periapical segments which appeared akinetic.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Coronary angiography revealed no obstructive coronary lesions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The patient was stabilized with medical therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Four weeks later she remained completely asymptomatic.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Echocardiogram revealed a normal ejection fraction and a resolution of the apical akinesis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pathogenetic mechanisms of cardiac complications in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy include coronary vasospasm, endothelial damage and consequent thrombus formation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In our patient, both supraphysiologic levels of plasma catecholamines and stress related neuropeptides caused by cancer diagnosis as well as chemotherapy may have contributed the development of ABS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reduction of pain during induction with target-controlled propofol and remifentanil.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pain on injection of propofol is unpleasant.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We hypothesized that propofol infusion pain might be prevented by infusing remifentanil before starting the propofol infusion in a clinical setting where target-controlled infusions (TCI) of both drugs were used.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A prospective, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial was performed to determine the effect-site concentration (Ce) of remifentanil to prevent the pain without producing complications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A total of 128 patients undergoing general surgery were randomly allocated to receive normal saline (control) or remifentanil to a target Ce of 2 ng ml(-1) (R2), 4 ng ml(-1) (R4), or 6 ng ml(-1) (R6) administered via TCI.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>After the target Ce was achieved, the infusion of propofol was started.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Remifentanil-related complications were assessed during the remifentanil infusion, and pain caused by propofol was evaluated using a four-point scale during the propofol infusion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence of pain was significantly lower in Groups R4 and R6 than in the control and R2 groups (12/32 and 6/31 vs 26/31 and 25/32, respectively, P<0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pain was less severe in Groups R4 and R6 than in the control and R2 groups (P<0.001).</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, both incidence and severity of pain were not different between Groups R4 and R6.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No significant complications were observed during the study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>During induction of anaesthesia with TCI of propofol and remifentanil, a significant reduction in propofol infusion pain was achieved without significant complications by prior administration of remifentanil at a target Ce of 4 ng ml(-1).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prenatal exposure to fluoxetine induces fetal pulmonary hypertension in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RATIONALE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor antidepressant widely used by pregnant women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Epidemiological data suggest that fluoxetine exposure prenatally increases the prevalence of persistent pulmonary hypertension syndrome of the newborn.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism responsible for this effect is unclear and paradoxical, considering the current evidence of a pulmonary hypertension protective fluoxetine effect in adult rodents.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To evaluate the fluoxetine effect on fetal rat pulmonary vascular smooth muscle mechanical properties and cell proliferation rate.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pregnant rats were treated with fluoxetine (10 mg/kg) from Day 11 through Day 21 of gestation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fetuses were delivered by cesarean section.</Chemical>

<Chemical>As compared with controls, fluoxetine exposure resulted in fetal pulmonary hypertension as evidenced by an increase in the weight ratio of the right ventricle to the left ventricle plus septum (P = 0.02) and by an increase in pulmonary arterial medial thickness (P < 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Postnatal mortality was increased among experimental animals, and arterial oxygen saturation was 96 +/- 1% in 1-day-old control animals and significantly lower (P < 0.01) in fluoxetine-exposed pups (79 +/- 2%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In vitro, fluoxetine induced pulmonary arterial muscle contraction in fetal, but not adult, animals (P < 0.01) and reduced serotonin-induced contraction at both ages (P < 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After in utero exposure to a low fluoxetine concentration the pulmonary arterial smooth muscle cell proliferation rate was significantly increased in fetal, but not adult, cells (P < 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In contrast to the adult, fluoxetine exposure in utero induces pulmonary hypertension in the fetal rat as a result of a developmentally regulated increase in pulmonary vascular smooth muscle proliferation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Syncope and QT prolongation among patients treated with methadone for heroin dependence in the city of Copenhagen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Methadone is prescribed to heroin addicts to decrease illicit opioid use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Prolongation of the QT interval in the ECG of patients with torsade de pointes (TdP) has been reported in methadone users.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>As heroin addicts sometimes faint while using illicit drugs, doctors might attribute too many episodes of syncope to illicit drug use and thereby underestimate the incidence of TdP in this special population, and the high mortality in this population may, in part, be caused by the proarrhythmic effect of methadone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this cross-sectional study interview, ECGs and blood samples were collected in a population of adult heroin addicts treated with methadone or buprenorphine on a daily basis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Of the patients at the Drug Addiction Service in the municipal of Copenhagen, 450 (approximately 52%) were included.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The QT interval was estimated from 12 lead ECGs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All participants were interviewed about any experience of syncope.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The association between opioid dose and QT, and methadone dose and reporting of syncope was assessed using multivariate linear regression and logistic regression, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: Methadone dose was associated with longer QT interval of 0.140 ms/mg (p = 0.002).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>No association between buprenorphine and QTc was found.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Among the subjects treated with methadone, 28% men and 32% women had prolonged QTc interval.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>None of the subjects treated with buprenorphine had QTc interval >0.440 s((1/2)).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 50 mg higher methadone dose was associated with a 1.2 (95% CI 1.1 to 1.4) times higher odds for syncope.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Methadone is associated with QT prolongation and higher reporting of syncope in a population of heroin addicts.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Peripheral neuropathy caused by high-dose cytosine arabinoside treatment in a patient with acute myeloid leukemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The central nervous system toxicity of high-dose cytosine arabinoside is well recognized, but the toxicity of cytosine arabinoside in the peripheral nervous system has been infrequently reported.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 49-year-old Japanese man was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After he achieved complete remission, he received high-dose cytosine arabinoside treatment (2 g/m2 twice a day for 5 days; total, 20 g/m2) as consolidation therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The first course of high-dose cytosine arabinoside resulted in no unusual symptoms, but on day 21 of the second course of treatment, the patient complained of numbness in his right foot.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Electromyogram and nerve-conduction studies showed peripheral neuropathy in both peroneal nerves.</Chemical>

<Chemical>This neuropathy was gradually resolving; however, after the patient received allogeneic bone marrow transplantation, the symptoms worsened, with the development of graft-versus-host disease, and the symptoms subsequently responded to methylprednisolone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although the mechanisms of peripheral neuropathy are still unclear, high-dose cytosine arabinoside is a therapy that is potentially toxic to the peripheral nervous system, and auto/alloimmunity may play an important role in these mechanisms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Atorvastatin prevented and reversed dexamethasone-induced hypertension in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To assess the antioxidant effects of atorvastatin (atorva) on dexamethasone (dex)-induced hypertension, 60 male Sprague-Dawley rats were treated with atorva 30 mg/kg/day or tap water for 15 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dex increased systolic blood pressure (SBP) from 109 +/- 1.8 to 135 +/- 0.6 mmHg and plasma superoxide (5711 +/- 284.9 saline, 7931 +/- 392.8 U/ml dex, P < 0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this prevention study, SBP in the atorva + dex group was increased from 115 +/- 0.4 to 124 +/- 1.5 mmHg, but this was significantly lower than in the dex-only group (P' < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Atorva reversed dex-induced hypertension (129 +/- 0.6 mmHg, vs. 135 +/- 0.6 mmHg P' < 0.05) and decreased plasma superoxide (7931 +/- 392.8 dex, 1187 +/- 441.2 atorva + dex, P < 0.0001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma nitrate/nitrite (NOx) was decreased in dex-treated rats compared to saline-treated rats (11.2 +/- 1.08 microm, 15.3 +/- 1.17 microm, respectively, P < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Atorva affected neither plasma NOx nor thymus weight.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, atorvastatin prevented and reversed dexamethasone-induced hypertension in the rat.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two prodrugs of potent and selective GluR5 kainate receptor antagonists actives in three animal models of pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Amino acids 5 and 7, two potent and selective competitive GluR5 KA receptor antagonists, exhibited high GluR5 receptor affinity over other glutamate receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Their ester prodrugs 6 and 8 were orally active in three models of pain: reversal of formalin-induced paw licking, carrageenan-induced thermal hyperalgesia, and capsaicin-induced mechanical hyperalgesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sirolimus and mycophenolate mofetil for calcineurin-free immunosuppression in renal transplant recipients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Calcineurin inhibitors, such as cyclosporine and tacrolimus, have been available for almost 20 years.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although these drugs are highly effective and represent the mainstay of transplant immunosuppression, they are associated with acute and chronic nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute nephrotoxicity, which occurs in the early period after transplantation, leads to a higher rate of dialysis, and chronic nephrotoxicity may eventually result in graft loss.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute and chronic nephrotoxicity is becoming more common as the use of marginal kidneys for transplantation increases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two recently available immunosuppressive agents, mycophenolate mofetil and sirolimus (rapamycin), have no nephrotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The use of these drugs in combination with other agents has led to the development of new paradigms of immunosuppressive therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This paper reviews the results of clinical trials that have investigated these new approaches to immunosuppression in renal transplant recipients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Erythropoietin restores the anemia-induced reduction in cyclophosphamide cytotoxicity in rat tumors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of this study was to examine the impact of anemia prevention by recombinant human erythropoietin (rHuEPO) treatment on the cytotoxicity of cyclophosphamide in solid experimental tumors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Anemia was induced using a single dose of carboplatin (50 mg/kg i.v.) resulting in a long-lasting reduction (30%) of the hemoglobin concentration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a second group, the development of anemia was prevented by rHuEPO (1000 IU/kg) administered s.c. three times/week starting 7 days before carboplatin application.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Four days after carboplatin treatment, tumors (DS-sarcoma of the rat) were implanted s.c. onto the hind food dorsum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neither carboplatin nor rHuEPO treatment influenced tumor growth rate per se.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When tumors were treated with a single dose of cyclophosphamide (60 mg/kg i.p.) 5 days after implantation, a growth delay with a subsequent regrowth of the tumors was observed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the anemia group, the growth delay was significantly shorter compared with nonanemic controls (13.3 days versus 8.6 days).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the group where anemia was prevented by rHuEPO treatment, growth delay was comparable with that of nonanemic controls (13.3 days).</Chemical>

<Chemical>These results suggest that chemotherapy-induced anemia reduces cytotoxicity of cyclophosphamide in tumors, whereas correction of anemia by rHuEPO treatment (epoetin alpha) increases the sensitivity, probably as a result of an improved oxygen supply to tumor tissue.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The role of nitrergic system in lidocaine-induced convulsion in the mouse.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effects of N-nitro-L-arginine-methyl ester (L-NAME) a nitric oxide (NO) synthase inhibitor and L-arginine, a NO precursor, were investigated on lidocaine-induced convulsions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the first experiment, four groups of mice received physiological saline (0.9%), L-arginine (300 mg/kg, i.p.), L-NAME (100 mg/kg, i.p.) and diazepam (2 mg/kg), respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty minutes after these injections, all mice received lidocaine (50 mg/kg, i.p.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the second experiment, four groups of mice received similar treatment in the first experiment, and 30 min after these injections, all mice received a higher dose of lidocaine (80 mg/kg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>L-NAME (100 mg/kg, i.p.) and diazepam (2 mg/kg) significantly decreased the incidence of lidocaine (50 mg/kg)-induced convulsions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, the L-arginine treatment increased the incidence of lidocaine (80 mg/kg, i.p.)-induced convulsions significantly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results may suggest that NO is a proconvulsant mediator in lidocaine-induced convulsions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of intravenous metoprolol or intravenous metoprolol plus glucagon on dobutamine-induced myocardial ischemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>STUDY OBJECTIVE: To determine the effect of metoprolol on dobutamine stress testing with technetium-99m sestamibi single-photon emission computed tomography imaging and ST-segment monitoring, and to assess the impact of intravenous glucagon on metoprolol's effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING: Community hospital.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS: Twenty-two patients with known reversible perfusion defects.</Chemical>
<Chemical>INTERVENTION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients underwent dobutamine stress tests per standard protocol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Before dobutamine was begun, no therapy was given during the first visit, and patients were randomized on subsequent visits to receive metoprolol or metoprolol plus glucagon 1 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Metoprolol was dosed to achieve a resting predobutamine heart rate below 65 beats/minute or a total intravenous dose of 20 mg. MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS:</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Metoprolol reduced maximum heart rate 31%, summed stress scores 29%, and summed difference scores 43% versus control.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Metoprolol plus glucagon also reduced the maximum heart rate 29% versus control.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Summed stress and summed difference scores were not significantly reduced, although they were 18% and 30% lower, respectively, than control.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No significant differences were found in any parameter between metoprolol and metoprolol-glucagon.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>During dobutamine stress testing, metoprolol attenuates or eliminates evidence of myocardial ischemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Glucagon 1 mg, although somewhat effective, does not correct this effect to the extent that it can be administered clinically.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Prednisolone-induced muscle dysfunction is caused more by atrophy than by altered acetylcholine receptor expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Large doses of glucocorticoids can alter muscle physiology and susceptibility to neuromuscular blocking drugs by mechanisms not clearly understood.</Chemical>

<Chemical>We investigated the effects of moderate and large doses of prednisolone on muscle function and pharmacology, and their relationship to changes in muscle size and acetylcholine receptor (AChR) expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>With institutional approval, 35 Sprague-Dawley rats were randomly allocated to receive daily subcutaneous doses of 10 mg/kg prednisolone (P10 group), 100 mg/kg prednisolone (P100 group), or an equal volume of saline (S group) for 7 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A fourth group of rats was pair fed (food restricted) with the P100 rats for 7 days (FR group).</Chemical>

<Chemical>On Day 8, the nerve-evoked peak twitch tensions, tetanic tensions, and fatigability, and the dose-response curves of d-tubocurarine in the tibialis cranialis muscle were measured in vivo and related to muscle mass or expression of AChRs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rate of body weight gain was depressed in the P100, FR, and P10 groups compared with the S group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tibialis muscle mass was smaller in the P100 group than in the P10 or S groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The evoked peak twitch and tetanic tensions were less in the P100 group than in the P10 or S groups, however, tension per milligram of muscle mass was greater in the P100 group than in the S group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The 50% effective dose of d-tubocurarine (microg/kg) in the tibialis muscle was smaller in the P10 (33.6 +/- 5.4) than in the S (61.9 +/- 5.0) or the P100 (71.3 +/- 9.6) groups.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AChR expression was less in the P10 group than in the S group.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The evoked tensions correlated with muscle mass (r(2) = 0.32, P < 0.001), however, not with expression of AChR.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The 50% effective dose of d-tubocurarine did not correlate with muscle mass or AChR expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our results suggest that the neuromuscular dysfunction after prednisolone is dose-dependent, and derives primarily from muscle atrophy and derives less so from changes in AChR expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>IMPLICATIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mechanisms by which chronic glucocorticoid therapy alters neuromuscular physiology and pharmacology are unclear.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We suggest that the observed effects are dose-dependent and derive primarily from muscle atrophy and derive less from changes in acetylcholine receptor expression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Rapid reversal of life-threatening diltiazem-induced tetany with calcium chloride.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe a patient who developed tetany with sudden respiratory arrest after the infusion of intravenous diltiazem.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The administration of calcium chloride rapidly resolved the patient's tetany with prompt recovery of respiratory function, averting the need for more aggressive airway management and ventilatory support.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The emergency physician should be aware that life-threatening tetany may accompany the administration of intravenous diltiazem and that calcium chloride may be a rapid and effective remedy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effects of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs on hemostasis in patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Platelet function is impaired by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) with prominent anti-inflammatory properties.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Their safety in patients undergoing intracranial surgery is under debate.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) were randomized to receive either ketoprofen, 100 mg, three times a day (ketoprofen group, n = 9) or a weak NSAID, acetaminophen, 1 g, three times a day (acetaminophen group, n = 9) starting immediately after the diagnosis of aneurysmal SAH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment was continued for 3 days postoperatively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Test blood samples were taken before treatment and surgery as well as on the first, third, and fifth postoperative mornings.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Maximal platelet aggregation induced by 6 microM of adenosine diphosphate decreased after administration of ketoprofen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Aggregation was lower (P < .05) in the ketoprofen group than in the acetaminophen group just before surgery and on the third postoperative day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, maximal platelet aggregation increased in the acetaminophen group on the third postoperative day as compared with the pretreatment platelet aggregation results (P < .05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>One patient in the ketoprofen group developed a postoperative intracranial hematoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Coagulation (prothrombin time [PT], activated partial thromboplastin time</Chemical>
<Chemical>[APPT], fibrinogen concentration, and antithrombin III</Chemical>
<Chemical>[AT III]) was comparable between the two groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ketoprofen but not acetaminophen impaired platelet function in patients with SAH.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>If ketoprofen is used before surgery on cerebral artery aneurysms, it may pose an additional risk factor for hemorrhage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Value of methylprednisolone in prevention of the arthralgia-myalgia syndrome associated with the total dose infusion of iron dextran: a double blind randomized trial.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The safety and efficacy of total dose infusion (TDI) of iron dextran has been well documented.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In 40% of treated patients, an arthralgia-myalgia syndrome develops.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The purpose of this randomized, double-blind, prospective study was to investigate whether intravenous (i.v.) administration of methylprednisolone (MP) prevents this complication.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Sixty-five patients, 34 women and 31 men, ages 36 to 80 years, received either normal saline before and after TDI (group 1), 125 mg i.v. MP before and saline after TDI (group 2), or 125 mg i.v. MP before and after TDI (group 3).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients were observed for 72 hours and reactions were recorded and graded according to severity.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fifty-eight percent of group 1 patients, 33% of group 2, and 26% of group 3 had reactions to TDI.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The severity of reactions (minimal, mild, and moderate, respectively) was as follows: group 1--6, 6, and 2; group 2--1, 5, and 0; group 3--5, 1, and 0.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Data were analyzed by the two-sided Fisher's exact test using 95% confidence intervals with the approximation of Woolf.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These data demonstrate that administration of MP before and after TDI reduces the frequency and severity of the arthralgia-myalgia syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that 125 mg i.v. MP should be given routinely before and after TDI of iron dextran.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Twenty-seven patients reported neuropathic symptoms.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In the other 14 patients symptoms had been present in the past.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Symptoms persisted maximally 40 months since cessation of therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was no age difference between patients with and without complaints at the time of examination.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Normal reflexes were found in two third of patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neuropathic complaints were not very troublesome on the long term.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is concluded that with the above mentioned vincristine dose schedule signs and symptoms of vincristine neuropathy are reversible for a great deal and prognosis is fairly good.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present work has been planned in order to elucidate the effect of phenobarbital (PB: 15 mg per rat of ingested dose) on carcinogenesis when it is administered simultaneously with diethylnitrosamine (DEN: 10 mg/kg/day).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Wistar rats (180 g) were treated by DEN alone or by DEN + PB during 2, 4 and 6 weeks according to our schedule for hepatocarcinogenesis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After the end of the treatment, the number and the size of induced PAS positive preneoplastic foci was significantly reduced when PB was given simultaneously with DEN for 4 and 6 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mitotic inhibition and the production of micronuclei normally observed after partial hepatectomy in DEN treated rats were also significantly decreased in DEN + PB treated rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When the treatment last only 2 weeks, the presence of PB did not change significantly the last parameters.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All patients were studied by repeated physical examinations, chest X-rays, electro- and echocardiography and radionuclide left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) determinations.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The cardiac failure was predicted by a drop in EF determined during a cold pressor test.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Based on the combined data from the present study and the literature, we suggest that MMC-related cardiotoxicity is dose dependent, occurring at cumulative dose levels of 30 mg m-2 or more, mainly in patients also (previously or simultaneously) treated with doxorubicin.</Chemical>
