text: <Chemical>Effects of the hippocampal deep brain stimulation on cortical epileptic discharges in penicillin - induced epilepsy model in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>AIM:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Experimental and clinical studies have revealed that hippocampal DBS can control epileptic activity, but the mechanism of action is obscure and optimal stimulation parameters are not clearly defined.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim was to evaluate the effects of high frequency hippocampal stimulation on cortical epileptic activity in penicillin-induced epilepsy model.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIAL AND METHODS: Twenty-five Sprague-Dawley rats were implanted DBS electrodes.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In group-1 (n=10) hippocampal DBS was off and in the group-2 (n=10) hippocampal DBS was on (185 Hz, 0.5V, 1V, 2V, and 5V for 60 sec) following penicillin G injection intracortically.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the control group hippocampal DBS was on following 8  l saline injection intracortically.</Chemical>

<Chemical>EEG recordings were obtained before and 15 minutes following penicillin-G injection, and at 10th minutes following each stimulus for analysis in terms of frequency, amplitude, and power spectrum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS: High frequency hippocampal DBS suppressed the acute penicillin-induced cortical epileptic activity independent from stimulus intensity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the control group, hippocampal stimulation alone lead only to diffuse slowing of cerebral bioelectrical activity at 5V stimulation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results revealed that continuous high frequency stimulation of the hippocampus suppressed acute cortical epileptic activity effectively without causing secondary epileptic discharges.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results are important in terms of defining the optimal parameters of hippocampal DBS in patients with epilepsy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Neural correlates of S-ketamine induced psychosis during overt continuous verbal fluency.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The glutamatergic N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor has been implicated in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administered to healthy volunteers, a subanesthetic dose of the non-competitive NMDA receptor antagonist ketamine leads to psychopathological symptoms similar to those observed in schizophrenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients with schizophrenia, ketamine exacerbates the core symptoms of illness, supporting the hypothesis of a glutamatergic dysfunction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In a counterbalanced, placebo-controlled, double-blind study design, healthy subjects were administered a continuous subanesthetic S-ketamine infusion while differences in BOLD responses measured with fMRI were detected.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During the scanning period, subjects performed continuous overt verbal fluency tasks (phonological, lexical and semantic).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ketamine-induced psychopathological symptoms were assessed with the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketamine elicited psychosis like psychopathology.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Post-hoc t-tests revealed significant differences between placebo and ketamine for the amounts of words generated during lexical and semantic verbal fluency, while the phonological domain remained unaffected.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketamine led to enhanced cortical activations in supramarginal and frontal brain regions for phonological and lexical verbal fluency, but not for semantic verbal fluency.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ketamine induces activation changes in healthy subjects similar to those observed in patients with schizophrenia, particularly in frontal and temporal brain regions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our results provide further support for the hypothesis of an NMDA receptor dysfunction in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Dopamine is not essential for the development of methamphetamine-induced neurotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is widely believed that dopamine (DA) mediates methamphetamine (METH)-induced toxicity to brain dopaminergic neurons, because drugs that interfere with DA neurotransmission decrease toxicity, whereas drugs that increase DA neurotransmission enhance toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, temperature effects of drugs that have been used to manipulate brain DA neurotransmission confound interpretation of the data.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Here we show that the recently reported ability of L-dihydroxyphenylalanine to reverse the protective effect of alpha-methyl-para-tyrosine on METH-induced DA neurotoxicity is also confounded by drug effects on body temperature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Further, we show that mice genetically engineered to be deficient in brain DA develop METH neurotoxicity, as long as the thermic effects of METH are preserved.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, we demonstrate that mice genetically engineered to have unilateral brain DA deficits develop METH-induced dopaminergic deficits that are of comparable magnitude on both sides of the brain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Taken together, these findings demonstrate that DA is not essential for the development of METH-induced dopaminergic neurotoxicity and suggest that mechanisms independent of DA warrant more intense investigation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The protective role of Nrf2 in streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Diabetic nephropathy is one of the major causes of renal failure, which is accompanied by the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nrf2 is the primary transcription factor that controls the antioxidant response essential for maintaining cellular redox homeostasis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Here, we report our findings demonstrating a protective role of Nrf2 against diabetic nephropathy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>We explore the protective role of Nrf2 against diabetic nephropathy using human kidney biopsy tissues from diabetic nephropathy patients, a streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy model in Nrf2(-/-) mice, and cultured human mesangial cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The glomeruli of human diabetic nephropathy patients were under oxidative stress and had elevated Nrf2 levels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the animal study, Nrf2 was demonstrated to be crucial in ameliorating streptozotocin-induced renal damage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is evident by Nrf2(-/-) mice having higher ROS production and suffering from greater oxidative DNA damage and renal injury compared with Nrf2(+/+) mice.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Mechanistic studies in both in vivo and in vitro systems showed that the Nrf2-mediated protection against diabetic nephropathy is, at least, partially through inhibition of transforming growth factor-beta1 (TGF-beta1) and reduction of extracellular matrix production.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In human renal mesangial cells, high glucose induced ROS production and activated expression of Nrf2 and its downstream genes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, activation or overexpression of Nrf2 inhibited the promoter activity of TGF-beta1 in a dose-dependent manner, whereas knockdown of Nrf2 by siRNA enhanced TGF-beta1 transcription and fibronectin production.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This work clearly indicates a protective role of Nrf2 in diabetic nephropathy, suggesting that dietary or therapeutic activation of Nrf2 could be used as a strategy to prevent or slow down the progression of diabetic nephropathy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>High-dose tranexamic Acid is associated with nonischemic clinical seizures in cardiac surgical patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>In 2 separate centers, we observed a notable increase in the incidence of postoperative convulsive seizures from 1.3% to 3.8% in patients having undergone major cardiac surgical procedures.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These events were temporally coincident with the initial use of high-dose tranexamic acid (TXA) therapy after withdrawal of aprotinin from general clinical usage.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of this review was to perform a retrospective analysis to examine whether there was a relation between TXA usage and seizures after cardiac surgery.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>An in-depth chart review was undertaken in all 24 patients who developed perioperative seizures.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Electroencephalographic activity was recorded in 11 of these patients, and all patients had a formal neurological evaluation and brain imaging studies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Twenty-one of the 24 patients did not have evidence of new cerebral ischemic injury, but seizures were likely due to ischemic brain injury in 3 patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients with seizures did not have permanent neurological abnormalities.</Chemical>

<Chemical>All 24 patients with seizures received high doses of TXA intraoperatively ranging from 61 to 259 mg/kg, had a mean age of 69.9 years, and 21 of 24 had undergone open chamber rather than coronary bypass procedures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All but one patient were managed using cardiopulmonary bypass.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No evidence of brain ischemic, metabolic, or hyperthermia-induced causes for their seizures was apparent.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Our results suggest that use of high-dose TXA in older patients in conjunction with cardiopulmonary bypass and open-chamber cardiac surgery is associated with clinical seizures in susceptible patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A phase III clinical trial assessed the recurrence of adenomatous polyps after treatment for 36 months with difluoromethylornithine (DFMO) plus sulindac or matched placebos.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Temporary hearing loss is a known toxicity of treatment with DFMO, thus a comprehensive approach was developed to analyze serial air conduction audiograms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The generalized estimating equation method estimated the mean difference between treatment arms with regard to change in air conduction pure tone thresholds while accounting for within-subject correlation due to repeated measurements at frequencies.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Based on 290 subjects, there was an average difference of 0.50 dB between subjects treated with DFMO plus sulindac compared with those treated with placebo (95% confidence interval, -0.64 to 1.63 dB; P = 0.39), adjusted for baseline values, age, and frequencies.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the normal speech range of 500 to 3,000 Hz, an estimated difference of 0.99 dB (-0.17 to 2.14 dB; P = 0.09) was detected.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Follow-up air conduction done at least 6 months after end of treatment showed an adjusted mean difference in hearing thresholds of 1.08 dB (-0.81 to 2.96 dB; P = 0.26) between treatment arms.</Chemical>

<Chemical>There was no significant difference in the proportion of subjects in the DFMO plus sulindac group who experienced clinically significant hearing loss compared with the placebo group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The estimated attributable risk of ototoxicity from exposure to the drug is 8.4% (95% confidence interval, -2.0% to 18.8%; P = 0.12).</Chemical>
<Chemical>There is a <2 dB difference in mean threshold for patients treated with DFMO plus sulindac compared with those treated with placebo.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Increased mental slowing associated with the APOE epsilon4 allele after trihexyphenidyl oral anticholinergic challenge in healthy elderly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The objectives of this study were to examine the relationship between APOE epsilon4 and subjective effects of trihexyphenidyl on measures reflecting sedation and confusion and to investigate the relationship between trihexyphenidyl-induced subjective effects and objective memory performance.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study comprised 24 cognitively intact, health elderly adults (12 APOE epsilon4 carriers) at an outpatient geriatric psychiatry research clinic.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This was a randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled, three-way, crossover experimental design.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All participants received 1.0 mg or 2.0 mg trihexyphenidyl or placebo administered in counterbalanced sequences over a period of three consecutive weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Bond and Lader's visual analog scales and alternate versions of the Buschke Selective Reminding Test were administered in a repeated measures design at baseline, 1, 2.5, and 5 hours postdrug administration.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>A 2.0-mg oral dose of trihexyphenidyl resulted in increased subjective ratings of mental slowness in carriers of the APOE epsilon4 allele only.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Drug effects as determined by difference scores between 2.0 mg trihexyphenidyl and placebo on ratings of mental slowness significantly correlated with total and delayed recall on the Buschke Selective Reminding Test in carriers of the APOE epsilon4 allele only.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, no significant effects were found with other visual analog scales reflecting subjective sedation and clear-headedness.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The epsilon4 allele in healthy elderly was associated with increased subjective mental slowing after trihexyphenidyl anticholinergic challenge.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Behavioral effects of pubertal anabolic androgenic steroid exposure in male rats with low serotonin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The goal of this study was to assess the interactive effects of chronic anabolic androgenic steroid (AAS) exposure and brain serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT) depletion on behavior of pubertal male rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serotonin was depleted beginning on postnatal day 26 with parachlorophenylalanine (PCPA 100 mg/kg, every other day); controls received saline.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>At puberty (P40), half the PCPA-treated rats and half the saline-treated rats began treatment with testosterone (T, 5 mg/kg, 5 days/week).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Behavioral measures included locomotion, irritability, copulation, partner preference, and aggression.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Animals were tested for aggression in their home cage, both with and without physical provocation (mild tail pinch).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Brain levels of 5-HT and its metabolite, 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), were determined using HPLC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PCPA significantly and substantially depleted 5-HT and 5-HIAA in all brain regions examined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronic T treatment significantly decreased 5-HT and 5-HIAA in certain brain areas, but to a much lesser extent than PCPA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Chronic exposure to PCPA alone significantly decreased locomotor activity and increased irritability but had no effect on sexual behavior, partner preference, or aggression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>T alone had no effect on locomotion, irritability, or sexual behavior but increased partner preference and aggression.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The most striking effect of combining T+PCPA was a significant increase in attack frequency as well as a significant decrease in the latency to attack, particularly following physical provocation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Based on these data, it can be speculated that pubertal AAS users with low central 5-HT may be especially prone to exhibit aggressive behavior.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Intracavitary chemotherapy (paclitaxel/carboplatin liquid crystalline cubic phases) for recurrent glioblastoma -- clinical observations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Human malignant brain tumors have a poor prognosis in spite of surgery and radiation therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cubic phases consist of curved biocontinuous lipid bilayers, separating two congruent networks of water channels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Used as a host for cytotoxic drugs, the gel-like matrix can easily be applied to the walls of a surgical resection cavity.</Chemical>

<Chemical>For human glioblastoma recurrences, the feasibility, safety, and short-term effects of a surgical intracavitary application of paclitaxel and carboplatin encapsulated by liquid crystalline cubic phases are examined in a pilot study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A total of 12 patients with a recurrence of a glioblastoma multiforme underwent re-resection and received an intracavitary application of paclitaxel and carboplatin cubic phases in different dosages.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six of the patients received more than 15 mg paclitaxel and suffered from moderate to severe brain edema, while the remaining patients received only a total of 15 mg paclitaxel.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the latter group, brain edema was markedly reduced and dealt medically.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Intracavitary chemotherapy in recurrent glioblastoma using cubic phases is feasible and safe, yet the clinical benefit remains to be examined in a clinical phase II study.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Significant obsessive-compulsive behavior ensued but diminished over several weeks when methylphenidate was replaced by fluvoxamine.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient had no prior psychiatric history, but he had a sister with obsessive-compulsive disorder.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient received metoclopramide 10 mg i.v. five times during 48 h. After interviewing the attending nurses and reviewing the written documentation, it is clear that every administration of metoclopramide was immediately (within s) followed by asystole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The asystole lasted 15-30 s on four occasions, on one occasion it lasted 2 min.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We interpret this as episodes of cardiac arrest caused by metoclopramide.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Cauda equina syndrome after spinal anaesthesia with hyperbaric 5% lignocaine: a review of six cases of cauda equina syndrome reported to the Swedish Pharmaceutical Insurance 1993-1997.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Six cases of cauda equina syndrome with varying severity were reported to the Swedish Pharmaceutical Insurance during the period 1993-1997.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All were associated with spinal anaesthesia using hyperbaric 5% lignocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five cases had single-shot spinal anaesthesia and one had a repeat spinal anaesthetic due to inadequate block.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The dose of hyperbaric 5% lignocaine administered ranged from 60 to 120 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three of the cases were most likely caused by direct neurotoxicity of hyperbaric 5% lignocaine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the other 3 cases, direct neurotoxicity was also probable, but unfortunately radiological investigations were not done to definitely exclude a compressive aetiology.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All cases sustained permanent neurological deficits.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We recommend that hyperbaric lignocaine should be administered in concentrations not greater than 2% and at a total dose preferably not exceeding 60 mg.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Cortical motor overactivation in parkinsonian patients with L-dopa-induced peak-dose dyskinesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We have studied the regional cerebral blood flow (rCBF) changes induced by the execution of a finger-to-thumb opposition motor task in the supplementary and primary motor cortex of two groups of parkinsonian patients on L-dopa medication, the first one without L-dopa induced dyskinesia (n = 23) and the other with moderate peak-dose dyskinesia (n = 15), and of a group of 14 normal subjects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Single photon emission tomography with i.v. 133Xe was used to measure the rCBF changes.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The dyskinetic parkinsonian patients exhibited a pattern of response which was markedly different from those of the normal subjects and non-dyskinetic parkinsonian patients, with a significant overactivation in the supplementary motor area and the ipsi- and contralateral primary motor areas.</Chemical>

<Chemical>These results are compatible with the hypothesis that an hyperkinetic abnormal involuntary movement, like L-dopa-induced peak dose dyskinesia, is due to a disinhibition of the primary and associated motor cortex secondary to an excessive outflow of the pallidothalamocortical motor loop.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dexamethasone-induced ocular hypertension in perfusion-cultured human eyes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Glucocorticoid administration can lead to the development of ocular hypertension and corticosteroid glaucoma in a subset of the population through a decrease in the aqueous humor outflow facility.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The purpose of this study was to determine whether glucocorticoid treatment can directly affect the outflow facility of isolated, perfusion-cultured human eyes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The anterior segments of human donor eyes from regional eye banks were placed in a constant flow, variable pressure perfusion culture system.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Paired eyes were perfused in serum-free media with or without 10(-7)</Chemical>
<Chemical>M dexamethasone for 12 days.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intraocular pressure was monitored daily.</Chemical>
<Chemical>After incubation, the eyes were morphologically characterized by light microscopy, transmission and scanning electron microscopy, and scanning laser confocal microscopy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A significant increase in intraocular pressure developed in 13 of the 44 pairs of eyes perfused with dexamethasone with an average pressure rise of 17.5 +/- 3.8 mm Hg after 12 days of dexamethasone exposure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The contralateral control eyes, which did not receive dexamethasone, maintained a stable intraocular pressure during the same period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The outflow pathway of the untreated eyes appeared morphologically normal.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In contrast, the dexamethasone-treated hypertensive eyes had thickened trabecular beams, decreased intertrabecular spaces, thickened juxtacanalicular tissue, activated trabecular meshwork cells, and increased amounts of amorphogranular extracellular material, especially in the juxtacanalicular tissue and beneath the endothelial lining of the canal of Schlemm.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dexamethasone-treated nonresponder eyes appeared to be morphologically similar to the untreated eyes, although several subtle dexamethasone-induced morphologic changes were evident.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION: Dexamethasone treatment of isolated, perfusion-cultured human eyes led to the generation of ocular hypertension in approximately 30% of the dexamethasone-treated eyes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Steroid treatment resulted in morphologic changes in the trabecular meshwork similar to those reported for corticosteroid glaucoma and open angle glaucoma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This system may provide an acute model in which to study the pathogenic mechanisms involved in steroid glaucoma and primary open angle glaucoma.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cognitive deterioration from long-term abuse of dextromethorphan: a case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dextromethorphan (DM), the dextrorotatory isomer of 3-hydroxy-N-methylmorphinan, is the main ingredient in a number of widely available, over-the-counter antitussives.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Initial studies (Bornstein 1968) showed that it possessed no respiratory suppressant effects and no addiction liability.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Subsequently, however, several articles reporting abuse of this drug have appeared in the literature.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The drug is known to cause a variety of acute toxic effects, ranging from nausea, restlessness, insomnia, ataxia, slurred speech and nystagmus to mood changes, perceptual alterations, inattention, disorientation and aggressive behavior (Rammer et al 1988; Katona and Watson 1986; Isbell and Fraser 1953; Devlin et al 1985; McCarthy 1971; Dodds and Revai 1967; Degkwitz 1964; Hildebrand et al 1989).</Chemical>
<Chemical>There have also been two reported fatalities from DM overdoses (Fleming 1986).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, there are no reports describing the effects of chronic abuse.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This report describes a case of cognitive deterioration resulting from prolonged use of DM.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Long-term lithium treatment and the kidney. Interim report on fifty patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is a report on the first part of our study of the effects of long-term lithium treatment on the kidney.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Creatinine clearance, maximum urinary osmolality and 24 hour urine volume have been tested in 50 affectively ill patients who have been on long-term lithium for more than one year.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These findings have been compared with norms and with values of the same tests from screening prior to lithium, available for most of our patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>No evidence was found for any reduction of glomerular filtration during lithium treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Low clearance values found in several patients could be accounted for by their age and their pre-lithium values.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urinary concentration defect appeared frequent but the extent of the impairment is difficult to assess because of the uncertainty about the norms applicable to this group of patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The concentration defect appeared reversible, at least in part.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Polyuria above 3 litres/24 hours was found in 10% of patients.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An attempt is made to draw practical conclusions from the preliminary findings.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The case illustrates that, despite the results of earlier studies, trazodone's effect on cardiac conduction may be severe in individuals at risk for conduction delay.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>After delivery, the patient underwent orthotopic liver transplantation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The epidemiology of the acute flank pain syndrome from suprofen.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Suprofen, a new nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, was marketed in early 1986 as an analgesic agent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Until physicians began reporting an unusual acute flank pain syndrome to the spontaneous reporting system, 700,000 persons used the drug in the United States.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Through August 1986, a total of 163 cases of this syndrome were reported.</Chemical>

<Chemical>To elucidate the epidemiology of the syndrome, a case-control study was performed, comparing 62 of the case patients who had been reported to the spontaneous reporting system to 185 suprofen-exposed control subjects who did not have the syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Case patients were more likely to be men (odds ratio, 3.8; 95% confidence interval, 1.2-12.1), suffer from hay fever and asthma (odds ratio, 3.4; 95% confidence interval, 1.0-11.9); to participate in regular exercise (odds ratio, 5.9; 95% confidence interval, 1.1-30.7), especially in the use of Nautilus equipment (p = 0.02); and to use alcohol (odds ratio, 4.4; 95% confidence interval, 1.1-17.5).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Possible risk factors included young age, concurrent use of other analgesic agents (especially ibuprofen), preexisting renal disease, a history of kidney stones, a history of gout, a recent increase in activity, a recent increase in sun exposure, and residence in the Sunbelt.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These were findings that were suggestive but did not reach conventional statistical significance.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These findings are consistent with the postulated mechanism for this unusual syndrome: acute diffuse crystallization of uric acid in renal tubules.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hemolytic-uremic syndrome associated with ingestion of quinine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hemolytic-uremic syndrome following quinine ingestion is a newly described phenomenon, with just two previous descriptions of 4 cases in the literature.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe a 5th case.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The reaction may be mediated by the presence of antibodies reactive against platelets in the presence of quinine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment has included use of plasma exchange, prednisone, aspirin, and dipyridamole.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patients have all regained some degree of renal function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, it is unclear whether pharmacological treatment or spontaneous resolution is responsible for the improvement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Quinine-associated hemolytic-uremic syndrome probably occurs more often than is recognized.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is important to recognize this reaction when it occurs and to avoid further quinine exposure, since the reaction seems to be recurrent.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pyeloureteral filling defects associated with systemic anticoagulation: a case report.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The etiology of pyeloureteritis cystica has long been attributed to chronic infection and inflammation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A case is presented that is unique in that the acute onset and the rapid resolution of pyeloureteral filling defects in this patient were documented by radiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>There is no evidence of antecedent or concurrent infection in this patient.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The disease occurred subsequent to the initiation of heparin therapy for suspected pelvic thrombophlebitis and cleared rapidly subsequent to its discontinuation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rate of resolution of the radiographic findings may be helpful in distinguishing between true pyeloureteritis cystica and submucosal hemorrhage.</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Peroxisomes in hepatomas and hyperplastic preneoplastic liver lesions induced in mice by 500 ppm alpha-benzene hexachloride were examined histochemically and electron microscopically.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Although most of the hepatomas were well-differentiated tumors and contained a considerable number of peroxisomes, the tumor cells did not respond to ethyl-alpha-p-chlorophenoxyisobutyrate with proliferation of peroxisomes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At the 16th week of carcinogen feeding, hyperplastic nodules appeared and advanced to further stages.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A majority of the nodules showed a considerable number of peroxisomes and the inductive proliferation of peroxisomes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Within the nodules, foci of proliferation of the cells that showed no inducibility of proliferation of peroxisomes appeared.</Chemical>
<Chemical>These cells proliferated further, replacing the most part of the nodules, and with this process hepatomas appeared to have been formed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No abnormal matrical inclusions of peroxisomes were formed in the cells of hyperplastic nodules by ethyl-alpha-p-chlorophenoxyisobutyrate unlike in the case of rats.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A challenge dose of quinidine caused clinical symptoms and abrupt elevation of SGOT, alkaline phosphatase, and lactic acid dehydrogenase values.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We concluded that this patient had quinidine hepatotoxicity and believe that this is the first case reported with liver biopsy documentation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This report also suggests that, even after long-term administration, the hepatic toxicity is reversible.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cholesteryl hemisuccinate treatment protects rodents from the toxic effects of acetaminophen, adriamycin, carbon tetrachloride, chloroform and galactosamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition to its use as a stabilizer/rigidifier of membranes, cholesteryl hemisuccinate, tris salt (CS) administration has also been shown to protect rats from the hepatotoxic effects of carbon tetrachloride (CCl4).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To further our understanding of the mechanism of CS cytoprotection, we examined in rats and mice the protective abilities of CS and the non-hydrolyzable ether form of CS, gamma-cholesteryloxybutyric acid, tris salt (CSE) against acetaminophen-, adriamycin-, carbon tetrachloride-, chloroform- and galactosamine-induced toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results of these studies demonstrated that CS-mediated protection is not selective for a particular species, organ system or toxic chemical.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 24-h pretreatment of both rats and mice with a single dose of CS (100mg/kg, i.p.), resulted in significant protection against the hepatotoxic effects of CCl4, CHCl3, acetaminophen and galactosamine and against the lethal (and presumably cardiotoxic) effect of adriamycin administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Maximal CS-mediated protection was observed in experimental animals pretreated 24 h prior to the toxic insult.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These data suggest that CS intervenes in a critical cellular event that is an important common pathway to toxic cell death.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism of CS protection does not appear to be dependent on the inhibition of chemical bioactivation to a toxic reactive intermediate (in light of the protection observed against galactosamine hepatotoxicity).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, based on the data presented, we can not exclude the possibility that CS administration inhibits chemical bioactivation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our findings do suggest that CS-mediated protection is dependent on the action of the intact anionic CS molecule (non-hydrolyzable CSE was as protective as CS), whose mechanism has yet to be defined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DSMM XI study: dose definition for intravenous cyclophosphamide in combination with bortezomib/dexamethasone for remission induction in patients with newly diagnosed myeloma.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>A clinical trial was initiated to evaluate the recommended dose of cyclophosphamide in combination with bortezomib and dexamethasone as induction treatment before stem cell transplantation for younger patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (MM).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thirty patients were treated with three 21-day cycles of bortezomib 1.3 mg/m(2) on days 1, 4, 8, and 11 plus dexamethasone 40 mg on the day of bortezomib injection and the day after plus cyclophosphamide at 900, 1,200, or 1,500 mg/m(2) on day 1.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The maximum tolerated dose of cyclophosphamide was defined as 900 mg/m(2).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At this dose level, 92% of patients achieved at least a partial response.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The overall response rate [complete response (CR) plus partial response (PR)] across all dose levels was 77%, with a 10% CR rate.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No patient experienced progressive disease.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The most frequent adverse events were hematological and gastrointestinal toxicities as well as neuropathy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The results suggest that bortezomib in combination with cyclophosphamide at 900 mg/m(2) and dexamethasone is an effective induction treatment for patients with newly diagnosed MM that warrants further investigation.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Results of a comparative, phase III, 12-week, multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind assessment of the efficacy and tolerability of a fixed-dose combination of telmisartan and amlodipine versus amlodipine monotherapy in Indian adults with stage II hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The aim of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of a new fixed-dose combination (FDC) of telmisartan 40 mg +</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>amlodipine 5 mg (T+A) compared with amlodipine 5-mg monotherapy (A) in adult Indian patients with stage II hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>This comparative, Phase III, 12-week, multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind study was conducted in Indian patients aged 18 to 65 years with established stage II hypertension.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Patients were treated with oral FDC of T+A or A QD before breakfast for 12 weeks; blood pressure (BP) and heart rate were measured in the sitting position.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Primary efficacy end points were reduction in clinical systolic BP (SBP)/ diastolic BP (DBP) from baseline to study end and number of responders (ie, patients who achieved target SBP/ DBP <130/<80 mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg) at end of study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Tolerability was assessed by treatment-emergent adverse events, identified using physical examination, laboratory analysis, and electrocardiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A total of 210 patients were enrolled in the study; 203 patients (143 men, 60 women) completed the study while 7 were lost to follow-up (4 patients in the T+A group and 3 in the A group) and considered with-drawn.</Chemical>
<Chemical>At study end, statistically significant percentage reductions from baseline within groups and between groups were observed in SBP (T+A</Chemical>
<Chemical>[-27.4%]; A</Chemical>
<Chemical>[-16.6%]) and DBP (T+A</Chemical>
<Chemical>Response rates were 87.3% (89/102) in the T+A group and 69.3% (70/101) in the A group (P < 0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The prevalences of adverse events were not significantly different between the 2 treatment groups (T+A, 16.0%</Chemical>

<Chemical>Peripheral edema was reported in 8.5% patients (9/106) in the T+A group compared with 13.5% (14/104) in the A group, and cough was reported in 3.8% patients (4/106) in the T+A group and 1.0% (1/104) patients in the A group; these differences did not reach statistical significance.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidences of headache, dizziness, and diarrhea were similar between the 2 groups.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Among these Indian patients with stage II hypertension, the FDC of T+A was found to be significantly more effective, with regard to BP reductions, than A, and both treatments were well tolerated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cutaneous leucocytoclastic vasculitis associated with oxacillin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A 67-year-old man who was treated with oxacillin for one week because of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia, developed renal failure and diffuse, symmetric, palpable purpuric lesions on his feet.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Necrotic blisters were noted on his fingers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Skin biopsies showed findings diagnostic of leucocytoclastic vasculitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Oxacillin was discontinued and patient was treated with corticosteroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The rash disappeared after three weeks and renal function returned to normal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Leucocytoclastic vasculitis presents as palpable purpura of the lower extremities often accompanied by abdominal pain, arthralgia, and renal involvement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Etiologic factors or associated disorders include infections, medications, collagen vascular disease and neoplasia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, in half of the cases no etiologic factor is identified.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Usually it is a self-limited disorder, but corticosteroid therapy may be needed in life-threatening cases since early treatment with corticosteroids in severe cases can prevent complications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oxacillin should be included among the drugs that can cause leucocytoclastic vasculitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Naloxazone pretreatment modifies cardiorespiratory, temperature, and behavioral effects of morphine.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Behavioral and cardiorespiratory responses to a lethal dose of morphine were evaluated in rats pretreated with saline or naloxazone, an antagonist of high-affinity mu 1 opioid receptors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pretreatment with naloxazone significantly blocked morphine analgesia, catalepsy and hypothermia at a dose which completely eliminated high-affinity binding in brain membranes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, naloxazone significantly attenuated the morphine-induced hypotension and respiratory depression, whereas morphine-induced bradycardia was less affected.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Results indicate that subpopulations of mu receptors may mediate selective behavioral and cardiorespiratory responses to morphine.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Dexrazoxane protects against myelosuppression from the DNA cleavage-enhancing drugs etoposide and daunorubicin but not doxorubicin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The anthracyclines daunorubicin and doxorubicin and the epipodophyllotoxin etoposide are potent DNA cleavage-enhancing drugs that are widely used in clinical oncology; however, myelosuppression and cardiac toxicity limit their use.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Dexrazoxane (ICRF-187) is recommended for protection against anthracycline-induced cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Because of their widespread use, the hematologic toxicity following coadministration of dexrazoxane and these three structurally different DNA cleavage enhancers was investigated: Sensitivity of human and murine blood progenitor cells to etoposide, daunorubicin, and doxorubicin +/- dexrazoxane was determined in granulocyte-macrophage colony forming assays.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Likewise, in vivo, B6D2F1 mice were treated with etoposide, daunorubicin, and doxorubicin, with or without dexrazoxane over a wide range of doses: posttreatment, a full hematologic evaluation was done.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Nontoxic doses of dexrazoxane reduced myelosuppression and weight loss from daunorubicin and etoposide in mice and antagonized their antiproliferative effects in the colony assay; however, dexrazoxane neither reduced myelosuppression, weight loss, nor the in vitro cytotoxicity from doxorubicin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although our findings support the observation that dexrazoxane reduces neither hematologic activity nor antitumor activity from doxorubicin clinically, the potent antagonism of daunorubicin activity raises concern; a possible interference with anticancer efficacy certainly would call for renewed attention.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our data also suggest that significant etoposide dose escalation is perhaps possible by the use of dexrazoxane.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Clinical trials in patients with brain metastases combining dexrazoxane and high doses of etoposide is ongoing with the aim of improving efficacy without aggravating hematologic toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>If successful, this represents an exciting mechanism for pharmacologic regulation of side effects from cytotoxic chemotherapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Effects of the novel compound aniracetam (Ro 13-5057) upon impaired learning and memory in rodents.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of aniracetam (Ro 13-5057, 1-anisoyl-2-pyrrolidinone) was studied on various forms of experimentally impaired cognitive functions (learning and memory) in rodents and produced the following effects: (1) almost complete prevention of the incapacity to learn a discrete escape response in rats exposed to sublethal hypercapnia immediately before the acquisition session; (2) partial (rats) or complete (mice) prevention of the scopolamine-induced short-term amnesia for a passive avoidance task; (3) complete protection against amnesia for a passive avoidance task in rats submitted to electroconvulsive shock immediately after avoidance acquisition; (4) prevention of the long-term retention- or retrieval-deficit for a passive avoidance task induced in rats and mice by chloramphenicol or cycloheximide administered immediately after acquisition; (5) reversal, when administered as late as 1 h before the retention test, of the deficit in retention or retrieval of a passive avoidance task induced by cycloheximide injected 2 days previously; (6) prevention of the deficit in the retrieval of an active avoidance task induced in mice by subconvulsant electroshock or hypercapnia applied immediately before retrieval testing (24 h after acquisition).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These improvements or normalizations of impaired cognitive functions were seen at oral aniracetam doses of 10-100 mg/kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Generally, the dose-response curves were bell-shaped.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The mechanisms underlying the activity of aniracetam and its 'therapeutic window' are unknown.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Piracetam, another pyrrolidinone derivative was used for comparison.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It was active only in six of nine tests and had about one-tenth the potency of aniracetam.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results indicate that aniracetam improves cognitive functions which are impaired by different procedure and in different phases of the learning and memory process.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Nicotine potentiation of morphine-induced catalepsy in mice.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study, effects of nicotine on catalepsy induced by morphine in mice have been investigated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Morphine but not nicotine induced a dose-dependent catalepsy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The response of morphine was potentiated by nicotine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intraperitoneal administration of atropine, naloxone, mecamylamine, and hexamethonium to mice reduced catalepsy induced by a combination of morphine with nicotine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intracerebroventricular injection of atropine, hexamethonium, and naloxone also decreased catalepsy induced by morphine plus nicotine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Intraperitoneal administration of atropine, but not intraperitoneal or intracerebroventricular injection of hexamethonium, decreased the effect of a single dose of morphine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It was concluded that morphine catalepsy can be elicited by opioid and cholinergic receptors, and the potentiation of morphine induced by nicotine may also be mediated through cholinergic receptor mechanisms.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Reduced cardiotoxicity and preserved antitumor efficacy of liposome-encapsulated doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide compared with conventional doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide in a randomized, multicenter trial of metastatic breast cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>To determine whether Myocet (liposome-encapsulated doxorubicin; The Liposome Company, Elan Corporation, Princeton, NJ) in combination with cyclophosphamide significantly reduces doxorubicin cardiotoxicity while providing comparable antitumor efficacy in first-line treatment of metastatic breast cancer (MBC).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PATIENTS AND METHODS: Two hundred ninety-seven patients with MBC and no prior chemotherapy for metastatic disease were randomized to receive either 60 mg/m(2) of Myocet (M) or conventional doxorubicin (A), in combination with 600 mg/m(2) of cyclophosphamide (C), every 3 weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cardiotoxicity was defined by reductions in left-ventricular ejection fraction, assessed by serial multigated radionuclide angiography scans, or congestive heart failure (CHF).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Antitumor efficacy was assessed by objective tumor response rates (World Health Organization criteria), time to progression, and survival.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Six percent of MC patients versus 21% (including five cases of CHF) of AC patients developed cardiotoxicity (P =.0002).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Median cumulative doxorubicin dose at onset was more than 2,220 mg/m(2) for MC versus 480 mg/m(2) for AC (P =.0001, hazard ratio, 5.04).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MC patients also experienced less grade 4 neutropenia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Antitumor efficacy of MC versus AC was comparable: objective response rates, 43% versus 43%; median time to progression, 5.1% versus 5.5 months; median time to treatment failure, 4.6 versus 4.4 months; and median survival, 19 versus 16 months.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Myocet improves the therapeutic index of doxorubicin by significantly reducing cardiotoxicity and grade 4 neutropenia and provides comparable antitumor efficacy, when used in combination with cyclophosphamide as first-line therapy for MBC.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Protective effect of a specific platelet-activating factor antagonist, BN 52021, on bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular impairments in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Administration of the local anaesthetic bupivacaine (1.5 or 2 mg/kg, i.v.)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>to rats elicited a marked decrease of mean arterial blood pressure (MBP) and heart rate (HR) leading to death (in 67% or 90% of animals respectively).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Intravenous injection of the specific platelet-activating factor (PAF) antagonist BN 52021 (10 mg/kg), 30 min before bupivacaine administration (2 mg/kg i.v.) suppressed both the decrease of MBP and HR.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In contrast, doses of 1 mg/kg BN 52021 given 30 min before or 10 mg/kg administered 5 min before i.v. injection of bupivacaine were ineffective.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>When BN 52021 (20 mg/kg i.v.) was injected immediately after bupivacaine (2 mg/kg), a partial reversion of the decrease of MBP and HR was observed, whereas the dose of 10 mg/kg was ineffective.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A partial recovery of bupivacaine-induced ECG alterations was observed after pretreatment of the rats with BN 52021.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Since the administration of BN 52021, at all doses studied, did not alter MBP and HR at the doses used, the bulk of these results clearly demonstrate a protective action of BN 52021, a specific antagonist of PAF, against bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, consistent with its direct effect on heart, PAF appears to be implicated in bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular alterations.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Benzylacyclouridine reverses azidothymidine-induced marrow suppression without impairment of anti-human immunodeficiency virus activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Increased extracellular concentrations of uridine (Urd) have been reported to reduce, in vitro, azidothymidine (AZT)-induced inhibition of human granulocyte-macrophage progenitor cells without impairment of its antihuman immunodeficiency virus (HIV) activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because of the clinical toxicities associated with chronic Urd administration, the ability of benzylacyclouridine (BAU) to effect, in vivo, AZT-induced anemia and leukopenia was assessed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This agent inhibits Urd catabolism and, in vivo, increases the plasma concentration of Urd in a dose-dependent manner, without Urd-related toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In mice rendered anemic and leukopenic by the administration of AZT for 28 days in drinking water (1.5 mg/mL), the continued administration of AZT plus daily BAU (300 mg/kg, orally) partially reversed AZT-induced anemia and leukopenia (P less than .05), increased peripheral reticulocytes (to 4.9%, P less than .01), increased cellularity in the marrow, and improved megaloblastosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>When coadministered with AZT from the onset of drug administration, BAU reduced AZT-induced marrow toxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In vitro, at a concentration of 100 mumol/L, BAU possesses minimal anti-HIV activity and has no effect on the ability of AZT to reverse the HIV-induced cytopathic effect in MT4 cells.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The clinical and biochemical implications of these findings are discussed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis in freely-moving conscious rats: behavioral approach to a new model of visceral pain.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To develop a model of visceral pain in rats using a behavioral approach.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cyclophosphamide (CP), an antitumoral agent known to produce toxic effects on the bladder wall through its main toxic metabolite acrolein, was used to induce cystitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>CP was administered at doses of 50, 100 and 200 mg./kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>i.p. to male rats, and their behavior observed and scored.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The effects of morphine (0.5 to 4 mg./kg. i.v.) on CP-induced behavioral modifications were tested administered alone and after naloxone (1 mg./kg. s.c.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, 90 minutes after CP injection, that is, at the time of administration of morphine, the bladder was removed in some rats for histological examination.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Finally, to show that the bladder is essential for the CP-induced behavioral modifications, female rats also received CP at doses of 200 mg./kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>i.p. and of 20 mg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>by the intravesical route, and acrolein at doses of 0.5 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>by the intravesical route and of 5 mg./kg. i.v. RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>CP dose-relatedly induced marked behavioral modifications in male rats: breathing rate decrease, closing of the eyes and occurrence of specific postures.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Morphine dose-dependently reversed these behavioral disorders.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A dose of 0.5 mg./kg. produced a reduction of almost 50% of the behavioral score induced by CP 200 mg./kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This effect was completely prevented by pretreatment with naloxone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At the time of administration of morphine, histological modifications of the bladder wall, such as chorionic and muscle layer edema, were observed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In female rats, CP 200 mg./kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>i.p. produced the same marked behavioral modifications as those observed in male rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Administered at the dose of 20 mg.</Chemical>
<Chemical>intravesically, CP did not produce any behavioral effects, whereas acrolein at 0.5 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>intravesically induced behavioral modifications identical to those under CP 200 mg./kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>i.p., with the same maximal levels.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Conversely, acrolein 5 mg./kg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>i.v. did not produce any behavioral effects at all.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Overall, these results indicate that this experimental model of CP-induced cystitis may be an interesting new behavioral model of inflammatory visceral pain, allowing a better understanding of these painful syndromes and thus a better therapeutic approach to them.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Hyperalgesia and myoclonus in terminal cancer patients treated with continuous intravenous morphine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Eight cancer patients in the terminal stages of the disease treated with high doses of intravenous morphine developed hyperalgesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>All cases were retrospectively sampled from three different hospitals in Copenhagen.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Five patients developed universal hyperalgesia and hyperesthesia which in 2 cases were accompanied by myoclonus.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 3 patients a pre-existing neuralgia increased to excruciating intensity and in 2 of these cases myoclonus occurred simultaneously.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although only few clinical descriptions of the relationship between hyperalgesia/myoclonus and high doses of morphine are available, experimental support from animal studies indicates that morphine, or its metabolites, plays a causative role for the observed behavioural syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possible mechanisms are discussed and treatment proposals given suggesting the use of more efficacious opioids with less excitatory potency in these situations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>A prospective study of adverse reactions associated with vancomycin therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A prospective evaluation of the efficacy and safety of vancomycin was conducted in 54 consecutive patients over a 16-month period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vancomycin was curative in 95% of 43 patients with proven infection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Drugs were ceased in six patients because of adverse reactions; in three of these vancomycin was considered the likely cause.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Reactions included thrombophlebitis (20 of 54 patients), rash (4 of 54), nephrotoxicity (4 of 50), proteinuria (1 of 50) and ototoxicity (1 of 11 patients tested by audiometry).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thrombophlebitis occurred only with infusion through peripheral cannulae; nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity were confined to patients receiving an aminoglycoside plus vancomycin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We conclude that vancomycin, administered appropriately, constitutes safe, effective therapy for infections caused by susceptible bacteria.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Blockade of both D-1 and D-2 dopamine receptors may induce catalepsy in mice.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>1.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>2.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dopamine antagonist fluphenazine, D-1 antagonist SCH 23390 or D-2 antagonist sulpiride induced catalepsy.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>The effect of fluphenazine and sulpiride was dose-dependent.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>4. Combination of SKF 38393 with quinpirole did not cause potentiated inhibitory effect on catalepsy induced by dopamine antagonists.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>5.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The data may indicate that although D-2 receptor blockade is involved in catalepsy, the D-1 receptor may plan a role.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Dextran-etodolac conjugates: synthesis, in vitro and in vivo evaluation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Etodolac (E), is a non-narcotic analgesic and antiinflammatory drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>A biodegradable polymer dextran has been utilized as a carrier for synthesis of etodolac-dextran conjugates (ED) to improve its aqueous solubility and reduce gastrointestinal side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>An activated moiety, i.e. N-acylimidazole derivative of etodolac (EAI), was condensed with the polysaccharide polymer dextran of different molecular weights (40000, 60000, 110000 and 200000).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>IR spectral data confirmed formation of ester bonding in the conjugates.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Etodolac contents were evaluated by UV-spectrophotometric analysis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The molecular weights were determined by measuring viscosity using the Mark-Howink-Sakurada equation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In vitro hydrolysis of ED was done in aqueous buffers (pH 1.2, 7.4, 9) and in 80% (v/v) human plasma (pH 7.4).</Chemical>
<Chemical>At pH 9, a higher rate of etodolac release from ED was observed as compared to aqueous buffer of pH 7.4 and 80% human plasma (pH 7.4), following first-order kinetics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In vivo investigations were performed in animals.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Acute analgesic and antiinflammatory activities were ascertained using acetic acid induced writhing model (mice) and carrageenan-induced rat paw edema model, respectively.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In comparison to control, E and ED1-ED4 showed highly significant analgesic and antiinflammatory activities (p <0.001).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Biological evaluation suggested that conjugates (ED1-ED4) retained comparable analgesic and antiinflammatory activities with remarkably reduced ulcerogenicity as compared to their parent drug--etodolac.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Hypersensitivity myocarditis complicating hypertrophic cardiomyopathy heart.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The present report describes a case of eosinophilic myocarditis complicating hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The 47-year-old female patient, known to have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, was admitted with biventricular failure and managed aggressively with dobutamine infusion and other drugs while being assessed for heart transplantation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>On transthoracic echocardiogram, she had moderate left ventricular dysfunction with regional variability and moderate mitral regurgitation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The recipient's heart showed the features of apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and myocarditis with abundant eosinophils.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Myocarditis is rare and eosinophilic myocarditis is rarer.</Chemical>
<Chemical>It is likely that the hypersensitivity (eosinophilic) myocarditis was related to dobutamine infusion therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Eosinophilic myocarditis has been reported with an incidence of 2.4% to 7.2% in explanted hearts and may be related to multidrug therapy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All- trans-retinoic acid-induced erythema nodosum in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Erythema nodosum associated with all- trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) for acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is very rare.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We describe four patients with classic APL who developed erythema nodosum during ATRA therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fever and subsequent multiple painful erythematous nodules over extremities developed on D11, D16, D17, and D19, respectively, after ATRA therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The skin biopsy taken from each patient was consistent with erythema nodosum.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients received short course of steroids.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fever subsided rapidly and the skin lesions regressed completely.</Chemical>
<Chemical>All patients achieved complete remission without withdrawal of ATRA.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>ATRA seemed to be the most possible etiology of erythema nodosum in our patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Short-term use of steroid is very effective in ATRA-induced erythema nodosum.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Delayed-onset heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia presents 5 to 12 days after heparin exposure, with or without arterial or venous thromboemboli.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Delayed recognition and treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia contribute to poor patient outcomes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To describe and increase awareness of a clinical scenario in which the onset or manifestations of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia are delayed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Retrospective case series.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING: Three large urban hospitals (with active cardiovascular surgery programs).</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS: 14 patients seen over a 3-year period in whom heparin-induced thrombocytopenia became apparent on delayed presentation with thromboembolic complications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MEASUREMENTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Platelet counts, onset of objectively determined thromboembolism, results of heparin-induced platelet factor 4 antibody tests, and outcomes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Patients went home after hospitalizations that had included heparin exposure--in most cases, with no thrombocytopenia recognized--only to return to the hospital (median, day 14) with thromboembolic complications.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thromboemboli were venous (12 patients, 7 with pulmonary emboli) or arterial (4 patients) or both.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Platelet counts were mildly decreased in all but 2 patients on second presentation.</Chemical>

<Chemical>On readmission, 11 patients received therapeutic heparin, which worsened the patients' clinical condition and, in all 11 cases, decreased the platelet count (mean at readmission, 143 x 10(9) cells/L; mean nadir after heparin re-exposure, 39 x 10(9) cells/L).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Results of serologic tests for heparin-induced antibodies were positive in all patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Subsequent treatments included alternative anticoagulants (11 patients), thrombolytic drugs (3 patients), inferior vena cava filters (3 patients) and, eventually, warfarin (11 patients).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three patients died.</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: Delayed-onset heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is increasingly being recognized.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To avoid disastrous outcomes, physicians must consider heparin-induced thrombocytopenia whenever a recently hospitalized patient returns with thromboembolism; therapy with alternative anticoagulants, not heparin, should be initiated.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Valsartan, a new angiotensin II antagonist for the treatment of essential hypertension: a comparative study of the efficacy and safety against amlodipine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To compare the antihypertensive efficacy of a new angiotensin II antagonist, valsartan, with a reference therapy, amlodipine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>One hundred sixty-eight adult outpatients with mild to moderate hypertension were randomly allocated in double-blind fashion and equal number to receive 80 mg valsartan or 5 mg amlodipine for 12 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 8 weeks of therapy, in patients whose blood pressure remained uncontrolled, 5 mg amlodipine was added to the initial therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients were assessed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The primary efficacy variable was change from baseline in mean sitting diastolic blood pressure at 8 weeks.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Secondary variables included change in sitting systolic blood pressure and responder rates.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS: Both valsartan and amlodipine were effective at lowering blood pressure at 4, 8, and 12 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Similar decreases were observed in both groups, with no statistically significant differences between the groups for any variable analyzed.</Chemical>
<Chemical>For the primary variable the difference was 0.5 mm Hg in favor of valsartan (p = 0.68; 95% confidence interval, -2.7 to 1.7).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Responder rates at 8 weeks were 66.7% for valsartan and 60.2% for amlodipine (p = 0.39).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both treatments were well tolerated.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The incidence of drug-related dependent edema was somewhat higher in the amlodipine group, particularly at a dose of 10 mg per day (2.4% for 80 mg valsartan; 3.6% for 5 mg amlodipine; 0% for valsartan plus 5 mg amlodipine; 14.3% for 10 mg amlodipine).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The data show that valsartan is at least as effective as amlodipine in the treatment of mild to moderate hypertension.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results also show valsartan to be well tolerated and suggest that it is not associated with side effects characteristic of this comparator class, dihydropyridine calcium antagonists.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>KF17837: a novel selective adenosine A2A receptor antagonist with anticataleptic activity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>KF17837 is a novel selective adenosine A2A receptor antagonist.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oral administration of KF17837 (2.5, 10.0 and 30.0 mg/kg) significantly ameliorated the cataleptic responses induced by intracerebroventricular administration of an adenosine A2A receptor agonist, CGS 21680 (10 micrograms), in a dose-dependent manner.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>KF17837 also reduced the catalepsy induced by haloperidol (1 mg/kg i.p.) and by reserpine (5 mg/kg i.p.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Severe congestive heart failure patient on amiodarone presenting with myxedemic coma: a case report.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This is a case report of myxedema coma secondary to amiodarone-induced hypothyroidism in a patient with severe congestive heart failure (CHF).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>To our knowledge and after reviewing the literature there is one case report of myxedema coma during long term amiodarone therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Myxedema coma is a life threatening condition that carries a mortality reaching as high as 20% with treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The condition is treated with intravenous thyroxine (T4) or intravenous tri-iodo-thyronine (T3).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Patients with CHF on amiodarone may suffer serious morbidity and mortality from hypothyroidism, and thus may deserve closer follow up for thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This case report carries an important clinical application given the frequent usage of amiodarone among CHF patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The myriad clinical presentation of myxedema coma and its serious morbidity and mortality stresses the need to suspect this clinical syndrome among CHF patients presenting with hypotension, weakness or other unexplained symptoms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Fear-potentiated startle, but not light-enhanced startle, is enhanced by anxiogenic drugs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RATIONALE AND OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The light-enhanced startle paradigm (LES) is suggested to model anxiety, because of the non-specific cue and the long-term effect.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, the fear-potentiated startle (FPS) is suggested to model conditioned fear.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, the pharmacological profiles of these two paradigms are very similar.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The present study investigated the effects of putative anxiogenic drugs on LES and FPS and aimed at determining the sensitivity of LES for anxiogenic drugs and to potentially showing a pharmacological differentiation between these two paradigms.</Chemical>
<Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Male Wistar rats received each dose of the alpha(2)-adrenoceptor antagonist yohimbine (0.25-1.0mg/kg), the 5-HT(2C) receptor agonist m-chlorophenylpiperazine (mCPP, 0.5-2.0mg/kg) or the GABA(A) inverse receptor agonist pentylenetetrazole (PTZ, 3-30mg/kg) and were subsequently tested in either LES or FPS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>None of the drugs enhanced LES, whereas mCPP increased percentage FPS and yohimbine increased absolute FPS values.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, yohimbine increased baseline startle amplitude in the LES, while mCPP suppressed baseline startle in both the LES and FPS and PTZ suppressed baseline startle in the FPS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast to findings in the FPS paradigm, none of the drugs were able to exacerbate the LES response.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thus, a clear pharmacological differentiation was found between LES and FPS.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A 59-year-old woman with ulcerative colitis developed red eyes, pleural effusion, eosinophilia and urinary abnormalities after restarting of sulphasalazine treatment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Light microscopy of a kidney biopsy revealed segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis without deposition of immunoglobulin or complement.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Proteinase 3-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (PR3-ANCA) titer was elevated at 183 ELISA units (EU) in sera (normal range less than 10 EU), myeloperoxidase-ANCA was negative.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Although cessation of sulphasalazine treatment resulted in improvements in fever, red eyes, chest pain, titer of C-reactive protein and volume of the pleural effusions, we initiated steroid therapy, because PR3-ANCA titer rose to 320 EU, eosinophil count increased to 1,100 cells/microl, and the pleural effusion remained.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>One month after steroid therapy, the pleural effusion disappeared, and PR3-ANCA titer normalized 3 months later.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This case suggests that sulphasalazine can induce PR3-ANCA-positive necrotizing glomerulonephritis.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A male neonate with a Chiari malformation and a leaking myelomeningocoele underwent ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion followed by repair of myelomeningocoele.</Chemical>
<Chemical>During anaesthesia and surgery, he inadvertently became moderately hypothermic.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The cardiac depressant actions of phenytoin and hypothermia can be additive.</Chemical>
