text: <Chemical>Amisulpride related tic-like symptoms in an adolescent schizophrenic.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tic disorders can be effectively treated by atypical antipsychotics such as risperidone, olanzapine and ziprasidone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, there are two case reports that show tic-like symptoms, including motor and phonic variants, occurring during treatment with quetiapine or clozapine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We present a 15-year-old girl schizophrenic who developed frequent involuntary eye-blinking movements after 5 months of amisulpride treatment (1000 mg per day).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The tic-like symptoms resolved completely after we reduced the dose of amisulpride down to 800 mg per day.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, her psychosis recurred after the dose reduction.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We then placed her on an additional 100 mg per day of quetiapine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>She has been in complete remission under the combined medications for more than one year and maintains a fair role function.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No more tic-like symptoms or other side effects have been reported.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Together with previously reported cases, our patient suggests that tic-like symptoms might occur in certain vulnerable individuals during treatment with atypical antipsychotics such as quetiapine, clozapine, or amisulpride.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Comparison of developmental toxicology of aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) in rats using selected dosing paradigms.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Analysis of the literature for nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) suggests that a low incidence of developmental anomalies occurs in rats given NSAIDs on specific days during organogenesis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>[ASA]), an irreversible cyclooxygenase 1 and 2 inhibitor, induces developmental anomalies when administered to Wistar rats on gestational day (GD) 9, 10, or 11 (Kimmel CA, Wilson JG, Schumacher HJ.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Teratology 4:15-24, 1971).</Chemical>
<Chemical>There are no published ASA studies using the multiple dosing paradigm of GDs 6 to 17.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Objectives of the current study were to compare results between Sprague-Dawley (SD) and Wistar strains when ASA is administered on GD 9, 10, or 11; to compare the malformation patterns following single and multiple dosings during organogenesis in SD rats; and to test the hypothesis that maternal gastrointestinal toxicity confounds the detection of low incidence malformations with ASA when a multiple dosing paradigm is used.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>ASA was administered as a single dose on GD 9 (0, 250, 500, or 625 mg/kg), 10 (0, 500, 625, or 750 mg/kg), or 11 (0, 500, 750, or 1000 mg/kg) and from GD 6 to GD 17 (0, 50, 125, or 250 mg/kg a day) in the multiple dose study to SD rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Animals were killed on GD 21, and fetuses were examined viscerally.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The literature evaluation suggested that NSAIDs induce ventricular septal defects (VSDs) and midline defects (MDs) in rats and diaphragmatic hernia (DH), MDs, and VSDs in rabbits (Cook JC et al., 2003); hence, the present study focused on these malformations, even though ASA induces several other low-incidence malformations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In single dose studies, DH, MD, and VSD were induced on GDs 9 and 10.</Chemical>
<Chemical>VSD also was noted following treatment on GD 11.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In contrast, DH and MD were noted in the multiple dose study design only in the high-dose group, and VSD was noted across all dose groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>CONCLUSIONS: High concordance in major developmental anomalies between Wistar and SD rats were noted with the exception of VSD in the SD rats and hydrocephalus in the Wistar rats.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Variations and malformations were similar when ASA was administered as a single dose or during the period of organogenesis (GDs 6 to 17).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>It was also evident that, by titrating the dose to achieve a maximum tolerated dose, malformations that normally occur at low incidence, as reported from previous single dose studies, could also be induced with ASA given at multiple doses.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report on a 92-year-old woman with preexisting complete left bundle branch block who developed torsade de pointes after intravenous and oral administration of metoclopramide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

<Chemical>This is the first documentation that metoclopramide provokes torsade de pointes clinically.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Metoclopramide should be used cautiously in patients with a risk of torsade de pointes.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Apomorphine: an underutilized therapy for Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Apomorphine was the first dopaminergic drug ever used to treat symptoms of Parkinson's disease.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>While powerful antiparkinsonian effects had been observed as early as 1951, the potential of treating fluctuating Parkinson's disease by subcutaneous administration of apomorphine has only recently become the subject of systematic study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A number of small scale clinical trials have unequivocally shown that intermittent subcutaneous apomorphine injections produce antiparkinsonian benefit close if not identical to that seen with levodopa and that apomorphine rescue injections can reliably revert off-periods even in patients with complex on-off motor swings.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Continuous subcutaneous apomorphine infusions can reduce daily off-time by more than 50% in this group of patients, which appears to be a stronger effect than that generally seen with add-on therapy with oral dopamine agonists or COMT inhibitors.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Extended follow-up studies of up to 8 years have demonstrated long-term persistence of apomorphine efficacy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, there is convincing clinical evidence that monotherapy with continuous subcutaneous apomorphine infusions is associated with marked reductions of preexisting levodopa-induced dyskinesias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The main side effects of subcutaneous apomorphine treatment are related to cutaneous tolerability problems, whereas sedation and psychiatric complications play a lesser role.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Given the marked degree of efficacy of subcutaneous apomorphine treatment in fluctuating Parkinson's disease, this approach seems to deserve more widespread clinical use.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>We describe an outbreak of deaths from cocaine-induced excited delirium (EDDs) in Dade County, Florida between 1979 and 1990.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>From a registry of all cocaine-related deaths in Dade County, Florida, from 1969-1990, 58 EDDs were compared with 125 victims of accidental cocaine overdose without excited delirium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with controls, EDDs were more frequently black, male, and younger.</Chemical>

<Chemical>They were less likely to have a low body mass index, and more likely to have died in police custody, to have received medical treatment immediately before death, to have survived for a longer period, to have developed hyperthermia, and to have died in summer months.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The epidemiologic findings are most consistent with the hypothesis that chronic cocaine use disrupts dopaminergic function and, when coupled with recent cocaine use, may precipitate agitation, delirium, aberrant thermoregulation, rhabdomyolysis, and sudden death.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Nerve growth factor and prostaglandins in the urine of female patients with overactive bladder.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PURPOSE:</Chemical>

label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We investigated changes in urinary NGF and PGs in women with OAB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>MATERIALS AND METHODS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The study groups included 65 women with OAB and 20 without bladder symptoms who served as controls.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Evaluation included patient history, urinalysis, a voiding diary and urodynamic studies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urine samples were collected.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, correlations between urinary NGF and PG, and urodynamic parameters in patients with OAB were examined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Urinary NGF, PGE2 and PGF2alpha were significantly increased in patients with OAB compared with controls (p <0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, urinary PGI2 was not different between controls and patients with OAB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In patients with OAB urinary PGE2 positively correlated with volume at first desire to void and maximum cystometric capacity (p <0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urinary NGF, PGF2alpha and PGI2 did not correlate with urodynamic parameters in patients with OAB.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>NGF and PGs have important roles in the development of OAB symptoms in female patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Urinary levels of these factors may be used as markers to evaluate OAB symptoms.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Postoperative myalgia after succinylcholine: no evidence for an inflammatory origin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A common side effect associated with succinylcholine is postoperative myalgia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The pathogenesis of this myalgia is still unclear; inflammation has been suggested but without convincing evidence.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We designed the present study to investigate whether an inflammatory reaction contributes to this myalgia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The incidence and severity of succinylcholine-associated myalgia was determined in 64 patients pretreated with saline or dexamethasone before succinylcholine (n = 32 for each).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Incidence and severity of myalgia did not differ significantly between the two groups: 15 patients in the dexamethasone group complained of myalgia compared with 18 patients in the saline group, and severe myalgia was reported by five patients and three patients, respectively (not significant).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>At 48 h after surgery, 12 patients in both groups still suffered from myalgia (not significant).</Chemical>
<Chemical>In addition, interleukin-6 (IL-6) as an early marker of inflammation was assessed in a subgroup of 10 patients pretreated with saline.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We found an increase of IL-6 for only three patients, but only one patient reported myalgia; no relationship between myalgia and the increase of IL-6 was found.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In conclusion, there is no evidence for an inflammatory origin of succinylcholine-associated myalgia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>IMPLICATIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Administration of dexamethasone before succinylcholine was not effective in decreasing the incidence or the severity of succinylcholine-induced postoperative myalgia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Furthermore, there was no significant relationship between postoperative myalgia and time course of interleukin-6 concentrations, a marker of inflammation.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pretreatment with dexamethasone is not justified to prevent postoperative myalgia after succinylcholine.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Ketamine in war/tropical surgery (a final tribute to the racemic mixture).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>A technique of continuous intravenous anaesthesia with ketamine was used successfully during the Somalia civil war in 1994 and in north Uganda in 1999 for 64 operations in 62 patients, aged from 6 weeks to 70 years, undergoing limb and abdominal surgery including caesarian sections and interventions in neonates.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Emphasis was placed on bedside clinical monitoring, relying heavily on the heart rate.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Local anaesthetic blocks were useful in decreasing the requirement for postoperative analgesia.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Steroid structure and pharmacological properties determine the anti-amnesic effects of pregnenolone sulphate in the passive avoidance task in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pregnenolone sulphate (PREGS) has generated interest as one of the most potent memory-enhancing neurosteroids to be examined in rodent learning studies, with particular importance in the ageing process.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism by which this endogenous steroid enhances memory formation is hypothesized to involve actions on glutamatergic and GABAergic systems.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This hypothesis stems from findings that PREGS is a potent positive modulator of N-methyl-d-aspartate receptors (NMDARs) and a negative modulator of gamma-aminobutyric acid(A) receptors (GABA(A)Rs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, PREGS is able to reverse the amnesic-like effects of NMDAR and GABA(A)R ligands.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To investigate this hypothesis, the present study in rats examined the memory-altering abilities of structural analogs of PREGS, which differ in their modulation of NMDAR and/or GABA(A)R function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The analogs tested were: 11-ketopregnenolone sulphate (an agent that is inactive at GABA(A)Rs and NMDARs), epipregnanolone ([3beta-hydroxy-5beta-pregnan-20-one] sulphate, an inhibitor of both GABA(A)Rs and NMDARs), and a newly synthesized (-) PREGS enantiomer (which is identical to PREGS in effects on GABA(A)Rs and NMDARs).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The memory-enhancing effects of PREGS and its analogs were tested in the passive avoidance task using the model of scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Both PREGS and its (-) enantiomer blocked the effects of scopolamine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The results show that, unlike PREGS, 11-ketopregnenolone sulphate and epipregnanolone sulphate failed to block the effect of scopolamine, suggesting that altering the modulation of NMDA receptors diminishes the memory-enhancing effects of PREGS.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Moreover, enantioselectivity was demonstrated by the ability of natural PREGS to be an order of magnitude more effective than its synthetic enantiomer in reversing scopolamine-induced amnesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>These results identify a novel neuropharmacological site for the modulation of memory processes by neuroactive steroids.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Preliminary efficacy assessment of intrathecal injection of an American formulation of adenosine in humans.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Preclinical studies of intrathecal adenosine suggest it may be effective in the treatment of acute and chronic pain in humans, and preliminary studies in volunteers and patients with a Swedish formulation of adenosine suggests it may be effective in hypersensitivity states but not with acute noxious stimulation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The purpose of this study was to screen for efficacy of a different formulation of adenosine marketed in the US, using both acute noxious stimulation and capsaicin-evoked mechanical hypersensitivity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHODS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Following Food and Drug Administration and institutional review board approval and written informed consent, 65 volunteers were studied in two trials: an open-label, dose-escalating trial with intrathecal adenosine doses of 0.25-2.0 mg and a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of adenosine, 2 mg.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cerebrospinal fluid was obtained for pharmacokinetic analysis, and pain ratings in response to acute heat stimuli and areas of mechanical hyperalgesia and allodynia after intradermal capsaicin injection were determined.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Adenosine produced no effect on pain report to acute noxious thermal or chemical stimulation but reduced mechanical hyperalgesia and allodynia from intradermal capsaicin injection for at least 24 h. In contrast, residence time of adenosine in cerebrospinal fluid was short (< 4 h).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>These results show selective inhibition by intrathecal adenosine of hypersensitivity, presumed to reflect central sensitization in humans after peripheral capsaicin injection.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The long-lasting effect is consistent with that observed in preliminary reports of patients with chronic neuropathic pain and is not due to prolonged residence of adenosine in cerebrospinal fluid.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Effect of lithium maintenance therapy on thyroid and parathyroid function.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To assess changes induced by lithium maintenance therapy on the incidence of thyroid, parathyroid and ion alterations.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These were evaluated with respect to the duration of lithium therapy, age, sex, and family history (whether or not the patient had a first-degree relative with thyroid disease).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN: Prospective study.</Chemical>
<Chemical>SETTING:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Affective Disorders Clinic at St. Mary's Hospital, Montreal.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS: One hundred and one patients (28 men and 73 women) with bipolar disorder receiving lithium maintenance therapy ranging from 1 year's to 32 years' duration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The control group consisted of 82 patients with no psychiatric or endocrinological diagnoses from the hospital's out-patient clinics.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OUTCOME MEASURES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Laboratory analyses of calcium, magnesium and thyroid-stimulating hormone levels performed before beginning lithium therapy and at biannual follow-up.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hypothyroidism developed in 40 patients, excluding 8 patients who were hypothyroid at baseline.</Chemical>

<Chemical>All patients having first-degree relatives affected by thyroid illness had accelerated onset of hypothyroidism (3.7 years after onset of lithium therapy) compared with patients without a family history (8.6 years after onset of lithium therapy).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Women over 60 years of age were more often affected by hypothyroidism than women under 60 years of age (34.6% versus 31.9%).</Chemical>
<Chemical>Magnesium levels in patients on lithium treatment were unchanged from baseline levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After lithium treatment, calcium levels were higher than either baseline levels or control levels.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, lithium treatment counteracted the decrease in plasma calcium levels associated with aging.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Familial thyroid illness is a risk factor for hypothyroidism and hypercalcemia during lithium therapy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Systemic toxicity following administration of sirolimus (formerly rapamycin) for psoriasis: association of capillary leak syndrome with apoptosis of lesional lymphocytes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>BACKGROUND: Sirolimus (formerly rapamycin) is an immunosuppressive agent that interferes with T-cell activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>After 2 individuals with psoriasis developed a capillary leak syndrome following treatment with oral sirolimus lesional skin cells and activated peripheral blood cells were analyzed for induction of apoptosis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBSERVATIONS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A keratome skin specimen from 1 patient with sirolimus-induced capillary leak syndrome had a 2.3-fold increase in percentage of apoptotic cells (to 48%) compared with an unaffected sirolimus-treated patient with psoriasis (21%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Activated peripheral blood T cells from patients with psoriasis tended to exhibit greater spontaneous or dexamethasone-induced apoptosis than did normal T cells, particularly in the presence of sirolimus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Severe adverse effects of sirolimus include fever, anemia, and capillary leak syndrome.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>These symptoms may be the result of drug-induced apoptosis of lesional leukocytes, especially activated T lymphocytes, and possibly release of inflammatory mediators.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Because patients with severe psoriasis may develop capillary leak from various systemic therapies, clinical monitoring is advisable for patients with inflammatory diseases who are treated with immune modulators.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Contribution of the glycine site of NMDA receptors in rostral and intermediate-caudal parts of the striatum to the regulation of muscle tone in rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of the present study was to assess the contribution of the glycine site of NMDA receptors in the striatum to the regulation of muscle tone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Muscle tone was examined using a combined mechanoand electromyographic method, which measured simultaneously the muscle resistance (MMG) of the rat's hind foot to passive extension and flexion in the ankle joint and the electromyographic activity (EMG) of the antagonistic muscles of that joint: gastrocnemius and tibialis anterior.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Muscle rigidity was induced by haloperidol (2.5 mg/kg i.p.).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>5,7-dichlorokynurenic acid (5,7-DCKA), a selective glycine site antagonist, injected in doses of 2.5 and 4.5 microg/0.5 microl bilaterally, into the rostral region of the striatum, decreased both the haloperidol-induced muscle rigidity (MMG) and the enhanced electromyographic activity (EMG).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>5,7-DCKA injected bilaterally in a dose of 4.5 microg/0.5 microl into the intermediate-caudal region of the striatum of rats not pretreated with haloperidol had no effect on the muscle tone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present results suggest that blockade of the glycine site of NMDA receptors in the rostral part of the striatum may be mainly responsible for the antiparkinsonian action of this drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Efficacy and tolerability of lovastatin in 3390 women with moderate hypercholesterolemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of lovastatin in women with moderate hypercholesterolemia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>
<Chemical>The Expanded Clinical Evaluation of Lovastatin (EXCEL)</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Study, a multicenter, double-blind, diet- and placebo-controlled trial, in which participants were randomly assigned to receive placebo or lovastatin at doses of 20 or 40 mg once daily, or 20 or 40 mg twice daily for 48 weeks.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>SETTING:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Ambulatory patients recruited by 362 participating centers throughout the United States.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PATIENTS: Women (n = 3390) from the total cohort of 8245 volunteers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>MEASUREMENTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Plasma total, low-density lipoprotein (LDL), and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides; and laboratory and clinical evidence of adverse events monitored periodically throughout the study.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Among women, lovastatin (20 to 80 mg/d) produced sustained (12- to 48-week), dose-related changes (P < 0.001): decreases in LDL cholesterol (24% to 40%) and triglycerides (9% to 18%), and increases in HDL cholesterol (6.7% to 8.6%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Depending on the dose, from 82% to 95% of lovastatin-treated women achieved the National Cholesterol Education Program goal of LDL cholesterol levels less than 4.14 mmol/L (160 mg/dL), and 40% to 87% achieved the goal of 3.36 mmol/L (130 mg/dL).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Successive transaminase elevations greater than three times the upper limit of normal occurred in 0.1% of women and were dose dependent above the 20-mg dose.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Myopathy, defined as muscle symptoms with creatine kinase elevations greater than 10 times the upper limit of normal, was rare and associated with the highest recommended daily dose of lovastatin (80 mg).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Estrogen-replacement therapy appeared to have no effect on either the efficacy or safety profile of lovastatin.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Lovastatin is highly effective and generally well tolerated as therapy for primary hypercholesterolemia in women.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment of ifosfamide-induced urothelial toxicity by oral administration of sodium 2-mercaptoethane sulphonate (MESNA) to patients with inoperable lung cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The protective effect of oral administration of the thiol compound sodium 2-mercaptoethane sulphonate (MESNA) against urothelial toxicity induced by ifosfamide (IF) was tested in a group of 45 patients with inoperable lung cancer under treatment with IF (2250 mg/m2 on days 2-5) as part of a polychemotherapy regimen repeated in a 4-week cycle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>MESNA was given orally on the days of treatment with IF in 3 doses of 840 mg/m2, each administered at 0 hr (= injection of IF), 4 hr and 8 hr p.i.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Out of a total of 88 courses of this treatment we observed 10 episodes of asymptomatic microscopic haematuria and no episodes of gross haematuria.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In this group of 45 patients under protection with MESNA there were 5 complete remissions and 9 partial remissions (total 31%).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>A further group of 25 patients under polychemotherapy with IF were treated by conventional prophylactic measures (raised fluid intake and forced diuresis).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In this group there were 1 complete and 5 partial remissions (total 24%), but nearly all patients developed either gross haematuria and/or symptoms of bladder irritation (cystitis and pollakisuria).</Chemical>

<Chemical>There were no appreciable differences between the MESNA series and the conventional prophylaxis series with respect to either haematological or systemic toxicity of the cytostatic treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Our results support the view that MESNA, given orally in conjunction with combined cytostatic regimens which include IF, simplifies the treatment and provides optimum protection for the urinary epithelium.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Protection with oral MESNA is particularly suitable for outpatients.</Chemical>

label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The movement disorder investigated in these studies has some features in common with human idiopathic dystonia, and information obtained in these studies may be of potential clinical benefit.</Chemical>

<Chemical>The present experimental results indicated that peptidergic stimulation of the LC resulted in a NE-mediated inhibition of cerebellar Purkinje cells located at terminals of the ceruleo-cerebellar pathway.</Chemical>

<Chemical>However, it is not certain as to the following: (a) what receptors were stimulated by the ACTH N-terminal fragments at the LC that resulted in this disorder; (b) whether NE, released onto Purkinje cell synapses located at terminals of the ceruleo-cerebellar pathway, did indeed cause the long-term depression at Purkinje cell synapses (previously described by others) that resulted in the long duration of the movement disorder; (c) whether the inhibition of inhibitory Purkinje cells resulted in disinhibition or increased excitability of the unilateral cerebellar fastigial or interpositus nuclei, the output targets of the Purkinje cell axons, that may have been an important contributing factor to this disorder.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Animals (n = 42) were treated intraperitoneally with one of the following six regimens: 1) L-MED (the inactive L-isomer of medetomidine), 30 micrograms/kg; 2) D-MED, 10 micrograms/kg; 3) D-MED, 30 micrograms/kg; 4) D-MED</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>[10 mg/kg], or; 6) saline.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Delayed institution of hypertension during focal cerebral ischemia: effect on brain edema.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The effect of induced hypertension instituted after a 2-h delay following middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) on brain edema formation and histochemical injury was studied.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Under isoflurane anesthesia, the MCA of 14 spontaneously hypertensive rats was occluded.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the control group (n = 7), the mean arterial pressure (MAP) was not manipulated.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In the hypertensive group (n = 7), the MAP was elevated by 25-30 mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg beginning 2 h after MCAO.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Four hours after MCAO, the rats were killed and the brains harvested.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The brains were sectioned along coronal planes spanning the distribution of ischemia produced by MCAO.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Specific gravity (SG) was determined in the subcortex and in two sites in the cortex (core and periphery of the ischemic territory).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The extent of neuronal injury was determined by 2,3,5-triphenyltetrazolium staining.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the ischemic core, there was no difference in SG in the subcortex and cortex in the two groups.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In the periphery of the ischemic territory, SG in the cortex was greater (less edema accumulation) in the hypertensive group (1.041 +/- 0.001 vs 1.039 +/- 0.001, P less than 0.05).</Chemical>
<Chemical>The area of histochemical injury (as a percent of the cross-sectional area of the hemisphere) was less in the hypertensive group (33 +/- 3% vs 21 +/- 2%, P less than 0.05).</Chemical>

<Chemical>The data indicate that phenylephrine-induced hypertension instituted 2 h after MCAO does not aggravate edema in the ischemic core, that it improves edema in the periphery of the ischemic territory, and that it reduces the area of histochemical neuronal dysfunction.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>To investigate the initial potassium loss and development of hypokalaemia during the administration of an oral diuretic, metabolic balance studies were performed in ten patients with essential hypertension who had shown hypokalaemia under prior oral diuretic treatment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The electrolyte balances, weight, bromide space, plasma renin activity, and aldosterone secretion rate were measured.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In both groups a potassium deficit developed, with proportionally larger losses from the extracellular than from the intracellular compartment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the normal-sodium group the highest mean potassium deficit was 176 mmol on day 9, after which some potassium was regained; in the low-sodium group the highest deficit was 276 mmol on day 13.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

label: Chemical

Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>It is concluded that dietary sodium restriction increases diuretic-induced potassium loss, presumably by an increased activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, while sodium delivery to the distal renal tubules remains sufficiently high to allow increased potassium secretion.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>The pressure dynamic responses of isolated blood vessels show a faster pressure change in gentamicin-treated animals (8.07 +/- 1.7 s vs. 5.64 +/- 0.18 s).</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Vitamin C administration induced slowdown of pressure change back to the control values.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The pressure dynamic properties, quantitatively defined by comparative pressure dynamic and total pressure dynamic, confirm the alteration in dynamic response of blood vessels during the change of pressure in gentamicin-treated animals and beneficial effects of vitamin C administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The hemodynamics of oxytocin and other vasoactive agents during neuraxial anesthesia for cesarean delivery: findings in six cases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Oxytocin is a commonly used uterotonic that can cause significant and even fatal hypotension, particularly when given as a bolus.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The resulting hypotension can be produced by a decrease in systemic vascular resistance or cardiac output through a decrease in venous return.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Parturients with normal volume status, heart valves and pulmonary vasculature most often respond to this hypotension with a compensatory increase in heart rate and stroke volume.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Oxytocin-induced hypotension at cesarean delivery may be incorrectly attributed to blood loss.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pulse power analysis (also called "pulse contour analysis") of an arterial pressure wave form allows continuous evaluation of systemic vascular resistance and cardiac output in real time, thereby elucidating the causative factors behind changes in blood pressure.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pulse power analysis was conducted in six cases of cesarean delivery performed under neuraxial anesthesia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hypotension in response to oxytocin was associated with a decrease in systemic vascular resistance and a compensatory increase in stroke volume, heart rate and cardiac output.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Pulse power analysis may be helpful in determining the etiology of and treating hypotension during cesarean delivery under neuraxial anesthesia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Exaggerated expression of inflammatory mediators in vasoactive intestinal polypeptide knockout (VIP-/-) mice with cyclophosphamide (CYP)-induced cystitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) is an immunomodulatory neuropeptide distributed in micturition pathways.</Chemical>
<Chemical>VIP(-/-) mice exhibit altered bladder function and neurochemical properties in micturition pathways after cyclophosphamide (CYP)-induced cystitis.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Given VIP's role as an anti-inflammatory mediator, we hypothesized that VIP(-/-) mice would exhibit enhanced inflammatory mediator expression after cystitis.</Chemical>

<Chemical>A mouse inflammatory cytokine and receptor RT2 profiler array was used to determine regulated transcripts in the urinary bladder of wild type (WT) and VIP(-/-) mice with or without CYP-induced cystitis (150 mg/kg; i.p.; 48 h).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Four binary comparisons were made: WT control versus CYP treatment (48 h), VIP(-/-) control versus CYP treatment (48 h), WT control versus VIP(-/-) control, and WT with CYP treatment (48 h) versus VIP(-/-) with CYP treatment (48 h).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The genes presented represent (1) greater than 1.5-fold change in either direction and (2) the p value is less than 0.05 for the comparison being made.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Several regulated genes were validated using enzyme-linked immunoassays including IL-1beta and CXCL1.</Chemical>

<Chemical>CYP treatment significantly (p < or = 0.001) increased expression of CXCL1 and IL-1beta in the urinary bladder of WT and VIP(-/-) mice, but expression in VIP(-/-) mice with CYP treatment was significantly (p < or = 0.001) greater (4.2- to 13-fold increase) than that observed in WT urinary bladder (3.6- to 5-fold increase).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The data suggest that in VIP(-/-) mice with bladder inflammation, inflammatory mediators are increased above that observed in WT with CYP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This shift in balance may contribute to increased bladder dysfunction in VIP(-/-) mice with bladder inflammation and altered neurochemical expression in micturition pathways.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Intraocular pressure in patients with uveitis treated with fluocinolone acetonide implants.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE: To report the incidence and management of elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) in patients with uveitis treated with the fluocinolone acetonide (FA) intravitreal implant.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN:</Chemical>

<Chemical>Pooled data from 3 multicenter, double-masked, randomized, controlled, phase 2b/3 clinical trials evaluating the safety and efficacy of the 0.59-mg or 2.1-mg FA intravitreal implant or standard therapy were analyzed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>

<Chemical>During the 3-year follow-up, 71.0% of implanted eyes had an IOP increase of 10 mm Hg or more than baseline and 55.1%, 24.7%, and 6.2% of eyes reached an IOP of 30 mm Hg or more, 40 mm Hg or more, and 50 mm Hg or more, respectively.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Topical IOP-lowering medication was administered in 74.8% of implanted eyes, and IOP-lowering surgeries, most of which were trabeculectomies (76.2%), were performed on 36.6% of implanted eyes.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Intraocular pressure-lowering surgeries were considered a success (postoperative IOP of 6-21 mm</Chemical>
<Chemical>Hg with or without additional IOP-lowering medication) in 85.1% of eyes at 1 year.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The rate of hypotony (IOP </= 5 mm Hg) following IOP-lowering surgery (42.5%) was not different from that of implanted eyes not subjected to surgery (35.4%) (P = .09).</Chemical>
<Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Elevated IOP is a significant complication with the FA intravitreal implant but may be controlled with medication and surgery.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pallidal stimulation: an alternative to pallidotomy?</Chemical>
<Chemical>A resurgence of interest in the surgical treatment of Parkinson's disease (PD) came with the rediscovery of posteroventral pallidotomy by Laitinen in 1985.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Laitinen's procedure improved most symptoms in drug-resistant PD, which engendered wide interest in the neurosurgical community.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Another lesioning procedure, ventrolateral thalamotomy, has become a powerful alternative to stimulate the nucleus ventralis intermedius, producing high long-term success rates and low morbidity rates.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pallidal stimulation has not met with the same success.</Chemical>

<Chemical>According to the literature pallidotomy improves the "on" symptoms of PD, such as dyskinesias, as well as the "off" symptoms, such as rigidity, bradykinesia, and on-off fluctuations.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pallidal stimulation improves bradykinesia and rigidity to a minor extent; however, its strength seems to be in improving levodopa-induced dyskinesias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Stimulation often produces an improvement in the hyper- or dyskinetic upper limbs, but increases the "freezing" phenomenon in the lower limbs at the same time.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Considering the small increase in the patient's independence, the high costs of bilateral implants, and the difficulty most patients experience in handling the devices, the question arises as to whether bilateral pallidal stimulation is a real alternative to pallidotomy.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Case report: Dexatrim (Phenylpropanolamine) as a cause of myocardial infarction.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phenylpropanolamine (PPA) is a sympathetic amine used in over-the-counter cold remedies and weight-control preparations worldwide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Its use has been associated with hypertensive episodes and hemorrhagic strokes in younger women.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Several reports have linked the abuse of PPA with myocardial injury, especially when overdose is involved.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report here the first case of Dexatrim (PPA)-induced myocardial injury in a young woman who was using it at recommended doses for weight control.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition, we review the 7 other cases of PPA related myocardial injury that have been reported so far.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Physicians and patients should be alert to the potential cardiac risk associated with the use of PPA, even at doses generally considered to be safe.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Risperidone-associated, benign transient visual disturbances in schizophrenic patients with a past history of LSD abuse.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Two schizophrenic patients, who had a prior history of LSD abuse and who had previously developed EPS with classic antipsychotics, were successfully treated with risperidone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>They both reported short episodes of transient visual disturbances, which appeared immediately after starting treatment with risperidone.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>This imagery resembled visual disturbances previously experienced as "flashbacks" related to prior LSD consumption.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Risperidone administration was continued and the visual disturbances gradually wore off.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>During a six-month follow-up period, there was no recurrence of visual disturbances.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This phenomenon may be interpreted as a benign, short-term and self-limiting side effect which does not contraindicate the use of risperidone or interfere with treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Conclusions based on two case reports should be taken with appropriate caution.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Activation of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase contributes to development of doxorubicin-induced heart failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Activation of the nuclear enzyme poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) by oxidant-mediated DNA damage is an important pathway of cell dysfunction and tissue injury in conditions associated with oxidative stress.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Increased oxidative stress is a major factor implicated in the cardiotoxicity of doxorubicin (DOX), a widely used antitumor anthracycline antibiotic.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, we hypothesized that the activation of PARP may contribute to the DOX-induced cardiotoxicity.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Using a dual approach of PARP-1 suppression, by genetic deletion or pharmacological inhibition with the phenanthridinone PARP inhibitor PJ34, we now demonstrate the role of PARP in the development of cardiac dysfunction induced by DOX.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>PARP-1+/+ and PARP-1-/- mice received a single injection of DOX (25 mg/kg i.p).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five days after DOX administration, left ventricular performance was significantly depressed in PARP-1+/+ mice, but only to a smaller extent in PARP-1-/- ones.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Similar experiments were conducted in BALB/c mice treated with PJ34 or vehicle.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Treatment with a PJ34 significantly improved cardiac dysfunction and increased the survival of the animals.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In addition PJ34 significantly reduced the DOX-induced increase in the serum lactate dehydrogenase and creatine kinase activities but not metalloproteinase activation in the heart.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, PARP activation contributes to the cardiotoxicity of DOX.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>PARP inhibitors may exert protective effects against the development of severe cardiac complications associated with the DOX treatment.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fluconazole-induced torsade de pointes.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>
<Chemical>To present a case of fluconazole-associated torsade de pointes (TDP) and discuss fluconazole's role in causing TDP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>CASE SUMMARY:</Chemical>

<Chemical>A 68-year-old white woman with Candida glabrata isolated from a presacral abscess developed TDP eight days after commencing oral fluconazole The patient had no other risk factors for TDP, including coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, congestive heart failure, and electrolyte abnormalities There was a temporal association between the initiation of fluconazole and TDP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The TDP resolved when fluconazole was discontinued; however, the patient continued to have premature ventricular contractions and nonsustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) until six days after drug cessation DISCUSSION:</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Use of the Naranjo probability scale indicates a probable relationship between the use of fluconazole and the development of TDP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The possible mechanism is depression of rapidly activating delayed rectifier potassium currents.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In our patient, there was no other etiology identified that could explain QT prolongation or TDP The complete disappearance of NSVT and premature ventricular contractions followed by normalization of QT interval after the drug was stopped strongly suggests fluconazole as the etiology.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSIONS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Clinicians should be aware that fluconazole, even at low doses, may cause prolongation of the QT interval, leading to TDP.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serial electrocardiographic monitoring may be considered when fluconazole is administered in patients who are at risk for ventricular arrhythmias.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>High-dose methylprednisolone may do more harm for spinal cord injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Because of the National Acute Spinal Cord Injury Studies (NASCIS), high-dose methylprednisolone became the standard of care for the acute spinal cord injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the NASCIS, there was no mention regarding the possibility of acute corticosteroid myopathy that high-dose methylprednisolone may cause.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The dosage of methylprednisolone recommended by the NASCIS 3 is the highest dose of steroids ever being used during a 2-day period for any clinical condition.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>We hypothesize that it may cause some damage to the muscle of spinal cord injury patients.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Further, steroid myopathy recovers naturally and the neurological improvement shown in the NASCIS may be just a recording of this natural motor recovery from the steroid myopathy, instead of any protection that methylprednisolone offers to the spinal cord injury.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>To our knowledge, this is the first discussion considering the possibility that the methylprednisolone recommended by NASCIS may cause acute corticosteroid myopathy.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Probing peripheral and central cholinergic system responses.</Chemical>
<Chemical>OBJECTIVE:</Chemical>

<Chemical>The pharmacological response to drugs that act on the cholinergic system of the iris has been used to predict deficits in central cholinergic functioning due to diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, yet correlations between central and peripheral responses have not been properly studied.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This study assessed the effect of normal aging on (1) the tropicamide-induced increase in pupil diameter, and (2) the reversal of this effect with pilocarpine.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Scopolamine was used as a positive control to detect age-dependent changes in central cholinergic functioning in the elderly.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>DESIGN: Randomized double-blind controlled trial.</Chemical>
<Chemical>PARTICIPANTS: Ten healthy elderly (mean age 70) and 9 young (mean age 33) volunteers.</Chemical>
<Chemical>INTERVENTIONS: Pupil diameter was monitored using a computerized infrared pupillometer over 4 hours.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The study involved 4 sessions.</Chemical>
<Chemical>In 1 session, tropicamide (20 microL, 0.01%) was administered to one eye and placebo to the other.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>In another session, tropicamide (20 microL, 0.01%) was administered to both eyes, followed 23 minutes later by the application of pilocarpine (20 microL, 0.1%) to one eye and placebo to the other.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>All eye drops were given in a randomized order.</Chemical>

<Chemical>In 2 separate sessions, a single dose of scopolamine (0.5 mg, intravenously) or placebo was administered, and the effects on word recall were measured using the Buschke Selective Reminding Test over 2 hours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>OUTCOME MEASURES:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Pupil size at time points after administration of tropicamide and pilocarpine; scopolamine-induced impairment in word recall.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>There was no significant difference between elderly and young volunteers in pupillary response to tropicamide at any time point (p > 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The elderly group had a significantly greater pilocarpine-induced net decrease in pupil size 85, 125, 165 and 215 minutes after administration, compared with the young group (p < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Compared with the young group, the elderly group had greater scopolamine-induced impairment in word recall 60, 90 and 120 minutes after administration (p < 0.05).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>There is an age-related pupillary response to pilocarpine that is not found with tropicamide.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Thus, pilocarpine may be useful to assess variations in central cholinergic function in elderly patients.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report a case of acetazolamide-induced Gerstmann syndrome in a patient with normal renal function, to highlight predisposing factors that are frequently overlooked.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Neutrophil superoxide and hydrogen peroxide production in patients with acute liver failure.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Defects in superoxide and hydrogen peroxide production may be implicated in the high incidence of bacterial infections in patients with acute liver failure (ALF).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In the present study, oxygen radical production in patients with ALF due to paracetamol overdose was compared with that of healthy volunteers.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Neutrophils from 14 ALF patients were stimulated via the complement receptors using zymosan opsonized with ALF or control serum.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Superoxide and hydrogen peroxide production by ALF neutrophils stimulated with zymosan opsonized with ALF serum was significantly reduced compared with the control subjects (P < 0.01).</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This defect persisted when zymosan opsonized by control serum was used (P < 0.05).</Chemical>

<Chemical>Superoxide and hydrogen peroxide production in neutrophils stimulated with formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine (fMLP) from a further 18 ALF patients was unaffected compared with control neutrophils.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Serum C3 complement levels were significantly reduced in ALF patients compared with control subjects (P < 0.0005).</Chemical>

<Chemical>These results demonstrate a neutrophil defect in ALF due to paracetamol overdose, that is complement dependent but independent of serum complement, possibly connected to the complement receptor.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Absence of effect of sertraline on time-based sensitization of cognitive impairment with haloperidol.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study evaluated the effects of haloperidol alone and haloperidol plus sertraline on cognitive and psychomotor function in 24 healthy male subjects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>METHOD:</Chemical>
<Chemical>All subjects received placebo on Day 1 and haloperidol 2 mg on Days 2 and 25.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>From Days 9 to 25, subjects were randomly assigned to either sertraline (12 subjects) or placebo (12 subjects); the sertraline dose was titrated from 50 to 200 mg/day from Days 9 to 16, and remained at 200 mg/day for the final 10 days of the drug administration period.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Cognitive function testing was performed before dosing and over a 24-hour period after dosing on Days 1, 2, and 25.</Chemical>
<Chemical>RESULTS:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Impairment of cognitive function was observed 6 to 8 hours after administration of haloperidol on Day 2 but was not evident 23 hours after dosing.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>When single-dose haloperidol was given again 25 days later, greater impairment with earlier onset was noted in several tests in both treatment groups, suggesting enhancement of this effect.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was no indication that sertraline exacerbated the impairment produced by haloperidol since an equivalent effect also occurred in the placebo group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Three subjects (2 on sertraline and 1 on placebo) withdrew from the study because of side effects.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ten subjects in each group reported side effects related to treatment.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The side effect profiles of sertraline and of placebo were similar.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>CONCLUSION:</Chemical>
<Chemical>Haloperidol produced a clear profile of cognitive impairment that was not worsened by concomitant sertraline administration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Ciprofloxacin-induced nephrotoxicity in patients with cancer.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Nephrotoxicity associated with ciprofloxacin is uncommon.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Five patients with cancer who developed acute renal failure that followed treatment with ciprofloxacin are described and an additional 15 cases reported in the literature are reviewed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Other than elevation of serum creatinine levels, characteristic clinical manifestations and abnormal laboratory findings are not frequently present.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Allergic interstitial nephritis is believed to be the underlying pathological-process.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Definitive diagnosis requires performance of renal biopsy, although this is not always feasible.</Chemical>
<Chemical>An improvement in renal function that followed the discontinuation of the offending antibiotic supports the presumptive diagnosis of ciprofloxacin-induced acute renal failure.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Time dependence of plasma malondialdehyde, oxypurines, and nucleosides during incomplete cerebral ischemia in the rat.</Chemical>

Chemical

text: <Chemical>Incomplete cerebral ischemia (30 min) was induced in the rat by bilaterally clamping the common carotid arteries.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Peripheral venous blood samples were withdrawn from the femoral vein four times (once every 5 min) before ischemia (0 time) and 5, 15, and 30 min after ischemia.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Plasma extracts were analyzed by a highly sensitive high-performance liquid chromatographic method for the direct determination of malondialdehyde, oxypurines, and nucleosides.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

Chemical

text: <Chemical>During ischemia, a time-dependent increase of plasma oxypurines and nucleosides was observed.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Plasma malondialdehyde, which was present in minimal amount at zero time (0.058 mumol/liter plasma; SD 0.015), increased after 5 min of ischemia, resulting in a fivefold increase after 30 min of carotid occlusion (0.298 mumol/liter plasma; SD 0.078).</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Increased plasma malondialdehyde was also recorded in two other groups of animals subjected to the same experimental model, one receiving 20 mg/kg b.w. of the cyclooxygenase inhibitor acetylsalicylate intravenously immediately before ischemia, the other receiving 650 micrograms/kg b.w. of the hypotensive drug nitroprusside at a flow rate of 103 microliters/min intravenously during ischemia, although in this latter group malondialdehyde was significantly higher.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present data indicate that the determination of malondialdehyde, oxypurines, and nucleosides in peripheral blood, may be used to monitor the metabolic alterations of tissues occurring during ischemic phenomena.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>In one patient, enflurane administered during a donor nephrectomy resulted in unexpected partial motor seizures.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Until the cause of the seizures was correctly identified, the patient was inappropriately treated with anticonvulsants.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Two other patients suffered from partial, complex and generalized seizures uncontrolled by medication.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Epileptic foci delineated and activated by enflurane were surgically ablated and the patients are now seizure-free.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Previous exposures to enflurane have to be disclosed to avoid mistakes in clinical interpretation of the EEG.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>On the other hand, enflurane may prove to be a safe fast acting activator of epileptic foci during corticography or depth electrode intraoperative recordings.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Reversible cerebral lesions associated with tiazofurin usage: MR demonstration.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Tiazofurin is an experimental chemotherapeutic agent currently undergoing clinical evaluation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>We report our results with magnetic resonance (MR) in demonstrating reversible cerebral abnormalities concurrent with the use of this drug.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The abnormalities on MR were correlated with findings on CT as well as with cerebral angiography.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The utility of MR in the evaluation of patients receiving this new agent is illustrated.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Antagonism of diazepam-induced sedative effects by Ro15-1788 in patients after surgery under lumbar epidural block. A double-blind placebo-controlled investigation of efficacy and safety.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The aim of this study was to assess the efficacy of Ro15-1788 and a placebo in reversing diazepam-induced effects after surgery under epidural block, and to evaluate the local tolerance and general safety of Ro15-1788.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Fifty-seven patients were sedated with diazepam for surgery under epidural anaesthesia.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Antagonism of diazepam-induced effects by Ro15-1788 was investigated postoperatively in a double-blind placebo-controlled trial.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The patient's subjective assessment of mood rating, an objective test of performance, a test for amnesia, and vital signs were recorded for up to 300 min after administration of the trial drug.</Chemical>
<Chemical>No significant differences between the two groups were observed for mood rating, amnesia, or vital signs.</Chemical>
<Chemical>The Ro15-1788 group showed a significant improvement in the performance test up to 120 min after administration of the drug.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>There was no evidence of reaction at the injection site.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Enhanced stimulus-induced neurotransmitter overflow in epinephrine-induced hypertensive rats is not mediated by prejunctional beta-adrenoceptor activation.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The present study examines the effect of 6-day epinephrine treatment (100 micrograms/kg per h, s.c.) on stimulus-induced (1 Hz) endogenous neurotransmitter overflow from the isolated perfused kidney of vehicle- and epinephrine-treated rats.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Renal catecholamine stores and stimulus-induced overflow in the vehicle-treated group consisted of norepinephrine only.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, epinephrine treatment resulted in the incorporation of epinephrine into renal catecholamine stores such that approximately 40% of the catecholamine present was epinephrine while the norepinephrine content was reduced by a similar degree.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Total tissue catecholamine content of the kidney on a molar basis was unchanged.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Stimulus-induced fractional overflow of neurotransmitter from the epinephrine-treated kidneys was approximately twice normal and consisted of both norepinephrine and epinephrine in proportions similar to those found in the kidney.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>This difference in fractional overflow between groups was not affected by neuronal and extraneuronal uptake blockade.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Propranolol had no effect on stimulus-induced overflow in either group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Phentolamine increased stimulus-induced overflow in both groups although the increment in overflow was greater in the epinephrine-treated group.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>In conclusion, chronic epinephrine treatment results in enhanced fractional neurotransmitter overflow.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>However, neither alterations in prejunctional beta-adrenoceptor influences nor alterations in neuronal and extraneuronal uptake mechanisms appear to be responsible for this alteration.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Furthermore, data obtained with phentolamine alone do not suggest alpha-adrenoceptor desensitization as the cause of the enhanced neurotransmitter overflow after epinephrine treatment.</Chemical>

text: <Chemical>Ocular manifestations of juvenile rheumatoid arthritis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We followed 210 cases of juvenile rheumatoid arthritis closely for eleven years.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Thirty-six of the 210 patients (17.2%) developed iridocyclitis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Iridocyclitis was seen most frequently in young female patients (0 to 4 years) with the monoarticular or pauciatricular form of the arthritis.</Chemical>
<Chemical>However, 30% of the patients developed uveitis after 16 years of age.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Although 61% of patients had a noncontributory ocular history on entry, 42% had active uveitis on entry.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Our approach was effective in detecting uveitis in new cases and exacerbations of uveitis in established cases.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Forty-four percent of patients with uveitis had one or more identifiable signs or symptoms, such as red eye, ocular pain, decreased visual acuity, or photophobia, in order of decreasing frequency.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Even after early detection and prompt treatment, 41% of cases of uveitis did not respond to more than six months of intensive topical treatment with corticosteroids and mydriatics.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Despite this, there was a dramatic decrease in the 50% incidence of blinding complications of uveitis cited in earlier studies.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Cataract and band keratopathy occurred in only 22 and 13% of our group, respectively.</Chemical>
<Chemical>We used chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine in 173 of 210 cases and found only one case of chorioretinopathy attributable to these drugs.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>Systemically administered corticosteroids were used in 75 of 210 cases; a significant number of posterior subcapsular cataracts was found.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Typical keratoconjunctivitis sicca developed in three of the uveitis cases.</Chemical>
<Chemical>This association with uveitis and JRA was not noted previously.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Surgical treatment of cataracts, band keratopathy, and glaucoma achieved uniformly discouraging results.</Chemical>
<Chemical>Water intoxication associated with oxytocin administration during saline-induced abortion.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>Four cases of water intoxication in connection with oxytocin administration during saline-induced abortions are described.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The mechanism of water intoxication is discussed in regard to these cases.</Chemical>

<Chemical>Oxytocin administration during midtrimester-induced abortions is advocated only if it can be carried out under careful observations of an alert nursing staff, aware of the symptoms of water intoxication and instructed to watch the diuresis and report such early signs of the syndrome as asthenia, muscular irritability, or headaches.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The oxytocin should be given only in Ringers lactate or, alternately, in Ringers lactate and a 5 per cent dextrose and water solutions.</Chemical>
label: Chemical
Chemical
Chemical
Chemical

text: <Chemical>The urinary output should be monitored and the oxytocin administration discontinued and the serum electrolytes checked if the urinary output decreases.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>The oxytocin should not be administered in excess of 36 hours.</Chemical>
label: Chemical

text: <Chemical>If the patient has not aborted by then the oxytocin should be discontinued for 10 to 12 hours in order to perform electrolyte determinations and correct any electrolyte imbalance.</Chemical>
